site_title: Departure of 244 agents 'a long time coming', says defence lawyer
summary: A Singaporean defence lawyer claims that the departure of 244 Prudential agents and leaders in 2016 was "a long time coming" due to cost-cutting measures and unhappiness, rather than any actions by former top agency manager Peter Tan. The lawyer, Senior Counsel Thio Shen Yi, argues that personal reasons, including better prospects elsewhere, were the root cause of the departures. The lawyer also disputes the claim of up to S$2.5 billion, saying the calculation ignores productivity losses and personal circumstances.

images.alt_text: Prudential's former top agency manager Peter Tan is being sued for allegedly instigating a mass defection to rival insurer Aviva Financial Advisers in mid-2016.

site_title: Serial System review says chairman/CEO Derek Goh may continue in his roles
summary: Serial System's board of directors has concluded that chairman and CEO Derek Goh can continue in his roles following a review by its nominating committee. The review was requested by the Singapore Exchange after Goh was called up by Taiwanese authorities in 2015 and 2018 to assist in investigations. Despite Goh's status being unclear, the board found no issues with his continued service, citing that no action has been taken against him by regulatory bodies.

site_title: Banks roped in to disrupt scammers' operations
summary: The Singapore Police Force has collaborated with three major banks to freeze suspicious bank accounts linked to scams, disrupting scammers' operations and minimizing victim losses. The Anti-Scam Centre, established two months ago, aims to impede fund transfers, effectively freezing accounts in a few days. This move is part of the centre's efforts to combat scams and protect victims.

site_title: URA moves to conserve former SCGS buildings at Emerald Hill
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has proposed conserving three historic buildings on the site of the former Singapore Chinese Girls' School (SCGS) in Orchard Road. The buildings, including the Main Block (1925), Principal's House (1930), and Song Ong Siang Block (1956), are of high historical and architectural significance. The URA plans to adapt the buildings for new cultural and lifestyle uses, aligning with the government's plans to strengthen Orchard Road with unique offerings. The decision was influenced by a campaign by former students to save the old campus from redevelopment.

site_title: Fintech founder Joe Cho 'under police probe in South Korea'
summary: Fintech founder Joe Cho, a Singapore permanent resident, is under investigation by South Korean police over allegations of financial crimes. Cho was sent back to South Korea from Indonesia following a request through Interpol, and his lawyer says about 40 investors have sued him for over S$6 million. Cho was once based in Singapore's fintech scene and was involved with the Marvelstone Group. The investigation is ongoing, but Cho's lawyer claims his client is innocent.

site_title: Five selected for Asian event have good chemistry
summary: Five Singaporean golfers selected for the Asia-PacificAmateur Championship have demonstrated good chemistry, according to their brief CVs. The quintet will participate in the event in Shanghai next month, suggesting an academic exercise amidst their golfing pursuits.

site_title: How US firms cope with Trump's trade gyrations
summary: US companies are struggling to cope with President Trump's trade gyrations with China, which have led to escalating tariffs and uncertainty. Executives at Columbia Sportswear and other firms are having to quickly adjust their strategies, including shifting supply chains, raising prices, and postponing investments. The tariffs have rippled across corporate America, prompting manufacturers and retailers to try to adjust their strategies based on the President's latest whim. The uncertainty has made it difficult for businesses to invest and hire, as they need to know what tax rates to pay and what laws and regulations to heed.

site_title: Darren Clarke talking pints and putts on the Champions Tour
summary: Golf legend Darren Clarke recently shared his experiences on the Champions Tour, reminiscing about his 2012 Open Championship victory at Royal St George's. Clarke, now focusing on the social side of golf, enjoys talking pints and putts with fellow players. He reminisced about a 2012 conversation at the upscale Chateau De Bonmont golf club in Geneva, Switzerland. Clarke's shift from competitive golf to social golf has allowed him to appreciate the camaraderie and enjoyment of the game.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust's share price surged 26% year-to-date on investors' appetite for defensive yield plays and optimism over its latest acquisitions. The trust's stake in PGIM Real Estate Asia Retail Fund increased to 21.1%, and its suburban malls continue to perform well, despite signs of weakness in retail demand. Analysts recommend waiting for a pullback due to the trust's relatively high valuation.

site_title: Raffles Infrastructure back in the black
summary: Raffles Infrastructure Holdings, formerly China Fibretech, reported a net profit of 32.6 million yuan (S$6.3 million) for 18 months, reversing a loss of 3.1 million yuan for the 12 months to Dec 31, 2017. The company plans to apply to the Singapore Stock Exchange (SGX) to be dropped from the watch list after its profit turnaround. The change in financial year from Dec 31 to June 30 has also been announced.

site_title: Brazilian minister meets Trump, says on 'same page' over Amazon fires
summary: Brazilian Foreign Minister Ernesto Araujo said he and US President Donald Trump are on the same page regarding Amazon fires, pushing back against foreign interference in Brazil's affairs. Araujo met with Trump at the White House, accompanied by Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro's son Eduardo, who is set to become ambassador to Washington. This agreement comes as fires continue to rage in the Amazon rainforest.

images.alt_text: Brazil and the United States are in agreement over fires raging in the Amazon rainforest, Brazilian Foreign Minister Ernesto Araujo said Friday after meeting President Donald Trump at the White House.

site_title: Gas pipeline in Nigeria's Delta state shut following breach
summary: A gas pipeline in Nigeria's Delta state was shut down following a breach, according to state oil company NNPC and local authorities. The pipeline, which produces 390 million standard cubic feet of gas per day, was closed after a leak was reported, with police investigating the incident. Two local residents reported an explosion, but NNPC stated it was a rupture, not a fire. Repair works are expected to commence soon.

site_title: Muted updates to DC rates amid challenging macro scene
summary: Singapore's government has announced muted adjustments in development charges (DC) amid a challenging macroeconomic environment. DC rates for commercial use increased by 1.7% on average for the period Sept 1, 2019 to Feb 29, 2020, while non-landed residential use rates decreased by 0.3%. DC rates for hotels and other uses remained unchanged. The increases and decreases are based on the government's assessment of land values and recent land sales.

site_title: France to run no-deal Brexit dress rehearsal: minister
summary: France is set to run a month-long "no-deal" Brexit dress rehearsal starting in October, ahead of Britain's exit from the EU on October 31. French customs minister Gerald Darmanin has prepared measures to ensure companies are ready for the UK's departure, including online border declarations and the deployment of 700 extra customs officers. The test run aims to minimize disruptions and traffic jams, particularly in Calais, a key port for trade between the EU and Britain.

site_title: India unveils mergers involving 10 state-owned banks
summary: India has announced mergers involving 10 state-owned banks, cutting the total number from 27 in 2017 to 12. The mergers, aimed at strengthening the sector and boosting economic growth, include Oriental Bank of Commerce and United Bank merging with Punjab National Bank, and Canara Bank and Syndicate Bank merging with Union Bank. Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman said the move will create solid, well-consolidated banks to boost lending and revive the economy.

site_title: US penalises shipping firms said to help North Korea circumvent UN sanctions
summary: The US Treasury announced penalties against Taiwanese and Hong Kong shipping firms, Jui Pang Shipping Co Ltd, Jui Zong Ship Management Co Ltd, and Jui Cheng Shipping Company Limited, for helping North Korea circumvent UN sanctions on oil exports and imports. The companies engaged in illicit ship-to-ship transfers to evade sanctions, and the Treasury also targeted two Taiwan-based individuals and a vessel. The actions aim to prevent North Korea from obtaining resources to support its weapons of mass destruction and missile programs. The penalties block the companies' assets and expose them to significant sanctions risk.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices ease for 2nd consecutive month in July
summary: Hong Kong private home prices fell for the second consecutive month in July, with a 0.1% drop compared to June's 0.6% fall. Property agents expect the downward trend to continue over the next few months due to low transaction volumes. Analysts attribute the deceleration to the gap between buyers' and sellers' expectations, with some predicting a 10-15% correction in the remainder of the year. The market is pressured by the US-China trade war and social unrest in Hong Kong.

site_title: Trump prods General Motors over its auto plants in China
summary: US President Donald Trump tweeted that General Motors should move its operations back to the US, citing the company's significant workforce cuts and its major plants in China. GM's hourly workforce has fallen to 46,000 US workers, behind Fiat Chrysler. Trump's ire with GM comes as contract talks with the United Auto Workers union intensify. GM has sold 3.6 million vehicles in China last year, generating $2 billion in equity income. The US president's comments come as China reinstalled 25% tariffs on US-made vehicles in response to recent tariffs.

site_title: Corporate digest

Geo Energy Resources submitted a revised proposal to acquire new coal assets in Indonesia, and China Sports International is in discussions about a proposed restructuring exercise.

site_title: China's factory activity shrinks for 4th month as trade pressure mounts
summary: China's factory activity shrank for the fourth consecutive month in August, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 49.5. The decline, driven by trade pressure and sluggish domestic demand, fuels expectations of a more aggressive stimulus from Beijing to weather the slowdown. Export orders and total new orders continued to fall, with manufacturers in the auto sector particularly vulnerable. The data also showed job shedding and a contraction in activity at medium and small-sized firms, despite expansion at large manufacturers. The Sino-US trade row escalated in August, with both sides discussing further negotiations.

site_title: Bank lending dips in July, weighed down by fall in business loans
summary: Bank lending in Singapore declined 0.9% to S$680.7 billion in July, its first drop after five months of growth, due to a 1.3% fall in business loans. This reversal was driven by a 4.6% drop in general commerce loans and a 3% decline in loans to financial institutions. However, some sectors, such as building and construction and transport, saw growth. The decline in business loans is attributed to the US-China trade war, while housing loans continued to fall for a seventh straight month.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end brutal August on a positive note
summary: European stocks rose 0.7% on Friday, ending a brutal August on a positive note, as investors took comfort from China and US willingness to return to trade talks. Tariff-sensitive stocks surged, with commodity-linked stocks up 2.5%, automakers 1%, and technology stocks gaining 0.9%. The Stoxx 600 index hit its highest level since August 2, with the real estate sector jumping 2% and German real estate companies rising between 4% and 9%. Most European indices have lost this month, but Denmark, Romania, and Switzerland bucked the trend.

site_title: Hong Kong protesters defy rally ban after crackdown
summary: Thousands of pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong defied a police ban on rallying on Saturday, marching through streets in black t-shirts and singing "hallelujah" in an attempt to sidestep the ban. The ban came after a crackdown on activists and lawmakers, with at least five high-profile arrests on Friday. The European Union's Federica Mogherini and US President Donald Trump expressed concern over the arrests, while Amnesty International described the dawn swoops as "scare tactics straight out of Beijing's playbook." The protests, sparked by opposition to a bill allowing extraditions to mainland China, have damaged Hong Kong's reputation for stability and prosperity.

site_title: Hong Kong protesters expected to regroup despite police ban
summary: Hong Kong protesters are expected to regroup despite a police ban, with the Civil Human Rights Front cancelling a mass demonstration. Prominent pro-democracy activist Joshua Wong was arrested on charges of inciting an unauthorised assembly. The city faces its worst political crisis in decades, with speculation growing that the government may impose emergency laws. The UN has urged restraint, while China denies meddling in Hong Kong and accuses foreign powers of fomenting the demonstrations.

site_title: Samsung billionaire's horse-bribe case closed? Court says neigh
summary: South Korea's Supreme Court ordered Samsung Electronics vice-chairman Jay Y Lee to face trial again for corruption, citing a gift of three horses valued at 3.4 billion won (S$3.9 million) to ex-president Park Geun-hye's friend, Choi Soon-sil. The court ruled that the horses should be considered a bribe, potentially leading to a minimum 5-year prison sentence with no possibility of suspension. The move is seen as a symbolic gesture, but its impact on the diplomatic row remains unclear.

summary: A hospital in Oklahoma used contaminated gastroscopes in procedures performed on nearly 1,000 patients, exposing them to bacteria that can cause infections. Despite no reported infections, the FDA and Pentax described the incident as a "failure by the facility reprocessing personnel to completely follow" cleaning instructions. The hospital notified affected patients of their options for post-exposure medical screening.

site_title: End of Libor will see replacement of SOR benchmark
summary: Singapore will transition from the Sing-dollar Swap Offer Rate (SOR) to the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (SORA) over the next two years, replacing the scandal-tainted Libor benchmark. The SOR, used to price derivatives and loans, will be impacted by the demise of Libor, which uses US-dollar Libor in its computation. The SORA is expected to take over as the Singapore rates benchmark after Libor ends in 2021, with a committee overseeing the transition.

site_title: Brexit: Northern Irish court sets Sept 6 for challenge to parliament suspension
summary: A Northern Irish court has set a September 6 hearing date for a challenge to British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's order to suspend parliament for over a month before Brexit. Rights activist Raymond McCord is seeking to have the suspension reversed, citing fears that a chaotic Brexit could wreck the peace process in Northern Ireland. McCord's legal team argues that the suspension is unconstitutional and a threat to the 1998 Good Friday Agreement. The challenge comes as a Scottish court rejected a similar request and former Prime Minister John Major has joined the case in London.

summary: Argentina's central bank has implemented a measure to limit banks' access to hard peso currency, sparking concerns of capital controls amid growing market turmoil. Credit rating agencies have downgraded Argentina's debt, citing the measure and heightened political uncertainty. The peso has extended its year-to-date losses to 36% and Argentine spreads have blown out to levels not seen since 2005, driving down shares of financial services companies.

site_title: Trade war with US won't affect China's pork supply
summary: China's trade dispute with the US won't impact its pork supply, according to an official at the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs. Despite soaring pork prices due to African swine fever, the US tariff of 10% on farm imports will only affect 0.2% of China's pork output. China aims to boost pork imports and release frozen meat from state reserves to increase supply. The country produced 54.04 million tonnes of pork in 2018, with production expected to fall to 34 million tonnes in 2020 due to ASF.

site_title: New tariffs to test the strength of US consumers
summary: US tariffs on Chinese goods, worth about $112 billion, will take effect Sunday, including consumer food items, household goods, and apparel, with a 15% import tax. The move is the latest escalation of a trade war between the two countries. Critics, including the US Chamber of Commerce, are calling for a ceasefire and more talks, but President Trump is monitoring the situation. The tariffs will test the strength of US consumers, who are expected to absorb the increased costs. A coalition of trade associations is making a last-ditch plea to postpone duties on other goods.

site_title: STI rides trade optimism ahead of tariff hike

site_title: US to use fake social media to check people entering country

This change, made after a July 2019 review, aims to help investigators search for potential evidence of fraud or security concerns. The move reverses a prior ban on creating fake profiles, which will now be used to aid in the decision-making process for allowing someone entry into the US.

site_title: TPV flags delay for privatisation scheme document

This delay allows TPV to finalize the document and accommodate the Supreme Court's timetable. The company's shares closed at S$0.65 on Friday, up 1.56% from the previous day.

site_title: US personal spending increased more than forecast in July
summary: US personal spending increased 0.6% in July, exceeding forecasts, and indicating household consumption remains solid at the start of the third quarter. Consumer outlays for goods and services account for about 70% of the US GDP. Despite recent concerns about economic growth, Americans are showing signs of continued spending despite falling prices and risks from overseas economies and trade wars.

site_title: Hong Kong IPO activity finally picks up after dry summer
summary: Hong Kong's IPO activity has finally picked up after a six-year dry spell. However, activity is now gathering pace with several companies planning or already gauging investor demand for IPOs, including Shanghai Henlius Biotech Inc and Bank of Guizhou, which could raise at least US$600 million and US$1 billion respectively. The move aims to boost Hong Kong's struggling IPO market, which has raised only US$10.8 billion this year.

site_title: Indonesia urges calm in Papua after two weeks of protests
summary: Indonesia's chief security minister, Wiranto, urged calm in Papua after two weeks of protests, saying demonstrators' demands for an investigation into racism had been met. Protests, sparked by a racist slur against Papuan students, have resulted in violence, including a shooting incident that killed one soldier and two civilians. The government has ruled out a referendum on independence and deployed additional police officers to the region. Despite reports of calm, protests are planned, and a legal process is underway for military personnel involved in a separate incident.

site_title: Airbus drops bid to replace Canada fighter jets
summary: Airbus has withdrawn from a Canadian government call for proposals to replace 88 aging fighter jets, valued at C$15 billion. The decision cited high security requirements and insufficient industrial technological benefits. The company's Typhoon fighter will no longer be considered, leaving the field open to Saab's Gripen, Lockheed Martin's F-35, and Boeing's F/A-18 Super Hornet. The contract award is expected in early 2022, with delivery due in 2025.

site_title: Sri Lanka court orders remains of Easter attacker moved after protests
summary: A Sri Lankan court ordered the exhumation and relocation of the remains of an Easter Sunday attacker after residents protested his burial in a Hindu cemetery, citing hurt sentiments. The bomber, linked to Islamist outfits, killed over 250 people in Easter Sunday attacks on churches and hotels. The remains will be exhumed on Monday and kept in a mortuary until a suitable burial place is found. This move comes after the government withdrew an emergency law allowing police to detain suspects without court orders.

site_title: Market value of Singapore stocks shrinks again in August
summary: Singapore's stock market value decreased 6.8% in August to S$862.5 billion, driven by an uninspiring corporate earnings season, inverted yield curves, and US Federal Reserve rate cuts. Defensive stocks and Reits, such as Thai Beverage and Mapletree Commercial Trust, gained ground, while banks like DBS, OCBC, and UOB fell due to slowing loan growth. The market is bracing for further rate cuts and their impact on net interest margins.

site_title: Speculators already rushing to buy land around Indonesia's new capital
summary: Speculators are rushing to buy land in East Kalimantan, Indonesia, as the country prepares to build a new capital city. The government controls 180,000 hectares of land, but private developers are making plans to develop the area, despite restrictions on commercial forestry. The relocation of the capital is expected to ease pressure on Jakarta and spread economic activity, with construction set to begin by the end of 2020.

site_title: Hong Kong cyber attack briefly disrupts key protester forum
summary: A large digital attack briefly disrupted Hong Kong's LIHKG forum, used by protesters to organize mass rallies, on Saturday. The attack, described as a distributed denial of service (DDoS) attack, was the second to hit apps used by protesters this summer. The forum's services were restored hours later. This comes as Hong Kong's Chief Executive Carrie Lam has threatened to invoke emergency measures to quell protests, including shutting down the internet or blocking apps helping protesters organize. The attack is the latest challenge to the protesters' use of digital platforms to coordinate their efforts.

site_title: Modi creates banking behemoths to boost India's flagging economy

site_title: Are fish oil supplements good for the heart?
summary: Fish oil supplements containing omega-3 fatty acids EPA and DHA have unclear benefits for heart health in the general population without pre-existing heart disease. While they may reduce sudden death from heart artery disease in patients with existing heart artery disease, they do not prevent future heart attacks. For healthy individuals with no prior stroke, there is currently no evidence that omega-3 PUFA supplements can prevent strokes. The benefits of omega-3 PUFAs are mainly seen in reducing sudden cardiac death in the context of a recent heart attack, through stabilizing the electrical milieu of the heart muscle cells.

site_title: US: Wall Street swings to split finish ahead of tariffs
summary: US stocks closed with mixed results on Friday, finishing the month in the red after a choppy session. Investors exercised caution ahead of President Trump's planned tariff hike on Chinese imports, which could escalate the trade war. site_title: How not to grow old in America
summary: The assisted-living industry in the US has grown significantly, with over 30,000 facilities, despite being a financially lucrative business that often fails to provide adequate care for its residents. The industry's marketing focuses on autonomy and independence, which is not suitable for those who need more assistance. Regulations are lax, and complaints are mounting. To address this issue, experts suggest that assisted living needs serious reform, including higher staffing levels and training, which will increase costs but provide better care for those who need it.

site_title: Canada sees strong Q2 growth just before elections, data shows
summary: Canada's economy grew 3.7% in Q2, beating forecasts of 2.9%, driven by a 3.7% jump in exports, particularly energy products. This growth comes after a disappointing 2018 and a 0.4% rise in Q1 2019. The uptick is good news for Prime Minister Justin Trudeau ahead of elections, contrasting with the US economy's 2.0% growth in the same period. Business investment was a drag on growth, but analysts attribute the Canadian economy's recovery to the boost from trade.

site_title: A spoonful of medicine to grow your wealth
summary: Healthcare companies offer attractive investment opportunities, with average yields of around 3% and some European pharmaceuticals providing the best yields. Despite the industry's complexity, the median return on equity for 20 companies examined is an appealing 16%, with steady returns over the years. These healthcare companies consistently generate an average of $16 of net profit on every $100 invested by shareholders, making them a lucrative sector for investors.

site_title: New green corridor to connect Singapore's three national gardens
summary: Singapore is set to complete a new 11km green corridor connecting its three national gardens, the Singapore Botanic Gardens, Jurong Lake Gardens, and Gardens by the Bay, by the coming years. The Bukit Timah-Rochor Green Corridor, which will be elevated above the Bukit Timah Canal, will provide a safe path for cyclists and pedestrians. Construction for the first phase, a 1.4km elevated linear park, will begin in 2021. The corridor will also connect to the Rail Corridor, a 24km green stretch that runs from Woodlands to Tanjong Pagar, with plans to extend it to Kallang Riverside Park in the future.

site_title: North Korea says Pompeo's remarks make talks with US more difficult
summary: North Korea's vice-foreign minister, Choe Son Hui, has stated that US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo's remark about "North Korea's rogue behavior" has made talks with the US more difficult. Pompeo's comment was deemed unreasonable and provocative by Choe, who warned that North Korea's patience is wearing thin. The remark comes amid stalled nuclear and missile programme negotiations since the failed Hanoi summit in February. North Korea has also fired short-range missiles in protest against US-South Korea joint exercises, complicating the reopening of talks.

site_title: Personal spending increases more than forecast in July
summary: US personal spending increased 0.6% in July, exceeding forecasts and indicating solid household consumption at the start of the third quarter. This growth is expected to continue as the economy's dominant growth engine. In contrast, incomes rose less than forecast, and the Federal Reserve's preferred inflation gauge remained range-bound.

images.alt_text: US personal spending accelerated in July, exceeding forecasts and indicating household consumption remained solid at the start of the third quarter and will continue as the economy's dominant growth engine.

site_title: Oil falls ahead of hurricane but posts weekly gain as US-China trade war eases
summary: Oil prices fell on Friday ahead of Hurricane Dorian, with US crude down 2.8% and Brent crude down 1.1%. Despite the drop, prices are still on track for the biggest weekly gain since early July, boosted by easing US-China trade rhetoric. US crude output fell for the second straight month, while Opec output rose for the first time this year. Hedge funds cut their long positions in US crude futures, and analysts slashed price forecasts for Brent to an average of $65.02 in 2019.

site_title: Lexus raises the RX's core competencies
summary: Lexus has revamped its RX crossover, strengthening its frame with added adhesive and laser screw welding to create a stiffer shell, resulting in a quieter, more crashworthy car with crisper handling. The new model also features a refreshed exterior design, including new lamps and a revised front grille, as well as an improved interior with a touchscreen infotainment system and added Apple CarPlay and Android Auto capabilities. The RX's engine options remain largely unchanged, but the hybrid model is improved, offering soothing refinement and low fuel consumption.

images.alt_text: You can actually feel the difference behind the wheel, where the RX feels noticeably more eager and accurate than before, in the way it hooks into corners.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares rose on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 16.96 points to 1,612.94. The market saw a gain of 525 to 315 gainers and losers, with 2.2 billion lots traded worth RM 2 billion.

site_title: Profit vs sustainability: How to manage the conflict
summary: This year marked a turning point in the world's response to climate change, with over half the population experiencing its effects. Behavioral changes, such as increased exercise and healthier diets, have become more prevalent. The decline in alcohol consumption has shifted societal norms, with a healthy lifestyle becoming the accepted norm. Businesses must adapt to tackle sustainability, and companies can start by implementing sustainable practices and prioritizing long-term benefits over short-term profits. By doing so, they can contribute to a healthier and more sustainable future.

site_title: Gold equity funds have a place in a portfolio
summary: Gold and gold-related equities have seen a significant 20% rally in the past year, driven by economic growth concerns, escalating trade tensions, and negative yielding fixed income markets. The price of gold is inversely correlated with the expected return from other asset classes, making it an attractive diversifier in a portfolio. Gold-related equity funds, which invest in gold mining companies, have strong performance and are highly correlated to the general direction of gold prices. These funds are suitable for investors looking to diversify their portfolios and can potentially benefit from the ongoing trend in gold prices.

site_title: Pakistan PM Khan leads nationwide protests over Kashmir
summary: Thousands of Pakistanis rallied nationwide in support of Kashmir, with Prime Minister Imran Khan leading the protests. The demonstrations come ahead of Khan's UN trip, where he vowed to fight for Kashmir's liberation. Khan compared Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's administration to Nazi Germany, calling for solidarity with Kashmiris. The protests are the first in a series of weekly rallies until Khan's trip in late September, amid rising tensions between Pakistan and India over Kashmir's autonomy.

site_title: Is Hong Kong safe?
summary: Hong Kong remains "safe" for travelers, with physical risk at a low level. However, travel plans can be disrupted due to protests and demonstrations. Visitors can stay informed and avoid areas with gas masks and yellow helmets. Despite the unrest, travelers can find discounted rates at hotels, with some offering free breakfasts and no cancellation fees. Airlines have been cautious with ticket prices, but some carriers have reduced seat inventory. Seasoned travelers can navigate the city, but first-time visitors may want to reconsider due to the unpredictability and frustrations surrounding the protests.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally wiped out by new protest fears
summary: Hong Kong stocks suffered a significant loss on Friday as the arrest of pro-democracy figures sparked fears of fresh violence. Despite a brief rally, the Hang Seng Index ended 0.08% higher, while the benchmark Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.16%. Property firms Swire, Sino Land, and New World Development saw substantial losses, ranging from 1.56% to 1.81%. The arrests overshadowed news of China's decision not to retaliate against US tariffs, fueling hopes for easing trade tensions.

site_title: Soilbuild Construction CEO resigns
summary: Soilbuild Construction Group CEO Ding Yen Shee Daniel resigned effective immediately to pursue personal interests. The company's executive chairman Lim Chap Huat will assume the role of CEO and oversee daily operations. Despite the short tenure, the board accepted the resignation and will review the CEO succession plan. Shares closed at 5.4 Singapore cents, down 1.82% on Friday.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks jump on China-US trade optimism
summary: Tokyo stocks surged on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 1.19% and the Topix index gaining 1.46%, driven by renewed optimism over US-China trade talks and a weaker yen. The benchmark indices closed at 20,704.37 and 1,511.86, respectively.

site_title: Trump says he is not pining for negative interest rates in US
summary: US President Donald Trump stated he does not want to see negative interest rates in the United States. He made this comment while departing the White House for Camp David, referencing the current negative interest rates in Germany. Trump has previously noted the disparity between US interest rates and those in global markets, but expressed no desire for negative rates in the US.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump, who has decried the relative loftiness of US interest rates compared to rates in nations that compete with the United States in global markets, said on Friday he did not want to see negative rates in the United States.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady at open
summary: European stock markets opened flat on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.1% to 7,191.31 points, and the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices also rising 0.1% and remaining unchanged, respectively. The steady performance was attributed to gains in mining and healthcare shares, while US-EU trade talks were a focus.

site_title: British PM's Brexit position 'totally unreasonable', Ireland says
summary: Ireland's foreign minister, Simon Coveney, criticized British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Brexit position as "totally unreasonable" that the EU cannot facilitate. The EU has proposed the Irish border backstop to avoid a hard border in Northern Ireland, but Johnson's new approach puts the onus on the UK to find a solution, with Coveney stating that the EU is waiting for convincing alternatives.

site_title: 'Goodbye Gagarin': Paris razes estate built by Communists
summary: The "Cite Gagarine" housing estate in Ivry-sur-Seine, France, built in 1963, is being demolished after decades of decline. The estate was a symbol of the Communist Party's appeal in post-war France, named after Russian space pioneer Yuri Gagarin, who visited the site in 1965. The neighborhood's fortunes began to fade in the 1970s, and the estate's demolition marks a shift towards gentrification. The demolition is seen as a farewell to a piece of France's communist past, as the area undergoes significant transformation.

site_title: Google reveals years-long 'indiscriminate' iPhone hack
summary: Google security experts have uncovered a years-long hacking operation targeting iPhones, using websites to implant malicious software to access photos, user locations, and other data. The exploit server attacked devices simply by visiting the hacked site, and if successful, installed a monitoring implant that sent back stolen data every 60 seconds. The vulnerabilities targeted were in the default Safari Web browser, affecting iOS 10-12 versions. Apple released a security patch in response, and the tech giant is expected to unveil a new-generation iPhone at an upcoming event.

site_title: IHH Healthcare's Q2 earnings up 12% on better turnover
summary: IHH Healthcare's Q2 earnings rose 12% to RM185 million due to higher revenue and adoption of the MFRS 16 Leases accounting standard. Revenue increased 37% to RM3.6 billion, driven by organic growth and new hospital openings. However, excluding exceptional items, net profit decreased 6% due to higher financing costs. The company remains confident in its turnaround plan for Fortis in India and plans to diversify earnings in cash-generative markets.

site_title: Japan's curbs on high-tech materials exports to South Korea could backfire
summary: Japan's curbs on exports of high-tech materials to South Korea may backfire, potentially eroding its dominance in the global chip supply chain. The restrictions, imposed last month, could disrupt the supply of fluorinated polyimides, photoresists, and hydrogen fluoride to South Korean chipmakers Samsung and SK Hynix, which rely on Japanese materials for quality and stable supply. Industry experts warn it will take time for South Korean firms to replicate these materials, and Japan's suppliers have built up their capabilities through decades-long experience.

site_title: Serial System says CEO to continue in role, following review
summary: Serial System's board has cleared CEO Derek Goh to continue in his role following a review by its nominating committee. Goh was asked to assist in investigations in Taiwan and Singapore in 2015 and 2018, but the company says it's unclear if he's under investigation or just assisting. Despite limited information, the NC found Goh suitable to serve, citing no action taken against him. Serial System shares closed unchanged at 7.5 Singapore cents after the announcement.

site_title: Sun Venture secures maiden green club loan of S$455m for 71 Robinson Road
summary: Sun Venture, a Singaporean real estate investment company, secured its first green club loan of S$455 million for the acquisition of 71 Robinson Road, a 15-storey office tower in the Central Business District. The loan was delivered in partnership with OCBC Bank, with the aim of achieving the higher-tiered Singapore Building and Construction Authority (BCA) Green Mark GoldPlus award in the future. The loan will finance the acquisition and improvements to the building's energy, water, and waste footprints, aligning with Sun Venture's strategy of building an environmentally friendly portfolio of assets.

images.alt_text: OCBC's Mr Goh says there is a growing awareness and commitment towards sustainability across the bank's corporate and SME customers, especially in the real estate sector.

site_title: Trump confirms latest China tariffs set for Sunday are 'on'
summary: US President Donald Trump confirmed on Friday that new tariffs on Chinese goods, set to rise to 15%, will go into effect on Sunday. The tariffs, which affect billions of dollars' worth of Chinese imports, are part of the ongoing trade war between the US and China. Trump attributed the recent crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Hong Kong to US economic pressure, saying it was preventing a harsher crackdown. The move underlines the ongoing tensions between the two countries and raises concerns about the impact on global trade.

site_title: Getting ahead of your clients? A look at front-running
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued prohibition orders against three individuals who engaged in front-running, a form of insider trading where personal trades are made before client trades. The individuals, former representatives of First State Investments Singapore and UOB Kay Hian Pte Ltd, colluded to misuse confidential information and made significant profits. The MAS has stated that front-running is a serious offense and that the perpetrators were over-confident in their ability to evade detection. The case highlights the importance of prioritizing client interests over personal financial gains and the long arms of the law.

site_title: Pernod Ricard plans new made-in-China whiskey brand
summary: Pernod Ricard is launching a new made-in-China malt whiskey brand, with a planned distillery in Sichuan province. The company aims to produce at least one new whiskey brand by 2023, with a planned investment of up to $150 million. The move is part of its efforts to tap into China's growing $178 billion alcohol market, where interest in western spirits like whiskey is rising. The company expects revenue growth in China to be at high single digits to low double-digits in the mid to long-term.

site_title: DC rates raised 1.7% on average for commercial use, trimmed 0.3% for non-landed residential use
summary: The government of Singapore has raised development charge (DC) rates for commercial use by 1.7% on average, effective Sept 1, 2019 to Feb 29, 2020. For non-landed residential use, DC rates were trimmed by 0.3% on average. The increases and cuts apply to 118 geographical sectors, with some sectors experiencing larger rate changes. The Ministry of National Development revises DC rates annually, based on land values and recent land sales. The rate changes take effect on March 1 and Sept 1, with no changes for landed residential, hotel, and other use groups.

site_title: Swedbank CEO defends client privacy amid dirty-money probes
summary: Swedbank's new CEO, Jens Henriksson, defends client privacy amid probes into allegations of money laundering, stating transparency is a goal but within existing restrictions. Henriksson acknowledges the need for transparency but also emphasizes the importance of maintaining client confidentiality. He begins his tenure as CEO, tasked with steering the bank through multiple investigations and restoring trust with investors and the public. Henriksson's appointment comes after his predecessor, Birgitte Bonnesen, was fired due to her handling of the crisis, and shares have plummeted nearly 40% this year.

site_title: Geo Energy Resources submits proposal for potential acquisition
summary: Geo Energy Resources has submitted a revised non-binding proposal to acquire new coal assets for a producing coal mine in East Kalimantan, Indonesia. The acquisition, if successful, would be a "very substantial acquisition" under Singapore Exchange listing rules. There is no certainty that the transaction will materialize or be concluded, and the company will make further announcements as necessary. Geo Energy shares closed at S$0.147 on Friday, down 0.3 Singapore cent or 2 per cent.

site_title: Singapore shares ride trade talk hopes to close 0.8% higher on Friday
summary: Singapore's stock market is expected to close 0.8% higher on Friday, following positive Asian markets that rose despite US-China trade tensions. US tariffs set to take effect this weekend have sparked uncertainty, but investors remain optimistic. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) has rallied for five consecutive days ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Late-night airport arrivals about to become easier at Japan's Narita
summary: Japan's Narita International Airport is set to become more user-friendly with the expansion of train and bus schedules to accommodate late-night flights. East Japan Railway Co and Keisei Electric Railway Co will operate extra trains until 10 minutes after midnight, while Keisei's bus company will offer additional buses until 30 minutes after midnight. This change aims to reduce the inconvenience faced by passengers and staff on early and late flights, as the airport prepares for an influx of tourists ahead of the 2020 Tokyo Olympics and potential integrated resorts.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,105.29, up 0.76% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Friday at 3,105.29, up 0.76% on the day. The Straits Times Index gained 23.46 points, driven by positive signals from the US and China on trade. Key gainers included UOB, DBS Bank, and OCBC Bank, with UOB leading the banking stocks up 1.3%. Other active index securities included Genting Singapore and SingTel.

site_title: Amid crisis, China rejected Hong Kong plan to appease protesters: sources
summary: China has rejected Hong Kong's plan to withdraw a contentious extradition bill, which was part of a proposal submitted by Chief Executive Carrie Lam to address the city's mounting political crisis. The proposal, which included other demands such as an independent inquiry and fully democratic elections, was rejected by Beijing, with the central government ordering Lam not to yield to any of the protesters' demands. This move represents concrete evidence of China's control over the Hong Kong government's response to the unrest, which has led to widespread protests and criticism of Beijing's influence.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks surge on trade optimism, growing rate cut bets
summary: South Korean stocks surged 1.78% on Friday as trade optimism boosted the market, with the KOSPI closing at 1,967.79 points. The US and China are set to restart trade talks, and the Bank of Korea indicated a rate cut is likely. This marks the second straight week of gains for the benchmark index, despite a 2.8% monthly decline. The KOSPI has fallen 3.59% this year and 6.7% in the previous 30 trading sessions.

site_title: Olam adds three directors to board
summary: Olam International has appointed three new non-executive directors to its board, effective from September 1. The new directors, Joerg Wolle and Ajai Puri, are regarded as independent and bring experience from various industries, including logistics and food science. This move aims to enhance the company's governance and decision-making capabilities.

site_title: China banks see margins squeezed by efforts to spur economy
summary: China's major banks reported disappointing profits and shrinking loan margins in response to government demands to spur the slowing economy. The country's biggest banks increased loans to small businesses by 35% in the first half, while cutting financing costs more than the desired 1 percentage point. However, analysts predict further margin pressure and asset quality issues, citing the recent change in how China calculates the one-year benchmark rate. This move is expected to squeeze net interest margins across the industry, posing challenges for lenders and investors.

site_title: Baidu bumped from China's Internet top 5 list again
summary: Baidu Inc has dropped from China's top 5 most valuable Internet companies, losing its spot to younger rival Pinduoduo Inc. PDD's shares surged 8.7% in New York, surpassing Baidu's market value. This marks the second time Baidu has been pushed out of the top 5, following a brief overtake by NetEase Inc earlier this month. Baidu's decline is attributed to a slowdown in China's economy and increased competition for advertising from ByteDance Inc.

site_title: Australia: Shares ride trade war 'sugar rush', NZ also rises
summary: Australian stocks rose 1.3% on Friday, driven by gains in the banking and mining sectors, amid signs of easing US-China trade tensions. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 6,592.9, with Australian bank stocks and mining units like BHP Group and Rio Tinto advancing. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 0.8%.

site_title: A tennis talent who generates both buzz and suspensions
summary: Nick Kyrgios, the Australian tennis player, is facing another potential suspension from the men's professional tennis tour due to his on-court behavior. He has been fined a record sum for unsportsmanlike conduct and verbal abuse during a match, and an investigation is ongoing. Kyrgios' recent comments at a news conference, in which he questioned the ATP's integrity, have led to another major-offense investigation. The ATP may reach a ruling quickly, and if Kyrgios is suspended, Grand Slam officials and the Laver Cup organizers would need to decide whether to extend the ban to their events.

images.alt_text: Above: Kyrgios, 24, regularly attacks the game at which he intermittently excels. The Australian's violations of the game's unwritten codes can be fine theatre.

site_title: Raffles Infrastructure back in the black with 32.6m yuan FY2019 profit
summary: Raffles Infrastructure Holdings reported a net profit of 32.6 million yuan (S$6.3 million) for FY2019, reversing a net loss of 3.1 million yuan in 2017. Revenue surged to 208.9 million yuan, driven by its infrastructure segment, particularly the Xingwen County rural road infrastructure project. The company will not declare a dividend, instead choosing to reinvest profits for business growth. Raffles Infrastructure aims to exit the SGX watch list, subject to approval, after meeting the financial exit criteria.

site_title: Singapore bank lending drops in July as home loans shrink further: MAS preliminary data
summary: Singapore bank lending declined 0.9% in July to S$680.7 billion, driven by a 1.3% drop in business loans and a 4.6% decline in general commerce loans. Housing loans, accounting for 75% of consumer lending, fell 0.2% for the seventh consecutive month. Total consumer loans dropped 0.3% to S$262.7 billion. The decline in lending is attributed to the US-China trade war and cooling measures in the local property market.

site_title: Australia, NZ shares end firmer as China fires up trade deal hopes
summary: Australia's S&P 200 index rose 1.5% on Friday, its second straight week of gains, as investors cheered signs of a thaw in stalled Sino-U.S. trade talks. Mining stocks, including iron ore miners BHP and Rio Tinto, surged 2.2-4.2% and heavyweight banking stocks led gains, while technology and healthcare stocks also rose. New Zealand's benchmark index surged 1.7% on the same day, its best weekly gain since late June. Despite a 3% monthly loss in August, the positive trade salvo helped lift shares.

site_title: URA to conserve former Singapore Chinese Girls' School buildings at Emerald Hill
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) plans to conserve three historic buildings at the former Singapore Chinese Girls' School (SCGS) site in Orchard Road, Singapore. The buildings, including the Main Block (1925), Principal's House (1930), and Song Ong Siang Block (1956), will be adapted to house new cultural and lifestyle uses. The conservation proposal was sparked by a campaign by ex-students to save the site, which was initially set to be redeveloped. The URA will work with relevant agencies to study possible uses, including the ideas proposed by the SCGS alumnae.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 10.22 points to 1,605.40. Volume was 54.7 million lots worth RM33.3 million. Gainers outpaced losers 146 to 41. The gains followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record close in the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq.

site_title: Apple loosens grip on iPhone repair work
summary: Apple has begun supplying parts and training to independent repair shops, offering more options for iPhone repairs. The move comes after criticism of the company's tight grip on repair work. The program, starting in the US, will eventually be expanded internationally and requires independent shops to have an Apple-certified technician. There will be no cost for participating shops, and Apple will provide parts, tools, and diagnostics. This change aims to ensure the safest and most reliable repairs, using genuine parts and trained technicians.

site_title: China iron ore rebounds, but set for first monthly drop in nine
summary: China's iron ore futures rose 2.1% to 596 yuan (US$84.03) a tonne, rebounding from a 3-month low, but are set for a first monthly decline since November 2018. Rising supply and uncertain demand prospects sparked selloffs, despite some restocking demand emerging. The steel glut in China and seasonal demand lull weighed on prices, with Dalian iron ore expected to post a 20% slump in August. Analysts expect a possible buildup in steel demand starting from September, supporting prices.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally on fresh trade hopes after troubled week
summary: Asian markets rallied on Friday after China expressed no intention to retaliate against US tariffs, boosting hopes for trade talks. The news followed a volatile week and comes as US tariffs on hundreds of billions of dollars in Chinese goods are set to take effect over the weekend. This sets up a positive end to the week, with investors focusing on the long-running trade war between the world's top two economies.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) and the Singapore Foreign Exchange Market Committee have set up a steering committee for transitioning Singapore Open Rate (SOR) to Singapore Overnight Rate Agreement (SORA) due to the impending discontinuation of the US dollar Libor. Meanwhile, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) reported a 1.7% increase in development charge rates for commercial use and a 0.3% decrease for non-landed residential use. Singapore bank lending dipped to S$680.7 billion in July, and the Singapore Police Force has established an Anti-Scam Centre to disrupt scammers' operations.

images.alt_text: THE MAS on Friday said it has established a steering committe to oversee an industry-wide interest rate benchmark transition from the Singapore dollar (SGD) Swap Offer Rate (SOR) to the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (SORA).

site_title: WeWork caught between Peloton, Flywheel Sports legal battle
summary: WeWork is caught in the middle of a legal battle between Peloton and Flywheel Sports, with Peloton seeking information about potential talks between WeWork and Flywheel. Peloton accuses Flywheel of copying technology and infringing on patents, and WeWork denies ever discussing acquiring Flywheel. The subpoena could force WeWork to disclose its thoughts on adding fitness equipment to office spaces, potentially compromising its own business strategies. The lawsuit could also impact WeWork's IPO plans, which value Peloton at over $8 billion.

site_title: Trump launches new Pentagon command for space warfare
summary: President Donald Trump launched a new Pentagon command, SpaceCom, dedicated to space warfare, recognizing the threat from China and Russia. The command elevates space to a focused theater of combat, equal to other major commands, and aims to ensure US dominance in space. The move follows Trump's 2018 order to create a dedicated Space Force, which could become the sixth branch of the US armed forces. The new command will enhance space warfare capabilities and counter potential threats from adversaries jamming communications and GPS satellites.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump launched a new Pentagon command dedicated to warfare in space Thursday, as American armed forces chiefs see China and Russia pressing hard to erode the US advantage in the newest military frontier.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged more than 1% in the morning session on Friday, August 30, 2019, following China's decision to hold off retaliating against US tariffs and US President Donald Trump's announcement of talks between the two sides. The Hang Seng Index rose 1.20% to 26,011.64, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also increased.

site_title: Forever 21 might not last as retailer said to prepare for potential bankruptcy filing
summary: Forever 21 Inc is preparing for a potential bankruptcy filing due to dwindling cash and stalled debt restructuring talks. The company has been exploring additional financing options, but negotiations with lenders have stalled. A bankruptcy filing could help shed unprofitable stores and recapitalize the business. Founded in 1984, Forever 21 operates over 800 stores globally and has been plagued by internal disagreements, including a dispute over controlling stake ownership. The company's cash dwindling and turnaround options fading have led to the consideration of a Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing.

images.alt_text: Forever 21 Inc is preparing for a potential bankruptcy filing as the fashion retailer's cash dwindles and turnaround options fade, according to people with knowledge of the plans.

site_title: Why the fate of Samsung's billionaire heir turns on horses
summary: South Korea's Supreme Court has ordered Samsung Electronics' billionaire heir Jay Y Lee to face a retrial for corruption, citing a gift of three horses valued at 3.4 billion won as a bribe. The case, which also involves former president Park Geun-hye, may signal a shift in the government's scrutiny of chaebol conglomerates. Lee could face a minimum of five years in prison if convicted, and the decision may deprive Samsung of a charismatic leader with global connections. The ruling has had minimal impact on the stock market, with Samsung shares initially sliding 2.5% before recovering.

site_title: A US$15b oyster sauce family aims to survive 1,000 years
summary: The Lee Kum Kee family, owners of the US$15 billion oyster sauce empire, have implemented a comprehensive governance system to ensure the business's survival for 1,000 years. The system, introduced in the early 2000s, includes a family council, constitution, and training programs for younger generations. The family has also diversified its businesses, including real estate, healthcare, and venture capital, to meet changing market needs. With the patriarch, Lee Man Tat, set to retire, the family is adapting its governance system to appeal to a younger generation and maintain the business's success.

site_title: Uber, Lyft, DoorDash put US$90m to possible ballot war
summary: Uber, Lyft, and DoorDash are investing $90 million in a ballot measure campaign to prevent California's Assembly Bill 5 from reclassifying their contractors as employees. The bill, which passed the state Assembly in May, would apply a 2018 court ruling to a wide range of state laws, potentially providing workers with overtime and unionization protections. If the bill passes, the companies fear they will have to reclassify their workers, leading to significant costs and operational changes. The ballot measure aims to block the bill's implementation.

images.alt_text: Uber Technologies Inc, Lyft Inc, and DoorDash Inc are putting US$90 million behind a ballot measure strategy to ensure they don't have to reclassify their California workers as employees.

site_title: South Korea central bank holds fire but October rate cut seen likely
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, held its benchmark interest rate at 1.50% on Friday, despite expectations of a possible rate cut in October to support the faltering economy. The decision was in line with forecasts of 13 out of 18 analysts surveyed. Economists attribute the decision to avoiding a second consecutive rate cut and saving "firepower" to address economic challenges, including a brewing trade conflict with Japan and a cooling global economy.

site_title: France's antitrust cop is wary of new actors in online payments, 'killer acquisitions'
summary: France's antitrust regulator, Isabelle de Silva, is set to increase scrutiny of online payments, citing concerns over "killer acquisitions" by tech giants like Apple and Facebook. She warns that these deals could enhance dominant market power and stifle competition. De Silva is prioritizing the issue, with plans to study fintech and payment systems, and is also investigating online advertising and mergers. Her team is working on cases that could impact Silicon Valley tech giants, and she is calling for greater powers to regulate such acquisitions.

site_title: Key Hong Kong protest organizer attacked by armed masked men
summary: A Hong Kong protest organizer, Jimmy Mr Sham, was attacked by two unidentified armed masked men inside a restaurant in Kowloon. The attack occurred as the city prepares for a 13th straight weekend of pro-democracy demonstrations. Mr. Sham was shielded by a friend and was not injured. Hong Kong police confirmed the attack and are investigating. Amnesty International condemned the attack as a deliberate attempt to target a peaceful activist, and the incident has sparked concerns about the safety of protesters ahead of a planned mass march on Saturday.

site_title: Cathay warns staff to stay away from Hong Kong general strike
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd warned employees not to participate in a planned Hong Kong general strike, which could result in termination. The airline, facing pressure from Beijing, expects staff to report to work and will closely monitor attendance. The strike, set for Monday and Tuesday, is part of months-long protests in the city. Cathay has seen seven employees leave and its CEO resigned amid concerns about companies' efforts to avoid angering Beijing and uphold employees' rights.

site_title: Indian state on alert ahead of publication of citizenship register
summary: Tens of thousands of paramilitary personnel and police are deployed in Assam, India's border state, ahead of the publication of a citizenship register that could leave millions of people stateless, mainly Muslims. The register, finalized after four years of efforts, left off four million people, prompting concerns of protests. The government has backed the test and said it could extend the exercise to other border states. Critics say the search for illegal immigrants has been targeted at minority Muslims, with no facilities to hold rejected individuals and Bangladesh refusing to accept deportees.

images.alt_text: Indian workers of National Register of Citizens (NRC) office check different documents which were submitted by people for NRC ahead of the release of the final draft of NRC in Guwahati, Assam, on Saturday.

site_title: One big tobacco deal is enough
summary: A planned US$200 billion tie-up between Philip Morris International Inc and Altria Group Inc may deter other tobacco companies from making similar deals, as the market remains cautious. The two companies complement each other's businesses, including alternative tobacco products, and integration should be straightforward. However, potential deals involving British American Tobacco Plc, Japan Tobacco Inc, and Imperial Brands Plc face antitrust hurdles and may not provide significant benefits. Other companies, such as China National Tobacco Corp, may still pursue mergers, but none are expected to be as transformative as the Philip Morris-Altria deal.

site_title: Singapore Police sets up Anti-Scam Centre, working with banks to disrupt scammers' operations
summary: The Singapore Police Force has set up an Anti-Scam Centre, working with three major banks to disrupt scammers' operations. Since its establishment in June, the centre has referred over 1,000 police reports and frozen 815 suspicious bank accounts linked to scams, recovering 35% of the total losses of S$2.4 million. The centre aims to streamline the investigation and prosecution process, working closely with digital platforms, telecommunications companies, and other authorities to prevent scams and minimize losses.

site_title: Magnus Energy Q4 loss widens to S$16.2m
summary: Magnus Energy reported a widened fourth quarter net loss of S$16.2 million, from S$13.5 million a year ago, due to the winding down of its oil and gas equipment distribution segment in South-east Asia and Australia. Revenue fell 23.4% to S$4.5 million. The company's full-year net loss widened to S$17.5 million, with a loss per share of 0.14 Singapore cent. Despite this, the group remains focused on the energy sector and expects funds from a capital reduction in one of its subsidiaries.

site_title: Kitchen Culture narrows 2019 full-year loss to S$3.7m
summary: Kitchen Culture Holdings reported a narrowed 2019 full-year net loss of S$3.7 million, down from S$4 million last year. Revenue slipped 26.7% to S$10.5 million due to lower contributions from residential and distribution segments. Despite this, the company's order book stands at S$4.5 million and S$19.1 million for residential projects, with plans to add new appliance brands to its portfolio. The company's management expects to capitalize on a surge in new project launches in Singapore.

site_title: MAS sets up steering committee for switch from interest rate benchmark SOR
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has established a steering committee to oversee the transition of interest rate benchmark SOR to SORA over the next two years. This change is necessary due to the likely discontinuation of the US dollar Libor, which SOR relies on. The Association of Banks in Singapore and the Singapore Foreign Exchange Market Committee have concluded that financial contracts referencing SOR should transition to SORA, particularly SGD interest rate derivatives. The transition aims to ensure the sustainability of the interest rate benchmark.

site_title: Apple expected to unveil new iPhone at Sept 10 event
summary: Apple is set to unveil a new iPhone on September 10, marking the launch of a new-generation iPhone model. The event, held at Apple's Silicon Valley campus, is expected to feature improved processing power and camera capabilities, but no radical changes or 5G offerings. This comes after Apple delivered stronger-than-expected results in the second quarter, driven by growth from services and wearables. The premium smartphone market has grown fiercely competitive, with rivals such as Samsung and Google introducing new models, and Apple is prioritizing digital content and services.

site_title: Dell beats profit estimates on higher desktop sales, shares surge
summary: Dell Technologies Inc beat Wall Street profit estimates in the second quarter, driven by higher demand for cloud services and personal computers. The company reported a 6% jump in revenue from its client solutions business and posted net income of $4.51 billion. Dell's shares surged 6% in extended trading after the announcement, exceeding analyst estimates of $1.47 per share. The company's total revenue rose 2% to $23.37 billion, following a six-year hiatus from the stock market after it acquired VMware.

site_title: Prudential's S$2.5b damages claim branded 'absurd' by lawyers
summary: Prudential plc is suing former Singapore agent Peter Tan Shou Yi for allegedly orchestrating the defection of 244 agents and agency leaders to rival Aviva plc in 2016. The London-based insurer claims damages of up to S$2.5 billion, but Tan's lawyers have described the claim as "absurd" and an attempt at revenge. The case, with its spy thriller-like allegations, has sparked criticism of Prudential's motives and the use of dramatic language in the lawsuit.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Friday as Wall Street soars; STI up 0.7% to 3,102.71
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.7% on Friday, reaching 3,102.71, following a strong performance on Wall Street. US stocks notched their biggest one-day gain in two weeks after Chinese officials hinted at no retaliation against US tariffs, easing trade war fears. Asian equities followed suit, with Japan and Australia stocks advancing 0.8% each. The rally was driven by banking stocks, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC all rising. The Straits Times Index (STI) has now gained 5 days in a row ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Asean must boost centrality and integration efforts: Chan Chun Sing
summary: ASEAN must prioritize centrality and integration efforts to remain a viable economic partner, according to Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing. He emphasized the need for coherence, commitment, confidence, and consistency in achieving Asean centrality, particularly in addressing non-tariff barriers and aligning standards and regulations. The minister highlighted the importance of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) in promoting a multilateral trading order and stated that its conclusion would bring together 16 economies into a single cooperative framework for shared prosperity.

site_title: Crypto exchange Binance says it'll handle regulators better than Libra
summary: Binance, a leading cryptocurrency exchange, plans to launch its own digital currency, Venus, with a focus on regulatory compliance. Unlike Facebook's Libra, which faced widespread regulatory scrutiny, Venus will prioritize partnerships with governments and companies in non-Western countries, including China. Binance's co-founder, He Yi, aims to engage with regulators from the start and form an independent association to oversee the project. The exchange will use a basket of government-backed currencies and securities as its reserve and has set up regulatory-compliant exchanges in friendlier jurisdictions.

site_title: UK says it will hold twice-weekly Brexit talks with EU officials
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced that Britain will hold twice-weekly Brexit talks with EU officials starting next month, aiming to rework the rejected agreement. Johnson wants to remove the 'backstop' provision, which the EU seeks to maintain an open border between Ireland and Northern Ireland. He emphasized the need for increased talks after recent discussions with EU leaders showed willingness to explore alternatives to the backstop.

images.alt_text: British negotiators will hold twice-weekly talks with European Union officials next month in an attempt to rework the Brexit agreement that Britain's parliament has repeatedly rejected, Prime Minister Boris Johnson said on Thursday.

site_title: Inflight Workout
summary: A long-haul flight doesn't have to mean a sedentary experience. According to Bernice Liu, a senior physiotherapist, it's essential to move every 1-2 hours to promote circulation and prevent muscle stiffness. Simple exercises can be done in the seat, galley, or aisle, such as toe taps, leg lifts, and arm circles. By staying active, passengers can reduce the risk of blood clots and discomfort during long flights.

site_title: Hong Kong activist Joshua Wong, two others arrested in crackdown on protests
summary: Hong Kong pro-democracy activist Joshua Wong, along with two other prominent activists Andy Chan and Agnes Chow, were arrested on suspicion of organizing illegal protests. The arrests follow a crackdown on unrest in the city, which has plunged into its biggest political crisis in over two decades. The protests, sparked by anger over a suspended extradition bill, have evolved into calls for greater democracy under the "one country, two systems" formula. The arrests come as China has accused foreign powers of fomenting the demonstrations and warned against foreign interference.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong democracy activist Joshua Wong was arrested on Friday ahead of another weekend of planned protests in the Chinese-ruled city which is grappling with its biggest political crisis since its handover to Beijing more than two decades ago.

site_title: ASL Marine Q4 loss deepens to S$116.6m
summary: ASL Marine reported a net loss of S$116.6 million for its fiscal fourth-quarter, a 123% increase from the previous year. Revenue fell 6.9% to S$63.3 million, while full-year net loss widened to S$141 million. The company attributed the losses to impairment losses on financial assets and operating expenses. ASL Marine expects a volatile business environment due to mixed macroeconomic trends, but notes that capital goods will benefit from these factors gradually.

site_title: Asia: Shares rise on conciliatory trade tone but mood cautious
summary: Asian shares rose on Friday as China struck a conciliatory tone on trade with the US, but investors remained cautious due to ongoing fears of a global growth slowdown and recession. China's commerce ministry said Beijing and Washington were discussing the next round of face-to-face talks scheduled for September, boosting hopes for progress. However, analysts remain skeptical, citing ongoing tariff tensions and the risk of a near-term trade deal. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index rose 0.6%, with Japan's Nikkei and South Korea's KOSPI index also gaining.

images.alt_text: Asian shares rose on Friday as China struck a hopeful tone on trade with the United States but continued fears about a global growth slowdown, or even a recession, capped sharp rallies.

site_title: Europe: Shares rally, bond yields rise as China fuels trade deal hopes
summary: Europe's stocks rallied, with the STI up 0.4%, as China's commerce ministry announced discussions on the next round of US-China trade talks, sparking hopes for progress. The US and European shares advanced, with bond yields rising, following China's retaliatory tariffs on $75 billion of US goods. The Chinese yuan snapped a 10-day losing streak, boosting the market. Investors remain positive despite tariff uncertainty, with some analysts attributing the rally to improved sentiment on US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Gold slips as positive US-China trade vibes lift equities
summary: Gold prices fell 0.8% to $1,526.62 per ounce, hovering near its highest level since 2013, due to a rising dollar and optimistic US-China trade talks. Despite concerns over a decelerating global economy, gold prices have gained about 8% this month, driven by fragile sentiment and demand for the safe-haven metal. Silver also eased alongside gold, while platinum and palladium rose. Experts attribute the recent gains to accommodative global central banks and supportive economic conditions.

images.alt_text: Gold fell on Thursday as the dollar rose and stock markets gained confidence with the latest positive development in the US-China trade deal, but concerns over decelerating global economy kept prices hemmed near a multiyear peak.

site_title: US home-price gains in cities slow for 15th month in a row
summary: US home-price gains in 20 cities slowed for a 15th consecutive month, increasing 2.1% from the previous year, below projections. This slowdown underscores buyers' hurdles, including mounting personal debt and rising home prices outpacing income gains. Solid labor market support sales, with the weakest results on the West Coast and southwestern markets maintaining their lead.

site_title: UOB prices US$500m covered bonds due 2022 at 1.625%
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) issued US$500 million of three-year covered bonds due 2022 at a fixed coupon of 1.625% and sold at 99.694% of the principal amount. The bonds are expected to be issued on Sept 5, 2019, and are guaranteed by Glacier Eighty. Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's Rating Services are expected to rate the bonds Aaa and AAA, respectively. UOB shares rose 1.5% to close at S$24.78 on the day of the announcement.

site_title: EU carworkers target Brexit spoils
summary: European carmakers, including French, Spanish, German, and Portuguese plants, are poised to take over Vauxhall's production if the UK fails to reach a Brexit deal, with the Ellesmere Port plant in line to build an upgraded Astra model. PSA Group plans to move production out of the UK if a no-deal Brexit occurs, with French and Spanish sites considered as alternatives. The move comes as UK car production continues to decline, with exports cratering 15% in July.

site_title: More investors warm to a US ultra-long bond: survey
summary: US investors are warming to the idea of owning ultra-long Treasury bonds, with 39% saying they would buy such a bond, up from 19% two years ago. However, most still prefer a 20-year security, with 50% of respondents expressing this preference. The US Treasury Department is considering issuing ultra-long bonds, with yields on 30-year Treasury bonds falling to record lows due to recession and trade tensions fears. Some fund managers see the idea as appealing, but Wall Street remains cautious, citing concerns about cannibalizing demand for existing long-dated Treasuries.

site_title: Signs of new US-China trade discussions emerge as increased tariffs loom
summary: The US and China are set to resume trade talks in September ahead of a looming deadline for additional US tariffs, which are scheduled to take effect on Sunday. President Donald Trump confirmed discussions on Thursday, while China's commerce ministry urged Washington to cancel the tariff increase. The talks come as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. The US has imposed tariffs on Chinese goods, sparking a bitter trade war between the two economic superpowers. A new round of in-person negotiations is expected to take place in September.

site_title: These are the most luxurious airport lounges in Asia
summary: Seven luxurious airport lounges in Asia offer a five-star escape for business travelers. The Pier First Class Lounge in Hong Kong, designed by Ilse Crawford, features warm materials and elegant design. The Centurion Dining Room at Hong Kong's American Express Centurion Lounge offers a Michelin-starred menu. The Royal Orchid Spa at Bangkok's Thai Airways lounge provides hour-long massages. The Private Room in Singapore's Changi Airport offers a serene space with seasonal menus. Japan Airlines' first-class lounge at Tokyo's Narita Airport features sushi chefs and a ramen counter. The Qantas Lounge in Hong Kong serves authentic Hong Kong meals. The Qatar Airways Premium Lounge in Bangkok offers à la carte dining.

site_title: Stripped Back
summary: Snow Patrol, a Northern Irish band, is set to perform a special acoustic show in Singapore on September 1 at the University Cultural Centre (UCC) Hall. The show, titled "Snow Patrol - Live and Acoustic," will feature songs from their latest album "Wildness" and classic hits like "Chasing Car" and "Run." The band, known for selling 16 million records worldwide, will be in unplugged mode, marking their first studio album since 2011's "Fallen Empires." Tickets are available for S$98 at Sistic.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, CapitaLand, Chuan Hup, Hatten Land, ASL Marine, Sakae
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean companies saw new developments that may impact trading on Friday. United Overseas Bank issued US$500 million in three-year covered bonds at a fixed coupon of 1.625%. CapitaLand divested its 100% interest in a Chinese property to an unrelated party for S$19.6 million. Silverlake Axis secured a contract to work on a digital transformation project in Malaysia. Chuan Hup Holdings posted a net loss of US$26.4 million for FY2019, while Hatten Land reported a net profit of RM9.3 million for Q4. ASL Marine and Sakae Holdings also reported significant losses.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The secrets to Chope's success
summary: Chope, a Singapore-based restaurant reservation site, has achieved significant success despite being a startup for eight years. With 200 employees and over 4,000 restaurant clients in seven markets, Chope's revenue doubled to $19.5 million in 2018. The company's secret to success, according to COO Sean Tan, has not been disclosed, but the podcast episode aims to explore this. Chope's growth and success have been impressive, with the company now standing out as one of the few startups that have endured in the industry.

site_title: US hopeful EU will impose sanctions on Venezuela in coming months: US envoy
summary: US envoy Elliott Abrams expressed hope that the European Union will impose sanctions on Venezuela in the coming months due to stalled talks between the government and opposition. Abrams stated that European nations are waiting for the outcome of negotiations, but if talks fail, they will impose sanctions. The US is also examining more sanctions to pressure President Nicolas Maduro to step down, despite Abrams' skepticism that negotiations will succeed.
