site_title: Singapore shares inch up 0.04% to 3,057.57 at Thursday's open
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.04% to 3,057.57 at Thursday's open, driven by a rebound in US stocks on higher oil prices, despite Brexit and recession worries. Gainers outnumbered losers 72 to 39, with Singtel and Rex International Holding advancing. Financial stocks DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank also edged up, while United Overseas Bank fell. The index closed flat in Tokyo and lower in Europe amid global recession concerns.

site_title: International students face hurdles under Trump administration policy
summary: International students face increased hurdles in obtaining US visas under the Trump administration. Long delays and unexpected denials have become common, with many students facing extended security checks and harsher penalties for overstay violations. The State Department says national security is the top priority, but university officials claim the increased vetting has resulted in a chilling effect on international student recruitment. The number of Chinese students has quadrupled in the past decade, but they are disproportionately affected by the increased scrutiny.

site_title: Apple to start online sales in India after country eases rules: source
summary: Apple is set to start online sales in India within months, thanks to the country's easing of rules that allowed for exports to be included in local sourcing requirements. The move benefits Apple, which has been lobbying against the rule, and could help it reduce its dependency on China by building an alternative supply chain in India. Apple will begin selling its iPhone, iPads, and Mac computers online and is firming up its first company-owned store in India, likely to open next year.

site_title: Trump to announce plan to boost biofuel demand soon: US agriculture secretary
summary: US President Donald Trump plans to announce a plan to boost demand for biofuels within weeks, his agriculture secretary said. The move comes after the administration expanded oil refinery waivers, angering farmers who grow corn used to make ethanol. The EPA granted 31 waivers to small refineries, prompting the Trump administration to scramble for a solution. The proposed plan may include increasing biofuel blending quotas or strengthening infrastructure to allow more widespread use of E15, a higher-ethanol blend of petrol.

site_title: Amazon in talks for stake in Indonesia ride-hailing startup Gojek: source
summary: Amazon is in early talks to buy a stake in Indonesian ride-hailing startup Gojek, according to a Reuters source. The talks are private, and details of the stake are not known. Gojek, valued at around $10 billion, has expanded services beyond ride-sharing to include online payments and grocery ordering. This deal would follow Amazon's recent acquisition of a stake in British food delivery company Deliveroo.

site_title: Europe: Global growth worries keep a lid on shares, chaotic Brexit looms
summary: European shares declined 0.2% on Wednesday due to concerns of a looming global recession and a potential no-deal Brexit, which could disrupt the UK economy. Sterling tumbled after UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced plans to suspend parliament, limiting opposition to his Brexit plans. UK house-builders were hit hard, with shares of Persimmon and Taylor Wimpey falling 3-5%. The Stoxx 600 index ended lower, with most European sub-sector indexes falling, while US bond prices trimmed earlier gains after Wall Street's major indexes turned positive.

site_title: A crypto firm hopes to get banking licence from Singapore
summary: Sygnum, a Swiss-based crypto firm, aims to obtain a banking license in Singapore, despite the country's initial hesitation towards digital assets. The company plans to apply for a banking license after becoming a full bank in Switzerland, allowing it to offer asset-management services, custody, brokerage, and tokenization for digital assets like Bitcoin and Ethereum. Sygnum has raised 60 million Swiss francs and secured backing from established players, including Singapore Telecommunications, and is conducting due diligence on potential customers to comply with anti-money laundering rules.

site_title: Hyflux says no definitive deal reached with white knight Utico
summary: Hyflux clarified that no definitive agreement was reached with Utico, pending resolution of "certain final outstanding issues" in the draft definitive agreements. Despite Utico stating it had "signed and released" a restructuring agreement, Hyflux emphasized the ongoing discussions and negotiations. The deadline for a definitive agreement was August 26, but no announcement was made as of press time. The restructuring deal aims to resolve issues for creditors and PNP investors, with Utico to take on new projects with Hyflux's support.

site_title: New China tariffs a 'job killer,' US industry tells Trump
summary: US industry groups, including major brands like Nike and Foot Locker, warn that President Trump's new China tariffs will be a "job killer," costing US consumers an additional $4 billion annually and increasing recession risks. The tariffs, set to roll out in stages through December, target popular items like laptops, mobile phones, and shoes, potentially driving up prices ahead of the holiday shopping period. Over 360 trade groups, including software and electronics manufacturers, also urge Mr. Trump to abandon the tariff strategy, citing higher prices and damaged consumer confidence.

site_title: Bolton back from brink as takeover deal completed
summary: Bolton Wanderers, a struggling English third-tier football club, has found a buyer, Football Ventures (Whites) Limited, averting liquidation and a possible expulsion from the Football League. The sale comes after the club's joint administrator, Paul Appleton, praised the late Eddie Davies' family trust for its efforts to save the club, criticizing previous owner Ken Anderson's behavior. The new owners, who took over despite initial complications, have vowed to restore the club to its former glory, despite a 12-point deduction at the start of the season.

images.alt_text: A buyer has been found for stricken Bolton Wanderers, staving off the imminent threat of extinction, the English third-tier club announced on Wednesday.

site_title: USDA to probe beef market after Tyson Foods slaughterhouse fire
summary: US Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue ordered an investigation into the beef market after a fire at a Tyson Foods Inc slaughterhouse in Kansas temporarily eliminated a key buyer of livestock, causing cattle prices to plummet. Beef prices rose as buyers scrambled for meat, while packers' profit margins increased to over $400 per head of cattle. The USDA will examine whether there is evidence of price manipulation, collusion, or other unfair practices. The investigation aims to address concerns about the power of large packers in the US beef sector.

images.alt_text: US Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue ordered an investigation into widening prices between cattle and beef on Wednesday after a recent fire at a Tyson Foods Inc slaughterhouse in Holcomb, Kansas, shut the plant.

site_title: Facebook expands 'Local Alert' tool in bid to help in emergencies
summary: Facebook is expanding its "Local Alert" tool to provide users with reliable information in emergencies, such as mass shootings and extreme weather. The tool allows local authorities and first responders to send messages that are then disseminated by Facebook, aiming to improve the platform's public image and counter misinformation. The service has been tested in 300 cities and will now be available across the US, although its effectiveness in pilot phase was unclear.

site_title: Nine Singapore firms make Forbes Asia's Best Over A Billion list
summary: Nine Singapore companies made Forbes Asia's inaugural Best Over A Billion list, including Big 3 banks and companies like Wilmar International and City Developments. The list highlights top-performing listed companies across Asia-Pacific with revenues of $1 billion or more, evaluated on metrics such as sales growth, operating income, and projected growth. The largest Singapore companies featured on the list are DBS Group Holdings, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank, ranking 13th, 20th, and 23rd by market value.

site_title: Pacific Star sinks into red with S$22m fiscal 2019 loss
summary: Pacific Star Development, a Catalist-listed company, reported a net loss of S$22 million for the 12 months ended June 30, 2019, due to poor market sentiment in the Iskandar, Malaysia, property market. Revenue declined 96.5% to S$4.3 million, primarily due to decreased sales in its Puteri Cove Residences project. The company's cost of sales narrowed to S$3.1 million, while gross profit fell 98% to S$1.2 million. Pacific Star expects the residential property market to continue deteriorating, with tighter bank mortgage loans and reduced sales prices.

site_title: US Congress probes Trump's bid to host G-7 at his resort
summary: US Democratic lawmakers are investigating Donald Trump's offer to host the 2020 G-7 summit at his Trump National Doral Miami golf course, citing potential conflicts of interest and corruption. The investigation was announced by House Judiciary Committee chairman Jerry Nadler and Steve Cohen, who claim Trump's financial interests are shaping official US government activities. The probe comes as concerns about Trump's ability to remain impartial grow.

site_title: Pound dives on increased no-deal Brexit prospect
summary: The British pound plummeted against the dollar and euro as the UK government extended parliament's suspension until October 14, increasing the likelihood of a no-deal Brexit. The pound slid by over 1% in early business, with some losses pared later. Anti-Brexit MPs criticized Prime Minister Boris Johnson's move, calling it a coup and declaration of war. Despite this, global stocks, including the FTSE 100, outperformed, with energy stocks benefiting from a drop in crude oil inventories.

site_title: Red wine could be good for digestive system
summary: A study by King's College London found that red wine drinkers had a greater diversity of bacteria in their digestive tracts, associated with improved gut health, lower obesity, and "bad" cholesterol levels. The study, involving 916 female twins, suggests that polyphenols in grape skin may be responsible for this effect. However, lead author Caroline Le Roy emphasized that moderate red wine consumption is still not recommended, as excessive drinking is bad for health, and other sources of polyphenols, such as fruits and nuts, can provide similar benefits.

images.alt_text: A study by a team of scientists from King's College London has found that red wine drinkers had a greater diversity of bacteria in their digestive tracts, which is a marker of gastrointestinal health, compared to those who consumed other kinds of alcohol.

site_title: Christie's to auction items from I M Peis' personal collection
summary: Christie's has acquired a 59-piece art collection from the late architect I.M. Pei and his wife Eileen, featuring works by artists such as Barnett Newman, Jean Dubuffet, and Zao Wou-Ki. The collection, valued at over $25 million, includes gifts from artists and reflects the Peis' connections to China and their friendships with artists. The collection will be auctioned in November and December, with exhibitions planned in Paris, Hong Kong, and Los Angeles.

site_title: Toyota, Suzuki to form capital tie-up: sources
summary: Toyota and Suzuki plan to form a capital tie-up, with Toyota taking a 5% stake in Suzuki. The deal, valued at around $1.26 billion, aims to accelerate technological development and meet industry changes. Suzuki will invest about $4.8 billion in Toyota. The move follows a 2016 partnership to produce electric vehicles and compact cars for each other, as carmakers face challenges in an industry transformed by electric vehicles and autonomous driving.

site_title: 'Help me': Aussie accused of spying in China pleads to return home
summary: An Australian academic, Yang Jun, arrested in China on spying charges, has asked Prime Minister Scott Morrison to help him return home. Yang, who has been detained since January, pleaded innocence in a statement, saying Beijing's claims of spying were "nonsense". Morrison denied Australia's involvement in Yang's alleged espionage and promised to stand up for his citizen's human rights. Yang's arrest has strained relations between Australia and China, with Beijing warning Australia not to intervene in the case. Yang's fate remains uncertain, with Morrison's response seen as a significant development in the deteriorating ties between the two countries.

images.alt_text: Yang Jun, an outspoken writer who also goes by his pen name Yang Hengjun, has been detained in China since January without access to his lawyer or family.

site_title: China housing market seen to slow on drop in sales forecast
summary: China's housing market is expected to slow this year, with sales forecast to drop due to tightened measures and a decline in prices. Despite this, prices are still projected to rise 6% in 2019, with a further slowdown to 3% in the first half of 2020. Analysts attribute this to strong underlying demand, a lack of investment options, and government support. However, some warn of a large downside risk in regional markets, and a sharp downturn is not expected on the national market as a whole.

site_title: Australia construction spending at 3-year low
summary: Australia's construction spending has reached a three-year low in the latest quarter, with a decline in home building affecting other sectors. The housing downturn is attributed to an oversupply of new apartment blocks, which is unlikely to improve soon. This poses a downside risk to Australia's economic growth.

site_title: Eurozone bond yields near record lows as US yield curve inversion deepens
summary: Eurozone government bond yields are near record lows amid a deepening US yield curve inversion, fuelling recession concerns. Italy's bond yields steadied after a one-day fall, as the country inches towards forming a new government. The US Treasury curve inversion, combined with economic slowdowns in China, has raised pressure on policymakers. Meanwhile, other news includes the retirement of OCBC CEO Helen Wong, China's slowing GDP growth, and Citigroup setting a mid-2026 target for the MSCI global equity index.

site_title: Make cybersecurity everyone's business
summary: KPMG Singapore emphasizes the importance of a holistic cybersecurity approach, encompassing six sub-domains: leadership and governance, human factors, information risk management, business continuity and crisis management, operations and technology, and legal and compliance. The organization notes that human weaknesses, such as spear-phishing, are a major contributor to cyberattacks, and that a cybersecurity program is essential to increase cyber-readiness. Effective cybersecurity requires active management, investment, and regular testing of incident response plans.

site_title: Darth Vader helmet among Hollywood treasures in US$10m auction
summary: Darth Vader's helmet from "The Empire Strikes Back" is set to be auctioned off for nearly US$500,000 in the "Icons and Legends of Hollywood" sale on September 25-26 in Los Angeles. The mask and helmet, one of only a handful worn by actor David Prowse, is part of a vast collection of coveted Hollywood treasures expected to sell for over US$10 million. The auction features iconic items from movies such as "Star Wars," "The Wizard of Oz," "Titanic," and "Back to the Future."

site_title: Maybank could be in the running for digital banking licences
summary: Maybank Singapore is considering applying for one of the five digital banking licences in Singapore, with the option to partner with a regional player to complement its strengths and weaknesses. The bank is still strategizing on its value proposition, which is a key factor in its decision. Maybank has already established an internet-only bank and currently holds a licence that allows it to provide digital banking services. The bank believes that digital banks and incumbent banks can co-exist and complement each other, with digital banks targeting underserved small businesses.

site_title: Oil prices gain nearly 2% after drop in US crude inventories
summary: Oil prices rose nearly 2% on Wednesday after US crude inventories fell by 10 million barrels, exceeding analyst expectations. This decline eased concerns about weakening oil demand due to the US-China trade war. Brent crude futures rose 98 cents to $60.49 a barrel, and West Texas Intermediate crude rose 85 cents to $55.78 a barrel. The unexpected decrease in US crude stockpiles was attributed to slower imports. The increase in oil prices was seen as a positive sign for the energy market.

site_title: HK protesters denounce Cathay Pacific for dismissing crew
summary: Hundreds of Hong Kong protesters gathered to denounce Cathay Pacific Airways for dismissing crew members who took part in or supported anti-government rallies. The airline had terminated 20 pilots and cabin crew, citing "white terror" and a directive from the Civil Aviation Administration of China. Protesters, including the Hong Kong Confederation of Trade Unions, called for the airline to reinstate the fired staff and uphold freedom of speech. The move is seen as a challenge to the airline's compliance with Chinese authorities, amid growing tensions between Beijing and protesters in Hong Kong.

site_title: Laying the foundations for vehicles of the future
summary: Indonesia aims to establish itself as a major player in the electric vehicle sector by 2025, with plans to produce 20% of total car production. The country has secured investments from Toyota, Hyundai, and Softbank Group Corp, totaling $5 billion. Grab Indonesia, a privately-held startup, has committed to creating a digital ecosystem and improving livelihoods through its services. The government hopes to reduce reliance on imported oil and compete with Singapore and Thailand in the electric car market. Production of electric vehicles is expected to start by 2022.

site_title: Find this 1 on Lazada
summary: BMW is partnering with Lazada to launch its new 1 Series, the first car brand in Singapore to do so on an e-commerce platform. 11 units of the 118i will be available for sale on Lazada during the 9.9 Sale event, with financing options starting at 1.18% interest. Customers can book the car online and complete the sale at a BMW showroom, with the platform aiming to reach a younger, tech-savvy customer base. This partnership may lead to car brands partnering with outsiders to expand their reach, but Lazada's CEO sees it as a way to synchronise online and offline sales.

site_title: Rate cuts not enough to re-fire damp India housing market: poll
summary: India's housing market is expected to remain stagnant, with house prices predicted to rise only 1% this year and 2% in 2020, the lowest median predictions in over 70 years. Experts attribute this to the lack of available credit, which is the worst in over 70 years, according to the government's assessment. This will restrain housing market activity and limit price rises, despite aggressive interest rate cuts.

site_title: US: Wall Street shrugs off recession, Brexit fears
summary: US stocks rebounded on Wednesday, closing 1% higher as bargain-hunting investors snatched up equities that opened in the red. Energy stocks benefited from a decline in crude oil inventories, while tech stocks gained 0.4%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished at 26,035.21, with investors rebalancing portfolios ahead of the end of the month. Fears of a Brexit-induced recession and a US-China trade conflict weighed on stocks, but the market shrugged off concerns, with yields on 30-year Treasury bonds hitting a fresh all-time low.

images.alt_text: US stocks rebounded on Wednesday, rallying as bargain-hunting investors snatched up equities that opened in the red.

site_title: Virgin Australia cuts 750 jobs as it swings to loss
summary: Virgin Australia has cut 750 jobs to save A$75 million, amid an annual underlying loss of A$71.2 million due to soft market conditions and higher fuel costs. The airline will also merge business divisions, review operations, and conduct a cost-cutting review to become profitable. CEO Paul Scurrah has formed a new management team to focus on cutting costs, but declined to promise a return to profit this financial year.

site_title: A slow boat off France's tourist track
summary: A slow boat cruise along France's Soane and Rhone rivers offers a unique way to explore the region, visiting picturesque towns and chateaux without the hassle of constant packing and unpacking. The journey takes place from Lyon and Viviers to Arles and Avignon, showcasing the area's rich history and inspiring artists such as Van Gogh, Cezanne, and Gauguin. Along the way, travelers can indulge in Provence's gourmet cuisine and soak up the local traditions, making for a memorable experience.

site_title: Najib 'pivotal' in 1MDB plunder, trial hears
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Najib Razak is facing his biggest graft trial, accused of 21 counts of money-laundering and 4 counts of abuse of power over his alleged role in plundering state fund 1MDB. Prosecutors claim Najib used an "elaborate charade" to channel hundreds of millions of dollars to his bank account, with the aim of enriching himself. Najib denies all charges and faces up to 20 years in jail if convicted. The trial is a significant development in the 1MDB saga, which has led to the defeat of Najib's long-ruling coalition and sparked widespread protests in Malaysia.

site_title: Singapore's palm-oil plays endure a sullen month
summary: Singapore's palm-oil stocks have lost momentum this August due to weak commodity prices and Indonesia's dry spell. However, analysts see a silver lining in Indonesia and Malaysia's push for biodiesel, which could offset losses and drive demand for palm oil. China's growing demand for palm oil as an alternative to soybean oil amid the US-China trade war is also expected to neutralize the impact of European Union's biodiesel levies.

site_title: Why there is climate hope - despite the Amazon tragedy
summary: Despite the devastating Amazon wildfires, a transformation in attitudes towards climate change is underway, driven by growing public consciousness and a shift towards national self-interest. Populist leaders like Donald Trump and Jair Bolsonaro's views on climate change are increasingly seen as outdated and scientifically illiterate. The Paris Agreement, despite being seen as a starting point, will require more ambition and domestic legislation to be implemented to effectively tackle global warming. A growing number of countries are moving to replicate and ratchet up their climate frameworks, driven by economic benefits and a sense of national responsibility.

images.alt_text: Students taking part in a rally at the Consulate of Brazil in Kolkata in eastern India, to protest against Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro's policies and his response towards the fires raging in the Amazon.

site_title: Philippine stocks may bounce back into bull market on earnings: analysts
summary: Philippine stocks may bounce back into a bull market later this year, according to analysts, as corporate profits recover and economic growth accelerates. Earnings of companies in the benchmark gauge grew faster in the second quarter, supporting expectations of double-digit expansion this year. Analysts forecast earnings per share to grow by 14.3% this year, the fastest pace since 2012, with the Philippine Stock Exchange Index expected to reach 8,600 this year.

site_title: CPFIS funds deliver returns of 1.9% in second quarter
summary: CPFIS funds delivered an average return of 1.9% in the second quarter, with mixed asset funds performing best at 2.04%, followed by equity funds at 1.94%. Bonds climbed 1.61% and money market funds edged up 0.34%. The encouraging performance continues in tandem with global equity markets, which rallied 4.08% in the same period. However, uncertainty remains, with investors watching US-China trade talks and the impact of the US Federal Reserve's interest rate cuts.

site_title: #MeToo movement takes centre stage in star-studded Venice festival
summary: The 76th Venice film festival has sparked controversy over its selection of directors, including Roman Polanski, who was convicted of statutory rape in 1978, and Nate Parker, who was accused of rape while in university. The festival has been criticized for lacking diversity, particularly in the number of female directors, with only two women out of 21 in the running for the top prize. Festival director Alberto Barbera has defended the line-up, saying that it features films that "reveal a new sensitivity" despite the inclusion of Polanski and Parker. The controversy has reignited discussions about gender disparity in the film industry.

site_title: Avenue South Residence pricing half of units below S$1.5 million
summary: Avenue South Residence, a 1,074-unit 99-year leasehold development in Singapore, will offer half of its units priced below S$1.5 million. One-bedroom units start at S$858,000, and two-bedroom units at S$1.15 million. The project, developed by UOL Group and its partners, features commercial facilities and will draw interest from owner-occupiers and investors. The consortium expects strong sales momentum, with public previews set to begin on Friday and a marketing push to include overseas sales.

site_title: India's voice at G7 shows forum's ineptness with global issues
summary: India's participation in the G7 Summit highlighted the forum's ineptness in addressing global issues. Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi addressed key topics such as climate change and digital transformations, showcasing India's importance in tackling these issues. Discussions focused on regulating digital flows, managing the social, political, and economic effects of digital transformations, and promoting citizen-centric AI. India's policy shift on data management, mandating only "critical" information be held in India, is seen as a positive step, soothing concerns from the Trump administration. India's forward-looking climate commitments and emphasis on citizen-centric AI are significant in addressing global challenges.

site_title: Uneventful session sees STI slide
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,056.47, down 11.05 points or 0.4% on Wednesday, amid an uneventful trading session. However, property stocks and Reits saw a noticeable pick-up, with the iEdge S-Reit Index gaining 13.84 points or 1% to close at 1,413.65. Safe haven assets are expected to outperform equities due to recession fears and rising US-China trade tensions.

site_title: India's economic growth shows little sign of recovery from five-year low
summary: India's economic growth shows little signs of recovery from a five-year low, with investment and consumption activity worsening in July. The country's purchasing managers index (PMI) for services rebounded into growth territory, but car sales slumped 36% and infrastructure sector output grew at the slowest pace in over four years. The weakening came despite Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman's recent measures to revive the economy, which are expected to fall short of spurring growth.

images.alt_text: Consumption, which contributes nearly 60% to gross domestic product, has been largely hurt by a shadow banking crisis, and that in turn has dragged growth down to a five-year low.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as recession fears loom
summary: US stocks opened lower on Wednesday, August 28, 2019, amid recession fears due to the ongoing US-China trade war. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.25%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.27%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.37%. These losses follow recent bond market moves that have fueled concerns about a potential economic downturn.

site_title: Fear mongering distracts from crux of AI use - data dependence
summary: Artificial Intelligence (AI) has sparked intense debate over its potential benefits and risks. While some predict catastrophic consequences, the real issue lies in the misuse of AI by humans, which can lead to harm. The quality and success of AI programs depend heavily on the data they are fed, with larger datasets providing a significant advantage. This has led to countries like China and US technology giants dominating the AI landscape, while smaller companies struggle to compete. To overcome this, data sharing and collaboration between countries and organizations are essential, as data is now the world's most valuable resource.

site_title: Happy ending for S$401.9m collective sale of City Towers in Bukit Timah
summary: The sale of City Towers in Bukit Timah, a District 10 freehold site, has been completed at S$401.9 million after four attempts, with a unit linked to Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing acquiring the site. The sale marks a successful en bloc sale for the property.

site_title: HSBC extends help to struggling HK SMEs
summary: HSBC is offering rebates and fee reductions to struggling small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Hong Kong, amid the city's first recession in a decade. The bank will provide a six-month interest rate rebate on loans and fee subsidies for applications to its financing guarantee scheme. The measures aim to support SMEs affected by the prolonged US-China trade war and anti-government protests. This is the first large-scale support package from a major lender in Hong Kong, with HSBC's single biggest market accounting for 52% of its US$12.4 billion in first-half pre-tax profits.

site_title: Will banks' courtships end in marriage?
summary: Singapore banks are considering partnerships with digital banking aspirants, but the cost of taking a minority stake may outweigh the benefits. Under the new digital banking licence setup, banks are free to take a minority stake, but must meet stringent capital requirements and adhere to anti-money laundering and know-your-customer standards. OCBC and UOB have expressed openness to partnerships, while DBS has been focused on "reimagining banking" through integration with customers' lives. The Monetary Authority of Singapore will issue up to five digital banking licences, with only a few expected to succeed.

site_title: Nassim Road condo up for collective sale at S$223m
summary: A prime freehold condominium, Beaufort On Nassim, in Singapore's District 10 has been launched for collective sale at a minimum price of S$222.68 million, translating to a unit land rate of S$3,508 psf ppr. The 30-unit development, built in 2008, is expected to attract luxury developers, given the site's low-density location and limited availability of plots on Nassim Road. The sale satisfies the requisite majority consent of at least 80% for developments 10 years and older, and the tender closes on September 30.

site_title: Integrated refinery of the future
summary: A new generation of refineries is being designed with integrated systems and visual interfaces to meet market demand and profitability. The next-generation refinery will operate with AI-assisted analytics, knowledge worker pods, and prescriptive maintenance systems, allowing for autonomous decision-making and real-time optimization. The refinery will be connected through the Industrial Internet of Things, with data sensors and analytics deployed at the edge to drive process control. The goal is to create a sustainable, flexible, and adaptable refinery that can thrive in a hypercompetitive global market, with stakeholders having immediate visibility into their decisions and the impact on sustainability metrics.

site_title: Final Girl With Dragon Tattoo novel hits shelves
summary: Swedish crime writer Stieg Larsson's bestselling novel series, The Millennium saga, concludes with the release of "The Girl Who Lived Twice." The final installment of the series, featuring Lisbeth Salander, is hitting bookstore shelves in 30-odd countries. This marks the conclusion of the series, which has been a global phenomenon since its inception.

site_title: Qualcomm says carriers need to get serious about Wi-Fi
summary: Qualcomm urges carriers to adopt new Wi-Fi technology, Wi-Fi 6, to stay competitive, as the number of connected devices doubles every two years and will reach 24 per household by 2020. The company's new chips enable simultaneous connections and broader radio frequencies, making mesh networks a key factor in improved technology. If carriers don't adapt, major cloud companies like Amazon will step in, offering products and services to users. Qualcomm expects carriers to shift their focus from basic modems to investing in Wi-Fi technology, viewing Wi-Fi as the primary technology for handling indoor traffic.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: ISOTeam, a CATALIST-listed company, reported a fourth-quarter net profit of S$2.9 million, reversing a net loss of S$1.9 million the previous year. Revenue growth from its repairs and redecoration business drove the improvement. Earnings per share rose to 1.03 Singapore cents from a loss of 0.65 cent the year prior. The company recommended a full-year dividend of 0.42 Singapore cent per share.

site_title: Japan regulator to step up surveillance of stressed banks
summary: Japan's Financial Services Agency plans to increase surveillance of local banks that show signs of stress due to years of low interest rates and a shrinking population. The regulator will conduct on-site inspections and impose administrative penalties if banks post continuous deficits or have a capital adequacy ratio below 4%. This move aims to prevent bank stress and maintain financial stability.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: UG Healthcare's full-year revenue rose 17% due to increased production capacity, leading to a 47% rise in gross profit. However, net profit declined 59% due to higher expenses. Wing Tai Holdings reported lower net profit in FY2019, driven by lower property development profits. Despite challenges in the residential segment, the group expects revenue growth from investment properties. Key risks include higher raw material prices for UG Healthcare.

site_title: Johnson gets Queen's nod to suspend Parliament
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson has received Queen Elizabeth II's approval to suspend Parliament from September 12 to October 14, potentially hindering lawmakers' efforts to block a no-deal Brexit. The move, which could trigger a constitutional crisis, is deeply controversial, with opposition lawmakers vowing to continue meeting despite the suspension. The timing also coincides with a crucial European Union summit on Brexit on October 17-18. The decision has led to a slump in the pound, with Sterling trading at a six-day low.

site_title: Strong demand for PSA, UBS bond deals as market heats up
summary: The Singapore bond market saw strong demand for two deals launched on Wednesday, August 28, 2019. PSA's 10-year US dollar issue was priced at 2.125% after exceeding a US$2 billion orderbook, while UBS's S$750 million Singapore dollar perpetual issue was priced at 4.85%. Both deals were well-received by investors, meeting market expectations and reflecting the market's increasing demand for bonds.

site_title: 737 MAX fallout won't slow Boeing's appetite for services deals: CEO
summary: Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenburg says the 737 MAX crisis won't slow the company's appetite for services deals. Despite the grounding of its fastest-selling jet, Boeing has completed around 560 flights with the new software and aims to return the jet to service in the fourth quarter. The company plans to expand its services business to $50 billion in revenue by 2029, with the goal of managing the MAX situation while continuing to invest in the future. Boeing has diverted resources to the 737 MAX from other projects, but development work on a new middle-of-the-market aircraft remains on track.

site_title: Triyards subsidiary ordered to hand over collateral worth 542b Vietnamese dong
summary: A Vietnamese court has ordered Saigon Offshore Fabrication and Engineering Limited (SOFEL), a subsidiary of Triyards Holdings Limited, to transfer collateral worth 542 billion Vietnamese dong (S$32.4 million) to Vietnam Asset Management Company. The collateral includes buildings, machineries, and equipment from a shipbuilding project. This comes after Triyards' parent group, Ezra Holdings, filed for bankruptcy protection in the US last September, suspending the counter's trading.

site_title: Singapore unveils intellectual property initiatives to support Asean Industry 4.0
summary: Singapore has unveiled intellectual property initiatives to support Asean's Industry 4.0 development, including expedited patent applications for emerging technologies such as fintech and cybersecurity. The government agency, along with eight other Asean IP offices, has launched a pilot project called ASPEC Acceleration for Industry 4.0 Infrastructure and Manufacturing, which aims to reduce waiting times to six months. Additionally, IPOS has signed partnerships with global innovation communities, including the UK Intellectual Property Office and Brazil's National Institute of Industrial Property, to promote IP protection and commercialization.

site_title: Thailand sees scope for more fiscal support, lower interest rate
summary: Thailand's government is considering further fiscal support and interest rate cuts to boost its economy, which is growing at its slowest pace in nearly five years. The country's export-reliant economy has been hit by the US-China trade war and a surging currency, with the gross domestic product rising 2.3% in April through June. Finance Minister Uttama Savanayana said the government has fiscal space to do more and may undertake further interest-rate cuts to boost growth, although it's unclear if another rate cut will happen.

site_title: Hyundai, union agree on wage deal, avoiding strike for first time in 8 years
summary: Hyundai Motor Co and its South Korean workers' union have reached a tentative wage deal, averting a strike for the first time in eight years. The agreement, which includes a one-off payment, additional salary, and basic salary increase, is aimed at helping the carmaker survive in an uncertain business environment. Hyundai's shares rose over 4% following the announcement, as the union's decision to avoid a strike is seen as a positive move for the company's earnings recovery. The deal is subject to approval from union members in a vote on Monday.

site_title: Investors stick with yen as recession fears grow
summary: The Japanese yen holds its gains against the US dollar as recession fears grow, with investors seeking safer assets. The yen stands at 105.78 per US dollar, close to its 7-month high. Sterling slumps on British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's plan to limit parliament's ability to block Brexit. US bond yields deepen the yield curve inversion, raising concerns about an economic slowdown, with the US dollar index rising marginally to 98.091.

site_title: US trade agency affirms Trump's tariff hike on Chinese goods
summary: US Trade Representative's office reaffirmed President Trump's plans to impose additional 5% tariffs on $300 billion Chinese imports starting September 1 and December 15. The tariffs will increase to 15% on some goods starting September 1 and the rest on December 15. The move comes in response to Chinese retaliatory tariffs on US$75 billion worth of US goods. The Trump administration accuses China of "unfair acts, policies, and practices," citing currency manipulation and intellectual property protection issues.

images.alt_text: The US Trade Representative's office on Wednesday reaffirmed President Donald Trump's plans to impose an additional 5 per cent tariff on a US$300 billion list of Chinese imports starting on Sept 1 and Dec 15.

site_title: Cycling startup Peloton files for IPO as sales, losses surge
summary: Peloton Interactive Inc, a home exercise startup, has filed for an initial public offering (IPO) worth US$500 million, likely to be one of the year's biggest IPOs. The company, which has over 1.4 million members and sells exercise bikes with TV screens, is unprofitable, losing US$196 million on sales of US$915 million in the last year. Peloton warns it may not turn a profit or maintain profitability in the future, seeking a valuation of US$8-10 billion.

site_title: Bringing Batam into the next phase
summary: Batam, Indonesia, has seen over 1.8 million tourists visit the island in 2019, with Singaporeans making up 49.66% of the arrivals. Plans are underway to grant Special Economic Zone (SEZ) status to two enclaves on the island, including the Nongsa Digital Park, to boost growth and attract more investors. The SEZ status would leverage Batam's proximity to Singapore, low operating costs, and favorable location outside Indonesia's "Ring of Fire". This move aims to further establish Batam as a major tourist hub and economic destination.

site_title: Will sea change engulf developers?
summary: Singapore's long-term approach to mitigate climate change could benefit construction and civil engineering companies, potentially offering them a role in projects like building polders to protect the eastern coastline and reclaiming islands for freshwater reservoirs. However, climate change poses existential challenges to residential property developers, who may face decreased demand and changing consumer behavior, with waterfront living potentially losing its allure. The government's steps to cope with climate change may prompt Singaporeans to rethink their mindset about property buying, potentially shifting from investment to consumption.

site_title: Foreign investors flock to Indonesia
summary: Indonesia has received a record-breaking $29.3 billion in foreign direct investment (FDI) in 2019, with a further $14.18 billion in the first semester of 2020. Singapore remains the top foreign investor, followed by Japan and China. The country is expected to become the seventh-largest economy in the world by 2030 with 135 million middle-class consumers. Indonesia's strong political stability, improved ease of doing business, and growing economy are attracting foreign investors. The country aims to rank 40th in the World Bank's ease of doing business index by 2024 and is targeting major industries such as Industry 4.0, infrastructure, and tourism.

site_title: Nassim Road condominium up for collective sale at S$223m reserve price
summary: A freehold condominium, Beaufort On Nassim, in District 10, Singapore, has been launched for collective sale by tender at a minimum reserve price of S$223 million. The 30-unit development occupies a 4,212.6 sq m site and comprises two- and three-bedroom apartments. 26 of the 30 owners have agreed to the sale, satisfying the requisite majority consent. The sale is seen as a rare opportunity for developers to secure a land along Nassim Road, which is currently zoned for residential use with a gross plot ratio of 1.4.

site_title: A perfect mix of business and leisure
summary: Indonesia's tourism industry is experiencing healthy growth, with visitor arrivals reaching 15.8 million last year, a 13% increase from 2017. The government aims to draw 18 million tourists this year, with ongoing initiatives to increase tourist numbers, including the development of 10 New Balis and a seven km sea bridge linking Batam and Bintan. Bintan, a popular resort island, saw its visitor numbers cross the one million mark last year, with a 18.4% year-on-year growth. The island is expected to benefit from the bridge, new hotels, and a range of sporting events, including the International Bintan Marathon.

site_title: Hong Kong protesters denounce Cathay Pacific for firing cabin crew
summary: Hundreds of protesters gathered in Hong Kong to denounce Cathay Pacific Airways for firing 20 pilots and cabin crew who took part in or supported anti-government rallies. The protests come as China has denounced the demonstrations and accused the US and Britain of interfering in its affairs. The Hong Kong Confederation of Trade Unions called for the airline to revoke the terminations and stop creating a "climate of fear." The protests are part of the ongoing pro-democracy movement in Hong Kong, which has grown into the biggest challenge for authorities since the city's return to Chinese rule in 1997.

site_title: Iran's Rouhani calls for unity to overcome US "economic war"
summary: Iranian President Hassan Rouhani urged unity to counter the US's "economic war" amid heightened tensions between the two nations. Rouhani stated that Iran would use diplomacy to resolve the standoff despite distrust in US President Donald Trump. The US sanctions on Iran are seen as "economic warfare" by Tehran, and Rouhani vowed that talks would only resume once sanctions are lifted. Iran has threatened further nuclear breaches unless sanctions relief is provided, escalating the crisis.

site_title: Pound falls on report Britain's Queen could be asked to suspend parliament
summary: The British pound fell 0.5% to $1.2220 on Wednesday after a BBC journalist reported that Queen Elizabeth could be asked to suspend parliament as early as the day, potentially hindering efforts to stop a no-deal Brexit. This news followed recent hopes that opposition parties could block the exit.

site_title: Citi raises minimum wage to US$15 per hour
summary: Citigroup Inc raised its minimum wage to US$15 per hour in June, following pressure from US Representative Maxine Waters and similar moves by other big banks. This decision comes after lawmakers criticized the bank's large pay gap between executives and median workers. The move is part of a trend among major banks, including JPMorgan Chase & Co and Wells Fargo & Co, which have also raised their minimum wages.

site_title: 500 protests, hundreds injured in Kashmir lockdown
summary: At least 500 protests have broken out in Indian Kashmir since New Delhi revoked its autonomy, with nearly 100 civilians injured and 300 police and paramilitary troopers hurt. The strict lockdown, imposed hours before the decision, has restricted movement and cut phone and internet services. Authorities have promised to create 50,000 jobs in the region, but efforts to ease the conditions have been unsuccessful. The Supreme Court has given the government one week to respond to a legal challenge calling for an end to the communications blackout.

site_title: Dowry's S$1.5b - but suitors are queueing at virtual bank altar
summary: A dozen new players are vying for Singapore's five digital banking licenses, with fintechs and large corporates forming consortia with non-bank players to increase their chances. Suitors include Grab, Validus Capital, and European digital bank startups like Revolut, while traditional lenders like M1 and Ping An Insurance's fintech arm OneConnect are also in the running. To qualify, applicants must demonstrate a sustainable digital banking business model and meet the same capital requirements as local banks, with the maximum licenses comprising up to two full-bank licenses and three wholesale bank licenses.

site_title: EU will be blamed for lack of 'flexibility' if no-deal Brexit: British minister
summary: British Brexit Secretary Stephen Barclay warned that the EU will be blamed for its "lack of flexibility" on the Irish border question if the UK leaves the EU without a deal after October 31. Barclay criticized the EU for prioritizing the European single market over maintaining peace on the island of Ireland. The EU has ruled out ditching the Irish "backstop" unless the UK presents workable alternatives. The deadline for the UK's departure looms, with both sides warning that a no-deal Brexit will cause economic and travel chaos.

site_title: Singapore shares retreat 0.4% on uneventful Wednesday session
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) retreated 0.4% to 3,056.47, marking a down day despite a rise in property stocks and real estate investment trusts (Reits). Trading volume was low, with 890.79 million securities traded, and the blue-chip index remains down 0.4% in 2019. Markets in Australia, Japan, and South Korea closed higher, while China and Hong Kong dipped.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.02 points to 1,589.82. The market saw 1.9 billion lots worth RM1.5 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 517 to 305.

site_title: SMEs must beef up their cyber defences
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) must strengthen their cyber defenses and make cybersecurity a business priority, according to KPMG. SMEs are vulnerable to cyber-attacks, with attackers using them as conduits to target larger companies or governments. KPMG recommends three key pillars for securing businesses: understanding and protecting core business assets, making cybersecurity everyone's business, and investing in the right balance of people, process, and technology. SMEs can take simple steps to shape their cybersecurity strategy without breaking the bank, such as effective hiring of cyber talent and implementing good cyber hygiene practices.

site_title: Thailand's Central Pattana to go ahead with mall opening despite airport row
summary: Thailand's Central Pattana plans to open its luxury mall on August 31 despite a dispute with state-owned Airports of Thailand (AOT). AOT had blocked the mall's entrance due to concerns about the building's height and lighting. A court hearing was held after Central filed a complaint, and the mall operator stated it had complied with regulations. The new mall's opening may increase retail competition around Suvarnabhumi International Airport, a key tourist destination.

site_title: India eases foreign investment rules for several sector to boost growth
summary: India's federal Cabinet approved further liberalization of foreign direct investment (FDI) rules in four sectors, including digital media, coal mining, contract manufacturing, and single-brand retailers. The government allowed up to 26% foreign investment in digital media, 100% foreign investment in coal mining, and eased sourcing norms for single-brand retailers. The moves aim to boost economic growth, which has been sluggish at 5.8% in the first quarter. Analysts predict slower growth in the next quarter, and the government plans to use $21 billion in dividends to stimulate the economy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower again
summary: Hong Kong shares ended the day in negative territory for the third consecutive day, falling 0.19% to 25,615.48, amid uncertainty over China-US trade talks. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. Investors are shifting cautiously due to the ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: De Beers diamond sales keep falling as buyers allowed to say no
summary: De Beers diamond sales plummeted to $280 million this month, a 44% decline from last year, as buyers were allowed to reject stones. The company offered flexible terms to its sightholders, including the option to refuse half of smaller stones and sell back diamonds on favorable terms. This is the largest decline in sales since July, when buyers refused to buy amid concerns about profitability. De Beers' sales are down $1 billion from the same time in 2018, as the industry faces a surplus of polished stones and stagnant demand for diamond jewelry.

site_title: CRCT preferential offer 1.4 times subscribed
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) received 120.7 million valid acceptances and excess applications for its preferential offering, exceeding the 1.4 times subscription rate. The offering, part of a larger equity funding exercise, raised approximately S$125.1 million, with total gross proceeds of S$279.4 million from the exercise, including a private placement of S$154.3 million.

site_title: Strong demand for PSA and UBS issues
summary: The Singapore bond market experienced strong demand for two deals launched on August 28, 2019. PSA's 10-year US dollar issue was priced at UST+80bps, exceeding US$2 billion in orderbook, while UBS's second Singapore dollar perpetual issue was priced at 4.85%. The deals demonstrate the market's resilience and appetite for new issuances, with expected sizes of US$500 million and S$3.4 billion respectively. Joint bookrunners for both deals include DBS Bank and HSBC, with UBS, DBS Bank, Standard Chartered Bank, and United Overseas Bank serving as joint lead managers for the UBS deal.

site_title: CPFIS funds deliver 1.9% returns for Q2
summary: CPFIS funds delivered an average 1.9% return for the second quarter of 2019, with mixed asset funds performing best at 2.04% and equity funds rising 1.94%. The MSCI World TR USD index rallied 4.08% during the same period. For the one-year period, CPFIS-included funds posted an average positive return of 2.21%, with unit trusts rising 1.81% and ILPs up 2.46%. The three-year period saw 26.23% growth for CPFIS-included funds, with unit trusts gaining 28.28% and ILPs rising 24.91%.

site_title: US warship sails in disputed South China Sea amid trade tensions
summary: A US Navy destroyer, the Wayne E Meyer, sailed near islands claimed by China in the South China Sea on August 28, 2019, challenging China's "excessive maritime claims" and preserving access to the waterways according to international law. The operation came amid tense US-China trade relations, with both sides having imposed tariffs on each other's exports. China had denied a US Navy warship a visit to its port city of Qingdao earlier that week. The US military operation is part of a long-standing position that its operations are separate from political considerations.

site_title: Australian shares rise as mining gains outpace downbeat banks; NZ also up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% as mining stocks outperformed banks, driven by concerns over margin pressure for lenders amid a deepening US debt yield curve inversion. BHP Group and Woodside Petroleum led gains, while the "big four" banks lost between 0.3% and 1.3%. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 1.1%, with Fisher and Paykel Healthcare Corp being the top gainer.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Grab invests $500m in Vietnam over 5 years, while Singapore unveils intellectual property initiatives. The sale of City Towers in Bukit Timah is completed, and DBS and CapitaLand make Forbes Asia's Best Over A Billion list. AVIC International Maritime calls for a trading halt, and ISOTeam swings to profit. Meanwhile, international news highlights China's slowing GDP growth, Citigroup's mid-2026 MSCI target, and UK economy shrinkage.

site_title: Trump's Art of the Flail is starting to hurt the US economy seriously
summary: US President Donald Trump's unpredictable trade policies are having serious economic consequences, with China responding to new tariffs with new tariffs of its own. Trump's actions have created uncertainty, causing businesses to postpone investment plans and affecting the global economy. Unlike stable tariffs, which can lead to full employment, unstable trade policy is detrimental to economies, making it difficult for businesses to plan for the future. The US economy is already slowing, and Trump's trade belligerence is contributing to the slowdown, creating a vicious circle. The lack of economic rationality in the White House is exacerbating the situation, with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin being overruled by Trump's decisions.

site_title: Digitisation among drivers for growth in Islamic banking sector
summary: Islamic banking sectors in Malaysia and Indonesia are on track to meet growth targets, driven by digitisation and regulatory support. Analysts from Moody's attribute this growth to digitisation, which reduces operating expenses, automates internal processes, and boosts revenue despite a small physical presence. This trend is expected to continue, with Islamic banks investing in digitisation to expand further at a lower cost. Regulatory support has also been cited as a key factor in driving growth in the sector.

site_title: Johnson to restrict parliament time before Brexit
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson plans to limit parliament's time before the UK's October 31 EU exit date, reducing the time available for lawmakers to block a no-deal Brexit. Johnson will set October 14 for the Queen's Speech, effectively shutting parliament from mid-September for around a month. The move has sparked outrage from opposition parties, who accuse Johnson of a constitutional outrage, and led to a sharp decline in the pound against the euro and dollar.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson will limit parliament's opportunity to derail his Brexit plans by cutting the amount of time it sits between now and EU exit day on Oct 31, infuriating opponents who accused him of a constitutional outrage.

site_title: Thomas Cook gets rescue package from China's Fosun Group
summary: Thomas Cook Group Plc, a UK travel giant, secured a £900 million (S$1.52 billion) bailout from China's Fosun Tourism Group, led by a 50% stake in its tour-operator arm and airline. The bailout provides stability for Cook as it prepares for the winter low season and will leave Fosun holding at least 75% of Cook's main holiday business. The deal, announced in July, will also see lenders get the rest of the airline and up to 25% of the tour business, with the possibility of other investors participating in the recapitalisation.

site_title: Singapore unveils intellectual property initiatives to support Asean Industry 4.0
summary: Singapore's Intellectual Property Office (IPOS) has launched initiatives to support Asean's Industry 4.0 development, including expedited patent applications for key emerging technologies such as fintech, cybersecurity, and robotics. IPOS signed six MOUs with global stakeholders to enhance innovation networks and partnered with eight other Asean IP offices to launch a joint initiative, aiming to boost innovation flow in the region. The move is part of a collective effort to support Asean's Industry 4.0 development and foster a more innovative and competitive ecosystem.

site_title: UK holiday firm Thomas Cook agrees key terms of rescue deal
summary: Thomas Cook Group has agreed the key commercial terms of a rescue package with Fosun Tourism, its banks, and bondholders. The Hong Kong-based investor will contribute £450 million in return for 75% of the tour operator business and 25% of the airline. Lending banks and noteholders will provide a further £450 million for 75% of the airline and up to 25% of the tour operator business. The deal aims to rescue the struggling UK holiday firm.

site_title: Powering Singapore's 5G future
summary: Singapore is set to launch its 5G mobile network by 2020, positioning itself as a frontrunner in the adoption of the next-generation technology. The government has invested S$40 million in 5G innovation and identified six strategic clusters for early adoption trials. Consistency and reliability are crucial for the technology's applications, particularly in industries requiring precise processes, such as healthcare and autonomous vehicles. To support its 5G future, Singapore will need to invest in expansive data platforms, including data centres, to ensure reliable and consistent data transmission.

site_title: F J Benjamin returns to profitability in FY2019
summary: F J Benjamin Holdings returned to profitability in FY2019, posting a net profit of S$177,000, after a period of restructuring. Revenue declined 21% to S$131.5 million, but cost controls and store closures resulted in a 19% decrease in operating expenses. The company's CEO, Nash Benjamin, attributed the turnaround to a healthier portfolio of brands and vowed to maintain cost management despite global uncertainties.

site_title: Civmec Q4 net profit slides 96.3%
summary: Civmec Limited reported a net profit of A$120,000 for the fourth quarter, down 96.3% year-on-year due to lower revenue and project completion. The company's full-year net profit fell 66.5% to A$6.08 million. Revenue decreased 30.5% to A$488.5 million, and earnings per share dropped to 1.21 Singapore cents. Despite this, Civmec declared a cash dividend per share of 0.7 Singapore cent, unchanged from the previous year. Shares closed flat at S$0.335.

site_title: Avenue South Residence preview to start on Friday
summary: The public preview of Avenue South Residence in Singapore will begin on Friday, offering 300 units for sale at the launch on September 7. The apartment complex features two 56-storey towers and five four-storey blocks, with units ranging from 474 to 1,668 sq ft. The development will also include 10,000 sq ft of commercial facilities. The consortium behind the project expects strong interest from owner-occupiers and investors, citing nearby projects and the Greater Southern Waterfront area.

site_title: Wake up and smell the coffee, from your Ukrainian sunglasses
summary: Ukrainian eyewear brand OCHIS Coffee has created eco-friendly sunglasses made from coffee waste, with the brand's CEO Maksym Havrylenko experimenting with herbs and coffee waste to create a unique material. The sunglasses, priced at $78-89, are made from coffee grounds and flax glued by vegetable oil, and can turn into a fertilizer after 10 years. The brand's first Kickstarter campaign raised $13,000, with customers from the US, Europe, Japan, and Australia. Havrylenko aims to promote clean product production and proper waste disposal globally.

site_title: At start of biggest 1MDB trial, prosecution paints a tale of excess and abuse
summary: Malaysian former Prime Minister Najib Razak's trial began, with prosecutors alleging he abused his power to cover up the theft of hundreds of millions of dollars from the state fund 1MDB. Najib faces 21 charges of money laundering and four charges of abuse of power for allegedly receiving illegal transfers of at least RM2.3 billion. Prosecutors claim he used 1MDB as a vehicle for self-gratification, colluding with fugitive financier Jho Low to carry out abnormal financial transactions. Najib denies any wrongdoing and claims the charges are politically motivated.

site_title: HSBC to cut fees, offer rebates to boost struggling small Hong Kong firms
summary: HSBC is offering rebates and fee reductions to small and medium-sized companies in Hong Kong, amid the city's economic struggles. The bank will provide a six-month interest rate rebate on loans, fee subsidies for financing guarantee schemes, and reduced transaction fees for mobile payment services. The measures aim to support struggling businesses, with Hong Kong on the verge of its first recession in a decade. This is the largest lender in Hong Kong to offer such support, with SMEs accounting for over 98% of local enterprises and 45% of total employment.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall as recession fears ramp up
summary: European stocks fell on Wednesday, led by losses in technology stocks, amid recession fears. A deep inversion in the US Treasury yield curve heightened concerns about economic growth, particularly in the face of a US-China trade war. The STOXX 600 index dropped 0.47%, with Germany's DAX underperforming at 0.54%. The decline follows a mixed day in the US, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Japan carmakers Toyota, Suzuki to form capital tie-up: reports
summary: Toyota Motor Corp and Suzuki Motor Corp plan to form a capital tie-up worth around 144 billion yen (S$1.74 billion) to accelerate technology development and adapt to the global auto industry's changes. Toyota will invest 96 billion yen in Suzuki, taking a 5% stake, while Suzuki will invest 48 billion yen in Toyota. This partnership aims to address technological challenges and keep up with consolidation in the industry, particularly in research and development for automated driving functions.

images.alt_text: Japan's Toyota Motor Corp and Suzuki Motor Corp plan to form a capital tie-up, local media including NHK said on Wednesday, to accelerate development of technology and adapt to sweeping changes upending the global auto industry.

site_title: Asean-5 countries likely to ease rates more in 2019: Maybank Kim Eng
summary: The Asean-5 economies (Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, Singapore, and Thailand) are likely to ease interest rates in 2019, with economists at Maybank Kim Eng predicting most countries will cut rates after the US Treasury yield curve inverted for the first time since 2007. This inversion is attributed to the US-China trade war, similar to the Asian financial crisis in 1998-2000. The US economy's stronger footing and the Fed's mid-cycle easing also support this prediction. Rate cuts are expected in Singapore, Malaysia, and the Philippines, while Thailand is expected to keep rates unchanged.

site_title: Vodafone races against time to salvage India deal
summary: Vodafone Idea, a 44%-owned Indian mobile operator by Vodafone, is struggling to salvage its deal after its stock price plummeted 90% since the merger in 2017. The company faces increased competition from Jio, with rivals adding 4G users faster, and its own service quality deteriorating due to network disruption. To stay afloat, Vodafone Idea may need to raise more capital, sell assets, or receive support from its British parent. The company has already raised $3.6 billion in a discounted rights issue and is expected to make further cuts to reduce its $14 billion net debt.

site_title: Indonesia millennials' coffee craze may spur record consumption
summary: Indonesia's millennials are driving a surge in domestic coffee demand, with a projected 36% increase to 5.3 million bags in 2019. This growth is attributed to the rise of cafes in urban areas, where young people socialize, and the increasing popularity of ready-to-drink and high-value beverages. To meet the demand, Indonesia plans to boost arabica production to 40% of its total crops from 15% now. The coffee industry has attracted venture capitalists, with companies like Kopi Kenangan securing funding to expand their outlets.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks gain on improved sentiment in pharma sector
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.86% on Wednesday, with the KOSPI index closing at 1,941.09 points, as investors flocked to pharmaceutical stocks after a sharp sell-off. The medical sub-index gained 4.6%, driven by bullish drugmakers, despite foreign investors selling US$42.80 million worth of shares. The KOSPI has fallen 4.90% this year, but the rebound in pharmaceutical shares led to broader market gains.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,068.44, up 0.03% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.03% to 3,068.44 on Wednesday, driven by a 0.92-point gain. Decliners outnumbered advancers 172 to 128, with 392.3 million shares changing hands. Banking stocks traded mixed, while Asian equities diverged, with Japan's Topix flat, Australian stocks up 0.2%, and South Korea's Kospi adding 0.4%.

site_title: Japan orders 240,000 to evacuate over flood, landslide fears
summary: Japanese authorities have ordered the evacuation of 240,000 people in the southwestern region of Kyushu due to flood and landslide fears triggered by heavy rains. The Japan Meteorological Agency has issued its highest-level alert, confirming a man's death in the disaster. The evacuation is a rare move, and officials are taking measures to protect lives.

site_title: Ground shifts in Indonesia's economy as conservative Islam takes root
summary: Indonesia's economy is shifting towards a more conservative Islamic direction, driven by a growing number of "born-again" Muslims who are embracing stricter interpretations of Islam. This movement is influencing various aspects of the economy, including entertainment, housing, and banking. Celebrities and businesses are now promoting Islamic branding and marketing, with products such as halal food, modest fashion, and Islamic travel gaining popularity. The government has also introduced measures to support the growth of the Islamic economy, with estimates suggesting it could account for up to 40% of the country's GDP.

site_title: MOM slaps S$230,000 fine on hazardous waste treatment firm for putting workers in danger
summary: A Singaporean hazardous waste treatment firm, Eco Special Waste Management, was fined S$230,000 for failing to ensure the safety and health of its employees. A flash fire broke out on February 23, 2017, due to improper storage of flammable liquid hexane, which was not suitable for storage in plastic containers. The fire was brought under control, but the facility was badly damaged. The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) found that Eco failed to conduct a risk assessment and ensure workers followed safe operating procedures.

site_title: Ousting Huawei, Australia finishes laying undersea internet cable for Pacific allies
summary: Australia completed its A$137 million undersea internet cable project to the Solomon Islands and Papua New Guinea, bypassing Huawei's involvement. The project aims to counter Chinese influence in the Pacific. The cable, funded by Australia, will provide high-speed internet to the two Pacific islands, which had previously partnered with Huawei. The move is seen as a strategic move by Australia to maintain control over its broadband network and limit Chinese influence in the region. The final piece was laid on Wednesday, marking the completion of the project.

site_title: Australia: Shares inch up as miners counter losses in banks
summary: Australian shares rose 0.1% on Wednesday, driven by gains in resource stocks, offsetting losses in financials. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 6.8 points to 6,478.0. The "Big Four" banks, however, declined 0.4-1.2% due to a deepening US debt yield curve inversion.

site_title: Can global matcha craze save Japan's tea industry?
summary: Japan's traditional tea industry is facing a decline in domestic consumption, with green tea leaves for drinking dropping 30% since 2001. However, global interest in matcha green tea is on the rise, with exports increasing 10 times since 1998. Producers are capitalizing on this trend by creating matcha-flavored products, such as ice cream and cake, to cater to the global demand. Despite efforts to modernize the traditional drink, many tea farmers are struggling to compete with global competition, and the industry's future remains uncertain.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close marginally higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed marginally higher on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.11% at 20,479.42. The dollar edged up against the yen, reaching 105.84 yen, as investors welcomed stability in foreign exchange rates. Real estate firms led gains, while Nintendo and Sony also rose. However, investors remained cautious due to uncertainty surrounding the US-China trade talks, with the market expected to remain subject to the issue.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 0.45 points to 1,590.39, opening lower on Wednesday. Volume was 20.2 million lots worth RM8.02 million, with 86 gainers out of 72 losers. This article does not appear to be related to the Malaysia share prices opening lower on Wednesday.

site_title: DFS to expand elsewhere in Asia as it leaves Singapore's Changi
summary: DFS Group Ltd plans to expand in Asia, opening its seventh store in Macau and fourth in Hong Kong by the end of the year, while its Hong Kong flagship store will be renovated. The travel retailer has decided not to bid to continue selling alcohol and cigarettes at Singapore's Changi Airport, citing changing regulations and geopolitical uncertainty as reasons for its exit. The concession ends in June, with options available to about 500 people who work at the liquor and tobacco operations, including potential deployment at DFS's other businesses in Singapore.

site_title: Australia home building craters, prices promise some relief
summary: Australian construction spending dropped 3.8% in the June quarter, the lowest in almost three years, as the home building industry continues to decline. This slowdown is expected to negatively impact the economy, potentially by 0.4 percentage points. Analysts predict annual growth will slow to its lowest in a decade at 1.5%, mainly due to poor consumer spending. Despite this, home prices appear to have turned a corner, with a 0.7% increase in August and values in Sydney and Melbourne rising 1% on the month.

site_title: Cargo ships urged to cut speed and pollution
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron has proposed cutting maritime transport's carbon emissions by slowing down cargo ships. The shipping industry emits 2.3% of global CO2 emissions, with heavy fuel contributing to airborne particulate matter. To reduce emissions, ships will need to switch to lower-sulfur fuel and install exhaust gas cleaning systems. Slowing down ships can cut fuel consumption by up to 30%, and France aims to regulate pollutant emissions in the Mediterranean by 2022. The International Maritime Organization has set a goal to reduce CO2 emissions by 50% by 2050, but negotiations on short-term measures are stalled.

site_title: Australia's Macquarie raises A$1b for renewables, tech investment
summary: Australian investment conglomerate Macquarie Group plans to raise approximately A$1 billion through a private share placement for investments in renewable energy, technology, and infrastructure sectors. The shares are being offered at a price of A$118 to A$123.5 each, with demand already exceeding the initial requirement. This placement is not underwritten, indicating Macquarie's confidence in the strong demand for the shares.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Wednesday, edging up 0.63% to 25,824.95, following a two-day decline due to China-US trade uncertainty and ongoing protests in the city. The Shanghai Composite Index remained flat, while the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.71 points. The gains were seen as a positive sign for investors, despite ongoing global market volatility.

site_title: Asia: Investors tread uneasily as trade hopes dim
summary: Asian markets experienced volatility on Wednesday due to uncertainty over China-US trade talks, with investors becoming increasingly skeptical about the sincerity of US President Donald Trump's comments. Despite a recent surge in oil prices, worries about a potential recession continue to dim hopes for an eventual agreement. Trading remains volatile, with markets reacting to Trump's unpredictable statements and China's downplaying of the need for further talks. The yield on two-year Treasury notes has risen above those for 10-year notes, indicating a higher risk of recession.

site_title: UK shipyard braces for Brexit turmoil
summary: A UK shipyard in Milford Haven, Wales, is bracing for a potential no-deal Brexit, which could lead to job losses among designers and engineers working on sensitive communication masts for British warships. The plant, which also produces prototypes for marine renewable energy, may shut down due to the uncertainty surrounding the UK's exit from the EU. The situation highlights the potential economic impact of Brexit on the UK's shipbuilding industry.

site_title: ST Integrated Engineering to raise S$4m via private listing on 1exchange
summary: ST Integrated Engineering (STIE) plans to raise S$4 million via a private listing on 1exchange, a Singapore-based regulated private securities exchange. The Singapore-based company, offering integrated facilities management and IT services to clients in Singapore, Malaysia, and the UAE, aims to support its expansion. STIE will list an undisclosed portion of its equity on 1exchange, an affiliate of private capital platform CapBridge, which is backed by the Singapore Exchange.

images.alt_text: ST Integrated Engineering's chairman Mushtaq Ahmad said that the capital raising comes as the company enters its next major phase of growth.

site_title: Business group issues wake-up call on China's corporate 'social credit' plan
summary: China's corporate "social credit" system is accelerating, with companies and individuals receiving scores based on financial credit, personal behavior, and corporate misdeeds. The system, aimed to be completed by 2020, could become a powerful tool for controlling companies and regulating their behavior, with negative ratings potentially leading to penalties. Foreign companies operating in China have expressed concerns about restricted access to the market and the growing state role in the economy. The European Union Chamber of Commerce in China warns that foreign governments need to wake up to the system's potential risks, calling it a "wake-up call" to take action.

site_title: Hong Kong good citizenship applications jump as people eye exit
summary: Applications for Hong Kong good citizenship cards surged 49% in the first two weeks of August compared to the same period last year, indicating residents may be considering leaving the city amid ongoing pro-democracy protests. The increase suggests Hong Kongers are seeking foreign residency options to potentially escape the city's unrest. Georg Chmiel, executive chairman of Juwai.com, believes the data indicates many are applying for police checks for foreign visa applications, offering an escape route.

site_title: Grab to invest US$500m in Vietnam over 5 years; partners Sovico Group
summary: Grab has announced a $500 million investment in Vietnam over five years to expand its services, including fintech, new mobility solutions, and logistics. The investment will also be used to launch new services and enhance its transport, food, and payments networks. Grab has partnered with Vietnamese conglomerate Sovico Group to improve Vietnam's first and last-mile delivery networks. The partnership aims to tap into opportunities in the country's growing market and provide innovative mobility and logistics solutions.

site_title: Pentagon in talks with Australia on rare earths plant: official
summary: The US Department of Defence is in talks with Australia to host a facility that processes rare earth minerals, aiming to reduce reliance on China for these specialised materials used in military equipment and consumer electronics. China, the world's largest processor and producer, threatens to curb exports to the US, following a push by the Chinese government to reduce its reliance on the US. This move aims to counterbalance the US's efforts to diversify its supply chain.

images.alt_text: The US Department of Defence is in talks with Australia to host a facility that would process rare earth minerals, part of an effort to reduce reliance on China for the specialised materials used in military equipment, a senior American official said.

site_title: Hyundai Motor agrees wage deal, avoids strike for first time in 8 years
summary: Hyundai Motor has reached a tentative wage deal with its South Korean workers' union, averting a strike for the first time in 8 years. The deal includes a one-off payment, additional salary, and basic salary increase, and is seen as a way for the company to survive in an uncertain business environment.
