This partnership aims to expand insurance options for Bukalapak's customers and merchants.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,071.57, up 0.2% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading at 3,071.57, up 0.2% on Tuesday, driven by the Straits Times Index. The market saw 158 losers and 145 gainers, with 513.9 million securities worth S$491.4 million changing hands. Notable movers included Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, Golden Agri-Resources, and Singtel, while banking stocks DBS and OCBC Bank saw minor fluctuations. The market's gains came despite ongoing tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: IT sector best performer on SGX with 29.8% total return for first 7 months
summary: The Singapore IT sector was the top performer on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for the first seven months of 2019, with a total return of 29.8%. The sector saw a net outflow of S$57.6 million in July, but the top five IT stocks, including Venture Corp and NetLink NBN Trust, have an average dividend indicated yield of 6.1%. The sector's combined market capitalization is S$15 billion, with a 24% total return year-to-date.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.38 points to 1,600.15. The index saw a volume of 48.88 million lots worth RM22.38 million. Gainers outpaced losers 111 to 56.

site_title: Spacecraft carrying Russian humanoid robot docks at ISS
summary: A Russian unmanned spacecraft carrying the humanoid robot Fedor successfully docked at the International Space Station on Tuesday, following a failed attempt over the weekend. Fedor, a lifesize robot that copies human movements, is due to stay on the ISS until September 7 and will assist astronauts in tasks remotely. The failed docking attempt had raised uncertainty over Russia's space programme, but NASA attributed the issue to the station, not the spacecraft. This mission marks a new test of Russia's emergency rescue system.

site_title: China's Sichuan province to remove restrictions on pig farming
summary: China's southwestern province of Sichuan is removing restrictions on pig farming to stabilize supply after African swine fever reduced herds. Sichuan, China's top pig-farming province, aims to reach a target of 40 million pigs a year. The province plans to promote modern farming, support large-scale farms, and encourage the use of land for pig farming. Beijing also aims to reduce live pig transport, which contributed to the spread of African swine fever. The measures come as China's hog herd has shrunk by almost a third since last year.

site_title: Hoarding sticky rice in Thailand could land you in jail
summary: Thailand has warned individuals and businesses against hoarding sticky rice, citing a recent surge in prices. Those found attempting to manipulate prices or failing to report stockpiles risk fines of up to $227 or five years in jail. The country is addressing a shortage caused by drought and a late harvest, with prices reaching a five-year high. The government plans a $683 million program to support rice farmers, who rely heavily on the commodity for income.

site_title: India gets US$24b windfall from RBI to spur growth
summary: India's government is set to receive a record $24.4 billion windfall from the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) to spur economic growth. The RBI's board approved the payout, which includes a dividend of $24.4 billion and surplus capital, amid a slowdown in India's growth and depressed consumer spending. The funds will likely be used to cut government borrowings, recapitalize banks, and inject fresh capital into state-run lenders. The move is seen as a boost to the economy, with analysts predicting lower lending rates and improved growth prospects.

site_title: Australia, NZ shares end higher as trade rhetoric dials down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% on Tuesday, recovering from a 1.3% drop the previous session, as US President Donald Trump's comments on a possible trade deal with China boosted market sentiment. Trump's remarks, made on Monday, suggested Beijing was sincere in its desire for a trade agreement. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,471.2, marking a higher close for the second session in a row.

site_title: CEO of Malaysia's RM301.4b state fund is leaving: source
summary: Malaysia's Permodalan Nasional Bhd (PNB), the country's largest state-owned fund, will be led by new CEO Jalil Rasheed, replacing Abdul Rahman Ahmad. Rahman, who joined PNB in 2016, will leave the position. This move follows a series of leadership changes at government-linked companies, which started after Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad returned to power in the 2018 election.

site_title: Singapore services business receipts up 2.8% in Q2
summary: Singapore's services business receipts grew 2.8% year on year in Q2, slowing from 3.6% in Q1 and 4.1% in Q4 2018. On a quarterly basis, receipts declined 0.1%, marking the second consecutive quarterly drop. Transport and storage saw the highest growth, followed by education and health services. Business services performed the worst, with a marginal 0.1% increase. The decline in quarterly growth is attributed to the exclusion of wholesale and retail trade, accommodation, and food services from the index.

images.alt_text: Singapore's services industries are still seeing their takings rise year on year, though at a slowing pace, according to second quarter data from the Department of Statistics on Tuesday.

site_title: European stocks dip at open
summary: European stock markets slid on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 0.4% to 7,065.10 points, and Paris' CAC 40 and Frankfurt's DAX 30 indices also declining 0.3% and 0.2%, respectively. The losses followed a three-day weekend and were attributed to concerns over US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Thai tycoon goes on ad blitz calling for end to Hong Kong unrest
summary: Thai billionaire Dhanin Chearavanont has taken out advertisements in Hong Kong newspapers calling for an end to the violence and unrest in the city, joining local tycoons in urging a peaceful resolution. Chearavanont, senior chairman of Charoen Pokphand Group Co, has appealed for the restoration of order, rule of law, and mutual prosperity. His plea comes as businesses face economic fallout from the months-long conflict between protesters and Beijing, with some local tycoons backing the administration and others, like Li Ka-shing, urging restraint on both sides.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start Tuesday with small gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks started Tuesday with small gains, recovering from the previous day's sell-off. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.14%, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices added 0.56% and 0.63%, respectively. The gains were attributed to Donald Trump's announcement that US-China trade talks would resume soon, which boosted investor confidence.

site_title: India's trade ministry recommends import tax hike on Malaysian refined palm oil
summary: India's trade ministry recommends increasing the tax on refined palm oil imports from Malaysia to 50% from 45% to curb cheaper purchases. This move aims to reduce the effective duty difference between crude palm oil and refined palm oil, which has led to a surge in Malaysian refined palm oil exports to India. The decision could provide a level-playing field to Indonesia and reduce imports of cheaper refined palm oil, impacting local refiners.

images.alt_text: India's trade ministry has recommended raising the tax on refined palm oil imports from Malaysia to 50 per cent from 45 per cent to curb cheaper purchases of the commodity, a government document said.

site_title: Papa John's preparing to appoint Arby's President Rob Lynch as its CEO
summary: Papa John's is set to appoint Arby's President Rob Lynch as its new CEO, replacing Steve Ritchie. Lynch, a fast-food industry veteran, will lead the struggling pizza maker as it faces slowing sales and revenue decline. Starboard Value, an activist shareholder, has invested $250 million in Papa John's since February and played a role in the management change. Lynch's appointment is seen as a turnaround attempt, following a series of shake-ups and efforts to improve performance.

site_title: AIA to transfer Brunei life insurance business to AIA Singapore
summary: AIA plans to transfer its life insurance business in Brunei to AIA Singapore Private Limited, with the proposed transfer expected to take effect on Jan 1, 2020. Existing policies will remain unchanged, and the new branch will be regulated by the Autoriti Monetari Brunei Darussalam. The transfer aims to enhance operational efficiencies and provide a streamlined approach in the region, allowing AIA to better serve customers.

site_title: Hong Kong protests fuel buyer interest in luxury Australia, NZ homes
summary: Hong Kong's anti-government protests have fueled increased interest in luxury Australian and New Zealand homes among wealthy buyers, with property agents and real estate data showing a significant spike in enquiries. Real estate agencies report a 50% increase in Hong Kong enquiries for Australian properties, while a 33% increase is noted for Melbourne-based Kay & Burton. The protests have created a sense of uncertainty, prompting investors to seek a safe haven, particularly in countries like Australia and New Zealand that offer residency-free property ownership.

site_title: Hotels have piled on the brands. In a downturn, that could be a problem
summary: Hotels have rapidly expanded their brand portfolios in recent years, but industry analysts worry that this may be unsustainable in a potential economic downturn. Major hotel companies have added numerous brands to differentiate themselves and attract younger travelers, but this can lead to over-saturation in a market, making it difficult to attract developers. The proliferation of digital booking platforms has also driven the brand arms race, as hotel companies can negotiate better terms with online travel agencies by offering a diverse range of options. Experts caution that hotel brands have a relatively low survival rate, with some suggesting that up to 50% may fail.

site_title: Warily, Saudi shops push boundaries on prayer-time shutdown
summary: In Saudi Arabia, some shops are pushing boundaries by staying open during prayer times, despite the government's decree allowing businesses to operate 24 hours for a fee. Retailers are cautiously testing the waters, with some paying no fee to stay open, while others risk being penalized if the religious police enforce the Islamic world's only mandatory prayer-time shutdown. The move is part of a sweeping reform drive by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman to project a business-friendly image, with potential benefits including increased worker productivity and business activity.

site_title: WhiteCoat partners Grab to boost digital healthcare delivery
summary: WhiteCoat, a digital healthcare provider, has partnered with Grab to enhance medication delivery services via GrabExpress. The collaboration aims to provide patients with timely medical attention, reducing the wait time from three hours to 90 minutes. WhiteCoat's telemedicine services allow users to video call general practitioners for medical attention. This partnership aligns with Grab's vision to support local tech companies in Singapore, enabling patients to receive prescribed medication quickly and receive better healthcare support.

site_title: Oil rises after Trump says China trade deal likely
summary: US President Donald Trump predicted a trade deal with China, calming global markets and causing oil prices to rise. Oil prices increased by 0.5% for Brent crude and 0.4% for US crude, reversing a three-day decline. The expected trade deal is seen as a positive development after the US-China trade conflict led to a 20% drop in oil prices in 2019.

site_title: Rare earth mining, textiles and ICT manufacturing seen as areas Vietnam can benefit from trade war
summary: Vietnam is poised to benefit from the US-China trade war, particularly in rare earth mining, textiles, and information and communications technology (ICT) manufacturing. The country's rare earth reserves and favorable business environment make it an attractive alternative to China, which currently holds a near-monopoly on the global supply of rare earth metals. Vietnam's textiles industry is also expected to see increased investment, as multinational firms diversify and maintain access to US markets. The ICT sector is also shifting its supply chain out of China, with Vietnam emerging as a major beneficiary, driven by its established electronics manufacturing capabilities and investment from companies like Samsung.

site_title: Liberia ex-central bank officials plead not guilty in graft scandal
summary: Five former Liberian central bank officials, including Charles Sirleaf, pleaded not guilty to charges of money laundering and "economic sabotage" related to the printing of $22.7 million in surplus cash between 2016 and 2018. The officials, who cannot account for the cash, have denied the allegations. Liberia's President George Weah vowed to tackle corruption when he took office in 2018, but protests have continued over graft, living standards, and inflation. An investigation by US agency Kroll Associates found failings in the process, but the exact fate of the money remains unclear.

site_title: Google parent's investing arm battles suspicion in profit quest
summary: Alphabet's private investment arm, CapitalG, has generated billions of dollars in gains in the last year and a half, with four of its portfolio companies going public and four being acquired. The success has raised questions about the company's strategy and influence over the technology industry. CapitalG has made a record nine "unicorn" investments, and its deals are scrutinized due to concerns over antitrust regulation. The company's independence from Google is emphasized, but some critics argue that its involvement with companies like Lyft could create conflicts of interest.

site_title: Hardware troubles slow profit growth for Australia's Wesfarmers
summary: Australian conglomerate Wesfarmers reported a 13.5% increase in annual profit to A$1.94 billion, driven by diversified operations. However, its hardware division Bunnings saw its slowest profit growth in 8 years, with same-store sales growth halving. The company's retail businesses, including Kmart and Target, also saw earnings fall, while its chemicals division remained strong. Wesfarmers has been exploring new growth opportunities, including acquisitions, to offset slowing growth in the Australian economy.

site_title: KFC to test meatless chicken at Georgia restaurant
summary: KFC is testing vegetarian, plant-based chicken at a restaurant in Smyrna, Georgia, in partnership with Beyond Meat. The product, dubbed "Beyond Fried Chicken," will be available as complimentary samples and for purchase on Tuesday. This test follows Burger King's debut of the Impossible Whopper, a meatless version of its signature burger. Feedback from the test will help KFC consider a national rollout of the meat-free chicken.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on US rallies, easing yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, driven by US President Donald Trump's upbeat comments on a possible China trade deal. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.02% or 207.05 points to 20,468.09. The yen declined against the dollar. This follows rallies on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. The market reaction suggests easing tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Japan closely watching yen moves 'with urgency': Aso
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso expressed concern over the recent yen spike, urging policymakers to monitor currency moves with "a sense of urgency." The yen's stability is crucial for Japan's export-reliant economy, and excessive volatility could undermine competitiveness. Aso declined to comment on specific exchange levels, but emphasized the importance of preventing the yen from strengthening, which could hurt Japan's economy.

site_title: Thai July factory output falls 3.23% y-o-y, slightly worse than forecast
summary: Thailand's manufacturing production index (MPI) in July dropped 3.23% from a year earlier, surpassing the forecast of 3.05% decline. The decline was attributed to lower production of cars, petroleum, and steel. This is slightly worse than the 5.3% contraction in June. Capacity utilisation was at 65.68% in July, down from June's revised 65.28%.

site_title: Singapore faces rising tide of bad debt with record bonds maturing
summary: Singapore's economy is facing a rising tide of bad debt due to US-China tensions and weak export data, prompting lenders and bond investors to prepare for potential defaults. A record S$12 billion of bonds in the Singapore dollar bond market are maturing next year, with sectors such as logistics and construction expected to be affected. Experts predict "more defaults" and increased business for debt restructuring firms as the government cuts its economic growth forecast to almost zero.

site_title: Asia: Trade hope helps markets bounce back from sell-off
summary: Asian markets rebounded from Monday's sell-off after US President Donald Trump said China-US trade talks would resume soon, despite his previous sharp changes in tone. Trump's comments, including a phone call with China, sparked a mix of optimism and caution among investors. Regional equities rose, with Shanghai, Tokyo, and Sydney up over 1%, while the yuan remained under pressure near an 11-year low. Analysts warn markets could flip at any time, driven by White House headlines, and caution that Trump's comments are too late to fuel a meaningful recovery.

site_title: CEO's buyout offer for Delong 'not fair but reasonable': IFA
summary: Delong Holdings' CEO Ding Liguo has relaunched a voluntary cash offer to take the company private at S$7 per share via his vehicle Best Grace Holdings. The offer, valued at S$771.3 million, has been deemed "not fair but reasonable" by PricewaterhouseCoopers Corporate Finance (PwCCF), the appointed IFA. Delong's independent directors have recommended shareholders accept the offer, citing the offer price is a premium to the closing price of S$6.87 and represents a significant discount to the net asset value per share. The offer closes on September 10.

site_title: Utico says has inked restructuring agreement with Hyflux
summary: Utico has signed a restructuring agreement with Hyflux, acquiring 88% of the debt-laden water treatment firm. The deal resolves creditors' and PNP investors' concerns, allowing for the revival of stalled projects. Utico will inject S$300 million in equity and provide a S$100 million shareholder loan. The agreement was reached after Hyflux engaged exclusively with Utico until August 26.

site_title: Trump says next G-7 summit likely to be at his golf club
summary: US President Donald Trump announced he may host the 2020 G-7 summit at his Trump National Doral Miami golf club, sparking criticism that he is profiteering from his presidency. Trump stated that his club's location, near Miami International Airport, and amenities make it an ideal venue. Critics, including transparency group CREW, accused him of using his administration to promote his struggling businesses, raising concerns about the constitution's ban on using his office for profit.

site_title: Trade war means US dairy is missing out on China's demand boom
summary: US dairy farmers are missing out on a demand boom in China due to the trade war, with exports dropping 54% in the first half of 2019. The trade dispute has made it difficult for the US to compete with rival suppliers like New Zealand and the European Union. The American dairy industry has been in decline, with Americans drinking 40% less milk than in 1975 and prices suffering a significant downturn. The US dairy industry's struggles are the latest blow to stalwarts like Dean Foods Co, whose shares have plummeted over 70% this year.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge up as Trump ratchets down trade war rhetoric
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% on Tuesday, following comments by US President Donald Trump that eased concerns over the Sino-US trade war. The S&P ASX 200 index climbed 24.8 points to 6,464.9. The previous day's 1.3% decline, largely due to the trade war, was reversed as investors returned to risk markets. The comments, while still hawkish, suggested some de-escalation in the trade war, prompting a positive response from the market.

site_title: Asean construction sector feeling effects of US-China trade war
summary: The US-China trade war is affecting the Asian construction sector, with varying impacts across countries. Vietnam and Indonesia are expected to outperform, driven by domestic growth and infrastructure investments. Vietnam's commercial property sector is expected to accelerate, while Indonesia's total construction is forecast to grow 11% in 2019. In contrast, trade-reliant Singapore's construction activity is expected to slow due to weakening economic prospects, but investment in health and education buildings may provide a bright spot. Other countries, such as the Philippines and Malaysia, are also investing heavily in infrastructure projects, with the Philippines committing $500 billion over four years.

images.alt_text: Singapore's construction sector faces increasing risks of a protracted slowdown in growth in the medium term, due to the poorer global economic outlook over the next few years, Fitch Solutions Macro Research said in a report on Monday.

site_title: China's July industrial profits swing to growth but outlook clouded
summary: China's industrial profits rebounded in July, rising 2.6% year-over-year to 512.7 billion yuan, driven by improvements in the petrochemical and auto sectors. However, the broader economic slowdown and US trade war are expected to weigh on the business outlook. Despite a 1.7% decline in January-July profits, the uptick in July is seen as a temporary boost. China's policymakers have rolled out growth measures, but analysts warn of a "flood-like stimulus" and a prolonged economic slowdown.

site_title: New IPOS entity to help Singapore firms take their intangible assets global
summary: Singapore's Intellectual Property Office (IPOS) has launched IPOS International, a new entity to support businesses in commercializing intangible assets and intellectual property globally. The entity aims to help Singaporean firms expand their IP presence worldwide. This move follows the launch of Singapore's first Skills Framework for IP, a world first, at the IP Week @ SG 2019 conference. The new entity will support businesses in developing and protecting their IP, enhancing Singapore's position as a hub for innovation and entrepreneurship.

site_title: G-7 pledges millions to fight Amazon fires
summary: The G-7 pledged $45 million to combat Amazon fires, with the US and Canada contributing $15 million and $20 million, respectively. The funds will be used to send firefighting planes to tackle the blazes in Brazil's Amazon basin. The G-7 leaders also agreed to support a reforestation plan to be unveiled in September, with Brazil and indigenous communities required to agree to the plan. The UN Secretary General emphasized the need for reforestation to preserve the Amazon, a "universal heritage essential for the world's well-being."

site_title: Odebrecht proposes to creditors to swap debt for equity instruments: statement
summary: Brazilian conglomerate Odebrecht SA has proposed to creditors a swap of their debt for equity instruments, giving them rights to receive proceeds from asset sales and future profits. The plan, filed with the court, has no explicit discount on the 51 billion reais (S$17.2 billion) debt being restructured, leaving it unclear how much creditors could receive or within what timeframe.

site_title: J&J to pay US$572m for opioid addiction crisis
summary: A US Oklahoma judge ordered Johnson & Johnson to pay $572 million in damages for its role in the state's opioid addiction crisis. The company was found to have contributed to a "public nuisance" through deceptive promotion of highly addictive prescription painkillers. J&J will fund an abatement plan for care for addicts and their families, and the company plans to appeal the decision. This ruling is a landmark case and may set the basis for potentially billions of dollars in settlements across the US.

site_title: English billionaire Ratcliffe's Ineos completes Nice takeover
summary: English billionaire Jim Ratcliffe's Ineos completed its takeover of French club Nice with a reported 100 million euro deal, pledging investment to establish the team as regular challengers in Ligue 1 and Europe. This marks Ratcliffe's addition to his sports portfolio, which already includes the former Sky cycling team and Swiss club Lausanne-Sport. The takeover was approved by the French Competition Authority last week, following a protracted process.

site_title: Mooncakes, trade war boosting China's demand for palm oil
summary: China has nearly tripled its palm oil imports from Malaysia to 265,045 tons between Aug. 1-25, amid a trade war with the US and the Mid-Autumn festival. This surge in demand is driven by lower supplies of soybean oil due to African swine fever and trade tensions. China may import a record 6.7 million tons of palm oil in the year from October. This increase could support Malaysian palm oil prices, but Indonesia may still dominate China's demand due to its larger market share and lower costs.

site_title: Australian arrested in China for 'espionage': foreign minister
summary: An Australian academic, Yang Hengjun, has been formally arrested in China on suspicion of "espionage". The 61-year-old, a pro-democracy activist, was detained in January after returning to China from the US. Australian Foreign Minister Marise Payne confirmed the arrest, which is likely to deepen tensions between the two countries. Yang had been held in Beijing for several months without charge. The development comes amid existing strained relations between Australia and China.

site_title: China's Baidu passes Google to become Amazon's top smart-speaker rival
summary: Baidu has surpassed Google to become the top smart-speaker rival, with 17.3% of the global smart speaker market share in the second quarter, according to research firm Canalys. Amazon remains the leader with 25% market share. Baidu's success is attributed to its focus on the fast-growing China market, while Amazon and Google have primarily targeted the US market. Experts warn that the escalating trade war between the US and China could impact the global smart speaker market, but the shift in market share indicates a growing competition between tech giants.

site_title: G-7 leaders back Hong Kong autonomy, call for calm
summary: G-7 leaders have backed Hong Kong's autonomy as outlined in the 1984 Sino-British agreement, calling for calm in the city amid ongoing protests over an extradition bill. The protests, which have lasted over two months, were seen as a threat to Hong Kong's autonomy. The G-7 reaffirmed the importance of the 1984 agreement and urged avoidance of violence. The statement was released after a meeting in Biarritz, France.

images.alt_text: G-7 leaders meeting in France on Monday backed Hong Kong's autonomy as laid out in a 1984 agreement between Britain and China and called for calm in the protest-hit city.

site_title: Bukit Panjang GCB up for auction with S$9m asking price
summary: A Good Class Bungalow (GCB) in Bukit Panjang, Singapore, is up for auction with an asking price of S$9 million. The freehold property at 7 Chestnut Crescent has a total land area of 9,232 square feet and is priced at around S$975 per square foot. The owner will put the property up for sale via auction next month.

site_title: Oil falls 1% as US-Iran optimism faces US-China trade deal hopes
summary: Oil prices fell 1% on Monday, with Brent crude losing 64 cents to settle at $58.70 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures settling 53 cents lower at $53.64 a barrel. The decline came after French President Emmanuel Macron hinted at a possible meeting between US and Iranian leaders to resolve a nuclear standoff, potentially leading to an increase in Iranian oil supply. Meanwhile, optimism surrounding a US-China trade deal also buoyed prices, with President Trump expressing hope for a deal after meeting with Chinese Vice-Premier Liu He.

images.alt_text: Oil prices fell 1 per cent on Monday on the outlook for increased supply of Iranian crude after France's president lifted hopes for a deal between Washington and Tehran, but losses were limited by optimism surrounding a US-China trade deal.

site_title: Air Canada's planned Transat acquisition requires additional scrutiny: minister
summary: Canada's Transport Minister Marc Garneau says Air Canada's planned acquisition of Transat requires additional scrutiny due to public interest concerns. The deal, worth C$720 million, would give Air Canada a 60% market share of select trans-Atlantic routes. A public interest assessment will be conducted, involving consultations with the air industry and public, and must be completed by May 2, 2020. Regulatory approval is expected, with analysts believing any proposed remedies can be managed, but investors are watching closely.

images.alt_text: Air Canada's planned acquisition of Transat AT raises issues of public interest and will require additional scrutiny, including the impact on airline competition, before it can be approved, Canada's transport minister said on Monday.

site_title: Scientists reproduce coral in lab, offering hope for reefs
summary: Scientists at the Florida Aquarium successfully reproduced coral in a lab setting for the first time, using induced spawning techniques. The reproduction of endangered Atlantic Pillar coral offers hope for saving the Florida Reef tract, which is deteriorating rapidly due to climate change and disease. By mimicking natural conditions, the team aims to reproduce healthy corals and repopulate reefs, potentially preventing extinction. This breakthrough is a significant step in conservation efforts, following previous success with Pacific corals at the Horniman Museum in London.

images.alt_text: A team of scientists in the US have managed to reproduce coral in a lab setting for the first time ever, an encouraging step in the race to save "America's Great Barrier Reef" off the coast of Florida.

site_title: S-Reits' robust yields in low-rate environment keep investors hooked
summary: S-Reits in Singapore have maintained their appeal despite recent market volatility, with investors drawn to their robust yields in a low-rate environment. Analysts attribute this to the 'lower-for-longer' interest rate scenario, which benefits the asset class. This resilience is evident in new contract signings and green loan approvals for S-Reits, showcasing the sector's continued growth and expansion. The robust performance of S-Reits suggests investors will remain hooked on the asset class.

site_title: Why the euro zone and G7 may be jolted by new Italian instability
summary: Italy's political parties have until August 28 to form a new government after the collapse of the previous administration. The country's chronic instability poses a threat to the euro zone, given its significant debt load and under-performing banking sector. A new government's ability to secure structural reforms is uncertain, raising concerns of further political paralysis. Potential alliances between the far-right League and anti-establishment Five Star Movement could lead to new domestic spending and policy shifts on the European Union, potentially including a re-evaluation of Italy's relationship with Russia.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Tuesday's open; STI up 0.23% to 3,072.49
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.23% to 3,072.49 at Tuesday's open, driven by US President Donald Trump's optimistic comments on resuming trade talks with China. Gainers outnumbered losers 73 to 53, with ESR-Reit, TEE International, and Singtel advancing 2%, 5%, and 0.3% respectively. Total trading volume was 42.5 million securities worth S$137.7 million.

site_title: US: Wall Street rises as Trump holds out China trade hope
summary: US stocks rose on Monday, recovering some losses from the previous week, driven by President Donald Trump's comments on a potential China trade deal. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 1.0%, the S&P 500 gained 1.1%, and the Nasdaq jumped 1.3%. Despite the gains, all three indexes are still on track to close the month in the red. Trade-exposed companies, such as Apple, saw gains, while shares in Celgene and Amgen rose after a merger announcement.

site_title: Rare earths miner Lynas looks to soothe tensions in Malaysia
summary: Rare earths miner Lynas Corp is assessing options for an initial processing plant in Australia to address concerns in Malaysia about radioactive waste. The plant will remove low-level radioactivity from materials shipped to Malaysia for separation into elements used in products like fighter jets and wind farms. Lynas has four years to build the plant, which is a requirement to continue shipping to Malaysia. The move aims to soothe tensions between the company and the Malaysian government.

site_title: US city to replace lead pipes that sparked water crisis
summary: US officials have announced a $120 million plan to replace approximately 18,000 lead pipes in Newark, New Jersey, amid a growing water crisis. The crisis began after the Environmental Protection Agency found high lead levels in the city's water supply, prompting residents to drink only bottled water. The plan, which will be completed over 24-30 months, aims to defuse the crisis and avoid social injustice, drawing comparisons to the Flint, Michigan water crisis. The city will not charge residents for the pipe replacements.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Coffee with Nespresso
summary: Claressa Monteiro of Workday Afternoon on MoneyFM 89.3 discussed coffee culture in Singapore with Peilin Lee, marketing manager of Nespresso Singapore. They talked about the Nespresso Professional range tailored for working environments and the company's efforts towards sustainability. The conversation highlighted the importance of coffee in the workplace and how Nespresso aims to make a positive impact on the environment.

site_title: Nissan's Infiniti names new design chief as another non-Japanese exec quits
summary: Infiniti, Nissan's premium brand, has named Taisuke Nakamura as its new design chief, replacing Karim Habib who resigned after just two years in the role. This move follows other non-Japanese senior executives leaving Nissan, including the ouster of chairman Carlos Ghosn. The changes come as Nissan continues to navigate its post-Ghosn era.

site_title: Trump not considering US tariffs on Japanese autos 'at this moment'
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that the US will not impose new tariffs on Japanese autos 'at this moment' amid ongoing trade negotiations. A preliminary deal, announced by Trump and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, includes concessions from Japan on agriculture and maintains US tariffs on autos. The agreement aims to boost US agricultural exports to Japan by up to $7 billion and provide high standards for digital trade. However, the deal does not address the US$56 billion automotive trade deficit with Japan, with industry groups calling for more reciprocal market access and addressing non-tariff barriers.

site_title: Volkswagen ex-boss Piech has died: wife
summary: Ferdinand Piech, the former chairman of Volkswagen, has died at 82, according to his wife Ursula. Piech led VW from 1993 to 2002 and again from 2002 to 2015, credited with the company's rise from bankruptcy to global status. He was known for his autocratic management style and was at the center of the "dieselgate" scandal, which involved fitting millions of cars with devices to cheat emissions tests. Piech died suddenly and unexpectedly at a hospital in Rosenheim, Bavaria, on August 25, 2019.

site_title: Argentine court rejects Kirchner bid to throw out corruption case
summary: An Argentine court rejected a request by former president Cristina Kirchner's lawyers to throw out a corruption case, accusing her of favoring companies in awarding 52 public works contracts worth $1.67 billion. The trial, which opened in May, will continue on September 2. Kirchner's defense team argued that there was no overcharging in the assessed works contracts, but the court decided to proceed with the trial. This is one of 12 corruption cases Kirchner faces, and she also faces five requests for pre-trial detention.

images.alt_text: An Argentine court rejected a request from lawyers to throw out a corruption case against former president and current vice-presidential candidate Cristina Kirchner.

site_title: Europe: Shares steady as trade tensions ease; Italy outperforms
summary: European shares stabilized on Monday as trade tensions between the US and China eased, with the Stoxx 600 index ending flat. Italian stocks rose 1% as the opposition parties in Rome moved closer to forming a coalition government. Despite a decline in business sentiment, economists expect a trade deal between China and the US by the end of the year, with US President Donald Trump seeking a deal ahead of elections.

site_title: British PM Johnson says prepared to take Brexit talks down to last minute
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has stated he is prepared to take Brexit talks with the EU down to the last minute before the October 31 exit deadline. Johnson has 68 days to convince the EU to give him a new Brexit deal, but neither side is willing to compromise on contentious issues. If a deal cannot be reached, Johnson plans to leave the EU without a deal, despite concerns it could lead to food shortages and border disruption.

site_title: Court approves OUE C-Reit, H-Trust merger; updated timetable released
summary: The Singaporean court has approved the merger of OUE Commercial Real Estate Investment Trust (C-Reit) and OUE Hospitality Trust (H-Trust) through a trust scheme of arrangement. The updated timetable has been released, with the books closure date set for September 3 and the trust scheme effective on September 4. Trading for H-Trust stapled securities will be suspended from September 2, with the last day of trading on August 30. The merger will see C-Reit acquire H-Trust for 4.075 Singapore cents in cash and 1.3583 new C-Reit units per stapled security.

site_title: Singapore exports to Turkmenistan see five-fold rise from 2016
summary: Singapore has seen a five-fold increase in exports to Turkmenistan since 2016, with the country exploring cooperation in the chemicals and private education sectors. Senior Minister Koh Poh Koon stated that further trade growth is possible. The announcement came during a two-day state visit by Turkmenistan President Gurbanguly Berdimuhammedow, which included a business forum.

site_title: Stocks to watch: StarHub, OUE C-Reit, OUE H-Trust, Sunpower, ISEC Healthcare
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several companies saw significant developments on Tuesday, August 27, 2019. StarHub signed a memorandum of understanding with Chinese ISPs to co-build data links between Singapore and Chongqing. OUE C-Reit and OUE H-Trust announced a proposed merger, with a new timetable and expected completion on September 4. Sunpower Group secured 65.5 million yuan in manufacturing and services contracts. ISEC Healthcare agreed to a mandatory general offer by Aier Eye International, which will trigger a buyout of ISEC shares. Aspen Holdings invested RM5 million in online food delivery platform Delivereat.

site_title: Meituan posts surprise profit after pipping Alibaba in food
summary: Meituan, a Chinese internet services giant, posted its first quarterly profit, exceeding analysts' expectations with a net income of 877.4 million yuan. Revenue rose 51% to 22.7 billion yuan, driven by gains from one-time investments. Meituan has gained market share from rivals, including Alibaba, and has become China's third-largest publicly traded tech company, overtaking Baidu and JD.com in capitalization. Founder Wang Xing is focusing on the company's core dining business and expanding up the value chain, envisioning a super-app modelled on WeChat.

site_title: Angel Has Fallen rises to No 1 with US$21 million debut
summary: Angel Has Fallen, the third installment in the action franchise, debuted with a strong US$21.25 million in its opening weekend, surpassing expectations and topping the domestic box office charts. The film, starring Gerard Butler, outperformed last weekend's comedy Good Boys, which generated US$11.75 million. This marks the strongest opening weekend for the franchise, nearly matching its predecessor London Has Fallen's US$21.2 million debut in 2016.

site_title: The rise of Industry 4.0 lays out opportunities for South-east Asian manufacturers
summary: Industry 4.0, the fourth industrial revolution, offers opportunities for South-east Asian manufacturers to boost productivity and efficiency, with potential gains of $294 billion to $853 billion. However, many Asean businesses have been slow to adopt these technologies, with only 13% of business leaders saying their companies have begun transforming to Industry 4.0. By embracing automation and smart machines, businesses can reduce production waste, streamline processes, and increase efficiency, transforming the manufacturing sector in the region.

images.alt_text: Industry 4.0, which incorporates the use of robots and robotic tools to capture, exchange and interpret crucial data in real time, offers South-east Asia a chance to transform its manufacturing sector.

site_title: Thailand aims to be S-E Asia's middleman in trading power
summary: Thailand aims to become the middleman in trading power in South-East Asia by creating an electricity super-grid. The country plans to triple the amount of electricity from Laos it resells to Malaysia and upgrade infrastructure across the region. This move is part of Thailand's efforts to make its power system cleaner, cheaper, and more efficient. The plan could increase energy security and opportunities to develop renewable resources, with benefits including additional revenue and lower electricity costs.

site_title: Singapore is right to frame climate change as a national-security issue
summary: Singapore is framing climate change as a national-security issue due to the existential threat it poses. The city-state aims to adapt to climate change through long-term planning, financing, and community involvement. Rising sea levels and extreme weather events threaten Singapore's economy and way of life. The government has already invested in climate-resilient infrastructure, but more needs to be done to address the issue. Singapore can learn from other vulnerable cities like New York, which is incorporating resilience planning into its urban environment. A multifunctional approach, involving communities and citizens, is essential for effective climate change adaptation.

site_title: Cityneon bags investment from Singapore's EDBI
summary: Cityneon Holdings, an experience entertainment firm, has secured a strategic investment from EDBI, the investment arm of the Singapore Economic Development Board. EDBI now holds a 2.3% minority stake in Cityneon, which will aid the company's expansion into new markets. The investment will also leverage EDBI's expertise in emerging technologies to develop new innovations in experience entertainment. Cityneon plans to expand its headquarters in Singapore and partner with global movie studios to create exclusive experiences.

images.alt_text: "Today, about 90 per cent of the group's profits are derived from outside of Singapore. We intend to step up our pace of expansion," says Cityneon's Mr Tan.

site_title: China to set floor on mortgage rates to curb housing risks
summary: China's central bank will set a floor on mortgage rates, effective from October 8, to curb housing risks. Banks will base mortgage loans on the new loan prime rate (LPR), with interest rates for first-time home buyers set at or above the LPR, and for second-time buyers, at or above the LPR plus 60 basis points. The goal is to keep individual mortgage rates stable and safeguard the rights of borrowers and lenders. This move follows concerns over high house prices and their impact on the economy.

site_title: Yuan, equities take a hit as Sino-US trade war escalates sharply
summary: The yuan fell to an 11-year low against the US dollar as the Sino-US trade war escalated, with China's currency sliding 0.7% in early trading before recovering slightly after US President Donald Trump said he believed Beijing wanted to make a trade deal. The yuan's depreciation is seen as a cushion against US tariffs, and experts expect further depreciation if controlled. The Sino-US trade war has intensified with Washington and Beijing raising tariffs on each other's imports, fuelling global economic tensions and warnings of a worldwide downturn.

site_title: Sygnum, SEBA Crypto clinch Swiss banking licences
summary: Sygnum and SEBA Crypto, two Singapore and Switzerland-focused startups, have secured conditional banking and securities dealers' licences in Switzerland. Sygnum, which tokenises assets, aims to onboard institutional investors and later develop bank-to-bank technology solutions. SEBA Crypto plans to launch with partner Julius Baer in early October 2019. The licences, issued by Finma, are the first to pure-play blockchain service providers in Switzerland, marking a significant milestone for the digital asset economy.

site_title: Quarter of China's sportswear factories idled due to trade war: Nike rival
summary: A quarter of China's sportswear factories are idle due to the ongoing trade war, with global brands such as Nike and Adidas shifting sourcing overseas. Factories are offering discounts to companies like Nike rival Xtep International Holdings Ltd to use their dormant production lines. The trade war is forcing Chinese manufacturers to adapt, with some seeing opportunities in the domestic market. Despite growing demand, local sportswear brands still trail international brands, but may gain ground as younger Chinese consumers increasingly favor local brands.

site_title: Aier Eye to make pre-conditional offer for ISEC Healthcare shares
summary: Aier Eye International, a subsidiary of Aier Eye Hospital Group, has agreed to buy approximately 186.3 million ISEC Healthcare shares at S$0.36 each in a conditional sale and purchase agreement. The deal, valued at S$67.1 million, will trigger a mandatory general offer for the remaining shares at the same price. The offer aims to address ISEC Healthcare's low trading liquidity and will result in Aier Eye International owning 35% of the company's total shares.

site_title: Harnessing data starts with a data management framework
summary: A growing amount of data is available to companies, but effective data management is crucial for harnessing its value. Many companies, especially smaller or traditional ones, underestimate the amount of digital data they rely on, believing their processes are paper-based. A good data management framework is essential, involving mapping data, establishing a data management policy, and optimizing data use. It also requires managing data risks, such as cyber security and data loss, and embedding data management into the corporate culture. A well-established framework can provide unrivalled insights, allow faster responses, and propel businesses forward.

images.alt_text: There are riches to be gained if one harnesses data well; the Internet is filled with stories of companies that have reduced inventory holding costs or achieved increased sales bundling with smart data management and analytics.

site_title: Singapore July factory output beats forecasts, technical recession may be averted
summary: Singapore's factory output beat forecasts in July, increasing 3.6% on a seasonally adjusted month-on-month basis, with the electronics sector leading the gain. Despite the improvement, economists caution that it's too early to hail a manufacturing turnaround, as the US-China trade war intensifies. The stronger-than-expected numbers may save Singapore from a technical recession in the third quarter, but the Monetary Authority of Singapore is still expected to ease monetary policy in October.

site_title: Vonovia expects Berlin's rent cap to cut its 2020 revenue by 10%
summary: Vonovia SE, Germany's largest landlord, expects a 10% revenue cut in 2020 due to a proposed rent cap in Berlin, estimated at 25 million euros. The company plans to redirect funds from Berlin property modernization to other regions and believes the legislation is unconstitutional. Vonovia remains committed to its guidance for 2019 and will reassess its strategy after the rent cap takes effect.

site_title: Darco to give up solar energy, focus on core businesses
summary: DARCO Water Technologies announced it will focus on core businesses in environmental systems and water management services, abandoning its solar energy investment. The decision comes after the group's previous CEO and founder, Thye Kim Meng, spearheaded plans to venture into the solar power industry. DARCO had relaunched itself two years ago following an embezzlement scandal. The company will now concentrate on its traditional areas, shifting away from its recent foray into solar energy.

site_title: The big gamble not to follow Fed
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell signaled potential US interest rate cuts, but Asian central banks are already relaxing monetary policy, cutting rates in countries such as India, Malaysia, and Indonesia. This divergence from the Fed's moves is due to Asia's willingness to gamble on slowing down to fight a trade slowdown, despite risks to currency and market volatility. The International Monetary Fund has trimmed global growth forecasts, and continued chaos from Washington may lead to further rate cuts, accelerating a transition from dollar dominance. Asian central banks are charting their own course, influenced less by the Fed.

site_title: Businesses should keep all avenues of funding open
summary: Businesses in the growth phase of a small to medium-sized enterprise often face challenges in obtaining financing due to disproportionate capital requirements and limited balance sheet size. To address this, companies may choose to reinvest profits, partner with external investors, or seek bank loans. However, each option has its drawbacks, and there is no ideal mix of debt and equity. The best approach is to keep all avenues of funding open, ensuring flexibility to rebalance financing according to business needs and life cycle. This allows companies to adapt to changing circumstances and capitalize on opportunities.

site_title: A company's shareholder is still the stakeholder that rules them all
summary: A US-based Business Roundtable recently changed its definition of a corporation's purpose to include stakeholders beyond shareholders, elevating customers, employees, suppliers, and communities to the same level. While this shift is welcome, it overlooks the shareholder as the ultimate stakeholder who decides company direction and resource allocation. Shareholders' priorities often conflict with long-term sustainability, making it challenging to develop a culture of stewardship. To make progress, investors must prioritize long-term sustainability, rein in CEO compensation, and demand responsible management practices.

site_title: SIA bans some models of 15-inch MacBook Pro from flights
summary: Singapore Airlines has banned some models of 15-inch MacBook Pro laptops from its flights due to an Apple recall of older generation devices. The recall, prompted by the European Union Aviation Safety Agency and US Federal Aviation Administration, alerts airlines of the risk of overheating batteries. Affected units, sold between 2015 and 2017, can be identified by their product serial numbers. Passengers are advised to check Apple's battery recall programme for details on replacement options. Other airlines, including Thai Airways, have also banned the affected laptops from their flights.

site_title: Aussie building materials maker Boral warns of bigger profit decline
summary: Australia's largest building materials maker Boral Ltd reported a 7% decline in underlying net profit to A$440.1 million for the year to end-June, below analyst forecasts. The company attributed the decline to a housing construction slump, which has impacted its US division. Boral expects a further 5-15% profit decline in 2020 due to a lag between the drop-off in home builds and infrastructure projects. The company plans to offset the shortfall with infrastructure and industrial building work, and shares fell 20% amid a broader market sell-off.

site_title: Gold rallies towards US$1,600 as US-China trade war bites
summary: Gold prices surged to a 6-year high, reaching US$1,565 an ounce, amid the escalating US-China trade war, boosting demand for the traditional safe-haven asset. The trade tensions have hurt global growth and boosted risk aversion, driving up prices by over 20% this year. Analysts predict further price gains, citing the Fed's rate-cutting plans and currency depreciation as factors driving investors towards gold.

site_title: Shanghai Henlius Biotech gauging demand for US$600m HK IPO
summary: Shanghai Henlius Biotech Inc, a unit of Fosun group, is gauging investor demand for a US$600 million initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong. The offering would be the city's first since mid-July, amid a summer drought of IPOs. The company, an unprofitable biopharmaceutical firm, plans to use the funds for clinical trials and general corporate purposes. This could mark the end of Hong Kong's summer IPO drought, which has been hurt by ongoing protests and a trade war between China and the US.

site_title: Chinese AI start-up Megvii files for HK IPO of at least US$500m
summary: Chinese AI start-up Megvii Technology Ltd, backed by Alibaba, has filed for an initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong targeting proceeds of at least US$500 million. The IPO comes amid Hong Kong's recession and anti-government protests, but Megvii expects the unrest to ease later this year. The company, which provides facial recognition and AI technology to governments and companies, may raise up to US$1 billion in the IPO. Megvii will use the funds for research and development, marketing, and global expansion.

site_title: British Airways riles customers by cancelling scores of flights, some by mistake
summary: British Airways faced widespread criticism after initially cancelling scores of flights in September due to a planned pilots' strike, only to later correct the mistake, stating it was an "error". The airline received 38,000 calls and 33,000 tweets within the first 24 hours, prompting an increase in customer service staff. The incident highlighted the airline's handling of customer communication, with many expressing frustration over the initial cancellation announcement.

site_title: Battered STI counters spur talk of shuffle in next index review
summary: Singapore's blue chip stocks plummeted on Monday, with 28 out of 30 components on the ST Index ending in the red due to escalating US-China trade tensions. Key counters like Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPH Trust), Singapore Airlines (SIA), and Sembcorp Industries hit multi-year lows. Analysts expect the market to remain weak, with HPH Trust seen as a prime candidate to be dropped from the STI index due to its low market cap and liquidity. Dairy Farm International and SIA are also vulnerable to trade-related issues, while Sembcorp Industries faces challenges in its operations.

site_title: From voodoo economics to evil-eye economics
summary: US President Donald Trump's economic policies have failed to deliver predicted results, despite his claims of success. His tax cuts, in particular, have been criticized for their lack of impact, with recent data revisions downgrading GDP and employment growth estimates. Trump has shifted blame to various parties, including the Federal Reserve, Democrats, and his own opponents, labeling it "evil-eye economics." With no clear Plan B, Trump may not need to implement effective policy, relying on his perceived divine right to lead the economy.

site_title: Credit Suisse to shift focus from branches to digital banking by end-2021
summary: Credit Suisse plans to shift its focus from physical branches to digital banking by the end of 2021, investing hundreds of millions of francs in digital services. This move comes as European banks continue to close branches and cut jobs due to declining brick-and-mortar costs. The bank's decision aims to save on costs while maintaining competitiveness in the market.

site_title: Trump moves to cool tensions over China, Iran
summary: US President Donald Trump offered an olive branch to China, saying China was ready to negotiate and diffusing tensions over trade, which had spooked financial markets. Trump also eased tensions with Iran, indicating openness to discussions on a nuclear deal and saying he was not looking for regime change. The G7 summit in Biarritz, France, resulted in a deal to provide $20 million in emergency help to Brazil and its neighbors to stop the Amazon forest fires, and a compromise agreement on France's digital tax.

site_title: Going beyond sharp suits
summary: Benjamin Barker, a Singapore-based menswear label, is transforming into a global lifestyle brand under CEO Nelson Yap's vision. The company has already made significant strides in retail, F&B, and hospitality, with plans to harness technology and novel franchising models to expand globally. Benjamin Barker has 10 outlets across Singapore and is stocking its products at international retailers abroad. The brand is focusing on franchising as its main mode of internationalization, with successful partnerships in Australia and Cambodia. Yap aims to take the brand global, with a boutique hotel being a long-term goal, while adapting to challenges such as rising retail rents and manpower shortages.

site_title: Asia markets suffer sell-offs on trade row
summary: Asian markets experienced a sell-off on Monday, driven by escalating US-China trade tensions, which led to a 1.5% decline in Singapore's Straits Times Index to close at 3,065.33. The Hang Seng Index fell 1.9% to 25,680.33, while other markets in Australia, China, Hong Kong, Japan, Malaysia, and South Korea also suffered sharp declines. Despite some recovery, the sell-offs marked the local benchmark's first loss of the year. The US and China are reportedly engaging in trade talks, with US President Donald Trump saying Beijing called Washington to restart negotiations.

site_title: China firms have unseen foreign debt maturing fast
summary: China's foreign debt is estimated to be around $2 trillion in official data, but approximately $650 billion more, totaling $2.65 trillion, held by subsidiaries overseas. This debt is expected to mature, with $63 billion due in the first half of 2020, potentially straining the country's currency reserves. China's foreign currency reserves, currently $3.1 trillion, are considered insufficient to cover the risks, and the yuan's value has already dropped below 7 per dollar amid a trade war with the US. Authorities must enforce capital controls to mitigate the risk of a rapid decline in foreign-currency reserves.

site_title: StarHub signs MOU to co-build data links with top China service providers
summary: StarHub has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with China Mobile, China Unicom, and China Telecom to co-build data links between Singapore and Chongqing, providing Singapore companies operating in Chongqing with direct data connectivity. The initiative will offer robust, fast, and competitively priced data connectivity, supporting increasing China-Singapore trade. This is StarHub's first direct collaboration with China's major ISPs, leveraging its five submarine cable systems to support the collaboration.

site_title: Telcos will do well to deepen engagement with SMEs in good times or bad
summary: Singapore telcos have made headway in the small and medium-sized enterprises (SME) space, with Singtel and DBS' 99%SME campaign launch in 2015 and participation in the S$80 million SMEs Go Digital scheme. Despite a cooling economy, the SME segment remains a deep pool for companies offering business solutions and services. Telcos have supported over 8,000 SMEs in their digitalisation journey, and the government is targeting newly formed businesses with the "Start Digital" effort. A tie-up between Singtel and OCBC for a digital bank licence is also expected to increase their presence in the SME market.

site_title: Auction sales of Australian homes hit two-year high
summary: Auction sales of Australian homes have reached a two-year high, marking the end of a long downturn in the housing market. This uptick is expected to be a boon for Australia's struggling economy and the construction sector, which has seen a decline in new home approvals. The gains in cities such as Sydney and Melbourne are the third consecutive month of increases, indicating a recovery in the housing market.

site_title: Engage with stakeholders in distressed times
summary: Volatility in financial markets has been particularly challenging for investors over the past six months, exacerbated by Brexit, a struggling offshore marine sector, and the US-China trade war. The Singapore government has revised its growth outlook downward, and companies are experiencing squeezed profits. Stakeholders, including corporate debt and equity holders, are also feeling the economic anxiety. As uncertainty grows, companies must prepare to reach out to stakeholders and navigate these uncertain times. The situation is expected to continue with China's GDP growth set to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Silverlake Axis reported a 58.2% year-on-year growth in core net profit to RM57.4 million (S$19 million) in Q4 FY2019, driven by 30.1% topline growth. The company expects to benefit from the rise in digital initiatives among banks and further consolidation in developing countries. However, project-related revenue growth is expected to soften in Q2 FY2020 and decelerate to 5.5% y-o-y in FY2020. Analysts, including GS-CIMB, maintain a "hold" call on the company.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks tumble on trade worries
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.91% on Monday due to escalating US-China trade tensions and violent police-protester clashes in the city. The Hang Seng Index dropped 499 points to 25,680.33, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.17% to 2,863.57. The US and China introduced fresh tariffs, causing investors to sell their shares. The decline was attributed to concerns over the ongoing trade war and its impact on the global economy.

site_title: Yuan falls to 11-year low as trade war rattles investors
summary: The Chinese yuan fell to an 11-year low in the onshore market and a record low offshore after the latest US-China trade war escalation. The yuan slid to 7.1500 per dollar in the onshore market and 7.187 yuan in the offshore market, before recovering after US President Trump's comments. The US dollar rebounded against other currencies, while the Japanese yen, considered a safe-haven, fell 0.5%. Market sentiment remains uncertain, with analysts predicting a lower chance of a trade truce and possible yuan depreciation.

site_title: Australian PM says UK's Johnson convinced him he can deliver Brexit
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison stated that after meeting with UK counterpart Boris Johnson, he is convinced Johnson can deliver Brexit. Morrison also expressed hope for a trade deal with Britain, suggesting it could be completed in under a year, but emphasized the need for an agreement that works for both sides.

site_title: WeWork rival IWG mulls over spinoff for US business: report
summary: IWG, a UK-based shared office provider, is planning to spin off its US business into a separately listed company in New York, according to a report. The move, led by CEO Mark Dixon, could value the US operations at up to $3.7 billion. IWG's US business generates 41% of its revenue, with the company owning multiple office brands including Regus. The move aims to rival WeWork, which is valued at $47 billion and has a larger global space. The planned spinoff is expected to be among the year's biggest initial share sales.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Meanwhile, Grab's earnings growth is expected to slow in H2, prompting CGS-I to downgrade the stock to 'hold'. OCBC CEO Helen Wong is set to retire, with Tan Teck Long named as her successor. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay increased by 30.5% to S$3.1 million. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Tesla marked its formal entry into India with a Mumbai launch event. Analysts are optimistic about SGX earnings, raising target prices due to volatility.

site_title: On a smart journey
summary: Fong's Engineering & Manufacturing Pte Ltd, a Singapore-based company, is a leading manufacturer of surgical robotics products. The company, founded by Jeremy Fong, produces advanced medical and surgical solutions, including flexible endoscopy and multi-port robotic systems. Fong's aims to stay ahead in the Industry 4.0 era with its innovative solutions, positioning itself as a key player in the medical robotics market.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won slide on trade war fears, safe-haven demand
summary: South Korean stocks plummeted 1.64% on Monday, mirroring broader Asia's decline due to escalating US-China trade tensions. The won fell 0.4% and benchmark bond yields slipped as investors sought safe-haven assets. Chinese Vice Premier Liu He expressed willingness to resolve trade disputes through calm negotiations. The Kospi index has fallen 6.11% this year, its largest decline since August 5.

site_title: Turnaround may be tricky for Virgin Australia CEO
summary: Virgin Australia Holdings' new CEO Paul Scurrah faces pressure to present a strategic plan amid the airline's seventh consecutive annual loss and $1.2 billion in red ink over six years. Shareholders are expected to question his options, including cost-cutting, restructuring, rebranding Tigerair Australia, ending unprofitable flights to Hong Kong, and tightening control over the loyalty division. With shares trading near all-time lows, Scurrah's room for manoeuvre is limited, and his decisions may determine the airline's future.

site_title: Spanish beer isn't flowing and Brexit is part of the problem
summary: Spanish tourist hotspots are experiencing a decline in beer sales due to the decline of the British pound, which affects British travelers' spending power. The pound has dropped 16% since the 2016 Brexit vote, leading to a 5.3% decrease in British visitors to Spain this summer. This reduction, combined with cheaper competition from destinations like Turkey and Tunisia, is resulting in slower growth in beer consumption and tourism. The decline is not only affecting beer sales but also the entire tourism industry, which accounts for nearly 12% of Spain's economy.

site_title: Macron says deal struck with US on taxing tech giants
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron and US President Donald Trump have reached a deal to end a tax dispute, with Macron stating that the agreement is "very good." The deal follows Trump's threat to impose tariffs on French wine imports in response to France's planned tax on some tech giants. The agreement marks a resolution to the feud, allowing the two nations to move forward.

site_title: GrabFood launches 'Hawker Picks' services, offering dishes from popular stalls
summary: GrabFood has launched its 'Hawker Picks' service in Singapore, allowing users to order food from popular hawker stalls like Arcade Fish Soup and A Noodle Story through the app. The service uses 'Hawker Hubs' to pre-order dishes, which are then consolidated and delivered within four hours of collection from the stalls. The company follows food safety guidelines and has obtained international certification for the model, which is considered an "industry first". The service aims to help consumers beat long queues at popular stalls and expand their reach.

site_title: The anatomy of the coming recession
summary: US-China trade and technology disputes, as well as global oil supply issues, are triggering potential supply shocks that could lead to a global recession by 2020. These supply shocks are driven by political factors and are not amenable to traditional economic policies. The US-China trade war, escalating trade tensions, and a cold war over technology are among the concerns. The global economy faces significant risks, with no clear solution to mitigate these issues in the medium-term.

site_title: KIT unit Basslink's undersea cable out of service until October
summary: The Basslink undersea electricity cable, operated by Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT), will be offline until mid-October due to a failure in a low voltage metallic return cable. The outage affects the interconnector cable linking Victoria and Tasmania's electricity grids, but the telecoms cable providing broadband services continues to operate. KIT has notified the Australian Energy Market Operator and will update the market with any changes to the return-to-service date. The outage is not expected to have a material financial impact on KIT's net tangible asset per unit and distribution per unit for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2019.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 8.8 points to 1,600.53. Volume reached 2.2 billion lots worth RM1.8 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 656 to 216.

site_title: Digging deeper for social media insights
summary: Professor Lim Ee Peng from SMU's School of Information Systems has developed new models for analyzing social media data, enabling organizations to analyze small, large, and very large data to better engage target audiences and enhance marketing efforts. The models can determine geolocation of social media users based on their activity, create accurate user profiles, and select suitable social media influencers for marketing campaigns. The research also addresses the challenge of analyzing very large data by developing solutions that don't require human-labeled data, achieving accuracy levels sufficient for real-world applications.

site_title: Sunpower secures 65.5m yuan contract from JV company of repeat customers
summary: Sunpower Group secured 65.5 million yuan (S$12.7 million) in contracts with PSS Netherlands BV, a joint venture of three repeat customers, to supply heat exchangers for a Thai oil refinery's environmental project. The contracts, valued at 2020 delivery, are expected to positively impact the company's financial performance for FY2019 and FY2020. This is part of Sunpower's focus on expanding into anti-pollution investment projects, or green investments, generating long-term value through recurring income and cash flows.

site_title: Tokenisation startups Sygnum, SEBA clinch conditional Swiss banking, securities licences
summary: Swiss-focused tokenisation startups Sygnum and SEBA have secured conditional banking and securities dealer's licences from Switzerland's Financial Market Supervisory Authority (Finma). Sygnum, which tokenises assets, will become the first pure-play blockchain service provider to receive such a licence. The licences, which were awarded after fulfilling secondary criteria, will allow Sygnum and SEBA to operate in Switzerland. Sygnum plans to onboard customers once the licence is effective, while SEBA aims to launch with partner Julius Baer in early October 2019.

site_title: US: Stocks rally as Trump claims China wants to talk trade
summary: US stocks rose on Monday, erasing some of the prior week's losses, after President Trump stated that China wants to resume trade negotiations. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.8%, the S&P 500 rose 0.7%, and the Nasdaq increased 0.9%. However, Chinese officials disputed the claim, leaving investors uncertain about the trade war's trajectory. The news boosted individual stocks, including Amgen, which agreed to acquire Celgene's psoriasis drug for $13.4 billion.

site_title: Gold pares gains as Trump ratchets down China trade-war tension
summary: US President Donald Trump announced China's willingness to resume trade talks, easing demand for gold as a haven. Gold futures rose 0.1% to $1,539.60 an ounce, after surging 1.8% earlier, before paring gains. The metal has surged this year due to the trade fight's impact on the economic outlook, boosting odds of US rate cuts from the Federal Reserve. Analysts predict gold will extend gains as the US-China standoff harms growth and invites central-bank easing. Gold prices may reach $1,600 within three months, according to UBS Group AG.

site_title: Aspen (Group) Holdings unit invests in food delivery platform Delivereat
summary: Aspen (Group) Holdings' subsidiary, Aspen Vision All, invests RM5 million in online food delivery platform Delivereat, acquiring 138,750 convertible preference shares. The investment is part of Aspen's strategy to diversify its business and mitigate risks. Delivereat, founded in 2012, has partnerships with over 1,000 restaurants and delivers various items, including groceries and documents. The investment does not change Aspen's business risk profile, but if it does, shareholder approval will be sought.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes down more than 2% on trade fears
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index plummeted 2.17% to 20,261.04, while the Topix index fell 1.61% to 1,478.03, amid escalating US-China trade tensions. The yen surged against the dollar, hitting its highest level since November 2016, after US President Donald Trump announced tariffs on Chinese imports. Japanese exporters, such as Toyota and Nissan, led the decline, while the dollar dropped to 105.24 yen. Trading is expected to remain sensitive for the rest of the week.

site_title: Apple's US$44b drop shows growing cost of reliance on China
summary: Apple's market value dropped $44 billion after US President Donald Trump ordered American companies to find alternative manufacturing sources outside of China, where nearly all iPhones are made. Analyst Daniel Ives stated Apple is unprepared to make such a switch. This move highlights Apple's reliance on China, a growing concern for the company.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sunpower Group secured 65.5 million yuan (S$12.7 million) in manufacturing and services contracts with PSS Netherlands BV, a joint venture company, for heat exchangers at Thailand's Sriracha oil refinery. The contracts are due for delivery in 2020 and are expected to positively impact the group's financial performance for FY2019 and FY2020.

site_title: Aier Eye International to make pre-conditional offer for ISEC Healthcare shares
summary: Aier Eye International, a Chinese hospital group, agreed to buy 186.3 million ISEC Healthcare shares in a deal valued at S$67.1 million, at S$0.36 apiece. The offer price is a 5.88% premium over the closing price on June 28. The deal will trigger a mandatory general offer for the remaining shares at the same price, with Aier Eye International expected to own 35% of ISEC Healthcare's total shares upon completion. The offer was cited as a response to ISEC Healthcare's low historical trading liquidity.

site_title: Singapore shares drop 1.5% on Monday; in the red for 2019
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.5% on Monday, closing at 3,065.33, as trade tensions between the US and China escalated. The market's decline was part of a broader Asia-wide sell-off, with the Hang Seng down 1.9%. Local stocks, including banks and blue-chip companies, also fell, with DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank closing 1.2% and 0.8% lower, respectively. The market's decline marks a loss for 2019, with the STI now below last year's closing of 3,068.76.

site_title: Australia: Shares tumble as Sino-US trade war heats up
summary: Australian shares fell 1.3% on Monday due to a dramatic escalation in the US-China trade war, threatening global economic growth. Heavy selling of banking shares and iron ore miners pushed the S&P/ASX 200 index down. Iron ore miners BHP, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals lost between 2.1% and 5.3%, while energy units tumbled 3.1%. Australian gold stocks surged 6.8% as uncertainty boosted the appeal of gold. The US-China trade war has further dampened China's domestic demand, a key buyer of Australia's resource exports.

site_title: Asia stocks bleed as US, China drop the gloves
summary: Asian stock markets plummeted on Monday as the US-China trade war escalated, with major indices in Singapore, Japan, and Hong Kong suffering significant losses. The US and China each imposed new tariffs on each other's exports, threatening to cut off trade and investments. The dimming outlook has raised concerns about the global economy, with UBS going underweight on stocks for the first time since the euro zone crisis. The US yuan hit an 11-year low, while gold prices surged as investors sought safe-haven assets. Analysts warn of significant economic burdens from the trade feud, including a possible recession in the global manufacturing sector.

site_title: Gold touches over 6-year peak as risk-off appetite stoked
summary: Gold prices surged to a 6-year high on Monday, jumping 1.2% to $1,544 per ounce, amid escalating US-China trade tensions. The Sino-US trade war led to a decline in equity markets, causing investors to seek safe-haven assets. The US dollar index fell 0.5% and 10-year Treasury yields dropped, while the Group of Seven summit is expected to impact market sentiment. Hedge funds increased their bullish stance on gold and silver, with physical gold demand rising in Asian hubs.

site_title: Australian homes fly at auctions in boon for prices
summary: Australia's housing market is showing signs of recovery, with Sydney and Melbourne experiencing their third consecutive months of gains in sales at auctions. This uptick could boost the struggling economy, particularly for the construction sector, which has seen a downturn in new home approvals. The housing market's resurgence may also help restore consumer confidence and spending power, which have been eroded by the decline in housing wealth.

site_title: Conserved Neil Road shophouse up for auction with S$8m asking price
summary: A conserved two-storey shophouse at 65 Neil Road in Singapore is up for auction with an asking price of S$8 million (about S$2,800 per square foot), despite potential for additions that could increase the price. The 99-year leasehold shophouse has a land area of 1,413 sq ft and comes with a 15-year lease for the ground floor.
