The second floor lease is set to expire in 2019 and could be used for various commercial or residential purposes, attracting potential buyers. The sale will be held on September 30.

site_title: Australia's Boral warns profit to fall further, shares plunge
summary: Australia's largest building materials maker Boral Ltd reported a 7% decline in underlying net profit to A$440.1 million for the year to end-June, missing analyst forecasts. The slump in housing construction, a result of Australia's largest house price correction in a generation, has impacted Boral's profit. The company is also regaining control of its higher-margin plasterboard and sheeting materials unit. Boral's shares plummeted to their biggest ever intra-day fall, following the profit warning.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's factory output declined 0.4% in July, beating forecasts of a 5.8% drop. Cityneon Holdings secured a strategic investment from EDBI, and Grab plans to invest "several hundred million dollars" in Vietnam. Singapore Airlines banned certain MacBook Pro models from flights, and Alita Resources' lenders extended a standstill period for a loan. The STI fell 1.5% on Monday, posting losses for 2019 due to trade tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Persuading the crowd to back your innovation
summary: A new study by Associate Professor Hannah Chang of SMU's Lee Kong Chian School of Business found that having multiple people communicate a product innovation in a crowdfunding pitch can increase persuasion and funding. This phenomenon, known as the "voice numerosity effect," is more pronounced when the information is not overly complex and the audience can process the information easily. The study analyzed real-world Kickstarter data and found that businesses can use this effect to improve their product pitches and increase funding. However, the effect may not be effective for complex products or services, and it's essential to balance the number of speakers to avoid information overload.

site_title: Japan's Tepco may mothball reactors at world's biggest nuke plant
summary: Tokyo Electric Power (Tepco) may start decommissioning at least one reactor at its Kashiwazaki-Kariwa power plant, the world's largest nuclear plant, within five years of restarting two reactors. The plant, which has seven reactors, is the last remaining nuclear plant for Tepco after shutting its Fukushima Daini station. Tepco aims to secure non-fossil fuel energy sources to support decommissioning plans, with a target of 44% renewable and nuclear power by 2030. The decision follows a request by the city of Kashiwazaki in Niigata prefecture for plans on the plant's future.

site_title: Disney to launch 25 stores inside Target nationwide on Oct 4
summary: Disney to launch 25 stores inside Target nationwide on October 4, featuring over 450 Disney items, including 100 exclusive products. The stores will be located in major cities like Philadelphia, Denver, and Chicago, with plans for 40 additional sites by October next year.

site_title: Get cracking: Lynas scouts for rare earths plant to meet Malaysian demands
summary: Lynas Corp, a rare earths miner, is building an initial processing plant in Australia to meet Malaysia's demands for low-level radioactivity removal. The plant is part of a $500 million growth strategy to boost production by 2025. Malaysia had placed conditions on Lynas' licence renewal, including the construction of the plant, as a result of concerns over radioactive waste. The plant will be built within four years, with the licence review set to take place in six months. This move aims to soothe concerns and ensure the continued supply of rare earth elements to Malaysia.

site_title: China to set floor on mortgage rates to curb housing risks
summary: China's central bank has set lower limits on mortgage rates, effective from October 8, to curb housing risks and prevent a sharp correction in the market. The interest rate on individual mortgage loans for first-time home buyers cannot be lower than the new loan prime rate (LPR), while second-time home buyers' rates are capped at the LPR plus 60 basis points. The move aims to keep mortgage rates basically stable and safeguard the rights and interests of both borrowers and lenders.

site_title: Indonesian president unveils site of new capital on Borneo island
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo announced plans to relocate the country's capital from Jakarta to Borneo island, citing the city's environmental and infrastructure issues. The new capital, set to be completed in 2024, will be located in East Kalimantan province, near Samarinda City and Balikpapan port. The relocation aims to address Jakarta's sinking and pollution problems.

site_title: Meituan posts surprise profit after pipping Alibaba in food
summary: Meituan Dianping, a Chinese internet services giant, posted its first quarterly profit of 877.4 million yuan, surpassing analysts' expectations. Revenue rose 51% to 22.7 billion yuan, driven by market share gains in food delivery from rivals like Alibaba. Meituan's founder, Wang Xing, is waging a battle for market share in China's online services industry, which includes food delivery. The company aims to expand its dining business and eventually become a super-app modeled on WeChat.

site_title: Germany's biggest landlord expects rent cap to cut 2020 Berlin revenue by a tenth
summary: Vonovia SE, Germany's largest landlord, expects a rent cap in Berlin to reduce 2020 revenue by up to 10% (25 million euros), or 10% of rental income. The company plans to redirect funds for modernization to other regions, citing the cap as unconstitutional. The proposed rent cap, which has driven rent prices up by 50% in Berlin since 2011, is part of a larger effort to control rising costs in the city.

images.alt_text: Vonovia SE expects a rent cap proposed by the Berlin city government would cut revenue next year by as much as 25 million euros (S$38.8 million), or about 10 per cent of its rental income in the German capital.

site_title: Nearly 100 companies move to Netherlands ahead of Brexit: Dutch agency
summary: Nearly 100 companies have relocated to the Netherlands due to Brexit uncertainty, with another 325 considering a move, according to the Netherlands Foreign Investment Agency. The businesses are mainly in finance, IT, media, and life sciences. The Netherlands is competing with other EU countries to attract these companies, which are seeking to remain within the European Union. The relocation is seen as a response to the UK's planned departure from the EU, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson pledging to take Britain out at the end of October with or without a deal.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks plunge more than 3% at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted more than 3% at the open on Monday, August 26, 2019, amid rising tensions between the US and China. The Hang Seng Index fell 3.27% to 25,322, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The decline was driven by Donald Trump's escalated trade row with China and violent protests in Hong Kong over the weekend.

site_title: China state media blasts US after Trump threats
summary: Chinese state media criticized US President Donald Trump for announcing additional tariffs on Chinese goods and ordering US companies to find alternatives. The China Daily editorial stated that Washington will "never be allowed to control China's fate" and that the US will not succeed in forcing China to be content with playing second fiddle. The Global Times also warned US companies that leaving the Chinese market would be "suicide." The escalating trade war has damaged global growth and raised market fears of a recession.

images.alt_text: Chinese state media on Monday blasted the United States after US President Donald Trump announced additional tariffs on goods from China and lashed out at China and ordered US companies to find "alternatives" to China.

site_title: Top China trade negotiator calls for calm as Trump tensions grow
summary: China's top trade negotiator, Vice Premier Liu He, called for calm in US-China trade tensions, urging a measured dialogue to resolve the dispute. He stated China opposes the escalation of the trade war, which he believes is not conducive to China, the US, or global interests. Liu emphasized China's commitment to protecting property rights and building a favorable environment for foreign investors, including those from the US. He also highlighted China's macro-policy tools to ensure the country's economic fundamentals remain stable.

site_title: Trump-Abe trade deal helps US farmers, staves off auto tariffs
summary: The US and Japan agreed on a trade deal that slashes Tokyo's tariffs on American beef, pork, and other agricultural products, while delaying additional auto tariffs. The deal, announced by President Donald Trump and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, includes a "massive" purchase of US wheat and corn. Japan's concessions are seen as a small win, while the US gains a trade advantage in Japan's agricultural market. The agreement is seen as a positive for US farmers reeling from the trade war with China, but some Japanese officials have expressed disappointment over the lack of concessions on auto tariffs.

site_title: Turnaround may prove tricky for new Virgin Australia CEO Scurrah
summary: Virgin Australia Holdings is expected to report its seventh consecutive annual loss, on top of US$1.2 billion in losses over the previous six years. New CEO Paul Scurrah faces pressure to cut costs, rebrand underperforming budget carrier Tigerair Australia, and tighten control over the loyalty division. His options are limited due to decisions made by his predecessor, John Borghetti, which led to rising costs, expensive fleet, and a looming US dollar debt refinancing. Major shareholders have declined to provide more capital, and Scurrah has told staff the airline cannot rely on shareholder financing.

site_title: Trump says China called, requested to restart trade talks
summary: US President Donald Trump announced that China has asked to restart trade talks, following a weekend of tit-for-tat tariff increases. Trump stated that China's top trade negotiator, Vice Premier Liu He, called to request a return to the negotiating table. Trump accepted the invitation, indicating the US would resume talks. This development comes after Beijing's top negotiator publicly called for calm in response to the recent tariff increases, which sent global stocks plummeting.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump said China has asked to re-start trade talks, hours after Beijing's top negotiator publicly called for calm in response to a weekend of tit-for-tat tariff increases that sent global stocks plunging.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as US-China trade war escalates
summary: Australian shares plummeted 1.5% on Monday, following the escalation of the US-China trade war. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to 6,428.7, led by losses in banks and iron ore miners. The decline wiped out gains from the previous week, as investors sought safe-havens like gold amidst global uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore share index extends slide, resumes Monday afternoon down 1.67%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 1.67% to 3,058.45 as of 1:02pm on Monday, tracking losses in other Asian markets due to mounting trade fears. Losers outnumbered gainers 316 to 89, with key stocks like Singtel and DBS Group Holdings down 2.8% and 1.5% respectively. The Hang Seng index in Hong Kong and Nikkei in Japan also plummeted, with the Shanghai Composite Index down 1.2%. Market strategist Pan Jingyi attributed the decline to the unpredictability of the ongoing trade war.

site_title: SIA bans some models of 15-inch MacBook Pro from flights
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has banned certain models of 15-inch MacBook Pro laptops from its flights due to a battery recall by Apple. The affected units, sold between 2015 and 2017, may overheat and pose a safety risk. SIA advises passengers to check their laptop's serial number on Apple's recall page to determine if it's eligible for a free battery replacement. This ban follows similar directives from the European Union Aviation Safety Agency and the US Federal Aviation Administration.

site_title: British Airways cancels scores of flights, some by mistake
summary: British Airways canceled and then reinstated multiple flights due to a planned pilots' strike, causing widespread confusion and frustration among customers. The airline initially told passengers their flights were canceled, but later corrected the mistake, leading to a surge in calls and social media complaints. The pilots, seeking higher salaries, argued that the airline had rejected all proposed packages, resulting in a potential 120 million-pound loss. The airline offered alternative travel options, including refunds, to affected customers.

site_title: China's yuan sinks to weakest in 11 years amid trade tension
summary: China's yuan slid to its weakest point in over 11 years, reaching 7.1425 to the US dollar, amid intensified global economic tensions and trade war concerns. The People's Bank of China set the daily rate at 7.057, allowing the currency to depreciate and offset US tariffs. Economists believe further depreciation is likely as long as China controls the yuan's movement, providing a cushion against US punitive measures. The move follows the US branding China a "currency manipulator" and Washington's plans to impose fresh tariffs on Chinese imports.

site_title: As Amazon burns, fires in next-door Bolivia also wreak havoc
summary: Bolivia is facing devastating fires, with flames devouring farmland and environmentally sensitive forests, amid growing international alarm over fires in Brazil's Amazon region. Bolivian President Evo Morales suspended his reelection campaign and welcomed foreign aid after receiving calls from international leaders. The fires have destroyed 2.5 million acres of forestland, threatening 500 types of animals, including jaguars and endangered species. Experts say the fires are a result of the government's policies to hand out free land to peasants and open up new areas to agribusiness, leaving swaths of previously virgin jungle exposed to uncontrolled slash-and-burn farming.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing output dips 0.4% in July, beating forecasts
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output declined 0.4% in July from a year ago, beating forecasted decline of 5.8%. This marks the third consecutive month of negative growth. However, excluding the biomedical sector, output fell 0.7%. The electronics cluster contracted, but its 0.9% drop was smaller than the 18.2% plunge in June. The general manufacturing segment grew 6.9%, driven by the miscellaneous industries segment and beverages segment. The biomedical sector showed a 0.8% increase, with higher export demand for medical devices.

site_title: Spanish beer isn't flowing and Brexit is part of the problem
summary: Spain's tourism industry is experiencing a slowdown due to the decline of the British pound, making UK tourists more price-sensitive. With 18.5 million British visitors in 2018, a 5.3% decline in June marks the weakest start to the summer season in four years. The drop in visitors has led to weaker sales in the beer industry, with Spanish brewer Mahou-San Miguel Group noticing a slowdown. Brexit is a major contributor to this decline, with the pound down 16% versus the euro since the 2016 Brexit vote.

site_title: Hong Kong police arrest 36, youngest aged 12, after running battles with protesters
summary: Hong Kong police arrested 36 people, including a 12-year-old, after violent clashes with protesters on Sunday. The clashes, the second day of running battles, involved protesters hurling Molotov cocktails at police using water cannon and tear gas. The protests, which began over a suspended extradition bill, have plunged Hong Kong into a political crisis, with protesters seeking to protect the "one country, two systems" arrangement. The city's benchmark Hang Seng Index dropped over 3% as the protests continue to take a toll on the economy.

site_title: Asia: Shares sink, bonds surge as trade fears mount
summary: Asian shares plummeted, with the MSCI Asia-Pacific index falling 0.8% on Monday, as trade tensions escalated between the US and China. The Chinese yuan came under pressure, and gold surged to its highest level since 2013. US Treasury yields dropped to their lowest since 2016, while investors sought safe havens in bonds, gold, and the Japanese yen. The US dollar strengthened against emerging market currencies, while oil prices fell due to concerns over reduced demand.

site_title: Cityneon bags investment from Singapore's EDBI; to open new creative office here
summary: Cityneon Holdings has secured a strategic investment from EDBI, the investment arm of the Singapore Economic Development Board. The exact amount of funding was not disclosed. The entertainment firm, which creates licensed interactive exhibitions, plans to use the fresh funding to expand into new markets, including Scotland, India, the UAE, and China. This investment comes as Cityneon continues to grow despite recently delisting from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Jokowi to announce new Indonesia capital to replace Jakarta
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo will announce the site of the country's new capital on Monday, replacing Jakarta as the administrative headquarters. The new capital is expected to cost about 466 trillion rupiah (S$46 billion) and begin construction in 2021, with relocation of offices starting in 2024. The plan aims to alleviate Jakarta's gridlock and pollution issues, which have worsened over the years, with efforts to decongest the city showing little progress. The government will finance the project through public-private partnerships.

images.alt_text: Indonesian President Joko Widodo will announce the site of the country's new capital on Monday, ending months of speculation about the location of the new city to replace Jakarta as the administrative headquarters.

site_title: China signals intervention as Hong Kong's protests intensify
summary: China has signaled its intention to intervene in Hong Kong's protests, with the state-run Xinhua News Agency stating that Beijing will take action to restore order when riots occur. The agency described the protests as a "Colour Revolution" aimed at overturning Hong Kong's constitutional institutions. This warning comes amid reports of Chinese troops assembling near Hong Kong's border. Protests have turned violent, with clashes between demonstrators and police resulting in warning shots being fired in the air. China's actions have raised concerns about the erosion of Hong Kong's autonomy.

site_title: A bus journey to a time before ABBA
summary: Benny Andersson, ABBA's pianist and songwriter, leads a 15-member ensemble called Benny Andersson Orkester (BAO) that pays homage to Sweden's "dansbands," a tradition of hardworking, dance-oriented groups. The band tours by bus, playing 50 songs over four hours, including deep cuts like ABBA's "Lovers (Live a Little Longer)." Andersson's goal is to create a community celebration, and the band's sets feature diverse music styles, from waltzes to rockabilly. The group has become a beloved institution in Sweden, with fans praising its energy and Andersson's commitment to preserving traditional music and community.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened 0.8% lower on Monday, closing at 1598.28, amid a regional decline. The FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index shed 12.12 points. Volume was 112.5 million lots, with 275 losers beating 38 gainers.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust unit Basslink's under-sea cable out of service until Tuesday
summary: A Basslink, an under-sea electricity cable connecting Victoria and Tasmania, has been out of service since Saturday due to a trip. As a precautionary measure, the Basslink Interconnector remains out of service while investigations are ongoing. The expected return to service is on Tuesday, according to Basslink.

site_title: Alita Resources' lenders extend standstill again over A$40m loan default
summary: Lenders of lithium miner Alita Resources have extended a standstill period for a secured A$40 million loan until August 29, allowing discussions on refinancing options and recapitalization proposals. The initial standstill period was set until August 20, then extended to August 23, due to default events including non-acceptance of an updated life-of-mine plan, material adverse effects on business and financial performance, and weakened market demand for spodumene concentrate. Alita Resources' shares have been suspended since August 14.

site_title: Bukit Panjang GCB up for auction with S$9m asking price
summary: A Good Class Bungalow (GCB) at 7 Chestnut Crescent in Bukit Panjang is up for auction with an asking price of S$9 million, or S$975 per square foot. The property, which can be redeveloped into a luxury two-and-a-half-storey home, is located near the Dairy Farm Quarry and Bukit Timah Nature Reserve. The auction is scheduled for September 30, the same day another property will also be offered for sale. This rare opportunity to own a GCB at a relatively affordable price presents a chance for buyers to own one of Singapore's most prestigious properties.

site_title: Rule no 1 at the G-7 meeting? Don't get you-know-who mad
summary: At the G-7 meeting in Biarritz, France, President Donald Trump faced opposition from other leaders on key issues like trade, climate change, and North Korea. Despite a show of bonhomie in public, the leaders subtly pushed Trump's views on these issues, with some even wrapping their comments in flattery to avoid provoking him. The meeting highlighted the ongoing tensions between the US and its allies on global issues, with no clear resolution or consensus reached.

site_title: US lawmaker says still concerned about Facebook cryptocurrency after Swiss meetings
summary: US House Financial Services Committee Chair Maxine Waters expressed concerns about Facebook's plans for a digital currency, Libra, after meetings with Swiss officials. Despite appreciating the time taken by Swiss officials, Waters remains concerned about allowing a large tech company to create a privately controlled global currency. Policymakers and financial watchdogs are concerned about Libra's potential impact on the global financial system, with widespread adoption raising concerns about data security and consumer protection. Waters' comments follow a July hearing where lawmakers criticized Facebook for not showing it could be trusted to safeguard the financial system and consumers' data.

site_title: Nike challenger says quarter of China's sportswear factories are idled
summary: A quarter of China's sportswear factories are idle due to the protracted trade war, forcing factories to offer discounts to companies like Nike and Adidas to use their dormant production lines. This trend is part of a broader shift away from China by global firms, with companies like Microsoft and Giant Manufacturing Co. already making moves to diversify their supply chains. Existing local sportswear makers like Xtep International Holdings see opportunities to expand production and gain an advantage in the market.

site_title: Opportunities to start up in Vietnam
summary: Vietnam's startup scene is rapidly growing, with investments tripling to $889 million in 2018. The young and tech-savvy population, combined with government support, has created a vibrant ecosystem. The country has a strong pool of tech talent, and multinational corporations are attracted to set up offshore software development centers. Key sectors for Singapore startups include e-commerce, fintech, and cryptocurrencies. However, challenges include the language barrier, cultural differences, and unfamiliarity with the market. To overcome these issues, startups should invest time to understand the market, build relationships with local partners, and develop a customized market penetration strategy. Enterprise Singapore offers resources and support for Singapore companies to enter Vietnam's startup market, including the Global Innovation Alliance and networking events.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, Wilmar, UOL, Yangzijiang, SPH Reit, KIT, GuocoLand, Datapulse
summary: OCBC launched a new travel credit card with projected S$1 billion in annual card billings. Wilmar International set up four new subsidiaries in China. UOL Group sold its interest in a Chinese hotel to Bao Chang Long for S$80 million. Yangzijiang secured new shipbuilding orders for two bulk carriers. SPH Reit priced its subordinated perpetual securities at 4.1%. Keppel Infrastructure Trust's Australian subsidiary experienced a trip in its under-sea electricity cable. GuocoLand reported a 24% growth in net profit, while Datapulse Technology's hotel management agreements were deemed normal and not prejudicial to its interests.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei opens down 2.6% as yen surges on trade fears
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index plummeted 2.6% on Monday, led by the yen's surge against the dollar amid escalating US-China trade tensions. The Nikkei 225 fell to 20,181.05, while the Topix index dropped 2.45%. The yen's appreciation is attributed to concerns over potential trade restrictions and tariffs.

site_title: Germans done in by their saving habit
summary: Germany's saving habit is being threatened by the European Central Bank's negative interest rates, prompting politicians to seek ways to protect citizens' deposits. With over 2.35 trillion euros in retail deposits, Germany's banks are struggling with sub-par profitability. Some banks already charge customers for holding as little as 100,000 euros, and Finance Minister Olaf Scholz is considering a ban to prevent further losses. The move could stabilize the banking industry and ease the burden on German citizens.

site_title: Ride-hailing firm Grab plans major investment in Vietnam
summary: Grab, a Singapore-based ride-hailing firm, plans to invest "several hundred million dollars" in Vietnam, aiming to capitalize on the country's rapid growth. This investment follows Grab's $2 billion plan in Indonesia, and the company's eagerness to utilize its billions in funding. Grab President Ming Maa sees similarities between Vietnam and Indonesia, indicating a promising market for the company.

site_title: US stock futures tumble, yen gains on trade war
summary: US stock futures plummeted, with the S&P 500 futures down 1.4% and Nikkei 225 futures down 2.6%, amid escalating tensions in the Sino-American trade war. The yen rose to a fresh 2019 high against the US dollar, while the yuan slumped. Treasury contracts climbed, and oil prices extended losses. Economists warn of a recession in six to nine months if tariffs are raised to 25% on all imports from China.

site_title: Oil down nearly 2% as trade war shakes confidence
summary: Oil prices dropped nearly 2% on Monday, with US crude falling to its lowest in over two weeks, due to escalating US-China trade tensions and concerns of a global economic slowdown. Brent crude fell 89 cents to $58.45 a barrel, while US oil fell $1 to $53.17 a barrel. The trade war has reduced confidence in the global economy, with the US Federal Reserve indicating it will "act as appropriate" to keep the economy on track. US manufacturing industries contracted for the first time in almost a decade, exacerbating concerns of a potential recession.

site_title: Adding colour to the New York Major
summary: The US Open tennis championships, one of the oldest tennis events, has a long-standing tradition of adding colour to its courts and players' attire. Since 2005, the courts are painted US Open Blue inside the lines, while the outside remains US Open Green. Many players, including Serena Williams and Roger Federer, incorporate colourful attire and body art into their outfits, with some even getting tattoos. The event brings out the best in players, who often plan months in advance to choose their colourful fashion.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Difficulties of setting up a production house in Singapore's niche media market
summary: Big 3 Media, Singapore's largest production house, shares the challenges of setting up a production house in the country's niche media market. Founder Willie Lee discusses the difficulties of establishing a business in a small market with limited competition. Despite these challenges, Big 3 Media has successfully navigated the industry, achieving significant growth and success. Lee highlights the importance of adaptability, innovative thinking, and strategic partnerships in overcoming obstacles in the industry.

site_title: Singapore share index tumbles 1.44% to 3,065.71 at Monday's open on trade fears
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index plummeted 1.44% to 3,065.71 on Monday, driven by mounting trade fears. Investors shifted to safe-haven assets like sovereign bonds, gold, and the Japanese yen. Asia's Nikkei 225 and Topix indices also fell, while US shares sank on Friday due to US-China trade tensions. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 dropped 2.4% and 2.6% respectively.

site_title: Cuba's intranet creators thriving, despite regulatory clampdown
summary: Cubans have created their own intranet, SNET, to play online multiplayer video games despite the government's clampdown on internet access. The network uses a massive network of cables and antennas connecting thousands of homes in Havana, with its own servers and administrators. However, the government has regulated cabling and wireless technology, making SNET's signals interfere with state telecommunications. After a protest, authorities absorbed SNET into the state network, Joven Club, allowing it to connect to similar networks in other Cuban cities through fibre optic cables.

site_title: Little to save US stocks from continuing slide
summary: US stocks continue to slide as the trade war between the US and China intensifies, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling over 620 points. The market is losing confidence in the global economy, with copper futures hitting a two-year low and oil futures near bear-market territory. The Fed's inability to fix the damage done by trade policy and President Trump's attacks on the central bank have fueled concerns about a prolonged economic slowdown. With a planned high-level meeting between US and Chinese delegates in September, hopes for a truce are dwindling, and the market is bracing for a worst-case scenario.

site_title: Hong Kong officer fires shot; police use water cannons at protest
summary: Hong Kong police fired a warning shot into the air after protesters charged at them, marking a violent escalation of clashes between the two sides. The protests, sparked by an extradition bill, have expanded to demands for greater democracy in the semi-autonomous region. The police used water cannons and tear gas, and arrested 29 people, as tensions continued to rise. The government's response to the crisis has been criticized, with many calling for an independent committee to investigate the cause of the protests and the official response. The situation remains volatile, with concerns about the safety of frontline officers and the public.

site_title: Australia's big banks gear up for capital raising rush
summary: Australia's four major banks, Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Westpac, National Australia Bank, and ANZ, are expected to cut dividend payments and raise capital to meet tougher capital requirements. Regulators are tightening rules to safeguard the sector from future market volatility, with APRA requiring banks to hold 25% of their tier one capital in domestic operations, down from 50%. The banks will tap bond markets to raise funds, with analysts forecasting significant capital raising by 2024. This move comes as interest rates remain low and profit margins are under pressure.

images.alt_text: This week, Commonwealth Bank of Australia Chief Executive Matt Comyn and Chief Financial Officer Alan Docherty will finalise a roadshow with Australian equity investors before holding similar meetings in New York next month as well as London and Hong Kong.

site_title: Macron asks shippers to shun Arctic route to protect environment
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron is urging shipping companies to avoid the Arctic route, citing environmental concerns. Russia is promoting the Northern Sea Route, which could reduce travel time between Asia and Europe, but Macron warns it will have devastating consequences. CMA CGM, France's largest shipping line, has committed not to use the route, citing the threat to Arctic ecosystems. Macron is pushing for tougher climate action, amid concerns about global warming and its impact on the environment.

site_title: Costco bets on global appetite for first Chinese store
summary: Costco is opening its first store in China, targeting the country's affluent growing middle class with its "no-frills approach" and bulk-buy strategy. Despite a challenging market with many international retailers failing, Costco believes its membership model will work in China. The company aims to sign up at least 100,000 new members and will adjust its pricing strategy due to the impact of a bruising US-China trade war, which has seen punitive tariffs imposed on hundreds of billions of dollars of two-way trade.

site_title: Hong Kong turmoil may re-route some IPOs to Singapore
summary: Hong Kong's turmoil amid anti-government protests may lead some companies to consider Singapore as an alternative listing destination. Several Singapore firms are exploring listing options on the Singapore Exchange, while others are rethinking their plans due to more stringent rules for foreign company listings. The uncertainty may also affect Hong Kong's reputation as a safe financial hub, leading to capital outflows and a shift in investor sentiment. Analysts predict that Singapore's role as a neutral haven for investors will continue to attract listings, particularly in the real estate sector.

images.alt_text: As companies rethink fundraising plans in Hong Kong amid anti-government protests, some are said to be exploring Singapore as an alternative listing destination.

site_title: Battered Hong Kong faces economic recession, existential crisis
summary: Hong Kong is facing an economic and existential crisis due to the ongoing anti-government protests and the US-China tariff war. The city is experiencing its first recession in a decade, with retail sales expected to drop 20-30% this year. Banks have issued unprecedented profit warnings, hotels and restaurants are struggling, and several global events have been postponed. The government has announced stimulus measures, but analysts warn that handouts are ineffective in the current climate. Rating agencies have raised concerns over Hong Kong's governance, and Beijing's increasing assertiveness is fuelling worries about the city's independence and economic stability.

site_title: The cursed legacy of the most expensive plot of land in Los Angeles
summary: A 63.5-hectare vacant plot in Beverly Hills, known as "The Mountain" or "The Vineyard", was sold for $100,000 in a foreclosure auction after sitting on the market for a year. Despite initial prices of $650 million and being considered a potential location for a tech mogul's dream home, the plot has remained vacant due to various ownership changes and disputes. The property has been used as a luxury rental space, hosting events such as Rihanna's charity gala, but has never had a house built on it.

site_title: Singapore still pays interest in a world of negative yields
summary: Singapore is set to sell $2.9 billion in reopened 10-year government debt, offering positive-yielding quality bonds in a world with negative yields. The sale comes despite a yield curve near its flattest on record, with a yield premium of minus 1.14 basis points. The move is expected to attract solid demand, given Singapore's top AAA credit rating and high yields, similar to Australia's recent successful auction. The sale is the second-largest on record for a 10-year tenor, with investors seeking to "catch the tail" of the highest yields.

site_title: Trump aides downplay 'order' to US companies to leave China
summary: US President Donald Trump's top aides have downplayed the idea of forcing US companies to leave China, following a tweet from Trump ordering businesses to start looking for alternatives. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and White House economics advisor Larry Kudlow said there is no plan to regulate US companies in line with the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, and that companies will operate in places where they trade fairly. Despite tensions, talks between the US and China on trade are set to resume next month in Washington.

images.alt_text: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin (left) and White House economics advisor Larry Kudlow took to the airwaves from France, where Mr Trump is participating in the G-7 summit, to smooth out tensions in the business community prompted by Mr Trump's Friday tweet.

site_title: US-China trade bout sets the tone for the week
summary: China imposed additional tariffs on $75 billion of US goods, including soybeans, cars, and oil, prior to the US session, setting the tone for Asian trading in the last week of August. This move follows US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's speech at Jackson Hole, which was a key focus for Asian markets earlier in the week. The tariffs are likely to have a significant impact on US goods and could lead to a slowdown in the global economy.

site_title: Trump offers contradictory signals on China trade war
summary: US President Donald Trump sent conflicting signals about the China trade war, initially expressing "second thoughts" about new tariffs before escalating threats. He defended his authority to order US companies out of China, while acknowledging progress in a deal with Japan to avoid a trade dispute. Trump's contradictory statements injected uncertainty into his efforts to change Chinese behavior, and several world leaders distanced themselves from him on trade and other issues. The US-China trade war continues to impact the global economy.

site_title: Vietnam to see strong growth in 2019, unlikely to face US tariffs: reports
summary: Vietnam is expected to experience strong growth in 2019, with a forecasted 6.7% growth rate, driven by robust domestic demand and increasing foreign direct investment (FDI). The country is seen as a key destination for manufacturers relocating from China due to US-China trade tensions. Despite a significant trade deficit with the US, Vietnam is unlikely to face major tariffs in the near term, with the US focusing on China and valuing Vietnam's role in countering Chinese influence in the region.

site_title: Australia to block Internet domains hosting extremist content during terror attacks
summary: Australia plans to block internet domains hosting extremist content during terror attacks and consider legislation to improve digital platforms' safety. The move aims to prevent terrorists from exploiting digital platforms to post violent content. Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison stated the government's intention to deny terrorists the opportunity to glorify their crimes. The plan is part of efforts to enhance online safety and security.

site_title: Cloud gaming faces challenges as Google prepares launch
summary: Google's cloud-based gaming platform, Stadia, is set to launch in November, offering high-res surround sound games on various platforms. The platform aims to revolutionize gaming with its subscription model and minimal hardware requirements. Despite initial interest, hardcore gamers have expressed doubts about connectivity and game quality, citing the need for high-speed internet and compatible screens. To overcome these challenges, Stadia plans to focus on independent, original titles, positioning itself as a "Netflix for gaming."

site_title: Trump's only regret on China is 'not raising tariffs higher'
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that his only regret regarding the trade war with China is not raising tariffs higher. Trump's initial comments, made earlier, suggested he regretted the trade war, but his spokeswoman clarified that he actually expressed disappointment over not increasing tariffs further. The comments came during the G-7 summit in Biarritz, France.

site_title: Companies file suit in Canada challenging new rules to lower drug prices
summary: Five pharmaceutical companies, including Merck & Co and Johnson & Johnson, have filed a lawsuit in Quebec's Superior Court to challenge the constitutionality of Canada's new regulations to lower patented drug prices. The regulations, set to take effect in 2020, aim to save patients, employers, and governments money at the expense of drug company profits. The companies claim the regulations infringe on their authority to regulate drug prices and will limit Canadians' access to new breakthrough medicines. The lawsuit sets up a confrontation with the federal government ahead of an October election.

site_title: OCBC targets annual card billings of S$1b in 3 years for new travel credit card
summary: OCBC Bank launched a new travel credit card, the OCBC 90°N Card, targeting S$1 billion in annual card billings within three years by targeting 150,000 fresh graduates and emerging affluent individuals. The card offers 2.1 Travel$ per dollar spent in foreign currency and 1.2 Travel$ per Singapore dollar spent, with no conversion fee and no expiry date for miles earned. The bank aims to build on its existing strong growth in overseas credit card expenditure, which has more than doubled over the past five years.

images.alt_text: The new card, although travel themed by allowing the earning of miles for flight tickets, also offers two other reward types - cashback and reward points per dollar spent.

site_title: Who will stop Djokovic from making it US Open title No. 4?
summary: Rafael Nadal strengthened his title threat for the US Open with a dominant win over Daniil Medvedev in Montreal, improving his all-time record for Masters 1000 titles to 35. The victory, which lasted just over an hour, followed a Cincinnati Masters semi-final defeat to Medvedev. Medvedev joins a young group of players, including Nick Kyrgios and Stefanos Tsitsipas, who are looking to challenge the "Big Three" of Djokovic, Nadal, and Federer. Djokovic remains the favorite, but Nadal's form and recent title win give him a strong chance of claiming his fourth US Open title.

images.alt_text: Rolex Testimonee Jo-Wilfried Tsonga during the Australian Open 2019.

site_title: Boeing 737 Max's certification flight likely in Oct
summary: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is likely to conduct a certification flight for Boeing's 737 Max in October, a key milestone in returning the grounded jetliner to service. The flight comes after Boeing has addressed concerns raised by the FAA and completed testing of changes to the flight-control software architecture. The FAA has already spent 110,000 hours working on the project, and the certification process is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter. The return of the 737 Max to service is expected to happen early in the fourth quarter, with about 600 planes temporarily mothballed.

images.alt_text: Unpainted Boeing 737 MAX aircraft parked at Renton Municipal Airport near the Boeing Renton facility in Renton, Washington, recently. A certification flight with FAA test pilots is one of the final steps that must be conducted before Boeing's submission is finalised.

site_title: HK police briefly turn water cannon on protesters, fire tear gas
summary: Hong Kong police fired tear gas and water cannon at protesters on Sunday, marking a return to violent clashes after a day of relative calm. The protests, which started over a suspended extradition bill, have continued for three months, with over 700 arrested since June. The protesters, calling for democracy, marched to a sports stadium and then to nearby areas, using makeshift barricades and water cannon. Police warned of a "dispersal operation" and arrested 29 people, including 19 men and 10 women, after Saturday's violence.

site_title: Trump offers UK PM a 'very big' trade deal for post-Brexit Britain
summary: US President Donald Trump promised a 'very big' trade deal to UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson, praising Johnson as the right man to take Britain out of the EU. Trump stated that Britain's EU membership hindered trade ties, and a deal will be 'bigger than we've ever had with the UK.' The UK's exit from the EU is uncertain, with a deadline of October 31. Johnson met with European Council President Donald Tusk, stating Britain will leave the EU on that date, potentially avoiding the £39 billion divorce bill.

site_title: Osaka, Ash, Pliskova or Serena; no clear favourite for US Open
summary: The US Open women's tennis tournament lacks a clear favorite, with no player dominating the game like Serena Williams. After her 23 Grand Slam victories, the unpredictability of outcomes has sparked fresh interest among fans, with past winners including Flavia Pennetta, Angelique Kerber, Sloane Stephens, and Naomi Osaka. The absence of a dominant force has made the tournament more exciting, but it remains to be seen who will emerge victorious.

site_title: Trump says US would tax French wine in response to digital tax
summary: US President Donald Trump threatened to tax French wine in response to France's proposed digital tax on big US tech companies. Trump reiterated his criticism of the French proposal, stating he doesn't want France taxing American companies. If France proceeds, Trump said the US will retaliate by taxing French wine "like they've never seen before." This move comes as the US prepares for a Group of Seven summit in France.

site_title: Trump dampens Macron optimism on Iran talks
summary: US President Donald Trump dampened French President Emmanuel Macron's optimism on Iran talks, stating he would continue his own initiatives despite Macron's efforts to mediate between the two countries. Trump's comments came as tensions between Iran and the US remain high, following the US withdrawal from the 2015 nuclear deal and reimposition of sanctions on the Iranian economy. Macron had expressed hope for a peaceful resolution through diplomatic efforts, but Trump's response suggests a continued rift between the two nations.

site_title: KLCI: Correction before the next supercycle
summary: The FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index (KLCI) has been in a corrective phase, following a strong rally from 2008 to 2019. The index has proven resilient in major financial crises, but is currently expected to face further downside before a potential rebound. A wave 3 correction has already been completed, and a prolonged ranging mode has evolved into a complex flat corrective wave. Analysts predict a confluence level of 1,221.97 to 1,189.39 and a potential psychological support level at 1,500, before a strong rebound forms wave 5 of the cycle phase.

site_title: Weaving economic empowerment with South-east Asia's heritage
summary: The Maybank Foundation presents a travelling exhibition, "Entwine: Maybank Women Eco-Weavers meets Southeast Asian Artists", showcasing contemporary artworks inspired by South-east Asia's weaving heritage. The exhibition features six artists from Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia, including Sheryo, Sharon Chin, and Lugas Syllabus. The programme aims to support traditional weaving practices in a sustainable manner, highlighting the region's rich cultural history and art.

images.alt_text: The Maybank Women Eco-Weavers programme creates economic independence and financial inclusion (above).
The Naga Wheel is a re-interpretation of a Lao silk-spinning wheel (above).

site_title: Amazon's Audible sued by publishers over new text feature
summary: Amazon's Audible is being sued by major publishers, including CBS Corp.'s Simon & Schuster, Penguin Random House LLC, and Scholastic Corp., over its new text feature called Audible Captions. The publishers claim the feature violates copyrights by automatically converting narrated works into unauthorized text, potentially causing errors and harming the quality of the works. The lawsuit seeks to block the feature's launch while the case proceeds. This escalates longstanding conflicts between publishers and Amazon over issues like e-book pricing and counterfeiting.

site_title: Singapore healthtech startups attract US$105m in 2018
summary: Singapore's healthtech startups attracted US$105 million in 2018, with 21 deals, accounting for 24% of total deal value in Asia excluding China and India. China led with US$5.59 billion in funding, while the Asia-Pacific region saw US$6.3 billion in total investment across 294 deals. This marked a maturing ecosystem, with venture funding now spanning from seed stage to Series B stage, indicating a growing interest in the sector.

images.alt_text: The demand for cost-effective solutions for consumers and health systems is driving the growth of an emergent healthtech industry in South-east Asia, said Galen.

site_title: Trump says he wouldn't stop Fed chair Powell if he offered to resign
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, saying he wouldn't stop him if he offered to resign. Trump expressed dissatisfaction with Powell's performance, calling him "not happy" and a "bad chess player." The comments came after Powell stated the Fed would "act as appropriate" to keep the US economy healthy in a deteriorating global economy. Trump had sought rate cuts, but Powell stopped short of committing to them. Trump's comments triggered a sharp drop in the US stock market, amidst a broader global economic downturn.

site_title: Japan, US reach framework trade pact, no US concessions seen: report
summary: The US and Japan have reached a framework trade agreement, with Tokyo making concessions on agriculture, cutting tariffs on US beef and pork. The US maintains tariffs on Japanese autos, but separate talks will continue. The agreement is expected to be finalized in late September, with US President Donald Trump and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe signing the pact. Tokyo's concessions on agriculture were seen as a key step in reaching a deal, with US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer stating "big progress" was made during the talks.

site_title: For Singapore firms, home is the right place to list
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) remains a popular destination for companies with Asean operations, Reits, and business trusts. This year, the SGX saw 10 initial public offerings, with three Reit listings raising over $1.6 billion. Despite a current lack of quality companies seeking to list, there is strong demand for Reits and investor appetite for well-run Singapore companies. Analysts expect SGX earnings to benefit from volatility, raising target prices. The SGX continues to attract foreign issuer listings, solidifying its position as a key listing destination for companies in the region.

site_title: Bargains emerging in UK property as prices drop
summary: The UK property market is experiencing a decline in prices, with average traded London property prices falling by 15% since 2015 and 11% since June 2019. Foreign investors are taking advantage of the discounts, with some purchasing properties at a 40% discount due to the pound's fall against the US and Singapore dollars. The Brexit uncertainty and increased regulations on foreign corporate purchases have contributed to the decline. More expensive areas such as Kensington and Chelsea have seen the largest percentage drops, while prices in the midlands and north of England have been less affected.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report covers the week's tanker and dry bulk market. Key highlights include: 

- The Capesize market surged mid-week, with Brazil driving the market higher, while transatlantic trades were slow but steady. Pacific routes saw increased support from Rio Tinto and North Pacific/Australia round trips paid between $11,000 and $12,000. 

- Panamax rates were driven by South American grains, with numerous vessels fixed for September loading in Asia at $16,000 to $19,000. 

- Supramax/Ultramax rates surged, with the US Gulf increasing rapidly before settling back down, and vessels open in the Far East supported by North Pacific runs. 

- Handysize rates climbed, with the Baltic Handysize Index reaching 609, and rates from East Coast South America remained steady. 

- VLCC rates continued to climb, with 270,000mt to China at WS 66, and Suezmax rates regaining some ground lost in recent weeks.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding bags orders for two 325,000 DWT bulk carriers
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, China's largest non-state owned shipbuilder, has secured orders for two 325,000 dwt bulk carriers from a ship owner in Asia. The vessels will be built at the group's Xinfu shipyard and delivered by June 2021. This milestone marks a significant step in the company's capability expansion, allowing for more efficient shipbuilding, increased output, and reduced investment costs.

site_title: Putin could possibly be invited to G-7: Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump suggests it's "certainly possible" to invite Vladimir Putin as a guest to next year's G-7 summit in the US, despite fellow nations' opposition to Russia's readmission due to Ukraine tensions. Trump previously called for Russia's full readmission to the G-7. Putin has stated he would consider an invitation if offered. However, other G-7 leaders, including France, Germany, and Canada, have dismissed the idea unless Putin makes concessions on Ukraine.

site_title: Glamping with French flair in the wilds of North America
summary: A French company, Huttopia Group, has brought high-end glamping to the Canadian and US wilds, offering luxury tents with amenities like feather beds and mini-fridges. The company, which has tapped into the "glamping" trend, has 51 campsites in France and 80 in North America, generating C$81 million in annual revenue. Huttopia's success has expanded into new markets, including the US, Netherlands, and China, and has even attracted interest from a Canadian indigenous tribe wanting to offer ecotourism on its lands.

site_title: Family Dental Centre takes controlling stake in Bangkok dental chain
summary: Singapore-based Family Dental Centre has acquired a controlling stake in Bangkok-based dental chain MOS Dental, expanding its dental chain to 38 clinics in the region. The acquisition marks FDC's first international expansion. MOS Dental is the second-largest dental group in Bangkok, with a network of 20 clinics. The deal is expected to further establish FDC's presence in Southeast Asia's dental market.

site_title: Guests get investment insights at Money FM event
summary: More than 60 guests attended the Money FM 89.3's Money@Work investment networking event, where market experts shared insights on investment tools, benefits, and risks for the second half of 2019. Experts including Geoff Howie and Teh Hooi Ling discussed the impact of global growth concerns on defensive sectors in Singapore, such as Reits and telcos. The event, hosted by Elliott Danker and Ryan Huang, provided a platform for investors to gain valuable insights into the market.

site_title: China Evergrande sticks to its world's biggest EV maker pledge
summary: China Evergrande Group, the country's second-largest property developer, remains committed to becoming the world's largest electric vehicle (EV) manufacturer in three to five years, despite missing its initial goal of delivering a "pure battery" EV by June. The company has invested over $3.6 billion in EV-related companies, including battery manufacturers and car sales networks, and plans to spend another $1.2 billion this year on EV development. Evergrande's CEO remains optimistic about the industry, citing the reduction in government EV subsidies as a positive factor, which makes the industry "fairer and more market-oriented."

site_title: IMF to hold weekend meetings in Argentina with advisers for Macri, Fernandez
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) will hold weekend meetings in Argentina with advisers for presidential contenders Mauricio Macri and Alberto Fernandez. The team will discuss recent economic developments and policy plans, with a focus on Argentina's $57 billion standby agreement with the IMF. Fernandez, who is now the front-runner for the October presidential election, has been critical of the agreement and pledged to "rework" it if elected. The meetings come as investors worry about Argentina's economic stability and potential debt restructuring.

site_title: World needs to end risky reliance on US dollar: BoE's Carney
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney warned that the world needs to end its reliance on the US dollar, citing the dollar's "destabilising" role in the global economy. He suggested central banks may create their own reserve currency to reduce the dollar's dominance, which fuels demand for US assets and exposes countries to economic swings. Carney also warned of the risks of ultra-low interest rates and weak growth, and proposed a diversified multi-polar financial system as a solution.

images.alt_text: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney took aim at the US dollar's "destabilising" role in the world economy on Friday and said central banks might need to join together to create their own replacement reserve currency.

site_title: As Amazon fires become global crisis, Brazil's president reverses course
summary: Brazil's President Jair Bolsonaro has mobilized the armed forces to help contain Amazon fires, reversing his previous dismissal of the crisis. The move comes amid international outrage and calls for punitive measures, including a potential boycott of Brazilian products. Deforestation in the Amazon has surged, with over 1,330 square miles lost in the first seven months of the year, a 39% increase over the same period last year. Bolsonaro's environmental policies have emboldened miners, loggers, and farmers to clear protected areas, leading to the fires.

site_title: 26 director acquisitions filed; Q&M founder continues to build stake
summary: The Straits Times Index gained 0.1% over five trading sessions, with the Nikkei 225 and Hang Seng Index averaging a 1.1% gain. There were 26 director acquisitions and four disposals, with Q&M Dental founder Ng Chin Siau maintaining a 55.5% stake in the company. Other notable acquisitions include JB Foods' executive director Tey How Keong increasing his stake to 46.17%, Lian Beng Group's Ong Sek Chong & Sons acquiring 313,200 shares, and JEP Holdings' executive chairman Andy Luong increasing his stake to 39.55%.

site_title: North Korea fires 'unidentified projectiles' into sea: Seoul
summary: North Korea fired two unidentified projectiles into the sea off its eastern coast, according to South Korea's military. This is the latest in a series of launches by Pyongyang. South Korea's presidential Blue House announced a National Security Council meeting in response. The Joint Chiefs of Staff stated they are tracking the movement in the North in case of additional launches.

site_title: Fed says it's trade, not rates, that's undermining the US economy
summary: US President Donald Trump has blamed the Federal Reserve for the country's slowing economy, but the central bank says trade disputes are the main issue. Federal Reserve officials, including Dallas Fed President Robert Kaplan and Philadelphia Fed President Patrick Harker, have stated that trade uncertainty is the primary concern, not monetary policy. The Fed's job is to keep the economy on an even keel, but trade wars are making it difficult, and the central bank has no recent precedents to guide a policy response. Fed Chair Jerome Powell hinted at a potential interest rate cut in September, but markets plummeted after Trump vowed retaliation against China in the latest escalation of the trade war.

images.alt_text: Mr Powell and the Fed have been accused by President Trump of having a "horrendous lack of vision".

site_title: GuocoLand Q4 net profit up 24% at S$183.7m
summary: GuocoLand's Q4 net profit rose 24% to S$183.7m, driven by an 81% increase in revenue to S$323.5m. The company attributed the growth to progressive revenue recognition of residential projects in Singapore and Malaysia. However, its full-year net profit was 38% down at S$255.7m due to lower sales of completed residential units.

site_title: Fed's Powell vow to act to sustain US expansion, Trump lashes out
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell vowed to act to sustain the US economic expansion, but admitted the central bank has limited tools to respond to the intensifying trade war. Powell warned that there is no "settled rulebook" for international trade, and the US economy is now in a favorable place, but significant risks remain. US President Donald Trump criticized Powell and vowed a quick response to China, sparking a market reaction.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell vowed Friday to act to ensure that the US economic expansion continues, but admitted the central bank had limited tools to respond to an intensifying trade war.

site_title: Encouraged by Johnson's visit, UK officials now hoping rest of EU agrees to work on Brexit solution
summary: Britain is hoping the rest of the European Union will work on a Brexit solution after UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson's visit, with officials sensing a glimmer of hope. German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Emmanuel Macron offered "positive noises" on considering an exit deal agreement, but the bloc's position remains unchanged. The Withdrawal Agreement struck last year will not be changed much, and the clock is ticking for a deal. British officials are seeking a wider consensus in Europe, with Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte willing to listen to alternative plans for the Irish backstop.

site_title: Trump heaps another 5% tariff on Chinese goods in latest tit-for-tat escalation
summary: US President Donald Trump announced an additional 5% tariff on $550 billion in Chinese goods, escalating the trade war between the two countries. China retaliated with tariffs on $75 billion worth of US goods, prompting Trump to demand US companies move their operations out of China. The move stoked market fears of a global recession, with US stocks and crude oil prices falling. Trump raised existing tariffs on $250 billion worth of Chinese imports to 30% and increased planned tariffs on the remaining $300 billion worth of Chinese goods to 15%.

site_title: Stamp out ageism in the workplace
summary: Singapore's upcoming increase in retirement age, re-employment age, and CPF rates aims to enable older workers to stay employed for longer. Experts agree that this move supports active ageing, leveraging experienced workers to contribute to the economy. Companies will need to adapt their talent management and operating models, focusing on inclusion, technology, and reskilling. Many firms, including Ernst & Young, Real Estate Developers' Association of Singapore, and Standard Chartered Bank, support the move, citing benefits such as increased productivity, reduced stigma, and access to institutional knowledge. The government's support, including wage subsidies and training grants, will help employers sustain the employability of older workers.

site_title: Hotel management agreements deemed to be on normal commercial terms and non-prejudicial: Datapulse
summary: Datapulse's audit committee has deemed the hotel management agreements with Travelodge Hotels Asia as on normal commercial terms and non-prejudicial to the company's interests. The agreements, which include the management of Bay Hotel Singapore and Holiday Inn Express Euljiro, were reviewed by an independent financial adviser. The committee considered major terms such as contractual periods, fees, and termination clauses. The decisions come after Datapulse acquired stakes in both hotels, with chairman Aw Cheok Huat holding an indirect 10% stake in the company.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust war chest tops billion dollars
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) has a war chest of over $1 billion to make potential purchases, including hospitals, car parks, bridges, roads, and tunnels. KIT's manager, Matthew Pollard, said the ideal deal size is between $300 million to $500 million. The trust has recently raised $300 million in perpetual securities and $500.8 million in equity, with a gearing ratio of 34.2% as of June. Pollard hinted at opportunities from Keppel Corp, the trust's sponsor, and external markets, citing the potential for renewable energy deals and diversifying currency exposure.

site_title: US: Dow ends down 2.4% on escalating US-China trade war
summary: US stocks plummeted on Friday, with the Dow Jones sinking 2.4% to 25,628.90, marking its fourth straight weekly loss. The S&P 500 fell 2.6% and the Nasdaq Composite Index tumbled 3.0%. The decline followed President Donald Trump's vow of a tough response to new Chinese tariffs, escalating the US-China trade war. Rising fears of a recession also weighed on investors.

site_title: Four Hong Kong stations close to head off protest as China frees UK consulate worker
summary: Hong Kong's rail operator shut down four stations ahead of a planned protest, while the airport operated normally despite plans to disrupt traffic. The shutdown comes as China released a British consulate worker, Simon Cheng, who was detained for 15 days. Cheng's detention had fueled tension, with some protesters demanding his release. The rail shutdown follows criticism of the rail operator for allowing protesters to travel on trains after clashes with police. The protests, which began as opposition to a suspended extradition bill, have swelled into calls for democracy and autonomy for Hong Kong.

site_title: Spider-Man is the star of new disney attractions, if not its films
summary: Disney is set to feature Spider-Man in new theme-park attractions in France and Southern California, despite the character's expected departure from Marvel movies following a split with Sony Corp. Disney acquired Spider-Man when it bought Marvel Entertainment in 2009, but Sony retains the movie license. The new attractions will feature Spider-Man, Spider-Bots, and a high-tech version of the hero's suit, showcasing the character's enduring popularity.

site_title: China to slap additional tariffs on US$75b of US goods
summary: China plans to impose additional tariffs on US$75 billion of US goods, including soya beans, cars, and oil, in retaliation for US President Donald Trump's planned levies on Chinese imports. The tariffs will take effect starting September 1 and December 15, with some levies increasing to 50% on US-made cars. The move has sent US stock futures tumbling and raised concerns about the global growth outlook. China's announcement comes as the world's two largest economies continue to escalate their trade tensions.

site_title: When the pursuit of wealth does not bring happiness
summary: Wealth management firms focus on growing clients' wealth, often setting ambitious targets, but a surprising correlation emerges: the more wealth clients have, the more stressed and unhappy they become. This is despite achieving their financial goals, as the pursuit of more wealth displaces other life goals, such as retirement. The constant striving for more wealth leads to a vicious cycle of financial stress and dissatisfaction, challenging the conventional wisdom that wealth is a key to happiness.

site_title: Europe: Shares slide as US-China trade war intensifies
summary: European shares fell on Friday as US President Donald Trump reacted angrily to China's imposition of additional tariffs on US goods, effective September 1. Trump urged US companies to find alternatives to China, including bringing production back to the US. This move intensified the US-China trade war, causing investors to become frustrated. Despite this, some European stocks rose, with mining and healthcare sectors benefiting. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) also rose 0.4% on Thursday, as investors maintained a positive outlook despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Property boost for China loans
summary: Chinese commercial property acquisitions are boosting cross-border lending opportunities for international banks, despite the US-China trade war and lower outbound M&A activity. International buyers have raised around $1.9 billion in syndicated loans to buy office buildings, mainly in prime locations like Beijing and Shanghai. This is 18% higher than the same period in 2018, and is driven by foreign investors seeking quality commercial properties with stable rental income.

site_title: North Korea says it will remain 'threat' to US, slams Pompeo
summary: North Korea has launched a scathing attack on US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, calling him a "diehard toxin" and expressing skepticism about negotiating with him. The country vowed to remain the US's "biggest threat" and said annual joint military drills had complicated nuclear talks. North Korea's foreign minister, Ri Yong Ho, stated that the US is "sadly mistaken" if it thinks it can stand in confrontation with North Korea. The statement worsens prospects for revived talks between Pyongyang and Washington, which have stalled since a February summit collapsed without an agreement.

site_title: BMW, Mercedes-Benz ensnared again in US-China trade war
summary: BMW and Mercedes-Benz face a potential blow from a US-China trade war escalation. China threatened to impose a 25% tariff on US-made cars, cutting exports in half. German automakers that build SUVs in Alabama and South Carolina, including BMW and Mercedes-Benz, would be significantly impacted. This could prompt a US reaction, leading to more tariffs on Chinese parts, making it difficult for automakers to plan investments. Industry analyst Alan Baum described the situation as "very difficult."

site_title: Amazon opens its biggest global campus in India
summary: Amazon has launched its largest global campus in Hyderabad, India, with a 3.8-hectare site that will house over 15,000 employees. The move underscores the company's expansion plans in the country, which has been one of its fastest-growing overseas markets. Amazon has committed over $5 billion to India operations, seeking to fend off competition from local players like Flipkart. The new campus will host employees across divisions, including Amazon Web Services, and is the latest step in the company's efforts to establish a strong presence in the country.

site_title: Economists now expect easing of Singdollar slope in October
summary: Singapore's central bank, Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), has revised its inflation outlook, cutting its core inflation forecast to 0.8-1.2% for the full year, down from 1-2%. The MAS expects a half-point easing of the Singdollar slope at its October policy meeting, but warns that growth risks remain due to a slowdown in Singapore's economic fundamentals and global uncertainty. Private-sector economists also predict a half-point easing of the Singdollar slope and expect core inflation to remain low.

images.alt_text: Singapore's central bank pulled back its full-year inflation outlook on Friday, as July figures fell below expectations to a three-year low.

site_title: Turmoil in HK's streets, markets keeps investors worried about prospects
summary: Hong Kong's financial markets are experiencing volatility, with the Hang Seng Index losing nearly 9% since June, on track for its worst quarter in four years. Concerns over the impact of the trade war, protests, and a weak yuan on corporate earnings and the economy are driving investors' worries. The local dollar is returning to its weak end of its trading band, and the central bank may need to defend the peg, tightening liquidity and sparking interest rates. Despite some encouraging signs, such as mainland Chinese investors pouring in funds, analysts remain cautious about investing in Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: The protests at times have brought parts of Hong Kong - including Chek Lap Kok International Airport - to a standstill.

site_title: Oil spills into US-China trade war, prices slump
summary: China imposed 5% tariffs on US crude oil imports, starting Sept 1, amid the escalating US-China trade war. Oil prices fell nearly 4% to two-week lows due to global demand slowdown worries. site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday

site_title: Gold eases bullish gains over US monetary policy uncertainties
summary: Gold prices eased due to heightened market optimism and US monetary policy uncertainties. Investors will focus on Fed Chairman Jerome Powell's speech at the Jackson Hole summit for guidance on US monetary policy, which may erode bullish gains in gold for the near term.

site_title: Britain wants US trade deal quickly, but terms have to be right: UK spokesman
summary: Britain is seeking a quick trade deal with the US, but the terms must be favorable to both sides. Ahead of a G7 summit, Prime Minister Boris Johnson will meet with President Trump to discuss trade, Brexit, and international issues. The UK wants a deal that works for both countries, with Johnson emphasizing the importance of a mutually beneficial agreement. The talks are expected to be positive, but the outcome will depend on the terms of the deal.

site_title: A luxury home builder's woes show rising fears of US slowdown
summary: Toll Brothers, the nation's largest publicly traded luxury home builder, reported a 3% decline in purchase agreements from a year earlier, worse than expected. The company's orders in California fell 36% due to low mortgage rates and high prices, while purchases of previously owned US homes rose to a five-month high in July. The decline highlights a shift in the US housing market, with expensive markets experiencing a drop-off in demand, while entry-level homebuilders are better positioned to weather the shift.

site_title: China likely to cut MLF rate by mid-Sept ahead of US Fed review
summary: China is likely to keep its key loan rate steady next week, but a cut is expected by mid-September after the US Federal Reserve's policy review, as Beijing steps up stimulus efforts to support growth amid the intensifying trade dispute. Analysts predict a 10 basis-point cut in the People's Bank of China's medium-term lending facility (MLF) rate, which will signal a reduction in the new Loan Prime Rate (LPR). A cut is expected to occur before the Fed's September 17-18 policy meeting.

site_title: Scarlett Johansson tops Forbes best-paid actress list for second year
summary: Scarlett Johansson tops Forbes' best-paid actress list for the second year in a row, earning $56 million, largely due to the success of "Avengers: Endgame."
