site_title: Popeyes spicy chicken sandwich launch heats up social media
summary: Popeyes' launch of its spicy chicken sandwich on August 12 drew significant attention on social media, with over 85,000 retweets and 300,000 likes after a rival chain, Chick-fil-A, subtly jabbed at its recipe. The move is seen as a potential game-changer for the Cajun-inspired fast food chain, which now has more visibility and could attract new customers. Experts estimate Popeyes received $23.25 million in equivalent ad value, a significant increase from what the company would have spent on a multi-million dollar ad campaign to achieve similar engagement.

site_title: Teen tennis sensation Gauff eyes more glory at US Open
summary: 15-year-old tennis sensation Cori "Coco" Gauff is set to make a name for herself at the US Open, with expectations high on her shoulders. As the reigning champion Naomi Osaka prepares to defend her title, Gauff's impressive junior career and recent WTA doubles title have drawn comparisons to tennis legends. Gauff's talent, power, and speed have been praised by experts, with former US Open champion Andy Roddick calling her "the real deal." Despite her young age, Gauff has already gained significant attention, including a spot on the cover of Teen Vogue and an audience with former first lady Michelle Obama.

site_title: China demand for petrochemicals dwindles with trade war
summary: China's demand for petrochemicals has dwindled due to the ongoing trade war with the US, leading to a surplus of 3 million tonnes by the end of 2020. New production lines in China, South Korea, and Malaysia will further exacerbate the issue, with the US and Middle East accounting for over half of the new volumes. This has pushed profit margins for petrochemical makers to their narrowest in around seven years, with prices for polyethylene and other plastics falling to historic lows.

site_title: Ayondo inks convertible note deals worth up to S$9.9m, given extensions to release Q2, Q3 results
summary: Ayondo, a CATALIST-listed Singapore company, has entered into three convertible note agreements worth up to S$9.9 million. The notes will be used for working capital purposes and will bear a maximum simple interest rate of 12% per annum. The agreements were signed with Golden Nugget Jinzhuan Limited and Japanese investor Mamoru Taniya, with proceeds to be allocated towards working capital, loan repayment, business expansion, and cost expenses. Ayondo has also received a three-month extension to release its second-quarter results to Nov 14 from Aug 14.

site_title: Remember when governments used to run their economies?
summary: Governments are shifting back to fiscal policy to stimulate economies, after a decade of relying on monetary policy. This shift comes as central banks face limited room to cut interest rates in a severe downturn, and as the effectiveness of monetary policy has been questioned. Fiscal policy, which involves government spending and taxation, is seen as a more targeted and equitable way to boost economic growth, particularly in addressing inequality. Germany and the US are already exploring fiscal stimulus options, with the US considering a payroll tax cut, as policymakers recognize the limitations of monetary policy and the growing popularity of fiscal policy.

images.alt_text: Interest rate cuts and asset purchases from the Federal Reserve (above) in the wake of the great recession didn't prevent millions of workers from losing their jobs and homes, but they allowed investors to raise funds and borrow money cheaply to buy up most of the foreclosed housing inventory in the market at low prices early this decade.

site_title: Keeping an eye on dry eye syndrome
summary: Dry eye syndrome is becoming increasingly common, especially during hot, dry, and hazy weather. The condition, characterized by eye irritation, discomfort, and blurred vision, is often caused by a combination of eye dryness and allergic conjunctivitis. As the world gears up to address global warming and climate change, experts predict an exacerbation of dry eye disease symptoms. Simple measures such as hydration, taking frequent breaks, and avoiding direct drafts can provide relief, while specialist care and treatment may be necessary for more severe cases. The condition can lead to complications and has a significant economic and quality of life burden, making prevention and management strategies crucial.

site_title: Bond market on high alert over 'frickin' expensive' Treasuries
summary: The US Treasury market is on high alert due to concerns over rising volatility and deteriorating market depth following a historic bond rally. Investors are questioning the epic rally, which has driven yields to new lows and fueled the US Treasury market's best performance since the era of quantitative easing. Despite strong performance by trend-following strategies, strategists at Societe Generale warn that a strong performance is usually followed by a reversal. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's speech on Friday may further impact the market, with some expecting another easing in September.

site_title: SPH Reit prices S$300m in 4.1% perpetual securities
summary: SPH Reit has priced S$300 million in 4.1% perpetual securities under its S$1 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme. The securities, with no fixed final redemption date, will confer an annual distribution rate of 4.1% with resets every five years. Net proceeds will be used for financing general working capital, capital expenditure, and corporate requirements. The offering is expected to be completed on August 30. HSBC Singapore and OCBC have been appointed joint lead managers and bookrunners for the offering.

site_title: Median-income among older workers to gain most from changes
summary: Singapore's median-income older workers will benefit most from the government's recent moves to raise the retirement and re-employment ages, as well as CPF contribution rates. By 2030, these workers can expect an enhanced annuity payout of around 22% due to increased savings. Lower-income workers still require support, but the government is also exploring other measures, such as home ownership and retraining programs, to ensure retirement adequacy.

site_title: Argus to launch Singapore bunker fuel derivatives contract on CME
summary: Argus, an oil price reporting agency, is launching a Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME)-listed Singapore marine fuels future contract on Monday, targeting suppliers and shipowners. The 100-tonne contract for high-sulphur fuel oil (HSFO) 380-cSt will settle on Argus HSFO 3.5% delivered bunker assessments, helping manage risk in volatile bunker premiums following the IMO 2020 sulfur cap implementation. The contract is the world's first listed delivered bunker fuel derivatives contract, further solidifying Singapore's position as a financial and physical marine fuels hub.

site_title: UOL Group sells Pan Pacific Suzhou unit, will continue to run hotel
summary: UOL Group is selling its 100% stake in Suzhou Wugong Hotel Co, which owns the 480-room Pan Pacific Suzhou hotel, for a total net cash consideration of 408 million yuan (S$80 million). The sale will not affect UOL's net tangible assets per share and earnings per share for the current financial year. The Pan Pacific Suzhou hotel will continue to operate under a hotel management agreement with the purchaser, allowing UOL's hospitality arm, Pan Pacific Hotels Group, to maintain its presence in the market.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks finish week on positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week on a positive note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.50% to 26,179.33, driven by investor hopes for further interest rate cuts from the Federal Reserve. The Shanghai Composite Index also gained 0.49%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index was barely moved. The positive sentiment was seen as a result of investors looking ahead to a key speech by Jerome Powell later in the day.

site_title: Australia shares post first weekly gain in four, property sector shines
summary: Australia's benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.3% to close at 6,523.10, its first weekly gain in four weeks, driven by significant gains in real estate firms. The sector index gained 2.3% as property stocks like Goodman Group and Dexus rose. The gains were underpinned by the softening of interest rates and the government's focus on stimulating the residential market. Heavyweight financials also gained, while the mining sector declined due to a sixth straight session of losses in gold stocks.

site_title: Facebook's Libra project: a timely wake-up call
summary: Facebook's Libra digital currency project has sparked a critical debate on the current monetary system, which the author argues does not serve the needs of society as a whole. The system excludes 31% of the world's adult population, and payment infrastructure is inefficient and costly. The US dollar's dominance also poses problems for dollar users outside the US. Libra's concept of a basket-backed currency is not new, but its private entity and massive resources could have a significant impact. The author hopes for a wide and deep debate on how to create technology-enabled monetary solutions that better serve humanity, considering governance, client protection, and systemic risk.

images.alt_text: The appropriate response to Libra or the larger crypto phenomenon is to engage in a debate on how to create technology- enabled monetary solutions that better serve humanity.

site_title: Sinking Singapore stocks still seen as bright spot for dividends

site_title: GuocoLand posts 24% rise in Q4 net profit to S$183.7m

site_title: The joy of text
summary: Book editor Benjamin Dreyer's "Dreyer's English: An Utterly Correct Guide to Clarity and Style" aims to help writers improve their writing skills without rigid rules. His book addresses common writing confusions, such as the Oxford comma, and encourages readers to develop a "mindfulness" for proper English. Ultimately, the book emphasizes the importance of adding descriptive terms and phrases to flesh out writing and create a personal style.

site_title: Brazil faces global backlash over Amazon fires
summary: Brazil faces global backlash over Amazon fires, with dozens of fires burning large swaths of the Amazon rainforest. site_title: Athletes can have heart problems too
summary: Athletes can experience heart problems due to intense, long-term exercise. Research suggests a U-shaped curve, where moderate activity reduces heart disease risk, but vigorous exercise may increase it. This phenomenon may be attributed to the heart's response to stress and the potential for overtraining, highlighting the need for a balanced approach to exercise and cardiovascular health.

Singapore shares fell 0.2% on the week, weighed down by financials and dividend effects.

site_title: Amazon to acquire minority stake in an India supermarket chain operator
summary: Amazon is set to acquire a 3.58% minority stake in India's Future Retail, which operates over 1,500 stores and owns supermarket brands like Big Bazaar. The deal values Future Retail at around $8.32 billion, more than double its current market capitalization. The transaction, subject to regulatory approval, gives Amazon a stake in one of India's largest retail chains and marks its second move to acquire a stake in an Indian supermarket store operator.

site_title: Welcome to McDonald's. Would you like a podcast with those fries?
summary: Major companies are creating their own podcasts as a form of brand-building, with some success. Companies like McDonald's, Facebook, Microsoft, and New Balance are producing podcasts on various topics, often using the format of popular podcasts like Serial. These branded podcasts aim to entertain and persuade listeners, and some have broken into iTunes' top-100 chart. Industry experts say that companies have had success with shows that are not explicitly about their products or services, and that transparency is key to avoiding consumer concerns about propaganda.

images.alt_text: The Sauce was a branded podcast that McDonald's paid Gizmodo to produce as a tongue-in-cheek apology to disappointed customers.

site_title: Harvard economist Carmen Reinhart warns Hong Kong could trigger world recession
summary: Harvard economist Carmen Reinhart warns that Hong Kong's ongoing protests could trigger a global recession. The protests, which began nearly three months ago, are pressuring the city's economy, which is already being squeezed by China's economic slowdown and the US-China trade war. Reinhart cites Hong Kong as a concern due to its potential to have global consequences, noting that the protests could have a "tipping point" effect on the world economy. She previously warned of a housing bubble in Hong Kong and emphasizes that the situation can escalate with either a significant or subtle shock.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's rolling political turmoil could prove a tipping point for the world economy, Harvard University economist Carmen Reinhart said.

site_title: Wilmar sets up 4 new subsidiaries, associated firms in China
summary: Wilmar International has established four new subsidiaries and associated companies in China, all owned by its indirect unit Yihai Kerry Arawana Holdings Co. The new companies include Yihai Kerry (Kaiyuan) Oils, Grains & Food Industries Co, which processes soybean powder and corn germ crushing, and WI Kitchen (Shanghai) Food Technology Co, which provides e-commerce technology and services. The move aims to expand Wilmar's presence in China's food processing and logistics sectors.

site_title: China AI startup to file for Hong Kong IPO soon despite protests
summary: China's artificial intelligence startup Megvii is set to file for a Hong Kong IPO, despite ongoing protests in the financial hub, which could raise up to $1 billion. The company, owner of facial-recognition platform Face++, plans to submit an IPO filing to the Hong Kong Stock Exchange as soon as Friday. This move comes as other companies have delayed their Hong Kong IPO ambitions due to the protests. Megvii's IPO filing marks the formal start of the process, which could be months before its actual debut.

site_title: Pine Capital's Greater China chief exits after ACPAM board removal
summary: Pine Capital Group has removed Wang Meng as its head of Greater China, effective August 19, after his removal as ACPAM director at an extraordinary general meeting on August 12. Wang expressed surprise and concerns over the process, stating he was not informed about his removal and was only notified of the EGM result on August 15. He also raised concerns about the financial positions of ACPAM and Pine Capital Shanghai, as well as potential procedural irregularities. The move comes amid ongoing investigations into potential conflicts of interest and lapses in internal control at ACPAM.

site_title: Demand for tech jobs in Singapore grew 20% over last year: report
summary: The demand for technology jobs in Singapore increased by 20% over the past year, according to a report by Michael Page. High demand is seen in specialized e-commerce, digital marketing, and data science roles, while companies seek leaders who can drive digital strategy. The highest-paid roles include chief technology officer (S$22,000/month) and IT director/head of IT security (S$18,000/month). The report also notes that 29% of professionals would switch jobs to develop new skills, and 60% feel positive about the employment market.

site_title: CapitaLand unit prices S$800m 10-year notes at 3.15%
summary: CapitaLand, a subsidiary of CapitaLand, has closed the order book for S$800 million 10-year notes with a coupon rate of 3.15% per annum. The notes are unrated and will be sold at 100% of the principal amount, maturing on Aug 29, 2029. The proceeds will be used for refinancing existing borrowings, financing investments, and general corporate purposes. The issue was oversubscribed, with 96% of the proceeds going to Singapore investors, and was jointly bookrun by DBS and UOB.

site_title: Cordlife extends presence to Bangladesh with appointment of marketing agent
summary: Cordlife Group has appointed Cordcell Bangladesh as its marketing agent to expand its presence in the country. Cordcell, a Bangladesh medical tourism industry player, will provide sales and marketing support for Cordlife's AABB-accredited facility in Kolkata. This marks Cordlife's entry into the 10th country in Asia. The company will focus on Dhaka and Chittagong before expanding to other cities.

site_title: Singapore shares fall on Friday, down 0.2% on the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.6% on Friday, closing at 3,110.35, due to declines in financials and counters going ex-dividend. The market was cautious ahead of US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's speech in Jackson Hole, with expectations of a dovish tone and potential September rate cut. Trading volume was 1.07 billion securities, with 23 of 30 counters closing in the red. Notable decliners included Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and Jardine counters, while Thai Beverage extended its gains to close 0.5% higher.

site_title: Hong Kong braces for fresh protests, Canada stops staff travel to mainland China
summary: Hong Kong prepares for fresh anti-government protests and a stress test of its airport this weekend. Protests show no signs of abating, and diplomatic tensions between China and Western nations rise. Canada has suspended staff travel to mainland China, following the detention of a British Consulate employee in China. The Canadian move comes amid rising pressure on policymakers due to China's slowing GDP growth.

site_title: Demand for tech jobs in Singapore grew 20% over last year: report
summary: The demand for tech jobs in Singapore has increased by 20% over the past year, according to a recent report by Michael Page. High demand is seen in specialized e-commerce, digital marketing, and data science talent, with a shortage of supply. Top-paid roles include chief technology officer (S$22,000/month) and IT director or head of IT security (S$18,000/month). The report highlights the need for niche skills and the importance of workplace training and development to attract and retain top talent.

images.alt_text: The highest paid roles in the technology sector include chief technology officer, with an average monthly salary of S$22,000, followed by an IT director or head of IT security, who earns an average of S$18,000.

site_title: European stock markets rise at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.5% at 7,166.36 points. The eurozone's Frankfurt DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also gained 0.5% to 11,806.79 and 5,413.32 points, respectively. The rally was driven by gains in mining and healthcare shares, with US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: E-commerce upstart Pinduoduo wants its data back from Alibaba
summary: Pinduoduo, China's No 3 e-commerce platform, is taking back control of its data from Alibaba by developing its own shipping information technology. The move aims to free itself from dependence on Alibaba's Cainiao unit and presents a threat to Alibaba's dominance of Chinese e-commerce shipping data. Pinduoduo has successfully migrated almost all its orders to its new system, which shares real-time locations and unique product identifiers between merchants, couriers, and shoppers. The company plans to monetize its data in the long run, potentially lowering delivery costs for merchants.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close higher ahead of Fed speech
summary: Tokyo shares rose 0.40% to 20,710.91, supported by gains in Chinese shares. Investors await US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's speech, despite criticism from US President Donald Trump. The broader Topix index also gained 0.28% to 1,502.25. Major shares, such as Sony and Toyota, moved in the positive direction, while SoftBank Group declined. Traders remain in a wait-and-see mode ahead of Powell's speech, which may impact market sentiment.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,108.95, down 0.6% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) resumed trading at 3,108.95, down 18.79 points or 0.6% on Friday, amid a lacklustre US market session ahead of Jerome Powell's speech. Regional peers fared better, with Australia, China, and Hong Kong higher.

site_title: Another WeWork rival lures cash, tapping Brookfield and Equinox
summary: Industrious, a US-based coworking startup, has raised $80 million in funding from investors including Brookfield Properties, Equinox, and the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board. The company, which operates about 80 locations, aims to partner with landlords to manage their buildings as coworking spaces, avoiding long-term leases. This strategy is seen as more sustainable and less risky, allowing Industrious to focus on growth and potentially become profitable by early next year. The funding will be used to expand to new cities and build up its presence in existing markets.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares flat ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Powell's speech
summary: Tokyo shares remained flat ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Powell's speech, with the Nikkei 225 index slipping 0.01% and the Topix index adding 0.08%. Investors await Powell's address amid pressure from the White House to cut rates.

site_title: Getting smarter with smart manufacturing
summary: The Asia-Pacific manufacturing sector is embracing Industry 4.0, driven by emerging technologies like the Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) and artificial intelligence (AI). Companies are adopting smart manufacturing and smart factories, but face challenges such as data silos, lack of digital transformation, and insufficient skills. To overcome these challenges, companies must commit to a long-term plan, adopt a step-by-step approach, and prioritize secure management buy-in, break down silos through IT infrastructure, and optimize processes with AI. The journey to becoming a smart factory requires retraining and reskilling employees, sourcing new talent, and assessing the value of technologies.

site_title: July price increase the slowest in 3 years; MAS tweaks core inflation outlook
summary: Singapore's inflation cooled in July, with core inflation at 0.8%, its weakest showing since April 2016. This led the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to slightly ease its full-year core inflation forecast to 1-2% from 1-3%. The MAS chief economist maintained this forecast despite rejecting off-cycle adjustments to the Singdollar policy. The lower inflation rate was seen as a positive sign for the Singapore economy.

site_title: Australia: Shares set to post first weekly gain in four
summary: Australian shares are set to post their first weekly gain in four, rising 0.3% to 6,522.70, driven by gains in heavyweight financial stocks and real estate firms. The S&P/ASX 200 index is poised to gain 1.8% for the week, following a lack of significant market movements in recent times due to global recession and trade spat fears.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks flat at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened marginally higher on Friday, edging up 9.16 points to 26,057.88, following big losses the day before. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.06% and the Shenzhen Composite Index increased 0.05%. This follows a key speech by Federal Reserve boss Jerome Powell later in the day.

site_title: French winemakers jittery over Trump tariff threats ahead of G-7
summary: French winegrowers are on edge as US President Donald Trump threatens to impose tariffs on French wine in retaliation for the new GAFA tax. The tax aims to plug a loophole allowing US tech giants to pay little in countries where they make significant profits. The G-7 summit is underway, and winegrowers fear consequences from the tax. The French government has yet to respond to Trump's threats, and the outcome remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: French winegrowers are on tenterhooks as they wait to see whether Donald Trump will follow through with his repeated threats to raise tariffs on French wine in retaliation for the new GAFA tax.

site_title: Japan, US negotiators fail to reach agreement on trade, to extend talks
summary: US and Japanese top negotiators failed to reach an agreement on a two-way trade deal, extending talks for another day. Despite marathon four-hour talks, Japanese Economy Minister Toshimitsu Motegi stated that the countries were "getting closer to reach a conclusion" but negotiations were taking time due to the complexity of details affecting both countries' national interests. The bilateral summit is set to take place over the weekend, with the two sides aiming to bring tangible progress to the talks.

site_title: Russia launches floating nuclear reactor in Arctic despite warnings
summary: Russia has launched the world's first floating nuclear reactor, Akademik Lomonosov, in the Arctic despite environmental warnings. The reactor will embark on a 5,000km journey to northeastern Siberia. Nuclear agency Rosatom claims the reactor is a simpler alternative to building on frozen ground and plans to sell similar reactors abroad. The move has raised concerns about environmental risks in the Arctic region.

site_title: Asian petrochemical profits slammed by trade war crossfire, oversupply
summary: Asian petrochemical profits have plummeted due to the trade war's impact on Chinese demand, despite new production lines coming online in China, South Korea, and Malaysia. Global polyethylene output is expected to exceed demand by 3 million tonnes by 2020, driven by US and Middle Eastern production. This oversupply, combined with existing capacity, has led to a significant decline in profits for Asian petrochemical producers.

images.alt_text: Profits from making petrochemicals in Asia have plunged to their lowest in months as the unrelenting trade conflict between Beijing and Washington stifles Chinese demand for chemicals and plastics just as waves of new production start to come on line.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 6.70 points to 1,595.77. The market saw 30.19 million lots traded at RM14.12 million, with 87 losers beating 70 gainers. This comes after a global rally, with the US and EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: Hawker tech startup Kedai Sayur raises US$4m led by East Ventures
summary: Kedai Sayur, an Indonesian startup, has raised US$4 million in funding led by East Ventures. The fresh funds will help the company onboard more vegetable hawkers, extend its supplier networks, and develop its technology. Participating investors include SMDV, Triputra Group, and Multi Persada. The funding aims to accelerate the growth of the startup, which empowers vegetable hawkers using technology.

site_title: Asia: Investors bide time ahead of much-anticipated Powell speech
summary: Asian markets are cautious ahead of Federal Reserve boss Jerome Powell's speech, with investors waiting for an update on monetary policy. Despite a positive start to the week, hopes for further interest rate cuts have tempered, with analysts warning of potential disappointment given the US economy's strong health. The pound has held onto gains from a previous day's rally fueled by Brexit hopes. Investors are also watching GDP data in Singapore and US-EU trade talks, while stocks in Asia and the US edge towards fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Australia corporate watchdog charges Norwegian shipping firm with cartel conduct
summary: Australia's corporate regulator, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC), has charged Norwegian shipping company Wallenius Wilhelmsen Ocean AS with cartel conduct related to the international shipping of vehicles to Australia between June 2011 and July 2012. This is the third prosecution involving an international shipping company with cartel conduct. ACCC Chair Rod Sims stated that the charges are laid under the Competition and Consumer Act. The company has not commented on the charges.

site_title: Turmoil in Hong Kong's streets and markets keeps investors worried
summary: Hong Kong's financial markets are experiencing one of their most volatile periods in years due to ongoing anti-government demonstrations, a weak yuan, and the trade war's impact on corporate earnings and the economy. The Hang Seng Index has lost nearly 9% since June, on track for its worst quarter in four years. Investors remain cautious, with some seeking refuge in mainland Chinese equities. Despite some encouraging signs, such as increased investment from mainland China, the protests' long-term impact on the city's economy and the local dollar's value remains uncertain.

site_title: Japan's SMFG to acquire British asset manager for 20b yen
summary: Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group (SMFG) will acquire British asset manager TT International for approximately 20 billion yen, aiming to attract Japanese investors with expertise in emerging-market equities. This deal follows Japanese banks' shift to asset-based fees due to the Bank of Japan's ultra-low interest rates. SMFG seeks to bolster its revenue streams in a low-return environment.

site_title: New Zealand dollar inches off 3-1/2 yr low after RBNZ comments
summary: The New Zealand dollar rose 0.5% to US$0.6392 after Reserve Bank of New Zealand Governor Adrian Orr expressed satisfaction with the current interest rate level, reducing speculation of a further cut. Orr's comments were seen as a signal that the RBNZ would not ease rates at its September meeting, boosting investor confidence. Meanwhile, retail sales in New Zealand rose 0.2% in real terms, but domestic data pointed to subdued consumer spending and economic growth.

site_title: Hasbro buys Peppa Pig owner in US$4b deal
summary: Hasbro has acquired Entertainment One, the owner of Peppa Pig, in a US$4 billion deal, marking its biggest acquisition ever. The acquisition adds popular kids media properties to Hasbro's portfolio, expanding its presence in TV and movie production. The deal positions Hasbro as a bigger player in the industry, with the added benefit of Entertainment One's scripted and unscripted TV production capabilities. Hasbro's shares slipped in late trading following the announcement.

site_title: New Zealand central bank chief says pleased with current policy
summary: New Zealand Reserve Bank Governor Adrian Orr expressed satisfaction with current policy, citing the recent 50 basis point interest rate cut to 1% as a proactive measure to mitigate potential economic slowdown. The move was interpreted as reducing the likelihood of further policy easing in late September, resulting in a 0.3% rise in the New Zealand dollar.

site_title: US telecom titans and states align to mute "robocalls"
summary: US telecom firms and state attorneys general have agreed on principles to curb illegal "robocalls." A dozen companies, including AT&T, Comcast, and Verizon, will use technology to block automated calls from con artists or dodgy marketers. The principles include tracking down criminals behind frauds employing robocalls and monitoring for robocall traffic. The move aims to reduce the estimated $10.5 billion in US losses from robocalls in 2018-2019.

site_title: Ayondo in convertible note deals worth up to S$9.9m; granted extensions to release Q2, Q3 results
summary: Ayondo, a Catalist-listed company, has entered into three convertible note agreements worth up to S$9.9 million. The notes will be used for working capital purposes, with 39.5% going towards expansion, 30% towards loan repayment, and 30% towards business expansion. The company has also received a three-month extension for releasing its second-quarter results to Nov 14 and a one-month extension for its third-quarter results to Dec 14, citing senior staff turnover and a lack of a dedicated finance team.

site_title: Next US tariffs to drag China expansion below 6%, survey shows
summary: US tariffs on $300 billion of Chinese goods would drag China's annual economic growth below 6%, the slowest expansion since 1990, according to a Bloomberg survey of 14 economists. The tariffs, which would cut up to 0.5 percentage point from GDP expansion, would further slow China's growth, which is already forecast to slow to 6% next year. China's Ministry of Commerce said the impact would be controllable, but warned it would retaliate if the US follows through with new tariffs.

site_title: Japan's July core inflation hovers at 2-yr low, adds pressure on BOJ
summary: Japan's core consumer inflation remained at a 2-year low in July, increasing pressure on the Bank of Japan (BOJ) to expand its stimulus program. The core consumer price index (CPI) rose 0.6% year-on-year, matching economists' estimates. The data suggests the BOJ is behind in achieving its 2% inflation target, with an eight-month export slump due to the US-China trade war and slowing global demand. Expectations for further BOJ easing have grown, with a recent Reuters poll showing a majority of respondents expecting a policy change in the December quarter.

site_title: Lone analyst who cut Cathay to sell says he faces huge pressure
summary: A lone analyst, Zhao Dongchen, has sparked controversy with a "strong sell" rating on Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd, citing poor crisis management and a potential management reshuffle as risks. The analyst, head of equity research at state-run bank Industrial & Commercial Bank of China, faces pressure from the bank and the airline's management, but stands by his report. Cathay's shares have rebounded 6.1% since the report, making it the fifth-best performer among 64 listed global airlines.

site_title: London homes becoming more affordable though few may notice
summary: London's average house prices now stand at 13.1 times average earnings, the lowest in over four years, according to Zoopla. Despite flat prices in the past year, the gap between earnings and prices still needs to close for affordability to improve. Average home prices in London remain high at £483,100, with prices to earnings ratio higher than the 20-year average. Other areas like Cambridge and Oxford are also seeing improvements in affordability, with average homes being 12.2 and 11.9 times the average wage, respectively.

images.alt_text: London homes are becoming more affordable but buyers may not have noticed, according to Zoopla.

site_title: US charges 80 in internet fraud and money laundering scheme
summary: US authorities have charged 80 people, mostly Nigerians, in an internet fraud and money laundering scheme that netted millions of dollars from victims. The suspects allegedly targeted the vulnerable, using various scams to persuade them to send money online. At least $6 million in fraudulently obtained funds were laundered through a network, with attempted thefts totaling $40 million. The FBI warns citizens to be aware of these sophisticated financial schemes to protect themselves from becoming victims.

site_title: Frasers Property to redeem S$600m 4.88% perpetual bonds on Sept 24
summary: Frasers Property is redeeming S$600 million of 4.88% subordinated perpetual bonds on Sept 24, 2019, at 100% of the principal amount.
