summary: European shares fell on Thursday, with the FTSE lagging, amid mixed business growth data and uncertainty over US interest rates. The euro zone saw a marginal recovery in business growth, while factory activity shrank in Japan and the US. Germany's central bank ruled out fiscal stimulus, expecting the economy to shrink again this quarter. The pound's jump dented London stocks, contributing to the downturn.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Kashkari says US shouldn't ease bank capital rules
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis President Neel Kashkari stated that US banks require substantially higher capital than they currently have to mitigate risks. Kashkari emphasized that raising capital requirements is necessary to protect against potential unknowns and scenarios, despite the central bank's ability to never completely eliminate risk. He also highlighted the importance of transparency in leveraged lending, citing the 2008 crisis as a reminder of the need for increased oversight.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis President Neel Kashkari said American banks need substantially higher capital than they have today and that the central bank is closely monitoring risks associated with leveraged lending.

site_title: Battle heating up as exchanges vie for Aramco IPO: sources
summary: Global stock exchanges, including the London Stock Exchange, New York Stock Exchange, and Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing, are competing to host Saudi Aramco's world's biggest-ever initial public offering (IPO), with the oil giant expected to raise up to $100 billion. Top officials from the exchanges have been actively pitching to Aramco officials, with LSE CEO David Schwimmer visiting Saudi Arabia in the past month. Aramco has chosen Lazard Ltd and Moelis & Co to advise on the listing, and has not yet decided on other venues, despite having put its initial IPO plans on hold in 2017.

images.alt_text: The largest global stock exchanges have restarted efforts to court Saudi Aramco as the battle to host the world's biggest-ever initial public offering (IPO) heats up again, people with knowledge of the matter said.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday; STI down 0.1% to 3,124.75
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.1% to 3,124.75. This follows mixed US stocks overnight, ahead of a key Federal Reserve address. Banking stocks were mostly down, while Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust rose 0.8% and Thai Beverage increased 0.5%. Asian equities were mixed, with Japan's Topix up 0.1% and South Korea's Kospi down 0.3%.

site_title: Oil eases as Federal Reserve's Jackson Hole meeting gets underway
summary: Oil prices weakened on Thursday as global economy worries and uncertain US interest rate cuts took center stage. Brent crude settled down 0.6% at $59.92 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 0.6% to $55.35. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's speech at Jackson Hole, Wyoming, is expected to provide insight into the US central bank's monetary easing plans, which could impact oil prices. A weaker US dollar, a key factor in oil prices, has already fallen against a basket of currencies.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to pay US$16m to settle SEC claims
summary: Deutsche Bank AG agreed to pay US$16 million to settle US Securities and Exchange Commission claims that the bank failed to prevent employees from hiring relatives of government officials in Asia-Pacific and Russia to win business, violating the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. The Frankfurt-based bank resolved the allegations without admitting or denying wrongdoing.

site_title: An Arctic saga of profound absurdity in the age of Trumpism
summary: US President Donald Trump sparked controversy during a state visit to the UK, where he proposed purchasing parts of the British monarchy's territory without consulting the UK authorities. The Queen's palace was reportedly prepared for the visit, but Trump's sudden and public suggestion that land could be bought raised eyebrows, with the UK government swiftly denying any intention to sell. The move was seen as a departure from typical diplomatic protocol and a reflection of Trump's unconventional approach to foreign policy.

site_title: Sakae warns of fiscal 2019 loss on S$3.2m impairment charge
summary: Sakae Holdings expects to record a loss for the financial year ended June 30, 2019, due to a goodwill impairment of S$3.2 million related to its purchase of Cocosa Export in 2016. The impairment loss is further exacerbated by an additional S$2.8 million loss under other receivables. This news comes after the group was placed on the Singapore Exchange watch list in June.

site_title: US$3.7m claim against unit to hit Baker Tech's profitability
summary: Baker Technology faces a US$3.7 million claim against its subsidiary CH Offshore, which will impact the company's cash reserves and profitability for the current financial year. The claim, resulting from an arbitration, was awarded 2-1 in favor of the claimants, who are seeking unpaid brokers' commissions and damages. The final amount due will be determined after further submissions to the tribunal, and the board will make necessary announcements to update shareholders.

site_title: Panerai launches new line of diving watches
summary: Panerai has launched a new line of diving watches, the Submersible collection, featuring a unidirectionally rotating bezel and a cushion case. The collection includes three limited-edition models: Chrono Guillaume Nery, Marina Militare Carbotech, and Mike Horn, all water-resistant to 300 meters. These watches are designed with professional diving in mind and offer unique experiences for buyers, such as the Chrono Guillaume Nery, inspired by French free-diving champion Guillaume Nery.

site_title: Google says YouTube campaign targeted Hong Kong protests
summary: YouTube disabled 210 channels it deemed part of a coordinated influence campaign against Hong Kong's pro-democracy protests, following similar actions by Twitter and Facebook. The Chinese government is accused of backing a social media campaign to discredit the movement and sow discord. The campaigns allegedly spread disinformation, comparing protesters to Islamic State militants and alleging they planned to kill people. The actions are seen as part of a broader state-backed information operation.

site_title: Macron backs more Brexit talks but insists no concessions
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron backed holding more Brexit talks, but insisted no concessions would be made, two months before Britain's planned exit. Macron supported an additional month to find a solution on the Irish border issue, echoing German Chancellor Angela Merkel's comments. He also stated the Irish backstop was "indispensable" and that all talks must be based on the withdrawal deal negotiated by Theresa May, repeatedly rejected by the British parliament.

site_title: F P Journe launches new sports line
summary: F P Journe launches a new sports line featuring platinum and red gold models for the Centigraphe and Automatique Reserve watches, marking a major revamp of the LineSport line. The new models feature precious metal cases and bracelets, replacing rubber inserts. This follows the introduction of a titanium version last year. The watches boast chronograph and time-only movements with power reserve and day/night indicators.

site_title: Grand Debut
summary: Seiko marked its 50-year presence in Singapore with the opening of a new flagship boutique and the launch of three Grand Seiko commemorative timepieces. The boutique, located in Takashimaya Shopping Centre, features handcrafted watches that embody the brand's values of high precision, legibility, and durability. The three watches, including a stainless steel dress watch and two sports watches, were unveiled to celebrate the 20th anniversary of the Spring Drive movement, which combines mechanical and electronic watch technologies.

site_title: Pompeo says China's detention of two Canadians is 'wrong'
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo expressed concern over the detention of two Canadians, Michael Kovrig and Michael Spavor, by China, calling it "arbitrary and unacceptable." The detentions, which began in December, follow the arrest of Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou on a US warrant nine days earlier. Pompeo met with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and officials to discuss the situation, with the US seeking the Canadians' release. The detentions were seen as retaliation for the Huawei arrest.

site_title: US and Russia trade barbs at UN over 'new arms race'
summary: US and Russia traded accusations at the UN over a potential new arms race, with Russia accusing the US of violating the INF treaty after the US tested a ground-launched missile. China said it would not participate in any new missile deal. The US claims the test was for a conventional capability, while Russia accused it of provocation. The US wants "serious arms control" that includes China, while Russia is open to dialogue. The tension comes after a deadly explosion at a Russian testing site, which Western experts linked to Moscow's nuclear development.

site_title: G7's Biarritz meet will be heated like the 2018 Canadian summit
summary: G7 leaders meet in Biarritz, France, this weekend, amid expectations of heated debates over trade and policy differences. Last year's Canadian summit showed the group's inability to agree on a communiqué, with US President Donald Trump and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau displaying personal animosity. Trump is likely to raise tensions, calling for Russia's return to the G7, while the group may focus on building consensus on North Korea, Venezuela, and terrorism. Disagreements are expected, particularly over trade, potentially leading to splits among western powers.

site_title: EU set to halt imports of Canadian cherries, other fruits
summary: The European Union is set to halt imports of Canadian cherries and other fresh fruits starting September 1 due to new import requirements related to pests. The Canadian Food Inspection Agency has proposed pest risk mitigation measures to the EU, which may allow exports to resume. Frozen and dried fruit, as well as sea containers with export documents dated before September 1, are exempt from the ban. The move could have serious implications for Canada's 2020 cherry harvest if unresolved. Canada had shipped approximately $3.1 million in cherries to the EU in 2018.

site_title: It's not always excellent to be Jamie Oliver
summary: Jamie Oliver, the famous chef and food activist, has been through a tough time after his restaurant group went into administration, leaving him with significant debt and over 1,000 employees out of work. Despite this, Oliver remains committed to his mission of improving the food system and reducing childhood obesity rates. He has been working on various initiatives, including his Ministry of Food and the 2030 Project, which aims to halve childhood obesity by 2030. Oliver has also seen a resurgence in his career, with his books and social media channels remaining popular, and he has secured endorsement deals with companies like Tesco and Shell.

site_title: Australia to crack down on high-stakes derivatives trading
summary: Australia's market watchdog, ASIC, plans to ban the sale of "binary" options to retail customers and restrict the sale of other high-risk derivative instruments. This move follows a global crackdown on high-stakes financial betting by amateur traders, which has already affected companies such as IG Group Plus500 and Interactive Brokers Group Inc. ASIC estimates that retail client losses from trading binary options were at least A$490 million in 2018. The proposal, open to submissions until Oct 1, aims to protect retail investors from significant detriment.

site_title: UOB expands in Vietnam with Hanoi branch
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has expanded its presence in Vietnam with the opening of its first branch in Hanoi, a year after incorporating its fully-owned subsidiary in the country. The move reflects the bank's commitment to providing financial services to more customers across Vietnam. Vietnam's economy has been boosted by 8% in the last year, making it a key destination for foreign manufacturers. UOB's expansion in Vietnam is seen as a strategic move to support Vietnamese companies and connect them to opportunities across Asia and beyond.

images.alt_text: At the official opening of UOB Hanoi branch are (from left) Jason Yeo, branch director, UOB Hanoi Branch, UOB; Vu Van Chung, deputy director, Foreign Investment Agency; Nguyen Minh Tuan, director, State Bank of Vietnam Hanoi; Wee Ee Cheong, deputy chairman and group chief executive officer of UOB; Catherine Wong, Singapore's ambassador to Vietnam; Victor Ngo, head of Group Compliance, UOB, and chairman of UOB Vietnam; and Harry Loh, CEO, UOB Vietnam.

site_title: Tissot is the name of affordable luxury
summary: Tissot, a Swiss watch brand, defies the traditional luxury watch industry's pricing rule, which states that longer-established brands often come with higher prices due to their heritage and history. Despite being one of the oldest brands in the Swatch group, Tissot prioritizes affordability, offering high-quality watches priced under $1,000. The brand has introduced innovations such as the world's first anti-magnetic watch and the first tactile watch, showcasing its commitment to "innovations by tradition."

site_title: Tech giants enjoy permanent tax haven status, says Macron
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron criticized a "crazy" system that gives tech giants a "permanent tax haven status." Macron defended a global tax on tech giants at the G-7 meeting, criticizing the firms for not contributing to the funding of the common good. Macron discussed the issue with US President Donald Trump, who has opposed a French law taxing digital companies, and France has proposed an international agreement to include all OECD countries by the end of 2020.

site_title: Canada says no to Russia rejoining G-8
summary: Canada's Foreign Minister Chrystia Freeland stated that Russia's rejoining the G-8 is unlikely unless it leaves Ukraine. The US President Donald Trump had appealed for Russia's return. Freeland emphasized the importance of Russia's commitment to democracy and the rule of law. The G-7 meeting in France this weekend will discuss Russia's potential membership.

images.alt_text: Canada is opposed to Russia rejoining the G-8 unless it leaves Ukraine, Foreign Minister Chrystia Freeland said Thursday, rejecting an appeal from US President Donald Trump.

site_title: Behind The Bamboo Veil
summary: A Singaporean family of three commissioned architect Robin Tan to redesign their 15-year-old semi-detached home. Inspired by the Nezu Museum's bamboo facade in Tokyo, Tan created a unique bamboo screen that wraps around the house, providing shade, privacy, and flexibility for natural ventilation. The design also features a spacious ground floor for gatherings, a rooftop garden, and an attic for a study and chill-out area. The project took two years to complete and has exceeded the family's expectations, offering a modern tropical home that responds to Singapore's dense urban environment.

site_title: Cautious trading ahead of Jackson Hole
summary: The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) gained 5.17 points or 0.2% to close at 3,127.74, despite the US Federal Reserve's minutes from its July meeting, which suggested limited dovishness. Markets in Australia, China, Japan, and Malaysia rose, while Hong Kong and South Korea fell. Analysts say the mood in Asian markets is "very capricious" with a "risk-off" note, but the US economy's resilient growth despite global headwinds has helped maintain investor confidence.

site_title: Seven-seater SUVs herald the age of family planning for carmakers
summary: The seven-seater SUV segment is gaining popularity among carmakers, with many brands expanding their offerings to cater to the growing demand for family-friendly vehicles. Land Rover, Mercedes-Benz, and Volvo are among those introducing new seven-seat models, while others like Audi, Mazda, Hyundai, and Kia are also offering seven-seater SUVs. These vehicles offer increased space, comfort, and versatility, making them attractive to modern families. As the market continues to evolve, carmakers are focusing on creating more practical and convenient solutions for families, with features such as third-row seating, foldable seats, and advanced technology.

images.alt_text: While MPVs have been in steady decline, with no more than a handful of choices available today, seven-seater SUVs are everywhere.
While MPVs have been in steady decline, with no more than a handful of choices available today, seven-seater SUVs are everywhere.

site_title: Three South Koreans killed in Hungary train-car crash
summary: Three South Koreans were killed in a train-car crash in northern Hungary on Wednesday, near the Danube river. The accident occurred at a rail-crossing in the tourist area of Kismaros, approximately 55km north of Budapest. Hungarian police confirmed all three victims were South Korean, but did not provide further details on their identities or if they were tourists. The incident is currently under investigation.

site_title: The epitome of Swiss watchmaking
summary: Chopard's LUC collection is a premium Swiss watch line that epitomizes the highest standard of Swiss watchmaking. The collection features innovative high complications, meticulous workmanship, and elegance. Three new timepieces, LUC Flying T Twin, LUC XP Espirit de Fleurier Peony, and LUC Quattro, showcase exceptional craftsmanship and design. The LUC Flying T Twin boasts a flying tourbillon, while the LUC XP Espirit de Fleurier Peony features a peony motif on its dial. The LUC Quattro is a limited edition with a generous power reserve of nine days.

site_title: Airbus A380s face urgent checks after cracked part is recovered
summary: Airbus A380s are facing urgent checks after a cracked part, recovered from a 2017 Air France engine blast, was found to have a "sub-surface fatigue crack". The investigation, focusing on a possible manufacturing flaw, will trigger checks on dozens of the superjumbos that have flown over a certain number of flights. The checks, to be carried out urgently, will affect airlines such as Emirates, Qatar Airways, and Etihad, which operate the A380 with Engine Alliance powerplants. The incident is not related to a recent engine failure that killed 111 people in 1989.

site_title: Indonesia surprises with second interest rate cut in 2 months
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, cut interest rates for a second month in two, lowering the seven-day reverse repurchase rate by 25 basis points to 5.5% to spur economic growth amid a global slowdown and trade war. The move was seen as a pre-emptive measure to push economic growth momentum, and Governor Perry Warjiyo said it would retain the attractive yield on domestic assets. The rate cut aims to stimulate Indonesia's economy, which grew at a two-year low in the second quarter, and complements President Joko Widodo's plans to boost growth to 5.3% next year.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit to issue new units to fund Australia property buy
summary: Soilbuild Reit has launched a non-renounceable preferential offering to raise S$101.8 million to fund an Australia property acquisition. The Reit will issue 192.1 million new units at S$0.53 per unit, offering 18 new units for every 100 existing units. About S$99.6 million will fund the acquisition of a multi-tenanted office in Adelaide for A$134.22 million. The remaining proceeds will cover related fees and expenses. The offering is fully underwritten by joint underwriters, with Lim Chap Huat and his family providing an irrevocable undertaking for their total provisional allotment.

site_title: Tiffin Room's multi-layered spread
summary: The Tiffin Room at Raffles Hotel in Singapore offers a luxurious dining experience with a focus on North Indian cuisine. The restaurant serves traditional dishes with a modern twist, such as crispy papadums and flavorful curries. The menu features a range of options, including the Maharaja Kebab Platter and the signature dabba, which offers a variety of meats, seafood, or vegetables. The restaurant's interior decor is sumptuous and evokes the splendor of a bygone era. Overall, the Tiffin Room is a multi-layered experience that offers something for every palate.

site_title: Evolution of Omega's Moon Watch
summary: The Omega Speedmaster, also known as the "Moon Watch," has a rich history dating back to 1957. Initially designed for auto racing teams and engineers, it was later adopted by NASA as the standard issue watch for Apollo astronauts. The first watch to be worn on the moon was not on Neil Armstrong's wrist but on Buzz Aldrin's. Over the years, the Speedmaster underwent several design changes, introducing new features such as the "baton" hands and twisted lugs. The watch was first flight-qualified by NASA in 1969 and has since become synonymous with space exploration, with its design remaining largely unchanged to this day.

site_title: HSBC mulls bid for Aviva's Asian assets in diversity push: sources
summary: HSBC is considering a bid for Aviva's Asian assets, aiming to diversify its business in the region. A deal would bolster HSBC's insurance presence in Singapore and parts of South-east Asia. The bank is in the early stages of weighing an offer for at least part of Aviva's Asian business. This move would help HSBC expand its insurance operations in the region and potentially gain a competitive edge.

site_title: Microplastics in drinking water not a health risk for now: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has concluded that microplastics in drinking water are not yet a health risk, but emphasized the need for further research. Data on microplastics in drinking water is limited, making it difficult to analyze results. The WHO urges policymakers and the public to reduce plastic pollution to minimize human exposure to microplastics. Measures such as wastewater treatment can remove up to 90% of microplastics, also addressing faecally contaminated water issues.

site_title: Trump attacks Ford Motor for not backing fuel economy rollback
summary: US President Donald Trump has attacked Ford Motor Co for not backing his administration's plan to roll back Obama-era fuel efficiency rules, singling out the carmaker for a voluntary agreement with California on stricter fuel economy standards. Ford is one of four carmakers defying the administration's effort to strip California of its right to set its own climate change standards. The company claims it is focused on affordability while acting to protect the environment.

site_title: A German icon turns 25
summary: The A Lange & Sohne Lange 1 is celebrating its 25th anniversary, still revered for its unique design and innovative features. The watch's large date, inspired by the Dresden Semper Opera House, has become a classic in watchmaking. Its unconventional dial layout and lavishly finished movement have set new trends in timepiece design. The Lange 1 remains a sought-after watch among connoisseurs, symbolizing A Lange & Sohne's commitment to excellence.

images.alt_text: Above left: The Lange 1 Moon Phase 25th Anniversary offers a new way of depicting the moon phases by pairing the moon phase display with a day-night indicator. Above right: The Lange 1 Timezone 25th Anniversary offers travellers clearly legible double time indication.

(Left) The Lange 1 25th Anniversary features a second case-back cover engraved with an image of Lange's HQ dating back to 1873. (Right) The Little Lange 1 25th Anniversary is the smallest model in the Lange 1 family.

Above left: The Grand Lange 1 Moon Phase 25th Anniversary has a handengraved lunar disc in solid white gold - a first for a Lange watch. Above right: The Lange 1 Tourbillon Perpetual Calendar 25th Anniversary is the most complicated model in the Lange 1 family.
The Grand Lange 1 25th Anniversary is a larger version of the Lange 1.

site_title: Showing time
summary: This year marks significant anniversaries for watchmaking, with Omega's Speedmaster marking 50 years since the first moon landing, Zenith's El Primero celebrating its 50th year as the world's first automatic chronograph movement, and A Lange & Sohne's Lange 1 commemorating its 25th anniversary. New watch models with innovative features, such as the Patek Philippe Alarm Travel Time and Piaget's Altiplano Ultimate Concept, are also being introduced. Meanwhile, prices for watches have stabilized, with the exception of Ulysse Nardin's Freak, which has seen a decrease.

site_title: Moon watch: 50 years after Apollo 11
summary: Omega celebrates 50 years of the Apollo 11 moon landing with a limited edition Speedmaster chronograph watch, available in gold and stainless steel. The 1,014-piece gold model, released in March, was inspired by the 1969 Speedmaster BA 145.022, which was gifted to NASA staff. The stainless steel model, released in May, is part of a larger 6,966-piece edition. The watches pay tribute to the historic mission that put the first man on the moon.

site_title: Asia's chocolate bonanza sparks quest for locally grown beans
summary: Asia's cocoa industry is facing a shortage of locally grown beans, prompting efforts to increase production in Indonesia, the top supplier and processor in the region. Despite a 30% increase in processing capacity in the past three years, Indonesia's output has declined due to ageing trees, disease, and more profitable alternatives, leading to record bean imports from Africa and Latin America. Industry leaders are working with the government and farmers to promote planting and intercropping, aiming to meet growing demand and reduce reliance on imports.

site_title: Showcasing Hublot-Ferrari partnership
summary: Hublot has signed a 5-year contract with Ferrari to produce a range of timepieces, including the Classic Fusion Ferrari GT, a flyback chronograph with a 45mm diameter case. The watch features a new automatic Unico movement and comes in three limited-edition cases: titanium, King Gold, and 3D carbon. Additionally, Hublot has released the Big Bang Scuderia Ferrari 90th Anniversary and the Big Bang Sang Bleu II, both featuring the Unico movement and limited-edition designs.

site_title: Whisky Most Fowl
summary: Auchentoshan, a Single Scotch malt whisky brand, is launching a pop-up bar at Original Chew Kee Eating House in Singapore. The bar, running from August 22 to August 31, will serve five new cocktails and offer Auchentoshan whisky flights. The campaign aims to celebrate city living and highlight the brand's triple-distilled whisky, known for its smooth and easy-drinking qualities. The pop-up bar will be open every Wednesday to Saturday from 7pm to midnight.

site_title: Complications continue to thrive
summary: Complications continue to emerge in the watchmaking industry, with several innovative timepieces launched this year. The Citizen Caliber 0100 is the most accurate quartz wristwatch, while the Vacheron Constantin Twin Beat Perpetual Calendar boasts a 65-day power reserve. Other notable releases include the Audemars Piguet Royal Oak Perpetual Calendar Ultra-Thin, Patek Philippe's Calatrava Weekly Calendar, and the A Lange & Söhne Zeitwerk Date. Additionally, the Patek Philippe Grandmaster Chime remains the most complex wristwatch ever produced, with 20 complications.

site_title: Mori's new project reaches for new heights in Tokyo skyline
summary: Mori Building is investing 580 billion yen (S$7.5 billion) in a new 20-acre complex in Tokyo's core, set to open in 2023. The complex will feature shops, restaurants, office space, residences, a hotel, and an international school, aiming to become Tokyo's newest landmark. The project, dubbed the Toranomon-Azabudai project, will be connected to two subway stations and feature a 64-storey main tower. Mori's goal is to create a city within a city, catering to foreign businesses and visitors, amidst a thriving Tokyo real estate market with vacancy rates near record lows.

images.alt_text: Mori's properties often cater to foreign businesses and visitors, offering sanctuaries for them to stay, work and shop in a megalopolis that can be difficult to navigate.

site_title: Russia sends Fedor, its first humanoid robot, into space
summary: Russia launched Fedor, its first humanoid robot, into space on Thursday aboard a Soyuz MS-14 spacecraft. The robot will spend 10 days on the International Space Station, learning to assist astronauts and test emergency rescue systems. Fedor, standing 1.80 meters tall, has been adapted for space travel and will perform tasks such as opening a bottle of water in low gravity. The robot's capabilities include copying human movements, potentially useful for future spacewalks and rescue missions.

site_title: SMEs going global open door for banks to grow corporate credit cards
summary: Local SMEs venturing overseas has caught the attention of several banks, with American Express and Singapore Airlines surveying SME owners' travel habits. The results show that SME bosses travel at least once every six weeks for business, with 70% having employees traveling two or more times per month. This trend presents an opportunity for banks to expand their corporate credit card offerings, providing personal perks to SME bosses while managing and reconciling business expenses. The development is seen as a potential growth area for banks in the global market.

site_title: Montblanc's 1858 line goes green
summary: Montblanc's 1858 line has gone green, incorporating eco-friendly materials and production methods. This collection is a nod to Minerva's heritage, which has specialized in professional watches and mechanical stopwatches since 1858. Minerva's stopwatches played a significant role in the evolution of modern-day car racing, measuring time accurately to 1/100th of a second in 1916.

site_title: Singapore one of 4 markets to post double-digit growth in Swiss watch imports in H1
summary: Singapore's market for Swiss watches experienced a 12.6% increase in the first half of 2019, reaching 599.5 million Swiss francs (S$845.3 million), making it the 6th largest market for Swiss watches globally. This growth contrasts with a 1.4% increase in global Swiss watch exports.

site_title: China plays fast catch-up with the global ESG wave
summary: China is rapidly catching up with the global environmental, social, and governance (ESG) movement, with 25% of professionally managed assets now invested according to ESG criteria. The country is playing catch-up with speed, driven by government regulation, internationalization of capital markets, and a growing asset management industry. China's corporations are transitioning from a "box-ticking" approach to ESG compliance, with 3,000 listed companies and bond issuers set to make mandatory ESG disclosures next year. The country is also harmonizing its sustainability guidelines with international standards, with seven of its largest banks signing up to the Green Investment Principles.

site_title: El Primero story to be told at mock-up factory at Ngee Ann City
summary: A mock-up factory at Ngee Ann City's Civic Plaza in Singapore will showcase the 50-year history of Zenith's El Primero automatic chronograph movement. The immersive pop-up exhibition, "A Star Through Time," will feature vintage El Primero pieces, interactive displays, and the Le Monde Etoile showcase, highlighting Zenith's heritage and innovation. The exhibition will be open to the public from August 28 to September 1.

site_title: More notables of 2019
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

In 2019, notable watch releases included the Audemars Piguet Code 11.59 Perpetual Calendar, IWC Schaffhausen's Big Pilot's Watch Perpetual Calendar Spitfire, and Hermes' Arceau L'heure la lune. The Audemars Piguet watch features a moon indication complication, while the IWC watch has a bronze case and olive green dial. The Hermes watch features floating lacquer sub-dials and a pair of fixed mother-of-pearl moons. These watches showcase intricate craftsmanship and innovative timekeeping complications. Additionally, other notable releases included the Puma and Adidas running shoe revival and the expansion plans of IHH hospital operator into Indonesia and Vietnam.

site_title: F1 Headliners
summary: The Singapore Grand Prix is set to take place from Sep 20-22, featuring a diverse lineup of artists including Muse, Red Hot Chili Peppers, and Gwen Stefani. Lighthouse Family, a British duo that rose to fame in the 1990s, and The Ramona Flowers, an indie-synth quintet, have been added to the bill. The event will be held at the Marina Bay Street Circuit.

site_title: Accounting bodies, IMDA roll out plan to help smaller firms adopt technology
summary: Singapore's accountancy sector has launched an industry digital plan (IDP) to help smaller firms adopt technology, focusing on enhancing digital skills, promoting technology adoption, and developing accounting innovations. The plan aims to support the sector's digital transformation and competitiveness, with a digital roadmap providing guidance for small and medium-sized practices (SMPs) and employee training to undergo at each stage of their digital development. The IDP is part of a broader effort to develop Singapore into a leading global accountancy hub.

site_title: BT journalist Marissa Lee wins SGX Orb Award
summary: Journalist Marissa Lee from The Business Times won the SGX Orb Award in the "The Hidden Gem" category for her report on Isetan's need for more than a store refresh. This is her second win in the category, following her previous win for a report on Creative's Super X-Fi headphone. The awards, which recognize broader, deeper financial news coverage, were announced at SGX's annual media appreciation night.

site_title: Euro slips as PMIs signal gloomy outlook
summary: The euro fell 0.1% to US$1.1072, nearing a three-week low, as eurozone business growth picked up but trade war fears and a decline in China's currency knocked future expectations to their weakest in over six years. The Chinese yuan fell to an 11-year low against the dollar, and Asian currencies also declined, with the yen advancing 0.3% and the Australian dollar weakening 0.2%. Investors attributed the decline to trade tension between the US and China and the Fed's reluctance to cut interest rates.

site_title: Two floors at Southpoint sold for S$78.4m
summary: Two floors of the 16-storey Southpoint office building in Singapore have sold for S$78.4 million, or S$2,444 per square foot. A pair of freehold shophouses at East Coast Road sold for S$17.28 million to Cheong Keng Hooi, whose family developed International Plaza. The sales reflect significant investment in the area, particularly in the Greater Southern Waterfront.

site_title: Indians pawning family gold amid credit crunch
summary: In India, a credit crunch and bad debt have led to a surge in demand for cash, prompting many to pawn their family gold for loans. Desperate farmers like Babasaheb Mandlik, who pawns 70 grammes of gold for 150,000 rupees, are taking this drastic measure. Domestic gold prices have risen over a fifth this year, making gold loans more lucrative, with shadow lenders like Muthoot Fincorp seeing a 6.6% increase in gold loans. The trend has also led to restrictions and higher borrowing costs for lenders, with some imposing loan limits and increasing costs.

site_title: New academy to equip workers in environmental services
summary: A new training academy, initiated by WIS Holdings, aims to equip workers in environmental services with technology training, benefiting other companies in the industry. The academy's launch was announced by Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Chee Hong Tat, emphasizing the importance of people-led transformation in the industry. The move follows the evolution of environmental services, which has been driven by technological advancements and manpower constraints.

site_title: Delaying retirement and higher CPF contribution rates good for workers
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced plans to extend retirement age to 65 by 2030 and re-employment age to 70 by 2030. Retirement age will be phased in stages, starting from 62 to 63 in 2022. Additionally, CPF contribution rates for workers aged 55-60 will rise by 11 percentage points to 37% over the next 10 years. This move aims to promote financial adequacy in retirement and enable workers to stay active and engaged, enhancing overall health.

site_title: Rolex salutes sailing ties with Yacht-Master 42
summary: Rolex has launched the Yacht-Master 42, a watch designed specifically for sailors, 27 years after its predecessor, the Yacht-Master, was introduced in 1992. The new model features a 42mm wide case, a bidirectional rotatable bezel, and a new advanced movement with a 70-hour power reserve. The watch is water-resistant and features a matt black ceramic bezel that complements the black lacquer dial. This launch marks Rolex's ties with sailing, with the brand sponsoring about 15 major races globally.

site_title: Market Talk
summary: A young chef-author pays tribute to the traditional "wet market" in a new book, highlighting the institution's cultural significance. The article discusses how modern Singaporeans prefer online shopping and delivery services, and how the wet market's value lies in its community and cultural heritage. The author argues that the wet market's revival is essential for preserving Singapore's culinary identity and community spirit.

site_title: Jay Inslee pulls out of race for US presidency
summary: Washington state Governor Jay Inslee has dropped out of the 2020 US presidential race, citing lack of support and inability to compete for the Democratic nomination. Inslee, a climate change advocate, had argued that addressing the issue should be the top priority. Despite releasing a comprehensive plan and garnering significant attention from other candidates, he struggled to gain name recognition and support, with polling averages at 0.2% or lower. Inslee will not seek re-election as governor and expressed confidence in the party's ability to unify behind a nominee.

site_title: Five new timepieces join the presidents' watch line
summary: Rolex has introduced five new timepieces to its Presidents' watch line, including the Day-Date 36, which features distinctive new dials and gem-set bezels. The new watches join a collection that has been worn by famous individuals such as Marilyn Monroe, John F. Kennedy, and Roger Federer. The Day-Date 36 boasts a 70-hour power reserve and is certified as a Superlative Chronometer, with precision to within two seconds per day. The watches are available in 18-carat yellow, white, or Everose gold, with precious metal cases and the iconic three-link President bracelet.

site_title: Social responsibility won't save corporate America
summary: The Business Roundtable's statement on corporate purpose aims to balance shareholder interests with those of stakeholders, but its vagueness and lack of specific targets raise concerns about its effectiveness. This move is seen as a public relations exercise to preempt federal regulation, rather than a genuine attempt to change corporate behavior. The statement's failure to address issues like executive compensation and efficiency goals is also a concern. Historically, corporate social responsibility initiatives have been met with limited success, and the article suggests that a more effective approach might be to assign large social responsibilities to the public sector.

site_title: 'Productive longevity' is behind proposals for older workers
summary: Singapore is proposing a "productive longevity" vision, where older workers continue to contribute to the economy, with plans to raise retirement and re-employment ages to 65 and 70, respectively, by 2030. Minister for Manpower Josephine Teo emphasized that this is a political, social, and economic choice, aiming to treat the aging workforce as an opportunity rather than a burden. The government will support workers and businesses through a package of measures, including wage offsets and transition support, to help them adapt to the changes.

site_title: Magic In The Dark
summary: The Singapore Night Festival is returning with a focus on myth and folklore, particularly the Ramayana epic. The festival will feature various art forms, including dance, drama, puppetry, and projection mapping, showcasing the story of Rama's quest to save his wife from the demon king Raavana. The event will also include international street acts, live bands, and interactive light installations, with most events being free. The festival runs from August 23 to 31 at the Bras Basah and Bugis district.

site_title: Shopee leads region's e-commerce user activity in Q2: iPrice
summary: Shopee led Southeast Asia's e-commerce user activity in Q2 2019, with the most monthly active app users and heaviest web traffic, according to iPrice. The company's marketing and entertainment efforts paid off, with a 200.2 million average monthly web visits. However, Shopee continued to incur multi-million dollar losses, prioritizing user growth over monetization, with an adjusted Ebitda loss of US$248.3 million.

images.alt_text: According to web analytics service SimilarWeb, Shopee's average monthly web visits was 200.2 million.

site_title: Amazon, Microsoft may be putting world at risk of killer AI: report
summary: Amazon and Microsoft are at risk of contributing to a global AI arms race, according to a report by Dutch NGO Pax. The companies, along with Intel, are developing lethal autonomous technology and working on military projects, sparking ethical concerns. A third revolution in warfare, after gunpowder and the atomic bomb, could be triggered by AI-powered weapon systems. Companies like Google and Softbank are taking steps to abstain from contributing to lethal autonomous technology, while experts warn that autonomous weapons will become "scalable weapons of mass destruction."

site_title: Bibi looks to Sept 17 - and also to Nov 2020
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is expected to win a fifth term in office, potentially becoming the longest-serving premier in Israeli history. His party, Likud, is likely to form a coalition with the centrist Kahol-Lavan party, with Netanyahu possibly setting up a national-unity government. Netanyahu's popularity stems from his economic growth and security record, but he faces corruption scandals and criticism from the left. His close ties with US President Donald Trump, who is a key ally, are also a factor in his expected win. However, if Trump loses the 2020 US presidential election, Netanyahu's relationship with the US may be significantly impacted.

images.alt_text: Election banners in the Likud Party's headquarters in Tel Aviv trumpet Benjamin Netanyahu's key allies across the world.

site_title: G-Shock goes luxe
summary: Casio has released a luxury G-Shock watch, the G-D5000-9, priced at S$100,000, making it the most expensive G-Shock ever. The watch features 18-carat gold and is limited to 35 pieces worldwide. A more affordable version, the GMW-B5000V, is also available for S$1,349. The MR-G series, Casio's top-of-the-line G-Shock, has also been released, featuring a production run of 300 pieces and hand-finished by master craftsmen from the Gassan family of swordsmiths.

site_title: Cartier's ever-evolving timepieces
summary: Cartier has unveiled its new 2019 timepieces, featuring the Panthere de Cartier, Santos de Cartier, and Baignoire collections. The Panthere de Cartier includes the manchette and mini watch, with a flowing, silky bracelet and exaggerated jewels. The Santos-Dumont watch features an understated design with a beaded crown and automatic movement, while the Baignoire has been redesigned with a gold three-tiered case and dramatic design elements, available in 18k gold and diamond-set versions.

site_title: Tudor continues to expand its Black Bay line
summary: Tudor has introduced the Black Bay PO1, a new addition to its Black Bay line inspired by a 1967 US Navy prototype watch. The PO1 features a 42mm stainless steel case, a bidirectional rotating bezel, and a waterproof depth of 200 meters. Powered by a Tudor "Manufacture" automatic movement, the watch has a 70-hour power reserve. This is part of Tudor's expansion of its Black Bay line, which also includes the Black Bay Chrono S&G and Black Bay Bronze models.

site_title: From wild Maine blueberries comes a buzzworthy new bubbly
summary: A California winemaker, Michael Terrien, is creating a sparkling wine from wild Maine blueberries to help sustain the state's struggling blueberry farmers. Terrien, who grew up in Maine, has been perfecting his Bluet wine recipe over the past five years, using a combination of bottle fermentation and carbonation to produce a dry and savoury drink. The wine's unique flavour profile is said to capture the essence of the wild blueberries, which are Maine's official state berry.

site_title: Very rare timepieces
summary: Swiss watch company H Moser & Cie produces unique, handcrafted timepieces with in-house movements. The company, known for its rare watches, boasts a range of collections, including Endeavour, Venturer, Pioneer, Swiss Alp Watch, and Heritage. Recent releases include the Venturer Concept Vantablack, Endeavour Concept Minute Repeater Tourbillon, and Heritage Tourbillon Funky Blue, each featuring intricate complications and minimalist designs. The company's commitment to craftsmanship and innovation is evident in its focus on creating better watches.

site_title: Eat, Drink, Play in Margaret River
summary: Margaret River, a region in southwestern Australia, has been named the top destination in Asia Pacific for 2019 by Lonely Planet. The area offers a Mediterranean climate, ideal for wine production, with over 90 cellar doors and 62 five-star rated wineries. Visitors can explore wineries, enjoy local cuisine, and participate in outdoor activities such as cycling and coasteering. Accommodation options range from luxury resorts to boutique hotels, and the region is also known for its gourmet produce, including fresh seasonal fruits and vegetables. With its unique combination of natural beauty, wine, and outdoor activities, Margaret River is an ideal winter destination for Australians.

site_title: Boustead unit wins S$100m energy contract in Europe
summary: Boustead International Heaters, a subsidiary of Boustead Singapore, has secured a S$100 million contract in Europe to design, engineer, and supply waste heat recovery units for a major energy infrastructure development. This contract marks a significant win for the company in the oil & gas industry. The contract's value and scope are not specified in the article.

site_title: JLC law firm downsizes after managing partner Jeffrey Ong's scandal
summary: JLC law firm, once led by managing partner Jeffrey Ong Su Aun, has downsized after he was remanded in custody due to a scandal involving a missing S$33 million escrowed by the firm for Allied Technologies. The firm relocated from UOB Plaza 1 to International Plaza, with senior partner Vincent Lim holding the reins. Several lawyers have quit JLC, including former principal consultant Jeffrey Chan and salaried partner Karen Pok Mee Yau, amidst the scandal and Ong's 22 forgery and cheating charges.

site_title: Banking on Wine and Roses
summary: Ex-bankers Grant Ashton and Lelian Chew have created lifestyle concepts centered around wine and roses. Grant Ashton, 52, opened 67 Pall Mall, London's first private members' wine club, with 4,400 wines and 2,500 members. He now expands to Singapore with a 27th-floor penthouse wine club featuring 5,000 wines from 42 countries. Lelian Chew, 37, founder of The Atelier & Co, rose from a private banker to wedding planner for the rich and famous, leveraging her experience to create bespoke weddings and events. Both entrepreneurs prioritize affordability and unique experiences, targeting local markets and building long-term success through membership and event revenue.

site_title: A New, Refreshed Art Jakarta
summary: Art Jakarta, Indonesia's largest art fair, is set to open on August 30 with a refreshed look and concept under new director Tom Tandio. The fair has moved to the Jakarta Convention Center, doubling its space to 9,000 square meters and increasing booth sizes and aisle widths. This year's fair features 70 galleries, including 29 Indonesian and 41 non-Indonesian galleries, with notable debuts from top galleries such as Tang Contemporary Art and Tomio Koyama Gallery. Despite global market bumps, sentiment is positive in Jakarta, with a growing interest in art and culture among the local population.

site_title: Behind The Curtain
summary: Singaporean artist Hilmi Johandi's solo show "Stagecraft: Landscapes and Paradise" explores the reality behind the country's tourism marketing materials. His paintings reimagined the 1980s and 1990s postcards and posters as staged sets, featuring colonial buildings, palm trees, and stage lights. The show, featuring seven paintings and one video, is on display at Ota Fine Arts until September 28, with free admission. Johandi's work questions the authenticity of Singapore's portrayal as a paradise island, instead revealing a constructed reality.

site_title: Patek - The keen, illustrious innovator
summary: Patek Philippe unveiled new timepieces at BaselWorld, including the Alarm Travel Time Ref 5520P-001, a two-time zone watch with a 24-hour alarm and integrated movement. The Alarm Travel Time features a stop-seconds mechanism, a silicon-based balance spring, and a centrifugal governor for a regular striking cadence. Patek also introduced the Calatrava Weekly Calendar Ref 5212, a calendar watch with a week number display. Additionally, the brand released a new chronograph, refreshed sports models, and introduced new ladies' models with larger cases and diamond-encrusted bezels.

site_title: Spotlight On Local Talent
summary: The Singapore Lyric Opera (SLO) is set to perform Bizet's Carmen, highlighting local talent. Six of the 11 cast members are Singaporeans, including tenor Jonathan Charles Tay and Janani Sridhar, who returns from the US. Taiwanese star Jo- Pei Weng takes on the title role. SLO's artistic director Nancy Yuen praises the cast's passion, dedication, and hard work. Bizet's Carmen will perform on August 30 and 31 at 8pm, and September 1 at 5pm at Esplanade Theatre, with tickets starting from S$35.

site_title: The business of higher education
summary: Singapore's tertiary education landscape has shifted with a focus on local economy-relevant courses. High-profile overseas universities, such as those with Singaporean campuses, have pulled out due to enrollment or financial difficulties. This change is attributed to the country's emphasis on relevant education. Meanwhile, entrepreneur Martin Sorrell has restarted his career with S4 Capital, aiming to take on the advertising world's giants.

site_title: Hupsteel shares fall below public float, to be suspended at offer close
summary: Hupsteel shares have fallen below the public float threshold, prompting the Singapore Exchange to suspend trading. The company's shares breached the 10% public float requirement after the Lim family's 90% acceptance of its voluntary conditional cash offer. The offeror plans to delist the company and will not restore the public float or lift the trading suspension. The offer's closing date has been extended to September 13.

site_title: Toyota makes its marque with the Supra
summary: Toyota has revived its cult-favourite sports coupe, the Supra, after a 17-year hiatus. The fifth-generation model shares its platform and engine with the BMW Z4, but Toyota's engineers developed the car independently, tuning its components differently. The Supra boasts a 2.0L turbo engine or a 3.0L straight-six engine, offering a pure two-seater design with a low-slung seating position and sporty interior. The car is agile, sweetly balanced, and confidence-inspiring to drive, with a direct connection to the machine and responsive handling.

images.alt_text: The Supra (above) takes some cues from Toyota's classic 1960s icon, the 2000 GT, seen in the dual "bubble" roof and long bonnet.
The seating position (above) is low-slung and closer to the ground, which are spot-on features.

site_title: An exclusive Master Banker for Asia
summary: Franck Muller is reviving its iconic Master Banker Asia Exclusive, a complication timepiece featuring three time zones that can be viewed simultaneously. First introduced in 1996, the Cintree Curvex case houses the same three-time-zone mechanism, offering local time on the central hands, date, and actual times in two other zones. The model is exclusive to the Asia region and retains its original functionality.

site_title: Blockchain accelerator to launch platform to connect industry stakeholders
summary: Tribe Accelerator is launching an online platform called OpenNodes to connect government agencies, corporates, and blockchain companies. Backed by over 20 organizations, including Temasek and the Ethereum Foundation, the platform aims to facilitate industry-specific working groups and connections with global blockchain communities. This move is expected to explore blockchain applications in various verticals, such as mobility and healthcare, and unlock deep tech innovation for corporations.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Frencken Group's Q2 FY2019 profit after tax and minority interest rose 59% year-on-year to S$11.1 million, driven by a 129% year-on-year surge in its industrial automation segment to S$45 million. This offset a 23% year-on-year decline in its semiconductor business to S$24 million. The company's neutral rating has been downgraded to S$0.70, with a target price of S$0.81.

site_title: BT journalist Marissa Lee among winners at SGX Orb Awards
summary: BT journalist Marissa Lee won the "The Hidden Gem" category at the SGX Orb Awards for her story "Isetan needs more than a store refresh". The awards, now in its second edition, aim to encourage broader and deeper coverage of financial news. Other winners include Ben Paul for "Story of the Year" on securities, Tan Huileng for "Story of the Year" on derivatives, and dollardsense.sg for "GoTo.com" category. The awards recognize the best feature or analysis of under-covered stocks listed on SGX, promoting quality news and content for investors.

site_title: Bringing the Lange manufacture around the world
summary: A Lange & Söhne's head of the Zeitwerk department, Robert Hoffman, led a watchmaking class in Phuket, where students attempted to assemble and run an ETA 6498-1 movement within two hours. The class aimed to bring Lange manufacture to the world through hands-on training.

site_title: HK banks call for law and order, condemn violence in full-page newspaper advertisements
summary: Hong Kong's largest banks, HSBC, Standard Chartered, and Bank of East Asia, have published full-page advertisements calling for law and order and condemning violence in the city. The move comes as pro-democracy protests continue to escalate, with thousands of residents holding an anti-government demonstration and a rally by students planned for the coming weeks. The protests, which began over a now-suspended extradition bill, have grown into a broader challenge to the erosion of freedoms in Hong Kong, with demonstrators demanding an independent inquiry and resumption of political reform.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 7.88 points to 1,602.47. Volume reached 2 billion lots worth RM1.8 billion. Losers outpaced gainers 395 to 388.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on strong retail earnings
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by strong retail earnings, including Nordstrom. The Dow Jones rose 68.91 points, or 0.26%, to 26,271.64. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, with the Nasdaq up 18.58 points, or 0.23%, to 8,038.79. Investors await Fed Chief Jerome Powell's speech for insights into future interest rate moves.

site_title: Jazz Reunion
summary: Singapore's iconic jazz band, ChromaZone, is reuniting for one final show after nearly two decades. The band, which was the resident jazz group at Harry's Quayside Bar from 1992 to 2010, will perform at Maduro's live music show on August 24 at 9pm. The reunion is due to drummer Eddie Layman's departure from Singapore, making it a farewell concert for fans.

site_title: Black is back!
summary: Black is making a comeback in the watch world, symbolizing power, mystery, and strength. The trend, which started in 2019, has been adopted by various watch brands, including IWC Schaffhausen, with its new Double Chronograph Ceratanium pilot watch. This watch is made of a new material that combines the advantages of titanium and ceramic, and is the first completely jet black pilot's watch from IWC. Several other brands, such as Vacheron Constantin and Tudor, have also released black-colored watches, further solidifying the trend.

site_title: Drawing From The Past
summary: Veteran hobbyist illustrator Hassan Masod, 67, is reliving his childhood through his sketches, which he calls "old world" in style. He began drawing at a young age and would spend his pocket money on pencils and paper. Two years ago, he held an exhibition and now will hold a workshop on August 24, where he will share his life stories and do a live sketch. Participants will also get to sketch their own subjects, with Masod aiming to inspire others to explore their own creativity.

site_title: Tesla's EVs are about 'lifestyle', not climate: Masagos Zulkifli
summary: Singapore's Environment and Water Resources Minister Masagos Zulkifli stated that taking mass transit is a better climate-change solution than relying on electric vehicles (EVs), contradicting Elon Musk's views. Singapore prioritizes public transport, aiming to reduce travel times to 45 minutes by 2040, and controls car ownership licenses, which could facilitate a transition to plug-in vehicles. However, concerns over charging infrastructure and high demand for parking spots hinder the adoption of EVs, with hydrogen considered a more viable long-term solution.

images.alt_text: Mr Musk has criticised Singapore for being slow to adopt EVs, saying in a tweet that the government "has been unwelcome".

site_title: Boustead unit bags contract to build energy infrastructure in Europe
summary: Boustead International Heaters (BIH), a subsidiary of Boustead Singapore, has secured a S$100 million contract to design, engineer, and supply waste heat recovery units for a major energy infrastructure development in Europe. This contract raises BIH's order book backlog to S$823 million. The waste heat recovery units capture energy from turbine exhaust and flue gases, reducing energy demand and increasing operational efficiency. The contract is seen as a positive start to FY2020, with Boustead expecting a material impact on its profitability and earnings per share for FY2020 and FY2021.

site_title: Jump on this grand wagon
summary: The Volvo V60 wagon has been introduced in Singapore, offering a unique combination of driving characteristics of a sedan and the usefulness of an SUV. The third-generation model boasts improved performance, a spacious interior, and a generous cargo area. Powered by a 2.0-litre turbocharged engine, it accelerates from 0-100km/h in 6.5 seconds. The V60 T5 R-Design model is priced at S$195,000, making it a more affordable option compared to German rivals. Despite its lower sales potential, the V60 is considered the safest car in its class, with numerous active and passive safety systems.

site_title: The world's most famous chronograph movement is 50
summary: The El Primero, the world's first automatic chronograph movement, is celebrating its 50th birthday. Launched in 1969, it features a 36,000 beats per hour rotor, allowing for time measurement to a tenth of a second. In the 1970s, Zenith's US owner ordered the movement's production to stop, but watchmaker Charles Vermot secretly preserved the movement's design and components, ensuring its revival. The El Primero's longevity and impact on watchmaking are a testament to Vermot's dedication and foresight.

site_title: Bali High
summary: The Clubhouse at Ulu, a new sister property to Bali's Ulu Cliffhouse, has opened with seven individual suites named after legendary surf breaks. Each suite features a 1950's California aesthetic with retro decor and access to a private members' lounge, Clubhouse bar, and daily US$100 F&B credit. Introductory rates start at US$300++ per night for twin-sharing. The Clubhouse is located atop a rock face overlooking the Indian Ocean and offers a more laid-back alternative to the cliffside resort's beach club party lifestyle.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today

site_title: WeWork jams more folks into its space than others
summary: WeWork jams more people into its spaces than other commercial landlords, with its London spaces averaging around 4.1 sq m per person. The company's Waterloo facility has a 6,414-person capacity and its Canary Wharf space can house 6,009 employees, despite being smaller than recommended. This exceeds industry guidelines, highlighting the company's dense co-working model.

site_title: Vietnam a bright spot amid trade tensions: economists
summary: Vietnam is expected to be one of the world's fastest-growing economies in 2019, with a forecasted 6.7% growth rate, driven by robust domestic demand and increasing foreign direct investment. The country is becoming a key destination for manufacturers relocating due to US-China trade tensions, with FDI inflows rising 9.1% in 2018 to reach $19.1 billion. Vietnam's low labour costs and infrastructure development projects also make it an attractive location, with the central bank expected to keep the policy rate steady at 6.25% for the rest of the year.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks end with steep losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 0.84% on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index closing at 26,048.72, as investors weighed concerns over the city's economy and ongoing protests. Despite US interest rate cut hopes, worries about the city's economy overshadowed the news, while China's Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes saw slight gains. The losses marked the third month of protests in Hong Kong, which has had a significant impact on the city's economy and stock market.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks snap 3-day rally; Powell's speech in focus
summary: South Korean shares snapped a three-day rally as investors remained cautious ahead of Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell's speech on Friday. The Kospi fell 13.64 points, or 0.69%, to 1,951.01 points, with foreigners net selling 122.5 billion won worth of shares. The won weakened, and the benchmark bond yield fell, as the market awaits Powell's speech, which cast doubt on aggressive rate cuts.

site_title: Banks in Hong Kong condemn violence, urge restoration of 'harmony'
summary: Hong Kong's largest banks, including HSBC, Standard Chartered, and Bank of East Asia, have condemned violence and urged the restoration of social order in the territory. The banks, in full-page newspaper ads, called for law and order to be preserved and supported the government in upholding social order. The move comes as weeks of pro-democracy protests show no sign of abating, with demonstrators demanding an independent inquiry, waiver of charges, and resumption of political reform. The protests have already exacted a toll on the city's economy, with the Asian financial hub on the verge of its first recession in a decade.

site_title: Ryanair suffers minimal disruption as UK pilot strike begins
summary: Ryanair flights from London Stansted operated largely as scheduled as British Airline Pilots' Association (BALPA) members began a two-day strike ahead of the busiest travel weekend. The strike, which started after midnight, did not significantly disrupt services, according to data from FlightRadar24. The carrier and BALPA did not immediately respond to comments. The strike is the latest in a series of disruptions affecting the UK airline industry.

site_title: Singapore shares add 0.2% on Thursday on cautious sentiment
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,127.74, up 5.17 points or 0.2% on Thursday, driven by modest gains despite cautious sentiment. Markets in Asia were mixed, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng falling 0.8%. The local banks, including DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank, notched up slight gains. Trading volume was 1.42 billion securities, with Thai Beverage and DBS Group Holdings being the top-traded counters.

site_title: Mori Building's 580b yen mega project to eclipse Tokyo's Roppongi Hills
summary: Mori Building Co is investing 580 billion yen (S$7.55 billion) in a new 20-acre project in Tokyo's core, surpassing its existing Roppongi Hills development. The complex will feature shops, office space, residences, a hotel, an international school, and a food court, aiming to attract more foreigners to live and work in Tokyo. The project, similar in size to Rockefeller Center, is expected to become the city's hub of commerce and potentially eclipse Roppongi Hills.

site_title: Indonesia surprises with second rate cut to support growth
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, cut interest rates for a second month to support the economy, which faces risks from a global slowdown and intensifying trade war. The rate was lowered by 25 basis points to 5.5% to maintain low inflation and boost economic growth momentum. The move is consistent with the bank's low inflation forecast and aims to retain attractive yields on domestic assets. Indonesia is using a mix of monetary and fiscal policy to stimulate its economy, which slowed to a two-year low in the second quarter.

site_title: KTL Global sells 2 loss-making units to chairman's family for S$10,000
summary: KTL Global, an offshore and marine equipment dealer, has agreed to sell its two loss-making subsidiaries, KTL Offshore and KTL Investment, to Teck Leong Pte Ltd, a company controlled by the family of executive chairman Tan Tock Han, for S$10,000. The subsidiaries have been loss-making since 2016 due to challenging conditions in the oil and gas industry. The sale is expected to result in a substantial reduction in losses, lower liabilities, and a cash inflow for the group.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng proposes rights issue to raise S$96m for expansion
summary: Chip Eng Seng, a Singapore-listed developer, proposes a renounceable underwritten rights issue to raise S$96.3 million, mainly for expansion and strategic investments. The issue will be at S$0.63 per share, a 7.35% discount to the closing price, and 5.97% discount to the theoretical ex-rights price. The company's controlling shareholder, Celine Tang, has given irrevocable undertakings to subscribe for her portion of shares, totaling 31.51% of the total number of rights shares. The move aims to strengthen the group's financial position and improve its balance sheet and capital base.

site_title: China's warning to global CEOs: Toe the party line on Hong Kong
summary: China has issued a warning to global CEOs, urging them to toe the party line on Hong Kong and avoid public statements that may be perceived as supporting the anti-government protests. Multinational companies, including Big Four accounting firms KPMG and PwC, have issued directives to their employees in Hong Kong advising them to avoid discussing the protests or expressing dissenting views on social media. The warning comes after Cathay Pacific Airways, a Hong Kong-based airline, faced a backlash from China for supporting the protests, leading to the resignation of its CEO.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end flat ahead of US data, Fed speech
summary: Tokyo stocks closed flat ahead of US data and a Fed speech, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.05% to 20,628.01. Investors are in a wait-and-see mode, awaiting key US economic data and the Fed chairman's speech.

site_title: Indians pawning the family gold amid credit crunch
summary: Indian farmers are pawning their family gold due to a credit crunch, with many opting for gold loans as banks tighten lending practices. Domestic gold prices have risen over 20% this year, making gold loans more lucrative. Independent workers, including farmers and small shop owners, are most affected, with some lenders seeing a 46% increase in gold loan portfolios. The trend has prompted lenders to impose restrictions and raise borrowing costs, with some imposing loan limits and increasing interest rates.

site_title: Pacific Radiance in 'advanced discussions' for US$180m debt funding
summary: Pacific Radiance is in "advanced discussions" with debt funders for at least US$180 million of debt funding, which will be used to finance the acquisition of Allianz Marine and Logistics Services Holding (AMLS) and its subsidiaries. The company will issue new shares and/or warrants to the financier, who will own up to 15% of the enlarged share capital. The acquisition aims to create synergies and enhance shareholder value through complementary services and global expansion. The debt restructuring plan will also repay existing debts, including bank debt and general corporate purposes.

site_title: Australia sees rush of Hong Kong millionaires amid unrest
summary: Australia is experiencing a surge in applications from Hong Kong millionaires seeking a safety net amid the region's political unrest. The New South Wales state migration department has seen a significant increase in applications for the $5 million Significant Investor Visa program, which provides direct residency. The interest in the program has coincided with the beginning of the current unrest in Hong Kong, with wealthy residents eyeing a secure future in Australia.

site_title: Profit slumps at Australia's South32 as trade war hits aluminium prices
summary: Australia's South32 reported a 25% drop in annual profit due to a decline in aluminium prices, exacerbated by the Sino-US trade war. The miner's shares fell 5.8% on Thursday. South32 is also selling its South Africa thermal coal business to Johannesburg-based Seriti Resources, citing investor pressure and climate change concerns. The company's underlying earnings fell to $992 million, below analyst expectations. This sale follows Rio Tinto's coal exit in 2018 and comes amid Norway's US$1 trillion sovereign wealth fund considering selling its stake in South32 due to tighter ethical investing rules.

site_title: UOB expands to northern Vietnam with opening of first Hanoi branch
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has expanded to northern Vietnam with the opening of its first Hanoi branch. The move marks the bank's first branch beyond Ho Chi Minh City, following the incorporation of UOB's fully-owned subsidiary in Vietnam last year. UOB CEO Wee Ee Cheong and Singapore's Ambassador to Vietnam Catherine Wong officially opened the branch, highlighting the bank's commitment to serving customers in both northern and southern parts of the country. The expansion reflects UOB's confidence in Vietnam's growth and its role in facilitating investment flows.

site_title: What's floccinaucinihilipilification? Ask India's central bank
summary: India's central bank Governor Shaktikanta Das mentioned the term "floccinaucinihilipilification," a rare word meaning estimating something as worthless, during a speech. MPC member Chetan Ghate used the term to describe the underestimation of India's economic growth, despite the recent slowdown. The central bank cut interest rates by 35 basis points, with Ghate voting for a more conventional 25 basis point reduction. The move aims to boost economic growth, but central bank watchers are uncertain about the next policy move due to the economic uncertainty.

site_title: European equities mixed at open
summary: European stock markets opened mixed on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 0.4% to 7,178.39 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 rose 0.1% to 11,814.03 points. Paris' CAC 40 index fell 0.2% to 5,425.33. The mixed performance was attributed to mining and healthcare sectors, while US-EU trade talks were also in focus.

site_title: Australia shares end higher on strong earnings; NZ inches up
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.3% to 6,501.80, driven by strong earnings from local firms and US retailers, despite economic concerns. The benchmark had declined 0.9% on Wednesday. Solid corporate earnings provided relief to financial markets, which have been affected by the Sino-US trade war. Overnight gains on Wall Street also contributed to the increase.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start Thursday on front foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks started on a positive note on Thursday, driven by a strong lead from Wall Street and upbeat comments from US President Donald Trump on trade talks with China. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.06% to 26,285.93, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 0.25% each. The positive momentum followed a fresh record for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq despite tariff uncertainty, with investors remaining optimistic despite split Fed views.

site_title: Scores missing after mudslides in southwestern China
summary: Nine people have died and 35 are missing after a series of mudslides in southwestern China's Sichuan province, according to local authorities. A 33-year-old firefighter was killed when a flash flood tipped over an emergency response vehicle while helping those affected by a mudslide in Wenchuan county. Another firefighter was receiving emergency treatment. The incident occurred on August 22, 2019.

images.alt_text: Nine people have died and 35 are still missing after a series of mudslides in an autonomous region of China's southwestern Sichuan province, local authorities said Thursday.

site_title: Berlin's fintech wealth is attracting at least one private bank
summary: Berlin's fintech industry is attracting wealthy entrepreneurs, creating a demand for private banking services. Weberbank, a 70-year-old local bank, aims to grow its asset under management by 10% a year by catering to this new client base. The city's fintech boom has attracted big-name investors, with startups receiving 2.1 billion euros in financing this year alone. Established wealthy individuals are also drawn to Berlin's art and culture, further expanding the potential customer base for private banks. Weberbank's assets under management are around 6.2 billion euros, with an average private-banking customer having 2 million euros in assets.

site_title: Hong Kong faces worst earnings recession since 2008 crisis
summary: Hong Kong's stocks are poised for their worst quarter since 2008, with corporate earnings unlikely to save them. The Hang Seng Index is expected to slump 19% in operating income, the largest contraction since the global financial crisis. Protests and the US-China trade war are to blame, with analysts warning of a deeper issue as Hong Kong's economy slows. The city's slowing economy and weak yuan have also affected industries such as property, hotels, and retail. A stable political environment and trade war resolution are needed for earnings to turn around, according to experts.

site_title: North Korea dismisses nuclear talks if US 'hostile military moves' continue
summary: North Korea has stated it has no interest in nuclear talks with the US unless Washington stops "escalating hostile military moves". The country has carried out short-range missile tests in protest of annual US-South Korea joint military drills. US special envoy Stephen Biegun visited Seoul in an attempt to revive talks, but a North Korean spokesman dismissed the possibility of dialogue, calling the US's recent military actions "dangerous" and saying they could "trigger a new cold war". The US has nearly 30,000 troops in South Korea to defend it from its neighbor.

site_title: China considers testing no-go zones for petrol vehicles: ministry
summary: China is considering testing no-go zones for petrol vehicles, with the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology analyzing factors such as market demand and emission levels. The country aims to encourage electric vehicle sales as part of a pollution crackdown. China is the world's largest NEV market, with 1.3 million units sold last year, and may formulate a timetable to phase out petrol-fueled vehicles. The southern province of Hainan has already planned to stop selling petrol vehicles by 2030.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,128.75, up 0.2% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 6.18 points to 3,128.75, a 0.2% gain, on Thursday as investors digested US Federal Reserve July meeting minutes ahead of Fed chair Jerome Powell's speech. The market fared better than regional peers, with Australia and Malaysia up, while China, Hong Kong, Japan, and South Korea declined.

site_title: Senoko Drive industrial site tender not awarded after 2 rejected bids
summary: The tender for a 1.22-hectare industrial site at Senoko Drive in Singapore has not been awarded after two bids came in below the reserve price. The site, with a tenure of 30 years and a gross plot ratio of 2.5, was zoned for Business-2 food use only and was part of the 2019 Industrial Government Land Sales programme. JTC will now reassess the site.

site_title: Japan says gaps remain with US on trade after 'very tough' talks
summary: Japan's Economy Minister Toshimitsu Motegi stated that gaps remain in negotiations with the US on a bilateral trade deal, despite "very tough" talks. The two sides aim to narrow gaps on agriculture and automobiles, with the goal of clinching an early deal that could open Japan's agriculture sector. Japan wants the US to cut tariffs on car parts and industrial goods, while the US seeks to curb Japan's auto exports. The talks will continue on Thursday, with a possible meeting between Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and US President Donald Trump on the sidelines of the G-7 summit.

images.alt_text: Japanese Economy Minister Toshimitsu Motegi said on Wednesday there were still gaps that needed to be filled before Tokyo and Washington could agree on a bilateral trade deal and that negotiations with his US counterpart were "very tough."

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.47 points to 1,596.06. The market saw 30.6 million lots traded, worth RM11.28 million, with 89 gainers for every 40 losers.

site_title: Australia: Strong earnings push shares higher, New Zealand inches up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to 6,513.20, driven by strong earnings from local firms and US retailers, including Santos' 89% jump in half-year profit and Origin Energy's 41.6% rise in annual underlying profit. The energy sector led the gains, while Qantas Airways Ltd rallied 3.5% after its A$400 million share buyback announcement. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.1% to 10,724.19, led by EBOS Group's 4% gain.
