site_title: Qantas posts 17% fall in annual profit but shares up as buyback announced
summary: Qantas Airways Ltd reported a 17% fall in annual net profit to A$1.30 billion, driven by fuel costs and a weaker Australian dollar. However, the airline's underlying pretax profit beat expectations and shares rose 4.5% following a A$400 million share buyback and higher dividend. Qantas plans to maintain capacity flat in line with demand and has expressed confidence about the financial year ahead.

site_title: Qantas to test 20-hour non-stop flights to see if passengers can bear it
summary: Qantas plans to test 20-hour non-stop flights from New York and London to Sydney with Boeing Dreamliners, carrying staff and medical personnel, to gauge passenger tolerance. The airline aims to start direct services in 2022, but faces challenges in selecting a suitable plane and ensuring passenger comfort. CEO Alan Joyce believes the tests will provide valuable insights, and Qantas has more leverage in negotiations due to competition from Boeing and Airbus. The world's longest direct flights could become a reality with Qantas' 20-hour services.

site_title: UK's Johnson to hold Brexit talks with Macron after Merkel offers glimmer of hope
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is set to hold Brexit talks with French President Emmanuel Macron, following a glimmer of hope from German Chancellor Angela Merkel that an agreement could be reached within 30 days to avoid a chaotic "no deal" Brexit. Johnson will press for renegotiation of the UK's impending divorce from the EU, particularly on the Irish border issue, which Macron has dismissed as not an option. The talks come ahead of a G-7 summit in Biarritz, where Johnson will meet with US President Donald Trump and other world leaders.

site_title: Singapore unveils plan to help accountancy sector speed up technology adoption
summary: Singapore has unveiled a plan to help the accountancy sector speed up technology adoption, with a new accountancy industry digital plan (IDP) developed by the Singapore Accountancy Commission, Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants, and Infocomm Media Development Authority. The plan aims to enhance digital skills and knowledge, promote technology adoption, and develop accounting technology and innovations for small and medium-sized practices (SMPs), which make up 98% of the industry. An SMP Centre and Accounting Technology & Innovation Centre were launched to support SMPs' digital development and provide guidance on adopting digital solutions.

site_title: Alita Resources and lenders extend standstill over A$40m loan default
summary: Alita Resources, a lithium miner, has extended a standstill agreement with lenders until August 23 to discuss loan facility refinancing options and recapitalization proposals. The agreement was initially set until August 20 due to alleged events of default, including non-acceptance of a life of mine plan and failure to comply with physical parameters. The company had also scaled back mining operations due to weakened market demand. Alita Resources aims to continue monetizing its product stockpile amid challenging market conditions.

site_title: Fitbit targets 1m new users with Singapore government tie-up
summary: Fitbit Inc has partnered with the Singapore government to provide fitness trackers and services to up to 1 million users through a health programme. The company will supply trackers for free, with users required to spend S$10 per month on premium subscription for a year. The goal of the programme is to promote healthy lifestyles and track progress among Singapore residents.

images.alt_text: Fitbit Inc said on Wednesday it signed a contract with the Singapore government to provide fitness trackers and services in a health programme it said could reach up to one million users.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday; STI up 0.1% to 3,126.73
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.1% to 3,126.73 on Thursday, driven by Wall Street's upward climb after solid retail earnings and the release of Federal Reserve minutes. The S&P 500 jumped 0.8%, while the Nasdaq Composite and Dow Jones Industrial Average added 0.9%. Advancers edged out losers 47 to 43, with DBS, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank gaining 0.5% each. Asian equities also edged ahead, with Japan's Topix and Australia stocks rising 0.3% and 0.4%, respectively.

site_title: Trade woes slowing US economy, deficit to top US$1 trillion in 2020: Budget experts
summary: US trade policies, including President Trump's tariffs, are slowing the US economy and reducing household income, according to the Congressional Budget Office. The economy is expected to grow at a 2.1% annual rate in 2020 and soften to 1.8% in ensuing years. The federal deficit is projected to top $1 trillion in 2020, two years sooner than expected, and average $1.2 trillion between 2020 and 2029. Trade policies are also reducing real income for the average US household by 0.4%, or $580.

images.alt_text: The US budget deficit is growing faster than expected even as President Donald Trump considers more tax cuts and other ideas that would add to government debt.

site_title: Russia to send 'Fedor' its first humanoid robot into space
summary: Russia is set to launch its first humanoid robot, Fedor, into space on an unmanned Soyuz rocket from Baikonur cosmodrome in Kazakhstan. Fedor will spend 10 days on the International Space Station, learning to assist astronauts and performing tasks in low gravity. The robot, standing 1.8m tall and weighing 160kg, will trial manual skills such as opening a bottle of water and will eventually help carry out space walks. Fedor is not the first robot to go into space, but its capabilities could be useful for future deep space missions.

images.alt_text: Russia was set to launch on Thursday an unmanned rocket carrying a life-size humanoid robot that will spend 10 days learning to assist astronauts on the International Space Station.

site_title: WeWork rival Knotel vaults to unicorn status
summary: Knotel Inc, a rival to WeWork, raised US$400 million at a valuation of at least US$1.3 billion, catapulting the startup to unicorn status. The funding drew investors such as Kuwait-backed Wafra Inc and Japan's Mori Trust, Itochu Corp, and Mercuria Investment Co. Knotel's co-founder, Amol Sarva, predicted the company will leap past WeWork in 18-24 months, citing its focus on large corporate clients and longer lease terms. The new capital will help Knotel expand into new cities, including Tokyo, Seoul, and Hong Kong, and target US cities such as Houston and Chicago.

site_title: Federal Reserve will remain flexible, rates not on 'preset course': minutes
summary: The US Federal Reserve will remain flexible and not follow a preset course with interest rates, despite persistent risks from trade uncertainty and weak global growth. The central bank's decision to cut rates for the first time in over a decade was viewed as a recalibration or mid-cycle adjustment to address uncertainty. Officials highlighted the need for policymakers to remain flexible and focused on incoming data, rather than making a fixed decision. Despite this, the Fed cautioned that continued weakness in global economic growth and ongoing trade tensions could slow US economic activity.

site_title: No minorities, no meat? Gig economy deepens cities' divides
summary: The gig economy has exacerbated socio-economic divides in cities, particularly for minority communities. Allegations of discrimination, including racial, religious, and sexual orientation biases, have surfaced on platforms such as Uber, Ola, and Airbnb. Despite having anti-discriminatory policies, enforcement is challenging due to the informal nature of the industry. Experts recommend legislation, penalties, and data limitations to address bias, while companies can prioritize minority communities and implement stronger penalties for discriminatory behavior. The gig economy's influence on cities' social dynamics and the need for regulation are pressing concerns.

site_title: Trump slams Danish PM's 'nasty' rejection of Greenland deal
summary: US President Donald Trump has reacted angrily to Denmark's rejection of his attempt to purchase Greenland, calling Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen's response "nasty" and "insulting". Trump had scrapped a planned state visit to Denmark after Frederiksen dismissed the idea of buying the island as "absurd". The Danish government has insisted that Greenland is "not for sale", and Frederiksen said the US is one of Denmark's closest allies, despite the spat. The row has heightened tensions between the US and a traditional ally, with Trump accusing Frederiksen of showing disrespect.

site_title: 'I am the chosen one': Trump defends China trade war
summary: US President Donald Trump defended his trade war against China, calling himself "the chosen one" destined to take on Beijing. Trump slapped tariffs on $250 billion in Chinese goods, with a further $300 billion in imports targeted for new duties. Despite warnings from the IMF that the trade war is slowing global growth, Trump showed little sign of easing off, saying "somebody had to do it" and that he's "winning" against China. Trade talks are set to resume next month.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump proclaimed himself "the chosen one" on Wednesday as he defended his trade war against China, indicating that it was his destiny to take on Beijing.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Corp, Yanlord Land, Creative, Hupsteel, Raffles Education
summary: Keppel Corp and Yanlord Land are among the Singapore companies seeing new developments. Keppel Corp is entering a joint venture to acquire a 3.8-hectare site in Nanjing, China, with an estimated cost of over $990 million. Yanlord Land has priced its $400 million senior notes at 6.8% interest, with estimated net proceeds to be used for project development and acquisition. These developments may impact trading of their shares.

site_title: Microplastics in drinking water not a health risk for now: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has reported that microplastics in drinking water are not currently a significant health risk, but called for further research into potential future risks. Data on microplastics in drinking water is limited, and the organization has urged policymakers and the public to take measures to reduce plastic pollution. Experts recommend wastewater treatment to remove microplastics, which could also address faecally contaminated water and deadly diarrheal diseases. The WHO has warned that if plastic emissions continue at current rates, microplastics could pose widespread risks for aquatic ecosystems and human exposure in a century.

site_title: Oil steadies as US crude stocks draw but fuel inventories rise
summary: Oil prices steadied on Wednesday after US crude stocks drew down 2.7 million barrels, contrary to analyst expectations. Brent crude futures rose 27 cents to settle at $60.30 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude fell 45 cents to settle at $55.68 a barrel. However, lingering concerns about the global economy, particularly the US-China trade war and tensions with Iran, weighed on the market. Analysts expect little improvement in oil demand before the end of the year, citing anemic apparent demand and recession risks.

site_title: Singapore says Musk's electric cars are about 'lifestyle', not climate
summary: Singapore's Minister for Environment and Water Resources, Masagos Zulkifli, has criticized Elon Musk's electric vehicles, saying they are more about creating a "lifestyle" than addressing climate change. The city-state prioritizes mass transit, such as buses and trains, over individual EV adoption, citing infrastructure challenges and a focus on practical solutions. Singapore aims to enhance public transport options to reduce travel times to 45 minutes by 2040, and believes hydrogen is a better long-term solution for decarbonizing transportation due to battery production and disposal issues.

site_title: What you need to know before you travel to Hong Kong
summary: Protests in Hong Kong have led to a potentially hazardous environment for visitors, with demonstrations and clashes with police reported since June. Travelers should be aware of the following: airport restrictions, MTR disruptions, and frequent protest hotspots. Key areas to avoid include Victoria Park, Causeway Bay-Wan Chai, and government buildings. Travel advisories have been issued by multiple countries, including the US, Australia, and Singapore, with warnings of potential disruptions and restrictions on travel to and from China. Visitors are advised to exercise caution and follow local guidelines to minimize risks.

images.alt_text: Months of protests in Hong Kong have made travelling to the city a potentially dicey proposition for visitors.

site_title: Asia's chocolate bonanza sparks quest for locally grown beans
summary: Asia's cocoa industry is facing a shortage of locally grown beans, prompting a search for solutions to boost production in Indonesia, the top supplier and processor. Despite efforts to reverse a decline in output due to ageing trees, crop disease, and more profitable alternatives, Indonesia's production remains a challenge. To meet the growing demand, Asia's processors have turned to imports from Africa and Latin America, increasing bean imports by record levels. The industry is urging local production to meet the growing demand for cocoa products, driven by increasing affluence and changing lifestyles in the region.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit launches preferential offering to raise S$101.8m
summary: Soilbuild Reit has launched a non-renounceable preferential offering to raise S$101.8 million, with approximately 192.1 million new units priced at S$0.530 per unit, a 8.4% discount to the previous day's closing price. The offering will partially fund the acquisition of an Australian office property for A$127.5 million. The Reit's units closed at S$0.580 on Wednesday, and eligible unitholders can accept or decline their provisional allotments. The offering's book closure date is on Aug 29, and applications start on Sept 3.

site_title: HSBC weighs bid for Aviva's Asian assets in diversity push: sources
summary: HSBC Holdings is considering a bid for Asian operations being sold by Aviva plc, aiming to diversify its business in the region. The deal, valued at $3 billion to $4 billion, would bolster HSBC's insurance presence in Singapore and Southeast Asia. This move comes as Aviva's new CEO, Maurice Tulloch, seeks to revamp the company's business. An official process is expected to start later this year, following a recent examination of options for Aviva's Asian operations.

site_title: Japan manufacturing shrinks for 4th month in August as export orders fall: flash PMI
summary: Japanese manufacturing activity contracted for the fourth consecutive month in August, with a preliminary business survey showing a seasonally adjusted PMI of 49.5, below the 50.0 threshold. Export orders fell at a sharper pace, while the services sector expanded at the fastest pace in nearly two years, driven by resilient domestic demand. This suggests the economy is experiencing strong external pressures, but domestic demand is still supporting growth.

site_title: Trump attacks, economic fears focus spotlight on Fed's Powell speech
summary: US President Donald Trump is expected to intensify his attacks on Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell after Powell delivers a speech on Friday, amid economic fears and a possible recession. Powell must balance defending the Fed's independence, managing internal divisions, and making rate decisions without alienating Trump. Financial markets are demanding rate cuts, which could further anger Trump. The speech comes as warning signs about a recession flash red, and any misstep could roil markets and stoke Trump's anger.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher following Wall Street gains
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, following Wall Street gains. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.41% to 20,704.02, while the Topix index gained 0.27% to 1,501.51. Investors were monitoring US data and the Federal Reserve, contributing to the market's optimism.

site_title: Trump attacks Ford Motor for not backing fuel economy rollback
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized Ford Motor for not backing his administration's plan to roll back Obama-era fuel efficiency rules. Ford, along with Honda, BMW, and Volkswagen, reached a voluntary agreement with California to maintain stricter fuel economy standards. The rules are looser than Obama-era regulations but stricter than the Trump administration's proposed rules. Trump's attacks on automakers come as the administration seeks to strip California of its right to set its own climate change standards.

site_title: Europe: Italy leads bounce in shares, Fiat-Renault talks in focus
summary: European stock markets ended at a two-week high, led by Italy's rebound in shares. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 1.2% after Italy's main opposition party agreed to hold talks with the 5-Star Movement to form a government. Fiat Chrysler and Renault reportedly resumed merger talks, boosting auto stocks. Investors await the US Federal Reserve's Jackson Hole Symposium for signs of stimulus to boost global growth.

site_title: Canada accused of unlawfully questioning Huawei's Meng
summary: Canada's border agents allegedly detained Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou without informing her of a US warrant, and questioned her for hours before handing her over to the RCMP. Meng's lawyers claim the RCMP and border agents were acting on behalf of the FBI to obtain evidence. The US wants to put Meng on trial for alleged fraud related to violating Iran sanctions. Meng's detention sparked a diplomatic row between Canada and China, with her extradition hearing scheduled for January. The exact extent of FBI involvement remains unclear.

site_title: Macron says G-7 should discuss budget stimulus, including in Germany
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron urged G-7 countries, including Germany, to discuss budget stimulus measures to combat recession fears. Macron sought to encourage Germany to increase public spending, but Berlin is resistant to raising borrowing and debt. The G-7 meeting comes amid tense relations between Macron and German Chancellor Angela Merkel, who is set to leave office in 2021. Merkel has opposed Macron's calls for a shared eurozone budget to finance infrastructure investments.

site_title: SoftBank will let people invest in IPOs with less than 1,000 yen
summary: SoftBank's brokerage unit, One Tap BUY Co, plans to allow individuals in Japan to invest in initial public offerings (IPOs) with as little as 1,000 yen, marking a first in capital markets. This change will enable investors to specify the amount they want to invest, rather than the number of shares. The move aims to simplify the investment process, allowing investors to easily invest small amounts. One Tap BUY Co plans to start offering this service as early as March 2020, pending regulatory approvals.

images.alt_text: SoftBank Corp's brokerage unit plans to do something that may be a first in capital markets. It will allow individuals in Japan to participate in initial public offerings (IPO) with as little as a 1,000 yen note (S$13) - worth a bit less than a 10 US dollar bill.

site_title: DBS to enter India's credit card market in 2020
summary: DBS Group Holdings, Southeast Asia's largest bank, plans to enter India's credit card market in 2020, aiming to tap growth outside its home market. The bank's head of consumer banking in India, Shantanu Sengupta, stated that DBS will launch its credit card by the second or third quarter of next year. With India's credit card market still small compared to its debit card market, DBS expects to reach a five-million customer base in India by 2023, potentially beating its initial target.

site_title: Dwayne Johnson returns to top of Forbes best-paid actor list
summary: Dwayne Johnson reclaimed his position as the world's highest-paid actor, earning US$89.4 million over 12 months, surpassing Chris Hemsworth's US$76.4 million. Johnson's success can be attributed to his prolific acting career, lucrative profit-sharing deals, and multiple endorsement contracts. He has held the top spot since 2016 and is followed by Hemsworth, Robert Downey Jr., and Akshay Kumar, who are all from Marvel's superhero universe.

images.alt_text: Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson has reclaimed his position as the world's highest-paid actor, according to a Forbes rich list otherwise dominated by the cast of Marvel's record-breaking "Avengers" films.

site_title: US to allow indefinite detention of migrant children: DHS
summary: The US Department of Homeland Security announced it will terminate the 1997 Flores Settlement Agreement, allowing for indefinite detention of migrant children. The new policy, set to take effect in 60 days, will not limit how long children or their families can be detained. The move aims to deter migrant expectations of being released after arrest and is part of the administration's broader crackdown on undocumented immigrants. Migrant and human rights groups have criticized the decision, calling it a "cruel attack on children."

site_title: China casts itself as a responsible power in a new era
summary: China has taken a proactive role in promoting global stability, particularly in its neighborhood, as it assumes greater responsibility for maintaining peace. China's ambassador to the UN, Zhang Jun, expressed concern over the Kashmir crisis and called for a peaceful resolution in accordance with UN Charter and bilateral agreements. China's diplomatic efforts have been seen in its support for talks in Afghanistan and its continued backing of the Iran nuclear deal. China's increasing influence is also evident in its potential to mediate the Kashmir issue, with Beijing taking a neutral stance and showing willingness to take on tough tasks.

site_title: SPH Reit launches S$1b debt programme; in talks for potential acquisition
summary: SPH Reit launches a S$1 billion debt programme, with potential proceeds used for a possible acquisition. The Reit's manager is conducting due diligence on the acquisition, with discussions still preliminary. The debt issuance will be used for general working capital, capital expenditure, and refinancing existing borrowings. Units of the Reit closed up 1.87% at S$1.09 on Wednesday. HSBC and OCBC are arrangers and dealers of the programme, which includes issuing notes and perpetual securities.

site_title: Kaki Bukit Place factory up for sale with S$5.5m indicative price
summary: A five-storey intermediate terrace factory at 9 Kaki Bukit Place in Singapore has been put up for sale by expression of interest with an indicative price of S$5.5 million. The property has a gross floor area of 13,110 sq ft, translating to approximately S$420 per square foot. Foreigners and companies eligible to purchase are exempt from payable land rent and additional buyer's stamp duty.

site_title: OCBC in talks with Singtel on upcoming virtual bank licence
summary: OCBC is in talks with Singtel to secure a virtual bank licence in Singapore, with OCBC taking a minority stake in the joint venture. The move aims to tap new customers and markets, particularly among underserved groups. Singapore's Monetary Authority has announced plans to issue up to five new digital bank licences, amid increasing competition from telcos and tech firms in the financial services sector.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singtel issued US$750 million 10-year notes at 2.375% interest, 3.6 times oversubscribed. Yanlord Land proposed issuing US dollar-denominated senior notes with a non-call period. Creative Technology reported a net loss of US$2.8 million for the fourth quarter, down from a net profit of US$25.6 million in the same period last year. The notes and bonds were rated A1 and BB- by Moody's and S&P respectively.

site_title: Amazon, Microsoft, may be putting world at risk of killer AI, says report
summary: Amazon and Microsoft are among tech companies that could spearhead a global AI arms race, according to a report by Dutch NGO Pax. The companies ranked high for developing lethal autonomous weapons and working on related military projects. Google and Softbank were found to be practicing "best practices" in AI development, while 21 companies, including Amazon and Microsoft, were deemed "high concern" due to their involvement in the development of autonomous weapons. Experts warn that these systems could become "weapons of mass destruction" and threaten international security.

site_title: Air New Zealand annual profit hit by weak tourism, engine problems
summary: Air New Zealand's annual profit fell 31% to NZ$374 million due to weak tourism, higher fuel costs, and engine problems with its Rolls-Royce engines. The airline forecast a 2020 earnings range of NZ$350-450 million, citing a dip in travel demand and pressure from higher fuel prices. Maintenance issues with the engines, affecting 2,500 flights and 150 cancellations, impacted its financial performance. The company expects the engines to return to service in the coming months, and revenue rose 5.4% to NZ$5.83 billion.

site_title: Trudeau says Canada will push back in China row, urges de-escalation in Hong Kong
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau stated that the country will stand up to China in the ongoing diplomatic and trade spat, while urging de-escalation of Hong Kong protest tensions. The feud began in 2018 when Canada detained Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou on a flight stopover in Vancouver. In response, China arrested two Canadian nationals and blocked Canadian agricultural shipments. Trudeau emphasized that Canada will defend its citizens and interests, but also won't escalate conflicts. Canada and the EU have expressed support for Hong Kong protestors' right to assembly amid a government bid to introduce a law allowing extraditions to mainland China.

site_title: Del Monte to close two US facilities, sell another as it turns to asset-light strategy
summary: Del Monte Pacific Limited, a food and beverage firm, will close two US production facilities and sell a third in a bid to adopt an asset-light strategy. The closures will be made at the end of the current pack season, with production shifted to other existing facilities. The company aims to increase focus on branded growth and innovation, citing the need to remain competitive in a rapidly changing marketplace. The restructuring is expected to lead to more efficient and lower-cost operations.

site_title: Govt to engage businesses on support package for retirement, re-hiring age changes: Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced efforts to develop a support package for businesses to aid in the transition to higher retirement and re-employment ages. The statutory retirement age will rise to 63 by 2022 and 65 by 2030, while the re-employment age will increase to 68 by 2022 and 70 by 2030. Heng will engage stakeholders, including businesses, unions, and government ministers, to prepare for Budget 2020.

site_title: Property sales are picking up: What next?
summary: Property sales in Singapore are showing signs of improvement, with developers launching new projects at relatively high prices. This trend is expected to continue, despite concerns about a potential property bubble. The Urban Redevelopment Authority's price index for private homes rose 1.5% in Q2 2019, erasing the decline from the previous quarter. The government may consider easing cooling measures to foster the recovery of the property market, but it's unclear whether this will happen. The outcome will depend on how the various factors play out over the next few months.

site_title: E-cigarette firms probed over health concerns by US House panel
summary: The US House Energy and Commerce Committee has launched an investigation into four dominant e-cigarette manufacturers, including Juul Labs, Fontem Ventures, Japan Tobacco, and Reynolds American, over concerns about the health impacts of their products. The probe seeks information on research and marketing practices, and follows growing scrutiny of the industry. The committee has requested answers and documents by September 20, amid a recent CDC investigation into 153 possible cases of severe lung illness associated with e-cigarette use in 16 states.

site_title: Economic slowdown, yes, but Singapore is looking beyond the short term
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has addressed economic concerns, stating the domestic situation is well under control and no immediate stimulus measures are needed. The government is tracking trends and will respond promptly if the situation worsens. Despite a cut in 2019 growth forecast to 0-1%, the government is confident in its ability to navigate the slowdown, citing past experience with cyclical downturns. The business community also sees pressing issues such as sustaining the "Singapore brand," driving global talent and investments, and fostering trust among citizens, businesses, and institutions.

site_title: Disabled showcase their F&B abilities at Company of Good dinner
summary: A dinner event at the Enabling Village in Singapore showcased the culinary abilities of people with disabilities (PWDs) through a partnership between National Volunteer & Philanthropy Centre (NVPC), Samsui Supplies & Services Pte Ltd, and Standard Chartered Bank Singapore. The collaboration aims to provide a "through-train" training and employment programme for PWDs in the food and beverage (F&B) sector, with Standard Chartered contributing $160,000. The goal is to increase employment rates among PWDs, who currently face significant barriers to employment.

site_title: How cultural stereotypes shape US-China negotiations
summary: US-China trade negotiations are strained due to cultural stereotypes and perceptions of each side's ethics. A study found that Americans are more likely to use unethical tactics when negotiating with Chinese counterparts, while Chinese negotiators are less likely to do so. This suggests that both sides adjust their behavior according to their perceptions of the other's cultural and ethical standards. The study highlights the importance of considering cultural differences in international negotiations and the need for a nuanced understanding of ethical practices in different countries.

site_title: Companies might be smarter with workers in the boardroom
summary: Germany's co-determination policy, where workers elect representatives to corporate boards, has been shown to boost corporate productivity and shareholder value. Research by economists Simon Jäger, Benjamin Schoefer, and Jörg Heining found that companies with worker representation invested more in fixed capital, leading to higher value added per worker. This approach may improve job security and create a sense of worker ownership, potentially benefiting the US economy by reversing the decline in business investment and manufacturing companies.

site_title: Forget the World Cup, shoot for the SEA Games football gold first
summary: Singapore's Football Association (FAS) has set a goal for the national team to qualify for the 2034 FIFA World Cup finals, but many consider it unrealistic due to the country's current football landscape. Despite efforts to improve standards and youth development, Singapore's football remains mediocre, and the national team has failed to make an impact. Experts believe that aiming for the World Cup finals is premature and that a more realistic goal should be the South-east Asia Games football gold medal, which Singapore has not achieved in 60 years.

site_title: Lack of cues makes for a dull session
summary: Asian markets closed mixed on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index in Singapore down 0.4% to 3,122.57, as investors remained cautious ahead of the US Federal Reserve's minutes release and Jerome Powell's speech. Markets in Australia, China, Japan, and Malaysia ended lower, while Hong Kong and South Korea posted slight gains. Trading was directionless, with some analysts advising investors to stay hedged or stay away, citing reasons to remain cautious, including weak economic data and bond yield inversions.

site_title: Yanlord Land unit prices US$400m senior notes due 2024 at 6.8%
summary: Yanlord Land, a China-based property developer, priced its US$400 million senior notes due 2024 at 6.8% interest, payable semi-annually. The notes, issued by subsidiary Yanlord Land (HK) Co, are expected to be used for project development and acquisition, with estimated net proceeds of US$395 million. The notes are guaranteed by the group and are expected to be rated "BB-" by Standard & Poor's and "Ba3" by Moody's Investors Services.

site_title: COE prices fall across all categories despite cuts
summary: COE prices in Singapore fell across all categories in the latest tender, despite a reduction in COE supply until October. COE premiums for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp dropped 2.47% to S$31,917, while commercial vehicle COE prices fell 4.67% to S$26,501. Motorcycle COE premiums also decreased 2.25% to S$4,301. The drop in prices may indicate a weak market, with some attributing it to economic concerns and slower business at showrooms.

site_title: Redas launches new Bicentennial event at Raffles Place Park
summary: Redas launches a new Bicentennial event at Raffles Place Park in Singapore to commemorate its 60th year. The event, free for the public until August 30, showcases the built environment and landmarks, highlighting developers' contributions to Singapore's progress. National Development Minister Lawrence Wong announced new urban transformation plans, including the Greater Southern Waterfront project, and incentives for CBD rejuvenation. Redas president Chia Ngiang Hong reaffirmed the association's commitment to environmental responsibility and sustainable development.

site_title: Shock in Denmark after Trump, spurned over Greenland, cancels visit
summary: US President Donald Trump's state visit to Denmark was cancelled after Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen rebuffed his proposal to purchase Greenland, an autonomous Danish territory. Trump had initially expressed interest in buying Greenland, but Frederiksen called the idea "absurd" and said the territory was "not for sale." The cancellation has sparked shock and concern among Danes, with many expressing disappointment at Trump's unpredictability and strained relations with the European Union. The incident has also highlighted Greenland's strategic location and mineral resources, which have drawn attention from world powers.

site_title: Lim family's Hupsteel offer crosses 90% mark, declared unconditional
summary: The Lim family's voluntary conditional cash offer for steel trader Hupsteel has reached 90.013% acceptance, surpassing the minimum 90% needed to succeed. The offer, launched at S$1.20 per share, has become unconditional and will remain open for acceptance until Sept 13. Hupsteel shares closed at S$1.19 on Wednesday before the announcement.

site_title: China to speed up subsidies for pigs culled due to African swine fever
summary: China's cabinet announced plans to accelerate the distribution of subsidies for pigs culled due to African swine fever. The subsidies, set at 1,200 yuan (S$236) per pig, aim to prevent the spread of the deadly disease that has devastated China's pig industry. Some farmers have reported not receiving the subsidies, prompting the government's swift action to address the issue.

site_title: Rebooting the public sector starts with having the right data architecture
summary: Singapore's government is investing in a data-driven infrastructure to support digital transformation and improve public services. The country aims to build a Digital Government by 2023, with a focus on scalability, reliability, and data analytics. By 2025, the government plans to dedicate $40 million to 5G innovation and $500 million to AI systems. Effective data architecture can help remove data silos, accelerate AI development, and enhance public safety, while also improving citizen engagement and trust in government services.

site_title: S Africa relaxes trophy hunting rules for black rhinos
summary: South Africa has relaxed trophy hunting rules for black rhinos, allowing for nine adult males to be killed each year under a new policy that targets older, agitated non-breeding males. The move was approved by the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species in Geneva, despite concerns from wildlife advocates about poaching challenges. Proponents argue that the policy could increase revenue for conservation efforts and boost population growth, citing the success of similar strategies for the white rhino. However, critics say the policy is unnecessary and may hinder conservation efforts.

images.alt_text: The new policy will allow trophy hunters to kill more - not fewer - endangered black rhinos, a move that is highly controversial and contradictory.

site_title: Alibaba postpones HK listing amid protests: sources
summary: Alibaba Group, China's largest e-commerce company, has postponed its US$15 billion Hong Kong listing amid growing protests in the Asian financial hub. The company held a board meeting before its latest quarterly earnings release and decided to delay the listing, which was set to take place in late August. This decision comes as Hong Kong faces increasing unrest, potentially affecting the company's decision to proceed with the listing.

site_title: US: Stocks rise despite another yield inversion
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, driven by solid retailer earnings and Federal Reserve minutes that showed no major changes in monetary policy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.9%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.8% and 0.9%, respectively. Despite a brief yield curve inversion, stocks remained steady. Retailers Target and Lowe's reported higher profits, and the Fed indicated it will remain flexible with interest rates. The gains came despite concerns over trade uncertainty and weak global growth.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks resumed their upward climb on Wednesday, finishing solidly higher after solid retailer earnings and following Federal Reserve minutes that included no bombshells on monetary policy.

site_title: Dropping global bond yields and recession fears put BOJ in a bind
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is facing a challenge in maintaining economic growth due to downward-spiraling global bond yields and recession fears. The central bank must continue to pump money into the economy to spur growth, but preventing borrowing costs from falling too low is a concern. If yields continue to fall, the BOJ may be forced to consider yield curve control, a policy aimed at stabilizing long-term interest rates. This could be a significant shift in the bank's efforts to stabilize the Japanese economy.

site_title: The one job in banking that robots cannot take
summary: Artificial intelligence's ability to detect and prevent money laundering in the banking industry is limited due to a misleading historical dataset used to train AI models. The dataset's inaccuracies make it difficult for machines to learn and detect suspicious transactions, as criminals constantly adapt their methods. Despite efforts by banks and regulators to adopt AI, the lack of shared customer data, inadequate information sharing, and over-reporting of suspicious activity hinder the technology's effectiveness. As a result, human surveillance staff remain essential to prevent illicit transfers of up to $2 trillion annually.

site_title: Women to get gender-neutral rugby World Cup from 2021
summary: World Rugby has announced that the 2021 Women's Rugby World Cup in New Zealand will be renamed Rugby World Cup 2021, marking a shift towards gender neutrality. This decision aims to elevate the profile of women's rugby and eliminate perceived bias towards men's competitions. The move, considered a "first for a major sporting federation," will be applied to the Sevens World Cup competitions as well. The change is part of World Rugby's commitment to equality and brand consistency.

site_title: The last thing banks need is even lower rates
summary: Central banks' efforts to keep interest rates low may be hindering the banking industry's ability to thrive. Despite trillions of dollars in asset purchases and record-low interest rates, the demand for credit remains low, with only 12% of US small businesses saying a 100 basis-point reduction in borrowing costs would change their capital spending plans. This has led to an inversion of yield curves, causing bank stocks to rise despite increased bond yields in the eurozone. Analysts warn that further rate cuts could be contractionary, and that the banking industry's profitability may be at risk.

site_title: Macau set to choose Beijing-backed leader, the only candidate people can vote for
summary: Macau is set to elect a Beijing-backed leader, Ho Iat Seng, as the only candidate allowed to run. He will be chosen by a 400-member pro-Beijing committee and is expected to cement China's control over the special administrative region. This move is seen as a way to distance Macau from escalating protests in Hong Kong, and Ho's leadership will likely solidify China's grip on the territory for at least the next five years.

site_title: US: Wall Street rises at open as Lowe's, Target boost retailers
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, driven by strong results from Lowe's and Target, boosting retailers. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.7%, the S&P 500 gained 0.74%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.86%. Investors await the release of the Federal Reserve's July policy meeting minutes.

site_title: Noble to rebuild LNG, core energy businesses
summary: NOBLE Group Holdings, a Singapore-based commodities trader, plans to rebuild its liquefied natural gas (LNG) and core energy businesses, with a new Singapore desk established to focus on trading. The company has hired a former trader from Australia's Origin Energy and expanded its LNG team in London. Noble Holdings aims to prove its viability in the market, having previously faced insolvency protection and asset sales. The company is also exploring opportunities in rare earths, with a stake in Australian developer Arafura Resources.

site_title: Shell, BA planning EU's first waste-to-jet fuel plant
summary: Shell, British Airways, and Velocys plan to build Europe's first large-scale waste-to-jet fuel plant in North-east Lincolnshire, England, starting construction in 2021. The plant will produce sustainable aviation fuel from domestic and commercial waste, reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 70% compared to fossil fuels. The project aims to meet the aviation industry's target to cut emissions by 50% by 2050. Construction is expected to begin in 2021, with commercial volumes of sustainable aviation fuel produced by 2024, and BA and Shell will purchase the biofuel.

site_title: Bankers hawk hedging as trade war hits China's yuan
summary: China's yuan has fallen 11% against the dollar since the US imposed tariffs on Chinese imports, exposing companies to significant currency risks. To mitigate these risks, Chinese firms are increasingly adopting hedging tools, including onshore and foreign derivative markets. Experts say the yuan's volatility is largely driven by geopolitics and Sino-US relations, with no quick end to the trade war in sight. As a result, Chinese bankers and consultants are promoting risk-mitigating tools to help companies manage market uncertainty.

site_title: France says no-deal Brexit is now its central scenario
summary: France's government now considers a no-deal Brexit its central scenario, expecting the UK to leave the EU without an agreement. This would lead to immediate border controls and the UK still paying its financial obligations, estimated at around £39 billion. French President Emmanuel Macron is aligned with German Chancellor Angela Merkel on Brexit, and US President Donald Trump's intervention will not sway EU leaders. UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson will meet Merkel and Macron before the Group of Seven summit in Biarritz, France, where they will discuss Brexit and other issues.

site_title: Michael Jackson art show opens in Finland despite controversy
summary: A Michael Jackson art show opened in Helsinki, Finland, despite controversy surrounding the singer's abuse allegations. The exhibition, "Michael Jackson: On the Wall," features 90 works by artists including Andy Warhol and Grayson Perry, analyzing Jackson's cultural impact. Organizers, including the Espoo Museum of Modern Art, say the show is not a celebration but rather an open discussion on the singer's meaning in culture. The exhibition, which has previously toured London, Paris, and Bonn, will run as planned, with a text acknowledging the changed interpretation due to current conversations.

site_title: UK supermarkets testing plastic-free zones
summary: British supermarkets are introducing "plastic-free zones" in response to consumer pressure. Several major chains, including Waitrose, are testing areas where customers can buy loose products in bulk, reducing reliance on single-use plastic packaging. The trial, initially planned for 11 weeks, aims to reduce waste and save the oceans from plastic pollution. While some customers are supportive of the move, others are hesitant to pay more for groceries. The pilot has already seen a positive response, with customers pinning suggestions for the trial on a staff wall.

site_title: Cash is still king in high-tech Japan
summary: Japan, despite being a pioneer in cashless transactions, still relies heavily on physical cash, with four out of five purchases made with cash. The country's ageing population and preference for slow, face-to-face transactions contribute to this trend. The government aims to increase electronic payments to 40% by 2025, with a points system to encourage cashless payments and mitigate a consumption tax hike. Companies are also promoting a cashless society, but security concerns remain, particularly after a recent QR code hacking incident.

site_title: Climate change will cripple economies regardless of countries' wealth: Report
summary: A new report by the US National Bureau of Economic Research found that climate change will significantly impact economies worldwide, regardless of a country's wealth or temperature, by 2100. The report suggests that a 4°C temperature increase would lead to a 7% loss in global GDP per capita, with the US potentially experiencing a 10% loss in GDP. Even if countries adhere to the Paris Agreement goals, the US could still see a 2% loss in GDP. The report emphasizes the need for stronger mitigation efforts to avoid the negative economic effects of climate change.

site_title: Raffles Education full-year net profit nearly quadruples to S$40.2m
summary: Raffles Education Corporation reported a nearly quadruple increase in its full-year net profit to S$40.2 million, up from S$10.6 million in the previous year. Revenue and other operating income also rose, driven by a S$37.4 million gain on the disposal of a subsidiary. However, the group recorded a S$37 million currency translation loss, leading to a 64% decrease in comprehensive income to S$12.6 million. Despite this, the company expressed confidence in its operations and plans to strengthen its business amid global trade tensions and currency volatility.

site_title: China threatens retaliation over US arms sale to Taiwan
summary: China has threatened retaliation against the US$8 billion sale of advanced Lockheed Martin F-16 fighter jets to Taiwan, vowing to impose sanctions on American firms participating in the deal. China considers Taiwan part of its territory and considers the arms sale a severe interference in its internal affairs and a threat to its sovereignty and security. The deal is seen as a significant boost to Taiwan's military capabilities and a signal from the US to defend the island if China decides to attack.

site_title: Digitalisation must be a top priority for all companies
summary: Digitalisation is a top priority for 36% of Singapore businesses, according to a chamber of commerce survey. SMEs can experience efficiency and improve productivity through digitalisation in areas like accounting, marketing, and customer relationship management. Adopting cloud-based accounting software can also provide real-time insights into cash flow positions. To get started, business owners can speak to fellow entrepreneurs, take advantage of the Start Digital initiative, or try out digital solutions at no cost for six months. This can help them make informed decisions and stay competitive in today's digital landscape.

site_title: The real obstacle to climate action
summary: A growing global climate crisis demands drastic, immediate action to mitigate its effects. However, distributional issues, rather than aggregate costs, pose a significant obstacle to ambitious climate policies. The costs of a rapid transition may disproportionately affect certain groups, leading to resistance and blocking change. To overcome this, governments must compensate those who lose and isolate those who benefit from carbon-intensive assets. A cooperative global solution, including a carbon border tax or increased green investment in developing countries, may be necessary to deter free-riding and enhance global welfare.

images.alt_text: The infrastructure investments that the world makes today will determine the carbon intensity of its growth path for decades.

site_title: Keppel Land China inks JV to acquire, develop Nanjing mixed-use site
summary: Keppel Land China has entered a joint venture to acquire and develop a 3.8-hectare mixed-use site in Nanjing, China, with an estimated development cost of over $990 million. The company will hold a 25% stake in the JV, acquiring a 250 million yuan stake in Nanjing Zhijun Property Development Co. The project is expected to yield 211 residential units, 342 commercial units, and 79 shop units, with Phase 1 launching in Q2 2020 and completion in 2024.

site_title: 33 strata retail units at Parklane Shopping Mall put up for sale
summary: Parklane Shopping Mall in Singapore's Selegie Road is selling 33 strata retail units via an expression of interest exercise with an indicative value of S$55.7 million, or around S$2,200 per square foot. The units, which have a 99-year leasehold tenure, will be sold with existing tenancies, including McDonald's and cyber gaming cafes. The sale offers opportunities for investors to reposition the tenant mix or raise rents to yield higher returns. The expression of interest exercise closes on September 26.

images.alt_text: The 33 strata units at Parklane Shopping Mall have floor areas ranging from 23 sq m to 186 sq m, and have a 99-year leasehold tenure with effect from Dec 1, 1974. The expression of interest exercise will close on Sept 26 at 3pm.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's CFO Liu Hua reassured investors that the chairman's involvement in an investigation is not related to the group, and operations are proceeding as usual. The company's shipbuilding business has done well under CEO Ren Letian's leadership, and existing customers are comforted by the clarification. Analysts from DBS and OCBC Bank maintain their buy and neutral ratings, respectively, citing no trigger for loan reviews or significant impact on earnings. Share prices are expected to be volatile in the short term.

site_title: Synagie to provide brand store management services to Lazada
summary: Synagie, a Singapore-based e-commerce solutions provider, has partnered with Lazada to offer brand store management services across South-east Asia. Synagie's wholly owned subsidiary BTFL has signed a memorandum of understanding with Lazada to manage and operate brand stores on its online marketplaces. The partnership aims to accelerate Synagie's regional growth and expansion, and will provide marketing and e-commerce-related services to Lazada. Synagie currently manages over 280 brands in the region and will work with Lazada to provide best-in-class solutions for brands to manage their stores.

site_title: Turning passion into business concepts
summary: Two finance professionals, Grant Ashford and Lelian Chew, turned their passions into successful businesses. Ashford, a former banker, founded a private members' club for wine lovers, while Chew, also a former Goldman Sachs banker, discovered a lucrative niche in planning weddings for the super-rich. Meanwhile, author Amanda Lee Koe discusses her bestselling novel, and the article also features stories on local chefs, fashion designers, and sustainable living initiatives.

site_title: StanChart says its global network gives it an edge over rivals
summary: Standard Chartered sees opportunities in the complex cross-border financing landscape, thanks to its global network in 60 markets and 85 countries. The bank's global head of commercial, corporate and institutional banking, Simon Cooper, attributes the edge to its ability to differentiate itself from rivals by focusing on clients' needs. Network income in corporate and institutional banking grew 9% in the first half of 2019, while the bank is also expanding its presence in South-east Asia and Singapore, aiming to capture shifts in supply chains and promote Singapore as a global destination for foreign exchange.

site_title: China's Geely posts 40% slump in H1 profit as market dips
summary: China's Geely Automobile Holdings Ltd reported a 40% slump in first-half profit to 4.01 billion yuan, amid a sustained downturn in the world's biggest car market. The company forecast an uncertain outlook for vehicle demand for the rest of the year, citing higher discounts and incentives to reduce dealers' inventories ahead of stricter vehicle emissions standards. Total revenue fell 11% to 47.56 billion yuan, and vehicle sales decreased 15% to 651,680 units in the January-June period.

images.alt_text: Geely has reported a first-half net profit of 4.01 billion yuan.

site_title: Alibaba drives home costs of HK unrest
summary: Alibaba has postponed its planned $15 billion US listing in Hong Kong due to financial and political instability in the city, citing concerns about the impact of ongoing protests on business confidence. This decision may deter other companies from pursuing listings in the city, which is already lagging behind New York in terms of big listings. The delay comes as Hong Kong's economy shrinks and business confidence dwindles, with the benchmark Hang Seng Index down nearly 10% over the past month. The move may also be influenced by Beijing's influence and the need for Alibaba to avoid appearing to "gift" the city a lucrative deal.

site_title: Singapore shares fall 0.4% on Wednesday ahead of Fed's July minutes
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.4% to 3,122.57, closing at 13.38 points lower, ahead of the US Federal Reserve's July minutes and Chairman Jerome Powell's speech. Markets in the Asia-Pacific were mixed, with Hong Kong and South Korea posting slight gains. Trading volume was high, with 1.05 billion securities traded, but decliners edged out advancers 190 to 182. Local banks, including DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank, ended modestly lower.

site_title: In tough times, SMEs prioritise revenue ahead of innovation, talent retention
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are prioritizing revenue growth ahead of innovation, talent retention, and digitalization due to a slowing economy and US-China trade war. A survey by the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SCCCI) found that 82% of respondents considered expanding the topline as their key concern, with 40% predicting a drop in revenue. This shift in priorities highlights the pressing need for SMEs to focus on revenue growth to stay afloat in challenging economic times.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 8.16 points to 1,594.59. The market saw 2 billion lots worth RM1.6 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 447 to 318.

site_title: Merkel aims to work out friction-free Brexit with British PM
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel will discuss making the UK's Brexit as friction-free as possible with British Prime Minister Boris Johnson. Merkel emphasized the need for clear rules during the transition period to avoid air traffic disruption. She also stated that Britain would lose its EU air transport market rights, requiring a new agreement to be negotiated after Brexit.

site_title: South Korea exports tumble again as global outlook darkens
summary: South Korea's exports fell 13% in the first 20 days of August, the ninth consecutive monthly decline, due to trade battles and slowing global economic growth. Semiconductor sales plummeted 30%, and shipments to China, the largest buyer, dropped 20%. The weak trade data reinforces the downbeat outlook for South Korea's export-dependent economy, which is forecast to expand at the weakest pace in a decade this year.

site_title: Deutsche Telekom fights Google with a Netflix for gaming
summary: Deutsche Telekom is launching MagentaGaming, a cloud gaming service that allows users to stream over 100 titles, competing with Google's Stadia and Microsoft's xCloud. The service, set to begin beta testing on August 24, relies on superfast internet access and aims to reduce latency to under 50 milliseconds. Despite having a smaller game catalog, Deutsche Telekom believes its large broadband network and edge computing capabilities can compete with tech giants, with a focus on 5G investments to boost margins.

site_title: Euro pinned near recent lows as attention shifts to Fed
summary: The euro has been pinned near recent lows due to market expectations of a possible rate cut by the European Central Bank, despite a speech by US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell at the Jackson Hole meeting. The euro weakened to US$1.1097, while the dollar edged higher to 98.228. Analysts expect the euro to strengthen towards US$1.12 by September, driven by fiscal stimulus in Germany and a hit to the US yield advantage from falling interest rates. Sterling remains vulnerable to Brexit talks between the UK and EU.

site_title: Boeing to hire as it targets 737 MAX flights resuming 'early fourth quarter'
summary: Boeing plans to hire "a few hundred" temporary employees at Grant County International Airport in Washington state to assist with aircraft maintenance and customer delivery preparations for the resuming of 737 MAX flights in the "early fourth quarter." This is the first publicly detailed step in the planemaker's efforts to deliver hundreds of grounded jets to airlines globally. The hiring is part of Boeing's best-case plan to resume deliveries to airline customers, which has been delayed since the 737 MAX was grounded worldwide in March following two fatal crashes.

site_title: SIIC Environment enters JV for Yangtze Delta opportunities
summary: SIIC Environment Holdings has entered a joint-venture (JV) company, SIIC Yangtze Delta Environmental Resources (Hong Kong), for potential investments in waste-to-energy projects in the Yangtze River Delta region. The JV has a registered capital of HK$30 million, with SIIC Environment unit SIIC Environment Tech contributing HK$21 million and holding a 70% stake. Canvest Environmental Investment Company has a 30% stake with a HK$9 million contribution. This partnership aims to explore opportunities in the region.

site_title: Trump renews attacks on Fed's Powell
summary: President Donald Trump criticized Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, calling him "like a golfer who can't putt, has no touch," for keeping interest rates too high. Trump has repeatedly demanded the Fed cut rates by a full point to boost the economy and weaken the US dollar. This is the latest in a series of public attacks by Trump on Powell, who was appointed by Trump.

site_title: Chinese state media attack Twitter and Facebook for shutting accounts
summary: Chinese state media has criticized Twitter and Facebook for shutting accounts allegedly backed by China, calling it a "double-standard" and accusing the companies of suppressing Chinese netizens' voices. The Communist Party's Global Times and People's Daily newspapers claimed Twitter and Facebook failed to provide credible evidence of the accounts' Chinese government ties. The move drew ire from Chinese social media users, who questioned the companies' motives and freedom of speech. The Chinese government has long exercised control over domestic media and the internet, with restrictions on certain topics and censorship of critical coverage.

site_title: Norway's US$1 trillion wealth fund ends bet on higher rates
summary: Norway's $1 trillion wealth fund ended its long-standing bet on higher interest rates, shifting its massive bond portfolio to a more neutral stance due to negative yields. The fund raised its bond duration to 7 years, allowing it to profit more from falling rates. Despite delivering a 3% return in the second quarter, the fund's stocks and real estate holdings rose 3% and 0.8% respectively, driven by a selloff at the end of last year. The fund now holds a record 600 billion kroner in bonds with negative yields, or about a quarter of its fixed-income portfolio.

site_title: Oil climbs as drop in US stockpiles tempers economic worries
summary: US oil futures rose 1.5% after a 3.45 million-barrel drop in US crude inventories, easing concerns about slowing economic growth and diminishing demand. Crude prices have fallen 18% from their April highs due to the US-China trade war and tensions in the Middle East. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' efforts to curb output have also failed to boost prices. The drop in US stockpiles alleviated some of traders' worries, with investors awaiting a potential interest-rate cut by the Federal Reserve.

images.alt_text: Oil climbed after a reported drop in US crude inventories alleviated some of traders' concern that slowing economic growth will diminish demand.

site_title: 15 strata offices at Peninsula Plaza up for sale with S$17.6m guide price
summary: Fifteen strata offices at Peninsula Plaza in Singapore are up for sale via tender with a guide price of S$17.6 million, equivalent to S$2,255 per square foot. The offices, located on the sixth floor, have a combined strata area of 7,804 square feet. The sale price is within the range of recently transacted units at Peninsula Plaza, which hit S$2,500 psf earlier this year. The tender closes on September 25.

site_title: The one job in banking the robots can't take
summary: HSBC thwarted a $500 million central-bank heist by a teller, highlighting the finance industry's ongoing battle to stop illicit transfers of $2 trillion annually. Despite efforts to deploy artificial intelligence to screen transactions, machines are far from ready to replace humans, with key obstacles including poor customer data and lack of data sharing among banks and law enforcement agencies. As a result, banks are increasing regulatory efforts and spending on compliance, with over 1 in 10 institutions allocating 10% or more of their annual budgets to compliance.

site_title: Gas storage tanks in Europe are brimming with cheap LNG
summary: Spain is importing record levels of liquefied natural gas (LNG) due to persistent heat and depleted water for hydropower generation. With prices near their lowest in three years, traders are filling up LNG storage sites, which account for nearly a third of Europe's total capacity. This leaves a larger-than-usual buffer for potential winter shocks and raises questions about Europe's ability to absorb the influx of gas.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's economic slump widens, with SMEs bracing for a hit to profit margins. The Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry's annual business survey found that over half of SMEs see a drop in profit margins. The government plans to engage businesses on raising retirement age and developing a support package. Meanwhile, OCBC is in talks with Singtel about a virtual bank license, and SPH Reit has launched a S$1 billion multicurrency debt program. Singapore shares fell 0.4% on Wednesday ahead of the US Federal Reserve's July minutes release.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on US losses
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, following losses on Wall Street due to lingering trade war concerns and European falls amid Italy's political crisis. The Nikkei 225 index slid 0.91% and the Topix index fell 0.98%.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on US losses
summary: Tokyo stocks fell on Wednesday, mirroring losses on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.28% to 20,618.57, while the Topix index fell 0.61% to 1,497.51. Investors locked in profits after a three-session winning streak.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish on positive note
summary: Hong Kong shares closed higher on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index up 0.15% at 26,270.04. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index was barely moved, while the Shenzhen Composite Index dipped 0.1%. Traders focused on an upcoming speech by Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell later in the week.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks eke out gains; Fed in focus
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.22% to 1,964.65 points on Wednesday, ahead of the Federal Reserve's July meeting minutes and Chair Jerome Powell's speech at Jackson Hole. The won strengthened, and bond yields rose. Foreigners were net sellers of 128.6 billion won worth of shares, while the won was quoted at 1,202.5 per US dollar, up 0.48% from its previous close. The Kospi has fallen 3.74% so far this year, and the current price-to-earnings ratio is 12.10.

site_title: Golden Energy raises Stanmore Coal stake in A$9.7m deal
summary: Golden Energy and Resources (Gear) has increased its stake in Australia-listed Stanmore Coal to 28.42% from 25.85% after purchasing 6.6 million shares in an off-market block transaction for A$9.7 million. The move follows an earlier takeover offer that ended in January with Gear's stake at 25.5%. Gear's shares closed down 0.53% before the announcement.

site_title: Pressure mounting on EU to end ivory trade
summary: The European Union is under pressure to end the ivory trade within its borders to protect African elephants. Poaching has decimated the world elephant population, with 60% of deaths attributed to poaching. Conservation groups, such as WWF, are calling for an outright ban. The EU's inaction has contributed to the decline of elephant populations from millions to around 400,000 in 2015.

site_title: Cathay Pacific warns of 'significant' revenue impact from August
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways expects a "significant" revenue impact from August and beyond due to the ongoing protests in Hong Kong. Travel demand has weakened, with demand on China routes falling 2.8% in July, the largest decline since February. The airline has seen inbound traffic to Hong Kong decline and has faced a boycott from Chinese state-owned firms. Cathay filled 86.1% of its seats in July, down from 86.7% in the same month last year. The airline's revenue is expected to be affected by the protests, which are impacting its business and operations.

site_title: Alibaba postpones up to US$15b Hong Kong listing amid protests: sources
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd has delayed its planned US$15 billion Hong Kong listing amid growing protests in the Asian financial hub. The company postponed the listing due to a lack of financial and political stability in Hong Kong, following over 11 weeks of pro-democracy demonstrations. The decision was made in a board meeting before the company's latest quarterly earnings release. The listing, initially set for late August, could be rescheduled for October when market conditions become favorable again.

site_title: Creative posts Q4 net loss of US$2.8m on market uncertainty
summary: Creative Technology reported a Q4 net loss of US$2.8 million, down from a net profit of US$25.6 million in the year-ago period, due to uncertain market conditions affecting product sales. Revenue fell 9% to US$12.8 million, and the company expects an operating loss for the quarter. Full-year revenue was down 17% in the Asia-Pacific region and 19% in Europe, but increased 5% in the American region. Creative targets an improvement in revenue for the current financial year, driven by new product introductions.

site_title: Australia shares end lower as global growth fears hit Asia markets
summary: Australia's benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index declined 0.9% to 6,483.30, as global growth fears and concerns over industrial metals weighed on the market. Mining stocks, including BHP Group and Rio Tinto Ltd, fell 2.9% and 2.5%, respectively, due to lower Chinese iron ore futures. Consumer stocks, such as a2 Milk and Stockland, also declined, while Crown Resorts gained 1.3% on domestic revenue concerns.

site_title: Kaki Bukit Place factory up for sale with S$5.5m indicative price
summary: A five-storey intermediate terrace factory at 9 Kaki Bukit Place is up for sale with an indicative price of S$5.5 million, approximately S$420 per square foot. The 13,110 sq ft factory has a 36-year balance lease and is zoned "Business 2" with a gross plot ratio of 2.5. The sale will be on a vacant possession basis, with no payable land rent or additional buyer's stamp duty for eligible buyers. The location is expected to benefit from the transformation of Kaki Bukit into a hub for office and industrial buildings.

site_title: Asia: Markets drop as traders await Powell speech
summary: Asian markets fell on Wednesday as investors awaited Federal Reserve boss Jerome Powell's speech, despite recent gains driven by hopes for China-US trade talks. The focus shifted to Powell's address at the Jackson Hole central bankers' gathering, where experts expect clues about the Fed's monetary policy plans. Analysts disagree on whether Powell will announce further interest rate cuts or stick to current policies. Meanwhile, a political crisis in Italy offset hopes for European economic stability, weighing on currency markets.

site_title: Johnson, Merkel to face off in first Brexit talks
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is set to engage in tense talks with European leaders, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Emmanuel Macron, as the UK's impending divorce from the EU looms. The talks, which began in Berlin, aim to renegotiate elements of the UK's exit. Johnson will also meet US President Donald Trump and other international leaders at a G-7 summit in Biarritz. The EU has ruled out renegotiating, but Johnson seeks to convince them to reconsider, amid a growing threat of a chaotic no-deal Brexit.

site_title: Europe: Equities ahead at open
summary: European stock markets rose in initial trading on Wednesday, shrugging off losses elsewhere. The FTSE 100 index gained 0.4% to 7,151.86 points, while the DAX 30 added 0.4% to 11,698.83 points and the Paris CAC 40 rose 0.6% to 5,378.94 points. Investors appeared to brush off new US threats, focusing instead on mining and healthcare stocks, as well as US-EU trade talks.

site_title: US 'prepared to engage' with North Korea in nuclear talks: envoy
summary: The US is prepared to engage in nuclear talks with North Korea, according to US special representative Stephen Biegun. The talks have stalled since February's Hanoi summit, but anticipation has risen after a joint US-South Korea military drill. Biegun said the US is ready to start working-level talks "as soon as we hear from our counterparts in North Korea." This comes amid speculation of a potential meeting between Biegun and North Koreans at the demilitarized zone. The move is seen as a step towards resuming dialogue on denuclearization.

site_title: Businesses can now apply for trademark protection on Ipos mobile app
summary: Singapore's Intellectual Property of Singapore (Ipos) has launched an app called Ipos Go, allowing businesses to apply for trademark protection in under 10 minutes. The app streamlines the process, reducing the average time to apply from 45 minutes. It also features artificial intelligence to search for similar trademarks, preventing duplicate filings. This move is expected to benefit companies looking to differentiate themselves in the market, as trademark applications in Singapore have increased by 30% over the last five years. The app is an additional filing option for businesses.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,122.17, down 0.4% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) resumed trading at 3,122.17, down 0.4% on Wednesday, with 161 decliners outnumbering advancers 128. Key movers included YZJ Shipbuilding falling 2.1% and Synagie gaining 6.3%. Banking stocks were mostly down, while SPH Reit's units gained 0.9% after announcing a S$1 billion debt issuance program. Globally, equities traded mixed, with Japan and Australia's indexes declining, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng advanced 0.1%.

site_title: Indonesia-focused East Ventures closes 6th fund at target-busting US$75m
summary: East Ventures, a venture capital firm focused on Indonesia, has closed its sixth fund at a target-busting $75 million, surpassing its initial $30 million goal. The fund was supported by prominent investors including Facebook co-founder Eduardo Saverin, Alibaba co-founder Eddy Wu, and Temasek. East Ventures will focus on seed to Series A funding for Indonesian startups, with sectors including fintech, healthcare, and digital transformation. The firm has previously invested in notable Southeast Asian unicorns and has been named one of the world's top-performing venture capital fund managers.

site_title: Vegan product review startup abillionveg raises US$2m in seed funding
summary: abillionveg, a vegan product review startup, has secured US$2 million in seed funding led by 500 Startups, bringing total funding to US$2.6 million. The funding will be used to accelerate recruitment, technology, and community growth. Founded in Singapore, abillionveg is a community-driven platform that helps users find and share insights on plant-based foods, packaged goods, and cruelty-free products. The startup aims to expand its efforts in recruitment, technology, and community growth with the new funding.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 1.61 points to 1,601.14 at 9am on Wednesday, with a trading volume of 32.54 million lots worth RM11.61 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 69 to 68.

site_title: Thailand tourism confidence holds steady: survey
summary: Thailand's tourism confidence index remains steady at 100, indicating normal business, for the second quarter of 2019, with the same projection for the third quarter. The index forecasts 9.7 million international tourists in the third quarter, a 7.06% increase from the previous year, and a total of 40.06 million international tourists for 2019, a 4.65% increase. The survey highlights Bangkok and Chiang Mai's over-tourism issues, while Phuket is seen as a destination that can still take more tourists. Recommendations include improving transport infrastructure and information on transportation.

site_title: Schneider Electric launches automation starter pack for SMEs
summary: Schneider Electric has launched an automation starter pack for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), providing services, hardware, and software to improve machine management and maintenance. The package uses augmented reality and cloud-based monitoring to help SMEs automate their businesses, reducing support costs by up to 50%. The solution includes digital learning tools, remote machine tracking, and a scalable automation package to ensure a sustainable transformation process.

site_title: Over half of SMEs see drop in profit margins as Singapore economy slows: SCCCI
summary: Singapore's economic slump is affecting small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), with over half of them expecting a decline in profit margins this year, up from 45.4% last year. Nearly two in five SMEs also predict a drop in revenue, higher than 26.8% a year ago. The Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SCCCI) surveyed 972 respondents, mostly SMEs, and revealed these concerns. The economic slowdown is the key concern for SMEs, with revenue growth being a major issue going forward.

site_title: IPS Securex Q4 net loss narrows to S$0.61m from S$1.37m previously
summary: IPS Securex Holdings, a Catalist-listed company, reported a narrower fourth-quarter net loss of S$608,339, down from S$1.37 million in the previous year. Revenue fell 36.2% to S$2.34 million, with declines in security solutions and maintenance and leasing segments. The company attributed the decline to political and economic challenges in its key markets. The full-year loss narrowed 6.1% to S$1.21 million, and no dividend was declared.

site_title: Broker's take: Citi initiates coverage on 'hidden industrial gem' ESR Reit with 'buy'
summary: Citi Research has initiated coverage on ESR Reit, a fourth-largest Singapore real estate investment trust, with a "buy" rating and a target price of S$0.57. The trust has a significant exposure to high-value-add industrial space, with 46% of its assets under management and 44% of net property income. Citi analysts expect the Reit to benefit from ongoing rental recovery, asset rejuvenation, and potential acquisitions. The trust has the highest estimated yields among industrial S-Reits, and successful execution of key earnings drivers may expedite its inclusion in the FTSE EPRA/Nareit Index.

site_title: Australia: Shares slip on Wall Street weakness, growth woes
summary: Australian shares fell 0.9% to 6,103.70, dragged down by miners and retailers, amid renewed global economic worries. The decline follows a brief two-day gain streak, with investors awaiting Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's comments. The drop in Australian shares mirrored US stocks, which also fell after financial shares led the market lower.

site_title: US ports brace for surge of imports ahead of new tariffs on China
summary: US ports are preparing for a potential surge in imports ahead of new tariffs on Chinese goods, set to hit on September 1 and December 15. This is similar to the situation in late 2018, when imports flooded in before the holiday shopping season, resulting in record cargo volumes and high costs due to tight warehouse capacity. Importers, retailers, and shippers are bracing for the new tariffs, which are expected to drive a rush to get products before the holiday season, potentially leading to another record-breaking year for US ports.

site_title: 33 units at Parklane Shopping Mall up for sale with S$55.7m indicative price
summary: Parklane Shopping Mall is putting 33 strata retail units up for sale via an expression of interest exercise with an indicative value of S$55.7 million (around S$2,200 per square foot). The units, with floor areas ranging from 23 sq m to 186 sq m, have a 99-year leasehold tenure and are located in the Bras Basah/Bugis arts and cultural precinct.
