Foreigners are eligible to purchase, and the sale could potentially be repositioned to cater to growing demand in the area, including private education services, F&B operators, or a supermarket.

site_title: Yanlord Land to sell US dollar bonds with 4.5 years tenure and NC of 2.5 years
summary: Yanlord Land, a property developer, is issuing US dollar-denominated senior notes with a 4.5-year tenure and a non-call period of 2.5 years. The notes are expected to be rated "BB-" by S&P and "Ba3" by Moody's. The proceeds will be used for project development, acquisition, and general corporate purposes. DBS Bank, HSBC, and Standard Chartered have been appointed as joint global coordinators and lead managers. This move is part of the company's efforts to raise funds and support its growth strategies.

site_title: Australia to join US in Gulf maritime security mission
summary: Australia will join the US-led mission to protect shipping through the Strait of Hormuz amid heightened tensions with Iran. The country will contribute a frigate, a P8 maritime surveillance aircraft, and support staff, with the deployment set to begin in January. The move comes after the US and British governments urged Australia to participate in the mission to counter security incidents in the region, including the seizure of ships by Iran.

site_title: Water pollution can reduce economic growth by a third: World Bank
summary: The World Bank reports that heavily polluted water can reduce economic growth by up to a third in some countries. The report, based on the largest-ever database of global water quality, highlights the human and environmental harm caused by deteriorating water quality, stalling economic growth, worsening health conditions, and exacerbating poverty. World Bank Group President David Malpass emphasized the importance of addressing water pollution to support economic growth.

images.alt_text: Heavily polluted water is reducing economic growth by up to a third in some countries, a World Bank report said on Tuesday, calling for action to address human and environmental harm.

site_title: Facebook hiring journalists to curate its new News Tab
summary: Facebook is launching a new News Tab, separate from its traditional news feed, which will be curated by human journalists. The tab will feature relevant, reliable breaking and top news stories, while other sections will rely on algorithms to determine user interests. Facebook head of news partnerships Campbell Brown said the goal is to provide a personalized, highly relevant experience for users. The tab will be funded by licensing news content from publishers, and Facebook will also pay some publishers to license content for the tab.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday; STI down 0.3% to 3,127.37
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Wednesday, tracking Wall Street losses, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.3% to 3,127.37. The decline follows US equities slipping amid concerns over global growth and the protracted trade war between the US and China. Key stocks such as Synagie and YZJ Shipbuilding traded heavily, while banking stocks remained mixed.

site_title: Synagie to provide brand store services for Lazada
summary: Singapore-based e-commerce solutions provider Synagie has partnered with Lazada to provide brand store management services across South-east Asia. Synagie's wholly owned subsidiary, BTFL, has signed a memorandum of understanding with Lazada, which will appoint Synagie as a regional partner to offer marketing and e-commerce-related services. This partnership aims to help Synagie accelerate its regional growth and expansion, with Synagie currently managing over 280 brands in the region.

site_title: In high-tech Japan, cash is still king
summary: Japan, known for its high-tech society, still relies heavily on cash transactions, with four out of five purchases made with physical money. Despite a 2020 Tokyo Olympics push to increase electronic payments to 40% by 2025, the country's ageing population's preference for cash persists. The government aims to introduce a points system to encourage cashless payments and mitigate a consumption tax hike. Companies, such as Rakuten, are promoting a cashless society, but security concerns and the success of cashless initiatives in other countries like South Korea and Sweden hinder progress.

images.alt_text: Once a pioneer in cashless transactions, Japan is now lagging behind as the world's biggest economies increasingly embrace electronic payments - because its ageing population still prefers physical money.

site_title: Government to engage businesses on raising of retirement age, develop support package: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced plans to engage businesses and stakeholders to discuss the transition to higher retirement and re-employment ages, with the goal of raising the statutory retirement age to 63 by 2022 and 65 by 2030. Ministers will develop a support package to help with the transition. Heng spoke to unionists, students, and community partners after the National Day Rally on Sunday. The move aims to mitigate the impact of the increasing retirement age on the workforce.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start with fresh losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks began trading lower on Wednesday, extending previous day's losses, amid uncertainty over the China-US trade spat. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.27%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. Investors are awaiting news on developments in the trade spat, which has led to a negative lead from Wall Street.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Wednesday, extending the previous day's losses and tracking a negative lead from Wall Street as investors await news of developments in the China-US trade spat.

site_title: OCBC in talks with Singtel about virtual bank licence, say sources
summary: OCBC, Singapore's second-largest bank, is in talks with companies including Singtel to secure one of the city-state's planned virtual bank licenses. OCBC would take a minority stake in a joint venture, aiming to tap new customers and markets. This move follows global banks partnering with telcos and tech firms to expand their financial services offerings. A similar partnership was recently formed in Hong Kong between Standard Chartered and PCCW Ltd.

site_title: New Zealand's a2 Milk flags higher marketing spend as 'daigou' sales dry up
summary: New Zealand's a2 Milk reported a 41% leap in revenue for the year, driven by robust Chinese sales, but missed profit expectations due to higher marketing costs. The company plans to invest 12% of sales in China in 2020, prioritizing physical stores over "daigou" shoppers, who purchase products in bulk from stores outside China. A2 Milk's shares plummeted nearly 15% after the announcement.

site_title: UK supermarkets test plastic-free zones
summary: British supermarkets are introducing "nude zones" or "Food in the Nude" campaigns, stripping shelves of plastic wrapping to reduce waste and save the oceans. The initiative follows similar campaigns in New Zealand and South Africa, where fresh produce is readily available. Retailers in the UK, including major brands, are gradually adopting this practice, with the goal of reducing plastic waste and promoting sustainability.

images.alt_text: British supermarkets are starting to go "nude". Bowing to pressure from environmentally conscious consumers, big brand shops have begun taking steps to strip their shelves of plastic wrapping over concerns about saving the oceans from waste.

site_title: Del Monte to close 2 US facilities, sell another as it turns to asset-light strategy
summary: Del Monte Pacific Limited, a food and beverage firm, plans to close two US production facilities and sell a third as it adopts an asset-light strategy. The closures, set to occur at the end of the current pack season, will allow the company to utilize existing capacity and increase focus on branded growth and innovation. The decision, made by CEO Joselito D Campos, aims to make the company more efficient and competitive in a rapidly changing marketplace.

site_title: US State Dept approves sale of 66 F-16 fighters to Taiwan
summary: The US State Department has approved a $8 billion sale of 66 F-16 fighters to Taiwan, the latest version of the Lockheed Martin-built fighter, the F-16C/D Block 70. The sale, which was green-lit by President Donald Trump, is expected to anger Beijing, which regards Taiwan as part of China. The sale is seen as a response to increasing Chinese military incursions into Taiwan's airspace and is consistent with past US policy. The Defense Security Cooperation Agency stated that the sale will not alter the military balance in the region, but China's foreign ministry has warned of severe consequences.

site_title: Argentina's Kirchner leads call to free Brazil's Lula
summary: Argentina's presidential frontrunner Alberto Fernandez and his running-mate Cristina Kirchner have called for the release of Brazil's jailed leftist leader Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva. A petition signed by dozens of Argentine personalities, including Nobel Peace laureate Adolfo Perez Esquivel, urges Lula's freedom amid allegations of an unjust detention. Fernandez previously visited Lula in prison and criticized Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro as "misogynist, racist and violent". Lula maintains he is an innocent victim of a political conspiracy to prevent him from returning to power.

site_title: SPH Reit launches S$1b multicurrency debt programme; in talks for potential acquisition
summary: SPH Reit has launched a S$1 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme, with potential proceeds used for a possible acquisition. The Reit's manager is conducting due diligence on the acquisition, with discussions described as preliminary. The debt programme will issue notes and perpetual securities, with net proceeds used for general working capital, capital expenditure, and/or refinancing existing borrowings. Units of the Reit remained unchanged at S$1.07 following the announcement.

site_title: Singtel prices US$750m of 10-year notes at 2.375%
summary: Singtel priced US$750 million of 10-year notes at 2.375% per annum, with the issue receiving interest of approximately US$2.7 billion and being 3.6 times oversubscribed. The notes, which mature in 2029, are rated A1 by Moody's and A+ by S&P Global Ratings. The net proceeds will be used to fund Singtel's ordinary course of business, part of its long-term financing strategy. The issue extends Singtel's debt maturity profile and reflects investors' confidence in the group's high credit quality.

site_title: Can Singapore become an Electric Vehicle leader?
summary: Singapore is lagging behind other countries in electric vehicle (EV) adoption, despite being well-positioned for autonomous vehicle development. The city-state has only around 700 EVs on the road, with most being used by fleets like the HDT Singapore Taxi and BlueSG car-sharing service. However, experts believe that infrastructure and cost barriers are holding back personal EV sales. With the government offering a S$20,000 rebate for EVs and charging being significantly cheaper than filling up a tank, Singapore can potentially accelerate the EV transition and reduce 33,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions by 2021.

site_title: Ryanair cabin crew in Spain warn of September strike
summary: Ryanair cabin crew in Spain have warned of a 10-day strike in September over the anticipated closure of some airport bases due to Boeing's 737 Max crisis. The unions USO and Sitcpla, representing 13 bases, are protesting against the possible closure of bases on Canary islands and future uncertainty in Girona. The strike is set to affect mainly Fridays and Sundays in September, with more meetings between unions and Ryanair management to be held next week.

site_title: Saudi Arabia eases travel restrictions on women
summary: Saudi Arabia has begun implementing a landmark reform allowing women over 21 to obtain passports and travel abroad without permission from a male guardian. This reform weakens the restrictive guardianship system, a symbol of repression against women. The passport department is now accepting applications from women aged 21 and above to issue or renew passports and travel outside the kingdom. This move marks a significant step towards greater freedom and equality for women in Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Singapore has role in BRI's investment into South-east Asia
summary: Singapore can play a crucial role in the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) 2.0 by leveraging its third-party infrastructure frameworks and networks to facilitate more open, inclusive, sustainable, and market-driven projects in South-east Asia. Singapore can help China engage other countries by building relationships across governments, international business, and people, and can assist in creating an environment to entice Chinese firms to work within its frameworks. This includes setting up a dedicated arm within Infrastructure Asia to help Chinese companies identify and pitch projects, and fostering strategic partnerships between Chinese state-owned and privately owned enterprises and international firms.

site_title: Trump insists US recession not in the cards
summary: US President Donald Trump insists that a recession is not in the cards, despite a growing number of economists predicting a downturn. The president attributes the low unemployment rate and economic growth to his policies, while blaming the Federal Reserve and media outlets for fueling recession fears. Trump is considering a cut to capital gains taxes, which he believes will boost the economy without being related to a recession. However, the inverted yield curve, a statistical phenomenon that has previously predicted recession, has raised concerns about the economy's future.

site_title: More than 2,300 tigers killed and trafficked this century: report
summary: More than 2,300 endangered tigers have been killed and trafficked since the turn of the century, with an average of over 120 seized annually, according to a report by conservation group Traffic. The numbers are deeply concerning, with tiger population numbers estimated to be fewer than 3,900 in the wild. The report highlights the growing role of breeding centers in fueling the illegal tiger trade, particularly in Southeast Asia. It urges more action to protect the species, calling for CITES to monitor tiger farms to prevent the illegal trade chain.

site_title: People in protest-hit Hong Kong eye Malaysia's second-home programme
summary: Malaysia's "Malaysia My Second Home" (MM2H) programme has seen a surge in applications from Hong Kong residents, with 251 applications received this year, compared to 193 approved last year. The programme aims to attract wealthy foreigners to live in the country, with property consultants expecting Malaysia and Thailand to benefit from Hong Kong residents' frustration with the city's anti-Beijing protests. The programme has received a total of 3,500 applications this year, with applicants typically working in sectors such as information and communications technology and holding property valued at RM1 million or more.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Daly says she doesn't see a US recession on the horizon
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President Mary Daly stated that the US economy doesn't appear to be headed toward a recession, citing solid domestic momentum and data on labor markets and consumer spending. However, Daly noted that global growth and trade uncertainties pose considerable headwinds. The Federal Reserve has cut interest rates, and Fed Chair Jerome Powell is set to speak on Friday, with investors awaiting his comments on further easing. Daly's comments echo those of White House advisers who downplayed recession fears, but her support for the interest rate cut is based on her desire to see the economic expansion continue.

site_title: Keppel Logistics unit UrbanFox expands to Vietnam, Malaysia
summary: Keppel Logistics' unit UrbanFox is expanding to Vietnam and Malaysia with support from Enterprise Singapore. UrbanFox established online-to-offline capabilities at Estella Place shopping mall in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. This move marks the firm's entry into overseas markets. UrbanFox, a Keppel Logistics subsidiary, aims to leverage Enterprise Singapore's support to drive growth in the region.

images.alt_text: UrbanFox manages the logistics and e-commerce needs of more than 500 brands and over 20,000 products from various industries including food, books and fashion.

site_title: Trump unsettles G-7 with support for Russia return
summary: US President Donald Trump has expressed support for Russia's possible return to the G-7, sparking concern among G-7 partners. Trump's comments, made four days before the summit in Biarritz, contradict the group's history of non-confrontational discussions. The US leader has also threatened to retaliate against France over its digital tax, and will push for flexibility on NATO funding and trade issues. Despite criticism, Trump may find allies in Boris Johnson and other world leaders who see strategic challenges from China and Russia as a reason to work with him.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, OUE C-Reit, OUE H-Trust, Del Monte, Soilbuild Reit
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

Several Singaporean stocks are under scrutiny. Singtel closed its US$750 million 10-year notes, receiving strong demand and interest of US$2.7 billion. OUE C-Reit and OUE H-Trust are set to merge, with a court hearing scheduled for August 26. Del Monte Pacific is closing two US production facilities and selling a third, shifting to an asset-light strategy. Soilbuild Business Space Reit's tenant NK Ingredients has been put under judicial management, owing S$3.4 million. Noel Gifts International warned of an expected loss for its financial year, citing a write-down in valuation of its industrial investment property.

site_title: Apple debuts credit card as it readies TV+ launch
summary: Apple has launched a credit card tailored for iPhone users in the US, aiming to offset declining smartphone sales. The move comes as the company prepares to launch its TV+ streaming service before Disney's rival launch in November. This shift in focus highlights Apple's emphasis on digital content and services.

site_title: HK leader Lam hopes non-violent protest signals road to peace
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam expressed hope that a peaceful protest over the weekend marked the start of efforts to restore peace in the city. The protests, now in their 11th week, were sparked by a bill allowing extradition to mainland China and have been fueled by concerns over the erosion of freedoms. Lam announced a fact-finding study and a robust system to investigate police complaints, while also committing to the bill's death. Further protests are planned, and China has increased pressure on companies, including Cathay Pacific Airways.

site_title: Li Ka-Shing firm makes US$3.3b bet pubs will survive Brexit
summary: Hong Kong's CK Asset Holdings unit agreed to pay $3.3 billion for UK pub operator Greene King Plc, valuing the company at 850 pence per share. The deal reflects confidence in the UK economy despite Brexit uncertainty, with the conglomerate citing pubs' importance to British culture and their attractive real estate assets. The acquisition is CK Asset's largest bet since a 2017 purchase of an Australian power provider, and signals Victor Li's strategy to boost rental income and diversify away from real estate.

site_title: Barclays forecasts three more Federal Reserve rate cuts as Europe slows
summary: Barclays economists predict three additional Federal Reserve rate cuts in 2019, citing slowing global growth and a strengthening dollar. The forecast comes as the UK is expected to enter a mild recession next year and experience two interest-rate cuts by the Bank of England. The US economy is forecast to grow around 2% next year, with downside risks from global slowdowns and trade policy concerns. This contradicts the views of other major banks, which see only one more rate cut for 2019.

images.alt_text: Economists at Barclays PLC this week revised their outlook for central bank rates and growth across major economies and now project three additional quarter-point cuts by the Federal Reserve in 2019.

site_title: Most currencies slip under pressure from strong US$
summary: Emerging Asian currencies declined on Tuesday amid a strengthening US dollar, driven by expectations of a potential US Federal Reserve rate cut in September. The yuan, a bellwether for regional currencies, also weakened. Investors anticipate a fresh stimulus from global policymakers, further pressuring currencies.

site_title: Chairman, MD offer S$0.118 a share to delist PS Group
summary: PS Group, a Catalist-listed fastener supplier, has received a voluntary conditional cash offer of S$0.118 per share from two directors to take the company private. The offer price values the company at about S$8 million, nearly three times its last transacted price.

site_title: New Fortis CEO plans fixes after Singh brothers' alleged fraud
summary: New Fortis CEO Ashutosh Raghuvanshi plans to cut $31m in expenses over two years to revitalize India's second-largest hospital chain, following a regulator's findings of alleged fraud by the former owners. Raghuvanshi aims to reduce costs through measures such as energy-efficient lighting, automating business analysis, and renegotiating doctors' salaries.

images.alt_text: Mr Raghuvanshi was CEO at the Narayana Hrudayalaya hospital chain, which is famous for achieving some of the lowest costs in the world through its hyper-efficient processes, and is bringing to Fortis his old playbook.

site_title: WhatsApp in talks to launch mobile payments in Indonesia: sources
summary: WhatsApp is in talks with Indonesian digital payment firms to offer mobile transaction services, marking its entry into the nation's growing e-commerce sector. The move, pending regulatory approval, could serve as a template for WhatsApp's adoption in other emerging markets. This would follow WhatsApp's planned launch in India, its largest market, which has been delayed due to local data storage rules.

site_title: UOB, OCBC and DBS lead in study of Asean sustainable banking
summary: Singapore banks UOB, OCBC, and DBS are leading in a study of Asean sustainable banking, meeting at least half of the 70 criteria set by the World Wildlife Fund (WWF). The banks prohibited financing of new coal-fired power plants and implemented no-deforestation commitments, unlike 91% of their peers. However, only three banks (including Singapore banks) met at least half of the criteria, and most banks made improvements from last year's performance. The WWF warned that financial instability and social unrest may result if environmental degradation and climate change are not addressed in a timely manner.

site_title: Buyouts engineered by optimistic CEOs and pessimistic CFOs have best odds of success
summary: Global M&A activity is at a 10-year peak, driven by sustained economic growth and low debt costs, reaching US$4.1 trillion in 2018. Despite a 80% failure rate, research suggests that an optimal combination of an optimistic CEO and a pessimistic CFO can increase the odds of M&A success. In Singapore, 14 companies were bought out or privatized in the first half of 2019, fueling the trend. The study's findings provide a data-driven approach to identifying successful M&A deals, bucking the gloom of the US-China trade war.

site_title: Ares raises 1.78b euro Europe property fund
summary: Ares Management has raised 1.78 billion euros for its largest European real estate fund, Ares EF V, to target distressed and poorly managed assets. The fund will be managed by Ares Real Estate Group, led by Bill Benjamin. This is Ares' largest European fund yet, marking a significant step in the firm's expansion into distressed assets. The company plans to utilize the fund to capitalize on opportunities in the European real estate market.

site_title: 'Matrix 4' announced with Keanu Reeves to return as Neo
summary: Warner Bros. announced the fourth installment of "The Matrix" series, with Lana Wachowski set to write, direct, and produce. Keanu Reeves will reprise his role as Neo, and the film is expected to follow the popular series' storyline about humans trapped in a virtual reality by machines. The project has generated excitement, with studio chairman Toby Emmerich stating the team is "excited to be re-entering" the franchise. No release date has been announced.

site_title: No plans to extend pilot Medisave contribution scheme to private sector
summary: Singapore's Manpower Minister Josephine Teo has stated there are no plans to extend the Contribute As You Earn (CAYE) pilot scheme, which automatically channels a portion of freelancers' fees into their Medisave accounts, to the private sector. The pilot, set to begin in early 2020, aims to make it convenient for freelancers to save for healthcare and retirement. Teo emphasized that the scheme is not mandatory and will be evaluated to ensure its effectiveness.

site_title: US: Stocks fall, ending three-day winning streak
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday, snapping a three-day winning streak, amid concerns over global growth and the US-China trade war. The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 0.7% to 25,962.44, while the S&P 500 slid 0.8% to 2,900.51. US President Donald Trump's comments on a potential trade deal with China and a drop in the 10-year Treasury yield contributed to the decline. Analysts expect low trading volumes in August to exacerbate market moves, and some individual companies, such as Home Depot, reported mixed results.

site_title: Europe: Shares end lower as Italy's political crisis weighs
summary: European shares fell on Tuesday, closing 1.1% lower, as optimism over stimulus in major economies waned and investors awaited central bank guidance. Italy's government crisis, with Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte's resignation potentially paving the way for a new coalition, weighed on sentiment. Despite a 10% jump in Pandora's shares, all sub-sectors ended in the negative, with interest-rate sensitive banks weighing the most. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index is still down 3.4% for the month, with investors awaiting the Jackson Hole Symposium for substantive comments from US and European central bank heads.

site_title: Italian PM resigns, denounces Salvini for sinking government
summary: Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte resigned after criticizing Interior Minister Matteo Salvini for sinking the government and endangering the economy. Conte accused Salvini of seeking personal and political gain, following Salvini's declaration of a dead alliance with the 5-Star Movement. Salvini's move could lead to elections, potentially benefiting his rivals. Conte's resignation marks the end of a 14-month-old government, with Conte citing Salvini's actions as the reason for his departure.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: GSS Energy reported Q2 FY2019 profit of S$0.087 million, driven by price competition and cost-down pressures. Revenue decreased 5.7% year-on-year due to weaker demand, and margins narrowed to 15.4%. Thai Beverage posted a strong Q3 FY2019, with revenue up 3.3% and earnings accounting for 97% of FY2019 forecast. Analysts maintain neutral recommendations for both companies, citing tepid macroeconomic outlook and potential upside risks.

site_title: Inex, Nova Satra merge to tackle healthcare for Asian women
summary: Inex Innovate, a Singaporean molecular diagnostics group, has merged with Nova Satra Dx to address the unmet need for faster and more accurate diagnostics testing and precision healthcare for Asian women. The combined company, valued at US$72 million, will focus on developing technologies for women's reproductive health, including point-of-care kits and blood-based tests. With a pipeline of new technologies, Inex Innovate plans to commercialize its solutions across Asia by 2020, capitalizing on the growing demand for precision healthcare in the region.

site_title: Government to weigh economic conditions before each hike in CPF rates: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's government will consider economic conditions before increasing CPF rates and retirement ages. Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing stated that the increases will be implemented over 10 years to balance cost pressures. The retirement age will be raised to 65, and re-employment age to 70, with CPF contributions increasing to 37% over 10 years. The changes, announced in July, will start taking effect on January 1, 2021, and July 1, 2022, respectively.

site_title: Investors need a gilt hedge against 'psycho-currencies': Mobius
summary: Veteran investor Mark Mobius endorses buying gold as a hedge against "psycho-currencies" and a safe haven during times of economic uncertainty. He recommends allocating 10% of a portfolio to physical bullion, citing the increasing role of digital currencies as a boost to traditional haven gold. With central banks loosening monetary policy and signs of a global slowdown emerging, Mobius predicts gold prices will continue to rise, driven by increasing demand for hard assets. He correctly predicted gold prices would top $1,500 in early July.

site_title: Policymakers can fight next recession by 'going direct'
summary: Central bankers should adopt a "going direct" approach to combat the next recession, which involves directly providing funds to entities that can spend them, such as consumers. This is necessary due to the limited monetary policy space, as interest rates have reached record lows. A framework is needed to ensure fiscal policy is deployed efficiently and to avoid undermining central bank independence. Policymakers should consider creating a standing emergency fiscal facility to boost aggregate demand and inflation, while preserving central bank credibility. This approach requires unprecedented coordination and clarity on how to successfully combat the next recession.

site_title: It's getting harder to make easy money in Asia bonds as junk gets binned
summary: Asia's bond market faces challenges as speculative-grade junk debt loses money for three straight weeks, its worst streak since late last year. Fund managers are becoming increasingly selective, redeploying to safer investment-grade notes and sectors tied to government policy objectives. The ongoing US-China trade war, weak economic data, and yield curve inversion have unnerved investors, leading to a risk-off tone. Asia dollar bonds are expected to outperform high yield for the remainder of the year, but sustaining strong returns will be difficult due to the fading market appetite for riskier securities.

site_title: English town celebrates hometown hero Ed Sheeran
summary: The town of Ipswich in eastern England is celebrating hometown hero Ed Sheeran, marking the end of his two-year international tour with four homecoming shows. An exhibition, "Made in Suffolk," showcases Sheeran's career, from his early days playing gigs in Framlingham to his current status as a global hit machine with a £160 million fortune. The event highlights his humble beginnings and determination to succeed, as well as his private side and personal relationships. Sheeran is hailed as a hero in Ipswich, where fans celebrate his success and admire his down-to-earth personality.

site_title: Cathay Pacific's new boss puts emphasis on safety and security
summary: Cathay Pacific's new CEO, Augustus Tang, has emphasized the need to focus on safety and security amid Chinese scrutiny over staff involvement in Hong Kong protests. Tang also highlighted the importance of completing a three-year financial turnaround plan, following the sudden exit of Rupert Hogg. The airline faces significant challenges as it navigates the ongoing crisis.

site_title: SAP Ariba, Standard Chartered to offer one-stop supply chain solutions
summary: SAP Ariba has partnered with Standard Chartered Bank to offer one-stop supply chain solutions, bridging the gap between financing and procure-to-pay processes for its 4.2 million members in 190 countries. The partnership will enable buyers and suppliers to manage payments, financing, and foreign exchange needs on the SAP Ariba platform by the end of 2019. The collaboration aims to provide cost savings, flexible financing, and better connectivity across the ecosystem, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises.

site_title: Aramco to select Lazard, Moelis for world's biggest IPO: sources
summary: Saudi Aramco has selected Lazard and Moelis & Co to advise on the oil giant's second attempt at the world's largest initial public offering (IPO). The boutique investment banks have started preparatory work on the offering, which is expected to value around $100 billion. Lazard, which previously worked on Aramco's bond sale, is likely to replace one of the original advisers and has been selected for its role in selecting underwriters and listing venues. The IPO is part of Saudi Arabia's Vision 2030 plan to modernize the economy.

site_title: Furniture brand Commune taps tech tools for AR, VR experience
summary: Furniture brand Commune launches an augmented reality (AR) app that allows customers to digitally visualize furniture in their homes. The 90% accurate 3D models can be placed virtually in homes using AR and smart devices' camera function. The app aims to enhance shopping experiences and make informed decisions. Commune's new mobile point-of-sales system also reduces customer service time by 70%. The tools are part of Commune's experience technology roadmap and will be rolled out at the end of the month.

site_title: S-E Asia real estate markets stay the course amid global uncertainties
summary: S-E Asia real estate markets remain resilient amid global economic uncertainties, with foreign direct investments and domestic consumption driving growth. Despite slowing global growth, countries like Indonesia, Vietnam, and the Philippines see strong FDI and domestic consumption, bolstered by political stability. Real estate fundamentals remain strong, with demand for commercial space and office rents expected to rise 7% over 2.5 years, and retail rents projected to grow 3% annually. The region's currencies are expected to remain stable, supporting further investments and growth.

site_title: Humbled Deutsche Bank faces battle in its own backyard
summary: Deutsche Bank is facing a challenging time in Germany, where it's struggling to regain its footing as a major corporate bank. Despite CEO Christian Sewing's efforts to rebuild the bank's corporate division, it's facing resistance from companies like Zalando, which is spreading its cash across multiple lenders to mitigate risk. This trend is exacerbated by the crowded German market, where domestic and foreign banks are vying for corporate clients. Deutsche's push to re-establish itself as a Hausbank for German corporates is being hindered by its own data showing a decline in cash stored with the bank.

site_title: Microsoft co-founder's Vulcan Capital to deploy US$100m in venture funds across S-E Asia
summary: Microsoft co-founder Paul G Allen's venture capital firm, Vulcan Capital, has launched its first international expansion with a $100 million fund in Singapore. The office, led by managing director Tommy Teo, will focus on early-stage investments in Indonesia, Vietnam, and Singapore. Vulcan Capital aims to build a portfolio of 8-12 companies over the next 18-36 months, with investment returns supporting philanthropic efforts led by Vulcan Inc. The firm's Singapore office is seen as a natural fit, given its history of early-stage investments and the presence of local and foreign accelerators and venture capital firms in the region.

site_title: Gamers risk health hazard in bid to be eSports millionaires
summary: Professional eSports players risk physical health hazards, including deteriorating eyesight, digestive problems, and wrist and hand damage, in pursuit of lucrative prizes. Despite initial skepticism, injuries are a reality, with many players experiencing long-term consequences. The International eSports tournament in Shanghai offers a record $33.5 million in prize money, highlighting the high stakes and potential risks involved. As the eSports industry continues to grow, players must weigh the risks and rewards of competing at the highest level.

site_title: Oil steadies as hopes of easing trade tensions lend support
summary: Oil prices steadied on Tuesday, with Brent crude rising 0.5% to $60.03 a barrel and US crude increasing 13 cents to $56.34 a barrel. Optimism over easing US-China trade tensions and potential stimulus measures from major economies supported the gains. However, US President Donald Trump's comments later in the day raised concerns, causing US crude to turn lower. The United States extended a reprieve for Huawei Technologies to buy components from US companies, signaling a slight softening of the trade conflict.

images.alt_text: Oil prices steadied on Tuesday on optimism US-China trade tensions will ease and hopes major economies will take stimulus measures to ward off a possible economic slowdown, after falling earlier on concerns over future demand.

site_title: Napier Port soars on debut as investors toast rare NZ listing
summary: Napier Port Holdings, New Zealand's fourth-largest port by container volume, made its debut on the country's bourse at a 12% premium to its offer price. The company raised NZ$234 million to reduce debt and fund a new wharf construction. Despite a weaker log price affecting trading partners, CEO Todd Dawson stated that log volumes have not slowed. The IPO comes amid heightened uncertainty from the US-China trade war, but investors see the port as a "good quality asset and was fairly priced." The company's market cap is NZ$582 million.

site_title: Expedia puts Asia front and centre in global push
summary: Expedia Group, a leading online travel company, aims to shift its focus to international operations, particularly in Asia, to account for two-thirds of its revenue. The company's CEO, Mark Okerstrom, wants Asia to be a major contributor to the company's growth, with a compound annual growth rate of 17% over the past five years. Expedia plans to deploy locally relevant content and expand its presence in Asian markets, such as Japan, to drive its global agenda. The company's goal is to become the world's travel platform, and Okerstrom believes that winning in Asia is crucial to achieving this vision.

images.alt_text: Mr Okerstrom this month capped his second year as boss of the travel tech giant after he took over the top seat from Dara Khosrowshahi, who is now Uber's CEO, in August 2017.

site_title: Striking a balance in market regulation
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) have announced proposed initiatives to improve enforcement and raise standards of financial institutions, targeting 740 listed companies worth S$980 billion. The MAS released a consultation paper on requirements for control against market abuses such as market manipulation and insider trading, aiming to strike a balance in market regulation.

site_title: Are scrubbers really good for the environment?
summary: Full-scale testing on newbuild vessels has found that scrubbers are the most environmentally beneficial way to meet global greenhouse gas emissions targets. The use of scrubbers, which remove pollutants from ship emissions, is seen as a solution to the sulphur problem and a step towards reducing CO2 emissions. The findings come ahead of a global sulphur limit of 0.5% for marine fuels set to come into force in four months. This policy overlap highlights the need for shipowners and governments to work together to address emissions challenges.

site_title: AppleTV+ targeted for November launch
summary: Apple plans to launch its AppleTV+ movie and TV subscription service by November, aiming to reach $50 billion in service sales by 2020. The service will initially offer a small selection of shows, with a free trial and global availability in over 150 countries. Apple is considering a release strategy of offering the first three episodes of some programs, followed by weekly installments. The service is expected to cost around $9.99 per month, matching Apple Music and Apple News+. This move is part of Apple's strategy to generate revenue from its large user base of iPhone, iPad, Mac, and Apple Watch users.

site_title: Despite rifts and fissures, Malaysia's PH coalition remains intact
summary: Malaysia's ruling PH coalition remains intact despite recent internal conflicts. A sex video controversy involving Economics Affairs minister Azmin Ali and a debate over the teaching of Arabic calligraphy in schools have sparked dissent among leaders from Chinese and Tamil schools. However, the coalition has weathered these challenges, with Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad refusing to sack Azmin and the police unable to identify the men in the video. The government's refusal to deport outspoken Muslim preacher Zakir Naik has also been met with public outcry, but the coalition remains unified, with no evidence of defections or party splits.

site_title: Confiscated Beijing skyscraper sold via online auction
summary: A Beijing skyscraper, Pangu Plaza, confiscated from Chinese billionaire Guo Wengui, was sold in an online auction for 5.18 billion yuan (S$1 billion). The 40-storey building, shaped like a modernist dragon, was put up for sale by creditors after being seized in 2014. The buyer, a Beijing-based property development and management company, outbid 145,000 internet users, with the sale price being just over the reserve price. The building's history is marred by corruption allegations against Guo Wengui and Beijing deputy mayor Liu Zhihua.

site_title: Businesses, markets wait with bated breath for UK-EU compromise deal
summary: Business leaders, stock markets, and institutions are waiting anxiously for a UK-EU compromise deal on Brexit, with a no-agreement scenario potentially leading to an adjustment period and economic uncertainty. UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson is set to meet key EU players this week, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Emmanuel Macron, in hopes of forging a deal. The lack of a deal could lead to a recession in the UK and EU economies, with potential consequences for global markets and investors.

site_title: Shanghai aluminium hits over 9-month high on supply worries
summary: Shanghai aluminium reached its highest level in over nine months due to supply worries in top producer China. A power disruption at a northwest China smelter halted 500,000-tonne-per-year production, equivalent to 1.4% of total Chinese production last year. The Shanghai Futures Exchange aluminium contract surged 1.2% to 14,455 yuan (S$2,837) a tonne, while the London Metal Exchange three-month aluminium contract rose 0.1% to US$1,795 a tonne. Market analysts expect potential supply disruption to last 3-5 months, affecting prices.

site_title: Qualcomm strikes new licensing deal with LG
summary: Qualcomm has entered into a new five-year patent license agreement with LG Electronics to develop, manufacture, and sell 3G, 4G, and 5G smartphones. This deal comes after LG was unable to renew its chip license agreement in June. The agreement follows a settlement reached by Qualcomm in April that allowed iPhones to use its modem chips, despite a previous investment in Intel's modem business.

site_title: China iron ore futures hit 10-week low on easing of supply concerns
summary: China's iron ore futures plummeted to a 10-week low, falling 2.2% to 609 yuan (S$120) a tonne on the Dalian Commodity Exchange, as supply concerns eased and production curbs in Tangshan, a top steelmaking city, added downward pressure. This marks the contract's weakest finish since June 11.

site_title: Indian economy waits for dose of optimism
summary: India's business community is concerned about the government's policies, which have led to slowing economic growth, rising unemployment, and plunging consumption. The government's 2019 budget imposed new taxes on share transactions, dividends, and recipients, raising total taxes to around 60%. Investors pulled $1.8 billion out of Indian stocks in July. The finance minister, Nirmala Sitharaman, has stated that the new taxes will not have an adverse impact on investor confidence. However, analysts expect the government to consider an exemption for foreign investors and lower the burden of the Long Term Capital Gains tax. The economy's slowdown is largely due to sharply plunging consumption, with unemployment reaching a 45-year high and housing sales in the doldrums.

site_title: Boston Fed president not willing to back further rate cuts, says US economy still good
summary: Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren stated that he is unwilling to support further interest rate cuts, citing concerns that easing policy could encourage a debt build-up and worsen the next economic downturn. Rosengren believes it is a bigger risk to encourage excessive risk-taking at this time, leaving the Fed with limited ammunition for future spending. He emphasized that US economic conditions remain good, and the Fed should focus on maintaining current policies rather than cutting rates further.

site_title: Manila's 2020 budget plans big boost for infrastructure, schools, healthcare
summary: The Philippine government has submitted a proposed 2020 budget to Congress, which increases spending by 12% from the previous year. The budget aims to address poverty, improve education, and upgrade the country's infrastructure. A smooth passage of the budget is crucial for President Rodrigo Duterte to deliver on his key policy promises, particularly with three years remaining in his term. The budget's approval will help momentum from the mid-term elections in May, where his allies won overwhelmingly.

site_title: Freepoint to supply IMO-compliant bunker fuel in Singapore from Q4
summary: Freepoint Commodities Singapore will start supplying very low-sulphur fuel oil (VLSFO) in the fourth quarter, meeting International Maritime Organization (IMO) standards set for 2020. The company is upgrading a terminal in Indonesia to blend oil components and supply VLSFO to Singapore, where it will serve the world's largest bunkering port. Freepoint plans to guarantee the minimum viscosity required by shipowners, making it a preferred supplier, as concerns about VLSFO availability and compatibility issues persist.

site_title: Shares advance, build on Monday's gains
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 7.50 points or 0.2% to close at 3,135.95, driven by easing US-China trade tensions and accommodative central bank policies. Markets in Asia-Pacific were mixed, with China and Hong Kong finishing lower. Investors are hopeful for fiscal stimulus and potential interest rate reform, with some analysts warning that longer-term concerns remain, including recessionary fears and falling bond yields. Trading volume was 1.29 billion securities, and the blue-chip index had nine counters closing in the red.

site_title: Local banks satisfy at least 50% of criteria in sustainable banking study: WWF
summary: Singapore's three major banks - DBS, UOB, and OCBC - and Thailand's Kasikorn Bank are the only 35 Asean banks to meet at least half of the criteria in a WWF study on sustainable banking. The banks demonstrated leadership in sustainable banking by prohibiting coal financing and implementing no-deforestation commitments, but 91% of peers did not. Only 9% of banks have developed a climate risk strategy, leaving a significant financing gap in sectors such as infrastructure and energy efficiency.

site_title: Pine Capital's ACPAM board, legal counsel replaced at EGM
summary: Pine Capital Group's subsidiary Advance Capital Partners Asset Management (ACPAM) replaced its directors and legal counsel at an extraordinary general meeting on Aug 12. ACPAM's former interim CEO and executive chairman Tan Choon Wee was appointed a director, along with Chan Wai Leung. The changes were made via resolutions passed by ACPAM's two shareholders, Pine Capital and Mr Tan, who owns 49% of the company's issued shares. The new board will oversee the management and duties of ACPAM, subject to Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) approvals.

site_title: How Asians can protect their Crazy Riches
summary: Asia has a historic opportunity to redirect capital flows to improve its economies and financial industries, with an estimated $110 trillion in wealth surpassing North America and Europe. However, the region has a poor record of protecting assets stranded overseas, resulting in significant losses in the 1990s and 2008 crises. To capitalize on dollar asset diversification, Asia must prioritize productivity gains and asset protection strategies, such as diversifying investments and reducing reliance on the US dollar. By doing so, the region can drive growth and create wealth.

site_title: DBS Bank to enter India's credit card market next year
summary: DBS Group Holdings, South-east Asia's largest bank, plans to enter India's credit card market by the second or third quarter of 2020. The move aims to tap into growth outside its home market and offset weakness in the local economy. DBS has set a target of reaching 5 million customers in India by 2023, which it now expects to achieve early. The bank is focusing on increasing domestic branches despite an ongoing economic slowdown in India.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Nets appoints DBS's Shee Tse Koon to its board, replacing Tan Su Shan. Memtech International will be delisted from the SGX on Aug 22 after a consortium led by M-Universe Investments, a special purpose vehicle, offered S$1.35 in cash per share. China Taisan Technology Group's winding up application hearing is scheduled for Sept 6.

site_title: Getting it right in cybersecurity
summary: Cybersecurity threats are escalating, with 10.5 billion malware attacks blocked in 2018, a 217% increase in IoT attacks, and major data breaches in Singapore and Malaysia. The SingHealth data breach in 2018 exposed 1.5 million patients' personal information, while 46 million mobile subscribers' data were stolen in Malaysia in 2017. As organizations move online, protecting data and systems has become a top priority. The alarming numbers highlight the urgent need for adequate cybersecurity measures to prevent further attacks and data breaches.

site_title: Noel Gifts warns of full-year net loss on valuation write-down
summary: Noel Gifts International has warned of an expected full-year net loss due to a valuation write-down of its industrial investment property. The company is scheduled to announce its unaudited financial results on August 27. Shareholders and investors are advised to exercise caution when dealing in the company's shares, which closed unchanged at 19.4 Singapore cents on Tuesday. The write-down is attributed to the company's industrial investment property, resulting in a significant impact on its financial performance.

site_title: BOS hires head of bespoke investments for Greater China and North Asia
summary: Bank of Singapore (BOS) has appointed Kelvin Teo as head of bespoke investments for Greater China and North Asia, catering to ultra high net worth (UHNW) clients in the region. This move comes as the bank seeks to capitalize on the growing demand for exclusive investment opportunities in the region. Teo will leverage his expertise to provide unique and exclusive investment opportunities to UHNW clients.

site_title: 3 in 5 Singapore listed firms post poorer results in latest quarter
summary: Singapore-listed firms reported poorer quarterly results, with 60% of companies underperforming the year-ago quarter, and one in three companies posting losses. Total revenue slipped 2% to S$103.7 billion, and earnings fell 2.2% quarter-over-quarter. Disappointing performances were seen in sectors such as communication services, consumer staples, and materials, while banks, property firms, and telcos fared better. Analysts expect earnings to deteriorate further due to the US-China trade war's impact, with a possible technical recession in Singapore's economy in Q3.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat after three positive sessions
summary: US stocks retreated on Tuesday, closing lower after three consecutive positive sessions, amid concerns over the US-China trade war and low US bond yields. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.2%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite fell 0.5% and 0.4%, respectively. The market's decline came as investors digested reports of potential measures to head off a recession, including payroll tax cuts or tariff reversals.

site_title: Singapore shares put on 0.2%, continue Monday's gain
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% to close at 3,135.95, building on its positive start to the week. Investors are optimistic about accommodative central bank policies, fiscal stimulus, and easing US-China tensions. Markets in Australia, Japan, Malaysia, and South Korea were higher, while China and Hong Kong shares finished lower due to profit-taking.

site_title: Malaysia building sector to see short-term weakness: report
summary: Malaysia's construction sector may experience short-term weakness due to macroeconomic uncertainties, with forecasts predicting a 0.9% contraction in the residential sector and 0.8% contraction in the non-residential sector in 2019. However, completed transport infrastructure projects, such as the West Coast Expressway and Pan Borneo Highway, are expected to boost the sector in the long run, with Fitch Solutions forecasting 1.1% growth in 2019 and 3.5% growth in 2020.

site_title: Activist investor still pushing for Barclays overhaul
summary: Activist investor Edward Bramson is still pushing to overhaul Barclays, despite losing his bid for a seat on the board in May. His investment vehicle Sherborne Investors has advised the Barclays board that pursuing its strategy could boost the bank's financial strength and increase shareholder value. Bramson's stake in Barclays is worth around £1.3 billion, and he intends to continue his dialogue with the bank as long as it appears to be appropriate. The report suggests that Sherborne Investors remains committed to its goal of driving change at the bank.

site_title: The rise of the virtual restaurant
summary: Ricky Lopez, owner of four virtual restaurants, operates without physical storefronts, relying on Uber Eats for delivery. Virtual restaurants and "ghost kitchens" are reshaping the US$863 billion restaurant industry, allowing chefs to create cuisines specifically for delivery apps. Uber Eats and other companies are driving the change, analyzing neighborhood sales data to identify unmet demand. However, this shift may hurt traditional establishments, which pay commissions of 15-30% on every order, and undermine the connection between diner and chef.

site_title: Li Ka Shing's Husky bet has lost over 80% in a decade
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka Shing's oil sands investment, Husky Energy, has lost over 80% of its value since 2008 due to factors such as oil price slumps and production cuts. The majority stake owned by Li has lost C$26.5 billion in value. Analysts are considering whether Husky should go private to capture its underlying value and make strategic moves without market scrutiny. Several energy companies, including SemGroup and Continental Resources, are also being pitched as potential candidates for going private.

site_title: Keppel Logistics unit UrbanFox expands to Vietnam, Malaysia
summary: UrbanFox, a Keppel Logistics unit, is expanding to Vietnam and Malaysia with support from Enterprise Singapore. The company established an online-to-offline (O2O) capabilities at a shopping mall in Ho Chi Minh City, allowing shoppers to purchase products online or in-store. UrbanFox also plans to set up a corporate office and digitally enabled warehouse in Malaysia. The expansion is part of a growing e-commerce market in South-east Asia, predicted to exceed US$240 billion by 2025, with Vietnam's e-commerce market expected to grow to US$15 billion by 2025.

site_title: Banks giving back more money to shareholders: Buffett
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway has increased its stakes in several major banks, including Bank of America, JPMorgan Chase, and Wells Fargo, making it one of the top shareholders in each. Despite economic growth slowing and recession fears, Buffett believes bank stocks could be attractive due to high dividend yields and share repurchases. In the past year, banks have handed back $135 billion to shareholders, with the financial sector's total yield exceeding 7%. Analysts expect lower interest rates to hurt bank profitability, but Buffett sees this as a buying opportunity.

site_title: BOS hires head of bespoke investments for Greater China and North Asia
summary: Bank of Singapore (BOS) has appointed Kelvin Teo as head of bespoke investments for Greater China and North Asia. Teo, who joins from Credit Suisse, will lead a team in providing unique investment opportunities to ultra high net worth (UHNW) clients in the region, including direct investments in regional unicorns and bespoke solutions in buyout funds and property-related financial instruments. The move comes as BOS's UHNW client base has doubled since 2017, with assets under management from this segment growing by 40%.

site_title: Seoul to fine Volkswagen over 'illicit' emissions devices
summary: South Korea will fine Volkswagen and Porsche an estimated 11.5 billion won ($13.19 million) for installing "illicit devices" in over 10,000 diesel vehicles sold in the country from 2015 to 2018, resulting in 10 times more nitrogen oxide emissions. The devices allowed vehicles to cheat pollution standards. The certifications for affected models will be revoked, and Audi, Volkswagen's luxury arm, will also face fines. The move comes weeks after former Audi CEO Rupert Stadler was charged with fraud and illegal advertising in Germany related to Volkswagen's emissions scandal.

site_title: Crew describe climate of fear at Cathay after Hong Kong sackings
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways has been plunged into turmoil amid anti-government protests in Hong Kong, with pilots and crew describing a "white terror" of political denunciations and sackings by Chinese aviation officials. The airline's CEO, Rupert Hogg, was replaced last week, and two pilots were fired for their involvement in the protests. Staff are living in fear of being targeted, with some quitting their jobs and others seeking to avoid Chinese routes. The airline has confirmed that CEO Hogg's departure was due to internal pressure, and new CEO Augustus Tang has warned of "zero tolerance" for policy breaches.

site_title: SBI Offshore served summons for reimbursement of S$114,187
summary: SBI Offshore has received a summons for reimbursement of S$114,187.93, including legal costs, following a dispute with PricewaterhouseCoopers Advisory Services. The dispute dates back to 2016, when PwC reviewed issues surrounding the acquisition and disposal of Jiangyin Neptune Marine Appliance Co. SBI Offshore had previously provisioned US$110,000 for costs incurred by PwC, and the company is now seeking legal advice regarding the summons.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit tenant put under judicial management
summary: NK Ingredients, a tenant of Soilbuild Business Space Reit, has been put under judicial management due to owing almost S$3.4 million to the Reit. The property in question is located at 2, Pioneer Sector 1. A judicial manager, Yit Chee Wah of FTI Consulting (Singapore), was appointed after Soilbuild Reit supported the application, which aims to facilitate asset realisation. The Reit is prepared to defer payment of rent for two months under certain conditions to assist NK Ingredients' cashflow management.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise more than 1% as semiconductors shine
summary: South Korean stocks rose over 1% on Tuesday, driven by gains in semiconductor stocks such as Samsung Electronics. The Kospi index increased 20.35 points to 1,960.25. Analysts attributed the rise to reports of Japan approving shipments of a high-tech material to South Korea and the US granting Huawei more access to American suppliers. The Korean won strengthened, and the benchmark bond yield also rose.

site_title: Oil falls but losses capped by hopes of easing trade tensions
summary: Oil prices fell on Tuesday, with Brent crude down 51 US cents at US$59.23 a barrel and US crude down 73 US cents at US$55.48 a barrel. Despite losses, optimism over easing US-China trade tensions and hopes for stimulus measures to ward off an economic slowdown capped declines. The US extended a reprieve for Huawei, signaling a softening of trade tensions. OPEC cut its forecast for global oil demand growth, indicating a slight surplus in 2020, while equity markets rallied on expectations of economic stimulus.

site_title: Aug 26 hearing date set for sanction of OUE C-Reit, H-Trust merger
summary: A court hearing has been scheduled for August 26 to sanction the merger of OUE Commercial Real Estate Investment Trust (C-Reit) and OUE Hospitality Trust (H-Trust). The proposed scheme, approved by both trust managers, involves OUE C-Reit acquiring H-Trust by paying holders 4.075 cents in cash and 1.3583 new OUE C-Reit units for every H-Trust stapled security held. The expected last day of trading for H-Trust's stapled securities is now September 12, according to the updated indicative timetable.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks end with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day 0.23% lower on Tuesday, following a four-day rally, as profit-taking offset hopes for improved China-US trade talks. The Hang Seng Index fell to 26,231.54, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.11%. The Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.14%. The decline was attributed to profit-taking, despite fresh hopes for trade talks and positive market sentiment in other regions, such as Singapore and the US.

site_title: Furniture brand Commune taps tech tools to improve shopping experience
summary: Furniture brand Commune is launching a mobile augmented reality (AR) app to enhance the shopping experience for customers. The app, set to be released in late August, will allow users to virtually place 3D models of furniture in their homes, making it easier to visualize products. The app is part of Commune's experience technology roadmap, developed in collaboration with the Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA). The new tool will also complement a mobile point-of-sales system, reducing sales staff time by 70%. This is the latest addition to Commune's existing virtual reality and 3D space-planning services.

site_title: China's appetite for Australia's marbled beef is growing
summary: Australia's grain-fed beef exports to China are expected to surge to over 500,000 tons by 2030, a 65% increase from current levels, driven by rising consumption in Asia, particularly in China. Shipments to China alone could rise to almost 200,000 tons. The growth in demand will be driven by China's expanding market, with limited growth in local output, making imports a larger role. While grass-based beef will remain the backbone of the Australian industry, grain feeding will become more important.

site_title: EU's Tusk accuses UK PM Johnson of pushing towards post-Brexit Irish border controls
summary: European Council President Donald Tusk accused UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson of pushing for post-Brexit Irish border controls, stating that Johnson's demands to drop the Brexit backstop lack realistic alternatives. The backstop, an insurance policy to preserve open borders on the island of Ireland, is seen as crucial to avoiding full Irish border controls and maintaining the 1998 Good Friday agreement. The EU and Johnson's predecessor Theresa May have agreed that the backstop is the only means to honor this commitment, and the EU has reiterated its refusal to alter the divorce terms.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher, tracking US rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher for a third consecutive session, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.55% to 20,677.22. The gains were driven by positive trade on Wall Street, where the Dow Jones Industrial Average jumped 1.0% amid speculation of economic stimulus in Germany and China. Chip makers and auto giants were among the gainers, while IT investor SoftBank Group fell 0.86%. The rally was expected to continue despite US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's speech later this week.

site_title: Indonesia will implement IMO low-sulphur fuel rule on schedule -ministry
summary: Indonesia will implement International Maritime Organization (IMO) low-sulphur fuel rules on schedule, starting January 1, 2020, for all Indonesian-flagged vessels. The rule requires fuel with a maximum 0.5% sulphur content, down from 3.5%, unless equipped with scrubbers. The Transportation Ministry's director, Sudiono, confirmed the implementation, reversing earlier statements that suggested more time was needed to meet the requirement.

site_title: China Taisan winding-up application to be heard Sept 6
summary: China Taisan Technology Group Holdings' winding-up application is scheduled for September 6. The firm filed the application on August 14, citing inability to secure investment from potential investors. China Taisan has been under judicial management since August 2018 and its shares have been suspended from trading since June 2018. The company's shares have been on the Singapore Exchange's watch-list since June 5, 2017.

site_title: Singapore universities cancel Hong Kong exchanges after travel warning: report
summary: Singapore universities have cancelled exchange programmes to Hong Kong due to travel warnings issued by Singapore's foreign ministry. The warnings advise citizens to defer non-essential travel to Hong Kong due to unpredictable and potentially violent protests. The National University of Singapore, Nanyang Technological University, and Singapore Management University have cancelled exchanges and trips to Hong Kong amid the ongoing pro-democracy demonstrations.

site_title: HNA Group repays dollar bond after missing yuan note payment
summary: HNA Group repaid a $300 million dollar-denominated bond after missing a yuan note payment, with the Chinese government reportedly offering to help the debt-laden conglomerate meet payments to its offshore creditors. The repayment comes amid concerns about the financial stability of distressed conglomerates. Despite the challenges, HNA remains committed to meeting its financial obligations, according to the company.

site_title: WhatsApp in talks to launch mobile payments in Indonesia: sources
summary: WhatsApp is in talks with multiple Indonesian digital payment firms to offer mobile transaction services, aiming to tap the nation's growing e-commerce sector. The service, expected to be launched soon, will support payments via local digital wallets due to tough licensing regulations. WhatsApp is in advanced talks with firms like Gojek, DANA, OVO, and Bank Mandiri, and is considering a model that could be adopted in other emerging markets to get around foreign player regulations. This move comes as Indonesia's e-commerce industry is set to triple to $100 billion by 2025.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 6.30 points to 1,602.75. Volume was 2.1 billion lots worth RM1.7 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 389 to 380.

site_title: UBS names new CEO for European Union operations
summary: UBS named Christine Novakovic as CEO of its European Union operations, effective September 1. She succeeds Thomas Rodermann and will be based in Frankfurt. Novakovic is one of the most prominent bankers in Germany, where women hold less than 10% of top management jobs in the finance industry.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Tuesday; STI down 0.2% to 3,123.73
summary: Singapore shares declined 0.2% on Tuesday, reaching 3,123.73, despite a global rally on Wall Street. The Straits Times Index (STI) advanced for the third straight session overnight, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index gaining 1.2% and 1.4% respectively. Financials were mixed, with DBS and OCBC gaining 0.2%, while UOB lost 0.4%. Asian equities mostly posted modest gains, with Japan's Topix rising 0.4%.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly rise on optimism for trade, stimulus
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday, driven by hopes for central bank and government stimulus measures and easing tensions in the China-US trade war. Despite global economic concerns, Germany plans government support to avert a recession and central banks are easing monetary policy. The rally comes ahead of GDP data in Singapore and US-EU trade talks. Stocks in the US and Europe also reached fresh records, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging higher despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: English town celebrates hometown hero Ed Sheeran
summary: Ipswich, a town in eastern England, celebrates its hometown hero Ed Sheeran, who began his music career in nearby Framlingham. After playing to almost 9 million people on a two-year international tour, Sheeran caps off his tour with four homecoming shows in Ipswich. This marks a significant milestone for the town, which has traditionally focused on farming and football. Sheeran's rise to fame has brought international recognition to the town, showcasing its connection to the global pop sensation.

images.alt_text: The little-known town of Ipswich in eastern England has historically prided itself on farming and football, but is now celebrating the stellar pop career of its most famous son, Ed Sheeran.

site_title: South Korea may consider easing share buy-back rules
summary: South Korea's Vice-Finance Minister Kim Yong Beom hinted at easing market restrictions on share buybacks to stabilize local financial markets, while tightening short-selling rules. This move aims to counter excessive herd behavior and sharp reactions to temporary fluctuations. The government will also take action to stabilize the foreign exchange market if needed.

site_title: Estee Lauder sees no slowdown in China, forecasts robust fiscal 2020
summary: Estee Lauder Cos Inc forecasted robust fiscal 2020 revenue and profit, surpassing Wall Street expectations. The company attributed the growth to strong demand for luxury skin care products in China, driven by affluent millennials. Despite trade tensions and Hong Kong protests, Estee Lauder's shares rose 11% to a record high, as cosmetic companies in the Asia-Pacific region experience a boom in business. The company's Asia-Pacific sales surged, with L'Oreal also seeing growth in the region.

images.alt_text: Estee Lauder Cos Inc on Monday forecast full-year revenue and profit above Wall Street expectations, putting to bed concerns of slowing demand in China due to trade tensions and Hong Kong protests as sales of its luxury skin care products soared, propelling its shares to a record high.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,139.35, up 0.4% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.4% to 3,139.35 as trading resumed on Tuesday, with 814.5 million shares changing hands. Banking stocks were mixed, while CapitaLand and Hongkong Land rose 2% and 1.9%, respectively. Global indices also posted marginal gains, supported by positive signs on the Sino-US trade war, with US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross easing Huawei sanctions for another 90 days.

site_title: Apartments in Manhattan's financial district are languishing
summary: Manhattan's financial district is experiencing an oversupply of apartments, with many units spending time on the market and selling below asking prices. The area, which saw a surge in construction aimed at foreign buyers and finance workers, now faces dwindling demand. According to Steven Gottlieb, a broker, the neighborhood's popularity has waned, with many buyers who initially wanted to purchase there no longer doing so. This oversupply has led to a decline in apartment sales and prices in the area.

site_title: Australia shares extend gains on global stimulus hopes
summary: Australian shares rose 1.2% to 6,545.00, their second consecutive gain, driven by hopes for global stimulus measures from China and Germany, easing recession worries. China's central bank lowered interest rates, while Germany indicated it could make up to 50 billion euros in extra spending. Most sector-based indices finished in the black, with energy and financials sectors rising, while gold stocks fell. New Zealand's benchmark index also gained 1%.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain for 2nd day on stimulus hopes; BHP falls
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% on the second consecutive day, tracking a Wall Street rally, as hopes for more stimulus measures from China and Germany eased recession concerns. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose, with the Financials sub-index and energy sector gaining, while gold stocks fell. BHP Group fell 1% to a six-month low, despite a record dividend payout. Online retailer Kogan.com jumped 11.5% to its highest since May 30 after reporting a 22% profit jump.

site_title: DBS's Singapore country head Shee Tse Koon joins Nets board
summary: DBS's Singapore country head Shee Tse Koon has joined Nets' board of directors, replacing Tan Su Shan. Shee brings 25 years of banking experience, having held senior positions in Asia, the Middle East, and Europe. He expressed enthusiasm for contributing to Nets' Smart Nation vision. Nets CEO Jeffrey Goh welcomed Shee's experience in SME and international banking, citing his expertise as valuable for strengthening electronic payments in the SME market and international ties.

site_title: PODCAST: Tread Asian e-commerce investment trend carefully (Money Hacks, Ep 52)
summary: Investors should carefully consider the Asian e-commerce trend before investing, as it's an emerging sector with varying risks. Studying old-economy companies such as Singapore Post Limited, which provides logistics services, can provide valuable insights. However, cash flow-negative, unlisted companies in Asia may not be sustainable and could pose significant risks. It's essential to consult with a qualified financial adviser before making any investment decisions in the region.

images.alt_text: Money Hacks podcast host Ernest Luis (left) asks guest expert and equity analyst Nirgunan Tiruchelvam why investors should look at the booming Asian e-commerce trend and how to navigate it with caution.

site_title: Huawei's three closest Chinese rivals form rare partnership
summary: Huawei's top Chinese rivals, Xiaomi, Oppo, and Vivo, have formed a rare alliance to develop smartphone technology, introducing a protocol for wireless file transfers between their phones. This partnership comes as Huawei expands its lead in the Chinese smartphone market, now holding 37% market share. The three companies, once fierce competitors, aim to create a scale effect with their combined user base. This united front is seen as a response to Huawei's growing dominance, with the companies welcoming other Android vendors to their partnership.

site_title: Memtech to delist from SGX on Aug 22
summary: Memtech International will delist from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on August 22 at 9am following the approval of its delisting and the close of its privatization offer. The offer, made by a consortium led by company chairman Chuang Wen Fu, valued the company at S$189 million and offered S$1.35 in cash per share, a 23.9% premium over Memtech's last traded price. The delisting comes after independent financial adviser PwC Corporate Finance deemed the offer "fair and reasonable."

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Keppel Logistics unit UrbanFox is expanding to Vietnam and Malaysia with support from Enterprise Singapore. DBS's Singapore country head Shee Tse Koon has joined Nets' board. Meanwhile, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers, and the UK economy has shrunk for the second month. Asean leaders have agreed that Myanmar's election is not a priority, and US Senator Rubio is set to meet China's Wang on the sidelines of Asean talks.

site_title: Activist Bramson still pushing for Barclays overhaul
summary: Activist investor Edward Bramson's investment vehicle, Sherborne Investors, is still pushing to overhaul Barclays despite failing to secure a seat on the board in May. A half-year report shows that pursuing the strategy could boost the bank's financial strength and long-term competitiveness, increasing shareholder value. Bramson, who owns 5.48% of Barclays, has not made public statements on his plans since the bank's annual investor meeting in May. Despite the bank's robust performance at its investment bank, the unit still makes lower returns than its consumer and credit card businesses.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open slightly lower on Tuesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly lower on Tuesday, following four days of healthy gains, as profit-takers stepped in. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.13% to 26,256.54, while the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.14%. In contrast, the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.19%. The declines were attributed to profit-taking, but the overall market trend remains bullish.

site_title: Sony buying studio behind hit 'Spider-Man' video game
summary: Sony Interactive Entertainment has announced a deal to buy Insomniac Games, the studio behind hit video games "Spider-Man" and "Ratchet & Clank". The acquisition, valued by Sony, will add Insomniac to its stable of studios making games exclusively for the PlayStation consoles. Insomniac was founded 25 years ago and has worked with Sony and Marvel Games on "Spider-Man", which has sold over 13.2 million copies worldwide. The takeover requires regulatory approval and comes as the gaming industry shifts towards subscription services and cloud gaming.

site_title: Robust baht, travel trends rattle Thai tourism market
summary: Thailand's tourism market is being impacted by a strong Thai baht and a slowdown in Chinese arrivals, with visits from China falling almost 5% in the first six months of the year. Despite a record 40 million visitor target by year's end, the country's tourism growth is slowing, with total visits from all countries rising only 1.5% in the first half of the year. The Thai government has proposed a $10 billion economic stimulus package to boost domestic tourism, including visa-free proposals for Chinese and Indian travelers.

site_title: Huawei dismisses new suspension of 'unjust' US ban
summary: Huawei has dismissed a three-month delay to a US ban on selling components and services to the Chinese tech giant, calling the decision "unjust." The US Commerce Department suspended the ban for the second time, adding 46 more companies to its list of Huawei subsidiaries that would be covered by the ban if implemented. The total on the list now exceeds 100. Huawei stated that the delay would not change the fact it had been "treated unjustly."

site_title: Indian Islamic preacher apologises to Malaysians for racial remarks
