summary: Indian Islamic preacher Zakir Naik apologized for making racially sensitive remarks in Malaysia, where he was questioned by police. Naik, who faces hate speech charges in India, made comments that pitted Malaysia's ethnic and religious minorities against the Malay majority, sparking outrage. He apologized for the remarks, saying they were taken out of context, but insisted he was not a racist. Several Malaysian states have barred him from speaking in public, and the government has called for his expulsion. Naik has permanent residency in Malaysia and will continue to preach about Islam.

site_title: Indonesian planters see drought hitting palm oil output
summary: Indonesian palm oil production is expected to be impacted by drought, with major planting regions experiencing delays in fruit ripening and lower output. A mild El Nino has disrupted the dry season, leading to hotspots and increasing the risk of lower fresh fruit bunch production and oil extraction during harvest. Planters expect flat-to-slower growth in third-quarter production, with some predicting an impact only in the first half of 2020. This may result in lower palm oil output this year, with some planters estimating a production of 48-49 million tonnes.

site_title: Baidu Q2 revenue beats expectations but profit drops
summary: Baidu, China's largest search engine, reported a 1.4% increase in revenue to 26.3 billion yuan ($5.3 billion) in Q2, beating expectations. However, net profit dropped 62% due to consolidation costs. Despite this, daily active users grew 27% to 188 million. Baidu's management announced plans to focus on improving content and shift towards AI and driverless cars, while warning of a possible 5% decline in revenue in Q3. The company's shares surged 10% in after-hours trading.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher, tracking US rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, following a positive trend on Wall Street where stocks rose for a third straight session. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.21% to 20,605.35 and the Topix index climbed 0.27% to 1,498.40. This positive lead from the US market suggests that investors are optimistic about the global economic outlook.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, taking a positive lead from Wall Street where stocks rose for a third straight session.

site_title: US dollar near 3-week high as thaw in risk aversion lifts yields
summary: The US dollar rose to a three-week high as investors shifted back to riskier assets, driven by hopes for stimulus in major economies such as Germany and China. Yields on US Treasuries lifted from three-year lows, as investors anticipated global stimulus and easing of recession fears. The shift in investor sentiment was also influenced by China's new lending benchmark, set to be released on Tuesday, and ongoing trade tensions between the US and other countries.

site_title: French retailer Casino targets further 2b euros of asset sales
summary: French supermarket retailer Casino plans to sell an additional 2 billion euros of assets to cut debt and improve financial performance. This is part of a plan to dispose of 2.5 billion euros worth of assets by the first quarter of 2020. Casino has already signed agreements for sales worth 2.1 billion euros, mainly of non-core supermarkets and property assets to private equity investors. The company's net debts stood at 4.7 billion euros at the end of June. The asset sales are expected to be completed by the end of Q1, 2021.

images.alt_text: French supermarket retailer Casino is targeting a further 2 billion euros (S$3.05 billion) of asset sales, stepping up plans to cut debt and improve financial performance.

site_title: Alita Resources sold lithium concentrate below floor price amid challenging conditions
summary: ALITA Resources shipped 10,500 dry metric tonnes of lithium concentrate to Jiangxi Bao Jiang Lithium Industrial Limited at a price below the floor of US$680 per tonne, amid challenging market conditions. The price was around 14% deferred for six months. The company is continuing to monetize its product stockpile and is in discussions with Jiangxi Bao Jiang regarding the restructuring of the offtake agreement. This comes after Alita restructured offtake agreements with Burwill Lithium in January, which included market-linked pricing and the right to sell to other customers.

site_title: Release of Iranian tanker 'very unfortunate': Pompeo
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo expressed frustration over the release of an Iranian tanker held off Gibraltar, calling it "very unfortunate." The British territory rejected a US demand to seize the vessel, which has since entered international waters. The tanker, renamed Adrian Darya, was seized on July 4 on suspicion of transporting oil to Syria in breach of EU sanctions. Iran denied any violations, and a court ordered its release last Thursday, prompting the US to file a request to detain the ship, which was rejected by Gibraltar's government.

site_title: Chairman, MD offer S$0.118 a share to delist PS Group
summary: Chairman and MD of PS Group, Teo Choon Hock and Kwek Keng Seng, have made a voluntary offer of S$0.118 per share to take the company private. The offer values the company at about S$8 million, nearly three times its last transacted price. The offer is conditional on receiving at least 90% of the total shares, excluding those held by the duo and related corporations. A trading halt was called on Tuesday morning before the start of trading, and an offer document will be sent to shareholders in the next two to three weeks.

site_title: China sets new lending reference rate slightly lower on first day
summary: China set its new lending reference rate, the Loan Prime Rate, at 4.25% on Tuesday, a 6 basis point decrease from 4.31% previously. The rate, which will guide banks in setting rates for new loans, is 10 basis points lower than the People's Bank of China's existing one-year lending rate. The move is part of interest rate reforms aimed at lowering corporate borrowing costs. The new rate is effective immediately, marking the first publication of the benchmark since the central bank announced reforms.

site_title: To power AI, startup creates a giant computer chip
summary: A Silicon Valley startup, Cerebras, unveiled the largest computer chip ever built, measuring about 15 inches in diameter and 4 inches thick, challenging conventional wisdom on chip size. The chip, which weighs around 25 pounds, is designed to power artificial intelligence applications such as self-driving cars and digital assistants. Cerebras engineers believe the chip can accelerate AI progress and be used in giant data centers, paving the way for significant advancements in AI technology.

site_title: White House mulling tax cut to avoid recession: report
summary: The White House is considering a tax cut or reversing tariffs to prevent a recession, according to reports. Senior officials are exploring options, including temporarily cutting payroll taxes to boost workers' pay. However, the discussion is still in its early stages and officials have not discussed the idea with President Trump. This comes despite Trump's denial of a looming recession, citing strong economic data and predictions from most economists. A survey found 38% of economists expect a recession in 2020 and 34% in 2021.

images.alt_text: The White House is considering cutting taxes or revering tariffs to head off a recession, US media reported on Monday, despite President Donald Trump's insistence on the economy's health.

site_title: Hong Kong leader says she hopes non-violent protest puts city on road to peace
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam expressed hope that a peaceful weekend protest marked the beginning of efforts to restore peace in the city, amid 11 weeks of often violent demonstrations over a now-suspended extradition bill. Lam said the government would engage with peaceful protesters and address police complaints. Despite chaos spreading overseas, including social media campaigns, Lam emphasized the importance of Hong Kong's rule of law, citing its unique advantages in attracting foreign companies. Further protests are planned, with demonstrators demanding the withdrawal of the extradition bill and an independent inquiry.

site_title: Visa critical of India's move towards no-fee debit card transactions
summary: Visa criticizes India's plan to require banks and card networks to offer no-fee debit card transactions, citing the need for compensation for the cost savings. The move aims to boost electronic payments, but industry officials question who will bear the costs. Visa's India and South Asia head, T.R. Ramachandran, said the plan's logic is flawed, as the cost is not truly free. The plan could impact banks' fee revenues, which are already burdened with bad loans.

site_title: Stocks to watch: HMI, Figtree Holdings, Hong Leong Asia, RE&S Holdings, PS Group
summary: Health Management International (HMI) reported a 11% decline in net profit to 13.5 million yuan for the fourth quarter, despite a 10% rise in revenue. Figtree Holdings secured a S$43.53 million design and build contract for a food processing facility. Hong Leong Asia's takeover offer for its Malaysian subsidiary Tasek closed with an 88.16% stake. RE&S Holdings saw a 32.9% decline in net profit to S$628,000 for the fourth quarter. PS Group requested a trading halt pending an announcement.

site_title: Foreign trash 'like treasure' in Indonesia's plastics village
summary: In Indonesia's plastic waste village of Bangun, residents sift through discarded plastic bottles, wrappers, and cups to earn a living, with up to 40 dump trucks a day unloading garbage. The town's economy has boomed since China's ban on importing foreign waste, with residents earning up to $3 a day. However, environmentalists warn that the practice poses a significant environmental and public health risk, with non-recyclable plastic being burned and micro-plastics entering local waterways. The Indonesian government has pledged to reduce plastic waste in its waters by 70% by 2025, but the situation in Bangun remains unchanged.

images.alt_text: His weathered face breaks out in a big grin as Keman explains how sifting through rubbish paid for his children's education, one of many in his Indonesian hometown basking in a waste-picking boom.

site_title: Fintech Wave-2 isn't digital. It's hybrid
summary: Singapore and India are leading fintech innovation in Asia, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore taking bold moves during the 2018 Singapore Fintech Festival. Fintech combines financial services and technology, bringing disruption and synergies. The article corrects the misconception that Fintech Wave-2 is digital, stating it's actually a hybrid, representing a fusion of traditional and digital elements.

site_title: Ryanair legal bid makes UK strike more certain, union says
summary: Ryanair's bid to block a UK pilots' strike has made the walkout more certain, according to the British Airline Pilots' Association. The union claims Ryanair lost the chance to resolve the pay dispute by seeking a High Court injunction, instead opting to pursue a legal technicality. The 48-hour strike, set to begin on the busiest weekend for air travel, is now more likely to occur, with Balpa General Secretary Brian Strutton describing Ryanair's actions as "bullying tactics."

site_title: Li Ka-Shing's firm makes £2.7b bet pubs will survive Brexit
summary: Hong Kong's CK Asset Holdings Ltd has agreed to pay £2.7 billion for UK pub operator Greene King plc, a move seen as a bet that Brexit won't harm the UK's pub industry. The deal, worth US$3.3 billion, values Greene King at 850p per share, a 51% premium. The conglomerate believes pubs will remain an important part of British culture, despite Brexit uncertainty, and is expanding its UK pub presence to signal confidence in the economy. The acquisition is seen as a significant investment in the UK's pubs sector.

site_title: Ardmore Medical puts IPO plans on hold
summary: Ardmore Medical Group has put its initial public offering (IPO) plans on hold due to ongoing business developments and current market conditions. The decision was made after discussions with advisers and careful deliberation. The company did not specify the reasons for the hold. This move comes as the company specializes in orthopaedic surgery, aesthetics, and pain management.

site_title: Public Service gets ready for longer careers for workforce
summary: The Singapore public service is launching new programmes to prepare its workforce for longer careers, starting next month. The initiatives include job redesign, re-skilling, and digital literacy training to help officers stay employable. The move follows Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's announcement to raise retirement and re-employment ages to 63 and 68, respectively, starting July 1, 2021. Over 2,000 public officers will benefit from the new programmes, which aim to support officers in managing career transitions, retirement, and financial planning.

site_title: China plans to make Shenzhen a 'better place' than Hong Kong
summary: China has unveiled plans to boost the mainland city of Shenzhen, aiming to make it a "better place" than neighboring Hong Kong. The central government's guidelines, released Monday, outline goals to transform Shenzhen into a pilot area of "socialism with Chinese characteristics" by 2025, with the goal of leading the world in overall economic competitiveness by 2035. The plans also aim to build greater integration with Hong Kong and Macau, potentially undermining Hong Kong's development and leading to its economic decline.

site_title: US: Stocks rally on hopes for stimulus, dovish Federal Reserve
summary: US stocks rose for a third consecutive session on Monday, driven by hopes for economic stimulus and dovish Federal Reserve interest rate cuts. The 10-year US Treasury yield rose above that of 2-year notes, a sign of improving economic conditions. Analysts cited the Trump administration's delay in a Huawei ban as a conciliatory step in the US-China trade fight, contributing to the global rally. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Medtech hub opens with support from healthcare clusters
summary: A new medtech hub, Catalyst, has opened in Singapore, connecting healthcare startups, clinicians, and corporates to speed up the development of healthcare products. Supported by healthcare clusters SingHealth and the National Healthcare Group, the hub aims to improve the development of products and services that prevent or cure diseases. The 3,200 sq ft co-working space is near other healthcare and educational institutions and has already established over 10 startups, including ConnectedLife and eko.ai. The hub offers advisory services, mentorship, and access to clinicians for startups, and membership prices start at S$50 a month.

site_title: New planet discovered in orbit of young Milky Way star
summary: A second planet, b Pictoris c, has been discovered circling Beta Pictoris, a 23 million-year-old star in the Milky Way. The giant planet, 3,000 times more massive than Earth, completes its orbit every 1,200 days. This discovery provides a rare glimpse into a planetary system in formation, offering insights into the early stages of star and planet evolution. Located 63 light years from Earth, Beta Pictoris is a relatively young star, and its planetary system is still taking shape, with the two planets still in the process of formation.

site_title: Johnson tells EU he wants Brexit deal but without backstop
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has written to EU President Donald Tusk reaffirming his desire for a Brexit deal without the backstop, a mechanism to prevent a hard border in Northern Ireland. Johnson's government wants to achieve a divorce deal with Brussels, but the EU insists the backstop is necessary to preserve European trade. Johnson opposes the backstop, citing concerns it would undermine UK sovereignty and independence. He will seek support for his vision in European capitals ahead of the G-7 summit.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson wrote Monday to EU President Donald Tusk reaffirming his desire to conclude a Brexit deal as well as his opposition to the controversial "backstop" on Ireland.

site_title: Oil rises 2% after attack on Saudi field, stimulus expectations
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Monday after a drone attack on a Saudi oil facility by Yemen's Houthi forces and signs of a softening US-China trade war. Brent crude settled at $59.74 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose to $56.21 a barrel. The attack on Saudi Arabia's oil facility added to Middle East tensions, but oil production was not affected. Analysts also pointed to growing expectations of global economic stimulus and reduced corporate borrowing costs in China as supporting factors.

site_title: HDB flats on prime Keppel Club site: Premium prices or tweaked sales terms?
summary: The upcoming expiration of the lease on the Keppel Club site has sparked debate over the future of public housing on the site. A consultant estimates that a 5-room unit could be sold for close to S$1 million, raising concerns about the "lottery effect" and potential windfalls for lucky owners. This has led to suggestions for alternative sales terms, a proposal previously suggested by Lawrence Wong. The issue is expected to be addressed in the coming years as the lease expires in two years.

site_title: Shell rolls out electric vehicle charging points at Singapore fuel stations
summary: Shell has rolled out electric vehicle charging points at its Singapore fuel stations, with 10 stations expected to be equipped with a DC fast-charger called Shell Recharge by October. This marks the first time a fuel retailer in Singapore has offered EV charging points, following similar initiatives in Britain, the Netherlands, and China. The move aims to support the growing demand for electric vehicles in the country.

site_title: Mugabe VP flees Zimbabwe anti-corruption probe
summary: Zimbabwe's former Vice-President Phelekezela Mphoko, 79, fled anti-corruption questioning after being summoned over alleged criminal abuse of office. He drove away from the police post in Bulawayo, leaving officials to claim he is now a fugitive from justice. Mphoko had previously been summoned last week but was blocked from being arrested by his family. This is the second high-ranking member of the ruling Zanu-PF party to be probed by the Zimbabwe Anti-Corruption Commission.

site_title: Google, Facebook, Amazon decry French digital tax as 'discriminatory'
summary: US tech giants Amazon, Facebook, and Google have joined forces to condemn France's new digital tax as "discriminatory" and "retroactive." The tax, which adds a 3% levy on companies' revenues, applies to the largest tech companies, mainly US-based, and has sparked concerns about double taxation. The companies claim the tax creates an unfair precedent and may lead to punitive tariffs on French wine imports, prompting a US trade investigation. The companies support an international agreement on taxation of digital commerce through the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD).

site_title: BHP annual profit rises on robust iron ore prices, pays record dividend
summary: BHP Group, the world's largest miner, reported a 2% rise in full-year profit to US$9.12 billion, driven by higher iron ore prices. Iron ore shipments to China increased by 11% in June, and imports surged 21% in July to their highest level since January. The company declared a record final dividend of 78 cents per share, up from 63 cents last year. The profit increase was fueled by a windfall from higher iron ore prices, with underlying profit more than doubling to US$8.31 billion.

site_title: Learning from the Great Depression
summary: A recent bout of financial turmoil echoes parallels with the Great Depression of the 1930s, highlighting the importance of economic leadership. Charles Kindleberger's thesis, which posits that a vacuum of leadership led to the Great Depression, is echoed by economists J Bradford DeLong and Barry Eichengreen, who note the absence of a dominant economic power to stabilize the global economy. The current trade war between the US and China, Brexit, and the Federal Reserve's assault by President Trump are seen as contributing factors to the instability. Experts warn that high debt levels and the absence of effective leadership could lead to a hard economic landing if not addressed.

site_title: Baidu stock pops in late trading after sales top estimates
summary: Baidu Inc's quarterly revenue beat analysts' estimates, rising 1.4% to 26.33 billion yuan, despite a challenge from rivals like ByteDance Inc. The company's shares rose 10% in extended trading. Baidu's CEO, Robin Li, attributed the results to "groundbreaking changes" aimed at revitalizing the company. The search giant's net income dropped to 2.41 billion yuan, but analysts praised its strong content ecosystem and 174 million daily active users. Baidu's better-than-expected results may soothe investors' concerns about the company's slowing growth.

images.alt_text: Baidu Inc's quarterly revenue beat analysts' estimates after China's biggest search giant managed to hold onto advertising despite a challenge from aggressive rivals like ByteDance Inc.

site_title: US states ready antitrust probe of tech titans: report
summary: US states are preparing a joint investigation into whether major tech firms, including Google, Facebook, and Amazon, have violated antitrust law. The probe, led by top prosecutors, aims to determine if these companies have used their market power to reduce competition and harm consumers. The US Department of Justice has also announced a review of online platforms' market power and practices. The investigation follows recent regulatory actions, including a $5 billion fine on Facebook for data protection lapses. Tech firms deny monopolistic conduct and argue the digital economy has robust competition and benefits consumers.

site_title: Love, Bonito and Ninja Van founders share success tips
summary: Bilingual news platform sgsme hosted a networking event where Love, Bonito and Ninja Van founders shared success tips. Lai Chang Wen of Ninja Van and Rachel Lim of Love, Bonito discussed how to stay ahead in the digital economy. They emphasized the importance of making purposeful business decisions, having the right people in the right team, and not expanding for the sake of growth. They also highlighted the need for SMEs to be part of vibrant trading communities and create conducive workplaces. The event aimed to cultivate interaction and build bonds among SME members.

site_title: Re-employment helps workers ease into retirement, not meant to build up nest egg
summary: A Singaporean re-employment age cap is set to increase to 70 by 2030, but only after July 1, 2022, when the cap is lifted to 68. This change aims to help workers transition into retirement, not build a nest egg. The proposal, accepted by the government, is part of the Strengthening Support for Older Workers report. The move is intended to provide re-employment opportunities for older workers, easing the transition into retirement.

site_title: Japan again approved shipment of photoresists to South Korea
summary: Japan has approved the shipment of photoresists to South Korea for the second time since imposing export curbs in July. The high-tech material is crucial for Samsung Electronics' advanced contract chipmaking production. The approval comes ahead of a meeting between Japanese and South Korean foreign ministers in Beijing, amid deteriorating relations between the two East Asian countries. The dispute is rooted in their wartime past and Japan's refusal to compensate for forced laborers during its occupation. The move is seen as a gesture of goodwill, but tensions between the two US allies remain high.

site_title: The US must recommit to trade
summary: The US must recommit to trade to address growing concerns about unfair trade practices and the impact of trade policies on Americans. Despite the president's efforts to defend the US's record on trade, the country is losing confidence in its ability to compete and win in the global economy. The administration's tariff policy has been ineffective, costing US consumers and businesses billions of dollars. To regain momentum, the US must recognize its strengths in creating a rules-based trading system, protect intellectual property, and prepare American workers for a rapidly changing economy.

site_title: FTC chairman says Facebook's plan to merge Instagram, WhatsApp may make it harder to split
summary: FTC Chairman Joseph Simons stated that Facebook's plan to merge Instagram and WhatsApp may complicate any attempt to break up the social media giant. Simons said that integrating the brands could make it harder to split, as separate business structures and infrastructure would be compromised. This comes as Facebook faces scrutiny over data privacy practices and potential antitrust violations. The FTC is investigating Facebook, and the company has already agreed to pay a $5 billion fine to resolve a government probe into its privacy practices.

site_title: New Fortis CEO plans fixes after Singh brothers' alleged fraud
summary: Fortis Healthcare, India's second-largest hospital chain, plans to cut costs by 20% to resuscitate after being defrauded of $77.1 million by its former owners. New CEO Ashutosh Raghuvanshi aims to reduce expenses by $31 million over two years through measures such as renegotiating doctor salaries and automating business analysis. The company will also invest $84 million in fresh capital expenditure and divest underperforming facilities. Raghuvanshi plans to implement lean cost-saving techniques, including task-shifting, to restore the company's premium healthcare positioning.

site_title: Europe: Stimulus hopes drive up shares for second session
summary: European shares rose for a second session on Monday, driven by hopes of stimulus measures to boost growth in major economies. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index ended 1.2% higher, with Frankfurt shares up 1.3%. Germany's coalition government may ditch its balanced budget rule to take on new debt and launch stimulus, and China's central bank unveiled interest rate reforms to lower corporate borrowing costs. Investors will watch for minutes from US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank policy meetings, as well as global PMI numbers, to assess the world economy's health.

site_title: London homes' asking prices post first annual increase in 2 years
summary: London's asking home prices have seen their first annual increase in 2 years, rising 1.3% from a year earlier, according to Rightmove. This comes as Brexit uncertainty has led to a shortage of supply, with new sellers down 11% and sales agreements jumping. August also saw the largest number of sales nationwide in four years. The increase is attributed to buyers and sellers taking the plunge after years of waiting for Brexit to be resolved, and potential changes to stamp duty reforms are also expected to impact the market.

site_title: Manila checks for swine fever as pig deaths rise
summary: The Philippines has set up a crisis management team to investigate the rise in pig deaths, potentially linked to African swine fever, following reports of increased mortality in backyard pigs. The country has banned pork and pork-based products from over a dozen markets, including China, Vietnam, and Laos, to protect its US$5 billion hog industry. Further laboratory tests are needed to confirm the outbreak, with results expected in two weeks. If confirmed, the crisis team will implement measures to manage and control the suspected disease.

site_title: Greater Southern Waterfront a boost to likes of KepCorp, MCT
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced plans to develop the 2,000-hectare Greater Southern Waterfront (GSW) along the country's southern coastline, set to be completed over 5-10 years. Analysts predict that Keppel Corp, MAPLETREE Commercial Trust (MCT), and Frasers Commercial Trust will benefit from the development, with potential beneficiaries also including Genting Singapore. The project is expected to bring up to 9,000 new residential homes, boosting tourism and economic growth in the area.

site_title: Yangzijiang continues run as actively traded stock for third straight session
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's stock rebounded for a second consecutive session, advancing 7% on Monday before settling at S$1.01, with 107.9 million shares traded. The stock had plummeted 17.3% last Thursday after a report linked the company's executive chairman to a probe for "serious disciplinary violations." Despite this, analysts say the stock is now trading at attractive valuations, with Citi Research praising its fundamentals and order-win momentum expected to pick up in the coming months.

site_title: Up to 2 points total CPF hike for older workers in Jan 2021
summary: The Singapore government has announced a plan to increase Central Provident Fund (CPF) contributions for older workers starting January 1, 2021. The hike will range from 0.5 to 1 percentage point, depending on age bands, with subsequent increases capped at 1 percentage point. The aim is to raise the total CPF contribution rate for workers aged 55-60 to 37% by 2030, while extending the retirement age from 62 to 65 and the re-employment age from 67 to 70 in gradual steps.

site_title: China to boost Shenzhen's role in Greater Bay Area innovation
summary: China plans to grant Shenzhen City favorable policies to play a key role in science and technology innovation in the Greater Bay Area. Shenzhen will receive privileges in yuan internationalisation, according to guidelines issued by the Chinese Communist Party central committee and the State Council. This move aims to boost Shenzhen's innovation capabilities and position it as a key player in the region's growth.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Rosengren says cutting rates could worsen next downturn
summary: Boston Federal Reserve Bank President Eric Rosengren signaled no willingness to support further interest rate cuts, citing good US economic conditions and a risk of encouraging a worrying debt build-up. Rosengren stated that easing policy could worsen the next downturn and leave the Federal Reserve with limited ammunition. He emphasized the need for evidence that the US is entering a slowdown before considering further easing of policy.

site_title: A 'no-deal' Brexit is not a shoo-in
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson says he won't reopen Brexit negotiations unless the EU scraps the Irish backstop, but the EU remains committed to the backstop. As the UK's October 31 deadline approaches, parliament may take action to prevent a no-deal Brexit, including amending legislation to seek an Article 50 extension or passing a motion of no confidence against Johnson. The outcome is uncertain, with some speculating that Johnson could try to avoid an election by delaying it until after Brexit. The EU and EU governments are united in their support for the backstop, making a no-deal Brexit increasingly likely.

site_title: SRS account start date determines when penalty waiver kicks in
summary: Singapore's voluntary Supplementary Retirement Scheme (SRS) allows account holders to withdraw funds penalty-free at the prevailing statutory retirement age at the time of their first contribution. With the retirement age set to rise to 63 in 2022 and 65 by 2030, account holders who made their first deposit before July 1, 2022, can withdraw their savings without penalty at age 62, while those who did so after can take out their funds at 63 and beyond. The policy aims to support lower- and middle-income groups.

site_title: Disney whistleblower says revenue was inflated
summary: A former Walt Disney accountant, Sandra Kuba, has accused the company of inflating revenue by billions of dollars over years. Kuba, who worked for 18 years, claims employees in the parks division systematically overstated revenue by recording sales for gift cards twice and counting revenue for cards given to guests after complaints. The alleged overstatement may have occurred as far back as 2008-09, potentially affecting $6 billion in revenue. Disney denied the claims, but the accusations have rattled investors, causing the company's shares to drop.

images.alt_text: A former Walt Disney accountant has accused the company of overstating revenue for years and has filed a series of whistleblower tips with the US Securities and Exchange Commission.

site_title: China accused of using Twitter, Facebook against Hong Kong protests
summary: Twitter and Facebook have uncovered a campaign by China to use their platforms against pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong. The campaigns involved coordinated inauthentic behavior, including the removal of pages, groups, and accounts originating in China. The platforms are working together to mitigate the influence of the campaign and prevent further interference. This move comes as tensions between China and Hong Kong continue to rise.

site_title: Westpac overdue mortgages on the rise amid soft housing market
summary: Westpac Banking Corp reported a rise in overdue mortgages in Australia, with 90-plus-day delinquencies increasing 8 basis points to 0.9% over the third quarter. This comes amid a sluggish economy and soft housing market, highlighting concerns about the financial stability of borrowers.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Two Singapore-listed companies received updated broker ratings. Grand Venture Technology (GVT) was downgraded to a "Hold" by GS-CIMB due to its weak first half performance, with revenue from its semiconductor segment falling 44% year-on-year. OCBC Bank maintained its "Hold" rating by BS Equity Research, citing concerns over its non-performing assets and execution of market opportunities, despite its strong franchise value in Greater China.

site_title: Singapore dividend payout slides 11.6% to US$3.8b in Q2
summary: Singapore's dividend payout decreased 11.6% to US$3.8 billion in Q2, driven mainly by special dividends. Despite this, underlying dividend growth increased 17.7% due to a strong performance by Asian markets, including Indonesia, which saw a 10% increase in dividend payouts. The Janus Henderson Global Dividend Index reported a 1.1% global increase in total dividends, but the slowest rate of increase in over two years. The asset manager reaffirmed its 2019 forecast of US$1.43 trillion in dividends, equivalent to 4.2% growth on a headline basis.

site_title: Beginning of the end for globalisation?
summary: Globalisation is facing significant stress due to rising political risk, with the US-China spat and looming Brexit potentially leading to a full-blown trade war and disorderly no-deal Brexit. Other countries, such as Italy, are also experiencing political instability. However, there are countervailing developments, including recent multilateral trade agreements and the continued resilience of post-war international institutions like the UN. The future of globalisation will be determined by the US-China relationship, which could lead to greater instability or a collaborative strategic partnership.

site_title: Southeast Asia pulls back on online gambling as China rages
summary: Southeast Asian countries, including the Philippines and Cambodia, are pulling back on online gambling amid pressure from China. The Philippines will stop accepting new online gaming operations until the end of the year, while Cambodia will not renew existing licenses. China's efforts to curb online gambling have led to the halt, with the industry's growth projected to reach up to $264 million in revenue. The move is expected to hurt the economies of these countries, which have heavily invested in the industry.

site_title: Good Boys ends comedy drought in Hollywood
summary: Comedy film "Good Boys" breaks the drought in Hollywood, grossing an estimated $21 million at US and Canadian theaters. The movie, about three 12-year-old friends navigating R-rated misadventures, surpassed expectations and proved comedies can still attract audiences. This success comes after a period of declining box office performance for comedies, providing relief for studios. The film's success may signal a renewed interest in comedy films in the industry.

site_title: French startup IT school tears up the rule book
summary: A French startup, Ecole 42, is revolutionizing the IT education system by offering a coding college that focuses on project work and peer learning, open to even school dropouts. The month-long trial, called the "piscine," tests students' endurance and problem-solving skills. This unconventional approach aims to provide hands-on experience and foster a community-driven learning environment, unlike traditional schools. By tearing up the rule book, Ecole 42 seeks to provide accessible and effective coding education, paving the way for a new generation of tech professionals.

site_title: Business update lifts Rex International shares by 14.7%
summary: Rex International Holding's shares rose 14.7% to 7.8 Singapore cents after the company questioned its market valuation and announced plans to further monetize its assets. The firm, which owns interests in Norway and Oman, has a war chest of $70.8 million and has initiated a share buyback. Rex's subsidiary Lime Petroleum AS acquired a 30% interest in two Norwegian Sea licences, and the company expects to start oil production at its Oman asset by the end of 2019, generating revenue.

site_title: Tasek takeover offer closes with Hong Leong Asia holding 88.16% stake
summary: Hong Leong Asia's takeover offer for Tasek closed at 88.16% stake, surpassing the initial 80.8% stake held by the company. The offer price rose from RM5.50 to RM5.80 per share, with the offer closing at 5pm on August 19, 2019.

site_title: New guide offers Singapore maritime firms a framework for sustainability reporting
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has launched a sector-specific guide for maritime companies to create sustainability reports. The guide, developed in partnership with the Singapore Exchange, Global Compact Network Singapore, and Ernst & Young LLP, among others, provides best practices and a framework for reporting on environmental, social, and governance factors. The guide features MPA's own sustainability reporting journey as a case study and aims to champion sustainability reporting in the maritime industry, aligning with MPA's efforts to build a more sustainable future for Singapore and the region.

site_title: Scottish castle in perfect condition on sale for £8m
summary: Seton Castle, a 19th-century Scottish mansion designed by Robert Adam, is on sale for £8m. Originally the site of Seton Palace, the property has a rich history, hosting Mary Queen of Scots, who reportedly played golf there. After falling into disrepair, the castle was rebuilt in the late 18th century and has been well-maintained. The property is now being sold after nearly 800 years of aristocratic occupancy.

site_title: Commitment, capability and collaboration for the long haul
summary: Singapore Management University's Professor Annie Koh discussed key findings from a study on innovation in Singapore-based family-owned enterprises. The six-month survey of 86 family firms found that 78% were small- to medium-sized enterprises and 62% had not collaborated with government institutions. Collaboration, capability, and commitment were identified as essential for building a sustainable family-owned enterprise. The study's findings will be published by the end of 2020, and a new research partnership has been established with Bangkok University to explore innovation in Thailand-based family-owned enterprises.

site_title: Financial education should start as early as possible in ageing workforce
summary: A survey by OCBC Bank found that 69% of Singaporeans set a budget and stick to it, but 1/3 do not invest, 1/2 have no passive income, and 37% are unsure on how to grow their money. This lack of financial planning is a concern for retirement adequacy, with 3/4 not on track with their plans. Experts attribute this to behavioral finance and the prioritization of other financial commitments. To address this issue, financial awareness and training should be instilled in schools and workplaces, similar to initiatives in other countries like New Zealand.

site_title: More realistic visuals on Minecraft from Microsoft, Nvidia team-up
summary: Microsoft and Nvidia team up to provide Minecraft players with more realistic graphics on personal computers using Nvidia's real-time ray tracing technology. This technology simulates how light rays bounce around in visual scenes, enhancing shadows and reflections. Nvidia's real-time ray tracing is now available in games such as "Call of Duty: Modern Warfare" and "Watch Dogs: Legion". Microsoft's Minecraft, which has sold 176 million versions since its 2011 release, will also utilize this technology, further enhancing the game's graphics.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on stimulus hopes
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Monday, driven by hopes that China's interest rate reform will counter the impact of escalating global trade tensions. The Dow Jones rose 134.05 points, or 0.52%, to 26,020.06, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with gains of 24.80 points and 110.19 points, respectively. The positive start comes as investors await the outcome of US-EU trade talks.

site_title: HMI posts 11% fall in Q4 net profit to RM13.5m
summary: Health Management International (HMI) reported a 11% fall in Q4 net profit to RM13.5 million, despite a 10% increase in revenue to RM131.1 million. The decline was attributed to a decrease in gross profit margin due to the start-up costs of a new ambulatory care centre in Singapore. Full-year net profit was down 19% at RM48.8 million. A proposed privatisation deal with PanAsia Health is also underway, with a shareholder meeting scheduled for August 22.

site_title: Singapore shares add 0.4% on China policy support, trade talks hopes
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% to 3,128.45, driven by gains from Wall Street, China's rate reform, and US-China trade talks. The Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong posted its best session in two months, advancing 2.2%. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB ended higher, while upstream oil services player Rex International jumped 14.7% after announcing a war chest of $70.8 million.

site_title: Once sleepless in Singapore, now giving sweet dreams to the budget conscious
summary: RedDoorz, a budget hotel service in South-East Asia, has raised US$70 million in funding, bringing its total to US$140 million since its launch four years ago. Founder and CEO Amit Saberwal attributes the company's success to a prudent business plan, avoiding heavy spending. RedDoorz now operates in 80 cities across Indonesia, Singapore, the Philippines, and Vietnam, with plans to expand to Malaysia and Thailand. The company aims to grab 2,000 budget hotels by the end of the year and eventually reach a valuation of US$1 billion through a possible IPO.

images.alt_text: "The whole journey has shown us that the opportunity is humongous," Mr Saberwal says. "It's a virgin field."
RedDoorz's first-ever, fully-leased and operated budget hotel in Singapore on East Coast Road, seen in a March 2018 photo.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Figtree Holdings secured a S$43.53 million contract with OJJ Foods to design and build a six-storey food processing facility in Singapore. RE&S Holdings reported a 32.9% decline in net profit to S$628,000 for the fourth quarter. Health Management Intl's net profit fell 11% to RM13.5 million for the same period, despite revenue rising 10%. Hong Leong Asia's takeover offer for Tasek closed at 88.16% stake, with its preference shareholding interest increasing to 64.91%.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. CGS-CIMB Securities downgraded Grab to 'hold' due to slowing earnings growth in H2. OCBC CEO Helen Wong is retiring, with Tan Teck Long taking over as successor. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay increased 30.5% to S$3.1 million. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Citigroup set a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index. Analysts are positive on SGX earnings, raising target prices, citing a 'defensive play benefiting from volatility'.

site_title: STI rides tailwinds of PBOC rate reform
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.4% to 3,128.45, tracking gains from the Chinese central bank's rate reform and positive US-China trade talks. Analysts see the PBOC's move as a boost to regional sentiment and global commodity prices. In Singapore, trading volume was 15% higher than the daily average, with blue-chip counters like DBS Group Holdings, OCBC Bank, and Keppel DC Reit ending higher. Penny stocks like Rex International and GSS Energy also gained, driven by rising oil prices.

site_title: Facelift of Cairo's historic Baron Palace sparks outcry
summary: Egyptian authorities have defended the renovation of the historic Baron Palace in Cairo after social media backlash over white marble additions to the building's exterior. The restoration, which began in 2017, aims to restore the palace's original style, but critics claim the materials used are of poor quality and not in keeping with the original design. The Antiquities Minister, Khaled El-Enany, dismissed online criticisms as "fake news" and said the colors were correct and backed by historical sources. The project is expected to be completed by the end of 2019 with plans to open the building to the public in 2020.

site_title: China to base new lending benchmark on medium-term rates; shares rally on rate cut hopes
summary: China's central bank unveiled long-awaited reforms to lower borrowing costs and support businesses hurt by weak domestic demand and the trade war with the US. The new lending benchmark, the loan prime rate (LPR), will be linked to the PBOC's medium-term lending facility interest rate, aiming to establish a smooth policy transmission mechanism. Analysts expect the LPR to be lower than the current 4.31% rate, but some caution that the reform may not directly translate to lower bank lending rates. The move is seen as a "half step" towards interest rate liberalization, with potential implications for China's economy and financial markets.

site_title: Jaguar, Audi SUVs fail to dent Tesla's electric car dominance
summary: Tesla continues to dominate the American electric vehicle market, with its luxury SUVs remaining unchallenged despite the arrival of new models from Jaguar's I-Pace and Audi's e-tron. The I-Pace and e-tron have failed to dent Tesla's market share, with the company's electric vehicles still holding a significant lead. Elon Musk's strategic efforts have helped maintain Tesla's pre-eminence in the electric vehicle segment, making it a formidable force in the luxury SUV market.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: GIC to acquire a 25.1% stake in Lendlease's A$4.3b Sydney office property trust. Rex International plans to monetize its Oman asset by end-2019 with a US$70.8m war chest. Ardmore Medical Group puts IPO plans on hold due to "ongoing developments" and market conditions. Mapletree Commercial Trust is expected to benefit from the remaking of the Greater Southern Waterfront area. Shell launches Singapore's first electric vehicle charging points at its petrol stations, while 94% of fintech firms in Singapore intend to expand their workforce.

site_title: Singapore VC fund manager among world's top performers
summary: East Ventures, a Singapore-based VC fund manager, has been named as one of the world's top-performing venture capital fund managers by Preqin, tied with Benchmark Capital, Click Ventures, G Squared, and Merus Capital. The firm, which focuses on early-stage investments in South-east Asia and Japan, has consistently ranked highly in terms of returns, with three out of its four funds in the top quartile for returns as of the third quarter of 2018. East Ventures has backed over 400 startups, including unicorns such as Tokopedia and Traveloka.

site_title: Carlsberg CEO has a warning for his peers about negative rates
summary: Carlsberg CEO Cees 't Hart warns his peers about the risks of negative interest rates, cautioning that companies may issue debt they can't afford to expand. He notes that companies like Anheuser-Busch InBev have benefited from aggressive expansion, but risked financial problems later. Globally, almost $17 trillion of bonds trade at negative yields, with companies like Nestle and a Danish bank offering debt at negative rates. Carlsberg has focused on cutting debt and reducing costs, avoiding major acquisitions since its CEO joined in 2015.

images.alt_text: Mr Hart says the worry is that firms that succumb to the temptation to issue debt just because it's cheap could end up with balance sheets they can't afford.

site_title: Medtech hub opens with support from S'pore's healthcare clusters
summary: A new medtech hub, Catalyst, has opened in Singapore, aiming to accelerate the development of healthcare products and services. The hub is supported by healthcare clusters SingHealth, National Healthcare Group, and the National Health Innovation Centre. The opening ceremony was officiated by Vivian Balakrishnan, Minister for Foreign Affairs. The hub seeks to foster collaboration among startups, organizations, and professionals in the healthcare industry to improve disease prevention and cure. This move is expected to boost innovation in the sector.

site_title: RE&S posts 32.9% fall in Q4 net profit on outlet closures
summary: RE&S Holdings, a Japanese food and beverage group, reported a 32.9% decline in Q4 net profit to S$628,000 due to outlet closures at Great World City and Tiong Bahru Plaza. Revenue fell 4.9% to S$33.6 million, with a 4.3% rise in quick-service restaurant revenue. The company plans to conduct strategic business consolidation, refresh concepts, and increase new outlets to grow the top-line while improving operations. Full-year net profit was S$4.04 million, up 13.3% from the previous year.

site_title: Dutch families join 'people's farm' to counter climate change
summary: In the Netherlands, a cooperative of hundreds of local families has joined a "people's farm" to counter climate change. The farm, which is not traditional, features chickens, cows, and pigs, and aims to change habits in a low-lying country struggling with climate change. The cooperative aims to promote sustainable practices and reduce carbon emissions.

images.alt_text: The 200 families, members of the cooperative, decide what the farm will produce - and what they will eventually eat - and hire a farmer to tend to the animals for meat and eggs and grow the fruit and greens.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.77 points to 1,596.45. Volume reached 2.2 billion lots worth RM1.6 billion, with 429 gainers and 349 losers.

site_title: Camsing Healthcare suspends chairman
summary: Camsing Healthcare has suspended chairman and executive director Lo Ching, who remains in Shanghai police custody. The firm announced this move in a July 9 filing, stating it was made aware of Lo's detention on July 5. Camsing Healthcare cited concerns over Lo's duties and powers, but no further details were provided. The suspension affects all administrative and executive duties of Lo.

site_title: European stocks rally at open
summary: European stocks rallied at the start of trading on Monday, driven by hopes for US-China trade talks. London's FTSE 100 index rose 0.8%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 jumped 1.0%, and Paris' CAC 40 won 0.9%. The gains were attributed to positive sentiment over US-EU trade talks and sector-specific performances in mining and healthcare.

site_title: British parliament must reconvene immediately for Brexit crisis, Labour Party says
summary: The British parliament must reconvene immediately to discuss the Brexit crisis, Labour Party says, amid leaked documents forecasting possible shortages of food, fuel, and medicine. Prime Minister Boris Johnson's calls for the EU to renegotiate the existing exit deal have been rejected, putting Britain on course for an unmanaged exit. Labour wants to bring down Johnson's government and form an emergency coalition to delay Brexit, citing a majority in parliament committed to stopping a no-deal exit. The opposition party aims to bring MPs back to discuss the crisis before the current summer break ends on September 3.

site_title: Stock market shrinkage exacerbated by Europe IPOs at decade low
summary: The European stock market is shrinking due to a decade-low number of IPOs, with 84 companies listing this year, the fewest in a decade. Investor jitters amid the escalating trade war and structural changes, such as cash-rich funds nursing startups for longer, are contributing to the decline. This may lead to a vicious cycle of underperformance, fund outflows, and reduced demand for new listings, potentially weakening the role of equity markets in spreading wealth and increasing inequality.

site_title: Camsing Healthcare suspends chairman, who remains in police custody
summary: Camsing Healthcare has suspended chairman and executive director Lo Ching, who remains in police custody in Shanghai, with immediate effect. The company cited concerns for the best interests of shareholders and operations, as normal business functions remain stable. The Shanghai police have not disclosed reasons for Lo's arrest, which may be related to a 3.4 billion yuan asset management product lawsuit filed by China wealth manager Noah Holdings. Camsing Healthcare will continue to investigate and update shareholders on any developments.

site_title: Obamas' first film charts life in US factory under China bosses
summary: Former US President Barack Obama's production company, Higher Ground Productions, will release the documentary "American Factory" on Netflix and in select theaters on August 21. The film, directed by Steven Bognar and Julia Reichert, chronicles the lives of American and Chinese workers at a shuttered General Motors factory in Ohio that reopened under Chinese management. The documentary explores the impact of globalization on the community, featuring footage of the factory's closure and reopening, and the struggles of workers under Chinese management. The film was acquired by the Obamas after its premiere at the Sundance Festival.

site_title: Thailand growth weakest since 2014 as trade war, baht bite
summary: Thailand's economy grew at its slowest pace in almost five years in the second quarter, expanding 2.3% from a year ago, down from 2.8% in the first quarter. The slowdown was attributed to US-China trade tensions, a strong local currency, and a drought. The central bank unexpectedly cut its benchmark interest rate earlier this month, and a government stimulus package announced last week aims to offset the damage. The country's growth forecast has been cut to 2.7-3.2% for 2019, with downside risks including a looming delay in the budget and a potential delay in the budget since a new government took office.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks end with big gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged more than 2% on Monday, following a positive lead from Wall Street, as investors reacted to Donald Trump's comments on trade talks. The Hang Seng Index rose 2.17% to 26,291.84, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 2.10% and the Shenzhen Composite Index rallied 3.05%. The gains come as investors appear to brush off new US threats, instead focusing on positive comments from Trump's trade adviser.

site_title: Malaysia sees UK trade deal with palm producers after Brexit
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad announced that the UK will have the opportunity to make a trade deal with Southeast Asian nations, including top palm oil producers, once it leaves the EU. This move aims to avoid a potential trade war with Europe and steer clear of EU-imposed stricter limits on palm oil use in green fuels. Mahathir called for dialogue and joint solutions, including better regulation and stronger certification standards, to incentivize sustainable palm oil production.

site_title: Malaysian PM urges Britain to 'break with Europe' on palm oil
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad urged Britain to engage with palm oil growers to incentivize sustainable production instead of pursuing boycotts after the UK's exit from the EU. He called the EU's move to phase out palm oil in biofuels "a form of modern colonialism" and warned of a trade war. Mahathir hopes to avoid a trade war and believes better trade terms can be achieved through collaboration.

site_title: Philippines checks for African swine fever as pig deaths rise
summary: The Philippines has set up a crisis management team to investigate a rise in pig deaths, potentially linked to African swine fever. The Bureau of Animal Industry reported increased mortality among backyard-raised pigs, and further laboratory tests are underway to confirm the outbreak. The country has safeguards in place to protect its $5 billion hog industry, including a ban on pork and pork-based products from over a dozen countries where the outbreak has spread. The team will implement measures to manage and contain the suspected animal disease.

site_title: Australia shares see best day in 2 months; energy stocks power gains
summary: Australia's shares rose 1% on Monday, their best gain in two months, driven by energy firms and heavyweight financial stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,467.40 points. Global recession worries eased as expectations of more stimulus in major economies boosted investor sentiment. This followed a similar rally in US stocks, which ended higher on Friday due to an ebbing bond rally and news of potential German economic stimulus.

site_title: Asean to see fastest data centre growth in next 5 years: report
summary: Asean is expected to experience the fastest data centre growth in the next 5 years, with a 13% compounded annual growth rate, according to a Cushman & Wakefield report. The Asia-Pacific region is forecast to outpace North America and Europe, with Singapore being a key hub. The total market for Asia-Pacific co-location data centres is expected to reach $28 billion by 2024, with Malaysia and Indonesia also showing significant growth, driven by increasing IT consumption and e-commerce.

images.alt_text: Global Switch's Woodlands data centre in Singapore.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher following Wall St gains
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Monday, following Wall Street gains, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.71% to 20,563.16. The broader Topix index also gained 0.61% to 1,494.33. The US Federal Reserve chief's major speech this week is being closely watched. The gains follow a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record close for the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Hong Kong readies for further protests after huge, peaceful rally
summary: Hong Kong held a massive, peaceful protest on Sunday with an estimated 1.7 million demonstrators, marking a shift from violent clashes seen earlier. The rally, which called for the withdrawal of a suspended extradition bill and other demands, was largely peaceful despite some breaches of the peace and defacement of public buildings. The protest movement, which began in June, has presented a significant challenge to Chinese President Xi Jinping and has sparked a global response, with US President Donald Trump expressing a desire to see Beijing resolve the issue before a trade deal.

site_title: Jaguar and Audi SUVs fail to dent Tesla's electric-car dominance
summary: Tesla continues to dominate the US electric vehicle market with its luxury SUVs, the Model S and X, outperforming new entrants Jaguar's I-Pace and Audi's e-tron. Despite aggressive marketing efforts, including Formula E involvement, Jaguar's I-Pace and Audi's e-tron have struggled to gain traction, with Tesla selling more units in the first year of each model's release. Analysts attribute Tesla's success to its strong brand, range, and charging infrastructure, making it a more desirable choice for consumers.

site_title: Singapore's East Ventures among world's most reliably top performing VCs: Preqin
summary: Singapore-based East Ventures has been named one of the world's most reliably top-performing venture capital (VC) fund managers by Preqin, tying with Benchmark Capital and others. East Ventures, which focuses on South-east Asia and Japan, has backed over 400 startups, including unicorns Tokopedia and Traveloka. The firm's joint venture, EV Growth, recently closed its first fund at $200 million. East Ventures is among five firms with three out of three venture capital funds in the top quartile for returns as of the third quarter of 2018.

site_title: Goldman Sachs appoints lawyer to observe Najib's second 1MDB trial
summary: Goldman Sachs has appointed a lawyer to observe the second 1MDB trial of Malaysia's former leader Najib Razak, set to begin on August 26. The move follows Malaysia's escalation of efforts to prosecute the US bank, charging 17 of its directors with misleading investors over a $6.5 billion bond sale for the state fund 1MDB. Najib faces 25 money laundering and corruption charges linked to global transactions. The appointment comes after Goldman Sachs was charged with similar wrongdoing last year.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs Group Inc appointed a lawyer to observe the 1MDB trial of Malaysia's former leader Najib Razak.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,132, up 0.54% on day
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.54% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) at 3,132.00, driven by gains in local banks and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. The rally follows a strong lead from Wall Street and a move by China's central bank to reduce borrowing costs. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index and Shanghai Composite Index also rose, while Tokyo and Sydney added 0.5% and 0.8% respectively.

site_title: A Scottish castle in perfect condition is on sale for S$13.4m
summary: A Scottish castle, Seton Castle, is on sale for S$13.4 million. Originally built in the 18th century, the castle features neoclassical architecture designed by Robert Adam and has remained largely unchanged since its construction. The property, which was once the site of Mary Queen of Scots, boasts 18,196 square feet of living space, seven bedrooms, and a range of amenities. The current owners, who purchased the castle in 2007, are selling due to reduced family use and are seeking a buyer to continue preserving the property's history and integrity.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks gain on rate-cut hopes after China cenbank reforms
summary: South Korean stocks rose 0.66% on Monday, driven by hopes of a rate cut after China's central bank unveiled reforms to its monetary rate policy. The Kospi index ended at 1,939.90, with foreigners selling 141.1 billion won worth of shares. The won weakened, while the benchmark bond yield rose. Investors remain cautious ahead of Fed Chairman Jerome Powell's speech at Jackson Hole.

site_title: Carlsberg CEO has a warning for his peers about negative rates
summary: Carlsberg CEO Cees 't Hart warns his peers against negative interest rates, citing the risk of companies taking on too much debt to finance expansion. Despite cheap credit, Carlsberg has focused on cutting debt and reducing costs, and its leverage has decreased significantly since Hart's arrival in 2015. The brewer plans to invest its cash flow in strategic acquisitions, but will avoid large takeovers. Hart notes that low interest rates can be attractive, but interest rates can also increase, making it essential to manage debt sustainably.

site_title: HSBC gets the cold shoulder in China
summary: HSBC Holdings was excluded from China's interest-rate reform, a move seen as a snub by the bank. The lender, which is Hong Kong's biggest bank and Europe's largest, had been a key part of its growth strategy in China. Despite being the third-largest corporate bank in the country, HSBC was not included in a list of 18 lenders that will participate in pricing for a new loan prime rate. This decision comes after a turbulent period for HSBC, including the departures of its CEO and Greater China head.

site_title: Where went my empty nest?
summary: A single father reflects on the challenges of parenting, stating that despite the joys of watching his children grow, the difficulties never truly disappear, but rather transform. After his twins left for college four years ago, he felt a sense of freedom and entered a new life of his own. However, with their return home as they search for jobs, he is experiencing the "empty nest" phase again. He must navigate the transition, reminding himself that his children are young adults and this phase is temporary, while also encouraging them to leave home and start their own lives.

site_title: Over 90% of fintech firms in Singapore plan to expand headcount: poll
summary: A survey by the Singapore FinTech Association and PwC Singapore found that 94% of fintech firms in Singapore plan to expand their workforce within the next 12 months, despite a lack of talent shortages. The industry is expected to increase in size, with around 6,500 to 10,000 employees. The shortage of talent appears to have been mitigated, with 59% of firms reporting no talent shortfall. Experts note that relying solely on foreign talent is not sufficient to sustain growth, and that training and equipping the local workforce with the right skills is crucial.

site_title: France's 42: start-up IT school tears up the rule book
summary: France's Ecole 42, a free computer coding college, is revolutionizing the education system with its unique approach. Founded by billionaire Xavier Niel in 2013, the college has a 100% employment rate among graduates and attracts students from diverse backgrounds. With no teachers or conventional tuition, students complete projects and exams over four weeks, and some even sleep and shower on-site. The college has gained cult status, and its inclusive approach has won plaudits from politicians and businesses, despite some controversy. Niel plans to expand the program globally, aiming for 20 partner schools in 14 countries by 2020.

site_title: The children of Asia's elite are leaving home earlier than ever
summary: Children of Asia's elite are leaving home earlier than ever, with some as young as 12 years old. This trend is driven by the pressure to secure top college admissions, with boarding schools like Eaglebrook in the US becoming the first step in the process. Many Asian families view these schools as essential for their children's future success, despite the emotional challenges and sacrifices involved. This phenomenon highlights the intense competition and emphasis on education in Asian cultures, where social status and academic achievement are deeply valued.

site_title: New guide offers Singapore maritime firms framework for sustainability reporting
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has launched the first sector-specific guide for maritime firms to create sustainability reports. The guide, developed with partners including the Singapore Exchange and Ernst & Young, provides best practices for sustainability reporting. The guide features MPA's own sustainability reporting journey as a case study and aims to champion sustainability reporting for the maritime industry, aligning with MPA's efforts to build a more sustainable future for Singapore and the region.

site_title: Hong Kong immigration to Taiwan surges as protests grind on
summary: Hong Kong's unrest continues, with the number of people moving to Taiwan from Hong Kong surging 28% in the first seven months of 2019, compared to the same period last year. The city's anti-government protests have driven residents to seek a safer living environment in Taiwan, where they can enjoy cheaper property prices, business opportunities, and a safer living environment. Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen has supported Hong Kong's protesters, and her support ratings have rebounded since the movement began. The trend is expected to continue, with no caps on relocations from Hong Kong and the Taiwanese government open to more residents coming.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Rex International, SK Jewellery, Sinjia Land
summary: Rex International Holding reported a net profit of US$23.6 million for its latest quarter, despite buying back shares due to market undervaluation. SK Jewellery's dormant bullion unit, SK Bullion, was put into liquidation after shareholder meetings. The liquidation is not expected to impact SK Jewellery's net tangible assets or earnings per share.

site_title: MCT to benefit from revamp of Greater Southern Waterfront: DBS
summary: DBS analysts predict that Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) will benefit from the government's revamp of the Greater Southern Waterfront (GSW) area, as VivoCity, owned by MCT, is expected to remain a key component of the rejuvenation. The GSW, spanning 30km of coastline, offers 2,000 hectares of land for redevelopment, with up to 9,000 new residential homes and office spaces planned. The area's revitalization is expected to increase residential apartments, working population, and tourism, driving benefits to VivoCity and MCT.

site_title: Workplace design and build firm Space Matrix makes 2 senior hires in Singapore
summary: Space Matrix, a Singapore-based workplace design and build consultancy, has appointed Roger Clement as managing director, Singapore, and Tan Su-San as director of workplace strategy and insights. Clement replaces Benjamin Breen and will work closely with clients to address workplace design challenges, while Tan's role focuses on developing intelligent design solutions to support organizational needs. The appointments aim to strengthen the firm's leadership team and expand its global footprint.

site_title: Australia branded a leading 'emissions exporter'
summary: Australia is the world's third-largest emissions exporter, with over a billion tonnes of carbon dioxide shipped abroad annually in the form of coal and liquefied natural gas. The country's energy exports rank behind only Russia and Saudi Arabia in terms of emissions potential, according to a think tank study. Critics argue that Australia's steady supply of coal sustains demand, while supporters claim customers will remain dependent on coal regardless. The country's refusal to ease coal exports has prompted a rift with low-lying Pacific island neighbours threatened by rising sea levels.

site_title: Uber names new UK boss as London licence renewal nears
summary: Uber has appointed a new boss for Britain and Ireland, amid the expiration of its London licence on September 25. The company had previously faced a licence renewal rejection in 2017 due to failings in reporting serious criminal offences and driver background checks. A 15-month probationary licence was granted in 2018, but the outcome of the current renewal request is uncertain. The new boss's appointment comes as the UK's transport regulator, Transport for London, reviews Uber's licence renewal request.

site_title: Buyout firm Centerbridge nears US$1.5b deal for GoHealth -sources
summary: Private equity firm Centerbridge Partners LP is nearing a deal to acquire a majority stake in GoHealth LLC, a US online health insurance marketplace, valued at approximately US$1.5 billion. The deal, which could be announced as early as Monday, is confidential and has not been commented on by GoHealth or Centerbridge.

site_title: Figtree Holdings bags S$43.5m design and build contract
summary: Figtree Holdings, a Catalist-listed company, secured a S$43.53 million design and build contract for a food processing facility in Singapore. The six-storey facility, designed and built by Figtree unit Figtree Projects, will be completed in the third quarter of 2021. Construction began in the fourth quarter of 2019. The contract is expected to contribute to Figtree's revenue but is not expected to impact earnings per share and net asset value per share for the current financial year. The company's shares rose 1.1 Singapore cents or 10.28% after the announcement.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday; STI up 0.35% to 3,125.79
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.35% to 3,125.79 on Monday, following a strong US market close on Friday. The Straits Times Index gained 10.76 points, with 54.5 million shares changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 96 to 28. This marks the 5th consecutive day of gains ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Australia's Westpac overdue mortgages on the rise amid soft housing market
summary: Australia's Westpac Banking Corp reported a rise in overdue mortgages, with 90-plus-day delinquencies increasing 8 basis points to 0.9% over the third quarter. This comes amid a soft housing market, where housing prices have fallen every month since 2017. Properties in possession jumped 68 to 550, and stressed assets rose 10 basis points to 1.2%. Back-to-back rate cuts and recently passed tax cuts may boost consumer sentiment, but the bank's core equity capital ratio decreased to 10.5%. The increase in delinquencies is attributed to the soft property market and increased time to sell properties.

site_title: Japan's trade surplus with US soars ahead of talks
summary: Japan's trade surplus with the US increased by 15.6% in July, reaching 579.4 billion yen, the fifth consecutive monthly rise. Japanese exports rose 8.4% driven by chip-making equipment and construction machinery, while imports from the US grew 3.5% led by aircraft and crude oil. The surge in trade surplus comes ahead of US-Japan trade talks, which are set to restart.

site_title: Singapore dividend payout slides 11.6% to US$3.8b in Q2: index
summary: Singapore's dividend payout decreased 11.6% to US$3.8 billion in Q2, despite underlying dividend growth of 17.7%. Global total dividends rose 1.1% to US$513.8 billion, but at its slowest rate in over two years. The Janus Henderson Global Dividend Index attributed the decline to special dividends, while Japan saw a 10.3% increase in dividend payouts, and Indonesia also showed a 10% rise. The index maintained its 2019 forecast of US$1.43 trillion in dividends.

site_title: Ardmore Medical puts IPO plans on hold
summary: Ardmore Medical Group has put its initial public offering (IPO) plans on hold due to ongoing business developments and market conditions. The decision comes after a draft prospectus was lodged on June 28. The company cited concerns over a patient's death under the care of founder and CEO Sean Ng, who accounts for 42.9% of group revenue. An inquiry is still ongoing, and a hospital complaint lodged in 2017 is being investigated by the Singapore Medical Council. Despite this, Ardmore Medical remains optimistic about its expansion and diversification plans.

site_title: Oil rises after Saudi oilfield attack, but recession worries cap gains
summary: Oil prices rose 0.8% to $59.09 a barrel after a drone attack on a Saudi oil facility, but gains were limited by a downbeat OPEC report that cut forecasted oil demand growth. Brent crude rose 45 cents, while US crude rose 39 cents. The attack added to Middle East tensions, while concerns about an economic recession and surplus oil supply in 2020 also impacted prices. OPEC reduced its forecast for global oil demand growth by 40,000 barrels per day.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally on fresh hopes for trade talks
summary: Asian markets rallied on Monday following positive comments from US President Donald Trump's top economic adviser, Larry Kudlow, on trade talks with China. Kudlow said that talks with Chinese negotiators were "positive" and that high-level phone talks were "a lot more positive than has been reported." The comments boosted regional equities, with Hong Kong leading gains at 1.8%, followed by Shanghai, Tokyo, and Sydney. Investors remain hopeful that central banks will provide stimulus to limit the impact of a potential global economic recession.

site_title: HR startup StaffAny raises S$1m in seed round led by FreakOut, angel investors
summary: HR startup StaffAny has raised S$1 million in a seed round led by FreakOut Holdings and angel investors, including Kenji Niwa and Lim Qing Ru. The funding will support growth and expansion plans for the workforce management application, which connects HR and operations to better manage hourly workers in the labor-intensive food and beverage and retail sectors. StaffAny aims to achieve 10% of Singapore's F&B market share and expand overseas, with a long-term goal of becoming the easiest workforce management tool in South-east Asia.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 4.28 points to 1,594.94 at 9am. Volume was 38.21 million lots worth RM12.38 million, with 110 gainers beating 50 losers. The market's performance was not directly linked to global events, but rather domestic factors.

site_title: China's State Council calls for Shenzhen integration with Hong Kong, Macau
summary: China's State Council has called for the integration of Shenzhen with Hong Kong and Macau, aiming to boost the southern city's economic strength and development. The directive, published in response to anti-government protests in Hong Kong, calls for Shenzhen to become a global benchmark by the middle of the century. The move aims to modernize social governance through technology and further develop the Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area. This comes as Hong Kong faces its first recession in a decade due to protests and a decline in tourism and retail sales.

site_title: Chinese police investigate FedEx package containing handgun
summary: Chinese police are investigating a FedEx package containing a handgun sent from the US to a sporting goods company in Fuzhou, Fujian province. The incident occurred amid tense Sino-US relations, following FedEx's previous issues with Huawei packages. FedEx has apologized and cooperated with authorities, while the company also sued the US government, claiming it should not be held liable for inadvertently shipping banned products. The investigation is ongoing, with the gun impounded and authorities seeking to determine the origin and purpose of the firearm.

site_title: Petronas says begun restarting Saudi-Malaysian refinery CDU
summary: Petronas, Malaysia's state oil firm, has restarted a crude distillation unit (CDU) at its oil refinery in Pengerang, Malaysia, after a fire damaged the atmospheric residue desulphurisation (ARDS) unit in April. The refinery had started feeding crude oil into the CDU earlier this week, with repairs expected to take months. The ARDS unit is scheduled to return online in 2020. The restart follows modifications to the refinery's crude processing to low-sulphur oil, such as Murban crude from Abu Dhabi.

site_title: Malaysia ex-PM Najib's major 1MDB trial postponed
