The media has expressed support for Hong Kong police, with one newspaper's editor stating that a reporter caught up in clashes was "a real man". Beijing has condemned some protesters for using violent tactics, but has stopped short of calling for military intervention. The protests, which began 10 weeks ago, are centered on the erosion of freedoms in Hong Kong, with demonstrators demanding greater autonomy.

site_title: IBM, India's Tata join US tech platform's governing council
summary: IBM and Tata Communications have joined the governing council of Hedera Hashgraph, a distributed public ledger platform. Hedera, backed by Digital Currency Group and BlockTower Capital, aims to be faster and larger in scale than current blockchain technologies. The platform has raised $124 million and plans to open to the public later this summer. The governing council, which currently has 37 members, includes other notable companies such as Nomura Holdings and Deutsche Telekom. Members have equal say in updating the platform codebase and setting policies, with terms limited to two consecutive three-year terms.

site_title: Australia: Shares join global rally as miners bounce, CSL gains
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% on Wednesday, driven by gains in mining stocks and CSL Ltd, which reported record earnings. The rally was fueled by the US delay of tariffs on Chinese imports, which was seen as a step to ease trade tensions. Major miners Rio Tinto and Fortescue Metals Group jumped 4.8% and 5.5%, respectively. CSL climbed 7.4% to an all-time high, while gold stocks fell.

images.alt_text: Australian shares joined a global equities rally on Wednesday as heavyweight mining stocks benefitted after Washington delayed tariffs on some Chinese imports that were slated to take effect in September.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 5.56 points to 1,598.44, driven by a 50.6 million lots worth RM18 million. Gainers beat losers 189 to 37, indicating a positive market trend.

site_title: OUE C-Reit, OUE H-Trust's S$1.49b merger approved by holders
summary: OUE C-Reit and OUE H-Trust have approved a merger via a trust scheme of arrangement, with holders giving the green light at separate extraordinary general meetings. The managers of H-Trust will now submit an application to the court to sanction the trust scheme. The proposed merger involves a S$1.49 billion deal, combining the two trusts to create a new entity. The court's approval is expected to pave the way for the merger to proceed.

site_title: Malaysia's July consumer price index up 1.4% year-on-year, slightly below forecast
summary: Malaysia's consumer price index (CPI) rose 1.4% year-on-year in July, slightly below forecast, according to government data. This is a slower pace than the previous month and reflects mild inflation since the unpopular consumption tax was scrapped in June 2018. Despite increases in 10 out of 12 tracked groups, costs were down in the transport and clothing sectors. Analysts expect slowing economic growth to keep price pressures in check, with the central bank having cut interest rates in May to address low inflation and concerns over slowing growth.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's consumer price index rose 1.4 per cent in July from a year earlier, a bit slower than the previous month, government data showed on Wednesday.

site_title: Six shophouses along Kampong Bahru up for sale with S$39.6m guide price
summary: A row of six adjoining conservation shophouses along Kampong Bahru Road in Singapore has been launched for sale at a guide price of S$39.6 million, or about S$6.6 million each. The freehold two-storey shophouses, located near Outram MRT station, can be sold individually or collectively and are zoned for commercial use, making them eligible for foreign buyers. The property's proximity to the central business district and future Greater Southern Waterfront development makes it an attractive opportunity for investors.

images.alt_text: A row of six adjoining conservation shophouses along Kampong Bahru Road has been launched for sale at a guide price of S$39.6 million, or about S$6.6 million each.

site_title: Red meat could be the next sin tax after sugar, Fitch says
summary: Fitch Solutions Macro Research suggests that red meat could become a target for higher taxes due to its role in climate change, deforestation, and animal cruelty. The idea is emerging in Western Europe, where it could encourage a shift to poultry or plant-based protein and meat substitutes. While opposition from farming groups is expected, it's unlikely that a tax will be implemented in the US or Brazil anytime soon. The global rise of sugar taxes makes a similar approach to the meat industry more plausible, but a tax is not imminent.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start with a rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged at the open on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index jumping 1.70% to 25,711.10, following Donald Trump's decision to delay threatened tariffs on China and remove some goods. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose, with the Hang Seng Index rallying for a second day after tumbling on protests that have jolted the city for over two months. The rally was attributed to hopes for a breakthrough in the China-US trade row.

site_title: Japan's June machinery orders post surprise rebound
summary: Japan's core machinery orders unexpectedly rebounded 13.9% in June, marking the largest monthly expansion on record. This increase, exceeding economists' expectations, suggests corporate investment remains resilient despite global growth and trade frictions. Policymakers closely watch capital expenditure to offset risks to growth, as Japan's export-reliant economy faces global pressure. The rebound in machinery orders helped Japan's second-quarter GDP expand at an annualized rate of 1.8%, beating projections, but household sentiment remains weak ahead of a planned sales tax hike.

site_title: China's property investment slows in July as Beijing tightens curbs
summary: China's property investment slowed in July, marking its weakest pace this year, as Beijing tightens curbs on speculative investments and holds back on new stimulus. This slowdown may indicate waning resilience in the housing market, despite being a key driver of growth in the world's second-largest economy. The move comes as the country deals with the effects of a trade war with the US, where real estate has been one of the few bright spots in the economy.

images.alt_text: China's property investment slowed to its weakest pace this year in a sign the housing market's resilience may be waning as Beijing toughens its crackdown on speculative investments and holds back on new stimulus.

site_title: China is waging a disinformation war against Hong Kong protesters
summary: China is waging a disinformation war against Hong Kong protesters, using state media to create an alternate version of events that portrays protesters as violent and foreign-backed. The campaign has been intensified since July 21, when protesters surrounded the Chinese government's main office in Hong Kong and threw black ink on a government emblem. China's disinformation efforts aim to undermine sympathy for the protesters' goals, including demands for greater democratic freedoms. The campaign has received significant traction online, with over 10 million people reposting a message from China's state television network claiming the injured protester was not hit by police.

site_title: US airline safety regulators ban recalled Apple laptops from flights
summary: US airline safety regulators, the FAA, have banned select recalled Apple MacBook Pro laptops from flights due to a fire risk posed by batteries. The laptops, sold between 2015 and 2017, were recalled by Apple after determining that a limited number of units may overheat and cause a fire. Four airlines have implemented the ban, barring the laptops from being brought onto their planes as cargo or in carry-on baggage. The move is a precautionary measure to ensure customer safety, and customers are free to fly with the computers once new batteries are installed.

site_title: Deliveroo food deliveries hit European roadblocks
summary: British food delivery company Deliveroo is facing European roadblocks due to striking couriers, court setbacks, and regulatory challenges. The company is competing with growing startups for the pocketbooks of hungry city dwellers. Despite its popularity in London, Deliveroo is struggling to expand across Europe, with its efforts hindered by labor disputes and bureaucratic hurdles. The company's future expansion plans are uncertain, with its European operations facing significant challenges.

site_title: Hong Kong's Cathay shares jump 7.4% at open after slump this week
summary: Cathay Pacific shares jumped 7.4% at open on Wednesday after the Hong Kong airport reopened and the airline and its top shareholder condemned protests and vowed to follow China's aviation regulations. The shares had tumbled to a 10-year-low earlier in the week due to the Chinese aviation regulator's demand for personnel to be suspended from staffing flights. Cathay and Swire Pacific placed advertisements supporting the Hong Kong government and efforts to restore law and order, condemning illegal activities and violent behavior.

site_title: BreadTalk CEO quits, chairman to take over
summary: BreadTalk Group's CEO, Henry Chu Heng Hwee, will leave the company on December 31, 2019, due to personal and health reasons. He will be succeeded by Chairman George Quek Meng Tong, who will take over the roles and responsibilities of the group CEO. Chu's departure comes after BreadTalk reported a 57.9% decline in second-quarter net profit, largely due to increased distribution and selling expenses. The company has been expanding its store count worldwide, but this may have affected its revenue.

site_title: Facebook listened to users' conversations: report
summary: Facebook has paid hundreds of contractors to listen to and transcribe snippets of users' conversations, including those on Facebook Messenger, with users' permission. The practice, which was first reported by Bloomberg, has been stopped after contractors expressed concerns over listening to private audio and vulgar content. Facebook acknowledged the transcriptions in a statement, stating that the company had halted human review of audio more than a week ago. This practice is part of the company's efforts to improve its artificial intelligence.

site_title: White House Park GCB for sale, could fetch S$75m-S$80m
summary: A freehold good class bungalow (GCB) at White House Park in Singapore's District 10 is up for sale by tender, expected to fetch S$75 million to S$80 million. The two-storey property sits on a 35,290 sq ft land area, allowing for a single mansion or sub-divided into two GCB parcels. With only 2,800 GCB plots available across 39 safeguarded areas, the offering is seen as a rare find, particularly with its subdividable potential, making it an attractive proposition for wealth preservation.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust's maiden DPU beats forecast
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) has posted distributable income (DI) of US$5.65 million, beating its forecast by 1.2%. The company's distribution per unit (DPU) was 0.650 US cent, 1.2% higher than projected. Net income (NI) was also 0.1% higher than projections. EHT's portfolio, comprising 18 US hotels with 5,420 rooms, saw lower trust expenses and finance expenses, resulting from an easing interest rate environment. The company's RGI is 104%, 6.8% better than at its IPO. EHT's managers remain focused on driving revenues and stabilisation through asset management initiatives.

site_title: Tech suppliers shift away from China despite Trump tariff delay
summary: Tech suppliers are shifting production out of China as the US-China trade war escalates. Inventec, a HP-laptop maker, plans to move its US-bound laptop operation to Taiwan within two to three months. Other Taiwanese companies, such as Hon Hai Precision Industry Co, are reconsidering their reliance on China. Despite US President Donald Trump's delay in implementing tariffs on Chinese-made products, tech companies are taking proactive steps to diversify their production. This move is driven by the uncertainty and potential risks associated with the ongoing trade tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Wednesday's open after Wall St rally; STI up 0.81% to 3,172.23
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.81% to 3,172.23 on Wednesday, following a positive lead from Wall Street amid China tariff delays. Gainers outpaced losers 96 to 38, with CapitaLand Commercial Trust, AEM Holdings, and Ascendas Reit leading the gains. Banking stocks also rose, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC increasing 1-1.6%. The rally came ahead of Singapore's GDP data release and amid easing US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Climate deniers get more media play than scientists: study
summary: Climate deniers have received significantly more media attention than climate scientists, with 50% more coverage from 2000 to 2016. This disparity fuels public confusion and hinders efforts to address global warming. Despite overwhelming scientific consensus that human activities are causing the planet to heat up, contrarian views are frequently cited in mainstream media outlets. A study found that climate change contrarians were mentioned 49% more often than climate scientists, with social media platforms amplifying this imbalance.

site_title: Trump promises more big energy projects at Pennsylvania plant
summary: President Donald Trump visited a US$6 billion petrochemicals plant in western Pennsylvania, promising more big energy projects as his administration rolls back environmental regulations. Trump praised the Shell plant as part of the "revolution in American energy" and claimed it would have never happened without him. The Trump administration is pursuing an "energy dominance" policy, which includes slashing regulations to maximize oil, gas, and coal production. Critics, including environmentalists, express concerns about the impact on the environment and public health.

site_title: mm2 Asia Q1 profit falls 4.1% on higher cost of sales
summary: mm2 Asia's first-quarter net profit fell 4.1% to S$7 million due to higher amortisation of film rights and cost of sales rising 16.8% to S$18.8 million. Revenue inched up 0.1% to S$49.03 million, driven by core and cinema business growth, but offset by lower contributions from event and post-production segments. Shares declined 8.29% to S$0.188. The company intends to conserve cash for expansion and business opportunities, with no dividend declared for the quarter.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Olam, Wilmar, ST Engineering, OUE, Manulife US Reit, Metro, BreadTalk
summary: Olam International's second quarter net profit shrank 34.5% to S$61.5 million due to higher depreciation, finance costs, and exceptional losses. Wilmar International's net profit fell 52% to US$151 million, with revenue down 9% and earnings per share dropping to 2.4 US cents.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wall Street gains
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, following a rise on Wall Street, as US President Donald Trump delayed tariffs on key Chinese goods. The Nikkei 225 index climbed 0.98% and the Topix index rose 0.90%, with the yen weakening to 106-yen against the dollar. This easing of trade concerns boosted Japanese shares, particularly exporters, with Sony and SoftBank Group gaining. The delay in tariffs is seen as a positive for Japanese exporters, making their products more competitive.

site_title: First Resources Q2 profit slides 52.8% on weaker palm oil prices
summary: First Resources reported a 52.8% decline in Q2 net profit to US$17 million due to weaker palm oil prices, with sales falling 20.8% to US$143.4 million. This resulted in earnings per share of 1.07 US cents, down from 2.27 US cents in the same period last year. The decline was mainly attributed to lower average selling prices.

site_title: Asian stocks bounce in relief as Trump delays China tariffs
summary: Asian stocks rebounded on Wednesday, August 14, 2019, after US President Donald Trump delayed tariffs on Chinese imports, providing relief to markets. The delay on 10% tariffs on consumer goods, such as cellphones and laptops, was seen as a positive move for holiday sales. Despite disappointing China data, including weak industrial production, the news boosted global equities, with the yen rising on the news. Asian markets joined a global surge, with stocks such as Singapore's STI index up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: US senator warns China on Hong Kong trade status if it cracks down on protests
summary: US Senator Ben Cardin warns China that Hong Kong could lose its special trade status if Beijing intervenes in pro-democracy protests, threatening to take action in Congress to enforce autonomy agreements. Cardin, a Democrat, has co-sponsored bipartisan legislation requiring annual justification for Hong Kong's special treatment. If China cracks down on protesters, Cardin vowed to enforce autonomy agreements, potentially jeopardizing Hong Kong's trade status under US law.

images.alt_text: "I can assure you that if China comes down hard on the protesters that there will be action in Congress to enforce the autonomy agreements that were entered into that are part of the special recognition of Hong Kong," Senator Ben Cardin told Reuters.

site_title: UK gears up for Brexit-driven election that Johnson can't call
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson's staff anticipate an imminent general election, but the exact timing remains unclear due to the Fixed-term Parliaments Act, which requires a two-thirds majority of MPs or a confidence vote for a national ballot. Johnson's governing majority is slim, and he faces opposition from MPs plotting to block his Brexit plan. An election could be triggered if a confidence vote fails, but this route carries risks, including an accidental no-deal Brexit. Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has suggested supporting an election if Johnson agrees to delay Brexit, but the timing and terms of any election remain uncertain.

site_title: SoftBank upends Latin American startups with billion-dollar deal binge
summary: SoftBank Group is investing heavily in Latin America, with a multibillion-dollar deal spree that has minted "unicorns" and upended the region's startup landscape. The Japanese technology giant has around $4 billion left in its $5 billion fund and is targeting roughly 300 companies, with a focus on Brazil and the healthcare and real estate industries. SoftBank's investments have made up a significant chunk of the total market, with deals adding up to $2.1 billion so far this year, tripling the total from 2017.

site_title: Google, Facebook, Amazon to testify in US against French digital tax
summary: US companies Google, Facebook, and Amazon will testify at a government hearing on France's proposed 3% digital tax, which applies to companies earning over $38.8 million in French revenue. The tax is seen as "unreasonable" by the US Trade Representative's Office and could lead to new tariffs or trade restrictions. The companies argue that the tax will be passed down to consumers and hinder growth in the digital economy, while the French government claims the tax is needed to address multinational companies' tax avoidance practices.

site_title: Oil soars near 5% as US delays tariffs on some Chinese goods
summary: US delays imposing 10% tariff on certain Chinese goods, easing concerns over a global trade war. Oil prices surge, with Brent futures rising 4.7% to $61.30 a barrel and US WTI crude gaining 4.0% to $57.10. The delay boosts energy demand growth prospects, while Saudi Arabia's commitment to production cuts and potential IPO also support prices. Crude inventories unexpectedly rose last week, but analysts expect a drawdown in the coming weeks, which could lead to a tighter market.

site_title: Olam Q2 profit slumps 34.5% on higher costs, exceptional losses
summary: Olam International's Q2 profit slumped 34.5% to S$61.5 million due to higher depreciation, net finance costs, and exceptional losses. Revenue grew 15.7% to S$8.6 billion. Excluding exceptional losses, net profit would have fallen 21.7%. The company declared a one-tier tax-exempt interim dividend of 3.5 cents per share. Net profit for the half-year ended June 30 fell 8.5% to S$230.4 million.

site_title: Strong Singapore-US economic ties overrule political climate: AmCham chairman
summary: Singapore and the US have strong economic ties that surpass the current political climate, according to AmCham chairman Dwight Hutchins. The two nations collaborate on boosting the Asia-Pacific's technology and cybersecurity sectors, and have introduced initiatives training over 1,200 government officials in the region. This partnership has fostered a growing relationship between the two nations, with Singapore's focus on entrepreneurship and US corporates' strengths aligning to create a positive economic environment.

site_title: Pragmatic pathways for SME businesses and business owners
summary: SMEs must adapt to a rapidly changing business environment by innovating at an institutional level, shifting focus from product and service improvements to scale efficiencies and transformative change. Deloitte's "pragmatic pathways" framework provides a framework for SMEs to embark on this transformation, emphasizing the importance of embracing exponential technologies, fostering a culture of imagination and purpose, investing in employee support, and rethinking visibility in a virtual work environment. Leaders must seriously challenge their current playbook and rethink their perspective to identify opportunities for innovation and growth.

site_title: Bumitama Agri Q2 profit plunges 68% on lower palm oil prices
summary: Bumitama Agri, an Indonesian palm oil producer, reported a 68% plunge in Q2 profit to 124.6 billion rupiah due to lower palm oil prices and decreased sales volume. Revenue fell 24.3% to 1.8 trillion rupiah, mainly due to a 15.4% decrease in crude palm oil prices. The company expects no changes in palm oil prices unless supply and demand dynamics change. Net profit for the half year to June 30 fell 62% to 235.2 billion rupiah.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Singapore's favourites
summary: Julian Koh and Claressa review Singapore's most-loved cars in honor of National Day on the Money FM podcast "Chasing Cars". The episode features a discussion of the top favorites among Singaporeans, but no specific rankings or winners are mentioned. The review is a lighthearted and entertaining segment that allows the hosts to share their opinions and engage in conversation about the country's preferred vehicles.

site_title: US public opinion of China sours: Pew
summary: US public opinion of China has plummeted to 60% unfavorable, the highest in 14 years, according to a Pew Research Center survey. This surge in negative views comes despite the US-China trade tensions initiated by President Trump in 2017. For the first time, more Americans view China as a military threat than an economic menace. The unfavorable views have increased from 47% a year ago, reflecting a significant shift in public perception of China.

site_title: Trump delays tariffs on Chinese cellphones, laptops, toys; markets jump
summary: US President Donald Trump delayed 10% tariffs on Chinese imports, including cellphones, laptops, and toys, until December 15, aiming to avoid impact on the holiday season. The delay, which affects about half of the $300 billion target list, sent stocks sharply higher and drew cautious relief from retailers and technology groups. The tariffs will still be imposed on other products, including clothing and footwear, and on some electronics, such as smartwatches and televisions. The move is seen as a compromise, with Trump hinting that China may make concessions in exchange for the delay.

site_title: Hong Kong airport resumes flights after clashes, mass protests
summary: Hong Kong's airport resumed operations after a two-day disruption due to clashes between protesters and riot police. About 30 protesters remained at the airport, and check-in counters reopened to weary travelers. The clashes, part of 10 weeks of violent protests, have plunged the city into its worst crisis since 1997. Over 600 people have been arrested since the protests began in June, and Hong Kong's Hang Seng stock index fell to a seven-month low. The protests represent a major challenge for Chinese President Xi Jinping, with demonstrators fighting for democracy and the erosion of Hong Kong's autonomy.

site_title: UK destined for economic damage and weak currency
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson's hard-Brexit stance is causing economic damage and weakening the pound, with currency markets warning of a potential 5% slump. Despite warnings from the Bank of England and International Monetary Fund, Johnson has appointed hardline Brexiteers to his cabinet and instructed his government to prepare for a no-deal departure. Sterling has fallen 7% in the last three months, threatening a political crisis that could lead to an early general election, with markets fearing a return to failed policies of the 1970s if Jeremy Corbyn's Labour party wins.

site_title: FTC chief says he's willing to break up big tech companies
summary: US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) Chairman Joe Simons stated he's willing to break up big tech companies, including Facebook, if they're found to be harming competition. Simons emphasized that breaking up companies is a difficult process, but it could be necessary to restore competition. He expressed a willingness to undo past mergers if it's deemed necessary, saying "If you have to, you do it." This comes as part of a broad review of the technology sector.

site_title: Trump hopes 'tricky' Hong Kong situation works out 'for liberty'
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed hope that the Hong Kong protests would work out for "liberty" without violence, citing US intelligence that China's government is moving troops to the border. Trump urged calm as clashes continued between protesters and authorities, and warned that Beijing might directly intervene to quell the demonstrations. The US State Department said Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and top Chinese diplomat Yang Jiechi discussed US-China relations, while China's state media reported troops being assembled near the border.

site_title: Valuetronics Q1 profit hit by softer demand amid US-China trade war
summary: Valuetronics Holdings reported a 3.1% drop in net profit to HK$48.1 million for its first quarter, due to weaker consumer and business confidence amid the US-China trade war. Revenue fell 7.1% to HK$654.3 million, with industrial and commercial electronics business contributing HK$413.5 million and consumer electronics decreasing by 9.9% to HK$240.8 million. The company attributes the decline to escalating trade tensions, with 45% of revenue coming from US shipments subject to tariffs. Valuetronics plans to expand in Vietnam, acquiring a plot of land to build its own manufacturing campus.

site_title: Argentine peso on roller coaster after Macri defeat
summary: Argentina's peso continued its downward trend after President Mauricio Macri's crushing defeat in party primaries, falling 1.77% to 58.33 pesos per dollar. The stock market partially recovered, rebounding 10% after a 38% decline on Monday. Analysts warn of a higher likelihood of sovereign default, citing Macri's popularity slump and ongoing recession, inflation, and poverty. The peso's decline is attributed to Macri's pro-business policies, which are unpopular among ordinary Argentines.

images.alt_text: Argentina's peso slipped further against the dollar Tuesday while the stock market partially recovered as South America's third-largest economy continued to take a pummeling in the wake of pro-business President Mauricio Macri's crushing defeat in party primaries.

site_title: China denies US warship visits to Hong Kong: Navy
summary: China has denied US Navy ships' requests to visit Hong Kong, citing the ongoing pro-democracy protests. The USS Green Bay and USS Lake Erie were scheduled to stop in Hong Kong but were denied permission. The denial comes amid escalating tensions between the two countries, with China accusing the US of interfering in Hong Kong's affairs. The protests, which began weeks ago, have raised concerns about sliding freedoms in the semi-autonomous city. The US Navy last visited Hong Kong in April, and a request was previously denied in September due to US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Peter Tan ran agency 'like a cult': Prudential witness
summary: Former Prudential agency leader Wendy Ho Xiang Yu testified that Peter Tan Organisation was "run like a cult" under Peter Tan Shou Yi, driving her to join a defection plan to Aviva's subsidiary Aviva Financial Advisers (AFA) in 2016. Ho said a culture of fear motivated her actions, including joining an agency trip to Guangzhou despite her reservations. She claimed to have been pressured by Tan into attending the trip, and initially planned to remain at Prudential but later changed her mind. Ho's testimony has been met with inconsistencies, with screenshots showing she had initially decided not to follow Tan to Aviva.

site_title: ST Engineering Q2 earnings up 18% to S$138.2m
summary: ST Engineering reported an 18% increase in Q2 net profit to S$138.2 million, driven by higher earnings from its marine sector. Revenue rose 8% to S$1.78 billion, with its Aerospace sector contributing largely from the acquisition of MRAS. The company approved an interim dividend of five cents per share, unchanged from last year. For the six months, net profit rose 14% to S$269.3 million, while revenue increased 6% to S$3.51 billion. The company's order book remains strong, with a record high of S$15.6 billion.

site_title: Australian Prime Minister set to woo Pacific leaders at annual forum
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison is set to attend the Pacific Islands Forum in Tuvalu, where he faces a muted reception after his pledge to invest in renewable energy was publicly dismissed by island leaders. The two-day gathering aims to address climate change and regional concerns. Morrison's visit comes as Canberra fears the Pacific region is edging closer to China. The Australian government has committed A$500 million to renewable energy projects, but its efforts may be met with skepticism from Pacific leaders.

site_title: Singapore banks can be the rock for wealth clients
summary: Singapore banks have reported strong second-quarter performance in wealth management, with assets under management increasing 8-9% from a year earlier. Wealth-related fees now account for 37-48% of their core fees. The banks' regional expansion and presence in key markets like Asia and China are driving growth. Singapore's stable economy and favorable tax incentives for family offices are also attracting wealth clients. While geopolitical uncertainty presents challenges, Singapore banks are well-positioned to capitalize on the country's reputation as a safe haven for wealth management.

site_title: British retailers call for business rates freeze
summary: British retailers, including Sainsbury's and Marks & Spencer, have urged the UK government to freeze business rates to alleviate financial strain on the sector. Over 50 retailers signed a letter to finance minister Sajid Javid, citing the industry's significant contribution to the economy despite bearing a disproportionate share of taxes and rates. The retailers' lobby group, the British Retail Consortium, argues that the current system is unfair and damaging to high streets, with 10.3% of shops in Britain now vacant, the highest rate in four years.

site_title: European blockchain firm launches AI division
summary: European blockchain firm The Bitfury Group has launched its artificial intelligence (AI) division, operating alongside its existing blockchain services. The AI division is valued at over $1 billion, with the company's top official stating it will remain part of the company. This move aims to leverage AI technology to enhance blockchain services, although no specific details on the division's objectives or timeline have been disclosed.

site_title: Temasek's Heliconia takes stake in gaming chair firm Secretlab
summary: Temasek's Heliconia Capital Management is taking a minority stake in Singapore-based gaming chair brand Secretlab, valued at S$200 to S$300 million. This is the first outside investment for Secretlab, which was founded by former professional gamers Ian Alexander Ang and Alaric Choo in 2014.

site_title: Big 3 Singapore banks face rising asset risk: Moody's
summary: Singapore's three largest banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, face rising asset risk and slowing income growth in 2019 due to worsening global economic conditions. Despite posting record profits and stable asset quality, Moody's Investors Service warns that further improvement in profitability will be difficult. Income growth is expected to slow due to stagnant net interest margins and rising credit costs, while trading and wealth management income will be volatile. The banks' capital ratios remain strong, but non-performing loan ratios are expected to deteriorate amid rising volatility.

site_title: Hong Kong airport chaos giving huge boost to rivals across the border
summary: Hong Kong's international airport has experienced disruptions due to protests, causing shares of airports on the mainland border to surge. Shenzhen Airport Co rose 10% and Guangzhou Baiyun International Airport Co rose 4.5% to a record high. Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd's shares declined, and analysts predict international airlines may re-evaluate Hong Kong's role as a hub, potentially boosting Shenzhen's status. China Southern Airlines Co and Air China Ltd could also benefit from the shift. The disruptions have led to a decline in Cathay's shares, with some analysts warning of "irreversible damage" to the airline's brand.

site_title: Thai government's slim coalition majority under threat as one party withdraws
summary: Thailand's ruling coalition, led by Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha, faces a slim majority after the Thai Civilized Party withdrew its support, citing dissatisfaction with government policies. The party, which holds one seat, will become an independent opposition. The remaining nine small parties pledged continued support for the 18-party coalition, maintaining a three-seat majority in the lower house. This development increases the risk of legislative gridlock, particularly with the country's economy facing challenges from a surging currency and the US-China trade war.

site_title: Delfi Q2 net profit up 19% on stronger product sales
summary: Delfi, a Singapore-based confectionery maker, reported a 19.4% increase in net profit to US$6.1 million for the second quarter, driven by stronger product sales. Revenue rose 3% to US$112.3 million, primarily due to sales growth in Indonesia and increased sales of its own branded products. The company proposed an interim dividend of 1.73 Singapore cents per share. For the half-year, net profit rose 20.7% to US$15.4 million, with earnings per share increasing to 2.51 US cents.

site_title: MAS chief economist rules out off-cycle Singdollar tweaks
summary: MAS chief economist Edward Robinson ruled out an unscheduled change to monetary policy, despite a fresh economic downgrade. The MAS will continue to monitor developments and assess the inflation and growth outlook for the Singapore economy at its next scheduled review. Unemployment rates remain steady at 2.2%, but experts expect some upward pressure on unemployment rates and retrenchments due to economic headwinds. The MAS will carefully consider these factors when making its next policy decision.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: City Developments Limited's share price is upgraded to "Buy" with a target price of S$11.00. Analysts attribute the upgrade to the potential successful privatization of Millennium & Copthorne Hotels, investments and redevelopment opportunities, and better-than-expected sell-through rates in the luxury market, which could drive recurring income.

site_title: Mirae emerges as lead bidder for Anbang's US luxury hotel portfolio
summary: Mirae Asset Financial Group is emerging as the leading bidder for Anbang's US luxury hotel portfolio, valued at over $5.5 billion. An affiliate of Mirae is working to arrange financing and reach an agreement on terms. Despite Anbang not granting exclusivity, another suitor is still pursuing the assets. If talks are successful, Mirae aims to make a nonrefundable deposit by the end of the month. The portfolio includes iconic hotels such as the Westin St Francis and the Four Seasons in Jackson Hole.

site_title: Mecca hotels bank on stunning views
summary: Mecca, Saudi Arabia is becoming a hub for luxury religious tourism, with high-end hotels offering stunning views of the Kaaba, Islam's holiest site. Rooms can cost up to $25,000 per night, attracting super-wealthy pilgrims from around the world. These hotels feature lavish amenities, including marble and fine wood panelling, catering to the needs of premium pilgrims.

site_title: Public feedback wanted for code of practice for cryptocurrency sector
summary: The Association of Cryptocurrency Enterprises and Start-ups, Singapore (Access) has released a draft code of practice for the cryptocurrency sector in Singapore. The code, called Standardisation of Practice In Crypto Entities (Spice), aims to standardize anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing practices, as well as other key issues. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has welcomed the initiative, which is expected to enhance the reputation of crypto companies and assist banks in assessing money laundering risks. The code is open for public feedback until September 10.

site_title: Growth downgrades, heightened risks and the stimulus question
summary: Singapore's official GDP growth forecast has been slashed to 0-1% for the year, with a challenging period ahead. The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) warns of worsening trade relations and geopolitical tensions, citing risks to the economy. Private economists are calling for targeted stimulus measures, particularly for small businesses in manufacturing and trade-related industries. The government has promised to monitor the situation closely and may deploy support measures, but some experts believe it's premature to act. A stimulus package is expected in the next national Budget in February.

site_title: 2019 exports forecast slashed as Q2 performance dives 14.6%
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) declined 14.6% in Q2, extending a third straight quarter of decline, and the full-year forecast is now expected to contract -9 to -8%. The manufacturing sector is in technical recession, and economists predict no export recovery in the near future. The US-China trade conflict, Hong Kong uncertainties, and Japan-South Korea trade spat have contributed to the decline. Enterprise Singapore attributed the decline to a global electronics downcycle and sluggish global demand.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: HRnetGroup posted an 11.5% fall in net profit to S$11.5 million for the second quarter, driven by lower margins from flexible staffing. Rex International swung into profit with a net profit of US$23.6 million, while Yanlord Land's net profit narrowed 41% to S$170 million. Allied Technologies reported a S$1.8 million loss, citing weak global economic outlook and escrow issues. No dividend was declared by HRnetGroup, while Rex and Allied expect challenging business environments.

site_title: Passenger vehicle sales in India fall the most in two decades
summary: Passenger vehicle sales in India plummeted 36% in July, the largest decline in nearly two decades, with car sales down 31% and truck and bus sales falling 26%. This marks the ninth consecutive month of decline, forcing manufacturers to cut production and resulting in at least 15,000 job losses. The slowdown mirrors weak consumer confidence and a five-year low in economic growth, prompting the industry to call for an urgent revival package from the government.

site_title: Stock market falls as HK leader insists on clinging to power
summary: Hong Kong's stock market plummeted to a 7-month low, hitting the Hang Seng index, amid the ongoing protests against Chief Executive Carrie Lam's handling of the situation. The protests, sparked by opposition to a now-suspended extradition bill, have escalated into demands for democracy and the erosion of freedoms under Chinese rule. The United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights urged restraint and called for an investigation into allegations of forceful tear gas use. Lam insisted on clinging to power, saying she would rebuild the economy and engage with protesters.

site_title: US core consumer price index points to inflation firming
summary: The US core consumer price index (CPI) unexpectedly accelerated 0.3% in July, exceeding median estimates, signaling inflation may be firming. The core CPI rose 2.2% from a year earlier, with shelter costs, medical care, and apparel seeing gains. Faster inflation may strengthen the Federal Reserve's hand in debating interest rate cuts, while US-China trade tensions and a global economic slowdown weigh on the outlook.

site_title: America's superpower panic in the face of a rising China
summary: The US finds itself in a superpower panic as China's rise threatens its dominance. Unlike Britain and the Dutch Republic, which engaged with their successors to maintain a comfortable place in the world, US President Donald Trump's confrontational approach towards China could damage America's long-term interests. As the world's dominant military power and leader in industries and trade, the US should adopt a soft landing strategy to ensure a smooth transition. Trump's incoherent approach may lead to significant consequences for the US, unlike the historical examples of adapting to a new global power.

site_title: Junk bond demand grows, as do worries over liquidity
summary: Investors are shifting to junk-rated corporate debt amid concerns over liquidity in the European investment-grade bond market. Over $1.1 billion flowed into euro-denominated high-yield debt funds in June, the highest in nearly two years. This trend is driven by the European Central Bank's expected resumption of buying corporate bonds to revive the economy. However, high-yield debt is less liquid, and a sharp change in sentiment could lead to clients demanding their money back, potentially forcing some funds to suspend trading.

site_title: Acquisitions boost Manulife US Reit's Q2 DPU by 17.7%
summary: Manulife US Reit reported a 17.7% increase in second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.53 US cents due to contributions from newly acquired properties. However, adjusted DPU was flat due to an enlarged unit base from a preferential offering. The Reit's gross revenue rose 33.2% to US$43.3 million, while net property income increased 33.8% to US$27.3 million. The company's gearing improved to 37.1% and occupancy rate dipped slightly to 97.2%.

site_title: ComfortDelGro Q2 earnings up 1.2% at S$75.9m
summary: ComfortDelGro Corp reported a 1.2% increase in earnings to S$75.9 million for the second quarter, driven by higher public transport takings and new acquisitions, offset by lower investment income and financing charges. Revenue rose 4.2% to S$980.8 million, and net profit increased 3.5% to S$146.3 million. The company declared an interim dividend of 4.5 cents. Despite a 10-cent drop in shares, CEO Yang Ban Seng attributed the growth to new businesses and technology-driven initiatives.

site_title: PropNex's Q2 net profit slips 12% on lower commission income, higher staff costs
summary: PropNex, a Singaporean real estate agency, reported a 12% decline in Q2 net profit to S$3.7 million due to lower commission income and higher staff costs. Revenue fell 24% to S$92.1 million, mainly due to decreased commission income from agency services and project marketing services. Despite this, the group expects the primary private market to remain resilient and strong sales momentum to carry through to the end of the year.

site_title: US: Tech leads Wall Street higher as tariff delay sparks rally
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday as a delay in planned tariffs on Chinese imports sparked a broad-based rally, with tech stocks led by Apple's 4.2% gain. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 372.54 points, the S&P 500 gained 42.48 points, and the Nasdaq Composite added 152.95 points. The tariff delay calmed fears over the US-China trade war and recession, while a healthy inflation reading of 2.2% year-on-year in July's consumer prices reinforced market expectations for another interest rate cut from the Fed.

site_title: Construction looks to turn corner with slower 4.6% Q2 decline
summary: Singapore's construction sector is expected to turn a corner, with a slower 4.6% decline in Q2 growth, down from 5.2% in the previous quarter. The sector's contraction is attributed to weakness in construction demand since 2015, but demand has picked up since the second half of 2017. Despite this, public sector construction works remain lacklustre, and recent property cooling measures are expected to weigh on the sector. The economy, however, is expected to continue growing, with external-facing sectors driving growth, and manufacturing expansion moderating to 10.2% in Q2.

site_title: Best World Q2 net profit trebles to S$26.7m on surge in revenue
summary: Best World Q2 net profit nearly tripled to S$26.7m, driven by a surge in revenue and higher gross margins. Revenue rose to S$98.3m, with 62.8% coming from its franchise segment. The company's gross profit more than tripled to S$76.7m, reflecting a 78% gross profit margin. Despite a strong earnings report, Best World's stock remains suspended due to ongoing investigations into its business dealings. The company has proposed an interim dividend of 1.2 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: Google's jobs search draws antitrust complaints from rivals
summary: Google's job search tool has drawn antitrust complaints from European rivals, alleging the company's dominance has led to unfair practices and cost them users and profits. The complaints, from 23 job search websites, claim Google's placement of its tool at the top of search results and its widget on most search pages is illegal. Industry executives expect Google to sell ads in the tool, potentially generating billions of dollars in revenue from rivals. Google maintains its tool is fair and allows rival search services to participate, but some companies, like Zippia, claim it's difficult to compete due to Google's dominance.

site_title: It's time to act on container fires
summary: Container fires pose a significant threat to ships, with reported incidents increasing in 2019. A new fire-fighting system, the HydroPen System, has been launched to enable crews to tackle fires in containers safely and efficiently. However, preventing fires in the first place is crucial, with mis-declaration of cargo being a major cause. Major insurers are calling for penalties to be imposed on shippers who mis-declare cargo, and some shipping companies are implementing measures to discourage such practices.

site_title: Tunisia's delicate date palm drink is a gift from the oasis
summary: In southern Tunisia, a unique date palm drink called "legmi" is a prized commodity, mainly consumed from March to October, particularly during Ramadan. The delicate drink is produced by expert producers like Ridha Omrane Moussa, who harvests the sap from palm trees and carefully extracts it to create a high-sugar content beverage. Due to its fragility and limited reach, legmi is mainly sold locally, with some producers warning of the threat of chemical pollution from nearby factories. The drink is deeply rooted in the culture of the region, with some viewing its limited availability as a positive aspect of preserving the traditional oases.

site_title: OKP Q2 net profit more than doubles despite revenue slide
summary: OKP Holdings reported a net profit of S$278,000, more than doubling from the previous year, despite a 29% decline in revenue to S$19.4 million in the second quarter. The company attributed the improvement to higher rental income, construction projects, and management consultancy fees. Revenue fell due to a 66% decline in maintenance segment revenue. OKP's order book stands at S$282.6 million, with work expected to last until 2023.

site_title: Halcyon Agri swings into the black for Q2
summary: Halcyon Agri Corp reported a net profit of US$2.3 million for Q2, reversing a loss of US$4.1 million previously. Operating profit surged to US$11.1 million, driven by investments in operational technology. Earnings per share increased to 0.14 US cents from a loss of 0.26 US cents. This marks a significant turnaround from the same period last year.

site_title: Is this August of financial troubles more like 1998 or 2007?
summary: Financial markets are experiencing turbulent events in late summer, reminiscent of past crises in 1989, 1998, 2007, 2011, and 2015. The coincidental timing may be due to traders being on vacation, reducing market liquidity. This August's financial troubles could be similar to 1998, with wilder swings, but also share similarities with 2007. The article suggests that the global financial system's wobbles often occur in August, leaving both reassurance and anxiety among investors.

site_title: MMA player Rebel FC acquires AV business for S$10m
summary: Rebel Fighting Championship (Rebel FC) has acquired Singapore-based Expo AV-InSync for S$10 million to enhance its in-house production capabilities. This acquisition aims to strengthen the global brand and produce more of its own video content. With the acquisition, Rebel FC gains access to production and audio-visual equipment and systems, bolstering its capabilities in the MMA entertainment industry.

site_title: Sustainable floating cities need to be more than just a temporary solution
summary: The UN is seeking advanced proposals for sustainable floating cities to address climate change and sea-level rise. Designers are drawing from existing industrial structures, such as offshore oil platforms and cruise ships, to create modular, adaptable cities. However, critics warn that such projects can lead to dystopian spaces if not carefully planned, citing examples from the 1960s and 1970s. The UN must also address legal and funding issues, including the development of a framework for sustainable economic activities and financing mechanisms for floating cities. Research on affordable, flood-resilient housing and ocean-related sustainable economic practices is also needed.

site_title: Irregularities, potential breaches uncovered at Raffles Infrastructure
summary: An interim independent review report by KPMG Forensic has uncovered irregularities and potential breaches in listing rules at Raffles Infrastructure Holdings, formerly known as China Fibretech. The company is currently on the SGX Watch-List. The review highlights concerns over the firm's compliance with Singapore Exchange listing rules.

site_title: Andy Murray returns to singles tennis to a trouncing
summary: Andy Murray returned to singles tennis after a seven-month hiatus, losing to Richard Gasquet 6-4, 6-4 in the Cincinnati Masters first round. Murray, 32, showed flashes of his former ability, using creative off-speed shots, but struggled with rust and a "bad habit" of not running down every ball due to hip issues. He announced he won't play singles at the US Open, instead opting for doubles, citing a desire to avoid more media scrutiny and being fair to himself.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower amid geopolitical tensions, trade worries
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday amid geopolitical tensions and trade worries. The Dow Jones fell 0.03%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.08%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.10%. Investors are grappling with simmering tensions and fears of a recession due to the US-China trade war.

site_title: Europe: China tariff delays pull European shares out of doldrums
summary: European shares rebounded from early losses on Tuesday after the US administration delayed imposing tariffs on certain Chinese goods, including laptops and cell phones. The delay provided a boost to global sentiment, lifting commodity stocks, automakers, and tech sectors. The pan-European STOXX 600 index closed up 0.5% after erasing session losses of up to 0.8%. The move was seen as a relief, with market analysts crediting it to the willingness to compromise from both sides.

site_title: Yen and dollar rise as investors seek safety
summary: The Japanese yen and US dollar rose against other currencies due to investors seeking safety amid the Sino-US trade war, protests in Hong Kong, and Argentina's peso crash. The yen reached a seven-month high, while the dollar rallied against a basket of other currencies. The Swiss franc also rose to a two-year high as investors sought safe havens. Analysts expect the yen to rally further to 102 or 103 per dollar later this year, driven by interest rate cuts and risk aversion.

site_title: Clashes erupt at Hong Kong airport
summary: Protesters clashed with police at Hong Kong's international airport on Tuesday, disrupting operations for a second day. The scuffles broke out after an injured person was taken out of the main terminal by medics, with protesters blocking police vehicles and riot police pushing back protesters, using pepper spray at times. The Airport Authority reported "serious disruptions" to operations, further plunging the former British colony into turmoil.

site_title: UK train fares set to rise after year of commuter misery
summary: UK train commuters are bracing for fare hikes, with regulated fares set to rise by almost 3% due to inflation, based on the July Retail Prices Index (RPI) measure. The increase would add over £100 to an annual standard-class season ticket from London, following a year of cancellations, delays, and strikes. Economists forecast a 2.8% increase in the RPI, which would disproportionately affect rail users and student loan borrowers. The fare hike comes amid public resentment over high ticket prices, with some calling it "another kick in the teeth" for commuters.

site_title: Construction sector has solid role - even in this digital age
summary: Singapore prioritizes the construction and infrastructure sector despite economic slowdown, citing long-term growth potential and upcoming projects such as the Tuas megaport and Changi Airport Terminal Five. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of infrastructure in tiding over short-term challenges and signaling Singapore's strengths to the world. The government is also taking steps to address climate change and rising sea levels, with measures such as raising low-lying roads and piloting the use of polders and dikes.

site_title: Moscow, Hong Kong and the liberalism of the streets
summary: Protests in Moscow and Hong Kong demonstrate the resilience of liberal ideals, despite authoritarian governments' claims of stability. Both cities have seen massive demonstrations, with Hong Kong's largest drawing 2 million and Moscow's largest around 50,000. Despite differences in scale and tactics, protesters in both cities share a desire for democratic representation and an end to perceived corruption. The authorities' responses, ranging from repression to concession, risk fueling the protests and have historically backfired. As one Moscow protester notes, the liberalism that Putin dismisses appears to be a recurring "fever" that will eventually resurface.

site_title: Henkel cuts outlook, blames lower Q2 sales on beauty, adhesives units
summary: Henkel, a German consumer goods company, lowered its full-year outlook for sales and earnings due to disappointing performance at its beauty unit and a decline in its adhesives business. The company attributed the decline to lower industrial production. Henkel has been underperforming its peers, such as Procter & Gamble and Unilever, and has warned of earnings falls in 2019 as it invests in brands and digital technology to revive growth.

site_title: Boeing deliveries fall 38% in the first seven months of 2019
summary: Boeing delivered 258 aircraft in the first seven months of 2019, a 38% decline from the same period last year, due to the grounding and uncertainty surrounding its 737 MAX jets. This puts Boeing on track to lose its position as the world's largest planemaker, a title it has held for seven years. In contrast, European rival Airbus SE delivered 458 aircraft during the same period.

site_title: Delfi Q2 net profit up 19% on stronger product sales
summary: Delfi, a confectionery maker, reported a 19.4% jump in net profit to US$6.1 million for the second quarter, driven by stronger product sales and a 3% revenue increase to US$112.3 million. The company also proposed an interim dividend of 1.73 Singapore cents per share. Delfi's focus on building higher-priced products and extending into the snacking category is expected to drive growth, with the company remaining cautiously optimistic about this year's prospects.

site_title: A practical approach to Industry 4.0
summary: A recent seminar on Human Capital Development in Industry 4.0 highlighted the need for companies to adapt to the changing job market. Industry 4.0 is not just about advanced technologies, but also about job redesign and the need for diverse skill sets. Companies should focus on developing leaders with skills such as ideation, problem-solving, and communication to supervise operators and technicians. The gig economy is also on the rise, offering flexibility and creative work opportunities for workers. To retain talent, companies must integrate their departments and understand the skills needed for roles in marketing, sales, and product development. Singapore is well-positioned to benefit from the Industry 4.0 paradigm, with opportunities for innovative industries and startups.

images.alt_text: The gig economy has existed for a while in the creative industry, but technology has enabled its replication in other sectors, producing players like Deliveroo.

site_title: TPV Technology gets offer of HK$3.86 a share in privatisation bid
summary: CEIEC (HK) Limited and its concert parties, including China Electronics Corporation, have proposed a scheme of arrangement to take TPV Technology private by purchasing the remaining 50.96% of shares at HK$3.86 per share, representing a 41.4% premium over its closing price on August 8. The offer is valued at approximately HK$14.8 billion.

site_title: Irregularities, potential breaches uncovered at Raffles Infrastructure
summary: An interim independent review report by KPMG Forensic found irregularities and potential breaches at Raffles Infrastructure Holdings, including uncooperative legal representative Wu Xinhua, who failed to provide requested documents. The report highlighted several issues, including inaccurate compensation payments, misreported bank transactions, and a possible breach of listing rules in a property disposal. Although the report did not recommend remedial action, Raffles Infrastructure plans to consult with SGX Regulation and may convene an extraordinary general meeting to seek shareholders' approval for legal action.

site_title: Europe Inc suffering earnings recession
summary: Europe Inc is experiencing a recession, with companies listed on the STOXX 600 index forecasted to report a 1.6% drop in earnings per share in the second quarter, marking a second consecutive quarter of decline. Revenue is expected to rise 3%, but the slowdown in manufacturing and escalating trade tensions between the US and China are major concerns. In contrast, the euro-zone's GDP is expected to grow 0.2% and Germany's economy is forecasted to shrink 0.1%. This contrasts with a positive outlook in the US, where companies are expected to report growth in the second quarter.

site_title: Asia-Pacific markets close in sea of red
summary: The Singapore market closed at 3,146.73, down 22.21 points or 0.7%, due to concerns over trade risks, protests in Hong Kong, and a decline in non-oil domestic exports. The Straits Times Index fell 1% in the morning before ending at a seven-month low. Other Asia-Pacific markets also experienced a "sea of red" with declines in Hong Kong, China, and Japan. Analysts warn that the slump suggests markets are bracing for more backlash from trade risks and risk re-pricing.

site_title: Poly grads on Earn and Learn scheme get higher starting wage
summary: Polytechnic graduates who participated in the SkillsFuture Earn and Learn Programme (ELP) earned a higher starting wage than those who did not, with a 44% premium during the programme and 41% after graduation. This wage premium, which stabilizes at around 10% 19 months after graduation, suggests that employers value the human capital gained through the ELP. The study found similar results for graduates who pursued a private degree, which takes twice as long to complete. The ELP's sustained wage premium is encouraging, but further monitoring is needed to examine the long-term benefits.

site_title: Braddell View mega site relaunched for en bloc sale at same reserve price of S$2.08b
summary: Singapore's largest private residential site, Braddell View estate, has been relaunched for collective sale by tender with a reserve price of S$2.08 billion. Owners of residential units can expect to receive between S$2.04 million and S$4.03 million each if the sale succeeds. Commercial shops owners could receive S$529,500 to S$1.2 million. The relaunch comes after an initial sale attempt in 2019.

images.alt_text: Braddell View was originally put up for sale on March 27, but the tender closed in May with no bids. The estate sits on a 1.14 million sq ft hilltop site overlooking MacRitchie Reservoir Park.

site_title: Cosco Q2 net profit slides 30% amid expansion drive in Malaysia
summary: Cosco Shipping International's Q2 net profit declined 30% to S$1.7 million, driven by a 6% increase in cost of sales. Revenue rose 3% to S$41.2 million, despite the decline. The company announced several acquisitions in Malaysia to expand its operations, totaling RM88 million (S$29.1 million), and is also in talks to acquire assets from Golden Logistics. Cosco's unit, Cogent Malaysia, is discussing a lease for a 300,000 square foot warehouse in Port Klang.

site_title: OUE Q2 net profit soars on gain from divestment of stakes
summary: OUE Limited reported a significant increase in net profit to S$60.9 million for its second quarter, a 10-fold rise from the previous year. The gain was largely due to the one-off sale of the Aquamarina Hotel for S$136.6 million. Revenue rose 89% to S$285.3 million, driven by higher contributions from development property divisions. The company's board has proposed an interim tax-exempt dividend of one Singapore cent per share, payable on September 26.

site_title: Civmec inks engineering project with Australian iron ore firm Fortescue
summary: Civmec Limited has secured a new engineering project with Fortescue Metals Group, an Australian iron ore giant, valued at approximately A$120 million. The project involves the primary crushing and ore processing facility for Fortescue's Eliwana mine and rail in Western Australia. The contract will employ around 300 locals and is expected to be completed by late 2020, with Civmec's order book reaching A$850 million following recent contract awards.

site_title: US delaying new tariffs on Chinese electronics to Dec 15
summary: The US is delaying the imposition of new 10% tariffs on Chinese electronics until December 15, but will proceed with new duties on $300 billion in Chinese goods starting September 1. US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer spoke with Chinese Vice Premier Liu He, and another call is planned in two weeks. The decision comes amid escalating trade tensions and a deterioration in relations between the two countries. President Trump accused China of failing to meet its commitment to buy US agricultural goods, citing the delay in imposing tariffs on electronics.

site_title: India needs time to restore order in Kashmir - top court judge
summary: A Supreme Court judge in India stated that authorities need more time to restore order in Kashmir after the region's special status was revoked on August 5, sparking protests. The security clampdown entered its ninth day, with telephone lines, internet, and television networks blocked. The court is hearing a petition to lift curbs on communications and movement, which have disrupted normal life and essential services in the Himalayan region.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Singapore stocks have experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release. Meanwhile, CGS-CIMB Securities downgraded Grab to 'hold' due to expected earnings growth slowdown in H2. OCBC CEO Helen Wong will retire, with Tan Teck Long succeeding her. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay rose 30.5% to S$3.1 million. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Tesla marked its formal India entry with a launch event. Citigroup predicts a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index. Analysts remain positive on SGX earnings, raising target prices.

site_title: Allied Tech posts Q2 net loss of S$1.8m, reverses year-ago profit
summary: Allied Tech reported a Q2 net loss of S$1.8 million, reversing a year-ago profit, due to a 21% decline in revenue to S$31.1 million. The company's e-commerce segment was absent, while its precision metal stamping segment generated higher revenue. Allied Tech has ceased generating revenue since Q4 2018, citing restructuring. The company expects a challenging business environment and is exploring business opportunities. It is also working to recover S$33 million in escrow funds and complete a special audit.

site_title: Swine fever hurts crush margins, halves Wilmar's Q2 net profit
summary: Wilmar International's Q2 net profit halved to US$150.9 million due to the impact of African swine fever on soybean meal demand, hurting crush margins. Revenue fell 9% to US$9.78 billion, and core net profit dropped 20% to US$427 million for the first-half period. The company attributed the decline to the swine fever's impact, but noted strong performance from consumer products and oleochemicals. Wilmar has declared an interim dividend of three Singapore cents per share and submitted an application to list its China operations on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange, which could raise at least US$2.1 billion.

site_title: Hong Kong airport halts check-ins as UN urges restraint over protests
summary: Hong Kong's airport halted check-ins for a second day as protests against the Chinese government's erosion of freedoms and autonomy continued. The UN urged restraint and called for an investigation into police actions, including the use of banned tear gas. The city's stockmarket fell to a seven-month low, and its leader described the situation as "panic and chaos." Ten weeks of violent clashes between police and protesters have plagued the Asian financial hub, raising concerns about its economic stability.

site_title: Prince Andrew's connection to Jeffrey Epstein under new scrutiny
summary: Prince Andrew, Duke of York, is under scrutiny over his connection to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. A 2001 photograph shows Prince Andrew with his arm around Virginia Roberts, then 17, who claims she was paid to have sex with the prince. New allegations surfaced in a defamation suit, stating Roberts was "trafficked" to Prince Andrew and had sex with him three times. Buckingham Palace has denied the allegations, but British lawmakers are calling for a new investigation into Prince Andrew's ties to Epstein.

site_title: Thai government's majority under threat as party pulls out
summary: Thailand's ruling coalition is facing a majority in danger after the Thai Civilized Party, which holds one seat, pulls out citing dissatisfaction with government policies. The party will become an independent opposition. The remaining nine small parties have pledged continued support, maintaining a three-seat majority in the lower house. This development could make it challenging for Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha's government to pass key legislation, such as the annual budget bill. The move increases the risk of instability in Thailand's government, which has been buffeted by economic challenges and a disputed general election in March.

site_title: US consumer prices increase broadly in July
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.3% in July, driven by gains in energy and other goods. The core CPI, excluding volatile food and energy, also increased 0.3% and 2.2% over the past 12 months. Despite the inflation increase, economists expect the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates again in September due to worsening trade tensions and the risk of a recession. The Fed tracks the core PCE price index, which has undershot its 2% target this year.

images.alt_text: US consumer prices rose broadly in July, but the increase in inflation will likely do little to change expectations that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates again next month amid worsening trade tensions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 22.17 points to 1,592.88. Volume reached 2.2 billion lots worth RM1.7 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 744 to 173.

site_title: Advice for London bankers in no-deal Brexit: refundable tickets
summary: UK-based financial professionals face restrictions on short EU work assignments if Britain exits the EU on October 31, potentially leading to fines and penalties for companies. EU member states may require visas for paid work during short stays, despite the UK's visa-free travel agreement. Companies and employees must adapt to new rules, which could lead to "immediate overnight disruption" for businesses relying on short-term EU work. The EU wants firms to hire more people locally, and a no-deal exit could significantly damage businesses.

site_title: New acquisitions boost Manulife US Reit's Q2 DPU to 1.53 US cents
summary: Manulife US Reit's second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) increased to 1.53 US cents, up from 1.3 US cents in the same period last year. The boost was attributed to contributions from newly acquired properties, including Centrepointe in Washington DC, 1750 Pennsylvania Avenue, and the Phipps Tower in Atlanta. The enlarged unit base due to a 2018 preferential offering also played a role in the year-over-year increase.

site_title: Singapore shares drop 0.7% amid trade war fears, HK protests
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.7% on Tuesday, down 22.21 points, amid trade war fears, protests in Hong Kong, and economic concerns. The market was weighed down by poor Q2 non-oil domestic exports data and a cut to Singapore's GDP forecast. Other Asia-Pacific markets also declined, with shares in Australia, China, Hong Kong, Japan, Malaysia, and South Korea falling.

site_title: Straco Q2 net profit drops 17% on higher expenses, weaker RMB
summary: STRACO Corporation reported a 17% drop in Q2 net profit to S$9 million due to higher expenses and weaker RMB, with group revenue falling 6.5% to S$26.4 million. Lower visitor numbers at its China attractions were the main cause, but higher revenue at Singapore Flyer partially offset this. The company attributed the decline to lower visitor numbers at its China attractions, with Shanghai Ocean Aquarium, Underwater World Xiamen, and Lintong Lixing Cable-Car seeing a decline.

site_title: 'When will you die?' Hong Kong leader grilled at press conference
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam faced a hostile press conference on Tuesday, with reporters questioning her about her handling of the city's recent violence and her willingness to step down. The intense questioning, in both Cantonese and English, came after a weekend of clashes between protesters and police, leaving dozens injured. Lam defended the police and refused to acknowledge her mistakes, leaving the press conference abruptly ended. The event highlighted the rising tensions in Hong Kong and the city's media, which enjoys freedoms not seen in mainland China.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets drop at open
summary: Europe's leading stock markets began the day with a decline, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.2%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index down 0.3%, and Paris's CAC 40 index down 0.4%. The declines followed a rally in the previous five days. In contrast, the US stock market edged to fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions between the US and EU.

site_title: Proptech startup REALly raises S$500,000 in seed funding
summary: REALly, a Singapore-based proptech startup, has raised S$500,000 in seed funding from Huntington Partners and angel investors. The company's app helps property managers coordinate tasks, featuring a marketplace with over 2,500 suppliers and contractors. The funding will enhance the app and expand into Malaysian and Indonesian markets. REALly currently has 50 property managers on its platform, including firms like Savills and Colliers International. The startup aims to bring efficiency and transparency to the industry with its technology-enabled platform.

site_title: PropNex reports lower Q2 earnings, declares 1.25 cents dividend
summary: PropNex, a Singapore-based real estate agency, reported a 24% decline in revenue to S$92.1 million for the second quarter, mainly due to lower commission income from agency and project marketing services. Net profit attributable to shareholders fell 12% to S$3.7 million. The company declared a dividend of 1.25 cents per share for the period. Expenses such as staff costs and depreciation increased, contributing to the decline in earnings per share, which fell to 1 cent from 1.36 cents in the previous year.

site_title: Companies could lease elsewhere in Asia as US-China trade war bites
summary: US-China trade tensions may shift office leasing demand in Asia. Companies are considering leasing in South-east Asia or India, with Vietnam and Indian cities like Bengaluru and Hyderabad as potential alternatives. Finance, professional services, and technology firms may opt for Singapore or Tokyo. Despite this, up to one-third of office leasing demand in Shanghai may face delays due to trade uncertainty. Global property investment into Asia is expected to remain flat at US$24 billion in 2019.

site_title: New properties, higher occupancy boost Centurion's Q2 earnings
summary: Centurion Corporation reported a 4% increase in net profit to S$10.2 million for its Q2, driven by an 8% increase in revenue from newly added properties in Australia and the UK, as well as higher occupancy rates in Singapore. The company's South Korean and Malaysian properties incurred start-up losses, affecting the bottom line. New leases and developments were secured, including a 400-bed block in Malaysia and a 3,600-bed project in Singapore, expected to be completed in 2020. An interim dividend of one Singapore cent per share was declared.

site_title: Amazon in talks to buy up to 10% stake in India's Future Retail
summary: Amazon is in late-stage talks to buy up to 10% of Indian retail firm Future Retail Ltd, seeking to expand its presence in the Indian brick-and-mortar market. The deal, valued at around $281 million, comes as Amazon looks to compete with Walmart's majority stake in Flipkart. This move follows Amazon's recent investments in Indian retailers, including a 5% stake in Shoppers Stop Ltd and a grocery chain. The deal is part of Amazon's efforts to build up its stake in brick-and-mortar stores in India, a growing e-commerce market expected to reach $84 billion by 2021.

site_title: Hedge fund warns of 'distressed cycle' as trade war deepens
summary: A Hong Kong-based hedge fund, LIM Advisors, warns of a "distressed cycle" due to the deepening US-China trade war and slowing economies in Asia. Chief investment officer George Long notes that default rates have picked up in China this year and the US-China trade war has already stung the region. Central banks are cutting rates, and distressed debt investors face challenges finding soured debt to buy. LIM Advisors is shifting into private credit and high-yield bonds to prepare for a potential downturn, citing the trade war's "big shock" on sectors and the Chinese economy.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's economic growth forecast for 2019 has been cut to 0-1% by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), marking its third straight quarter of decline. The country's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) forecast was also slashed to -9 to -8% for 2019. Despite this, MAS ruled out an off-cycle policy meeting, and Moody's Investors Service warned that Singapore's three largest banks will face rising asset risk and slowing income growth in 2019.

site_title: Wilmar Q2 net profit halved due to lower crush margins
summary: Wilmar International's Q2 net profit fell 52% to US$151 million due to lower soybean crush margins, weaker associates, and sugar business performance. Revenue decreased 9% to US$9.8 billion, while core net profit halved to US$177 million. The company cited African swine fever's impact on soybean meal demand as the main culprit. Despite this, consumer products and oleochemicals performed strongly. Finance costs rose 27% to US$247 million, leading to a 20% decline in core net profit for the half-year period.

site_title: Head-scratching US corn planting data is still incomplete
summary: US farmers planted more corn than expected, but left 11.21 million acres unplanted, contradicting analyst predictions. The US Department of Agriculture reported 90 million acres planted, with 85.87 million acres actually sown, and 2.6% higher than average analyst estimates. The discrepancy between the two reports may be due to differences in data sets and incomplete reporting, with the USDA's Farm Service Agency reporting on producers who participate in assistance programs and NASS providing a broader measure of the US corn market. The situation may be adjusted as more data becomes available.

site_title: Plácido Domingo, opera star, accused of sexual harassment
summary: Plácido Domingo, a renowned opera star, has been accused of decades of sexual harassment by multiple women, including eight singers and a dancer. The allegations, made in a report by The Associated Press, claim that Domingo pressured women into sexual relationships with job offers and punished them professionally if they refused. Domingo, 78, denied the allegations, stating they were "inaccurate" and "painful" to hear. The accusations have sparked concern in the opera world, with seven women saying their careers were harmed after rebuffing his advances.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares slip on high yen, falling Asian markets
