summary: Tokyo stocks closed down 1.11% on Tuesday, with the Nikkei-225 index falling to 20,455.44 yen, amid a stronger yen and declines on Wall Street and in the Asia region. The benchmark index had been closed for three days. The broader Topix index also fell 1.15% to 1,486.57 points.

site_title: Mirae emerges as lead bidder for Anbang hotel portfolio
summary: Mirae Asset Financial Group is emerging as the lead bidder for a US luxury hotel portfolio valued at over $5.5 billion, being sold by Chinese insurer Anbang Insurance Group Co. An affiliate of Mirae is working to arrange financing and reach an agreement on terms, with at least one other suitor still actively pursuing the assets. Anbang has not granted exclusivity to Mirae, and Mirae aims to make a nonrefundable deposit by the end of the month if talks are successful.

site_title: Hundreds of protesters stage new rally at Hong Kong airport
summary: Hundreds of pro-democracy protesters gathered at Hong Kong's airport for a new rally on Tuesday, following a massive demonstration the previous day that caused airport shutdowns. Only a few protesters stayed overnight, but several hundred returned in the afternoon. The rally came after the airport reopened following the previous day's disruptions. The protesters' demands for greater democracy and autonomy in Hong Kong remain unresolved.

site_title: Google's jobs search draws antitrust complaints from rivals
summary: Google's job search tool has drawn antitrust complaints from European job search websites, with 23 firms alleging the company's dominance is hurting competition and user traffic. Rivals claim Google's prominent widget and partnerships with employers are unfair and restrict access to job listings. Google maintains its tool promotes industry innovation and competition, while executives expect the company to sell ads, generating billions of dollars in revenue. The European Union is investigating, with the competition commissioner preparing an "intensive" handover before her departure.

site_title: Australia business conditions subdued in July: survey
summary: Australia's business conditions remained subdued in July, with the National Australia Bank's index of business conditions falling 2 points to +2, reversing a rise in June. Employment waned, and the economy expanded at its slowest pace in a decade. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to cut interest rates further to stimulate growth, as business confidence remained below the long-run average.

site_title: Metro Holdings Q1 net profit halved on lower fair-value gains
summary: Metro Holdings' Q1 net profit dropped 47.5% to S$10.6 million due to lower fair-value gains from investments and weaker joint venture contributions. Revenue rose 85.4% to S$55.9 million, but cost of revenue surged 74.6%. The company remains optimistic on its recent expansion to Chengdu, citing potential to improve returns through active asset management. Metro chairman Winston Choo emphasized the group's focus on capital recycling and attractive investment opportunities.

site_title: UK train fares set to rise after year of commuter misery
summary: UK train commuters are bracing for a 2.8% fare hike, based on the July Retail Prices Index, which will add over $100 to an annual standard-class season ticket. The increase will be the latest blow to a year of commuter misery, marked by cancellations, delays, and strikes. Economists criticize the RPI measure, calling it a "simple mistake in price collection" that has gone unresolved for a decade. The fare hike is expected to be announced on Wednesday, further fueling public resentment towards high ticket prices.

site_title: Hong Kong hedge fund warns of 'distressed cycle' as trade war deepens
summary: A Hong Kong-based hedge fund, LIM Advisors, warns of a "distressed cycle" due to the deepening US-China trade war and slowing Asian economies. Chief Investment Officer George Long predicts a surge in soured debt, citing China's rising default rates and the impact on sectors like finance and technology. As central banks cut rates, investors are preparing for a potential downturn, with LIM Advisors shifting focus to private credit and high-yield bonds. The trade war's effects on China's economy could lead to more defaults, with Long describing it as a "big shock" to the market.

site_title: Pork giant Smithfield pushes into the market for plant protein
summary: Smithfield Foods, the world's largest pork processor, is launching a new line of soy-based products under its Pure Farmland brand, including burgers, meatballs, and breakfast patties. The move follows other big meat companies in embracing alternative protein, with plant-based protein expected to capture 10% of the global meat market in 10 years, reaching $140 billion. Smithfield's entry into the market comes as consumers increasingly adopt a "flexitarian" lifestyle, seeking to reduce meat consumption while still eating plant-based options.

site_title: Trump Jr kicks off sale of luxury condos in Indonesia projects
summary: PT MNC Land, an Indonesian builder, has begun selling luxury condos and mansions in two projects in partnership with The Trump Organization. The projects, valued at US$1.7 billion, include a six-star luxury hotel in Bali and a resort and condos in West Java. Donald Trump Jr. attended a pre-launch event, calling Indonesia an "under-served market" and stating that the projects will be completed in stages over three years. The Trump Organization will receive royalties and management fees for the use of the Trump brand.

site_title: Platinum giant wants in on batteries to ease electric car threat
summary: Platinum giant Anglo American Platinum Ltd plans to develop a new lithium battery using platinum-group metals instead of cobalt and nickel to address the growing demand for electric vehicles. The move aims to create a new multi-billion dollar source of demand for platinum and palladium. The company is investing up to $4 million in a venture to study the technology, with the goal of having a commercial prototype in 3-5 years. The development could help mitigate the threat to platinum demand from electric vehicles, which are forecast to reach 57% of the car market by 2040.

site_title: Singapore banks face rising asset risk, slowing income growth: Moody's
summary: Singapore's three largest banks by assets, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, face rising asset risk and slowing income growth in 2019 due to worsening economic conditions, according to Moody's Investors Service. Despite posting record results, the banks' profitability will be difficult to improve amid slowing global growth and potential US-China trade conflict. Income growth is expected to slow due to stagnant net interest margins and rising credit costs, with non-performing loan ratios potentially deteriorating amid rising volatility. However, the banks' capitalization and liquidity remain robust.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks wobble on recession, trade war concerns
summary: South Korean stocks ended lower, down 16.46 points or 0.85%, due to demand for safe-haven bets amid a drop in US yield curve and ongoing trade war concerns, including Sino-US and Japan's export curbs. Foreigners sold US$142.88 million worth of shares, marking the longest selling spree since January 2016.

site_title: Chinese state media ups ante over Hong Kong 'mobsters'
summary: Chinese state media has intensified its criticism of Hong Kong pro-democracy protesters, labeling them "mobsters" and warning that Beijing will not be appeased. The official state news agency Xinhua described the unrest as "terrorism emerging" and warned of potential mainland security forces intervention. The Global Times and CCTV have also made similar accusations, with some media outlets suggesting a possible military presence in Shenzhen. Beijing's hardline stance raises concerns about the future of democratic reform in Hong Kong.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with big losses
summary: Hong Kong shares plummeted 2.10% on Tuesday, following steep losses on Wall Street, amid worries over political unrest and the China-US trade standoff. The Hang Seng Index fell to 25,281.30, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. Investors were affected by concerns over Hong Kong's political situation and the uncertainty surrounding the trade standoff.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong shares sank more than two per cent Tuesday following steep losses on Wall Street, with investors hit by worries over political unrest in the city as well as uncertainty about the China-US trade standoff.

site_title: Hong Kong billionaires break silence, urge protesters to ease off
summary: Hong Kong billionaires, including Peter Woo and Sun Hung Kai Properties Ltd., have broken their silence to urge protesters to ease off amid escalating violence. The comments come after ten weeks of protests against the extradition bill, which have led to clashes with police, economic fallout, and a weakening of the territory's stock market. Billionaires have condemned the violent protests and called for rationality, while some have expressed concerns about the impact on the housing market and the economy. The unrest has also led to economic pressure from China and boycotts of brands perceived to be supportive of the establishment.

site_title: European blockchain firm Bitfury launches artificial intelligence unit
summary: European blockchain firm Bitfury has launched its artificial intelligence unit, valuing the move at over $1 billion. CEO Valery Vavilov believes data analysis is crucial and AI is the best way to extract value from the vast amounts of available data. The AI division will operate alongside Bitfury's existing blockchain services and focus on research, with plans to offer AI products by the end of 2020. The company has appointed technology expert Fabrizio Del Maffeo to lead the AI division.

site_title: British beverage giant Diageo to market Cuban rum
summary: British beverage giant Diageo has signed a joint venture deal with Cuba Ron SA to market Santiago de Cuba Rum, despite US efforts to dissuade investment in the Communist-run country. The 50-50 venture, Ron Santiago SA, has exclusive international rights to the premium brand. The agreement comes as the US ramps up sanctions on Cuba and allows lawsuits against foreign companies profiting from property taken after the 1959 revolution. Diageo's subsidiary claims to be unaffected, with no ties to the US. The deal is seen as a move to capitalize on the popularity of Cuban rum globally.

site_title: SAP launches Singapore accelerator for South-east Asia enterprise startups
summary: SAP has launched the SAP.iO Foundry Singapore, a startup accelerator for South-east Asian enterprise tech companies. The program aims to support seven early-stage startups, including Pulsifi, Notarum, and Adaface, which focus on workplace tools and automation. Participants will receive mentorship, access to SAP's technology and APIs, and potential collaborations with SAP customers. The accelerator will run for three months, with the goal of helping startups deliver value to SAP customers.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,145.06, down 0.75% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading Tuesday afternoon, down 0.75% to 3,145.06, amid news of 14.6% decline in Q2 key non-oil domestic exports and a cut to GDP forecast to between zero growth and 1% for the full year. The Straits Times Index (STI) saw losers more than double gainers, with 694.7 million securities worth S$701.6 million changing hands. Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan fell 1%, while US stock futures rose 0.13%.

site_title: Is your sleep cycle out of sync? It may be genetic
summary: A 63-year-old woman has an advanced sleep phase disorder, where her biological sleep-wake cycle is out of sync with the demands of modern life. She typically goes to sleep before 9 p.m. but wakes up at 4 a.m. and struggles to get back to sleep. This condition is often referred to as being an "early bird" or "morning lark." Research suggests that sleep phase disorders may be genetic, with some people's internal clocks being naturally set to an earlier or later time. This can lead to difficulties adjusting to societal norms and daily routines.

site_title: Braddell View mega site relaunched for en bloc sale at same reserve price of S$2.08b
summary: Singapore's Braddell View estate, a 1.14 million sq ft hilltop site, has been relaunched for collective sale by tender with a reserve price of S$2.08 billion. Owners of residential units can receive between S$2.04 million and S$4.03 million each, while commercial shop owners may receive S$529,500 to S$1.2 million. The site's location near schools, public transport, and upcoming developments in the Bishan-Toa Payoh area is seen as attractive, with potential for a solid development pipeline over the next few years.

site_title: One stabbed in central Sydney street attack
summary: Australian police arrested a man who stabbed a woman and chased others in central Sydney on Tuesday. The attacker, brandishing a large kitchen knife, shouted "Allahu Akbar" and "shoot me" before being pinned down by bystanders. The woman, whose identity is not specified, is in a stable condition. The motive behind the attack is currently unknown, but the incident has raised concerns about potential terrorism.

site_title: Japan says South Korea failed to justify trade restriction
summary: Japan has responded to South Korea's removal of Tokyo's fast-track trade status, citing Seoul's failure to justify the move. Industry Minister Hiroshige Seko stated that South Korea has not explained how Japan's export control measures fall short of international standards. The removal of Japan's fast-track trade status will apply to South Korean exports to Japan, with potential lengthy permit application processes. The move is the latest escalation in the trade row between the two countries, which has deteriorated since a Supreme Court ruling last year on wartime labor compensation.

site_title: Typhoon Lekima death toll hits 49 in China
summary: Typhoon Lekima has claimed 49 lives and left 21 missing in China's eastern coast after making landfall in Zhejiang province on Saturday. The storm caused widespread damage, with winds reaching 190 km/h and waves several meters high. Thousands of flights were cancelled, and hundreds of tourist sites were closed. The typhoon also inflicted economic losses of at least 26 billion yuan, according to authorities. Rescue efforts continued, with stranded residents being carried out by boats and rope pulleys.

site_title: Tencent-backed Kuaishou, Baidu invest US$434m in China's answer to Quora
summary: China's answer to Quora, Zhihu, has raised $434 million from investors including Kuaishou, Baidu, and existing backers Tencent Holdings and Capital Today. The funding will help expand the platform and amass more content to fend off competition from ByteDance. Baidu will add over 100 million Zhihu Q&A posts to its main app. Zhihu's CEO Zhou Yuan said the investment will help create a "huge synergies" and lay the foundation for long-term development, addressing the problem of an "isolated island of information" with rising content costs.

images.alt_text: Through the financing, Baidu will add more than 100 million of Zhihu's Q&A posts to its main mobile app, which is a combination of search engine and news feed.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte seen by public as 'selling out' to China, deputy says
summary: Philippine Vice-President Leni Robredo expressed concerns that President Rodrigo Duterte is "selling out" to China by not taking a stronger stance to protect the country's sovereignty in the disputed South China Sea. Robredo called for the President to draw a clear line between protecting the country's territory and being friendly to China. As she weighs her options for the 2022 presidential race, Robredo said she is ready for the presidency but has left her plans open, despite facing criticism and attacks from the President.

site_title: Temasek's Heliconia takes stake in homegrown gaming chair brand Secretlab
summary: Temasek-owned Heliconia Capital Management has invested S$200 to S$300 million in Secretlab, a Singapore-based gaming chair brand. This is Heliconia's first outside investment in Secretlab, which was founded in 2014 by Ian Alexander Ang and Alaric Choo. The investment aims to boost Secretlab's R&D, supply chain, and global partnerships. Secretlab has sold over 200,000 chairs in 50 countries and has won awards such as the Emerging Enterprise Awards in 2017. The investment is expected to add "turbo" to Secretlab's engines, according to CEO Ian Alexander Ang.

site_title: Hong Kong airport chaos gives big boost to rivals across mainland border
summary: Disruptions at Hong Kong's international airport, caused by protests, have boosted shares of airports on the mainland border. Shenzhen Airport rose 10% and Guangzhou Baiyun International Airport rose 5.4%, while Cathay Pacific Airways declined to its lowest level since 2009. The airport disruptions, which included protesters blocking the runway, led to a decline in Cathay Pacific's shares, further putting pressure on the airline under Chinese authorities' scrutiny.

site_title: Hotpot stock Haidilao still has room to run after jumping 78%, analysts say
summary: Haidilao International Holding, China's largest hotpot chain, has surged 78% since its Hong Kong listing in September, outperforming the Hang Sang Index. Analysts believe the stock still has room to run, with a 12-month consensus target price of HK$33 (S$5.84), 4% above the current level. The rally comes as the company continues to expand its presence in the market.

site_title: Canada sees biggest improvement in housing affordability in a decade -study
summary: Canada's housing affordability improved by the most in a decade in the second quarter, with mortgage payments decreasing 3.6% and reaching 45.1% of household income. This is the largest quarterly decrease since 2009. The benchmark mortgage rate fell 45 basis points, and median household income rose 1.7%. Affordability improved most in Vancouver, Victoria, and Toronto, but Vancouver and Toronto remain the least affordable cities in Canada.

site_title: China 10-year sovereign yield falls to 3% for first time since 2016
summary: China's 10-year sovereign bond yield fell to 3% for the first time since 2016, as escalating global trade tensions boosted demand for Chinese debt. The yield has dropped 40 basis points since April, with analysts attributing the rally to a US government bond surge and disappointing credit data. Despite this, investors remain cautious due to concerns over credit risks and the government's takeover of a lender.

site_title: India's passenger vehicles sales sink for ninth month in July
summary: India's domestic passenger vehicle sales declined for the ninth consecutive month in July, with 200,790 units sold, a 30.9% drop from the previous year. Commercial vehicles sales fell 25.7% to 56,866 units, and motorcycle and scooter sales dropped 16.8% to 1.51 million units. Passenger car sales plummeted 36% to 122,956 units. The decline is attributed to a deepening crisis in India's automobile sector, resulting in large-scale job losses.

site_title: The 'gift' of Tunisia's delicate date palm drink
summary: In southern Tunisia, a unique drink called legmi made from date palm sap is a cherished local tradition. Produced by skilled producers like Ridha Omrane Moussa, who harvests sap from palm trees without harming them, legmi is consumed primarily during Ramadan for its high sugar content. The drink is fragile and requires careful processing to preserve its quality, with a limited supply that has allowed it to maintain its organic and chemical-free status. Producers like Moussa aim to preserve the tradition for future generations.

site_title: Industry body seeks feedback on code of practice for Singapore digital asset industry
summary: The Association of Cryptocurrency Enterprises and Startups, Singapore (Access) has released a draft code of practice for the Singapore digital asset industry, aiming to standardize anti-money laundering and counter financing of terrorism, Know-Your-Customer best practices, and other key issues. The code was developed in consultation with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS). Access is seeking public feedback on the draft code, which complements the Payment Services Act and strengthens regulatory compliance for the sector.

site_title: China stimulus pressure grows as credit demand weakens
summary: China's credit growth tumbled to the second-lowest amount this year in July, with aggregate financing reaching 1.01 trillion yuan, amid weak demand and seasonal factors. The drop reflects tight credit conditions and weak loan demand, with new yuan loans to the real economy down 477.5 billion yuan from a year earlier. Pressure on policy makers to boost stimulus is growing, with economists warning of a need to loosen policy to support economic growth amid the trade war with the US.

site_title: World's longest undersea rail tunnel hits first obstacle
summary: Estonia has expressed concerns over the world's longest undersea rail tunnel project between Helsinki and Tallinn, citing a lack of clarity on financing and the business plan. Estonian Economy Minister Taavi Aas wants more details on the funding and guarantees before giving the green light. The project, estimated to cost 15 billion euros, has already faced criticism from experts, with some questioning the feasibility of the 15-year construction timeline. The Estonian government is seeking more detailed plans before approving the project, which is expected to be completed in 2024.

site_title: China's steel futures rise on production limits, iron ore extends losses
summary: China's steel futures rose 2.5% on Tuesday as some steel mills limited production due to recent price falls and expected demand softening. The most-active construction steel rebar on the Shanghai Futures Exchange rose 1.7% to 3,662 yuan per tonne. Analyst Richard Lu from CRU Group stated that some steel firms had reached breakeven levels and were limiting production. This move is attributed to the price falls and expected demand decline, indicating a response to the market's conditions.

site_title: Good news for chocolate lovers as rains boost Africa cocoa crops
summary: Heavy rains in Africa have boosted cocoa crops in top producers Ivory Coast and Ghana, supporting the development of the upcoming harvest. The rains have led to favorable conditions, with farmers optimistic about the new season. While a slight bias towards better-than-average yields is expected, a threat of drier weather in August may negatively impact crops. Despite this, the region is on track to produce a record 2.3 million tons of cocoa in Ivory Coast and 2 million tons in Ghana, with a cocoa shortfall likely in the 2019-20 season due to supply risks and strong global demand.

site_title: TPV Technology heading for privatisation by scheme of arrangement
summary: CEIEC (HK) Limited and its concert parties are proposing a scheme of arrangement to take mainboard-listed electronics company TPV Technology private. CEIEC owns 49.04% of TPV shares, aiming to acquire the remaining 50.96% by paying HK$3.86 per share, a 41.4% premium. Other concert parties, including rollover shareholders, will hold their shares after the deal is concluded. The move is aimed at taking TPV Technology private, marking the company's shift away from a public listing.

site_title: MAS rules out off-cycle policy meeting, economists mixed on stimulus
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), has ruled out an off-cycle policy meeting to address the country's downgraded economic forecast. Despite softening labour market conditions and downward pressure on the economy, MAS chief economist Edward Robinson confirmed that the central bank's monetary policy stance remains unchanged. The MAS will monitor developments and assess the inflation and growth outlook at its October monetary policy review. Economists are divided on the prospects of stimulus injections, with some expecting a rescue package for businesses and workers, while others predict a more cautious approach.

site_title: Australia: Shares dip as healthcare stocks weigh but miners cap losses
summary: Australian shares declined 0.2% to 6,576.1, as healthcare stocks weighed on the market despite gains in the mining sector. The decline followed a negative lead from the US, where stocks dropped due to tensions including the Sino-US trade war and Argentina's peso crash. The US stock market had previously reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: The billion-dollar race to become China's Amazon Twitch
summary: China's Douyu, a game-streaming platform, is competing with Huya for dominance in the market, with analysts predicting a $3 billion industry by 2023. Douyu's biggest celebrity, Liu Mou (aka PDD), has 10 million followers and generates significant revenue through virtual gifts from fans. The platform's success is built on its user base and partnerships with top streamers, but it faces challenges such as cash burn, competition, and government censorship. Douyu's founder, Chen Shaojie, aims to expand the platform's offerings and monetization strategies, while Liu Mou plans to groom new talent and diversify his income streams.

site_title: Australian court rejects responsible lending claims against Westpac
summary: An Australian Federal Court dismissed a case against Westpac Banking, rejecting claims that the lender used inappropriate standards to approve thousands of mortgages. The court found that Westpac did assess applicants' declared living expenses before approving home loans, contrary to allegations by the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC). The ASIC had alleged breaches of laws on up to 262,000 home loans, but the court ordered the regulator to pay costs after finding no evidence of wrongdoing. A $35 million settlement was previously rejected by the court.

site_title: South Korea: Shares drop on recession fears, global political woes
summary: South Korean shares declined 0.85% on Tuesday due to recession fears and global political tensions, with the yield curve flattening significantly. The KOSPI index fell 16.60 points to 1,925.69, and the won declined 0.19% against the US dollar. Investors flocked to safe-haven assets amid persisting trade worries and US yield curve inversion.

site_title: Fears of Argentina default loom large as traders dump everything
summary: Argentina's financial crisis fears intensified after President Mauricio Macri's primary election loss, with investors dumping stocks, bonds, and currency. Credit-default swaps now show a 75% chance of default in the next five years, and dollar-denominated government bonds lost 25% on average. The peso tumbled to a record-low 60 US dollars, and yields on shorter-maturity notes soared past 35%. The country has billions in foreign-currency debt due in the coming year, with investors fearing a protectionist government will renegotiate debts and agreements with the International Monetary Fund.

site_title: Hong Kong leader says violence will push city 'down path of no return', rule of law damaged
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam warned that violence during anti-government protests will push the city "down a path of no return," damaging the rule of law. She defended police actions, citing "extremely difficult circumstances" and strict guidelines on force. The city's recovery from protests is expected to take a long time, and Lam urged calm, calling on citizens to put aside differences. China has described the protests as showing "sprouts of terrorism." The situation has led to a decline in Hong Kong shares, with the Hang Seng Index falling 1.12% at the open.

site_title: Asia shares slide as Hong Kong unrest, Argentine peso crash rattle investors
summary: Asian shares declined on Tuesday as investors fled to safe-havens amid concerns over the Sino-US trade war, protests in Hong Kong, and Argentina's peso crisis. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index fell 1% and Chinese stocks dropped 0.8%, while Hong Kong's main market index plummeted 1% to a seven-month low. Safe-haven assets such as gold, bonds, and the Japanese yen rose, and US Treasury yields dropped to 1.6471%. The Argentine peso collapsed, and oil prices edged lower, further exacerbating market anxiety.

site_title: Investors bet on India social commerce startup in US$125m funding round
summary: Facebook Inc has participated in a $125 million funding round for Indian social commerce startup Meesho, led by South Africa's Naspers Ltd. Meesho, which connects people online and allows them to sell through services like Facebook and WhatsApp, has a network of over 2 million "social sellers" in 700 Indian towns. The funding round also includes Sequoia, Shunwei Capital, Venture Highway, and Arun Sarin, former CEO of Vodafone Group. Meesho aims to bring more commerce to social networks, joining a growing crop of e-commerce companies targeting social connections.

images.alt_text: Facebook Inc is participating in a US$125 million fundraising for an Indian startup that is aiming to bring more commerce to social networks like, well, Facebook.

site_title: China sets yuan midpoint at fresh 11-year low, but remains firmer than expectations
summary: China's central bank lowered its official yuan midpoint to a fresh 11-year low of 7.0326 per dollar, weakening 0.16% from the previous fix. This is the ninth consecutive day of a decrease, but the actual rate was 95 pips, or 0.14%, firmer than market expectations. The move reflects broad weakness in the local unit, but is seen as a more cautious approach than expected.

site_title: Cathay shares resume slide as flight cancellations compound woes
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways shares plummeted 5.4% on Monday, reaching a 10-year low, amid hundreds of flight cancellations following the closure of Hong Kong's airport. The airline's parent, Swire Pacific, also dropped. The stock's decline was attributed to near-term uncertainties, with Bocom International Holdings cutting its investment rating. The company has emerged as a target for China amid ongoing protests in Hong Kong, further exacerbating the challenges facing the carrier.

images.alt_text: Shares of Hong Kong flag carrier Cathay Pacific Airways, which tumbled to a 10-year low on Monday, extended their slide after the carrier cancelled hundreds of flights in the wake of the abrupt closure of Hong Kong's airport.

site_title: Oil prices edge down as traders weigh slowing demand against supply curbs
summary: Oil prices edged down 0.2% to $58.46 a barrel, as traders weighed slowing demand against supply curbs by major producers. International benchmark Brent crude futures fell 11 US cents, while US West Texas Intermediate futures declined 12 cents. Saudi Aramco's financials showed curbed capital spending, suggesting tight supply growth. Opec+ supply curbs, however, continue to limit global supply, despite booming US shale oil production. Gloomy forecasts for the global economy and trade tensions between the US and China also impacted oil prices.

site_title: Caution: Remove false teeth before surgery
summary: A 72-year-old British man, Jack, forgot to inform his surgeon about wearing dentures before undergoing a general anaesthesia procedure to remove a benign lump from his belly. Six days later, Jack turned up at the emergency room with complications, highlighting the importance of disclosing dental implants before surgery. This incident serves as a cautionary tale, emphasizing the need for patients to inform their medical teams about any dental work before undergoing surgery.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Tuesday, down 3.26 points to 1,611.79. Volume was 72.5 million lots worth RM36.4 million. Losers outpaced gainers 165 to 47.

site_title: United Food, CDW issue profit warnings
summary: Singapore-listed companies United Food Holdings and CDW Holding issued profit warnings, citing lower income from trading and animal pre-mixed segments. United Food Holdings expects a loss for its Q1, while CDW Holding is likely to report a consolidated operating loss for the first six months. The warnings are attributed to lower utilization rates and higher material costs. Details of their financial performance will be disclosed in their results announcements, scheduled for Aug 14 and a later date, respectively.

site_title: US Treasury yields tumble on trade worries, political tension
summary: US Treasury yields fell on Monday, reaching their lowest since July 2016, amid trade worries and global political tensions. The 30-year bond yields slid to 2.13%, while the yield curve flattened, suggesting rising anxiety. Protests in Hong Kong and Argentina's primary elections added to the global stress, triggering a bond rally. Analysts attributed the decline to diminished risk appetite and the impact of holidays in Asia.

site_title: Class dismissed: Surge in arrests of foreign teachers in China
summary: China has seen a surge in arrests and deportations of foreign teachers, with a significant increase in detentions for alleged crimes such as drug use, fighting, and cybersecurity violations. The crackdown is part of Beijing's push for a "cleaner" education system, with President Xi Jinping's efforts to promote patriotism and core socialist values. Lawyers say foreign teachers are vulnerable to exploitation, with some facing docking of pay, refusal to provide documentation, and changing contracts without warning. The situation is exacerbated by China's use of hair tests to detect cannabis use, which can be detected for up to 90 days.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks drop at open after protesters shut airport
summary: Hong Kong stocks dropped by 1.12% at the open on Tuesday after protesters shut the city's airport, causing over 200 flights to be cancelled. The Hang Seng Index fell to 25,536.62, with shares of Cathay Pacific Airways and Swire Properties plummeting to 10-year lows. Mainland investors bought Hong Kong-listed equities, netting a US$289 million gain, as the Hong Kong dollar weakened. The airport reopened on Tuesday morning, but the economic fallout from protests continues to affect the city's markets.

site_title: Default risks are rising in India, putting focus on stimulus
summary: India's economic outlook is deteriorating, prompting the government to consider stimulus measures. Credit market woes, fueled by a year-long shadow banking crisis, have led to a 19-month low in company credit profiles. The Reserve Bank of India has cut its interest rate for the fourth time in 2019 and lowered its economic growth forecast to 6.9%. Experts warn that further measures are needed to address the lack of demand and deteriorating debt quality, which could lead to defaults. The government is expected to announce stimulus measures this week to boost demand in key sectors.

site_title: A Goldman Sachs analyst is bullish on bitcoin. But is Goldman?
summary: Goldman Sachs technical analyst Sheba Jafari predicts bitcoin could rise 23% in the short term, reaching US$13,971, based on technical analysis. The views, presented in a 28-page packet of slides, are not considered an "official" stance by the bank. Jafari used the Elliott Wave theory to make her predictions, cautioning that investors should buy on weakness if it doesn't retrace further than the 9,084 low. The prediction comes after bitcoin dropped 11% since June 26 and is now at US$11,365.

site_title: Trump considering North Korea envoy as next ambassador to Russia: source
summary: US President Donald Trump is considering Stephen Biegun, the US special representative for North Korea, as his next ambassador to Russia. Biegun is set to step down from his current role leading US denuclearization talks with North Korea. Current US Ambassador to Moscow Jon Huntsman is expected to step down in October, sparking speculation he may run for Utah governor. A source familiar with the matter says Trump views Biegun as his likely choice for the Moscow post.

site_title: Texas power demand sets record high as heat wave bakes US South-east
summary: Texas power demand hits a record high of 74,163 megawatts on Monday as a heat wave affects the US Southeast, with temperatures expected to reach 111-113 F in Houston. The state's power grid operator, ERCOT, warned of low reserves and urged customers to conserve energy. Despite high demand, power prices remain low, trading at $70 for Monday, compared to a one-year high of $209.25 per megawatt hour. ERCOT has more than 78,000 MW of generating capacity, but a historically low planning reserve margin of 7.4% due to generator retirements.

site_title: Rex International back in the black with US$23.6m Q2 earnings
summary: Rex International Holding, a Catalist-listed oilfield services firm, reported a net profit of US$23.6 million for the second quarter, swinging into the black from a net loss of US$2.7 million a year ago. Earnings per share rose to 1.83 US cents from a loss of 0.21 US cent last year. The company did not record any service revenue for Q2 and has not declared a dividend. Its non-service revenue surged to US$29.4 million, mainly due to gains from licence sales. The company aims to achieve first oil in Oman by the end of the year.

site_title: Singapore shares open sharply lower on Tuesday; STI down 1% to 3,138.49
summary: Singapore shares plummeted 1% to 3,138.49 on Tuesday, following a long weekend break amid rising US-China trade tensions, escalating Hong Kong protests, and slashed growth forecasts. The Straits Times Index lost 0.96% to its lowest level in two weeks. The decline followed a similar downturn on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 fell 1.2% and the Nasdaq Composite declined 1.2%. The market's fall was attributed to concerns over the protracted US-China trade war and its impact on global markets.

site_title: Hong Kong's airport reopens after protests, more than 200 flights cancelled
summary: Hong Kong's airport reopened after a day of protests, with flights resuming despite the airport administrator's warning of affected flight movements. Over 200 flights were cancelled, and most protesters had left the airport. China described the protests as showing "sprouts of terrorism," which could lead to the use of anti-terror laws. The protests, which began as opposition to a suspended extradition bill, have become a broader bid for democracy and freedoms in Hong Kong, with demonstrators calling for an independent inquiry into police brutality.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower amid higher yen, falls in US shares
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 1.07% or 221.35 points at 20,463.47. The decline was attributed to a stronger yen and falls on Wall Street, where the Dow ended down 1.5%. Japanese exporters, including Nintendo, Panasonic, and Sony, led the losses, with automakers Toyota, Honda, and Nissan also down. The US dollar fetched 105.36 yen in early Asian trade, up slightly from 105.28 yen in New York.

site_title: Singapore cuts economic growth forecast to 0-1% for 2019
summary: Singapore has cut its economic growth forecast for 2019 to 0-1% due to a flat performance in the first half of the year. The country's GDP is expected to grow between zero growth and 1% for the full year, down from 3.1% in 2018. The Ministry of Trade and Industry attributed the downgrade to weak growth in the manufacturing sector, particularly in electronics and precision engineering, as well as a slowdown in global trade. The government has reassured that it will continue to monitor the situation closely and support businesses and workers.

site_title: Outrage as Trump administration weakens endangered species law
summary: The US President Donald Trump's administration finalized rollbacks to key provisions of the Endangered Species Act, a law credited with saving several species. The changes include removing automatic protections for threatened species and allowing economic impact assessments when listing species. Environmental groups and Democratic politicians, including presidential candidate Joe Biden, expressed outrage, with two states announcing plans to take legal action.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump's administration on Monday finalised rollbacks to key provisions of the Endangered Species Act, a law supported by a large majority of Americans and credited with saving the gray wolf, bald eagle and grizzly bear.

site_title: Walmart slammed for vendor's pro-gun t-shirt, adding to pressure
summary: Walmart faces renewed pressure over pro-gun t-shirts sold on its website by third-party vendors. Two shirts sparked controversy, with one suggesting buyers can be either gun owners or victims, and another featuring a crosshairs reading "Gun control is being able to hit your target". The company has stopped selling military-style weapons in the past and has increased the age to purchase firearms and ammunition to 21 years old. The t-shirts were available on Walmart's website for a short time before being removed, following criticism from social media users.

site_title: Halcyon Agri swings into the black for Q2
summary: Halcyon Agri reported a net profit of US$2.3 million for Q2, compared to a net loss of US$4.1 million a year ago, driven by increased investments in operational technology. Operating profit was US$11.1 million, a significant increase from US$2 million in the previous year. Revenue dropped 10.8% to US$512.1 million. Earnings per share were 0.14 US cents, versus a loss per share of 0.26 US cents a year ago. The company's shares closed down 4.5% at S$0.42.

site_title: Changing hands
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several key business and economic developments were reported on July 11, 2025. Companies such as Grab and SGX saw changes, with Grab downgraded to 'hold' by CGSI due to slowing earnings growth, and SGX analysts raising target prices due to volatility. OCBC CEO Helen Wong is retiring and being succeeded by Tan Teck Long, while Sats CEO Kerry Mok received a 30.5% pay hike. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Additionally, Tesla marked its formal entry into India and Citigroup set a target for the MSCI global equity index.

site_title: Stocks to watch: HRnetGroup, GS Holdings, CDW Holding, United Food Holdings
summary: Singapore stocks to watch: HRnetGroup reported a 11.5% fall in net profit to S$11.5 million for the second quarter due to lower margins from flexible staffing. GS Holdings posted a net profit of S$5.49 million for its first six months, reversing from a S$1.24 million loss last year. CDW Holding warned of a consolidated operating loss for the first six months, while United Food Holdings expects a loss for its financial first quarter.

site_title: Australian rate cut working to support demand 'as usual': central bank
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia's assistant governor Christopher Kent stated that the recent interest rate cuts are working as expected, supporting demand in the economy. The benchmark cash rate has been reduced to 1% and will be kept low for longer, leading to a decline in corporate bond yields and supporting equity prices. The Australian dollar has also depreciated to a decade low due to the rate cuts, providing additional support to demand in the period ahead.

images.alt_text: Two back-to-back interest rate cuts in Australia to all-time lows was expected to provide some additional support to the country's economy going forward, a senior central bank official said on Tuesday.

site_title: NODX forecast slashed to -9 to -8% for 2019; Q2 performance sinks by double-digits
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) contracted by 14.6% in Q2, with electronics and non-electronics contributing to the decline. This is the third straight quarter of NODX decline. The forecast for 2019 has been slashed to -9 to -8%, down from -2 to 0% previously, due to a global electronics downcycle, weak global demand, and lower oil prices. The decline in NODX was also seen in Singapore's top markets, with China, EU 28, and Japan being the biggest contributors.

site_title: Oil steadies as Saudi, Kuwait signals offset demand fears
summary: Oil prices remained steady on Monday as Saudi and Kuwait signaled their commitment to reducing global supplies, despite concerns over sluggish demand growth due to the US-China trade war. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) and its allies have agreed to cut 1.2 million barrels per day since January, and Kuwait has cut its output by more than required. Analysts expect further production cuts to support prices, which have been boosted by tensions between the US and Iran, and a weakening US dollar.

site_title: Russia pays tribute to dead nuclear workers, vows to develop new weapons
summary: Russia's top nuclear official, Alexei Likhachev, vowed to develop new nuclear weapons after paying tribute to five scientists killed in a botched test of a new missile, suspected to be the Burevestnik nuclear-powered cruise missile. The test, which occurred on a sea platform off northern Russia, resulted in a radiation spike, prompting US-based nuclear experts to suspect a mishap during the testing process. The Kremlin has not commented on the accident, while US President Donald Trump expressed concern over the incident, calling it "not good".

site_title: PSA, Dongfeng to drop 2 China auto plants: document
summary: PSA Group and Dongfeng Group have agreed to cut thousands of jobs in China and drop two of their four shared assembly plants, with the joint venture in Wuhan halving its workforce to 4,000. The move aims to curb mounting losses as the world's largest auto market loses steam. The plants, Wuhan 1 and Wuhan 2, will be closed and the workforce reduced, with the remaining workforce of 5,500 to be cut to 4,000 within three years.

site_title: India imposes Kashmir clampdown on Eid, rejects China criticism
summary: India imposed strict restrictions on Kashmir for the Eid al-Adha festival, shutting down the largest mosque and limiting gatherings, amid fears of protests. The move has sparked regional tensions, with China warning of "regional tensions" and Pakistan comparing India's tactics to those of the Nazis. The lockdown has also affected local businesses, with many residents too fearful to celebrate. A petition against the lockdown will be heard in the Supreme Court, and the Indian government maintains that the decision to strip Kashmir of autonomy is necessary for economic development and to stop terrorism.

site_title: S Korea to drop Japan from its fast-track trade 'white list'
summary: South Korea plans to drop Japan from its "white list" of countries with fast-track trade status from September, a move in response to Japan's recent export restrictions on key materials for South Korea's electronics industry. This decision will lead to tighter trade regulations, including lengthy permit application processes, affecting South Korean exports to Japan. The move deepens the diplomatic and trade rift between the two countries.

site_title: L'Oreal's bad hair day: Startup beats French giant in court
summary: A US federal jury has ordered L'Oreal to pay California startup Olaplex $91.3 million for stealing its trade secrets, breaching a contract, and infringing two patents related to a popular hair-bleaching treatment system. The jury found L'Oreal's acts were intentional, leaving room for further damages. Olaplex, a small startup with limited advertising, claims to have developed its products independently, while L'Oreal says it independently conceived the use of a critical acid. The verdict is a significant win for Olaplex, which will net around $37.4 million after damages are adjusted.

site_title: Singapore to ban sale of elephant ivory from 2021
summary: Singapore will ban the domestic sale of elephant ivory and products from September 1, 2021, as part of its campaign against illegal wildlife trade. The ban follows a consultation with non-government groups and the public, with 99% in favor of a total ban. Violators face up to one year in jail and fines. The move follows a large seizure of smuggled ivory last month, and Singapore has already banned international trade in elephant ivory products since 1990.

site_title: HRnetGroup Q2 profit falls 11.5% on lower staffing and contract margins
summary: HRnetGroup reported a 11.5% fall in Q2 net profit to S$11.5 million, mainly due to lower margins from flexible staffing and government contracts. Revenue rose 0.5% to S$108.5 million, while earnings per share decreased to 1.14 Singapore cents. The company cited trade disputes and muted hiring in Singapore as factors contributing to the decline. Despite this, Adeline Sim, executive director, expressed confidence in the company's flexible staffing business and growth opportunities across product offerings and geography.

site_title: Verizon to sell Tumblr as part of scaling back media ambitions
summary: Verizon Communications agreed to sell blogging platform Tumblr to Automattic, the latest step in the wireless giant's dismantling of its online empire. Verizon acquired Tumblr in 2017 as part of its purchase of Yahoo. The sale marks a strategic shift for Verizon, which has been cutting staff and writing down the value of its online business. The move comes as the company refocuses on its core wireless service business. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed, but Automattic, which owns WordPress and Longreads, is expected to take on approximately 200 Tumblr staff.

site_title: Businesses today must prepare for aggression by nation-states
summary: Businesses must prepare for potential nation-state aggression by participating in military exercises and national security contingency planning. Industry involvement can enhance preparedness and mitigate devastating consequences, such as supply chain disruptions and cyberattacks. Experts, including retired Major-General Mats Engman, emphasize the importance of cooperation between the private sector and armed forces. By doing so, companies can benefit from increased resilience and adaptability in the face of emerging threats.

site_title: US to deny citizenship to immigrants who use public benefits
summary: The US government announced new rules that aim to deny permanent residency and citizenship to immigrants who receive public benefits, including food stamps and Medicaid. The rules, set to take effect October 15, 2019, would apply to 22 million non-citizen residents who use public services, threatening the citizenship hopes of millions of mostly Hispanic migrants. The move is part of President Trump's broad assault on immigration, with pro-migrant activists and Democrats in Congress vowing to sue and block the rules, calling them "racially motivated" and "cruel."

site_title: Money FM podcast: Staying employable in the midst of economic slowdown
summary: A Money FM podcast discusses staying employable during an economic slowdown, featuring a hiring manager and recruitment consultant from Volt. Experts advise job seekers to focus on developing transferable skills, networking, and being adaptable. They also emphasize the importance of staying proactive in their job search and being open to new opportunities. By doing so, individuals can increase their employability and stay ahead in the job market, even during economic uncertainty.

site_title: UPS hires Pepsi executive to be CFO as Richard Peretz retires
summary: UPS names 50-year-old Pepsi executive Brian Newman as its new CFO, effective September 16, replacing Richard Peretz who is retiring in December. This move marks a departure from tradition as CEO David Abney continues to revamp the company to handle the rise of online shopping. Newman brings international experience from 26 years at PepsiCo, including a role in Latin America. The appointment is part of Abney's effort to hire outsiders for key positions as the company invests $20 billion to boost capacity and efficiency.

site_title: Yum Brands promotes COO David Gibbs to top job
summary: Yum Brands has promoted David Gibbs, its current COO, to CEO, succeeding Greg Creed, who will retire at the end of 2019. Gibbs, 55, has been with the company since 1989 and previously held roles including CFO and COO. Creed will remain on the board as a part-time adviser. Gibbs assumes the new role on January 1, 2020, and will oversee the company's global restaurant operations model, which has faced a competitive market. The company has over 48,000 Pizza Hut, Taco Bell, and KFC restaurants worldwide.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall as growth worries grip
summary: European shares fell 0.3% on Monday, extending last week's 1.7% loss, amid concerns over the US-China trade war and global economic recession. The decline was led by banks, with worsening protests in Hong Kong and a collapse in the Argentine peso adding to the downbeat mood. The pan-European STOXX 600 index closed lower, as investors sought safer assets amid escalating trade tensions and Italy's political turmoil.

images.alt_text: European shares fell on Monday, with banks leading the decline, as worries that the protracted US-China trade war could push the global economy into recession sent investors scurrying to safer assets.

site_title: Citi puts bigger bet on Singapore with family offices as ace in hand
summary: Citi Private Bank is expanding its presence in Singapore, leveraging the city-state's reputation as a secure and stable financial center to attract global family offices. With a "real lead" over other regional hubs, Singapore's clear rules and tax exemption schemes are drawing ultra-high net worth individuals to set up family offices. The number of family offices in Singapore has quadrupled since 2016, and Citi sees itself in a prime position to capture opportunities in this fast-growing segment, with a focus on customization and exclusive services.

site_title: Berlin rent freeze gives real estate stock investors cold feet
summary: Berlin's plan to freeze rents for five years has led to a significant decline in the market value of its publicly traded landlords, with a $8 billion drop in the second quarter. This is the worst performance among European countries, with Deutsche Wohnen, Berlin's largest apartment owner, seeing its shares drop by nearly a quarter. The move threatens to sully the market's reputation and has prompted investors to reconsider their investments in the city.

site_title: American Airlines wins permanent court block against alleged disruption by mechanics
summary: A US federal court issued a permanent injunction against the TWU-IAM Association, the mechanics union of American Airlines, for allegedly causing disruptions to the airline's operations during the peak summer travel season. The court order prohibits employees from interfering with American's airline operations, including refusing overtime or completing maintenance repairs. The union had denied the accusations, but American Airlines claimed hundreds of flight cancellations and maintenance delays were caused by the disruptions. The union group is prohibited from engaging in any form of disruption or interference with American's operations.

site_title: China's builders brace for winter; buy less land as home sales weaken
summary: Chinese property developers are slowing land purchases and becoming more selective due to weakening sales and a deteriorating economic outlook. Sales declined 29% in July, and land value dropped 16.6%. Developers, such as CIFI Holdings and Guangzhou R&F Properties, plan to buy less land or stop purchases altogether to replenish existing stock. Analysts expect margins to decline and some companies to lower 2019 earnings forecasts due to rising land costs and housing price caps, with nearly 300 property developers filing for bankruptcy in the first half of the year.

site_title: US: Wall St stocks tumble on trade war, weakening outlook
summary: Wall Street stocks plummeted 1.5% as US-China trade tensions and protests in Hong Kong weighed on risk assets globally. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index all declined, with Citigroup, Goldman Sachs, and Bank of America suffering significant losses. The 10-year US Treasury yield slumped, translating to a dismal session for large banks. Analysts attribute the downturn to escalating trade tensions and mounting unrest in Hong Kong, which may impact global economic growth.

site_title: Luxury brands apologise over China T-shirt blunders
summary: Luxury brands Versace, Coach, and Givenchy have apologized for selling T-shirts that listed Hong Kong and Taiwan as separate countries, a perceived affront to China's national sovereignty. The brands had attempted to minimize the damage by pulling the T-shirts and correcting their websites. However, Chinese users were not mollified, with some calling for the brands to leave China. The incident highlights the sensitivity of Hong Kong and Taiwan issues in mainland China, with protests in Hong Kong and Beijing's criticism of foreign companies perceived as backing the protests.

site_title: Made in Singapore
summary: China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Citigroup forecasts a 1,150 target for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026. Thai Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra remains optimistic about clearing his daughter's suspension from the PM role in an ethics case. ASEAN has deemed Myanmar's election a non-priority, with Malaysia in agreement. The UK economy shrank for the second consecutive month, causing a fresh blow to UK Prime Minister Starmer. South Korea's trade chief seeks a 'landing zone' in US trade talks.

site_title: Hobbs & Shaw dethrones Lion King at US box office
summary: Hobbs & Shaw dethroned The Lion King at the US box office, earning $60 million in its opening weekend. The Fast & Furious spin-off, starring Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson and Jason Statham, ended The Lion King's three-week reign. The Lion King earned $38.5 million on its third weekend, while Once Upon A Time In Hollywood took in $20 million. Other films, including Spider-Man: Far from Home and Toy Story 4, rounded out the top 10.

site_title: Swiss bank accounts aren't as great as they used to be
summary: Swiss banks UBS Group AG and Credit Suisse AG are charging wealthy customers negative interest rates, with UBS passing -0.75% and Credit Suisse charging -0.50%. This practice, which began in Europe nearly a decade ago, is seen as a monetary policy tool by central bankers despite concerns it may amount to expropriation of savers. The move reflects the unusual economic times, where lenders are passing on negative rates to their biggest account holders.

site_title: China's Tencent Music revenue misses estimates, share fall 4%
summary: China's Tencent Music Entertainment Group reported quarterly revenue that missed estimates, with its shares falling 4% due to the slowest growth in monthly average revenue per user since its debut. The company's social entertainment services, including music streaming platforms, reported a 16.5% increase, but this was the slowest growth since going public last year.

site_title: ByteDance brings Google-like search to China, but with censorship
summary: ByteDance, the creator of TikTok, has launched a search engine in China that resembles Google's clean home page but produces heavily censored results. The search engine, Toutiao Search, prioritizes content from ByteDance's own news app and excludes sponsored products and ads. The move challenges Baidu, China's dominant search engine, and comes as ByteDance faces pressure to comply with strict censorship in the country. The search engine yields sanitized results, with pro-Beijing sources and state media content dominating searches related to sensitive topics such as Hong Kong protests and the Tiananmen Square massacre.

site_title: Prison where Jeffrey Epstein died has 'serious irregularities', says Attorney-General
summary: US Attorney-General William Barr has stated that the federal jail where Jeffrey Epstein died had "serious irregularities" and vowed to pursue justice for Epstein's victims. Epstein, 66, died in an apparent suicide while in a federal jail in Lower Manhattan, despite not being on a suicide watch. Barr promised to get to the bottom of the incident and ensure accountability. The investigation into Epstein's death is ongoing, and the Bureau of Prisons has said the FBI is involved. Epstein's victims are seeking justice, with lawyers calling for his entire estate to be frozen for those filing lawsuits.

site_title: Digitalisation will leave an impact on the future of work
summary: Digitalization is set to significantly impact the future of work, with 25% of US jobs and over half of the workforce in Asia susceptible to automation. According to a report, 64% of respondents expect a decline in clerical roles, 59% in plant and machine operations staff, and 58% in laborers in various industries. While automation may create new job opportunities, it may also lead to mass unemployment if workers cannot retrain quickly enough. However, some experts believe that AI can enhance human work and life, and companies are already adopting flexible work arrangements to support their employees.

site_title: AI-powered maths practice platform makes learning fun
summary: Practicle, a Singapore-based AI-powered maths practice platform, has launched to make learning math fun for primary school students. Founded by former teachers Eileen Choo and Chongming Ng, the platform uses an adaptive engine to tailor questions to individual learning styles. Students can earn "Thinky Points" by completing questions and can redeem them for rewards such as phone time and game time. The platform aims to gamify math learning and provide deeper insights into student performance, while empowering and complementing teachers.

site_title: Power-hungry phone companies dial into surging green bonds
summary: Phone companies are increasingly using green bonds to fund environmentally friendly projects, such as replacing copper wires with fibre-optic cables and building 5G networks. Since January, at least $3 billion has been issued, with estimates suggesting this year's total could exceed $370 billion. To access a wider pool of investors, green bonds offer similar interest rates to conventional securities. However, investors must carefully consider the environmental impact of these bonds, as diverting proceeds to non-green purposes can be a risk. Despite initial concerns, 5G technology is expected to offer significant energy savings, outweighing its emissions.

site_title: Cathay Pacific, icon of Hong Kong's rise, now reflects China's grip
summary: Cathay Pacific, Hong Kong's iconic international airline, is facing pressure from the Chinese government, which has forced the company to bar employees who support or participate in the territory's anti-government protests from working on flights to mainland China. The airline has also been ordered to submit information about crew members flying to or above the mainland for prior approval. The move represents an escalation of China's influence over Hong Kong's business affairs and has raised concerns about the economic impact on the territory's economy, which is already struggling due to the trade war and protests.

site_title: Carmakers warm up to friendly hackers at cybersecurity conference
summary: Carmakers are partnering with white hat hackers to improve the security of their vehicles. The DEF CON convention in Las Vegas brought together carmakers and hackers to identify vulnerabilities in car systems. Attendees were able to hack into a 2012 Ford Focus, controlling its speed, radio volume, and doors. The collaboration aims to redefine the term "hacker" from a criminal to a security expert, helping carmakers make their systems more secure. The partnership is expected to grow, with Volkswagen AG, Fiat Chrysler, and suppliers sponsoring the event.

site_title: Germany can fulfil its tasks without new debt: minister
summary: German Finance Minister Olaf Scholz stated that the country can implement ambitious climate protection measures and other big policy steps without incurring new debt. This contradicts previous comments suggesting the need for new debt to finance a costly climate package. Scholz's comments aim to reassure the public and maintain the government's goal of a balanced budget.

site_title: Trump's Asia-led strategy is not driving 'US endgame' in Afghanistan
summary: US President Donald Trump's "Asia-led strategy" for Afghanistan, announced in 2017, is not driving the country's "endgame" in the conflict. The strategy, which emphasized Pakistan's role, was actually a attempt to cut a deal with the Taliban ahead of Trump's re-election bid. The current peace talks, set to conclude on September 1, aim for a withdrawal of foreign forces in exchange for security guarantees, but the country faces significant challenges, including continued violence, economic instability, and corruption. The US-led NATO mission has around 20,000 troops, but experts question its size and effectiveness in securing the country.

site_title: Championing a global education movement
summary: David Chiem, founder of MindChamps, a global preschool pedagogy empire, is now focusing on bringing his sustainable, scalable model of early childhood education back to Australia. With over 80 preschool and enrichment centers globally, including a growing presence in Australia, Abu Dhabi, Dubai, and Southeast Asia, MindChamps has seen a 33% jump in net profit to S$6.5 million in 2018. Chiem aims to launch "MindChamps Version Two" and expand to Australia, the US, and UK, with a 90-10 balance between franchising and ownership. The company emphasizes teacher training and is eyeing targets in these markets, with a focus on retaining control and growing a global education movement.

site_title: Yen hits 1-1/2 year highs as rush for safety escalates
summary: The Japanese yen reached its highest level in over 1.5 years against the dollar, rising 0.5% to 105.15 yen, amid growing concerns of a prolonged China-US trade conflict. Investors are shifting their bets towards safe-haven currencies, driving up demand for the yen and Swiss franc. The yen's value is also influenced by expectations that the US dollar may weaken, and the yen's performance is seen as a signal of the shift in sentiment.

site_title: No-deal Brexit could deepen Europe's shortage of medicines
summary: A no-deal Brexit on October 31 could worsen Europe's shortage of medicines, with 45 million packs of medicines shipped from Britain to the EU every month. Increased customs controls and border disruptions could disrupt supplies of essential medicines, including cancer treatments and flu medication. The European Medicines Agency has finalized authorisations for nearly all 400 drugs under its watch, but some medicines may not have required regulatory approval by the deadline, and nearly 6,000 nationally authorised medicines need a new licensing process.

site_title: Hong Kong airport grinds to a halt as anti-government protests swell
summary: Hong Kong's airport cancelled all flights on August 12, 2019, due to disruptions caused by anti-government protesters occupying the arrivals hall. The protests, which began over a extradition bill, have escalated into violence, with police firing tear gas and bean-bag rounds at protesters. Chinese officials have warned of "terrorism" emerging, and China's People's Armed Police assembled in Shenzhen for exercises. The protests have plunged Hong Kong into its most serious crisis in decades, with over 600 arrests since the unrest began two months ago.

site_title: Bees swarm Berlin, where beekeeping booms
summary: In Berlin, a surge in urban beekeeping has led to a boom in bee swarms, with the city having over 20 hives per square mile. This has resulted in a shortage of registered beekeepers, with many newcomers mistakenly believing beekeeping is an easy hobby. As a result, bee swarms are being collected by volunteer swarm catchers, who wear protective suits to contain the bees. Experts warn that focusing on honeybees may be misleading, as their decline could have broader impacts on biodiversity, and suggest that cities prioritize preserving wild spaces and reducing pesticide use to protect insect populations.

site_title: Indochina states drive Asean investor appeal
summary: The Indochina quartet of Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, and Vietnam are forecast to remain the fastest-growing sub-region within Asean until 2022, driven by high economic growth rates of 6.8-7.5% and a combined GDP of over 12% of Asean's GDP. Foreign investors are drawn to their advantageous geographical locations and relatively stable governments, with Japanese multinational companies increasing business operations in Myanmar by 1,000% in six years. However, the CLMV countries need to catch up with more prosperous partner states by creating a more conducive business environment, building strong small and medium enterprises, and nurturing local industries to sustain growth and domestic consumption.

images.alt_text: The largest of the sub-group's four economies, Vietnam is expected to cross the US$300 billion GDP mark by 2022, based on robust growth of 6.2 per cent annually between 2016 and 2022.

site_title: Death toll rises to 44 as typhoon Lekima wreaks havoc in eastern China
summary: Typhoon Lekima made landfall in eastern China, causing widespread damage and 44 reported deaths, with 12 more fatalities and 16 missing. The storm has disrupted travel and economic activity, with estimated losses of 18 billion yuan (S$3.53 billion) and 364,000 hectares of crops damaged. The typhoon is expected to weaken as it heads northwest off the coast of Shandong.

images.alt_text: The death toll from typhoon Lekima in eastern China rose to 44 people on Monday morning, according to official data, as the storm continued up the coast, racking up billions of dollars in economic losses and widely disrupting travel.

site_title: Residents are targets for dirty money fronts in business friendly Singapore
summary: Singapore's business-friendly environment has made it vulnerable to money laundering and terrorism financing threats, with thousands of corporate services firms offering Singapore residents as directors for shell companies at low costs. These companies can be used to funnel illicit funds, with Singapore residents often being prosecuted for their roles. Regulators, including the Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Commercial Affairs Department, have set up partnerships with banks to improve detection of illicit activities and have prosecuted several cases of money laundering and terrorism financing. The use of Singapore shell companies for nefarious activities has been linked to the Panama Papers incident in 2016.

site_title: Battle over Epstein's mysterious estate
summary: Jeffrey Epstein's estate, valued at at least $500 million, is being contested by his accusers and relatives, who are vying for control of his assets. Lawyers for victims of his alleged sex crimes are seeking a freeze on the estate, while Epstein's known relatives, including his brother and niece, may also stake a claim. The estate's administrator and potential executors will need to navigate the probate process, which could drag on for years, to determine the distribution of Epstein's wealth, including his Manhattan mansion and Caribbean island.

site_title: Golf: Patrick Reed ends title drought at Northern Trust
summary: Patrick Reed won the US PGA Tour's Northern Trust tournament with a two-under 69, ending his title drought since the 2018 Masters. Reed's seventh career title put him at 16-under 268, one stroke ahead of Abraham Ancer. Despite a late surge, Spain's Jon Rahm faded after a strong front nine, finishing third. The victory moves Reed into prime position to challenge for the US$15 million playoff purse at the season-ending Tour Championship.

images.alt_text: Patrick Reed fired a two-under 69 on Sunday to win the US PGA Tour's Northern Trust tournament, his first victory since his 2018 Masters triumph.

site_title: Australia to step up rare earths output amid fears over China supplies
summary: Australia plans to increase production of rare earths and other "tech metals" amid concerns over China's reliability as a supplier. Defence Minister Linda Reynolds said the country has significant reserves of these metals, crucial for electronics, lasers, and military equipment. China produces over 95% of the world's rare earths, and the US relies on it for 80% of its imports. Australia aims to secure a guarantee of supply, and a recent deal between Thyssenkrupp and a mining company in northern Australia is seen as a step towards this goal.

site_title: No injection of PGIM malls for now: Frasers Property
summary: Frasers Property and Frasers Centrepoint Trust have acquired nearly three-quarters of PGIM Real Estate Asia Retail Fund, but remain tight-lipped on plans to inject five suburban malls into Frasers Centrepoint Trust. A spokesperson for Frasers Property stated that the group has no immediate plans to access the suburban mall assets. This move may not meet analysts' expectations for a quick injection of the malls, potentially benefiting the trust's defensive stance amid market volatility.

site_title: Can Komodo dragons survive tourist invasion?
summary: The Komodo National Park in Indonesia is facing a surge in tourist arrivals, threatening the survival of the Komodo dragons and the park's pristine beauty. The influx of visitors has led to issues such as trash, human encroachment, and occasional lizard smuggling. Provincial leaders plan to close the island of Komodo in January 2020 to give the dragons their habitat, but the Indonesian national government may thwart this plan. The national government aims to create 10 new tourist destinations, including Labuan Bajo, to diversify tourism and mitigate over-tourism issues.

site_title: China's small farmers struggle to stop destructive march of the armyworm
summary: China's fall armyworm, a destructive pest, has spread over 3,000km north since migrating from Myanmar, affecting 21 provinces and posing a threat to grain output. The pest has devastated sugarcane, corn, and other crops in Yunnan province, where 86,000 hectares were affected by mid-June. Small farmers lack knowledge and resources to tackle the pest, and the government has allocated millions of yuan to affected regions and sent experts to educate farmers. Despite efforts, the problem persists, with farmers reporting high costs and difficulty in eradicating the pest.

site_title: Saudis to buy Reliance oil refining stake for US$15b
summary: Saudi Aramco will acquire a 20% stake in Reliance Industries' oil-to-chemicals division, including the 1.24 million barrels-a-day Jamnagar refining complex, for $15 billion. Reliance Industries values the division at $75 billion, including debt. The deal marks Saudi Aramco's entry into the Indian oil refining market, with the acquisition set to be completed by the end of 2019.

site_title: 'They're being used': Hong Kong protests divide neighbourhood
summary: In Hong Kong, pro-democracy protests have divided some neighborhoods, including Wong Tai Sin, where police officers live. Residents, including police officers' families, have been caught in the crossfire, with tear gas and bricks being hurled at their homes. Some, like Poppy Chan, have fled their apartments, while others, like Joe, a middle school teacher, want the government to crack down harder on protesters. The protests, which began over a bill allowing extradition to mainland China, have drawn a broad support base, but some residents are ambivalent about protesters accused of brutality.

site_title: Grooming a strong management team vital for int'l expansion
summary: Singapore businesses expanding internationally often leverage the country's reputation for rigor in education, but a strong management team is crucial for success. Many small-to-medium enterprises are entering new markets, with destinations like Malaysia, Indonesia, and China offering advantages. A top-tier management team can navigate unfamiliar market environments, demonstrate resilience, and drive market development efforts. Grooming a strong team early on, particularly for businesses planning expansion across multiple geographies, is essential for a successful engagement overseas. This investment can pay off, even for young businesses, and is a key factor in international expansion.

site_title: China's PBOC says own cryptocurrency 'close' to release
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), is "close" to issuing its own cryptocurrency, according to a senior official. The digital currency is intended to replace cash in circulation and support the yuan's circulation and internationalization. The PBOC aims to give Beijing more control over its financial system, unlike decentralized blockchain-based offerings. The move comes as a response to Facebook's Libra cryptocurrency, which has raised concerns among global central banks about foreign exchange risks and monetary policy. The PBOC will expedite its research on a digital tender and monitor virtual currency development.

site_title: China's Ivy League dreams fuel lucrative admissions industry
summary: China's lucrative admissions industry has been booming, with wealthy parents paying tens of thousands of dollars for "shortcuts" to secure places at foreign universities. Admissions middlemen advise families on ways to circumvent the traditional application process, including hiring ghostwriters, forging sports credentials, and "gift-giving" to admissions agents. The industry is expected to grow to $35 billion by 2021, driven by rising incomes and a desire for world-class education. Many Chinese students are taking a risk by skipping the country's notoriously difficult college entrance test to prepare for foreign university exams, with some parents willing to spend hundreds of thousands of dollars to secure a spot.

site_title: NZ's Fonterra to report loss of up to NZ$675m, stop dividend
summary: New Zealand's Fonterra, the world's biggest dairy exporter, reported an annual loss of up to NZ$675 million, its second consecutive loss and largest in history, due to write-downs of NZ$820-860 million on over-valued assets. The company will not pay a dividend this year to reduce debt, which stands at NZ$7.4 billion. Fonterra aims to cut debt by NZ$800 million by year-end, and analysts predict a potential reinstatement of dividends in 12-18 months.

site_title: Chinese firms learn to adapt as US trade war rages
summary: Chinese export-reliant companies are adapting to the US trade war by slashing prices, moving production abroad, creating new domestic markets, and rebranding goods. Factories along the eastern coast, fish processors, and farmers have changed their business models since US President Trump launched the conflict, with some experiencing significant declines in exports, such as 93% for Chinese apple juice. However, some Chinese sectors, like soybean farmers, have benefited from retaliatory tariffs.

site_title: The Sino-American decoupling will translate into human costs
