summary: The United Nations has signed the UN Convention on International Settlement Agreements Resulting from Mediation, a treaty aimed at enforcing mediated settlement agreements across countries. The US and China were among the first signatories. Meanwhile, Citigroup has set a target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026, and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) has agreed that Myanmar's election is not a priority. The UK economy has shrunk for the second month in a row, and the IMF says new US tariffs keep trade uncertainty high.

site_title: Europe's interrail passes hit the buffers in Britain
summary: European Interrail passes will no longer be valid in Britain starting January 2020, affecting EU citizens. The Eurail group and British Rail Delivery Group blame each other for the decision, with neither party linking it to Britain's Brexit departure. Passes bought in 2019 remain valid, and undersea Eurostar trains will not be affected. Interrail passes, costing between 20-400 euros, allow travel across 31 countries, including Britain, until the change. The decision ends Eurail's 35-year membership in the Interrail program.

site_title: Allied Tech says it expects net loss for Q2, first-half of year
summary: Allied Tech, a precision metal stamping manufacturer, expects to report a net loss for the second quarter and first half of the year due to declining gross profit margins amid an uncertain global economic outlook. The company will announce its financial results on or before August 14.

site_title: Trump says talks with South Korea under way over defence costs
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that talks have begun with South Korea to increase payments for the US troops stationed in the region, amid North Korea threats. The discussions aim to get South Korea to pay more for the cost of maintaining US troops. This comes ahead of US Secretary of Defence Mark Esper's visit to Seoul, with joint military exercises planned. Trump's comments follow an agreement signed in February, which increased Seoul's contribution to US$927 million, but the interim agreement was set to expire in a year.

site_title: Nations agree landmark UN climate report after marathon talks
summary: Negotiators from 195 countries agreed on the UN's landmark climate report, a 1,000-page document assessing the impact of land use on climate change. The report highlights the stark choices facing a warming planet with a growing population, emphasizing the need for enormous land areas to achieve emissions reductions. Bioenergy, a key topic of debate, was seen as a potential solution but raised concerns about land availability. The final report is expected to reveal food inequality on a global scale and will be made public on Thursday.

site_title: F&N Q3 net profit rises 9% on higher dairy, soft drink sales
summary: Frasers & Neave (F&N) reported a 9% increase in Q3 net profit to S$54.8 million, driven by higher sales of soft drinks and dairy products. Revenue rose 6.7% to S$489.7 million, with the food and beverage division seeing a 7% increase. The company expects consumer sentiment in the F&B segment to remain challenging due to competition and volatility in foreign currency movements.

site_title: COE premiums rise across the board, Cat A price jumps $6,000
summary: COE premiums rose across the board in Singapore's latest tender, with the COE price for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp closing at $32,725, up from $26,667. The commercial vehicle COE price finished at $27,800, up from $24,599. The motorcycle premium rose to $4,400, a 10-month high, due to a smaller quota and longer bidding period. The smaller supply and reduced quotas are expected to tame demand, with industry experts warning of a weakening underlying demand.

site_title: Vicom Q2 net profit up 4.9% to S$6.6m on higher vehicle-testing volumes
summary: Vicom, a vehicle-inspection group owned by ComfortDelGro, reported a 4.9% increase in second-quarter net profit to S$6.6 million, driven by higher vehicle-testing volumes. Revenue rose 3.7% to S$25.6 million. For the half-year, net profit grew 4.9% to S$13.9 million and earnings per share increased to 15.68 Singapore cents. The company expects its vehicle-inspection business to remain strong due to new emission test requirements.

site_title: Chinese government hackers suspected of moonlighting for profit
summary: Chinese government-backed hackers, known as Advanced Persistent Threat 41 (APT41), have been found to engage in both state-sponsored espionage and financially-motivated side operations. According to US firm FireEye, APT41 targeted global tech, communications, and healthcare providers for the Chinese government while using ransomware against game companies and cryptocurrency providers for personal profit. This dual role poses a significant threat to consumers and companies, blurring the lines between state-backed espionage and cybercrime. The findings were announced at the Black Hat security conference in Las Vegas.

site_title: NZ shares soar on hefty rate cut, Australian market snaps 5-day slump
summary: New Zealand's central bank cut interest rates by 50 basis points, sparking a 1.9% gain in the S&P/NZX 50 index. The move followed a global sell-off after a trade escalation between the US and China, but was supported by US President Trump's comments downplaying the trade dispute. In Australia, the S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.6%, with safe-haven gold stocks reaching a record high. Rare earths miners also gained, while major mining stocks fell.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei closes lower
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index fell 0.33% to 20,516.56, extending its losing streak to four days, amid concerns over US-China trade ties. The benchmark index closed lower despite a 0.05% gain in the broader Topix index. The market's volatility continued despite recent positive sentiment, with stocks in other regions, such as Singapore and the US, also experiencing fluctuations.

site_title: OUE Commercial Reit posts 34.5% rise in Q2 DPU to 0.78 S cent
summary: OUE Commercial Reit reported a 34.5% increase in Q2 DPU to 0.78 Singapore cents, up from 0.58 cents in the same period last year. Total income available for distribution rose 36.6% to S$22.5 million, driven by the inclusion of OUE Downtown Office. Committed portfolio occupancy was 94.5% as of June 30. Distributions for the first half of 2019 will be 1.68 Singapore cents, 22.9% lower than last year's first-half DPU.

site_title: Global easing gather pace as New Zealand stuns with big rate cut, sending kiwi diving
summary: New Zealand's Reserve Bank cut its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point to a record low of 1%, surprising markets and sending the kiwi currency plummeting 2% to US$0.6397. The move aims to combat slowing economic growth and prevent inflation from returning to the central bank's goal. Governor Adrian Orr signaled further easing is possible, including non-conventional policy measures such as negative interest rates, and hinted at the need to "get ahead of the curve" in a worsening global economic outlook.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks extend losses on lingering trade worries
summary: South Korean shares extended losses for a sixth consecutive session on August 7, 2019, amid lingering US-China trade war concerns. Despite China's efforts to stabilize the yuan, investors remain cautious, and foreign buyers sold 97.7 billion won worth of shares. The Kospi index fell 0.41% to 1,909.70, while the won barely moved against the US dollar. Policymakers stand ready to intervene if needed, and analysts expect a rangebound market until favorable signs from US-China trade talks are seen.

site_title: UK's opposition Labour Party open to a Scottish independence referendum
summary: The UK's opposition Labour Party is open to allowing Scotland to hold another independence referendum if the Scottish parliament votes for one, said Labour's John McDonnell. A recent poll shows Scottish voters want another referendum in the next two years, potentially leading to the UK's break-up shortly after leaving the EU.

images.alt_text: Labour's John McDonnell told an event at the Edinburgh festival fringe that his party should not try to block a second vote on independence, the Guardian reported.

site_title: India's central bank cuts rates by 35 bps, more than expected
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) cut interest rates by 35 basis points, exceeding expectations, to boost a sluggish economy growing at its slowest pace in nearly five years. The repo rate was cut to 5.40% and the reverse repo rate to 5.15%. The move, the fourth in 2019, maintains an "accommodative" stance but depends on inflation levels. Analysts had predicted a 5.50% repo rate cut, but four MPC members voted for the 35 basis point cut.

site_title: CAO's profit falls 2.9% for Q2 on larger allowance for doubtful debts
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) reported a 2.9% drop in net profit to US$28.4 million for its Q2, primarily due to higher operating expenses from a larger allowance for doubtful debts. Revenue grew 2.85% to US$5.97 billion, while total expenses surged 36% to US$8 million. CAO's middle distillates business saw growth, driven by an increase in jet fuel supply and trading volumes. No interim dividend was declared for Q2.

site_title: Singapore Medical Group Q2 net profit up 3.5% to S$3.5m
summary: Singapore Medical Group reported a 3.5% increase in Q2 net profit to S$3.5 million, with earnings per share remaining unchanged at 0.73 Singapore cents. Revenue rose 6.8% to S$23 million. The company's net asset value per share was 28.68 Singapore cents as of June 30. The counter closed flat at S$0.37 before the results were announced.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 7.09 points to 1,604.70. The market saw 2.6 billion lots traded worth RM2.6 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 499 to 313.

site_title: Koufu Q2 net profit up 16.2% to S$7.2m on F&B revenue growth
summary: Koufu Group reported a 16.2% increase in Q2 net profit to S$7.2m, driven by revenue growth from its food courts and coffee shops. The company has proposed an interim dividend of one Singapore cent and plans to expand its network of 65 outlets across both segments. Overseas markets, including Macau and Indonesia, also contributed to revenue growth. Second-quarter revenue rose 7.3% to S$58m, with the outlet and mall management segment growing in line with the reopening of the Marina Bay Sands food court.

site_title: Singapore Airlines, Tata Sons JV Vistara to boost fleet to 41 by year end
summary: Vistara, a joint venture between Tata Sons and Singapore Airlines, plans to expand its fleet to 41 aircraft by the end of 2019, up from 30 currently. The airline aims to benefit from the collapse of rival Jet Airways and has announced plans to add routes from India to Bangkok and Dubai. This expansion is part of its international expansion plan, driven by the collapse of Jet Airways in April.

site_title: Spirits distributor Proof & Company raises S$11m to expand in Asia-Pacific
summary: Proof & Company, a Singapore-based spirits distributor and consultancy, has raised S$11 million to expand its operations in the Asia-Pacific region. The growth-capital round was led by Aglaia Family Office, with existing investors also participating. The funding will support the growth of its spirits distribution platform, innovation initiatives, and increasing inventory levels. The company expects to exceed its annual revenue milestone of S$50 million and foresees sustained annual growth of over 50 per cent.

site_title: Toyota turns to AI startup to accelerate goal of robots for the home
summary: Toyota Motor Corp has partnered with Japanese startup Preferred Networks to develop service robots for homes, particularly in Japan, where it aims to support the country's aging population. The two companies will collaborate on the project for three years, sharing intellectual property and using Toyota's Human Support Robot (HSR) as a platform for Preferred Networks' advanced artificial intelligence software. The robots will be capable of learning in typical living environments and will be used in hospitals and at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics.

site_title: Haw Par Q2 earnings up 10.2% on higher operating profit, dividend income
summary: Haw Par Corp reported a 10.2% increase in second-quarter net profit to S$90.5 million, driven by higher operating profit and dividend income. Revenue rose 9.3% to S$70.1 million, with gross profit gaining 4.2% to S$40.9 million. The company announced a 15 Singapore cents per share interim dividend for 2019. Half-year net profit rose 11% to S$112.5 million, with earnings per share increasing to 50.9 Singapore cents.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,170.88, up 0.01% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading at 3,170.88, up 0.01% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index inching up 0.01% or 0.41 point. Gainers outnumbered losers 164 to 158, driven by ComfortDelGro's expansion into the heavy vehicle leasing business. Asian stocks traded mixed, while US futures fell 0.6% ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge higher on materials, industrials
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.1% to 25,997.03, snapping a five-session losing streak, driven by gains in materials and industrial stocks. China Molybdenum surged 19.6% after Glencore Plc announced it would halt production at the Mutanda mine. Despite trade tensions and slowing growth concerns, the Hang Seng index rebounded.

site_title: Thai central bank unexpectedly cuts key rate, worried by baht strength
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, unexpectedly cut its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 1.50% for the first time since 2015. The decision aims to support faltering growth and weaken the strong baht, which has appreciated about 6% against the dollar this year. The move was seen as a surprise by economists, with 14 out of 15 predicting no change to policy. The decision reflects the bank's concerns about the baht's strength and its impact on the economy.

site_title: GoJek, on tackling the Singapore market
summary: GoJek, a ride-hailing startup, has expanded into the Singapore market, dubbed "Project Simba". The company has leveraged differences between Singapore and its Southeast Asian counterparts to its advantage, testing features in Singapore that may be deployed in Indonesia. Despite initial challenges, such as users searching by postal codes and providing honest feedback, GoJek has improved its product to better suit Singaporean users. The company aims to maintain a balance between its "GoJek DNA" and "local DNA" in each market, with plans to expand into Malaysia and offer food delivery services in Singapore.

site_title: SGX to set up whistleblowing office as it enlists market players to tighten oversight
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) plans to introduce a whistleblowing office and stricter inspections of market professionals, starting with Catalist sponsors. SGX RegCo CEO Tan Boon Gin emphasized the importance of market professionals in maintaining market integrity, encouraging them to "think like a neighbourhood watch" to address non-compliance. This approach aims to target non-compliant companies without burdening compliant ones with overly inclusive rules. The goal is to create a community-driven approach to regulation, leveraging peer pressure, scrutiny, and advocacy to address issues like conflicts of interest.

site_title: Hong Kong protests take a toll as companies flag impact
summary: Hong Kong protests have taken a toll on businesses, with Cathay Pacific Airways and the Peninsula hotel owner citing reduced passenger traffic and disrupted bookings due to violent clashes between protesters and police. The protests, which began in June over a suspended extradition bill, have now escalated into demands for greater democracy and the resignation of Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam. Retail sales have fallen 6.7% from a year earlier, and tourism to Hong Kong has dropped, weighing on hotel occupancy rates and prompting travel alerts from several countries.

site_title: Prudential raises CPF contribution rate for staff above 55 to on par with those younger
summary: Prudential Singapore has raised its Central Provident Fund (CPF) contribution rate for staff above 55 to 17% to match that of younger employees, with the option to increase individual contribution to 20%. This move aims to help older workers save more for their extended retirement years. The change applies to 4% of Prudential's 1,200 employees, aged 61 and above, and could save them up to $12,300 per year.

site_title: Indonesia central bank's new deputy chief sees prolonged monetary easing
summary: Bank Indonesia's new senior deputy governor, Destry Damayanti, forecasts a prolonged period of monetary policy easing due to the global economic slowdown, low inflation rate, and other central banks' loosening stance. The central bank has already cut its benchmark policy rate by 25 basis points, and Damayanti plans to continue setting accommodative monetary and macroprudential policies to support loan growth. This easing cycle is expected to last into the future, with the goal of supporting economic growth in Indonesia.

site_title: China builders weaken debt safeguards as buyers chase yield
summary: Chinese property developers are weakening debt safeguards as investors chase yield, with the average covenant quality score for property firms falling to its weakest level since 2011. The trend is driven by a 10% return on Asian junk bonds, with Chinese real-estate firms accounting for a majority. This may store up risks on developer notes, which could materialize due to yuan volatility and curbs on financing, leading to an uptick in defaults. The move is a concern for policymakers, who may need to take action to counter the slowdown in China's GDP growth.

site_title: MAS launches Sandbox Express for faster market testing of innovative financial services
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) launched Sandbox Express, a faster market testing option for innovative financial services, allowing firms to test products and services in a pre-defined environment within 21 calendar days. This is a shorter approval process compared to the existing fintech regulatory sandbox, which typically requires at least three months. Sandbox Express is suitable for low-risk activities with well-understood market parameters, and it will initially be available for insurance brokers, market operators, and remittance businesses. The scheme aims to encourage innovation and experimentation in the financial sector.

site_title: China suspends movies, stars from Taiwan's Golden Horse Awards
summary: China has suspended mainland Chinese movies and their personnel from participating in Taiwan's Golden Horse Awards this year, citing the event's potential to spark debate on Taiwanese independence. The move comes amid heightened tensions between Beijing and Taipei, including China's recent halt on issuing travel permits for Taiwanese visitors. The Golden Horse Film Festival has stated that related events will proceed as scheduled, while Chinese netizens have expressed disappointment and frustration with the decision.

site_title: StanChart's Singapore-based private equity spinoff plans Middle East investment
summary: Affirma Capital, the private equity spinoff of Standard Chartered Plc, plans to complete at least one acquisition in the Middle East and Africa over the next year, targeting deals between $25 million and $100 million. The Singapore-based emerging markets group has $700 million to spend and is particularly interested in Egypt, Nigeria, and Jordan. Affirma aims to achieve an internal rate of return of 25% and is seeking to prove itself to limited partners in the emerging markets after the Abraaj scandal. The company plans to exit one of its investments in the region within the next 12 months.

site_title: SoftBank Group Q1 profit blows past estimates on Vision Fund gains
summary: SoftBank Group Corp reported a better-than-expected Q1 operating profit of 688.8 billion yen, up 3.7% from last year, driven by a 66% surge in operating profit at the US$100 billion Vision Fund. The fund's investments are now worth US$82.2 billion, up from US$66.3 billion. SoftBank's CEO, Masayoshi Son, will discuss the results at a news conference. The company plans to launch a second Vision Fund with US$108 billion in pledges, relying on proceeds from the first fund to bankroll the contribution.

site_title: MindChamps Q2 profit slides 74% on higher costs from acquisitions
summary: MindChamps PreSchool's Q2 net profit dropped 74% to S$323,000, mainly due to higher costs from acquisitions of preschool centres in 2018 and 2019. Revenue jumped 64% year-over-year to S$12.5 million, driven by increased school fees. The company's company-owned centres grew to 27 globally, with operating administrative expenses surging 43% to S$5.6 million. No dividend was declared for the quarter, as the company plans to reinvest profits.

site_title: Tens of thousands losing jobs as India's car crisis deepens: sources
summary: India's car sector is experiencing a severe downturn, with tens of thousands of jobs lost since April due to slumping sales. Carmakers, parts manufacturers, and dealers have laid off around 350,000 workers, with the industry facing its worst downturn in years. The crisis is posing a challenge for Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government, with car executives planning to demand tax cuts and easier financing at a meeting with the finance ministry. The sector employs over 35 million people and contributes 7% to India's GDP.

site_title: Australia dollar drops to lowest since 2009 after New Zealand's aggressive rate cut
summary: Australia's dollar dropped to its lowest in a decade, reaching 66.77 US cents, after New Zealand's surprise 50-basis point interest-rate cut. The move is seen as a pre-emptive measure to address slowing global growth and trade tensions. Traders now expect a 25-basis point cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia at its September meeting, with some speculating a cycle of competitive devaluation. Economists warn that markets may be getting ahead of themselves, and the RBA may rely on economic data to drive its next move.

site_title: GIC affiliate to invest 44b rupees in India's IRB Infra road assets
summary: IRB Infrastructure Developers Ltd announced a deal with GIC sovereign wealth fund's affiliate to invest 44 billion rupees (S$858.4 million) in its road and highway assets. IRB will hold a 51% stake and maintain management control through a private infrastructure investment trust. The trust will also explore other road sector opportunities in India, according to CEO Virendra Mhaiskar.

site_title: 46 countries sign international mediation treaty named after Singapore
summary: Forty-six countries signed the Singapore Convention on Mediation, an international treaty aimed at enforcing mediated settlement agreements across borders. The US and China were among the first signatories, with Asian economic heavyweights India and South Korea also participating. The treaty will come into effect once three countries ratify it, and signatory countries must ensure that international commercial settlement agreements are enforced by their courts. The signing ceremony was attended by ministers and senior officials from 70 countries, with Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasizing the treaty's potential to advance international trade and commerce.

site_title: South Korean imports of Japanese beer nearly halve as consumer backlash grows
summary: South Korean imports of Japanese beer plummeted 45% in July, down to $4.3 million, amid a consumer boycott sparked by a dispute over wartime forced labor. The boycott has led to a wider removal of Japanese products and services, including cars and travel. Japanese automakers Toyota and Honda are bracing for further sales drops, while South Korean airlines are suspending flights to Japan. The dispute has resulted in a significant decline in Japan's beer exports to South Korea, with the country buying only 61% of Japan's beer exports.

site_title: China state banks seen supporting yuan in forwards market: sources
summary: China's state banks have been actively supporting the yuan in the onshore forwards market, using swaps to reduce dollar supply and tighten yuan value. This comes as tensions between China and the US escalated, prompting fears of a currency war. Banks conducted significant buy-sell swaps on Tuesday to reduce dollar access and help the yuan. The move is seen as an attempt to stabilize the yuan and mitigate the impact of the US-China trade war on the Chinese currency.

site_title: Facebook sues Singapore developer over malware on Android apps
summary: Facebook sued two Singapore-based developers, JediMobi Tech Ltd and LionMobi Holding Ltd, for allegedly installing malware on Android apps to inflate ad revenue. The malware generated over 40 million ad impressions and 1.7 million clicks through Facebook's Audience Network. The company discovered the issue in December and disabled the apps and banned the developers. Facebook is seeking damages and restitution, following its own struggles with data exploitation and harmful content.

site_title: China warns India of 'reverse sanctions' if Huawei is blocked: sources
summary: China has warned India not to block Huawei from participating in the country's 5G trials, threatening "reverse sanctions" on Indian firms operating in China if they do so. China hopes India will make an independent decision on Huawei's participation, citing the company's contributions to Indian society and economy. The US has put Huawei on a blacklist, citing national security concerns, and has asked allies not to use its equipment. India is set to hold 5G trials in the coming months, but has not yet made a decision on Huawei's participation.

images.alt_text: China has told India not to block its Huawei Technologies from doing business in the country, warning there could be consequences for Indian firms operating in China, sources with knowledge of the matter said.

site_title: Papua New Guinea seeks Chinese help to refinance debt, boost trade
summary: Papua New Guinea's Prime Minister James Marape has requested China to refinance its 27 billion kina (S$10.7 billion) government debt and establish free trading arrangements with Pacific island nations. This comes as competition for influence in the region intensifies between Beijing and Washington. The request coincides with China's increased financing for Pacific nations, which has raised concerns about debt burdens. Marape aims to boost economic corridor zones in the region, amid a backdrop of aggressive warnings from US Defence Secretary Mark Esper about China's "predatory economics".

site_title: HSBC Singapore rolls out global mortgage solution, starting with Australia
summary: HSBC Singapore launched its first overseas mortgage solution, HSBC International Mortgage, targeting Australian property investors. The loan allows customers to choose the currency, offering benefits such as access to relationship manager support via HSBC Premier International Centres. This solution will initially be offered to Australian customers, with plans to roll it out to other markets in the future.

site_title: Fintech platform Helicap acquires securities firm Arcor Capital
summary: Helicap, a fintech platform, has acquired securities firm Arcor Capital, expanding its alternative lending services in South-east Asia. Arcor Capital, specializing in private debt securities, will join Helicap Investments under the Helicap Group. The acquisition aims to source investment opportunities for accredited investors in the US$500 billion Asia-Pacific alternative lending market. Helicap Investments plans to launch its first fund with a target assets under management of S$200 million, investing in a portfolio of loans from alternative lending platforms in Asia.

site_title: Food delivery startup Glovo held early-stage talks with Uber, Deliveroo: sources
summary: Spanish food delivery startup Glovo has held early-stage talks with Uber and Deliveroo, with the companies showing preliminary interest in a potential acquisition. However, Glovo is not actively looking for a buyer and may prefer to explore partnerships or deals on a region-by-region basis. The company is also raising fresh funding and has held talks with SoftBank Group Corp about a potential investment. Glovo operates in Europe, Latin America, and Africa, and the outcome of these talks is unclear.

site_title: Asian stocks turn lower on lingering trade war fears, yuan slips
summary: Asian stocks fell for an eighth consecutive session on lingering trade war fears, despite White House assurances on US-China negotiations. The MSCI's Asia-Pacific index was down 0.2% as investors remained cautious about a possible global currency war. China's yuan slipped further, but signs of steadying after its recent sharp fall eased investor fears. The US-China trade tensions continue to weigh on markets, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: BOJ flagged need to discuss ideas on easing, meeting summary shows
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) policymakers discussed the need to ease monetary policy, citing risks to the economic outlook and the strain on financial institutions. Some members recommended a stimulus boost, while others advised caution. The central bank may consider loosening policy as early as next month, amid heightening overseas risks that could tip Japan into recession. The debate highlights a rift among BOJ members, with differing opinions on the timing and extent of stimulus.

site_title: Boeing holds workshops with China carriers to bring back 737 MAX
summary: Boeing is holding workshops with Chinese airlines to bring back the grounded 737 MAX plane. The workshops, starting with China Southern Airlines, aim to address concerns and redesign the flight-control system. Boeing is still targeting a final software package presentation to regulators by September, although the timeline may slip. Chinese carriers are seeking compensation for order delays and losses due to the grounding, with 96 of their 737 MAX jets suspended. The airlines planned to introduce 130 more planes this year, but the situation remains unclear.

site_title: South Korea becomes world's worst major equity market in 2019 to date
summary: South Korea's benchmark Kospi Index dropped 6.1% year-to-date, becoming the world's worst major equity market in 2019. The decline was fueled by the ongoing trade war with Japan and tensions between the US and China, slashing the nation's earnings outlook. Analysts have cut their earnings-per-share estimates by 23% since the beginning of the year. Technical indicators suggest the market may be nearing a turning point, with potential relief ahead.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 3.96 points lower at 1,607.83 on Wednesday, with 57.3 million lots traded at RM62.1 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 123 to 45. This article does not provide further information on the cause of the decline.

site_title: SPH takes 20% stake in Prime US Reit manager
summary: SPH completed its acquisition of a 20% stake in KBS US Prime Property Management, the manager of newly listed Prime US Reit. Prime US Reit debuted on the Singapore bourse on July 19, becoming the third US office real estate investment trust to list here. The acquisition brings the Reit manager under SPH's control, solidifying its presence in the US real estate market.

site_title: Samsung seeks alternatives to Japanese suppliers in trade row
summary: Samsung Electronics is seeking alternatives to Japanese suppliers due to the ongoing trade dispute between South Korea and Japan. The Japanese government has imposed restrictions on chemical exports crucial to chipmaking, including hydrogen fluoride gas, photoresists, and fluorinated polyimide. These chemicals are essential for making memory chips and high-spec TV screens. The move is part of Seoul and Tokyo's efforts to remove each other from their "white lists" of trusted trading partners. Samsung is exploring other suppliers to mitigate the impact of the trade row.

images.alt_text: South Korean tech giant Samsung Electronics, the world's biggest smartphone and memory chip maker, is seeking alternatives to Japanese suppliers for some key materials, it said Wednesday with Seoul and Tokyo embroiled in a bitter trade dispute.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks inch up in early trade
summary: Hong Kong shares rose in early trade on Wednesday, ending a week-long losing streak. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.16%, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.41%. Investors remained cautious due to the escalating US-China trade war. The market's gains were also influenced by positive sentiment from the US stock market, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Chinese official says Hong Kong facing biggest crisis since 1997
summary: Hong Kong is facing its biggest crisis since returning to Chinese rule in 1997, according to Chinese official Zhang Xiaoming. The crisis began with opposition to a suspended extradition law and has broadened into a backlash against the government, fueled by fears of eroding freedoms under China's tightening control. Protests have been sometimes violent, with residents expressing concerns over the erosion of their rights and freedoms. The situation has been described as a major challenge for the Hong Kong government and China's Communist Party leaders in Beijing.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong is facing its biggest crisis since it returned from British to Chinese rule in 1997, the head of China's Hong Kong and Macau Affairs office said on Wednesday.

site_title: Coinbase must face negligence suit over bitcoin cash launch
summary: US District Judge Vince Chhabria ruled that Coinbase must face a negligence lawsuit over the botched launch of bitcoin cash (BCH). The judge rejected claims that the suit should be handled in arbitration and allowed buyers to move forward with the suit, finding that Coinbase breached its duty to maintain a functional market. The lawsuit centers on Coinbase's decision to halt trading after briefly enabling orders in US dollars, leading to a surge in price and potential insider trading allegations.

site_title: Cathay Pacific swings to half-year profit on higher revenue, lower fuel costs
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd reported a net profit of HK$1.35 billion (S$237.4 million) for the first half of 2019, its first profit in six years, driven by rising passenger revenue and lower fuel costs. Passenger revenue rose 0.9% and capacity increased by 6.7%, while cargo revenue fell 11.4% due to the US-China trade war. The airline expects to achieve better financial results in the second half of the year despite headwinds and uncertainties.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd swung to a half-year profit, the first for the January-June period since 2016, as rising passenger revenue and lower fuel costs helped to offset a decline in the air cargo market.

site_title: Chinese banks probed over aid to North Korea's nuclear arms
summary: The US is investigating Chinese banks for allegedly helping North Korea's nuclear weapons program through financial transactions. The three banks, China Merchants Bank, Bank of Communications, and Shanghai Pudong Development Bank, are being probed for their role in exporting coal and minerals to North Korea, generating revenue in US dollars that could be used to fund the program. The investigation, which spans at least five years, could result in billions of dollars in fines if the banks are found to have willfully aided the operation.

site_title: New Zealand's central bank stuns markets with big rate cut; kiwi dives
summary: New Zealand's central bank unexpectedly cut the official cash rate by 50 basis points to a record low of 1%, sending the kiwi dollar tumbling and driving bond yields to all-time lows. The move aims to combat growing economic risks, including a slowdown in GDP growth and rising trade tensions. Economists predict further rate cuts, with some forecasting another 25bp cut in November. The decision follows similar moves by global policymakers and comes amid concerns about the impact of the US-China trade war on the global economy.

site_title: Fragile calm returns to stock markets as yuan steadies
summary: Asian shares steady slightly on Wednesday as investors recover from a week-long selloff, with China's yuan stabilizing after a firmer-than-expected fixing and a bond sale. The People's Bank of China's steps helped calm fears of a full-blown Sino-US trade and currency war. The S&P 500 gained 1.30% on Wall Street, while the MSCI's broad gauge of stocks rose 0.50%. The dollar and euro remain steady, while gold hits a six-year high due to safe-haven asset demand.

site_title: Twitter says it may have used user data for ads without permission
summary: Twitter says it may have used user data for personalized ads without permission due to issues with its settings. The company discovered the issue and fixed it on Monday, but hasn't yet determined who was impacted. The data in question includes country code, engagement details, and device information. Twitter apologized and promised to prevent similar mistakes, stating "You trust us to follow your choices and we failed here."

site_title: New international arbitration centre in Singapore to focus on China-Asean disputes
summary: Singapore is set to host the new Beihai Asia International Arbitration Centre (BAIAC), a lower-cost international arbitration hub for small- to medium-value China-Asean disputes. The centre, established by the Beihai Arbitration Commission, aims to provide efficient services for cross-border commercial transactions. The Singapore centre will also have a China-Asean panel of arbitrators to promote people-to-people exchanges. BAIAC's arbitration rules will be modified to include a small claims procedure, and fees will be pegged at a "more reasonable" lower level to encourage dispute resolution.

site_title: Tesla draws US regulatory blowback over Model 3 safety claims
summary: The US National Highway Traffic Administration (NHTSA) sent a cease-and-desist letter to Tesla over the company's safety claims for its Model 3, citing inconsistencies with its advertising guidelines. NHTSA also subpoenaed Tesla for information on several crashes, including a fatal one involving a Model 3 operating on Autopilot. The regulator claims the statements were unfair or deceptive acts. This move comes after Tesla's blog post stating the Model 3 had the lowest probability of injury of any vehicle tested, which NHTSA deemed inconsistent with its guidelines.

site_title: Indonesia woos Instagram generation for hip new bond raisings
summary: Indonesia's finance ministry is targeting digitally savvy millennials to fund its national savings bonds, aiming to reduce reliance on foreign investment. The latest two-year bond, dubbed "James bonds," was launched with a marketing event in Jakarta's hip district, featuring celebrities and social media influencers. Over half of the buyers were millennials, and the ministry plans to launch 10 such bonds this year. The push is driven by the growth of online marketplaces and fintech startups, which have opened new investment opportunities for young Indonesians.

site_title: Yuan weakens after China central bank sets fixing closer to 7 per US dollar
summary: China's yuan weakened 0.1% to 7.0320 after the central bank set its daily fixing near 7 per US dollar, slightly weaker than expected. The currency broke the key level of 7 for the first time since 2008 on Monday. The People's Bank of China set the reference rate at 6.9996 per dollar, slightly lower than the projected 6.9977. The move may signal the central bank's stance on the yuan's depreciation, with economists warning investors about the potential for further weakening.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, Ho Bee Land, OUE H-Trust, Perennial, GSH, EC World Reit
summary: CapitaLand reported a 4.2% drop in net profit to S$579.8 million for its second quarter, mainly attributed to one-off transactions costs from the acquisition of Ascendas-Singbridge. Revenue slumped 19.3% to S$1.08 billion, with earnings per share down 13.9 cents from the year-ago period. No dividend was declared for the quarter.

site_title: North Korea's Kim says missile launches are warning to US, South Korea over drill: KCNA
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un said the recent missile launch is a warning to the US and South Korea over their joint military drills, citing stalled nuclear talks with Washington. The launch, the fourth in less than two weeks, aimed to "send an adequate warning" to the joint US-South Korean exercises. Analysts see the launches as a demonstration of North Korea's confidence in its missile technology, while the US and South Korea downplayed the tests, calling them a computer-simulated drill. Diplomatic talks between the two sides remain stalled since February.

site_title: Brent oil in bear market as China-US trade tensions mount
summary: Oil prices fell over 1% on Tuesday, with Brent crude reaching a seven-month low below $60 a barrel, amid escalating US-China trade tensions. The decline puts Brent in "bear market" territory, with prices losing over 9% in the past week. The US and China have imposed new tariffs and restrictions, sparking concerns about weakening global demand. Global equities hit a two-month low, and analysts warn that oil prices may struggle to hold up due to the trade tensions.

site_title: Singapore shares recover at Wednesday's open after Wall St rebound; STI up 0.11% to 3,174.06
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.11% to 3,174.06 points on Wednesday, recovering from previous day's losses after US stocks rebounded overnight. The Straits Times Index gained 3.59 points, with 75 gainers outnumbering 39 losers in trading of 34.7 million securities worth S$81.1 million. The rally follows a 5-day upswing ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Perennial Q2 earnings slump 75% to S$2.2m
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings' Q2 earnings plummeted 74.9% to S$2.2 million due to higher finance costs and the absence of a fair value gain. This was largely attributed to increased interest rates and additional loans for new investments. Earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter fell to 0.13 Singapore cents, down from 0.52 cents in the previous year. The company's net finance cost increased, while interest expenses related to the Perennial International Health and Medical Hub project were expensed off upon completion.

site_title: SpaceX pulls off do-over flight years after launch pad explosion
summary: SpaceX successfully launched a communication satellite, Amos-17, into orbit for Israel's Space Communication Ltd. on Tuesday, nearly three years after a rocket explosion in 2016. The mission is a do-over launch, with SpaceX flying the satellite for free after owing $50 million in compensation or a future launch. The Amos-17 satellite will provide broadcast, broadband, and data services across Africa, marking a key step towards SpaceX's broadband constellation. The company has set a record with 21 launches in 2018 and 10 this year, with the launch of Amos-17 marking its 10th mission of the year.

site_title: Disney to bundle Disney+, Hulu, ESPN+ at popular Netflix price
summary: Disney plans to launch a $13-per-month bundle of Disney+, Hulu, and ESPN+ in November, matching Netflix's most popular plan. The bundle will include commercials and a $5 discount. Analysts say the move could intensify video streaming competition. Disney shares fell 5% after reporting a steeper earnings decline than expected. The bundle aims to attract audiences who have turned to digital services like Netflix.

images.alt_text: Walt Disney Co on Tuesday said it would offer a US$13-per-month bundle of its three streaming services starting in November, a move to attract audiences who have embraced digital services such as Netflix Inc.

site_title: Hong Kong assets turn toxic as trade war and protests cloud outlook
summary: Hong Kong's assets are experiencing a toxic downturn due to the trade war and protests, with investors becoming increasingly anxious. The city saw the largest spike in interbank rates in over a decade, longest equity declines since 1984, and wild stock swings in four years. The property market, tourist numbers, hotel occupancy, and retail sales are also suffering, with profits for Hang Seng Index members forecast to drop the most since the global financial crisis this year. A weak yuan is further exacerbating the situation, threatening mainland visitor spending and firm earnings.

site_title: Europe: FTSE 100 falls for 6th straight day on US-China trade spat
summary: The FTSE 100 in London fell for the 6th consecutive day, losing 0.7% and dropping below its 200-day moving average, amid ongoing US-China trade tensions. The decline was partly offset by strong corporate earnings from industrial firms, but was also driven by oil majors BP and Shell, as well as a slight recovery in the pound. Washington has formally tagged China a currency manipulator, deepening the conflict between the two economies.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on strong yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.32% to 20,519.32, amid a strong yen and concerns over US-China trade ties. The yen's value rose to 106.15 yen against the dollar, reducing profits for Japanese exporters. Investors remain cautious, with market analysts attributing the yen's strength to uncertainty over dollar-yuan rates.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened lower again on Wednesday, despite Wall Street snapping a multi-session losing streak, with investors still on edge over US-China trade ties.

site_title: Citi US high-yield credit analysts exit as bank disbands team
summary: Citi is disbanding its US high-yield debt research team, cutting jobs and assigning some members to other roles. Managing directors Manish Somaiya, David Phipps, James Yoon, and Bill Henry are among those exiting. The move doesn't affect the bank's macro strategist group. The disbanding is seen as part of a broader restructuring effort at the bank.

site_title: China to remove soybean oil, rapeseed oil, palm oil import quotas
summary: China plans to remove tariffs on soybean oil, rapeseed oil, and palm oil imports, effective immediately, following US President Donald Trump's imposition of tariffs on another $300 billion of Chinese imports. The move comes after Chinese companies halted US agriculture product purchases in response to the tariffs. The commodities will no longer be subject to restrictions, which may apply to other products like wheat, corn, and rice.

site_title: Short on cash, businesses in China rely on IOUs
summary: China's economy is struggling, and many businesses are relying on IOUs (informal notes) to stay afloat. With the country's trade war with the US escalating, private businesses like architect Zhang Zhiyang are accepting IOUs from clients instead of cash. Over $200 billion in IOUs are circulating in the financial system, with property companies issuing them to suppliers to stay afloat. This trend is reminiscent of the 2008 financial crisis, when state-owned enterprises issued IOUs that nearly paralyzed the business world. Regulators are concerned about the proliferation of IOUs, which could lead to a financial crisis.

site_title: Tech news site The Markup rehires editor for a do-over
summary: The Markup, a technology news startup, has rehired its former editor-in-chief Julia Angwin and appointed new president Nabiha Syed and managing editor Evelyn Larrubia. The move comes after the site's entire editorial staff resigned following Angwin's firing in April. The new leadership aims to reboot the site, which has been financed by nonprofit backers, and will focus on investigative journalism and data-driven reporting to cover the tech industry. The site plans to begin publishing by the end of the year and expand its staff.

site_title: PACC Offshore Q2 net loss deepens to US$8.6m
summary: PACC Offshore Services Holdings (POSH) reported a widened net loss of US$8.6 million in the second quarter, a 49% increase from the previous year, with loss per share at 0.48 US cents. Revenue fell 11% to US$74 million, mainly due to a decline in the offshore accommodation segment. The group is undertaking a comprehensive review of its business, including divesting non-performing assets and investments, amid ongoing market challenges.

site_title: The Oscar winners of corporate governance
summary: The 14th edition of the Singapore Corporate Awards honored 38 companies and six individuals for leading corporate governance and shareholder communication. Four groups - CapitaLand, DBS Bank, Keppel Corporation, and United Overseas Bank - received multiple awards. This recognition acknowledges their commitment to best practices in corporate governance and transparency, setting a high standard for the Singaporean corporate scene.

site_title: Gold's 'staying power' attracts investors to VanEck mining ETF
summary: Gold's recent surge has attracted investors to VanEck's mining ETF, with call and put options open interest near an all-time high. The VanEck Vectors Gold Miners ETF has climbed 36% this year, more than double the gold price gain. Investors are seeking refuge in gold and mining companies as financial markets are affected by the US-China trade war. Higher gold prices boost mining companies' cash flow, making them more appealing. Investors are gaining conviction that the gold rally has staying power, with some analysts predicting a buy-in from the generalist crowd.

site_title: Marriott jumps into all-inclusive resort business
summary: Marriott International is entering the all-inclusive resort business with plans for two new properties: a 650-room hotel in Punta Cana, Dominican Republic, and a multi-branded resort on Mexico's Riviera Nayarit. The projects, valued at over $800 million, are part of a push to compete with specialty companies offering all-inclusive experiences. Marriott aims to appeal to its 133 million loyalty program members and convince developers to partner with the company. The company will initially offer all-inclusive resorts under seven of its 30 brands, starting with the Ritz-Carlton and Westin brands.

site_title: Gold tops US$1,500 as investors seek shelter from gathering storm
summary: Gold futures rose to US$1,500.40 an ounce, the highest level since 2013, due to sustained demand as investors seek shelter from the US-China trade war, slowing global growth, and central banks' easing monetary policy. The 1.1% gain extends this year's advance to 17% and is underpinned by investor inflows into exchange-traded funds. The turmoil in global financial markets, including the Trump administration's threat of fresh tariffs, has boosted the odds of more easing from the Federal Reserve.

site_title: China warns currency manipulator labelling could cause chaos
summary: China's central bank warned that the US decision to label Beijing as a currency manipulator would "severely damage international financial order" and cause chaos in financial markets. China denies manipulating its currency and says the US label is driven by "political motive." The move has driven a wedge between the two economies, with China stopping buying US agricultural products and suspending flights to the US. Analysts warn that tit-for-tat measures could widen the scope and severity of the trade war, weighing on global economic growth.

site_title: US slaps duty on US$4.4b of China cabinets amid trade war
summary: The US Commerce Department imposed a 229% duty on approximately $4.4 billion worth of imported Chinese wooden cabinets and vanities, amid the ongoing trade dispute. The decision was made in response to a petition filed by the American Kitchen Cabinet Alliance, alleging dumping margins of over 200% and at least $2 billion in harm to the US industry. The cash deposits will be collected from Chinese companies Henan AiDiJia Furniture Co and Deway International Trade Co, with others facing lower subsidy rates. A final determination is set for December.

site_title: Tech giants facing probes for violation of privacy
summary: Tech giants Google, Apple, and Amazon are under investigation for violating privacy regulations by employing human reviewers to listen to voice commands recorded by digital assistants. Amazon has suspended its program and changed its terms to allow users to opt out, while Apple and Google have also suspended their programs. Regulators in the US and Europe are examining the practice, with some calling for stricter controls on AI development to avoid future scandals. The European Data Protection Board has the power to levy fines of up to 4% of a company's annual revenue for non-compliance.

site_title: Singapore Airlines picks crucial fight against Emirates in India
summary: Singapore Airlines' subsidiary Vistara launched its first overseas service between New Delhi and Singapore, marking a significant move against Emirates and Etihad Airways in India's growing aviation market. With over 520 million passengers expected by 2037, Vistara aims to capture a share of the 63 million passengers carried by foreign airlines last year. The airline faces competition from ultra-cheap fares offered by Middle East airlines and Indian low-cost carriers, but plans to expand its route network to Dubai and Bangkok.

site_title: US: Stocks gain as Chinese yuan stabilises
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, ending a multi-session losing streak, as China stabilized its currency amid the US-China trade war. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 1.2%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index rose 1.3% and 1.4%, respectively. China's central bank boosted the yuan, and Governor Yi Gang vowed not to engage in competitive devaluation. Analysts say the move calmed the currency market and boosted sentiment, but heightened uncertainty continues to hamper sentiment.

site_title: Queen's banker casts net wide as Brexit takes toll
summary: Coutts & Co, the Queen's banker, is expanding its client base amid Brexit uncertainty, targeting business owners from NatWest and pursuing overseas customers. The firm has started hosting receptions for online phenoms and gamers, and its bankers are advising anxious clients to focus on economic growth rather than politics. Despite a slowdown in revenue growth, Coutts is making progress in converting commercial banking customers into private banking clients, with a 13% increase in new clients in the first half of the year.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Reviewing Hot Hatches
summary: Claressa Monteiro and Julian Kho from SGCarMart review hot hatches, including the Golf R and Polo, discussing their key selling points. The episode, part of Money FM's podcast series, focuses on performance, handling, and features of these high-performance vehicles. No conclusions or ratings are provided in the article.

site_title: Why bombs alone cannot beat insurgents
summary: The US-led campaign against terrorism has been criticized for its hyper-militarized approach, prioritizing counter-terrorism and security over soft-power instruments like public diplomacy. Despite successes in unseating the Taliban and degrading ISIS, the emphasis on hard power has fueled controversy and alienated many globally. Experts, including former Secretary of State John Kerry, have called for a paradigm shift towards a more balanced approach, with a focus on winning "hearts and minds" through sustainable development assistance, exchange programs, and public diplomacy. The threat from terrorism remains a major concern, with a new wave of attacks possible before the end of the year, and the US and international partners must address this Achilles heel in the campaign against terrorism.

site_title: CompareAsiaGroup raises US$20m in Series B1 investment
summary: CompareAsiaGroup, parent company of SingSaver, has raised US$20 million in Series B1 investment led by Experian. The funding round includes a partnership allowing CompareAsiaGroup to access Experian's technology, enabling the financial management platform to utilize Experian's cloud native platform for digital onboarding and decision management services. This partnership aims to enhance CompareAsiaGroup's capabilities in banking and insurance products and services.

site_title: Mastercard buys Nets unit in record deal
summary: Mastercard has agreed to buy a 60% stake in Nets, a Denmark-based payments platform, for $4.4 billion. The deal aims to help Mastercard extend its push into faster payments, a growing trend globally. The purchase includes electronic-billing and clearing services, and is expected to impact Mastercard's profit for two years. This move follows similar efforts by companies and governments to develop real-time payment systems, and comes as the US Federal Reserve plans to build its own real-time gross settlement system.

site_title: CapitaLand Q2 profit falls 4.2% on one-off costs from Ascendas-Singbridge acquisition
summary: CapitaLand's Q2 net profit fell 4.2% to S$579.8 million due to one-off costs from the acquisition of Ascendas-Singbridge, completed on June 28. Excluding these costs, net profit would have increased 1.7%. Revenue slumped 19.3% to S$1.08 billion, mainly due to lower residential sales in Singapore and China. The group's core markets of Singapore and China accounted for 62.8% of revenue, down from 75.8% last year. No dividend was declared for the quarter.

site_title: China warns HK protesters: Don't play with fire
summary: China has warned Hong Kong protesters not to "play with fire" and mistake Beijing's restraint for weakness, vowing to bring demonstrators to justice. In its sharpest rebuke yet, Beijing described protesters as "criminals" and urged Hong Kong residents to stand up to them. The warning comes after a general strike and day of protests, which led to traffic chaos, mob violence, tear gas, and flight cancellations. China's restraint is seen as a calculated move to avoid escalating tensions, but the protesters remain defiant, challenging the government's authority.

site_title: Gold firms near six-year peak as trade tensions trigger safe-haven bets
summary: Gold prices held near six-year highs on Tuesday as investors sought safe-haven assets amid escalating US-China trade tensions. The US Treasury Secretary designated Beijing a currency manipulator, prompting a decline in the dollar index and US Treasury yields. Gold prices rose to $1,474.81 per ounce, while spot gold was down 0.2% at $1,460.19 per ounce. Analysts expect gold to consolidate before reengaging at higher levels, with some predicting prices could reach $1,500 per ounce.

site_title: Next steps in your enterprise risk management journey
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

The article discusses the evolution of enterprise risk management (ERM) and the need for organisations to mature their ERM programme to ERM 2.0. The four key pillars of this journey are exploring risk inter-connectivity, linking risk management to strategy, implementing a technology-enabled ERM, and breaking through the barriers of risk culture. Organisations must address challenges such as cost, risk culture, and maturity to effectively implement these pillars. A tailored ERM roadmap, continuous effort to improve risk culture, and the right technology-enabled solutions are crucial for organisations to achieve ERM 2.0 and enhance their risk management capabilities.

site_title: Shell considers solar panels to power Singapore refinery site
summary: Royal Dutch Shell is considering installing solar panels at its Bukom refining site in Singapore, a move aimed at reducing the site's carbon footprint. The company has not provided further details on the project. This initiative aligns with Singapore's efforts to increase the use of renewable energy sources. The installation of solar panels would help Shell reduce its reliance on fossil fuels and contribute to the country's goal of becoming a more sustainable energy hub.

site_title: Ancient monastery surrounded by conflict a sanctuary for different faiths
summary: A Lebanese monastery, Saint Anthony of Qozhaya, has become a sanctuary for different faiths amidst conflicts in the region. The monastery, which was last visited by the author in 1978, has seen a resurgence in visitors, particularly from minority sects, such as the Syriac Orthodox community, who are fleeing persecution in Iraq and Syria. The civil war in Lebanon ended in 1990, but the displacement of Christians continues, with many seeking refuge in the monastery, 41 years after the author's last visit. The site has become a symbol of hope and unity for those seeking peace and safety.

site_title: 3 ways banks, fintechs and FIs can harness AI for success
summary: Banks and financial institutions can harness AI for success by prioritizing high-quality data, focusing on the client experience, and having a clear roadmap. Investing in data quality is crucial to deliver tailored outcomes that enrich customers' lives. AI can optimize customer interactions, ensuring deeper and broader relationships, and can also change the user experience landscape by providing personalized conversations. To start, banks should focus on small steps, such as using AI to make recommendations, and gradually move towards the "curator" level, where AI-driven conversations become the norm.

site_title: Take risk-off approach as worst is yet to come: analysts
summary: Asian markets fell for a third straight session on Tuesday, with the Shanghai Composite Index and South Korea's Kospi Index plummeting 1.56% and 1.51% respectively, amid US-China trade tensions. Analysts predict the worst is yet to come and advise taking a risk-off approach, citing cyclical sectors like consumer and technology as vulnerable to rising trade tensions. Investors are advised to hedge against market risk by investing in asset classes like precious metals and safe-haven currencies, and to keep a close eye on the USD/CNH rate.

site_title: Paint mania!
summary: A new pop-up art studio, Splat Paint House, has opened in Singapore, offering a unique stress-relief experience where visitors can paint freely using water pistols and syringes. For S$39, guests receive a canvas, paint, gloves, and overalls. Unlike "rage rooms," the studio's founder, Andrea Lim, aims to create beautiful art pieces that clients can display at home. With no rules or time limits, guests can let their creativity run wild and leave with a unique piece of art. The studio's focus is on promoting self-expression and relaxation.

site_title: Car market slowdown 'threatens jobs at Bosch'
summary: Bosch's CEO, Volkmar Denner, warns of job cuts due to a global car market slowdown and the ongoing diesel cheating scandal. The company expects reduced demand for diesel-fuelled vehicles and a decline in revenue, forcing a 600-job reduction among 15,000 employees. Bosch also predicts a lower profit margin below 6% for the full year, down from 7% last year. The company's revenue is expected to remain at 2018 levels, but profitability will not be maintained. The decline in diesel demand is attributed to growing concerns over nitrogen oxide emissions and the shift to hybrid and electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: Expected by analysts to contract this year, the global car market is developing "much more weakly than we still thought a year ago," says Mr Denner, adding: "This isn't just a short-term dip that will quickly be recovered."

site_title: Shaping the future of MSME finance to help small businesses thrive
summary: Small and medium enterprises (MSMEs) in South-east Asia face a significant financing gap, with 51% of MSMEs in the region facing a US$175 billion financing gap. Despite fintech credit options, MSMEs often rely on alternative lenders due to limited credit history and financial experience. However, these options come with risks, such as high interest rates and harsh penalties. To address this issue, regulatory efforts and partnerships between fintech and traditional financial services providers are crucial. Implementing machine learning algorithms and creating bespoke financial identities for customers can help mitigate risks and promote responsible lending practices, ultimately improving access to finance for MSMEs.

site_title: India's top airline IndiGo co-founder says feud still unresolved
summary: Rakesh Gangwal, co-founder of IndiGo, denied reports of a truce with Rahul Bhatia, citing unresolved issues with corporate governance. Gangwal alleged violations of rules at InterGlobe Aviation Ltd and called for regulatory intervention. The dispute centers on IGE Group's controlling rights over IndiGo, which Gangwal claims allows "questionable" transactions. The stock lost $1 billion in value after Gangwal's complaint, but has since recovered. The situation remains unresolved, with Gangwal stating that he does not support a proposed board expansion that would benefit IGE.

site_title: Indonesia turns to social media to tap millennials' growing appetite for fixed income
summary: Indonesia is turning to social media to tap into millennials' growing appetite for fixed income, as the country seeks to reduce its reliance on foreign funds. The finance ministry launched a marketing event using celebrities, dance music, and social media influencers to promote national savings bonds, which attracted over half of its buyers, mostly millennials. Online marketplaces like Tokopedia and BukaLapak are also driving the push for millennials' funds, offering investments ranging from gold to mutual funds. The government aims to mobilize domestic savings to reduce its reliance on foreign investment and boost financial inclusion.

site_title: Philippine equities may be a haven for investors
summary: Philippine equities may be a haven for investors amid trade tensions in the region. Analysts from Credit Suisse Group and Citigroup predict economic growth exceeding 6% over the next two years, positive earnings revisions, and room for borrowing cost cuts. The Philippine Stock Exchange Index is expected to rebound, with a 12-month target of 9,200 set by Credit Suisse. Foreign investors have poured $471 million into Philippine equities this year, despite a recent single-day outflow of $23 million.

site_title: Air China to suspend Beijing-Hawaii flights amid weak travel demand
summary: Air China announced the suspension of its Beijing-Hawaii flights from August 27 due to weak travel demand amid the US-China trade war. Passengers who booked flights after the suspension date will receive full refunds. This decision comes as the airline reviews its network to optimize operations.

site_title: Singapore shares dip on China's yuan moves
summary: Singapore's benchmark index closed 0.75% lower at 3,170.47, despite China's central bank intervening to stabilize the yuan after it fell to its lowest level against the US dollar since August 2010. The Straits Times Index dropped as much as 1.6% earlier in the session, with industrials and financial stocks leading the decline. Despite this, the market regained ground, with DBS Group and UOB among the largest decliners. Analysts attributed the decline to escalating US-China trade tensions, with some warning of a currency war.

site_title: Curious coincidences behind Epicentre's missing CEO
summary: Epicentre Holdings CEO Lim Tiong Hian, also known as Kenneth Lim, was suddenly sacked in July after raising his stake in the company to 18.9%. He had been "entirely uncontactable" since May 24, sparking speculation about his disappearance. The company cited his lack of explanation for his absence. Lim's disappearance came a month after he set the company's strategic direction and track its financials, raising questions about his role and the company's future.

site_title: Ho Bee Land Q2 earnings slump 80% to S$14.4m
summary: Ho Bee Land, a Singaporean property company, reported a 79.9% slump in second-quarter earnings to S$14.4 million, due to losses from associates and jointly controlled entities. Revenue rose 21.2% to S$52.6 million, driven by contributions from a London investment property and positive rental reversions. Earnings per share fell to 2.16 Singapore cents from 10.74 cents last year, while the company declared no interim dividend. Net profit for the first half fell 65% to S$42.1 million.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: CapitaLand appoints Miguel Ko as non-executive deputy chairman and director, effective Tuesday. He is CEO of CLA Real Estate and holds a 50.4% stake in CapitaLand through Temasek Holdings. Additionally, Ko and existing board member Chaly Mah Chee Kheong will join the Strategy, Investment and Finance Committee.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore's property market remains stable despite a slowdown in new launch take-up rates, with ERA securing project marketing roles for 26 projects and private resale volumes improving. ERA's market share for new launches dipped to 26.4%, while private resale market share improved to 35.4%. Analysts expect overall transaction volumes to be similar to last year's, with Keppel Reit potentially divesting its Bugis Junction Towers for a sale price of S$2,200-2,400 per square foot.

site_title: Research and entrepreneurship can be bedfellows
summary: Singaporean universities are increasingly involved in a third mission: engaging in entrepreneurship activities. This has led to tangible dividends, including innovative products and jobs. Despite the benefits, balancing research and entrepreneurship can be challenging, particularly when universities prioritize global rankings. A study found that research scientists who are productive in releasing their findings also have higher levels of startup aspirations and industry-science interaction. To encourage entrepreneurship, universities should establish dedicated units, such as innovation and enterprise arms, and foster a culture that supports faculty's enterprising aspirations.

site_title: New licensing framework tightens reins on private-hire firms
summary: Singapore has introduced a new licensing framework for private-hire firms, including ride-hailing apps like Grab and Gojek. The framework, announced by Senior Minister of State for Transport Janil Puthucheary, requires operators with at least 800 vehicles to apply for a licence. Those caught providing a service without a licence or exemption can face fines of up to S$10,000 and jail time of up to six months. The framework aims to improve safety standards, track accidents and driver offences, and regulate vehicle maintenance.

site_title: OUE H-Trust Q2 DPS falls 9.4% on softer revenue, higher interest expense
summary: OUE H-Trust's distribution per stapled security (DPS) fell 9.4% to 1.06 Singapore cents in Q2, driven by lower revenue from the hospitality segment and higher interest expense. Gross revenue declined 4.4% to S$29.38 million, while net property income (NPI) dropped 4.5% to S$25.31 million. The company attributed the decline to downward pressure in the hospitality sector and negative rental reversions.

site_title: Travelodge Hotels Asia to manage Bay Hotel Singapore: Datapulse
summary: TRAVELodge Hotels Asia (TLA) has been appointed to manage Bay Hotel Singapore, following its successful management of a Holiday Inn Express hotel in Seoul. Datapulse Technology, which has a minority stake in both hotels, entered into conditional agreements for TLA to manage Bay Hotel. The agreement is conditional upon the successful completion of the Bay Hotel investment, and Datapulse's chairman Aw Cheok Huat, who also chairs ICP Group, now has an indirect interest in the Bay Hotel investment.

site_title: Will spike in financial market volatility lead to a Sept FOMC cut?
summary: The US Federal Reserve lowered interest rates for the first time since 2008, sparking debate about a potential prolonged lowering cycle. Markets are skeptical, with a 65% chance of another cut in September, amid concerns over the US-China trade and global economic slowdown. The Fed's chairman, Jerome Powell, described the rate cut as a "mid-cycle" adjustment, but economists worry about the effectiveness of traditional monetary policy given the low room for further rate cuts. A recession may be looming, with the yield curve inverting and global growth forecasted at 3.2% by the IMF.

site_title: SGX dollar-yuan futures trades sets daily records as Trump's tariff tweet roils markets
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) USD/CNH futures set a daily record with volumes reaching US$10.37 billion on Monday, a 38% increase over last Friday's record. This surge followed US President Donald Trump's tweet announcing a 10% tariff on US$300 billion of Chinese goods, starting from September. The increase in trading activity reflects market anxiety over potential trade tensions and its impact on the global economy.

site_title: Barneys files for Chapter 11 as rising rents, fewer shoppers hit business
summary: Barneys New York Inc filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection due to rising rents and declining shopper numbers. The luxury fashion chain listed assets of $100-500 million and estimated liabilities of $100-500 million. Barneys secured $75 million in new capital to meet financial commitments and plans to stay open at select locations, including Madison Avenue and Beverly Hills stores. The company will review store leases and consider options, while closing locations in Chicago, Las Vegas, and Seattle.

site_title: The threat of a US-China currency war
summary: The US and China are at risk of a currency war, following the escalation of the trade war between the two nations. China holds over $1 trillion of US Treasury securities, and a potential sell-off could lead to global financial instability. The US administration could intervene to weaken the dollar, targeting the yuan, euro, or sterling. However, alternative havens for Chinese reserves are limited, and the Chinese leadership fears instability above all else, making a sudden decision to sell off Treasury holdings unlikely. The interdependence between the two nations makes economic policies double-edged, with both countries contributing to the global economy.

site_title: UBS to charge HNW clients for accounts above 500,000 euros
summary: UBS plans to charge high-net-worth clients a 0.6% annual fee for holding more than 500,000 euros in cash, starting in November. The fee, 20 basis points above the European Central Bank deposit rate, aims to offset negative interest rates. This move expands the bank's fee policy, previously applying to clients with 1 million euros or more. The charge is expected to cast a wider net over UBS's client base, primarily targeting rich individuals.

site_title: Trade war widens spreads on Asian dollar bonds
summary: The trade war between the US and China has led to a widening of spreads in Asian dollar bonds, reaching their widest since August 2015. The weakening of the yuan and the US labeling China a foreign-exchange manipulator contributed to the increase. This exposes cracks in Asia's booming dollar bond market, which has seen record issuances and high returns this year.

site_title: SGX, NSE aim to trade Nifty products via Gift City by end-2020
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) and National Stock Exchange of India (NSE) have received regulatory approval to trade Nifty products via Gift City, Gujarat, by end-2020. The proposed NSE-IFSC-SGX Connect aims to increase liquidity by combining international and home market participants. The trading model will execute Nifty futures contracts in Gujarat's International Finance Tec-City, creating a larger pool of participants. This collaboration is expected to enhance market connectivity and facilitate trade between India and Singapore.

site_title: Trade spat means Asian export economies are in for a rough ride, Fitch Solutions warns
summary: Asian export-reliant economies, including Singapore, Taiwan, South Korea, Vietnam, and Malaysia, are expected to be severely impacted by waning demand for Chinese-made products and supply chain disruptions amid escalating US-China trade tensions. Fitch Solutions warns that these economies are deeply integrated with China's supply chains, supplying electronics and machinery as inputs for Chinese factories. The US-China trade row has led to a 10% tariff on US$300 billion of Chinese imports, with China threatening retaliation. Fitch Solutions suggests that some South-east Asian nations may be able to offset falling Chinese demand by hosting multinational corporations looking to relocate or expand production away from China, but investment will be difficult to justify until global trade policy clarity improves.

site_title: Japan's June household spending steady but real wages cloud outlook
summary: Japan's household spending rose 2.7% in June, a seventh straight month, despite weak global demand and softer wages. The Bank of Japan hopes this will help achieve its 2% inflation target. However, real wages slipped for a sixth month, raising concerns about the impact of a planned sales tax hike in October. The US-China trade war and slowing global demand also weigh on exports and business sentiment, with Japan's economic growth likely slowing in April-June.

site_title: Of plights, perils, piracy and politics
summary: Recent events in the Middle East Gulf and West Africa highlight the dangers faced by seafarers due to piracy, kidnapping, and political disputes. The seizure of two tankers, Grace 1 and Stena Impero, and reported attacks on tankers near the Strait of Hormuz have raised concerns about the safety of global shipping. The International Maritime Bureau warns that West Africa remains the world's most dangerous region for piracy, with 62 seafarers taken hostage in the first six months of 2019. Governments are urged to take immediate action to protect seafarers and prevent further escalations of tensions.

site_title: Mugabe still in Singapore hospital since April
summary: Robert Mugabe, Zimbabwe's former leader, remains hospitalized in Singapore for four months, receiving medical treatment for an undisclosed ailment. President Emmerson Mnangagwa stated that Mugabe's condition is stable and he is responding well to treatment. The 95-year-old was expected to return home by mid-May, but his physicians have determined that he needs longer observation. Mugabe's health issues are a concern given Zimbabwe's struggling public health services, which have led many citizens to seek treatment abroad.

site_title: Updated CPF, loan rules give HDB resale market 'new lease of life': OrangeTee
summary: HDB resale transactions in Singapore jumped 29.8% to 6,276 units in Q2 2019, marking the first increase in sales volume since Q3 2018. The surge in demand for older flats, aged 40 years and above, saw a 40% increase in sales of 40-year-old and above flats, while resale transactions for flats between 30 and 40 years old rose 10.4%. The government's policy updates on CPF usage and HDB housing loans gave buyers greater flexibility, contributing to the market's "new lease of life".
