The government sees the free ports as a way to create over 86,000 jobs and attract new investment.

site_title: Singapore banks get updated guide for safe use of cloud services
summary: Singapore banks have received updated guidelines from the Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) for safely using cloud services. The updated guide, released in August 2019, reflects technological advancements and evolving market practices. It provides best practice recommendations for categorizing cloud arrangements, due diligence on cloud service providers, and governing cloud operations. The ABS aims to support the safe adoption of cloud services by financial institutions.

site_title: EU states vote on IMF pick as field narrows
summary: EU governments began voting on their candidate to lead the IMF, with three contenders remaining: former Dutch finance minister Jeroen Dijsselbloem, Bank of Finland chief Olli Rehn, and World Bank's second-in-command Kristalina Georgieva of Bulgaria. The vote aims to settle differences between EU members, who have been discussing the role of the IMF during the financial crisis. Southern European countries are opposed to Dijsselbloem's candidacy due to his tough stance against nations like Greece, and Georgieva's age (66) may also pose a challenge.

images.alt_text: The candidate currently garnering the most support is Ms Kristalina Georgieva, who has served as chief executive of the World Bank since 2017.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as Trump's China tariff threat hits miners; NZ little changed
summary: Australian shares fell to their lowest level in over a week, with the S&P/ASX 200 index closing 0.3% down, after US President Donald Trump announced a 10% tariff on US$300 billion of Chinese imports. Mining stocks, which rely heavily on Chinese exports, led the decline, with BHP Group and Rio Tinto experiencing significant losses. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index ticked up 0.5% for its eighth consecutive week.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 9.60 points to 1,629.47. The market saw 235 losers versus 41 gainers, with a total volume of 102.4 million lots worth RM39.1 million.

site_title: Toyota Q1 net profit up nearly 4%, full-year profit revised down
summary: Toyota reported a 3.9% increase in Q1 net profit to 683 billion yen, driven by solid sales and cost-cutting efforts. However, the company revised its full-year profit forecast downward to 2.15 billion yen, citing a stronger yen. Operating profit rose 8.7% to 742 billion yen, with sales growing 3.8% to 7.64 trillion yen. Despite a firm performance, Toyota faces risks from the US-China trade war and foreign exchange losses.

site_title: Trump says he won't give 'advice' to China on Hong Kong protests
summary: US President Donald Trump stated he won't provide advice to China on Hong Kong protests, saying the matter is between Hong Kong and China. China's military has released a propaganda video showing troops quelling a protest, while protesters continue to demand more freedoms in the global financial hub.

site_title: 4 injured after multiple blasts hit Bangkok as city hosts top security meeting
summary: Multiple blasts hit Bangkok, injuring at least four people, as the city hosts a top security meeting attended by US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and other world leaders. The explosions, believed to be "ping pong bombs" around the size of a table tennis ball, occurred at several locations across the city, with one near the King Power Mahanakhon building. No immediate claim of responsibility was made, but Thai authorities condemned the attacks, urging the public not to panic. The bombings took place just before a keynote speech by Pompeo, who praised Thailand for rejoining the "democratic fold".

site_title: Japan finance ministry warns against yen gains, seeks FX stability
summary: Japan's finance minister Taro Aso warned against recent yen gains, citing the need for exchange rate stability to protect the country's export competitiveness. The yen surged against the dollar after US President Donald Trump broke a trade truce with China, prompting Aso to express concerns about the impact on the global economy. Japan has maintained a policy of not intervening in currency markets since 2011, instead focusing on promoting market-oriented exchange rates.

site_title: USP gets SGX nod to hold fiscal 2019 AGM by Sept 30
summary: USP Group has received a two-month extension from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to hold its fiscal 2019 annual general meeting (AGM) by September 30. The group initially applied for the extension on July 18 to compile additional information for its auditor's audit report. SGX has also granted in-principle approval for the listing and quotation of 1.5 million shares as part of USP's bid to satisfy the balance needed for its Supratechnic acquisition.

site_title: 'I like plastic': Pakistan's toxic 'love affair' with waste
summary: Pakistan's reliance on single-use plastic bags is exacerbating environmental issues, with the country using 55 billion bags annually. Despite efforts to ban plastic bags, enforcement remains weak, and public awareness is lacking. The nation's plastic pollution has reached alarming levels, with the Indus River becoming the second most polluted river in the world. Authorities have vowed to address the issue, with a ban on plastic bags set to be implemented in Islamabad, but experts warn that more needs to be done to change the "culture" of plastic use in the country.

site_title: Japan removes South Korea from favoured export 'white list'
summary: Japan has removed South Korea from its "white list" of trusted export destinations, effective August 28, amid escalating tensions between the two US allies. The move is expected to affect around 900 products, including building materials, chemicals, and technology components. South Korea has urged Japan not to proceed, citing grave consequences and prompting a rethink of security cooperation. The decision has sparked concerns about the impact on South Korea's already struggling economy and could further strain relations between the two countries, potentially hindering their ability to counter threats from North Korea and China.

site_title: Pentagon stalls US$10b cloud contract eyed by Amazon
summary: The US Pentagon has delayed awarding a $10 billion cloud computing contract to Amazon, citing a review by the newly appointed defense secretary. The Joint Enterprise Defence Infrastructure (JEDI) program is also being pursued by Microsoft, with critics arguing the bidding process favored Amazon. The decision comes a week after Mark Esper was confirmed as the new US secretary of defense, and will likely impact the outcome of the contract, which was initially expected to be awarded to Amazon. The review is expected to determine the winner of the contract.

site_title: Two injured in small 'explosions' as Bangkok hosts Asean summit: police
summary: At least two people were injured in small explosions at the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) summit in Bangkok, Thailand. The incidents occurred near the Mahanakorn Tower, where US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo was scheduled to give a keynote speech. Bomb disposal experts were deployed, and security measures were tightened. The Thai government has launched an investigation into the bombings, which come weeks after the country's civilian prime minister, Prayut Chan-O-Cha, was inaugurated. The blasts raise concerns about the country's history of political violence and the summit's security.

images.alt_text: Two people were injured Friday as at least two small explosions hit Bangkok, police said, as the politically febrile country hosts a regional summit attended by US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares fall sharply at Friday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 2.19% at Friday's open, following a global market downturn triggered by US President Donald Trump's new China tariffs. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 26,961.23, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.63% to 2,861.33. The losses mirror Wall Street's decline, despite a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and record highs in the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq.

site_title: Granddaughter of Robert F Kennedy dies after overdose at family's compound
summary: Saoirse Kennedy Hill, 22, granddaughter of Robert F Kennedy, died Thursday after an apparent overdose at the Kennedy compound in Hyannis Port, Massachusetts. She was taken to Cape Cod Hospital, where she was pronounced dead. The cause of death is under investigation by the Barnstable police and state police detectives. Kennedy Hill had written about her struggles with depression and mental illness in 2016. This is the latest tragedy to befall the Kennedy family, who have experienced a series of high-profile deaths and tragedies.

site_title: KPMG to give 20% pay bump to auditors for chartered accountant qualification
summary: KPMG in Singapore will give 20% pay bump to auditors who obtain the Singapore Chartered Accountant (SCA) qualification by July 1, 2020, to enhance audit quality and attract top talent. This move signals the firm's commitment to staff development and market-leading salaries. It is the first of its kind among Big Four professional services firms in Singapore. The salary increase is expected to make KPMG auditors significantly above the industry benchmark.

site_title: Aviva weighing options for Asian unit including sale: sources
summary: Aviva, a British insurer, is considering selling its Asian business unit, valued at $3-4 billion, as part of its efforts to overhaul the company under new CEO Maurice Tulloch. The unit, which has 885,000 clients in Singapore and strategic investments in China, Hong Kong, and other countries, has seen a rise in operating profit to £284 million in 2018. Several rival insurers have shown interest in acquiring the business, with some wanting only parts of the division. A formal process could begin later this year.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,267.93, down 0.72% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.72% to 3,267.93 at 1:03pm on Friday, August 2, 2019, amid a regional downturn. US President Donald Trump's new tariffs on Chinese goods led to losses in Singapore and other Asian markets. Losers outnumbered gainers 240 to 124, with mDR Limited and Genting Singapore among the most heavily traded stocks. Financials UOB and OCBC declined after releasing their quarterly results, while CapitaLand Commercial Trust rose 1.5% after heavy trading.

site_title: Katy Perry and others must pay US$2.8m in dispute over 'Dark Horse', says jury
summary: A federal jury in Los Angeles ordered Katy Perry and others to pay US$2.8 million in damages for copyright infringement over her 2013 song "Dark Horse", which borrowed from Christian rap song "Joyful Noise" by Flame. The jury found that 22.5% of "Dark Horse"'s profits came from the infringement. Perry must pay US$550,000, while her label Capitol Records owes nearly US$1.3 million.

site_title: Singapore shares fall amid global plunge after Trump tariff blow; STI down 0.57% at open
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.57% at the open on Friday, tracking global market declines after US President Donald Trump announced new tariffs on Chinese goods. The STI lost 18.87 points to 3,272.88 points, with CapitaLand Commercial Trust and ESR-Reit among the top losers. Banking stocks DBS and UOB reported Q2 results, with DBS flat and UOB gaining 0.5%. The decline follows a global market slump triggered by Trump's tariff announcement, which also affected Tokyo stocks and US stocks.

site_title: Blow for British PM Johnson after by-election defeat
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's candidate lost to a pro-EU Liberal Democrat in a by-election, potentially narrowing his parliamentary majority to one. The results showed Jane Dodd defeating Chris Davies with 13,826 votes to 12,401. This defeat marks a significant test for Johnson, who faces challenges in maintaining his party's majority and implementing his policies. The outcome could impact his ability to pass key legislation and may raise questions about his leadership.

site_title: Australia: Shares drop as Trump tariff threat rattles miners; New Zealand down
summary: Australian shares plummeted 0.5% to a two-week low, with China-reliant miners leading the decline, following US President Donald Trump's threat to slap a 10% tariff on $300 billion of Chinese imports. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to 6,758. Analysts say the escalation of US-China trade tensions has put the market in a tailspin, with Trump's comments sparking concerns of further tariffs. The decline follows a 0.4% gain on Thursday.

images.alt_text: Australian shares saw their worst day in more than two weeks on Friday, with China-reliant miners leading the fall, after USPresident Donald Trump said he will slap a 10 per cent tariff on US$300 billion of Chinese imports and could raise them further.

site_title: Pacific Star warns of fiscal 2019 loss
summary: Pacific Star Development, a Catalist-listed company, is expected to report a net loss for the financial year to June 30, 2019, due to challenging market conditions affecting sales of its Puteri Cove Residences project in Malaysia. The company's management is also assessing the appropriateness of its revenue recognition and may reverse previously recognized sales. This guidance is based on a preliminary review of the group's draft financial results, which will be released on or before August 29.

site_title: Eletrobras says Brazilian president approves privatisation plan, shares surge
summary: Brazil's state-controlled power company Eletrobras said President Jair Bolsonaro has authorized studies on privatizing the company through a share offering, sending its shares to a record high. The move is part of the government's plan to inject capital into the company and reduce its stake to a minority position. The Ministry of Mines and Energy has stated that the privatization could raise 18 billion reais (S$7.14 billion) and is expected to be approved by Congress.

site_title: Saudi Arabia allows women to travel without male 'guardian' approval
summary: Saudi Arabia has allowed women to obtain passports and travel abroad without male "guardian" approval, ending a longstanding restriction. The regulation, applicable to women over 21, marks a significant step in the kingdom's liberalization drive. The move follows recent reforms, including the lifting of the ban on female motorists and the expansion of women's roles in society. However, critics argue that the guardianship system remains a significant obstacle to women's rights, and that further reforms are needed to truly empower Saudi women.

site_title: CRCT private placement 3 times subscribed with S$154.3m raised
summary: Capitaland Retail China Trust (CRCT) has successfully raised S$154.3 million through a private placement, three times subscribed, to fund the purchase of three shopping centers from CapitaLand. The trust will issue 105 million units at S$1.469 each, a 5.2% discount to its closing price on August 1. A preferential offering for unitholders will also be conducted, aiming to raise S$125.1 million and issue 86.9 million units at S$1.440 each, a 7.1% discount to its closing price.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks down nearly 2% on US tariffs on China
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted nearly 2% on Friday due to US President Donald Trump's new tariffs on China, affecting investor sentiment. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 1.94% to 21,122.43, while the Topix fell 1.82% to 1,538.87. The yen's rise against the dollar also contributed to the decline. Global sell-offs and uncertainty over the US-China trade tensions dominated market sentiment.

site_title: North Korea fires unidentified short-range projectiles: Yonhap
summary: North Korea fired unidentified short-range projectiles from its eastern coast, according to South Korea's Joint Chiefs of Staff. This is the third round of missile launches in a week, following a warning to South Korea over joint US military drills. The launches come amid heightened tensions between the two countries.

site_title: Trump has 'no problem' with latest North Korean missile tests
summary: US President Donald Trump stated he has "no problem" with North Korea's recent ballistic missile tests, despite international condemnation. The North conducted three tests over the past week, with the latest being two short-range projectiles launched from its east coast. Trump downplayed the tests, saying they were "very standard" and targeting Seoul rather than Washington. The US and South Korea will proceed with joint military drills, despite Pyongyang's call for their cancellation.

site_title: SingPost Q1 earnings jump 37.2% on absence of fair value losses
summary: SingPost reported a 37.2% increase in net profits to S$25.7 million for Q1 2019, driven by improved results from associated companies and joint ventures. The absence of fair value losses from warrants in the prior year's first quarter contributed to the higher earnings. Revenue rose 1% to S$376.4 million, driven by higher International Post and Parcel revenue from e-commerce deliveries. The company declared a 0.50 Singapore cent per share dividend.

site_title: Brutal 48 hours for stock traders caught in the Trump-Powell squeeze
summary: US stocks plummeted over a 48-hour period, with the S&P 500 suffering its worst two-day decline since mid-May, following a statement by President Donald Trump that the US will impose a 10% tariff on $300 billion in Chinese goods starting September 1. The Fed's rate cut on Wednesday was overshadowed by Trump's move, with many investors interpreting it as a deliberate attempt to re-escalate trade tensions and pressure the central bank to reconsider rate reductions. The market's reaction was swift, with the Cboe Volatility Index surging to nearly 18 in just four sessions.

site_title: Pricey truck sales boost GM earnings despite lower volumes
summary: General Motors (GM) reported a 1.2% increase in second-quarter profits, driven by strong demand for pricey, high-end trucks in North America. The company's operating income rose to a record average price of $37,126, despite lower car sales and revenues falling 1.9% to $36.1 billion. GM cited lower costs following a 2018 reorganization and plans to launch upgraded pickup truck models and more light pickups at lower prices to maintain profits.

site_title: Dark Humour
summary: Little Damage, a Los Angeles-based soft-serve ice cream brand, has opened its first outlet outside the USA in Singapore. The shop features dark, gothic-inspired designs and unique flavors such as Unicorn Tears (bright blue) and White Chocolate. Vegan options are also available. To celebrate National Day, the shop will serve red waffle cones from August 5 to 11. The shop is located at Wheelock Place and offers charcoal-coloured knick-knacks for sale.

site_title: Iran says ready for worst in battle to save nuclear deal amid standoff with US
summary: Iran's President Hassan Rouhani has stated the country is prepared for the worst in its battle to save the 2015 nuclear deal, amid a standoff with the US. Iran has retaliated to US sanctions by breaching the deal and resuming uranium enrichment, while facing severe economic damage. Rouhani said Iran will not achieve results through talks and accords, and is instead planning for a long-term, prudential approach. The US has imposed sanctions on Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif, prompting concerns over the escalating tensions in the Middle East and the security of shipping in the Gulf.

site_title: US scientists announce 3D heart printing breakthrough
summary: US scientists have successfully 3D printed functional heart parts using a breakthrough technique that replicates the body's complex biological scaffolds. The method, known as Freeform Reversible Embedding of Suspended Hydrogels (FRESH), uses collagen and living cells to create structures with a resolution of 20 micrometers. The team has built a benchtop system that simulates the human body's pressure and flow rate, and the printed parts have shown synchronized beating and opening and closing of valves. The open-source design allows other labs to replicate the results, paving the way for potential organ printing in the future.

site_title: UK lawmakers want powers for watchdog to police market perimeter
summary: UK lawmakers are calling for the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) to gain powers to police the boundary between regulated and unregulated financial activities, citing the need for greater transparency and consumer protection. The FCA should have the power to recommend changes to the regulatory perimeter and highlight potential risks to consumers. The move comes after the collapse of London Capital & Finance and the rise of unregulated cryptoassets. Lawmakers argue that the FCA should be given formal power to request information from unregulated financial firms, allowing it to take a more proactive approach to regulating the market.

site_title: From phone makers to farmers, the toll of Trump's trade wars
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a 10% tariff on the remaining $300 billion of Chinese imports, set to begin on September 1, amid escalating tensions with China. The move comes after trade talks in Shanghai yielded little progress, with Washington seeking economic reforms, including better protection for intellectual property and access to China's markets. The tariff will hit a range of consumer goods, causing a decline in the S&P 500 and crude oil prices.

site_title: UOB Q2 profit up 8% to S$1.17b, raises interim dividend to 55 S cents
summary: UOB Group reported an 8% year-on-year growth in net profit to S$1.17 billion for its second quarter, driven by strong loan growth and higher trading and investment income. The bank raised its interim dividend to 55 Singapore cents per share, up from 35 cents in 2017. Net interest income rose 7% to S$1.65 billion, while net fee and commission income increased 6% to S$527 million. The bank's funding position and capital base remained strong, with a loan-to-deposit ratio of 88.5% and a common equity Tier 1 capital adequacy ratio of 13.9%.

site_title: Oil slumps 7% as Trump announces additional tariffs on Chinese imports
summary: US oil prices plummeted 7% on Thursday, with Brent crude falling to its lowest level since June 13, after President Donald Trump announced additional 10% tariffs on Chinese imports starting September 1. The tariffs undermined hopes for a detente in the US-China trade dispute, which has weakened global growth. Oil inventories in the US fell, but production remained near a record, and the market is expected to see bearish momentum remain after breaking below critical support levels.

images.alt_text: Oil prices plummeted more than 7 per cent on Thursday, with the US benchmark posting its worst day in more than four years, after President Donald Trump said he would impose additional tariffs Chinese imports starting Sept 1.

site_title: Amazon says French clients to bear cost of new French digital tax
summary: Amazon plans to pass the costs of France's new digital tax on internet giants to businesses using its Marketplace platform, rather than taking the hit itself. The 3% levy, applied retroactively from January 1, targets profits from online sales, advertising, and data sales. The move follows threats of retaliation from US officials, as France becomes a leader in countries imposing taxes on tech firms operating in their markets.

images.alt_text: Amazon plans to pass on the costs of France's new digital tax on internet giants to the businesses that use its Marketplace platform for finding customers, instead of taking the hit itself, the US online retailer said Thursday.

site_title: BreadTalk Q2 earnings fall 58% on bakery woes
summary: BreadTalk Group reported a 57.9% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$1.02 million for the second quarter, driven by a surge in distribution and selling expenses. Revenue grew 9.8% to S$163.3 million, but the bakery division sank into the red. The company plans to focus on expansion in key markets and open its first Song Fa Bak Kut Teh outlet in Taiwan by year-end, despite efforts to turn around the bakery business in China and Thailand.

site_title: Faked Facebook accounts linked to Saudi Arabia, Mideast region
summary: Facebook has removed 378 accounts, 217 pages, 5 groups, and 31 accounts linked to Saudi Arabia and the Mideast region for "coordinated inauthentic behavior" aimed at influencing conversation on the platform. The campaigns, which spent approximately $275,000 on ads, targeted regional news and politics, including Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman and the conflict in Yemen. Facebook's review found links to individuals associated with the Saudi government, and the campaigns used fake accounts and compromised identities to spread content and increase engagement.

images.alt_text: Facebook on Thursday said it derailed a pair of shady online influence campaigns in the Arabic-speaking world including one linked to the Saudi Arabian government.

site_title: New cars vulnerable to hacks that could leave thousands dead: report
summary: A consumer advocacy group has warned that new cars are increasingly vulnerable to hackers, posing a national security threat. The report, "Kill Switch," found that safety-critical systems in connected cars can be linked to the internet without adequate security, leaving thousands of lives at risk. Industry experts estimate that a fleet-wide hack could result in 3,000 deaths. The group recommends that all connected vehicles be equipped with an internet kill switch and that safety-critical systems be isolated from the internet. Automakers are aware of the risk but are prioritizing corporate profit over safety.

site_title: OCBC profit for Q2 up 1% to S$1.2b; H1 dividend raised to 25 S cents per share
summary: OCBC Bank reported a net profit of S$1.22 billion for Q2 2019, up 1% from the same period last year, driven by record earnings from its banking franchise. The bank's annualized earnings per share rose to S$1.15, and an interim dividend of 25 cents per share was declared. Total income increased 6% to S$2.62 billion, with net interest income growing 10% to S$1.59 billion. Despite a 26% decline in life insurance profit, the bank's healthy capital position and liquidity position will enable it to navigate the challenging operating environment.

site_title: Europe: British American Tobacco and financials lift stocks after Federal Reserve blow
summary: European shares ended higher on Thursday, lifted by strong earnings from British American Tobacco and a multibillion dollar merger in the financial sector. The Stoxx 600 rose 0.5% after British American Tobacco beat sales forecasts and predicted a stronger second half. London Stock Exchange Group surged 6.5% to a record high after announcing its $27 billion merger with Refinitiv, boosting the financial services index. The banking sector was also boosted by results from European majors Barclays, Standard Chartered, and Societe Generale.

site_title: The Fed got it just right, even if markets disagree
summary: The Federal Reserve made a quarter-point interest-rate cut, citing a mostly upbeat US growth picture, but also acknowledging global concerns. Chairman Jerome Powell left room for further, limited reductions, citing a global outlook that expects 3.2% growth this year and 3.5% in 2020. The cut was seen as a mid-cycle adjustment, rather than a response to a crisis, and is aimed at insuring against global crosscurrents, including the slowdown in China and the euro zone.

site_title: US: Stocks end lower on Trump's new China tariffs, Dow -1.1%
summary: US stocks ended lower on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 1.1% after President Donald Trump announced new tariffs on $300 billion in Chinese goods. The S&P 500 slid 0.9% and the Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 0.8%. Retailers such as Best Buy, Target, and Macy's were particularly hard hit, with losses ranging from 4.4% to 10.8%. The announcement jolted stocks after the Federal Reserve's interest rate cut, and Trump expressed confidence in the reaction, saying he had anticipated the negative response.

site_title: Dutch bank ING warns against further ECB money printing
summary: ING's head, Ralph Hamers, warns against further ECB money printing, citing the availability of cheap money and the potential pressure on bank profits. He notes that rock-bottom interest rates will impact net interest income, as the bank announced a 1.4 billion euro net profit in the second quarter. European Central Bank President Mario Draghi is set to loosen monetary policy further amid economic deterioration, despite Hamers' concerns.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Jurong Port's next-generation multipurpose port
summary: Jurong Port Pte Ltd, a leading international multipurpose port operator, has launched a joint venture with Oiltanking, Jurong Port Tank Terminals. The new venture aims to reinforce Singapore's status as an international maritime energy and chemicals hub. The development of the new liquid bulk terminal is part of Jurong Port's strategic vision to become a world-class multipurpose port operator. The joint venture will cater to the growing demand for energy and chemicals in the region.

site_title: Signs of an end to the tech slump offer hope to Asia's economies
summary: Signs of an end to the tech slump offer hope to Asia's export-driven economies, with Goldman Sachs economists citing a rebound in technology exports due to gradual improvement in South Korean trade and a low point in the memory-chip cycle. South Korean semiconductor shipments rose 15% by volume in July, while inventories fell for a second month, indicating orders are picking up. This suggests the worst may be over for an electronics slump affecting Asia's economies.

site_title: US to slap 10% tariff on US$300b more in Chinese goods: Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump announced an additional 10% tariff on $300 billion in Chinese goods, effective September 1, escalating the trade war between the two countries. The tariffs will cover virtually all of the US$660 billion in annual trade in merchandise, surpassing the $250 billion already in place. The move comes after China failed to meet Trump's demands, including buying US agricultural products and stopping the sale of fentanyl in the US. The tariffs will significantly impact everyday Chinese-made goods and consumer electronics, potentially hurting the retail sector and the global economy.

site_title: Trees for All Seasons
summary: Lee Kuan Yew's green vision led to the establishment of Tree Planting Day in 1963, with the goal of planting 5,000 trees to induce rain and beautify the environment. The first official event was in 1971, with 52 schools planting 592 trees. The focus shifted to fruit trees in the 1980s, and the launch of Clean and Green Singapore in 1990 encouraged environmentally-friendly activities. Today, Singapore remains known for its lush greenery, with tree-planting continuing as a national effort.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, UOB, Hongkong Land, Dairy Farm, Mandarin Oriental, Hi-P, A-HTrust
summary: Singapore stocks reported mixed results on Friday, with OCBC Bank and UOB Group posting strong earnings. OCBC reported a net profit of S$1.22 billion, up 1%, while UOB Group's net profit rose 8% to S$1.17 billion. Hongkong Land's underlying profit increased 2% to US$466 million, while Dairy Farm International's underlying profit rose 5.4% to US$176.6 million. Mandarin Oriental's underlying net profit plummeted 52% to US$10.7 million. Hi-P International's net profit rose 16.9% to S$14.4 million. A-HTrust's distribution per stapled security fell 5.2% to 1.28 Singapore cents, while LMIRT's distribution per unit increased 1.7% to 0.6 Singapore cents.

site_title: Dairy Farm H1 underlying profit rises 5.4% to US$176.6m
summary: Dairy Farm International's underlying profit rose 5.4% to US$176.6 million for the half-year ended June 30, driven by improved profit margins at Yonghui and investment in Robinsons Retail. Revenue dipped 2.8% to US$5.76 billion due to deconsolidation of Rustan Supercenters. Net profit was flat at US$178 million, while underlying earnings per share increased to 13.05 US cents. An interim dividend of 6.5 US cents per share was declared.

site_title: Spice Tales
summary: Executive Chef Chen Kentaro's cookbook, "A Dash of Szechwan," ranked second in the 'Best Cookbook by a Restaurant Chef' category at the 24th Gourmand World Cookbook Awards. The book, featuring 50 recipes, showcases Chen's signature dishes and family recipes from his grandfather, the 'Father of Szechwan cuisine,' and father, Iron Chef fame. Autographed copies are available exclusively at Shisen Hanten, while regular copies can be found at major bookstores or Amazon.

site_title: HK will survive protests: ARA chief
summary: Hong Kong's economy is expected to slow down due to ongoing protests, with tourists likely to stay away, according to ARA Asset Management group chief executive John Lim. The protests, which began in June, have broadened to include social grievances, but Lim believes the city's strong focus on capitalism and pragmatism will help it survive as protesters eventually run out of resources and energy.

site_title: Ensuring an equitable distribution of US economic prosperity
summary: The US economy is experiencing sluggish growth, with a 2.5% growth rate in 2018 and a possible slowdown to 2.1% in the second quarter of 2019. This poses a challenge for President Donald Trump, who promised economic growth above 3% per year. To address this, the article suggests two ideas: strengthening national manufacturing capabilities through public investments in translational innovation and introducing a public option for essential services such as health insurance, retirement funds, and childcare. These ideas aim to promote equitable distribution of economic prosperity across the country and regions, and to ensure broader participation in future growth.

site_title: Designer Pasar
summary: Design Pasar, a neighborhood gathering place, brings together beloved Singaporean brands like Supermama and Creamier Handcrafted Ice Cream. The event features music performances, retro carnival games, and a retail element, fostering community spirit among creators. Organized by The General Co, Roger&Sons, and Foreign Policy, Design Pasar takes place on Aug 3 from 4pm to 10pm at 115 King George's Avenue, aiming to promote community spirit and creativity among the next generation of designers.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: AMOS Group's CFO Dan Tan Song Boon succeeded Perry Kennedy as CEO, with Tan continuing to be based in Singapore. Kennedy, 57, quit to pursue other opportunities after less than a year in the role. Tan will relinquish his CFO duties and the senior finance team will handle finance matters until a new CFO is appointed.

site_title: Curtain Raiser
summary: "Supervision," a drama about a power struggle between a wheelchair-bound man, his controlling daughter, and a new domestic helper, is re-staged at the Ngee Ann Kongsi Theatre in Funan from August 8 to 18, 2019. The play, nominated for six Life! Theatre Awards 2019, won two awards, including Best Original Script. Directed by Glen Goei and written by Thomas Lim, it features sterling direction and performances, with an effective panopticon-like set design by Wong Chee Wai. Tickets are available from Sistic.

images.alt_text: Supervision runs at The Ngee Ann Kongsi Theatre @ Wild Rice in Funan.

site_title: STB chief aims to grow, anchor Mice events for the long haul
summary: Singapore Tourism Board (STB) chief executive Keith Tan aims to grow and anchor high-profile conferences and exhibitions in the city-state for the long haul. He cited the successful Singapore Airshow and Shangri-la Dialogue as examples, with the goal of attracting thousands of attendees and generating millions in tourism receipts. Tan also emphasized the importance of creating a gaming ecosystem in Singapore, positioning the city-state as a natural base for the development and commercialization of digital and gaming content.

images.alt_text: "Out of every 10 CEOs who come here (for events), hopefully two or three of them will think of Singapore when they want to set up a regional headquarters." - Singapore tourism chief Keith Tan.

site_title: Give aviation time to come up with greener methods of propulsion
summary: Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr expressed concern over the "Greta Effect," a potential impact of climate-conscious campaigner Greta Thunberg's "flygskam" movement on European air travel. The movement, which encourages passengers to opt for eco-friendly modes of transport, has gained traction in northern Europe and could affect European carriers. While its impact on fast-growing Asian air travel markets is uncertain, it could still impact carriers reliant on European markets. Airlines must adapt to greener methods of propulsion to mitigate the risk of this movement.

site_title: No quick fixes in condo defect cases
summary: No quick fixes exist in condo defect cases, as resolving property construction faults is a complex process. Building surveyors, contractors, and lawyers emphasize the need for thorough investigations and liability determination. Homeowners can work with experts to resolve issues, but the road to resolution is often long and challenging.

site_title: Investors worry Fed's rate cut might be a one-off
summary: The US Federal Reserve surprised investors by cutting interest rates 25 basis points for the first time in 11 years during its July meeting. However, the move was largely seen as a knee-jerk reaction, with analysts interpreting Chairman Jerome Powell's speech as a mid-cycle adjustment rather than a long-term easing cycle. Investors were more concerned about Powell's hawkish tone, which suggested the rate cut was not the start of a prolonged easing cycle.

site_title: Building a circular economy will need a collaborative approach. The time to act is now
summary: Singapore has declared 2019 as the "Year Towards Zero Waste" to promote a circular economy model, driven by socially responsible consumption and environmentally friendly strategies. The government aims to turn trash into treasure and reuse resources for as long as possible. Adopting the circular economy model worldwide can result in significant carbon emissions reduction and over $1 trillion in material cost savings by 2025. This collaborative approach is crucial for building a sustainable future, with the benefits of a circular economy model expected to be immense.

site_title: The UK, EU have to end the Brexit saga once and for all
summary: The UK, under new Prime Minister Boris Johnson, has pledged to end the Brexit saga by Halloween. This marks a shift in negotiation strategy, with the UK now telling the EU it intends to leave, regardless of the terms. The EU must respond, and the UK has prepared for a "no-deal" Brexit. Johnson's government aims to solve the issue, unlike his predecessor Theresa May, who faced deadlock in Parliament. The EU's response will be crucial in determining the fate of Brexit.

site_title: In Honour of Singapore
summary: Singaporeans are celebrating National Day with various brands paying tribute to the country. Casio released a limited edition watch designed by local artist SKL0, while Nespresso launched a Singapore Selections pack featuring the Merlion and Sir Stamford Raffles. The pack includes pop-out coasters and recipes for five blends. Other brands, such as Thevar 2.0 and Bank of Singapore, are also participating in the celebration.

images.alt_text: Nespresso has released a Singapore Selections five-sleeve pack.

site_title: Jardine C&C starts scholarship scheme to mark 120 years
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage (JCC) has launched a scholarship scheme to celebrate its 120th anniversary. The Jardine Cycle & Carriage Scholarship will sponsor tuition fees for 70 South-east Asian undergraduates over the next 10 years, with the goal of improving access to education and creating positive social impact. Partnering universities include National University of Singapore, Universitas Indonesia, and others, with selection criteria focusing on academic performance, community involvement, and household income. The scholarships will run in perpetuity or for 8-12 years, with the aim of unlocking the potential of South-east Asian talents and driving regional development.

site_title: YouTube: sounding like the world itself
summary: YouTube has become the primary destination for music consumption, with 1 billion monthly visitors accessing the platform for music. Unlike traditional music streaming services, YouTube's vast, user-generated content and chaotic nature require active engagement and focus. The algorithm-driven platform is both a blessing and a curse, offering personalized recommendations while also pushing users towards distracting content. As a result, YouTube has become a unique listening experience, blurring the lines between music and other media, and challenging traditional notions of music consumption and engagement.

site_title: Moon Walk
summary: Omega released its first numbered edition Speedmaster in 18 carat yellow gold with a rare burgundy bezel in 1969 to celebrate Apollo 11's moon landing. Only 1014 pieces were produced, with numbers 1 and 2 gifted to US President Richard Nixon and Vice President Spiro Agnew, who declined the gifts. The remaining pieces were given to NASA's serving staff, marking a significant milestone in the iconic watch's history.

site_title: Wee Wei Ling
summary: Wee Wei Ling, Executive Director of Pan Pacific Hotels Group, is a 67-year-old pioneer in inclusive hiring and corporate social responsibility. She encourages companies to view CSR as a corporate strategy, focusing on training and employing people with special needs. Ling is the chairperson of Project We Care and founder of Extra.Ordinary People, a performing arts charity. She has also curated a corporate art collection and supports local artists. Ling attributes her high energy to discipline, regular exercise, and maintaining social connections, and emphasizes the importance of simplicity and giving back in life.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is expected to continue benefiting from strong demand for risk management instruments amid uncertain market conditions. Analysts have upgraded their target prices for SGX, citing a 30% dividend yield and potential delays in the introduction of A-share index futures on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. Silverlake Axis is also expected to record robust earnings growth in FY2019, driven by margin expansion and new contracts. Analysts note that a re-rating catalyst could be a higher-than-expected growth in securities daily average value, while a potential earnings downside is a risk if SGX faces competition from the Hong Kong Stock Exchange.

site_title: Spatial Language
summary: Renowned Iranian-born artist and architect Siah Armajani has debuted his solo exhibition in Singapore at NTU CCA Gillman Barracks, showcasing 60 years of his career. The centrepiece of the exhibition is the installation Sacco & Vanzetti Reading Room, a tribute to poets, philosopher, and political activists. The exhibition, running until November 3, 2019, is free to admission and marks Armajani's latest public work following his notable contributions to the 1996 Atlanta Olympics and the Irene Hixon Whitney Bridge in Minneapolis.

site_title: Chinese drugmaker Chipscreen's IPO on Star market sees feverish demand
summary: Chinese drugmaker Chipscreen's initial public offering (IPO) on the Star market saw feverish demand, with shares almost 3,000 times oversubscribed among retail investors. The company's shares were priced at 20.43 yuan per share, or 467.51 times 2018 earnings, and valued at 8.38 billion yuan. The oversubscription would allow Chipscreen to raise 1 billion yuan, 27% more than originally planned, to fund growth and product development.

site_title: Americans can't afford to tune out Trump
summary: The article argues that despite Americans' attempts to filter out President Donald Trump's behavior, his actions have a significant impact on the nation. Trump's tweets and public comments, often criticized for being racist and vulgar, are seen by some as a sign of his true character. Critics argue that Trump's behavior is not presidential and that he should exercise more self-control. The article suggests that the normalization of Trump's misbehavior is a concern, with many Americans seeming to tune out his outrageous behavior, but still holding him accountable for his actions.

site_title: Hi-P product rejig lifts Q2 earnings
summary: Hi-P International, a mainboard-listed contract manufacturer, reported a 16.9% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$14.4 million in its Q2 earnings, driven by improved margins on product mix changes and new product launches. Revenue declined 5.2% to S$286.4 million, but better cost management helped. The company has initiated new projects in Thailand and plans to diversify its business to reduce the impact of the US-China trade war.

site_title: LSE's US$27b Refinitiv deal creates trading powerhouse
summary: The London Stock Exchange Group (LSE) has agreed to acquire Refinitiv in a $27 billion deal, creating a global trading powerhouse. The transaction is expected to complete in the second half of 2020 and will give LSE access to Refinitiv's data and trading services, expanding its reach beyond Europe. The deal will be funded with a $13.5 billion bridge loan and LSE will issue shares. Refinitiv's existing shareholders will retain a 37% stake in the enlarged firm, with the deal expected to produce annual savings of £350 million within five years.

site_title: Gaming doing well, but IRs coming into their own as truly integrated resorts
summary: Singapore's integrated resorts, Marina Bay Sands and Resorts World Sentosa, are expanding with new investments worth S$9 billion. The expansions include a 15,000-seat indoor arena at Marina Bay Sands and two new attractions at Resorts World Sentosa. The moves aim to attract more quality tourists, particularly from countries like India, the Philippines, and Indonesia. The resorts' parent companies, Las Vegas Sands and Genting, are financing the expansions without government funding, indicating they believe it is financially viable. The investments are seen as a step towards the resorts maturing into truly integrated resorts.

site_title: The Uninterrupted Life: Time to put down your phone?
summary: Tech titans including Apple CEO Tim Cook, Bill Gates, and Google's Sameer Samat are urging people to put down their phones. Some Singaporeans, such as blogger Joan Chong, are taking their advice by decluttering their smartphones every other month. Chong groups unused apps into folders and relies on a digital planner to stay organized. She believes apps are designed to be addictive and hindered her goal-achieving progress, so she removed unnecessary apps to maintain a clean and focused life. Many are adopting a more "analogue" approach to organization.

site_title: Euro at 26-month low on US dollar rebound
summary: The euro plummeted to a 26-month low against the US dollar after the Federal Reserve signaled caution on further rate cuts, indicating an end to the lengthy US easing cycle. The move followed the central bank's first rate cut since the financial crisis in response to growing import tariffs and slowing economies. Investors deemed the US rate cut unlikely to be the start of a prolonged economic stimulus, leading to a rebound in the US dollar and a decline in the euro.

site_title: SportCares sets up fund to open up avenues to sport for the underprivileged
summary: SportCares, the philanthropic arm of Sport Singapore, has set aside S$12 million to create opportunities for the underprivileged through its Communities of Care Fund. By 2023, the fund will disburse grants to groups or individuals creating sport-based programs for children, youth, seniors, and those with disabilities or special needs. The fund offers starter grants, development grants, and research grants to support initiatives and research into sport-based programs, aiming to increase access to sports for all segments of society.

site_title: Creator of John Wick to make movies with Japan's Rakuten
summary: Rakuten, Japan's leading web retailer and mobile provider, has partnered with Derek Kolstad, creator of the John Wick movie series, to create a movie production house. The joint venture, Rakuten H Collective Studio, will produce films, music, comics, and games based on its content, with plans to distribute content globally. This move follows similar strategies by e-commerce giants Amazon and Alibaba, aiming to attract more customers and compete with Netflix. Rakuten's founder, Hiroshi Mikitani, has been expanding the company's brand presence overseas through investments and sponsorships.

site_title: Affirma Capital eyes Singapore buyout opportunities
summary: Affirma Capital, a newly spun-off private equity unit of Standard Chartered Bank, is eyeing buyout opportunities in Singapore, focusing on mid-sized, founder-owned firms with potential for regional expansion. The firm's CEO, Nainesh Jaisingh, believes privatisation can help entrepreneurs realise better value for their companies and access institutional expertise for growth. Affirma Capital has announced its first investment in Singapore, a US$50 million stake in Tirupati Medicare, and plans to target Singapore-headquartered consumer brands with expansion potential.

site_title: Epicentre resists creditor's move to put it under judicial management
summary: Epicentre, a Catalist-listed company, has resisted a creditor's move to place it under judicial management. The company filed an affidavit to dispute claims by creditor Goh Chee Hong, citing former director Kenneth Lim's involvement in loans and disputes over debt repayment. Epicentre questioned the origin of a S$5 million loan from LLS Capital and claimed it was used for legitimate business purposes. Trading in the company's shares has been suspended since May 30.

site_title: Amex reaching out to SME sector
summary: American Express has launched a business travel credit card targeting small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), aiming to provide tailored financial products addressing cashflow and security concerns. The move follows the company's recognition of strong growth in the SME segment regionally and globally, which faces challenges in obtaining funding. This initiative is part of Amex's efforts to expand its offerings and change its perception as an imposing brand.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims rise; labour market still tightening
summary: US weekly jobless claims rose 8,000 to 215,000 for the week ended July 27, consistent with a tightening labor market. The Federal Reserve cut interest rates for the first time since 2008, citing downside risks from trade tensions and slowing global growth. Despite a slowdown in job gains, the labor market remains resilient, with economists expecting a 164,000 job increase in July. The unemployment rate is expected to hold steady at 3.7%.

site_title: Shop and Stay
summary: Hotel Indigo's "Shop the Neighbourhood" programme allows guests to purchase unique accessories made by local artisans or reflecting the neighbourhood's location. The programme is available at 100 hotels worldwide, featuring items such as vintage radios, limited edition prints, and miniature Trabant cars. This initiative supports local artisans and provides guests with exclusive, neighbourhood-inspired souvenirs.

site_title: Australian home prices find a floor; outlook improves
summary: Australian home prices rose 0.1% in June, marking a second consecutive month of gains, despite record household debt and slow wage growth. Economists remain cautious, predicting a "constrained" recovery, and warn that rate cuts and modest price gains may not boost consumption. The central bank's interest rate cuts have started to show effects, but a full recovery is still distant, with housing stock valued at nearly four times Australia's GDP. A slowdown in wage rises and an increasing supply of new apartments may keep home prices in check.

site_title: Wine And Dine On National Day
summary: To celebrate Singapore's 54th birthday, various restaurants and hotels have prepared special National Day-themed dining options. Pan Pacific Singapore offers a Pacific Club Lounge Package with exclusive access to the Pacific Club Lounge and 360-degree views of the Singapore skyline. Tablescape features a five-course menu priced at S$48, while Braci offers a five-course menu for S$154. LeVeL33 has created a special Black Glutinous Rice Beer for the occasion. Other options include a Peranakan Food & Fine Wine Masterclass, Zafferano's outdoor Terrace Lounge with a free-flow package, and Saint Pierre's Michelin-quality dinner with a star-studded view.

site_title: Newcomers up the ante in governance index for trusts
summary: The Governance Index for Trusts (GIFT) 2019 ranked 46 Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (Reits) and business trusts, with four new entrants: Cromwell European Reit, Keppel-KBS US Reit, NetLink NBN Trust, and Sasseur Reit. Keppel-KBS US Reit and NetLink NBN Trust debuted at No. 6, while Cromwell European Reit and Sasseur Reit debuted at No. 12.

site_title: Ascendas H-Trust DPS falls after China sale bonanza
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust, a Singapore-based company, will pay a lower distribution per stapled security (DPS) of 1.28 Singapore cents in the first quarter due to the absence of one-off proceeds from the sale of two Beijing hotels last year. This represents a 5.2% decrease from the previous quarter. The move is attributed to the trust's exit from the Chinese market.

site_title: BAT forecasts faster revenue growth on e-cigarette and oral products
summary: British American Tobacco (BAT) reported a 4.6% increase in first-half revenue to £12.2 billion, beating analyst forecasts. Growth was driven by e-cigarettes and tobacco-heating products, with revenue from these categories rising 27% to £531 million. BAT expects revenue growth from new categories to accelerate in the second half of the year, with its adjusted earnings per share beating analyst estimates. The company also secured a £3.4 billion pension fund deal, securing benefits for 10,600 members.

site_title: China's July PMI nudges up but numbers are still in contraction
summary: China's manufacturing sector showed signs of recovery in July, with the Caixin Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) reaching 49.9, up from 49.4 in June. However, the official PMI also edged up slightly to 49.7. Despite these modest improvements, analysts warn that manufacturers will remain under pressure due to the ongoing trade war, advocating for further stimulus measures. China's economy has been experiencing a slowdown, with quarterly growth reaching a record low in the April-June period, and more stimulus measures are expected this year to mitigate the negative impact of the trade war.

site_title: Cool Cats
summary: The Japanese department store Takashimaya hosts an exhibition of 200 Lucky Cats in Singapore's bicentennial year, with 200 unique interpretations of the feline figure designed by ITE students. The cats, up for auction, will benefit aspiring young artists and ITE students through various funds. Designs range from iconic Singaporean figures, such as ah-ma, Orchid Kitty, and prata sellers, to traditional Malay and Samsui women, and even a Singaporean bus captain. The exhibition runs until August 12.

site_title: Reits, trusts improve governance, but some lapses draw regulator's ire
summary: Singapore's Governance Index for Trusts (GIFT) shows real estate investment trusts (Reits) and business trusts improving their governance and business risk score since 2017, with new entrants like Netlink NBN Trust achieving top scores. However, some trusts regressed in performance, citing compliance as a reason for stopping certain practices. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) expressed concern over the lack of transparency in remuneration disclosures and the right to vote on director appointments, warning that such steps are "unacceptable" and must be addressed to maintain confidence in the sector.

site_title: US understands Singapore's position on WTO privileges: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing stated that the country has an understanding with the US that it does not use privileges as a developing country in the World Trade Organization. A recent letter from US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer confirmed this, showing the US understands Singapore retained the label but did not utilize the benefits. Chan expressed confidence in Singapore's economic outlook, despite short-term output fluctuations, and highlighted the government's focus on long-term strategies, including upgrading local workers' skills and attracting global top-tier talent.

site_title: Ezion likely to post 'significant net loss' in the year to date, board warns
summary: Ezion Holdings, a debt-stricken offshore and marine group, is expected to post a significant net loss in the year to date due to challenging market conditions and reduced reactivation and deployment plans. The company has assessed asset impairments, but a value has not been determined. Trading in Ezion shares has been suspended since March. A preliminary review of unaudited financial results will be released on or around August 8, providing a more detailed outlook.

site_title: Indonesia plans overhaul of rules to develop electric car hub
summary: Indonesia is planning to introduce incentives for electric car manufacturers and buyers, aiming to accelerate the adoption of battery-powered cars and build a base for production and export. The measures include lower taxes and benefits such as special parking areas. The country seeks to become a dominant force in South-east Asia's electric vehicle market, with EVs constituting a quarter of its car production by 2030. Global companies like Toyota, Hyundai, and SoftBank have already committed billions of dollars in investment, with Indonesian President Joko Widodo set to sign the decree once it receives his approval.

site_title: Truly Amazing
summary: The critically acclaimed documentary "Amazing Grace" is screening exclusively at The Projector, showcasing Aretha Franklin's 1972 performance at the New Temple Missionary Baptist Church in Los Angeles with the Southern Californian Community Choir. The film, which features cameos by Mick Jagger and Charlie Watts, was captured by filmmaker Sydney Pollack but remained in a vault for over four decades before its release. The documentary is a rare glimpse into Franklin's gospel classics, including her 10-minute rendition of "Amazing Grace," which was released as a live album in 1972.

site_title: Great Eastern Q2 net profit down 29% on non-operating losses
summary: Great Eastern Holdings' second-quarter net profit fell 29% to S$169 million due to non-operating losses of S$26 million, largely attributed to higher valuation of long-term insurance contract liabilities. Despite this, the company's operating profit rose 3% to S$161.7 million. Earnings per share decreased to S$0.36, while an unchanged interim dividend of 10 Singapore cents per share was declared. Total weighted new sales fell 9% to S$299.9 million, but the company's net profit for the first six months of 2019 rose 31% to S$511.7 million.

site_title: Dalian takes unusual steps to contain home prices
summary: Dalian, China's most developed city, has implemented unusual measures to control home prices. All home builders must now seek sales approval by inputting apartment prices into a centralized computer system, with prices limited to 5% below the bottom price for similar dwellings sold in May and June. Developers who fail to comply will be banned from the city. This is part of China's efforts to regulate the real-estate sector, with previous restrictions including restrictions on non-local buyers and those in certain life circumstances. The measures aim to curb price inflation.

site_title: Executive performance and rewards: Keeping up with changing global trends
summary: A growing demand for transparency on social impact is driving companies to adopt responsible investing, incorporating environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors into investment decisions. This approach is beneficial for both businesses and the community. Boards of directors have a collective responsibility to manage stakeholder needs, including consumers, society, and shareholders. They must define performance, set clear expectations, and articulate the company's values and vision. The role of boards is to oversee management, challenge initiatives, and communicate with stakeholders. Effective boards can fuel collaboration and drive long-term strategy, supporting sustainable and social impact.

site_title: A good show by La Dame de Pic at Raffles
summary: La Dame de Pic, a French restaurant by Anne-Sophie Pic, has opened at Raffles Singapore with a unique blend of fine French cuisine and Asian influences. The restaurant's elegant space features a contemporary vibe, with a focus on local nuances and ingredients. Lunch offers a refreshing introduction to Pic-style cuisine, with dishes such as honeycomb and yuzu bon bons. However, the main courses can be hit-or-miss, with some dishes standing out more than others. The restaurant's desserts, including whipped chocolate and pina colada creations, are a highlight. Overall, La Dame de Pic is a promising start to the hotel's culinary offerings, with a cast of engaging staff and elegant cuisine.

site_title: CapitaLand Retail China Trust to issue 191.9m new units to fund mall buys
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust plans to issue 191.9 million new units, raising S$273.4-279.4 million in a private placement and preferential offering. The funds will be used to purchase three shopping centers in Harbin and Changsha. Existing unitholders will receive 87 new units for every 1,000 held, while institutional investors will get 105 million new units at between S$1.428-1.469 apiece. The trust aims to raise S$268.4 million, with net proceeds going towards the S$505.4 million purchase.

site_title: Home of port now producing reds and whites that are surprisingly good
summary: A modern winery in Vila Seca, Portugal's Douro Valley, is producing high-quality red and white wines, including a rare 2018 Xisto Cru Branco made from the obscure rabigato grape. Luis Seabra's blend of rabigato with côdega, gouveio, and viosinho grapes results in a gorgeous white wine. This is a significant achievement, as rabigato is grown almost nowhere else in the world. The winery's success marks a new chapter for this small town's wine industry.

site_title: Bombardier reports loss in Q2 amid issues with rail contracts
summary: Bombardier reported a loss of $36 million in Q2, exceeding analyst expectations, due to delays in fulfilling rail contracts. The company revised its earnings forecast to $1.2-$1.3 billion, down from $1.5-1.65 billion. Revenue was up 1% at $4.3 billion. Bombardier will invest $250-300 million in its transportation division to complete legacy projects and protect delivery schedules. The company has also sold its Q Series turboprop line and CRJ Series regional jet program.

site_title: US: Wall Street muted at open as focus shifts to mixed earnings
summary: US stocks opened cautiously on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.06% and the S&P 500 nearly flat. The Nasdaq Composite gained 0.19%. The focus shifted from the Federal Reserve's interest rate message, which led to significant falls in the previous session. Investors are now monitoring corporate earnings, which have been mixed, and US-EU trade talks. Despite tariff uncertainty, the Singapore Stock Index rose 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Twitter CEO account hacked, offensive tweets posted
summary: Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey's account was hacked, posting racial slurs and a tweet supporting Nazi Germany. The account was compromised around 2000 GMT on Friday, with some tweets containing the hashtag #ChucklingSquad. Twitter is investigating and has called for two-factor authentication to prevent similar incidents in the future. Experts say the hack highlights the importance of security measures, with cybersecurity researcher Kevin Beaumont attributing the hack to a third-party app called Cloudhopper.

site_title: Homes sprout in US flood zones despite rising sea levels
summary: Despite rising sea levels, new homes are being built at faster rates in high-flood risk areas along the US coastlines. According to Climate Central, one-third of coastline states with a 10% risk of ocean inundation by 2050 saw new housing construction rates higher than on safer ground. States like Connecticut, New Jersey, Rhode Island, and others have seen significant growth in high-risk zones, with millions of dollars in housing investments. Experts warn that this trend is disheartening, highlighting the need for incentives to encourage people to live further from the coastline.

site_title: Hong Leong, TPG in advanced talks to buy Asian hospital operator
summary: A group of investors, including Hong Leong Group and TPG Capital, are in advanced talks to buy Asian hospital operator Columbia Asia for $1.2 billion, excluding operations in India. The deal could value the hospital business, which has 29 medical facilities across Malaysia, Vietnam, Indonesia, and India, at $1.2 billion. Other healthcare companies and buyout firms have expressed interest in acquiring the assets, following similar deals in the region. The sale process is ongoing and could still fall apart.

site_title: BreadTalk Q2 net profit drops 57.9% amid costs of expansion drive
summary: BreadTalk Group, a Singapore-listed food and beverage operator, reported a 57.9% drop in Q2 net profit to S$1.02 million due to expansion-related costs, despite a 9.8% increase in revenue to S$163.3 million. Higher distribution and selling expenses outweighed growth in bakery, food atrium, restaurant, and "4orth" food concept businesses.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release. Meanwhile, Grab's earnings growth is expected to slow in H2, prompting CGS-CIMB Securities to downgrade the company to 'hold'. OCBC announced the retirement of CEO Helen Wong, with Tan Teck Long to take over. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay rose 30.5% to S$3.1 million. China's GDP growth is forecast to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Tesla marked its formal entry into India with a Mumbai launch event, and Citigroup set a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index.

site_title: Asian markets ease on Powell's comments
summary: Asian markets, including Singapore's Straits Times Index, closed lower on Thursday, but to a lesser extent than on Wall Street, following the US Federal Reserve's rate cut of 25 basis points. Despite Chairman Jerome Powell's hawkish statements, Asian investors were less affected, with Japan and Malaysia bucking the trend. The US-China trade talks also ended early, adding to economic growth concerns. Financials had a mixed day, with some stocks, such as Singtel and StarHub, rising, while others, like OCBC Bank, fell. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) saw its shares finish lower, but analysts remain optimistic about its earnings.

site_title: Asia's highest-yield bonds slide after Fed's hawkish signal
summary: Asia's highest-yield bonds, including those in Indonesia and India, slid after Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell signaled a hawkish stance on interest-rate cuts, indicating that aggressive rate cuts in high-yield markets may not be imminent. The yield on Indonesia's 10-year bonds jumped 9 basis points to 7.46%, while India's benchmark debt rose 4 basis points to 6.41%. Asian central banks, including those in Saudi Arabia and the UAE, cut their benchmark interest rates by 25 basis points following the Fed's decision.

site_title: Former NSA contractor Edward Snowden publishing memoir
summary: Former NSA contractor Edward Snowden is publishing a memoir titled "Permanent Record" on September 17, 2019. Snowden, who leaked classified documents in 2013, is being praised as a whistleblower and privacy advocate. The US accuses him of endangering national security, with espionage charges that could lead to decades in prison. Snowden's memoir is being published globally by Macmillan Publishers, with CEO John Sargent calling it an "incredible American story" that highlights the importance of individual courage and the need for privacy.

site_title: Not Your Average Joe
summary: Coffee aficionados in Singapore are willing to pay a premium for high-quality, specialty coffee. The third wave coffee movement, which emphasizes unique flavor profiles and artisanal production, has gained popularity among locals and tourists alike. Prices, however, remain a concern, with some specialty coffee shops charging up to S$8 for a single shot. Experts attribute the rising costs to factors such as high-quality sourcing, specialized roasting and brewing methods, and fair trade practices. As demand for specialty coffee continues to grow, some shops are introducing cupping sessions and coffee appreciation courses to educate customers about the complexities of coffee.

site_title: Hi-P International posts 16.9% rise in Q2 net profit on cost controls
summary: Hi-P International, a mainboard-listed electronics contract manufacturer, posted a 16.9% rise in Q2 net profit to S$14.4 million, driven by cost controls and improved margins. Revenue declined 5.2% due to price pressure and lower sales from some customers. The company attributed the decline to a loss-making flexible printed circuit board business, which was partially offset by increased demand from other segments. Hi-P aims to diversify its business and increase sales in new markets, including the medical and automotive industries.

site_title: LMIRT raises Q2 DPU by 1.7% to 0.6 S cent after debt rejig
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) has raised its second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) by 1.7% to 0.6 Singapore cent, driven by a 4% increase in distributable income and 1.9% rise in net property income. The trust's gross revenue jumped 29.7% to S$68.3 million, despite a 5.8% drop in gross rental income. LMIRT's all-Indonesia portfolio comprises 23 shopping centers, with occupancy at 92.2% and a weighted average lease expiry of 4.31 years.

site_title: Pompeo criticises China after meeting top diplomat in Bangkok
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo criticized China's actions in Asia, including "coercion" of Southeast Asian neighbors in the South China Sea and dam-building on the Mekong River. The comments came during a meeting in Bangkok of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean), highlighting the US-China divide. Pompeo's remarks were seen as a challenge to China's growing influence in the region.

site_title: Mandarin Oriental H1 underlying net profit slides 52% to US$10.7m
summary: Mandarin Oriental's underlying net profit for the first half of 2019 fell 52% to US$10.7 million, driven by a 8% decline in revenue due to the closure of The Excelsior in Hong Kong and a Bangkok hotel undergoing renovation. The group posted a net loss of US$12.1 million, with loss per share at 0.96 US cents. Despite a mixed performance, the company expects to benefit from reopened hotels and new developments, with an interim dividend of 1.50 US cents per share declared.

site_title: Finance employees in Hong Kong stage a flash mob
summary: Finance employees in Hong Kong staged a flash mob protest in Chater Garden, near major financial firms, in response to the arrest of protesters charged with colonial-era rioting. The nearly 30-minute event, attended by hundreds, featured chants and silent protest. The move is part of a growing movement in the city, which has seen increasingly creative demonstrations. Pro-democracy groups have criticized the charges, which carry a 10-year prison sentence. The protest highlights ongoing unrest in Hong Kong.

site_title: Gold drops as investors try to make sense of 'an unclear Fed'
summary: Gold prices fell for a second day, staying above $1,400 an ounce, after the Federal Reserve signaled it won't embark on a lengthy easing cycle following the first US rate cut since the financial crisis. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell's remarks on the Fed's path ahead were unclear, causing market volatility. Two Fed rate-setters dissented, with economist Howie Lee stating an "unclear Fed" means confused markets and high volatility in the near term.

site_title: Facebook says it dismantles covert influence campaign tied to Saudi government
summary: Facebook has suspended over 350 accounts and pages with 1.4 million followers, linked to the Saudi government, in a covert influence campaign promoting state propaganda and attacking regional rivals. The network, which spent over $100,000 on ads, targeted countries in the Middle East and North Africa, including Qatar and the UAE. Facebook's head of cybersecurity policy confirmed the link to the Saudi government, citing it as a "significant" operation. This marks one of the few times Facebook has directly linked a government to "coordinated inauthentic behaviour" on its platform.

site_title: Japan's solid factory output masks trouble as retail sales slump
summary: Japan's industrial output rebounded 1.3% in July, but retail sales declined sharply, signaling a bumpy road for the economy. Despite strong household spending and capital expenditure, the country's export-reliant economy faces growing global strains, including the US-China trade war. Manufacturers expect output to rise 1.3% in August but fall 1.6% in September, leading some economists to predict a flat GDP growth. The economy's resilience is also threatened by weak business sentiment and a slowdown in overseas demand.

images.alt_text: A worker cycling near a factory at the Keihin industrial zone in Kawasaki, Japan. Industrial output rose 1.3 per cent in July, but it hardly recouped the sharp 3.3 per cent drop in the previous month.

site_title: TikTok's parent pushes into search business in threat to Baidu
summary: ByteDance, the parent company of TikTok, is launching a search engine business in China, a threat to Baidu's dominant position in the country's lucrative internet search market. ByteDance aims to create a "general search engine" for a better user experience, following its aggressive recruitment of top tech talent. This move could disrupt Baidu's advertising business, which has fueled its profit for years. The launch marks a significant challenge for Baidu, which has held a de facto monopoly in the Chinese search market since Google's exit in 2010.

site_title: Hongkong Land H1 underlying profit up 2% to US$466m
summary: Hongkong Land reported a 2% year-on-year rise in underlying profit to US$466 million for the first half of 2019, driven by increased contributions from investment and development properties. Despite net losses of US$55 million from revaluation, profit attributable to shareholders was US$411 million. The company declared an unchanged interim dividend and expects solid performance from investment properties in the second half of the year, with higher profits from development properties in mainland China.

site_title: Partners in Style
summary:
Here are concise summaries of the articles:

1. Fendi teams up with K-pop star Jackson Wang for a unisex capsule collection, blending Wang's streetwear style with Fendi's Italian heritage. The collection is available from August 5 at the Fendi boutique in Marina Bay Sands.

2. Alber Elbaz's "Tod's Happy Moments" collection features accessories with bold colors and playful designs. The iconic driving shoes are transformed into travel-handy ballerina pumps, and the collection is now available at all Tod's boutiques.

3. Gucci collaborates with Dover Street Market on a limited-edition collection that explores Gucci's relationship with color, pattern, and embroidery. The collection is now available at Dover Street Market Singapore.

4. Simone Rocha's Moncler Genius collection features classic designs with a touch of quirky femininity, inspired by girl guide uniforms. The collection is now available at the Moncler Marina Bay Sands flagship store.

5. Hugo Boss teams up with former One Direction singer-songwriter Liam Payne to create an exclusive capsule collection, featuring personal design references and unisex pieces. The collection is now open at ION Orchard Level 1 Atrium.

site_title: Ascendas Hospitality Trust Q1 DPS falls 5.2% to 1.28 S cents
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust reported a 5.2% decline in distribution per stapled security (DPS) for Q1 2019 to 1.28 Singapore cents. Despite lower DPS, distributable income from operations rose 6.4% to S$15.6 million. Net property income increased 13.6% to S$21.3 million, driven by contributions from five new hotels in Japan and South Korea. The trust expects full-year income from these hotels to outweigh lost contributions from sold properties in China.

site_title: Factory pain spreads through Asia, Europe; stimulus expected
summary: Factory activity in Asia and Europe contracted in July, with the euro zone experiencing its steepest decline since 2012, and Germany's manufacturers facing a deepening recession. The US manufacturing sector expanded, but at its weakest pace in nearly three years. Central banks, including the European Central Bank and the Bank of Japan, are expected to ease monetary policy in response, but have limited room to maneuver. The US-China trade war and economic slowdown fuel concerns of a global recession, with the World Bank and others warning of a prolonged slowdown.

site_title: Bank of England lowers UK growth forecasts for 2019, 2020
summary: The Bank of England lowered its UK growth forecasts for 2019 and 2020, citing continued uncertainty over Brexit. The central bank now expects 1.3% growth for both years, down from previous forecasts of 1.5% and 1.6%. A "no-deal" Brexit would likely lead to a weaker pound, higher inflation, and slower GDP growth, according to the committee's minutes. The decision was made despite the appointment of new Prime Minister Boris Johnson, who promised to deliver Brexit by October 31.

site_title: Dairy Farm H1 underlying profit rises 5.4% to US$176.6m
summary: Dairy Farm International's underlying profit rose 5.4% to US$176.6 million for the half-year ended June 30, driven by improved profit margins at Yonghui and additional contributions from investment in Robinsons Retail. Revenue dipped 3% to US$5.76 billion, while net profit remained flat at US$178 million. Sales from supermarkets and hypermarkets increased 8.8%, with convenience store operations growing in China and North Asia. An interim dividend of 6.50 US cents per share was declared.

site_title: IHH Healthcare's Q2 earnings up 12% on higher turnover
summary: IHH Healthcare's Q2 earnings rose 12% to RM185m due to higher revenue and the adoption of the MFRS 16 Leases accounting standard.
