Revenue increased 37% to RM3.6 billion, driven by organic growth and new hospital acquisitions. However, excluding exceptional items, net profit would have decreased by 6% due to higher financing costs and a high base in the same period last year. The group remains confident in its turnaround plan for Fortis in India and is diversifying its earnings base in cash-generative markets.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.20 points to 1,639.07. The market saw 2.5 billion lots worth RM2 billion, with losers beating gainers 482 to 350. This follows a broader Asian market trend, where traders are brushing off new US President Trump's threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Where port reigns, unfortified wines undergo a stylistic evolution
summary: In the Douro Valley, Portugal, a stylistic evolution is underway, as unfortified wines undergo a transformation, moving away from the traditional port style. Small, independent producers like Luis Seabra are making fresh, vivacious white wines and lighter, more elegant reds. The region's historic port production is being reevaluated, with many producers exploring table wines. Climate change and shifting consumer demand are driving this shift, with producers focusing on varietal wines and more precise viticulture. While still, some producers, like Quinta do Noval, are sticking to traditional port styles, the trend is towards lighter, more elegant wines.

site_title: Iran says US sanctioning of top diplomat "childish" as tensions rise
summary: Iran has denounced US sanctions on its foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, as "childish behavior" driven by fear, amid rising tensions between the two countries over Gulf shipping and Iran's nuclear program. The US imposed sanctions on Zarif after the US dropped out of the 2015 nuclear deal with Iran and revived sanctions on the country. Iran has retaliated by resuming uranium enrichment and Iran's President Hassan Rouhani has accused the US of resorting to "childish behavior" and violating its claims of liberty and democracy.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng Q2 earnings cut by two-thirds amid foray into education
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corp reported a net profit of S$3.99 million for Q2, down two-thirds from the same period last year, due to lower revenue in its core real estate and construction businesses. Revenue fell 7.2% year-on-year to S$237.4 million, with hospitality being the only division to post growth. The company plans to expand its education arm with an Australian pre-school, while maintaining a selective approach to replenishing its land bank and adopting competitive pricing strategies in its Singapore property development business.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's trusts saw improved corporate governance, with the Governance Index for Trusts (Gift) 2019 increasing to 68.0 from 62.2 in 2017. US President Donald Trump expressed concerns over countries abusing WTO privileges, but Singapore's Minister for Trade & Industry Chan Chun Sing clarified the country has not abused such benefits. The American Express Singapore Airlines Business Credit Card was launched for SMEs, and Epicentre resisted a creditor's application for judicial management. Meanwhile, Singapore shares fell 0.3% due to the Federal Reserve's commitment to a rate cut, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Engaging tomorrow's customers: The opportunity in ASEAN
summary: ASEAN is experiencing significant demographic and technological shifts, with 60% of its population under 35 years old and high smartphone penetration. This has led to a growing demand for simple, accessible, and intelligent digital banking services. To stand out, banks must prioritize customer experience, understanding the customer's point of view, and adapting to their needs. Innovative solutions, such as AI-driven credit assessment and data-driven personalization, are emerging to make banking more accessible and engaging. As a result, omni-channel and mobile-only banking platforms are likely to co-exist, with banks needing to tailor their services to distinct customer segments.

site_title: Magnus Energy's Q4 loss widens to S$16.2m
summary: Magnus Energy reported a widening Q4 net loss of S$16.2 million, from S$13.5 million in the same period last year, due to the winding down of its oil and gas equipment distribution segment. Revenue fell 23.4% to S$4.5 million, and the company expects funds from a capital reduction to support working capital. The group is focusing on its oilfield equipment supplies and services segment, and is exploring options for its microalgae crude oil production plant, which was initially intended as a renewable energy source.

site_title: UK PM boosts no-deal Brexit spending ahead of local election test
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson has announced an additional £2.1 billion to prepare for a potential no-deal Brexit ahead of a crucial by-election test in September. The funding will support a public information campaign and border preparations, with a parliamentary showdown looming. The move aims to reduce the risk of a no-deal Brexit and bolster Johnson's government. The by-election, which could reduce the parliamentary majority to one, will be a significant test of Johnson's leadership and ability to manage the Brexit process.

site_title: Campari finds buyer for exclusive French villa at 200m euros
summary: Campari has reached a preliminary agreement to sell its exclusive French villa, Villa Les Cedres, on the French Riviera for 200 million euros. The villa, surrounded by a 14-hectare botanical garden, was acquired by Campari as part of its 2016 purchase of the Grand Marnier Group. The sale is expected to close by the end of October, pending conditions including the departure of a family member. The villa, owned by the Marnier-Lapostolle family since the 1920s, was previously listed for 350 million euros.

site_title: Singapore's trusts put in better corporate governance showing, but lapses still evident
summary: Singapore's listed real estate investment trusts (Reits) and business trusts have improved their corporate governance and business risk management, according to the third edition of the Governance Index for Trusts (Gift). The average combined governance and business risk score increased from 62.2 in 2017 to 68.0 in 2019. This improvement is a result of better management practices, with the average score rising by 3.8 points from 2018. However, lapses in governance and risk management are still evident, indicating room for further improvement in the sector.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower after Fed rate cut
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Thursday, following Wall Street losses after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.76% to 27,565.70, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.81% to 2,908.77. Investors expressed caution about future rate cuts, despite the Fed's decision.

site_title: Singapore Reits could see more growth on possible rule change: analysts
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore considers loosening debt rules for real estate investment trusts (Reits), allowing them to take on up to 50% debt, up from 45%. Analysts say this change will enable Reits to access cheaper and faster funding for acquisitions, making them more competitive globally. The new measures are expected to drive higher distribution per unit and help level the playing field in property acquisitions.

site_title: Siemens pins hopes on rail as manufacturing gloom hits home
summary: Siemens reported a six percent year-on-year decline in net profits to 1.1 billion euros in its third quarter, despite a two percent increase in revenues to 21.3 billion euros. The company attributed the decline to global manufacturing woes, but remains confident in reaching full-year targets.

site_title: No EU consensus on new IMF chief to replace Lagarde: French govt
summary: The European Union has failed to reach a consensus on a candidate to replace Christine Lagarde as head of the International Monetary Fund. French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire has held conference calls with EU counterparts to discuss the process, but no name has been agreed upon. Several European candidates, including Spain's Nadia Calvino and former Dutch finance minister Jeroen Dijsselbloem, have been considered. A European is typically chosen for the IMF post, while an American heads the World Bank. Lagarde was tapped to head the European Central Bank, making the IMF position vacant.

site_title: London Lab advances use of AI in health care, but raises privacy concerns
summary: A London lab is advancing the use of AI in healthcare, aiming to identify acute kidney disease in its early stages. Acute kidney injury, or AKI, affects 1 in 5 hospital patients and contributes to nearly 300,000 US deaths annually. The lab's AI system can analyze patient data and detect AKI before symptoms appear. However, concerns have been raised about the potential for AI to compromise patient privacy. Researchers are working to balance the benefits of AI in healthcare with the need to protect sensitive patient information.

site_title: Marriott hotels ditching small plastic toiletry bottles
summary: Marriott International, the world's largest hotel chain, plans to ditch single-use toiletry bottles as part of efforts to reduce environmental impact. Instead, the company will use larger pump-action bottles containing 10-12 times the amount of shampoo, conditioner, or bath gel. These bottles will be removed by staff when low and sent for recycling, although many US municipalities currently send plastic marked for recycling to landfills or incinerators. The move is expected to prevent approximately 500 million tiny bottles from going to landfills annually, a 30% reduction from current amenity plastic usage.

site_title: Asia: Markets in retreat on trade uncertainty
summary: Asian markets declined on Thursday as investors grew increasingly pessimistic about the outlook for China-US trade talks, with a closely watched recession indicator hitting a level not seen since the financial crisis. The US and China had imposed tariffs on hundreds of billions of goods, and despite a phone call between top officials, analysts warn the strategy is undermining market confidence. The pound remained under pressure due to Prime Minister Boris Johnson's decision to suspend parliament, heightening the prospect of a no-deal Brexit.

site_title: Croatian tech firm that makes Uber calls private weighs US IPO
summary: Croatian tech firm Infobip is considering a US initial public offering (IPO) as it plans to expand in the US market. The company, which provides corporate notification technology, has 1,750 employees and generated 435 million euros in revenue in 2018. Infobip sees the US as a key growth area, particularly against US-focused Twilio, and aims to bolster its presence in the US by opening an office in New York. A public listing would provide liquidity and better exposure for the company, according to CEO Silvio Kutic.

site_title: Refocus on the core
summary: Franklin Resources' president and COO Jennifer Johnson emphasizes the need for the industry to focus on growth, as investors are seeking it. Johnson, an advocate for gender equality, believes a more inclusive environment would allow women to choose their career paths freely. She draws inspiration from her mother, who pursued a medical degree after raising seven children. Johnson's goal is to create an environment where women feel confident to work or choose not to, mirroring her mother's example.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks edge down on US-China worries
summary: Tokyo stocks closed marginally lower, down 0.09% to 20,460.93, due to uncertainty surrounding US-China trade talks and concerns about a no-deal Brexit. Despite bargain-hunting, investors remained wary, citing undervalued stocks. Energy shares rose, driven by oil explorer Inpex's 0.21% gain. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell, while Toyota shares rose 0.01% after announcing a nearly five-per-cent stake in Suzuki Motor.

site_title: UK alone will be to blame for no-deal Brexit: EU tells Johnson
summary: The European Union has told UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson that Britain will be solely to blame if it leaves the EU without a deal on October 31, as fears grow of a chaotic "no-deal" Brexit. EU leaders have challenged Johnson to come up with workable alternatives to the Irish backstop arrangements, which he insists must be changed. The EU is prepared for a "no-deal" scenario, but will do everything to avoid it, according to European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker. Johnson remains adamant that changes must be made to the withdrawal agreement.

site_title: Lawyers on boards - going beyond the 'legal' label
summary: Lawyers should downplay their legal credentials to become board members, focusing on business, management, and leadership skills instead. This shift is driven by the changing landscape of the legal industry, where technology and non-lawyer providers are disrupting traditional practices. Other professionals, such as accountants, have successfully transitioned to boards, while business leaders and politicians are also making the move. However, lawyers are still limited to advisory roles on boards, indicating a need for a broader definition of expertise in board selection.

site_title: South Korea slams Japan as 'white list' removal takes effect
summary: South Korea has strongly criticized Japan for removing it from the "white list" of trusted trade partners, labeling Prime Minister Shinzo Abe as treating the neighbor as an "adversary". The move, effective Wednesday, comes amid a long-running diplomatic dispute over Japan's use of forced labor during its colonial rule. Seoul has announced it will reciprocate and terminate a military intelligence-sharing pact, raising concerns in Washington. The US has expressed disappointment, while South Korea insists the move won't lead to fissures in the alliance. The dispute is heavily influenced by Japan's 35-year colonial rule of the Korean peninsula.

site_title: Singapore shares fall 0.3% on Thursday after Fed commits to rate cut
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.3% lower on Thursday, following the US Federal Reserve's 25 basis point rate cut. Asian markets were muted, with Australia, China, Hong Kong, and South Korea closing lower, while Japan and Malaysia bucked the trend. Financials had a mixed day, with Singtel rising and DBS Group Holdings increasing, while OCBC Bank and United Overseas Bank fell. Bourse operator Singapore Exchange (SGX) finished lower, despite upgrades from DBS Equity Research.

site_title: Longer lives, longer careers?
summary: Singapore is recalibrating its retirement age to 65 by 2030, with plans to raise the retirement age to 70 by 2030 and increase Central Provident Fund (CPF) contribution rates for workers aged 55-70. However, a study found that even with longer life expectancy, Singaporeans are likely to spend 10 years of their lives in ill health. Rising medical inflation poses a challenge, with Singapore's medical cost inflation rising 10% last year. Experts advocate for preventative healthcare as a key strategy to keep costs in check and promote healthy ageing. Despite the benefits of longer work horizons, younger Singaporeans are not taking proactive steps to prevent chronic conditions, highlighting the need for education and awareness.

site_title: Shaping cyber secure SMEs
summary: Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can significantly improve their cyber security without breaking the bank. SMEs need to prioritize cyber security as a business issue, not just an IT concern. Experts recommend that SMEs focus on three key pillars: protecting core business assets, making cyber security everyone's business, and investing in the right balance of people, process, and technology. Simple steps such as regular password changes, firewall checks, and staff education can also help reduce cyber risk exposure. By adopting a holistic and strategic approach to cyber security, SMEs can shore up their defenses and minimize the risk of a cyber attack.

site_title: Russian client sues Boeing to cancel 737 MAX order
summary: A Russian aircraft leasing company, Avia Capital Services, has filed a US$115 million lawsuit against Boeing to cancel an order for 35 737 MAX jets, citing "intentional" failure to disclose information about the aircraft's airworthiness. The lawsuit claims Boeing sold "defective" aircraft, resulting in two fatal crashes that killed 346 people. Boeing has developed a software upgrade and is seeking compensation deals with customers, leading to a record $2.9 billion loss in the second quarter.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars hostage to market's mood swings on trade
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars experienced significant swings due to market mood shifts on the Sino-US trade dispute. The Aussie dollar recovered to US$0.6760 from a low of US$0.6690, while the yen surged to 71.45 yen from a decade-low of 69.93. The currency pair faces stiff chart resistance from US$0.6790 to US$0.6822. Market volatility continues to impact the currencies, with investors seeking safe-haven assets amid trade tensions.

site_title: How SMEs can do their bit for Singapore's environment
summary: Singaporean Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) play a crucial role in addressing the country's mounting environmental issues. The World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) found that Singaporeans ingest 5 grams of plastic daily, equivalent to a credit card's plastic content. To alleviate this, SMEs can take proactive measures such as reducing power consumption by switching to energy-efficient technology, like inkjet printers, and minimizing waste by recycling paper, plastic, and electronic devices. The Singaporean government has also implemented a carbon tax to reduce emissions, and SMEs can benefit from the Energy Efficiency Fund.

site_title: Apple's US$44b drop shows growing cost of reliance on China
summary: Apple's stock price dropped $44 billion on Friday after recent tariffs announcements from Beijing and Washington highlighted the company's reliance on China for iPhone production. This marks a significant handicap for the world's largest consumer electronics company. The tariffs, imposed on Chinese goods, have increased production costs for Apple, leading to a decline in its market value. The company's massive Chinese production base has become a major concern for investors and analysts.

site_title: Sinking Singapore stocks still seen as bright spot on dividends
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index has dropped 8% since its recent high, largely due to the impact of a trade war between its two largest trading partners, the US and China. However, the index's estimated 12-month forward dividend yield remains high, among the highest in Asia, with many of its constituent companies paying steady dividends. Despite this, investors view Singapore stocks as a relatively stable option amidst global market volatility.

site_title: English Garden
summary: Jaan, a Michelin-starred British restaurant, has introduced a new seasonal menu celebrating English summer produce. Chef Kirk Westaway has reinterpreted classic British dishes with a personal twist, featuring ingredients such as cod brandade, summer beans, and salt marsh lamb from Northern Wales. The menu also includes traditional English desserts like Devon Cream Tea and Battenberg Cake. The restaurant offers reservations by calling 6837-3322, allowing diners to experience the chef's thoughtful reinterpretation of British cuisine.

site_title: US: Stocks end mixed ahead of key Federal Reserve speech
summary: US stocks ended the day mixed ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's speech, with the Dow gaining 0.2% and the S&P 500 slipping 0.1%. The Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.3% due to concerns about a global slowdown and the US-China trade war. The US business activity index dropped to 50.9, barely above the growth threshold, and investors await Powell's speech for a possible interest rate cut next month, with futures investors expecting a rate cut in September.

site_title: CapitaLand unit prices S$800m 10-year notes at 3.15%
summary: CapitaLand's unit closed the order book for S$800 million 10-year notes at 3.15% interest, with S$1.4 billion in orders from over 65 accounts. The notes, part of a S$5 billion euro medium term note programme, will be used for refinancing and general corporate purposes. 96% of the offering went to Singapore investors, and proceeds will be used to finance investments and repay existing borrowings. The issue was led by DBS and UOB, with CapitaLand shares closing at S$3.45 on Friday, down 0.6%.

site_title: Darco to focus on traditional core business segments
summary: DARCO Water Technologies has announced plans to focus on its traditional core businesses in environmental systems and water management services, reversing its recent foray into solar energy. The decision comes after the departure of its former CEO and founder, Thye Kim Meng, who spearheaded the solar energy plans. The company's management has re-evaluated its business strategy, citing the current business climate and its core competencies. For now, DARCO will focus solely on its traditional core business segments, leaving room for future opportunities outside the environmental systems and water management services industry.

site_title: US dollar skids on heightened US-China trade tension
summary: The US dollar plummeted on heightened US-China trade tension, with the euro and Japanese yen rising against it. President Trump's order for companies to find alternatives to China, in response to China's retaliatory tariffs, led to mass selling in the dollar. Benchmark US 10-year Treasury yields fell sharply, while the dollar strengthened against the Chinese yuan. Despite Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's speech not announcing major stimulus measures, the dollar's decline was attributed to Trump's tweet and China's tariffs on US goods, putting an extra 10% on top of existing rates.

site_title: Europe: Stocks tumble on trade war blows
summary: Europe's stocks plummeted on Monday due to US-China trade tensions, with technology stocks leading the decline. The STOXX 600 index fell 0.51% as investors fled riskier assets. The US imposed additional tariffs on $550 billion of Chinese goods, prompting a retaliatory move by China. The US President later appeared to back off his threat to order US companies out of China. Broad-based declines were seen, with technology companies falling 1.02% and German real estate stocks also suffering losses.

site_title: Finally, MB&F's first timepiece for ladies
summary: MB&F has unveiled its first women's timepiece, the Legacy Machine FlyingT, after a four-year development process. The watch features a highly convex sapphire crystal dome, a flying tourbillon, and a 280-component automatic movement with a four-day power reserve. The design combines elegance and vitality, reflecting the brand's founder's mother and the qualities he associates with women. The timepiece is available in three versions, each featuring diamonds, with prices not mentioned in the article. The Legacy Machine FlyingT is a three-dimensional horological art piece that embodies the epitome of femininity.

images.alt_text: The Legacy Machine FlyingT represents the epitome of femininity, combining supreme elegance with tremendous vitality.

site_title: SPH donates S$426,000 to Community Chest
summary: SPH donates S$426,000 to the Community Chest as part of its 35th anniversary celebrations. The donation, which includes S$76,000 raised from a fundraising campaign, will support Special Education Financial Assistance schemes and 20 charitable programs benefiting children with special needs, vulnerable seniors, and disadvantaged families. The donation is a result of a partnership between SPH and the Community Chest, with the goal of promoting a caring and compassionate society.

site_title: Amanda Lee Koe, Novelist
summary: Singapore novelist Amanda Lee Koe, 27, has released her debut novel "Delayed Rays of A Star", which follows the lives of three women - Marlene Dietrich, Leni Riefenstahl, and Anna May Wong - from relative obscurity to stardom and old age. The book, inspired by a 1928 photograph, went straight to No. 1 on Kinokuniya's bestseller list and has stayed there since its release. Koe drew from her own experiences and research to capture the women's vulnerabilities, pathos, and complexities, balancing fact and fiction in her sweeping epic.

site_title: Microlending goes digital, bringing debt stress to the masses
summary: Microlending has gone digital in sub-Saharan Africa, particularly in Kenya, with over 50 mobile lenders offering loans ranging from $10 to $400. However, this has led to a surge in debt stress, with almost one-fifth of mobile-banking borrowers defaulting last year. The proliferation of mobile-money accounts has created a level of stress, with two-thirds of Kenyan borrowers in debt stress. Regulators are concerned about unregulated finance companies and the need for proper regulation to supervise digital microlenders.

site_title: Macron says tech giants enjoy 'permanent tax haven status'
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron criticized tech giants, saying they have a "permanent tax haven status" and don't contribute financially to the funding of the common good. Macron discussed the issue with US President Donald Trump, who opposes a French law taxing digital companies, and France has offered to withdraw the tax if an international agreement is reached. Macron hopes to include all OECD countries by the end of 2020. The law affects US-based global giants like Google, Apple, and Amazon.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.16 points to 1,598.61 on Tuesday, with 106 gainers surpassing 42 losers. The market opened higher, with a trading volume of 32.69 million lots worth RM12.23 million.

site_title: China touts common ground with US allies Japan, South Korea
summary: China's top diplomat Wang Yi met with Japanese and South Korean counterparts in Beijing, highlighting common ground on free trade and regional growth. The three nations pledged to support free trade and complete negotiations on the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership by the end of the year. Despite tensions over Hong Kong protests and wartime laborers, Wang emphasized the need for three-way cooperation. The talks came as China seeks to strengthen ties with US allies amid a shifting global trade landscape.

site_title: 15 strata offices at Peninsula Plaza up for sale with S$17.6m guide price
summary: Fifteen strata offices at Peninsula Plaza in Singapore are up for sale via tender with an indicative price of S$17.6 million, or S$2,255 per square foot. This price range is within the recently transacted units at the building, which hit S$2,500 psf in April. The sale of these offices could be a test of demand for prime Singapore projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark, which is expected to arrive in Q3.

site_title: Boom time for bunker business and doomsday capitalists in the US
summary: In the US, a multimillion-dollar bunker business has emerged, catering to Americans' desire for disaster preparedness amid growing threats like climate change, terrorism, and cyber attacks. Luxury condominiums built into the Earth's crust, such as Larry Hall's "Survival Condo," are being marketed as safe havens. Proponents argue that these structures offer a sense of security and freedom, while critics label the trend "survival porn" and a hypermasculine fantasy. The industry has grown significantly, with high-end real estate agents and bunker builders capitalizing on the trend, with prices ranging from $1.3 million to $18 million.

site_title: China papers attack Twitter and Facebook for shutting accounts
summary: Twitter and Facebook faced backlash from Chinese state media and internet users after shutting accounts allegedly backed by China and attempting to manipulate news about Hong Kong protests. China's Global Times and People's Daily called the crackdown a "double-standard" and questioned the companies' claims of the accounts' Chinese government ties, citing no credible evidence. Chinese social media users expressed outrage, questioning how the companies confirmed the accounts' backgrounds and the legitimacy of their actions. The move drew comparisons to the companies' past involvement in inciting revolutions worldwide.

site_title: AD King's second act
summary: Sir Martin Sorrell, the 74-year-old former CEO of WPP, has launched his second venture, S4 Capital, a digital marketing outfit that employs around 1,400 people in 20 countries. The company, which has grown from a "peanut" to a "coco de mer" with a current market value of $600 million, is based on the "holy trinity of first-party data, digital content and programmatic". Sorrell aims to leverage this approach to score big with millennial-driven clients, despite WPP's struggles under his leadership. He vows to rebuild trust with clients and is open to working on any model, citing the need for agencies to adapt to changing market demands.

site_title: Back to school: Is the Singapore global schoolhouse back in business?
summary: Singapore's "Global Schoolhouse" initiative appears to be reviving, with several foreign universities opening campuses or expanding their presence in the country. Ecole hôtelière de Lausanne (EHL) recently received EduTrust certification for its planned Singapore campus, despite not having classes yet. Other universities, such as James Cook University and Curtin University, are also expanding their offerings in Singapore, focusing on industry-relevant courses. The move is seen as an attempt to attract international students and talent, as well as to provide training for Singapore's labor-intensive hospitality sector. Despite setbacks in the past, the Global Schoolhouse initiative remains a key part of Singapore's economic development strategy.

site_title: European stocks steady at open
summary: European stock markets steadied at the open on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.1% to 7,193.74 points. In contrast, eurozone indices, including Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40, fell 0.2% each. The recent volatility seems to have been alleviated, with investors focusing on US-EU trade talks and the impact of mining and healthcare sectors on shares.

site_title: Customer experience startup RateIt raises US$5m in Series A round
summary: RateIt, a customer experience startup, has raised US$5 million in a Series A round led by Tin Men Capital. The funds will be used to expand the company's operations and marketing in Singapore and South-east Asia. Founded in 2016, RateIt combines omnichannel microsurveys and real-time sentiment analysis tools to provide businesses with insights to improve customer experience. The company has doubled its revenue every year and plans to expand to Thailand and Malaysia, with over half of its revenue coming from South-east Asia.

site_title: BW Offshore wins Brazil's approval for US$115m oilfield purchase
summary: BW Offshore has secured approval from Brazil's ANP for the US$115 million purchase of the Maromba oilfield, expanding its operations in the country. The purchase, from Chevron Corp and Petrobras, marks BW Offshore's plan to become an operator rather than just a supplier. The deal is expected to increase production and be a key element in the company's growth strategy, with the first milestone payment of US$30 million due upon regulatory clearance.

site_title: Markets regain risk appetite after week of turmoil
summary: The euro advanced 0.2% to US$1.1114 on Monday after its biggest weekly drop in nearly two months, as risk appetite gradually returned to global markets. The euro's gain was attributed to hopes of fiscal stimulus from Germany and steps by China to cut corporate lending costs. However, safe-haven currencies like the Japanese yen and Swiss franc remained in demand, with the Swiss franc expected to appreciate to 1.07 francs per euro by the end of the year, according to JP Morgan.

site_title: Hotels of the future
summary: Singapore's hospitality industry is adopting technology to boost productivity amid looming cuts to foreign worker quotas. Hotels such as Marina Bay Sands, Park Avenue Rochester, and Pan Pacific Singapore are introducing robots to ease workloads and streamline processes. These technologies have saved hotels an estimated 9.3 man-hours daily and improved accuracy and security. The industry is also exploring cross-deployment of staff across multiple roles to optimize manpower and boost productivity. With the quota cuts expected to take effect in 2021, technology adoption is seen as crucial to the sector's survival.

site_title: Vietnam demands Chinese ship leaves its exclusive economic zone
summary: Vietnam has demanded that China remove an oil survey vessel and its escorts from its exclusive economic zone, amid a standoff in the South China Sea. The Haiyang Dizhi 8, conducted by the China Geological Survey, had returned to the area escorted by at least five Chinese coast guard vessels. Vietnam's Foreign Ministry spokeswoman has protested the repeated violations and demanded China withdraw the vessel group, fueling anti-Chinese sentiment in the country.

site_title: Park Place Residences nearly sold out; just 3 units available
summary: Park Place Residences, a 99-year leasehold condo in Singapore's Paya Lebar Quarter, is nearly sold out with only three units remaining. The development, which includes a 90% leased office space and a grand opening mall, is on track to be one of the most sustainable precincts in Singapore. Lendlease, the developer, is also launching a flexible workplace solution called csuites, offering clients shorter leases and other benefits. The project is set to open its preview on August 30 and grand opening on October 24.

site_title: Seroja Investments sells operating business for US$32m to become cash company
summary: Seroja Investments has agreed to sell its entire operating business, Trans LK Marine, to its executive director and chief operating officer Masdjan for US$32.2 million. The sale will cease the company's operating business, making it a cash company. The consideration is a 278% premium over the volume weighted average price of the shares, and Seroja expects to reap a profit. The company plans to use the proceeds to acquire new assets or businesses to satisfy listing requirements, and will seek independent shareholders' approval for the transaction.

site_title: Tencent's revenue falls short as ByteDance saps ad growth
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd reported a disappointing quarterly revenue of 88.8 billion yuan, falling short of analysts' projections due to competition from ByteDance Inc and a slowing Chinese economy. Online ad revenue grew 16% but was offset by a 7% decline in media ad revenue. The company's gaming revenue is expected to accelerate starting from the second quarter, driven by popular titles such as Peacekeeper Elite. Despite this, the company's shares tumbled 4% due to concerns about the macro environment and the impact of advertising inventory on revenue.

site_title: Hong Kong braces for more protests as world leaders urge calm, talks
summary: Hong Kong braces for more protests as the city's 10-week crisis escalates, with clashes between police and protesters intensifying. World leaders, including US President Donald Trump and French Foreign Minister Jean-Yves Le Drian, have urged calm, while China has warned against outside interference. The protests, sparked by opposition to an extradition bill, have disrupted the city's economy and pushed for greater freedoms under the "one country, two systems" formula. With several protests planned, including a teachers rally and one by animal lovers, the movement shows no signs of abating.

site_title: Going into the light
summary:
Key tech releases include: 
- mophie's 3-in-1 wireless charging pad for Apple devices ($209) and a dual wireless charging pad ($149)
- Naim's Mu-so Qb 2nd Generation wireless speaker with improved sound quality and multi-room capabilities ($899)
- Samsung's Galaxy Book S ultra-light notebook with a Qualcomm Snapdragon 8cx processor, 8GB RAM, and up to 23 hours of battery life ($999)
- Gigabyte's Aero 15 OLED XA gaming laptop with a 4K AMOLED display and improved performance ($3,799)

site_title: Territory is adding HK$19.1b in stimulus as unrest hits economy
summary: Hong Kong's government announced a HK$19.1 billion stimulus package amid ongoing anti-government protests, which are putting pressure on the economy. The economy is expected to post zero to 1% growth this year, down from a previous forecast of 2-3%. Measures include tax-free personal income increases, subsidies for social security recipients, and support for companies in sectors like retail and tourism. The government has a fiscal reserve of HK$1.17 trillion, but economists warn that the stimulus may not be enough to stimulate spending.

site_title: Invesco thrives in China as ex-executive Ross leads Trump's trade war
summary: US investment company Invesco has thrived in China under the leadership of former executive Ross, who is also a key figure in President Trump's trade war with China. Invesco's joint venture, Invesco Great Wall Management, has become the top foreign manager of Chinese money in China, surpassing Switzerland's UBS. The company's success is attributed to decades of relationships in China, despite Chinese ownership limits. Invesco's steel investment in China, Chongqing Iron & Steel, reported a 71% increase in operating profit in 2018, benefiting from reduced debt and rising global steel prices amid Trump's tariffs.

images.alt_text: The former investment company of US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross has been flourishing in China, even as he marshals billions of dollars' worth of punishing tariffs in America's deepening trade war.

site_title: Japan's new emperor speaks of 'deep remorse' in 1st speech marking World War II
summary: Japan's new Emperor Naruhito delivered his first speech on World War II, expressing "deep remorse" for the country's wartime past. The 59-year-old emperor echoed his father's language, vowing not to repeat the devastation of war. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe also spoke at the ceremony, reiterating Japan's commitment to peace and prosperity. The speeches were closely monitored for any change in tone, but both leaders stuck to the established script, amidst ongoing tensions with South Korea over Japanese wartime history.

site_title: CNMC posts Q2 net profit of US$0.83m, reverses year-ago loss
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings reported a net profit of US$0.83 million for Q2, reversing a year-ago loss of US$0.34 million. Higher gold production, lower operating costs, and no expenses related to a proposed Hong Kong dual listing contributed to the improved results. Revenue rose 7.4% to US$10 million, driven by increased output from the Sokor gold field in Malaysia and higher gold prices.

site_title: HK flights resume; fears rise of China intervention
summary: Hong Kong's airport resumed normal operations after a chaotic night of protests, with only a few dozen protesters remaining. Demonstrators had disrupted flights for the second straight day, but a court order was issued to bar further disruption. US President Donald Trump warned of Chinese troops amassing on the border, raising fears of Chinese intervention. The Hong Kong government condemned the violence and urged respect for agreements made when China took control of the city.

site_title: Accused Capital One hacker had stolen data from other targets, say officials
summary: A former Amazon Web Services employee, Paige Thompson, stole data from more than 30 companies and organizations, in addition to the 100 million people affected in the Capital One breach. Prosecutors found multiple terabytes of stolen data on seized servers from her home, including 140,000 Social Security numbers and 80,000 bank account numbers. Authorities expect to bring additional charges against Thompson, who had repeatedly threatened to harm herself and others, and found an arsenal of weapons and explosives in her home.

site_title: Unfinished business
summary: Morgan Stanley's chairman and CEO for South-east Asia, Ronald Ong, says he's not ready to hand over the reins as he wants to see through the firm's growth plans, particularly in wealth management. Ong has identified potential successors, including some Singaporeans, but notes that having "connectivity" and "lateral thinking" are more important than talent. The firm's wealth management business has seen significant growth, with revenue rising 1.9% to US$4.40 billion in the latest quarter. Ong aims to double the business's revenue in the next five years, and the firm is hiring 50 relationship managers in Hong Kong and Singapore to capitalize on growing high net worth wealth.

site_title: The rise of Manila as a restaurant destination
summary: Manila is emerging as a destination for fine dining, with veteran chefs Margarita Forés and Jordy Navarra contributing to the city's culinary scene. Restaurants such as Mecha Uma and Helm, run by chefs Bruce Ricketts and Josh Boutwood, respectively, are gaining international recognition. The city is also attracting attention for its sustainable practices, with companies like Sustainable Living Lab, founded by Veerappan Swaminathan, creating environmentally conscious products and practices.

site_title: Singapore ups the ante in chips industry's future
summary: Singapore remains a key player in the semiconductor industry, despite a recent decline in chip demand, according to Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat. The country is well-positioned to meet long-term global demand for semiconductor chips, driven by emerging technologies like AI and 5G. A new expansion by Micron Technology, an American semiconductor giant, is seen as a boost to the industry, with the company investing S$101,000 in science and technology studies at the National University of Singapore. The expansion is expected to create 1,000 new jobs, further solidifying Singapore's position as a hub for the industry.

site_title: China July industrial output rose 4.8%, slowest since Feb 2002, retail sales up 7.6%
summary: China's industrial output rose 4.8% in July, the slowest since February 2002, according to official data. Retail sales grew 7.6% in July, below expectations of 8.6%. Fixed-asset investment for the first seven months rose 5.7%, lower than forecast. The data suggests faltering demand in China's economy, amid US trade pressure. This is the latest sign of slowing growth in the world's second-largest economy, raising pressure on policymakers to address the issue.

site_title: Yanlord Land Q2 net profit tumbles 41% to 865.3m yuan
summary: Yanlord Land, a China-based property developer, reported a 41% decline in Q2 net profit to 865.3 million yuan, down from the same period last year. Revenue fell 58% to 4.1 billion yuan due to lower gross floor area delivered, but was partially offset by higher average selling prices. The company delivered new projects, including Riverbay Gardens and Yanlord on the Park, in line with its delivery schedule.

site_title: Sunpower completes 90% acquisition of China thermal plant for 293m yuan
summary: Sunpower Group has completed the acquisition of a 90% equity interest in Changshu Suyan Thermal Power Co for 293 million yuan (S$58 million). The acquisition is valued at 15.6% less than the deal amount, with an independent valuer estimating the stake at 347.3 million yuan. Sunpower expects the acquisition to have a positive impact on its performance for FY2019, driven by increasing demand for steam from the textile and garment industries in Changshu, Suzhou.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit subsidiary secures 124.8m euro note issuance debt facility
summary: Cromwell E-Reit's subsidiary, Cromwell EReit Lux Finco Sarl, has secured a 124.8 million euro debt facility with ING Bank NV and Credit Agricole Corporate and Investment Bank. The facility will fund a property acquisition in Poznan, Poland, and is part of a 246.9 million euro deal announced in June. The note issuance agreement comprises a 104.5 million euro facility and an 87 million zloty facility for tax payment. Cromwell E-Reit's units remained unchanged at 48.5 euro cents following the announcement.

site_title: Chile's LATAM Airlines posts US$63m loss, dragged by Argentina recession
summary: Chile's LATAM Airlines reported a narrower US$63 million loss in the second quarter, driven by growing revenue in Brazil but negatively affected by a recession in Argentina. Revenue in Brazil increased 20% to US$878 million, while Argentina's revenue almost halved to US$135 million. The airline's results were also impacted by weak currencies in both countries, increasing fuel and aircraft rental costs. Despite the challenges, LATAM's loss was a significant reduction compared to the same period last year.

site_title: The way back to black: Saving a sinking company is tricky in a sea of divergent interests
summary: Financially struggling listed companies in Singapore often face a lengthy and arduous process to recover, with only 13% of suspended companies resuming trading after 12 months or more. The Singapore Exchange's (SGX) watch-list includes 40 companies with pre-tax losses and low market capitalization, with only 8 eventually resuming trading. Industry professionals cite divergent interests and agendas among stakeholders, as well as inconsistent restructuring regimes in emerging markets, as major obstacles. Judicial management, a process that involves appointing a professional to oversee the company's turnaround, can be a complex and time-consuming process, with some companies ultimately ending in liquidation.

site_title: Trump is making Xi's China superpower plan much harder
summary: China's ambitious plan to become a superpower by 2050 faces significant challenges due to the US-China trade war. The trade tensions, combined with structural issues such as record debt levels, pollution, and an aging population, increase the risk of China getting stuck in a "middle-income trap." Economists suggest boosting domestic consumption, liberalizing markets, and increasing technological prowess could help China avoid this fate. However, the odds of a near-term trade deal appear low, and the US has fired back at China's attempts to access foreign markets and technology, threatening China's long-term outlook.

site_title: United Food Holdings warns of Q1 net loss due to lower income
summary: United Food Holdings warned of a net loss for its Q1 2019 financial results due to lower income from its trading and animal pre-mixed segments. The exact amount of the loss is not disclosed until the results announcement on August 14. The company's shares remained unchanged at 10 Singapore cents.

site_title: Maxi-Cash Financial Services Q2 net profit falls 20% to S$2.8m
summary: Maxi-Cash Financial Services reported a net profit of S$2.8 million in the second quarter, down 20% from the same period last year. Revenue fell 19% to S$45.4 million, and earnings per share decreased to 0.27 Singapore cents. The group attributed the decline to uncertain economic conditions, competition, and volatile market factors. A dividend of S$0.0025 per share was declared, down from S$0.003 per share in the first half of last year.

site_title: Singapore's rule of law, zero tolerance for graft big draws for foreign investors: US diplomat
summary: US diplomat Stephanie Syptak-Ramnath praises Singapore's rule of law and zero tolerance for graft, citing its commitment to transparency, good governance, and respect for a rules-based order as key factors in attracting foreign investors. Singapore has moved up three notches to third spot in Transparency International's 2018 Corruption Perceptions Index, ranking alongside Denmark and New Zealand. The country's strong anti-corruption legislation and efficient CPIB have given it a competitive advantage in attracting US foreign direct investment, with US FDI in Singapore growing at an average rate of 27% between 2011 and 2017.

images.alt_text: Ms Syptak-Ramnath says US firms choose to grow and expand in Singapore because they are confident in its environment.

site_title: Courting talent: Will Singapore remain attractive to the world's best?
summary: Singapore aims to remain attractive to the world's top talent, particularly in emerging areas of digital technology, amid a global shortage of tech-related skillsets. The city-state has launched a charm offensive, including a video campaign showcasing its business-friendly environment and cultural attractions. However, challenges persist, including a perceived lack of cultural vibrancy and strict immigration policies, which may deter some expats. The government is working to address these issues, introducing measures such as the Tech@SG scheme to attract tech startups and IT talent. Despite these efforts, Singapore faces competition from top destinations like Silicon Valley and rising tech hubs in China and ASEAN, highlighting the need for a stronger venture capital presence and innovation ecosystem.

site_title: Exercise during pregnancy may have lasting benefits for babies
summary: A new study suggests that mothers who exercise during pregnancy may give their babies a head start on physical coordination, with infants from exercise groups performing better in motor skills tests and displaying more advanced physical capabilities. The study found that babies of exercise mothers were slightly ahead of their peers in abilities such as gripping, rolling, and controlling movement. The findings support growing evidence that physical activity during pregnancy can have lasting benefits for babies, potentially influencing their motor development and coordination.

site_title: SIA-backed Vistara charts international flight path, to benefit from Jet's collapse
summary: Vistara, the Indian unit of Singapore Airlines, has launched its first international flight to Singapore, ahead of expanding to Dubai and Bangkok. The move is seen as a strategic advantage, given the collapse of Jet Airways, which has created a vacuum for carriers to accelerate their growth plans. Vistara aims to expand its international routes to Europe, Australia, and the US, and will offer direct flights to compete with Gulf carriers. The airline plans to increase its fleet to 42 aircraft by 2020 and has expanded its codeshare agreement with SIA and SilkAir.

site_title: White nationalists face an inconvenient truth
summary: A white nationalist gunman's manifesto in the 2019 El Paso, Texas, Walmart shooting espoused racist and anti-immigrant views, echoing the "Replacement Theory" promoted by the white nationalist movement. The manifesto's author, Patrick Crusius, aimed to stop a "Hispanic invasion of Texas" and blamed Democrats for attracting immigrants. Texas, once a Republican stronghold, is undergoing demographic changes with Hispanics replacing whites as the largest ethnic group, potentially shifting the state towards the Democratic Party. Recent studies show non-Hispanic whites make up 41.9% of the population, while Hispanics and Latinos comprise 40%.

site_title: British watchdog bans ads over sexist sterotypes
summary: The British Advertising Standards Agency (ASA) has banned ads featuring sexist stereotypes, including a Philadelphia cheese advert showing men neglecting their babies and a Volkswagen eGolf car commercial juxtaposing a male para-athlete with a woman caring for a baby. The ASA found these ads relied on outdated and harmful gender stereotypes, which can limit children's aspirations. The agency aims to crack down on sexist stereotypes, with only 9% of adverts featuring authoritative female characters, despite research showing strong women hold greater sway over consumers.

site_title: Doing well & doing good
summary: Global PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) chairman Robert Moritz says today's young hires want to not only do well in their careers but also make a positive impact in society. Moritz, who joined PwC in 1985, has seen a shift in the profession's focus from just financial success to also contributing to society. He emphasizes the importance of dialogue between the organization and individual to understand what they want to achieve. PwC is working to give its employees opportunities to contribute to society, such as through its "Doing Good" initiative, which aims to invest in 15 million people by 2022. Moritz also stresses the need for the profession to improve the quality of its work and adapt to changing expectations, including the growing demand for non-financial information and data-driven insights.

site_title: China blocks movies, stars from Taiwan's Golden Horse Awards
summary: China has blocked mainland movies and personnel from participating in Taiwan's Golden Horse Awards, citing no reason, amid rising tensions between Beijing and the self-ruled island. The move comes after the event sparked debate about Taiwanese independence and follows China's recent stoppage of issuing travel permits for Taiwan. The Golden Horse Awards, considered one of the most prestigious in the Chinese-speaking film industry, will continue with related events as scheduled.

site_title: Serena Williams tops Forbes list of best-paid sportswomen again
summary: Serena Williams has topped Forbes' list of highest-paid women in sports for the fourth consecutive year, earning $29.2 million in the 12-month period ending June 1, 2019. Naomi Osaka came in second with $24.3 million, followed by Angelique Kerber and Simona Halep. Tennis dominated the list, with Osaka and Williams being the only non-Grand Slam tennis champions to earn over $20 million in a year.

site_title: Singtel tops governance index for 5th year, overall score at record high
summary: Singtel has topped the Singapore Governance and Transparency Index (SGTI) for the fifth consecutive year, with a record-high score of 59.3 in the general category. DBS Group Holdings maintained its No 2 position, while CapitaLand overtook CapitaLand Mall Trust in the Reit and business trusts section. The SGTI's average scores rose to record-highs, with the trusts category scoring 78.6. Corporate governance experts emphasize the need for companies to evolve in response to disruption, citing the importance of high corporate governance standards in navigating complex business landscapes.

site_title: Hong Kong unrest spreads as leader warns city on brink
summary: Hong Kong's unrest escalated on Monday as riot police clashed with pro-democracy protesters at multiple locations, with the city's leader, Carrie Lam, warning of a "very dangerous situation." The protests, triggered by opposition to a planned extradition law, have evolved into a wider movement for democratic reform and a halt to eroding freedoms. A rare strike caused transport chaos, disrupting flights at Hong Kong International Airport and paralyzing parts of the city's subway network. Lam vowed not to cave to protesters' demands, describing them as trying to "destroy Hong Kong."

site_title: US construction spending posts biggest drop in seven months amid slump in private projects
summary: US construction spending fell 1.3% in June, the largest decline in seven months, as private projects dropped 0.4% to $962.9 billion, the lowest level since October 2017. Private residential projects fell 0.5%, while non-residential structures declined 0.3%. Investment in non-residential construction fell at its steepest pace in over three years, contributing to a 2.1% annualized economic growth rate in the first quarter.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, falling 0.72% or 151.14 points to 20,936.02, weighed down by a strong yen and US-China trade woes. The broader Topix index dropped 0.82% or 12.52 points to 1,520.94.

site_title: Jardine C&C posts 6.2% rise in Q2 underlying net profit to US$206m
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage (Jardine C&C) reported a 6.2% increase in underlying net profit to US$206 million in Q2, driven by improved corporate costs. Revenue slipped 2.3% to US$4.44 billion, while net profit surged to US$115.1 million due to lower fair-value losses. The company's direct motor segment declined 39% due to lower sales volumes, while its Indonesian conglomerate Astra's contributions fell 16.8% due to lower sales and manufacturing costs. The group's half-year underlying net profit dipped 1.4% to US$407.3 million.

site_title: Modelling is no child's play for young fashionistas in China
summary: In China, the demand for child models has led to concerns over their physical and emotional well-being. Thousands of child models, often working 12-hour days, are subjected to intense pressure and physical abuse, with some parents using violence to enforce compliance. Experts warn that this can have long-term emotional implications for children. Despite growing regulations, many parents continue to push their children into the profession, with some earning up to $1,962 per session. Authorities have introduced new regulations to limit child labor and protect their rights, but more needs to be done to prevent exploitation.

site_title: Thousands of HK civil servants rally; further wave of protests planned across territory
summary: Thousands of Hong Kong civil servants rallied in support of protesters, calling for authorities to rebuild trust. The rally, the first time government employees have promoted a demonstration, comes as protests against a suspended extradition bill and demands for greater democracy and the leader's resignation continue. Eight people, including a pro-independence leader, were arrested after a raid on suspected bomb-making material. A mass strike is planned for Monday, which could bring the city to a standstill. The protests pose a challenge to the Communist Party rulers in Beijing, who have allowed Hong Kong to retain extensive freedoms under Chinese rule.

site_title: Singapore banks brace for rate impact
summary: Singapore banks are bracing for the impact of low interest rates on lending margins, despite recording record earnings in the first half of the year. DBS, OCBC, and UOB reported 20%, 1%, and 8% growth in quarterly net profits, respectively. The banks attribute the growth to wealth management, but warn of potential belt-tightening if economic headwinds persist. The US Federal Reserve's rate cut has sparked concerns about global economic growth, while trade tensions between the US and China remain high.

site_title: HK leader warns of 'ruin' as massive strike chokes city, airport
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam warned of a "very dangerous situation" as protesters, who have been on strike for nine days, disrupted the city's airport, subway lines, and roads. Demonstrators chanted "strike!" and blocked roads, prompting police to fire tear gas to disperse crowds. Lam accused protesters of threatening national sovereignty and trying to "ruin" the city, while authorities in Beijing have backed her stance. The protests, which began over a bill allowing extraditions to China, have morphed into a broader challenge to China's tightening grip.

site_title: Britons set to protest against Johnson's Brexit move
summary: Protesters in the UK are expected to take part in demonstrations against Prime Minister Boris Johnson's move to suspend parliament ahead of Brexit. Hundreds of thousands are anticipated to participate, with organizers calling for the government to change its course. The opposition Labour Party is also considering a no-confidence vote against Johnson's government. Meanwhile, EU leaders remain awaiting concrete proposals from London, and the government is ramping up preparations for a potential no-deal Brexit.

site_title: Nouvel 18's like exclusive honey to China bees
summary: Mainland Chinese buyers dominate sales of luxury condos in Singapore's Nouvel 18 project, accounting for about 90% of the 17 units sold since July 18, despite paying 20% additional buyer's stamp duty. The units, priced at S$5-6 million for three-bedders and S$7.6-13 million for four-bedders, are mainly occupied by business owners planning to relocate their children to Singapore for education. The project's average selling price is S$3,300 per square foot, with a sky suite and four penthouses also available.

site_title: Italian hydroponics farm bets on 'red gold'
summary: An Italian hydroponics farm, Sfera Agricola, is revolutionizing the agricultural industry by producing pesticide-free crops in environmentally friendly greenhouses. The farm, launched in 2015, uses hydroponics to grow tomatoes and other crops, requiring just two liters of water per kilogram of produce, compared to 75 liters in traditional farming. The farm aims to increase production to 500 hectares in the next 10 years and is employing 230 people, providing fair wages and contracts to workers. The farm is also promoting local bee colonies and using natural pest control methods, aiming to restore Italy's reputation for producing high-quality, sustainable produce.

images.alt_text: The Italian tomato is prized around the world, but its reputation has soured in recent years over reports of mafia infiltration, slave labour and toxic fires that poison water sources.

site_title: L'Oreal fights startup Olaplex over secret to protecting hair
summary: L'Oreal is facing a federal court lawsuit from California startup Olaplex, claiming the beauty company stole its trade secrets for a popular hair-protecting system. Olaplex alleges that L'Oreal encountered the trade secrets in 2015 during takeover talks and has since infringed on two of its patents. The startup seeks cash compensation and damages, with the case potentially impacting L'Oreal's annual revenue. The trial is expected to last five days, with the jury deciding on the validity of Olaplex's patents and whether L'Oreal misused the startup's trade secrets.

images.alt_text: L'Oreal reported more than US$30 billion in sales for last year. The product lines in question, which all involve the three-step process that protects hair during bleaching treatments, are just one part of a division with about US$3.7 billion in sales, or 12 per cent of L'Oreal's 2018 revenue.

site_title: No Signboard posts Q3 net loss of S$1.4m on higher costs
summary: No Signboard Holdings, a Singapore-based seafood restaurant operator, reported a net loss of S$1.4 million in its fiscal third quarter, reversing from a profit of S$0.8 million the previous year. Revenue fell 15.1% to S$5.9 million, mainly due to weaker revenue from seafood restaurants and a decline in the beer segment. The company's CEO, Sam Lim Yong Sim, was arrested and released on bail earlier this year in connection to a share buyback probe. No Signboard plans to leverage its brand for growth outside Singapore and explore opportunities to strengthen its competitive edge.

site_title: honestbee seeks court protection for over US$180m of debt; lays off 38 staff
summary: honestbee, a Singapore-based startup, has applied to the High Court for a court-supervised restructuring process to address its over US$180 million debt. The company has laid off 38 staff and will convert all debt to equity. Honestbee's major creditors, including Formation Group and associates of Brian Koo, will be affected by the restructuring. The company is seeking a six-month moratorium from creditors, preventing winding up proceedings and enforcement of security over its property. This move aims to streamline operations and reduce debt.

site_title: Pompeo rips into China, urges Asean to trust in US
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo urged Southeast Asian nations to trust in US values, criticizing China's leadership in the region. He accused China of loading on debt and aggression in the disputed South China Sea, while promising not to intervene in Hong Kong protests. Pompeo also criticized China's "protectionism" and "predatory tactics" in global markets, following President Trump's latest tariffs on Chinese goods. The US wants the South China Sea to remain open, and Pompeo vowed to protect national sovereignty.

site_title: Familiar Favourites
summary: Luxury watch brands have released new timepieces that stick to traditional designs, with limited variations. The MB&F Legacy Machine No 2 Red Gold Blue features a double balance wheel and is limited to 12 pieces. Piaget's Altiplano Ultimate Concept is the world's thinnest mechanical hand-wound watch, measuring 2mm thick. Blancpain's Fifty Fathoms Automatic model now features a blue ceramic bezel, while Harry Winston's Project Z13 boasts a unique moon phase display and retrograde date. These watches showcase a return to classic designs in the luxury watch market.

site_title: Car suppliers take dimmer view of China's vehicle production
summary: Global car suppliers are increasingly pessimistic about China's vehicle production, citing 12 consecutive months of falling sales and a decline in demand for the second year in a row. Suppliers such as Aptiv, Garrett Motion, and BorgWarner have cut production forecasts, with some expecting double-digit declines. Fiat Chrysler Automobiles also reduced its China industry sales outlook by 4%. The industry is bracing for tougher emissions standards and a trade dispute with the US, which has hurt consumer confidence.

site_title: Negative interest rates: Carry an umbrella at all times
summary: Negative interest rates, introduced by the European Central Bank in 2014, aim to stimulate economic growth by forcing savers to spend or invest in riskier assets. However, the policy has been met with tepid growth in Europe and Japan, raising questions about its effectiveness. Despite this, central banks are expected to continue reducing interest rates, potentially leading to further market distortions. Portfolio managers are advised to consider adjusting their investment strategies, including underweighting debtors and creditors, designating Treasuries as a hedge against deflation, and gaining exposure to real assets. The authors caution that the central banks' efforts may not succeed in achieving economic growth, and investors should be prepared for the possibility of a disruptive scenario.

site_title: The magic of connectivity
summary: Epsilon Telecommunications, a privately-held interconnection company, has undergone significant growth and relocation in the past decade. Founded in London in 2003, the company has expanded its services to cater to large organizations and enterprises, with a focus on organic growth and innovative products. CEO Jerzy Szlosarek attributes the company's success to its ability to adapt to changing technology and customer needs. Despite the impact of 5G on the industry, Szlosarek is not unduly worried, as he believes that enterprises will continue to rely on service providers for their communication needs. Epsilon relocated its headquarters to Singapore in 2008, where it has grown significantly, with 40% of its revenue coming from Asia. The company's focus on customer experience, innovation, and adaptability has enabled it to thrive in a rapidly changing market.

site_title: How Trump and Xi can make America and China poor again
summary: US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping's trade dispute threatens to fracture the globalization system, leading to a more unstable and less prosperous world. The US-China trade has become "deep" due to China's technological advancements and its plan to become a global technology powerhouse. The lack of trust between the two countries, fueled by China's non-transparent communist society and the US's democratic values, makes it difficult to resolve the crisis. Trump's decision to sign the Trans-Pacific Partnership and line up European allies against China has reduced leverage, making a tit-for-tat tariff war more likely.

images.alt_text: Mr Trump and Mr Xi need to find a way to defuse the crisis before it becomes a runaway train.

site_title: Government rolls out tech measures to prevent bogus SkillsFuture claims
summary: The Singapore government plans to introduce QR codes for attendance-taking at SkillsFuture courses by next year to prevent bogus claims. The measure aims to deter individuals from abusing the system, following a series of offenses involving S$40 million worth of false claims. The government will also use data analytics and machine-learning to detect anomalies in claim submissions. These measures follow the formation of an Inter-Agency Process Review Task Force to address the issue of fraudulent claims.

site_title: Genting Singapore net profit falls 5% in Q2
summary: Genting Singapore reported a net profit of S$168.4 million for Q2, down 5% from the same period last year. Revenue rose 14% to S$636.8 million, driven by a 22% increase in gaming revenue. Adjusted ebitda rose 11% to S$294 million, while net impairments on gaming receivables stood at S$47.3 million. The company has drawn up plans to retire certain assets and has received approval for its bid to open an integrated resort in Japan. An interim dividend of 1.5 Singapore cents per share will be paid on September 20.

site_title: UK joins US for maritime security mission in Gulf
summary: The UK has joined the US in a maritime security mission in the Gulf to protect merchant vessels, following Iran's seizure of a British-flagged tanker. The move aims to secure the freedom of international shipping through the Strait of Hormuz, where a fifth of the world's oil passes. The UK's policy on Iran remains unchanged, and the deployment of Royal Navy assets is seen as a commitment to protecting UK-flagged vessels. The US-led mission is the UK's most significant non-Brexit foreign policy move under Prime Minister Boris Johnson's government.

images.alt_text: British Defence Secretary Ben Wallace says: "The deployment of Royal Navy assets is a sign of our commitment to our UK flagged vessels."
